title: PLAYBOY PUBLISHER FILLS 2 TOP POSTS
description: Hugh M. Hefner, the editor and publisher of Playboy magazine announced two major editorial promotions yesterday.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: The single sentence Fred Hechinger's Jan. 16 Week in Review article devoted to the Amish reason for resisting compulsory high school implies that nothing more is at stake for them than their rejection of luxuries. In point of fact, it is the entire religious social fabric of their community which threatened.

title: RAIL PLAN OFFERED AT BUSH TERMINAL
description: A plan to bring rail freight service back to the Bush Terminal industrialcomplex area of South Brooklyn was announced yesterday by the New York Dock Railway.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: In his discussion of the refusal of Amish parents to permit the schooling of their children beyond the eighth grade, Fred M. Hechinger omitted one aspect, to me the most important one, namely, the harm done to such children.

title: Pest Control Bill Passed
description: WASHINGTON (Jan. 31 (UPI) The Senate by voice vote approved today a bill to set up programs to develop and encourage the usext a wide variety of pest control measures. The bill is designed to develop measures for protection of the environnient, continued production of high quality foods and other agricultural commodities and reduction in the cost of producing such commodities.

title: Judge, a Witness in Dilts Case, Says He Saw No Wrongdoing
description: HACKENSACK, N. J., Jan. 31 (AP)Superior Court Judge Morris Pashman testified today that he had promised an accused hijackerextortionist a light sentence for his part in an undercover investigation of then Bergen County Prosecutor Robert Dilts.

title: Wilt Clears Mark From Boards
description: INGLEWOOD, Calif., Jan. 31 (UPI)  Wilt Chamberlain can hardly count all his records, but he thinks the National Basketball Association rebounding mark he set last night will be the hardest to break.

title: 6 MORE ARE ADDED TO BERMAN PANEL
description: HARRISBURG, Pa., Jan. 31 (UPI}Six persons were added to a preliminary panel of jurors today for the conspiracy trial of the Rev. Philip F. Berrigan and six others charged with plotting to kidnap Henry A. Kissinger, President Nixon's foreign policy adviser.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: Senator William Proxmire gave us his logical reasoning why unemployment will probably remain at the per cent level [letter Jan. 25]. This calls for action.

title: Advertising:
description: Cowles Communications is still trying to do right by the 6 million subscribers to Look.

title: Jersey Homeowners Secede From a Town and Save Tax
description: DEMAREST, N. J., Jan. 31 A dozen homeowners who live here in a heavily wooded crisscrossing of Duck Pond and Deerhill Roads have managed a rather neat way to cut their soaring property tax bills by more than 40 per cent.

title: Atlanta Blacks Back Annexation Plan
description: ATLANTA, Jan. 31 (UPI)Atlanta's black legislators today endorsed, with modifications, a plan to expand the city's boundaries, reducing the city's black majority to a minority.

title: Mory's Poor Little Sheep Face Dry Future Over Sex Bias Charge
description: NEW HAVEN, Jan. 31The Connecticut Liquor Control Commission announced today that it had voted to revoke the liquor license of Mory's, the famed alehouse refuge of Yale men for 110 years, on the ground that it discriminated against women.

title: City's New View of Welfare: A Job for Businessmen
description: Like managers everywhere, the new men at the Department of Social Services talk of productivity, time studies, utilization rates and costbenefit ratios. And they talk of the bottom line, meaning the place on the balance sheet where you read the profit or loss.

title: Dublin Protests Shootings;
description: DUBLIN Jan. 31  The Republic of Ireland today declared itself fully satisfied that there was an unprovoked attack by British troops on unarmed civilians in Derry yesterday.

title: AMEX REGISTERS 3D STRAIGHT RISE
description: The American Stock Exchange and the overthecounter market registered yesterday their third consecutive advance.

title: On Soviet TV, China is a State of Mind Control
description: MOSCOW, Jan. 31  The Soviet television network carried a onehour documentary tonight showing China as a thoroughly regimentated state determined to stamp out the individuality of its citizens.

title: S.E.C. Ends Registration Of Kevin Brokerage House
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 (AP) The Securities and Exchange Commission announced today it has revoked the brokerage dealer registration of the Kevin Securities Corporation, New York, and barred its president, Leonard N. Tarr, from associating with any brokerdealer or investment adviser.

title: Article 2  No Title
description: SAPPORO, Japan, Tuesday, Feb. 1 (AP)Emperor Hirohito and Empress Nagako of Japan arrived here today to officiate at Thursday's opening of the first Winter Olympics to be held in Asia. Hirohito had declared open Asia's first Summer Olympics in Tokyo in 1964.

title: Executive Returning to I.T.T. To Head 2 Levitt Subsidiaries
description: The International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation announced yesterday the election of Gerhard R. Andlinger as chairman and chief executive officer of ITT Levitt & Sons, Inc., and Levitt & Sons, Inc., both subsidiaries of I.T.T.

title: JACOB B. WALLACH
description: Jacob B. Wallach, a former business news editor of the old New York Sun, who retired as a partner in the Retail News Bureau, a merchandiser reporting service, in 1969, died yesterday at his home in Palm Beach, Fla. He was 69 years old and also lived in Water Mill,

title: Gasoline Strike Over
description: PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 31 (AP)The Atlantic Richfield Company and the Atlantic Independent Union reached art agreement today that ended a fourweek strike by 6,000 employes. The details were not revealed. Supervisory personnel had been delivering gasoline and other products to service stations since the strike began Jan. 3.

title: KIVITT PUTS VARIETY INTO CORSAIR WORK
description: Unhappily absent from the repertory for the better part of this season because of injury, Ted Kivitt returned during American Ballet Theater's last six performances to give a special lift to each of the works in which he appeared. In the closing performance Sunday evening at City Center he gave a passionately forceful interpretation in the Corsair Pas de Deux,

title: Breaking Up City Hall: II
description: 1834. January. The Brooklyn people, undaunted by previous defeats, and confiderit in their own resources and the justice of their claims, again renewed their application to the legislature for a city charter. The city of New York, with the spirit of the dog in the manger, still threw the whole weight of her wealth and influence against the movement  The real key to the opposition made by New York was  the fears of her real estate speculators and her municipal authorities. So capital, speculation, and monopoly joined hands in a most formidable league against the aspirations and endeavors of Brooklyn. Despite their exertions, however, Brooklyn triumphed; and by an act passed on the 8th of April, was fully invested with the name and privileges of a city. HENRY R. STILES, editor, History of Kings County

title: Taft Headmaster Named
description: Lance R. Odden, assistant headmaster of the Taft School in Watertown, Conn., was named headmaster of the school yesterday. The 32year administrator succeeds John C. Esty.

title: Advertising:
description: Television spots have just started to run for the first national fundraising drive of the 28  year  old National Council on Alcoholism.

title: Sports of the Times
description: Less than, a fortnight ago the voting members of the Baseball Writers Association looked with smug satisfaction on their most recent election to the Hall of Fame. They had hit the jackpot with three eminently worthy candidatesSandy Koufax, Yogi Berra and Early Wynn. It had been ages since they made such nifty, nominations and they were pleased that they had reached such a peak of selectivity.

title: Tax Bite by the State More Painful Today
description: Higher state taxes on cigarettes, liquor and gasoline take effect today.

title: Obituary 1  No Title
description: Obituary 1  No Title

title: Griffith Outpuints Whiz
description: ANAHEIM, Calif., Jan. 31 (UPI)Emile Griffith, a former middleweight and welterweight boxing champion, gained a unanimous decision over previously unbeaten Armando Muniz tonight in a 10round middleweight bout.

title: Tenant Bill Introduced
description: ALBANY, Jan. 31Two New York City Democratic lawmakers introduced a bill today creating a tenants bill of rights that fosters the formation of tenant organizations and requires landlords to participate in collective bargaining with tenants groups.

title: Dance: Interesting Finale
description: At last weekend three dance companies pulled up anchor and passed out of New Yorkthe Alwin Nikolais Dance Theater, the Murray Louis Dance Company, which had both been giving a most interesting joint season at the Brooklyn Academy of Music, and American Ballet Theater, which ended its run at the New York City Center.

title: Heating Engineers Strike 120 Office Buildings Here
description: The operating engineers who oversee the heating of 120 major office buildings in Manhattan went on strike just after midnight this morning.

title: Mardi Gras in Trinidad Put Off Because of Polio
description: PORT OF SPAIN, Trinidad, Jan. 31 (UPI)  Trinidad's colorful carnival, originally scheduled for Feb. 1415 and considered one of the world's great Mardi Gras celebrations, was postponed today for at least three months because of a polio outbreak that has taken 10 lives.

title: SOVIET SENDING CUBA NEW MISSILE BOATS
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 (AP) Pentagon sources report that the Soviet Union has started to send Cuba bigger and more heavily armed missilefiring patrol boats.

title: CANADA FOOTBALL READY FOR U.S. TV
description: An ambitious plan to televise 20 Canadian Football League games nationally on Wednesday nights live and in color was announced here yesterday.

title: A.B.A. Says Merger Delay Forces Collegian Signings
description: Jack Dolph, the comissioner of the American Basketball Association, said yesterday that professional basketball has been forced to seek out and sign college undergraduates because of the delay of the proposed merger of his league with the National Basketball Association.

title: Washington: For the Record
description: Tariff. The President announced that he delay for 90 days the first of three scheduled reductions in tariff rates on window glass imports. A reduction of tariffs on window glass was agreed on in the Trade Expansion Act of 1962, but the scheduling of the reductions was postponed until Feb. 27, 1970. At that time the President scheduled the first reduction for Jan. 31, 1972. Today's action will provide him with additional time in which to study new findings on the glass industry presented to him today in a report by the Tariff Commission.

title: MORALES DEFEATS TANAKA AT GARDEN
description: Medro Morales defeated Professor Toru Tanaka in a wrestling exhibition last night at Madison Square Garden when Tanaka was disqualified for throwing magic powder (salt) at Morales, missing and temporarily blinding the referee.

title: Elevator Crushes Janitor
description: A 45yearold maintenance man at a cooperative building at 573 Grand Street, on the Lower East Side, was crushed to death by a descending elevator at 3 P.M. yesterday, as he attempted to retrieve a letter dropped to the base of the elevator shaft by a resident, the police reported. The victim was identified as Leonidos Cruz, of 422 Hinsdale Street, Brooklyn.

title: Harlem School Principal Takes Leave
description: Ronald R. Evans, one of the first black teachers appointed as a principal directly from the classroom four years ago, as result of community pressure, is taking a oneyear leave of absence, starting today.

title: Strike and a Shortage of Funds Imperil Indianapolis Symphony
description: INDIANAPOLIS, Jan. 31 Though symphony orchestras throughout the country are in financial difficulties, the Hoosier capital is in immediate danger of losing the Indianapolis Symphony Orcestra, the centerpiece of its musical life for the last 42 years, because of a set of singular problems.

title: F.B.I. Cautions Judges.
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 31(UPI) Director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, J. Edgar Hoover, said today judges must deal promptly and decisively with court room disruptions or the judiciary will lose the faith of the American people. Mr. Hoover made his comment in the monthly law enforcement bulletin.

title: Kuhn Tackles Rozelle on No.1 Sport Claim
description: Bowie Kuhn, commissioner of baseball, told Pete Rozelle, commissioner of pro football, yesterday to quit kidding the people about football being the nation's No. 1 Sport.

title: DOW SLIPS BY 4.21 AS VOLUME DROPS
description: Leading stockmarket averages moved lower yesterday as glamour issues were buffeted and many lowprice issues showed gains.

title: City Police Start Course In Puerto Rican Culture
description: A training course for policemen in Spanish language and folkways of Puerto Rico in New York City was begun yesterday by the Police Department.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: I read with some interest the proposal that Phase Two wage controls be followed by Phase Three, eagerly put forth on the OpEd page, Jan. 13, by. Virgil Day, a vice president of General Electric and a member of the Phase Two Pay Boaxd.

title: Speech in Pittsburgh
description: PITTSBURGH, Jan. 31 (UPI) Secretary Connally said tonight that he realized it was a whole lot easier to criticize a $50billion increase in the legal national debt limit than justify it.

title: Shop Talk
description: Art themes, are nothing new to V'Soske, the carpet concern at 155 East 56th Street. But the op, Cubist and abstract patterns in the 1972 collection are quite different from the more conventional designs that the prestigious concern had produced in secent years. One reason for the change may be that Stanislav V'Soske now has two sonsPaul, age 31, and Stan Jr., 28, assisting him with the design of the collections. Thus far most of Paul's designs are strongly reminiscent of wellknown artists works. His circles on squares and rectangles, for instance, are very much like Vasarely's in pattern if not in their subdued colorings. The rug is $1,630 for a 5by7foot size. And the 6foot round rug called Genesis looks like an abstract version of one of Robert Dash's floral paintings. The rug is $1,177.

title: Teaneck Girl Sues to Join High School Tennis Team
description: Abbe Seldin's career started in her crib, with rattles shaped like tennis raquets; it took her to real racquets as a toddler, professional lessons when she was 11 years old, and a ranking by the Eastern Lawn Tennis Association this year as No. 22 among 15 and 16yearold girls.

title: Virginia Beats Clemson, 6260
description: CLEMSON, S. C., Jan. 31 (UPI)Virginia held on the final minutes of the game to beat Clemson, 6260, in an Atlantic Coast Conference tonight. Clemson trailed by two points, 6058, in the closing minute, missed a critical shot, and the followup attempt with 20 seconds to go. The Cavaliers got the rebound, which virtually clinched the victory.

title: Books of The Times
description: With good reason have Christians chosen fire as the metaphor of hell, writes Dennis Smith in Report From Engine Co. 82. What could be more fearful than the slow, agonizing crisping of the skin, the searing of the lungs as the throat passage closes? In nearly nine years as a firefighter, Mr. Smith has seen his share of charred bodies, and he carries his own scars tooyet he loves his job. For reasons that even he may not fully understand, he asked for a transfer from a quiet station to the busiest engine company in New York City.

title: TV: The Suburban Wall Examined on Channel 13
description: Restrictive zoning, propertytax structures, relocations of industryit's a familiar litany and, putting it all together, it spells Suburbia. The subject hay been getting heavy coverage in the print and electronic media, and tonight at 8:30 WNET (Channel 13) will present still another contender for the enlightenment sweepstakes.

title: Pullout Ahead of Schedule By 4 Days and 2,500 Men
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Jan. 31 (UPI) President Nixon's Feb. 1 deadline for reducing American troop strength in South Vietnam to 139,000 was met four days ahead of time, the United States command said today.

title: U.S. Planes Raid Foe in North;
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Tuesday, Feb. 1 (AP)American fighterbombers attacked surfacetoair missile sites, antiaircraftartillery batteries and radar defenses inside North Vietnam yesterday in the heaviest air action over the north this year, the United States command announced today.

title: Bloody Sunday in Derry
description: The bloody Sunday that claimed the lives of thirteen young men in Londonderry was precisely what the Catholic Primate of All Ireland called it an awful slaughter. It was the worst toll for one day in any city Of Northern Ireland since the violence began. The British Government has properly pledged an independent inquiry into the tragedy. In light of the fact that all the dead and nearly all the wounded were civilians, the investigation inevitably will have to look closely at the conduct of the paratroops involved in the affair.

title: RICHARD SHRYOCK OF JOHNS HOPKINS
description: Dr. Richard Harrison Shryock, a leading medical historian, died Sunday in Fort Lauderdale, Fla. He was 78 years old and lived in Bryn Mawr, Pa.

title: Proposals by Two Sides Compared
description: WASHINGTON, 31Following is a, comparison of the ninepoint peace proposal made public by the North Vietnamese delegation in Paris today and the eightpoint plan of the Governments of the United States and South Vietnam revealed by President Nixon on Jan. 25: North Vietnam plan: The withdrawal of the totality of all United States and allied foreign forces from South Vietnani and other Indochinese countries should be completed within 1971. (The plan was first proposed privately June 26, 1971.)

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: New Yorkers who have used up 39 weeks of unemployment insurance benefits became eligible yesterday for 13 more weeks of emergency federallyfinanced benefits under a new law that is in effect until June 30.

title: SAMUEL BERGER, LAWYER HERE, 88
description: Samuel A. Berger, a lawyer long active in Republican politics, died yesterday at his home, 1095 Park Avenue. He was 88 years old.

title: Park Bill Voted in House
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 (AP) The House voted today to authorize $26.5million for land buying, development and bodedary changes in 23 units or the National Park System.

title: Maryland Triumphs, 6665
description: RALEIGH, N. C., Jan. 31 (UPI)  Tom McMillen scored 22 points tonight in leading Maryland from a 16point firsthalf deficit to a 6665 victory over North Carolina state. Tom Burleson, t'e Wolfpack's own towering sophomore, wound up with 18 points as North Carolina state absorbed its sixth loss against 10 victories. Maryland is 133.

title: Yip Harburg Appears at the Y'; Three Artists Sing His Lyrics
description: After two cancellations and postponements, E. Y. (Yip) Harburg finally got his show on Sunday night at the 92d Street Y's Kaufmann Concert Hall. Mr. Harburg appeared in the Y's series of evenings with wellknown lyricists.

title: Executive Changes
description: Marvin S. Traub, president of Bloomingdale's, and Larrimore Wright, financial vice president of Texfi Industries, Inc., have been nominated for posts on the board of Texfi. Their admission will be voted on at the annual stockholders meeting March 14.

title: Attach Termed Heaviest of 72
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Jan. 31After nearly a week of talks with field commanders, Gen. William C. Westmoreland said today that there was every indication that the North Vietnamese were preparing for a major offensive in South Vietnam soon.

title: HANOI DISCLOSES PEACE PROPOSALS IT MADE IN PARIS.
description: PARIS, Jan. 31North Vietnam made public today the ninepoint peace program it had secretly submitted to the United States last June and charged that Washington had not seriously considered it.

title: Desertion Amnesty Opposed
description: COLUMBUS, Ohio, Jan. 31 (AP)  The national commander of the American Legion, John H. Geiger, said today that the veterans organization strongly opposes amnesty for Vietnam deserters who have fled to other lands.

title: IN THE NATION
description: MANCHESTER, N. H., Jan. 31Four years ago yesterday, the great Tet offensive of 1968 began in Vietnam. Eugene McCarthy, then a virtually ignored Presidential candidate, told reporters that if they give it three weeks to build, the political repercussions bring him victory in the New Hampshire primary.

title: Zionists Void Measure On Emigration to Israel
description: JERUSALEM, Jan. 31 (Reuters)  A controversial resolution calling on Zionist leaders to immigrate to Israel, which caused a storm last week at the 28th World Zionist Congress here, was declared invalid today.

title: Camp Nominated Again
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 (UPI) President Nixon today nominated William B. Camp for reappointment as Controller of the Currency for a new fiveyear term. Mr. Camp has held the $40,000ayear post, which includes supervision of national banks, since 1967. The native of Texas, who is 58 years old, now lives in Rockville, Md.

title: Safeguard for Urban Quality
description: One area in the vast limbo of New York City's unsolved problems to which the administration can point with pride is that of urban design. The art of city building simply was not practiced at the municipal level before; it was left to the tender machinations of realestate. From the appointment of the Task Force on Urban Design the setting up of the Urban Design Group, new skills have been coupled with a new vision of the city to foster design and legislative innovations that other communities are beginning to emulate.

title: ERNST GUNTHER
description: Ernst Gunther, president of the Kemm Furniture Company and Metro Furniture Frames, died Sunday in Yonkers. He was 69 years old and lived at 222 St. John's Avenue, Yonkers.

title: Atoms Club Mapping Road to Munich
description: Fred Thompson started the Atoms Track Club of Brooklyn, not as a track team, he said yesterday, but as a sort of social project, an experience.

title: A Record Is Achieved for 1971 Earnings
description: Strong profit performances in domestic and foreign business combined with increases in all company areas to enable the Dow Chemical Company to post record 1971 earnings. Sales surpassed $2billion for the first, time, it was reported yesterday.

title: PANEL BACKS RUSH FOR PACKARD POST
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 (UPI)The Senate Armed Services Committee approved today by a voice vote the nomination of Kenneth Rush to sueceed David Packard as Deputy Secretary of Defense.

title: Demonstrators at the British Consulate Here Protest laying of 13 in Londonderry
description: A group of demonstrators cut down the Union Jack flying in front, Of the British Consulate General at 845 Third Avenue yesterday and sought to burn it. They were protesting the killing of 13 Civilians during a demonstration Sunday in Londonderry, Northern Ireland.

title: 7Foot Basketball Player Is a First for Manhattan
description: Manhattan College has its first 7foot basketball player, a transfer student from Dayton.

title: Nixon Phones Conniff
description: MIAMI BEACH, Jan. 31 (AP) Ray Conniff, the orchestra leader, said today that he received a telephone call yesterday from President Nixon reassuring him that the President was not upset about an incident in which a singer staged an antiwar protest during White House performance Friday. He was very gracious, and I thought it was pretty wonderful that he take time out of his very busy schedule to call because he knew my wife and I were upset by the event, Mr. Conniff said.

title: May Have Talked Too Much
description: SAPPORO, Jan. 31 (UPI) Marc Hodler, president of the International Ski Federation, deplored today the barring of Karl Schranz from the Winter Games, but conceded the Austrian might have talked too much.

title: House Panel Cool to Dock Strike Plea
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 31The Democratic majority on the House Subcommittee on Labor listened with skepticism today as Secretary of Labor James D. Hodgson again appealed to Congress to pass legislation to end the West Coast dock strike.

title: WHITE, WELD ADOPTS CORPORATE STATUS
description: White, Weld & Co., a leading investmentbanking and brokerage house, announced its incorporation yesterday after 77 years as a partnership. It said L. Emery Katzenbach, formerly chairman of the management committee, had been named chairman and chief executive officer of the corporation.

title: Bridge: Polish Pair Wins First Title For stars Behind Iron Curtain
description: The first major victory ever recorded in international competition by players from behind the Iron Curtain was achieved during the weekend; in London by two Polish experts.

title: BHASKAR AND SHALA, DANCERS, ENTERTAIN
description: Bhaskar and Shala, whose performances of dances from India are wellknown in New York, presented a concert Saturday night at Kaufmann Concert Hall with another dancer, Sukanya, as guest artist. The program was shared with Oregon, a contemporary music quartet.

title: Stagehands at Kennedy Center Said to EarnUp to $1,500 a Week
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 Stagehands at the Kennedy Center are making as much as $1,500 a week under a union contract  apparently the richest in the American theater that has become the management's biggest embarrassment and headache.

title: 3 New Directors To Guide Phoenix
description: The Phoenix Theater, the nonprofit organization that has presented 132 productions since it was founded in 1953, has recruited a troika of artistic directors to lead it In a new theatrical direction next season, its 20th.

title: PRESIDENT PLANS VALUEADDED TAX TO HELP SCHOOLS
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 31The White House has developed a tentative proposal that might require as much as $16billion in valueadded taxes to close the gap between poor and wealthy school districts and to relieve the burden of local property taxes.

title: BERTHA PRESSMAN OF BARNEY'S STORE
description: Mrs. Bertha Gewirtz Pressman, who helped her husband, Barney Pressman, build Barney's from a mom and pop shop in 1924 to one of the country's largest men's and boys clothing stores, died Saturday at the New York University Medical Center. She Was 74 years old and lived at 650 Park Avenue.

title: 4 Yankees in Fold
description: The first four Yankee con tracts signed for 1972; the introduction of the team's newest players acquired in trades; the switching of Ron Blomberg from the outfield to first base, and a progress report on the city's planned acquisition and refurbishing of Yankee Stadium all these developments were the reason for the club's first news conference of the year yesterday at the Stadium press club.

title: Kentucky Tops Alabama, 7774
description: LEXINGTON, Ky., Jan. 31 (UPI)Kentucky defeated Alabama, 7774, tonight in a Southeastern Conference game, but the Wildcats may have lost Kent Hollenbeck for the rest of the season just when he appeared to be recovering from a fractured foot.

title: Limitation on Antibiotics in Feed For Livestock Urged by F.D.A.
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 31The Food and Drug Administration proposed today strict limitations on the use of antibiotics in livestock feed, describing such feed as a potential health hazard.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: The recent violation of U.S. fishing regulations in the Bering Sea may be just one of those things that happen in fishing waters. On the other hand, Russia is now finding It expedient to woo Japan, and Japan, having just regained her rights to Okinawa, is for a return of the Kuriles (Russian before 1875, Japanese to 1945), which the Yalta arrangements deprived her of so unceremoniously. Gromyko's pokerfaced insistence that the U.S.S.R. has no territorial questions to settle with Japan have deceived no one, least of all Chou Enlai, whose thoughts are on the Amur as he openly prods the Japanese to claim their northern lands.

title: Trieste Is a Busy Crossroads and EasttoWest Escape Hatch
description: TRIESTE, Italy, Jan. 16The camp high in the hills above this Italian border city is only half full these days, but that is because it's winter. Next summer it will probably be full again, the portly director says. It is full every summer.

title: Pope Conveys Sorrow Over Ulster Killings
description: ROME, Jan. 31 (Reuters)Pope Paul VI sent a telegram tonight expressing his deep sorrow over yesterday's shootings in Londonderry to William Cardinal Conway, the Roman Catholic primate of Ireland.

title: Hempstead Abortion Curb Upset As Beyond Village Authority
description: A Hempstead, L. I., village ordinance that restricted the performanceof legal abortions to hospitals was overturned by the Appellate Division of State Supreme Court yesterday.

title: Florida Mayor Bolts G.O.P.
description: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., Jan. 31 (AP)Mayor Herman Goldner announced his switch from the Republican to the Democratic party today and endorsed Senator Edmund S. Muskie's Presidential bid.

title: Ohio State Coach. Asks Legal Suit Over Brawl
description: COLUMBUS, Ohio, Jan. 31 (UPI)  Coach Fred Taylor says Ohio State University should take legal action because of injuries received by two Buckeye players in last Tuesday's basketball brawl at Minnesota.

title: Text of Hanoi Communiqu Disclosing Peace Plans 0ffered at Private Sessiotions
description: PARIS, Jan. 31Following, as issued in English today by the North Vietnamese delegation to the Paris talks, is the text of a communique in response to President Nixon's disclosure of the private peace negotiations. Included with it by Hanoi are the texts of the ninepoint North Vietnamese peace plan presented at the private sessions on June 26 and of the version of the eightpoint United States plan that Hanoi says it received at those sessions.

title: TOWER WILL SEEK 3D TERM IN SENATE
description: AUSTIN, Tex., Jan. 31Senator John G. Tower, Republican of Texas, said today that he seek a third term this year.

title: Assembly Votes Bill to Cut Sniffing of Glue by Youths
description: ALBANY, Jan. 31For the third time in as many years, the Assembly passed a bill today designed to end gluesniffing by youngsters by requiring that hobby glues sold in the state, contain a substance that cause coughing and sneezing when inhaled deeply.

title: ST, JOHN'S SCORES 86TO73 TRIUMPH
description: KINGSTON, R.I., Jan. 31Paced by the inside scoring of Mel Davis and Ed Searcy and the outside shooting of Richie Lyons, St. John's defeated Rhode Island, 8673, before 4,600 fans tonight at the losers fieldhenise.

title: KNICKS APPROACH THE BUSY SEASON
description: The Knicks begin, their busiest and perhaps most hazardous stretch of the National Basketball Association season tonight when they face the Detroit Pistons at Madison Square Garden.

title: Thomas and Cowboys Confer on Marijuana Incident
description: DALLAS, Jan. 31 (AP)Duane Thomas, the Dallas Cowboy running back charged with possession of marijuana, talked with the club president, Tex Schramm, by telephone today and Schramm said the conversation was limited to the subject of him being properly represented.

title: Economic Analysis
description: The business forecasters twomonth annual open season on the United States economy has just reached its climax with the Economic Report of the President and, if they are on target, 1972 could be one of the best years in our economic history. As readers of financial pages cannot be unaware, the forecasters are armed these days with increasingly sophisticated methods and are enjoying rising public visibility. Some years, in fact, what they enjoy approaches esteem and prestige resulting from accurate, though not always soundly conceived, prognostications. To what extent can we count on them to be aiming straight?

title: Treasury Bill Rates fell at Weekly Sale
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 31Yields on United States Treasury bills fell from last week's levels in the Government's competitive sale toclay of these shortterm securities.

title: British Set Inquiry On Ulster Shooting As Emotion Rises
description: LONDON, Jan. 31The British Government, facing a new wave of public emotion over the Irish question, today ordered an independent inquiry into yesterday's Londonderry killings.

title: A Virginia Town Wins Battle of the Starlings
description: RADFORD, Va., Jan. 31 (UPI) Local officials here said today that most of the 150,000 starlings that had turned lawns in this southwestern Virginia town into a steaming barnyard had been driven away or killed.

title: MRS. FRANK ABRAMS
description: SOUTHOLD, L.I., Jan. 31Mrs. Ruth Florence Corrigan Abrams, wife of Frank W. Abrams, who retired in 1953 as chairman of the Standard Oil Company (New Jersey), died Saturday at their home here. She was 81 years old.

title: Trading in Levitz Stirs 3 Investigations
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission, the New York State Attorney General's office and the New York Stock Exchange have begun investigations into the hectic trading and sharp price fluctuations in shares of the Levitz Furniture Corporation.

title: MUJIB IS PRESSING ROUNDUP OF ARMS
description: DACCA, Pakistan, Jan. 31 As shooting between Bengalis and nonBengalis continued for a third day in Dacca, the Prime Minister, Sheik Mujibur Rahman, offered forgiveness today to the nonBengalis, many of whom had collaborated with the Pakistan Army, but threatened force if they did not surrender their arms immediately.

title: A U.S.State Inquiry Announced HereTestimony Heard
description: A Federalstate investigation into the possibility of fraud arising from the purported autobiography of Howard R. Hughes was announced here yesterday as a Federal grand jury began taking testimony in the case.

title: Pakistan Has High Hopes for Revived Emerald Mines
description: MINGORA, Pakistan, Jan, 13Pakistan's emerald mines, closed down two years ago by a blend of inefficiency, greed and bloodshed, are to begin operating again, and visions of green treasure are dancing in the heads of an impoverished and defeated people.

title: Reid Says P.S.C. Voted Excessive Phone Increase
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 31Representative Ogden R. Reid, Republican of Westchester County, told the Price Commission today that rate increases granted recently to the New York Telephone Company by the state Public Service Commission were excessive and dangerously inflationary.

title: Geese Are Too Smart to Overeat, but Science is Fixing That
description: BENQUET, France  In the secrecy of their laboratories, scientists of a number of countries are racing to invent the selfstuffing goose.

title: White House Tells of Job It Considered for Schorr
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 Nixon Administration officials said tonight that Daniel Schorr, the television commentator, was considered last year for the position of assistant to the chairman of the Council on Environmental Quality.

title: LEGAL ROUND LOST BY GAMBLESKOGNO
description: Special Master Arthur H. Schwartz, in a 61page report filed here yesterday with the Federal District Court, found that GambleSkogmo, Inc., owes $12,062,416 to a group of former stockholders of the General Outdoor Advertising Company. A large part of the sum represents interest accrued from October, 1963, to date.

title: Merger News
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 (AP) The Interstate Commerce Commission ordered the indefinite postponement today of the merger of the Illinois Central Railroad and the Gulf, Mobile and Ohio Railroad, scheduled to take effect tomorrow. The merger has been delayed until petitions from the Kansas City Southern Lines, the Missouri Pacific and the Chicago and Northwestern Railroads can be disposed of. In a late move last Wednesday, the railroads filed complaints to block the scheduled merger, approved by the I.C.C. in late December.

title: BANK ROBBERY SET ARGENTINE RECORD
description: BUENOS AIRES, Jan. 31A $450,000 weekend bank robbery, for which a leftwing extremist group is taking credit as an expropriation for development of the revolutionary war, was the biggest robbery in Argentine history.

title: All CIGARETTE ADS TO BEAR WARNING
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 31The country's six leading cigarette manufacturers have agreed to point a clear and conspicuous health warning In all cigarette advertisements.

title: PALMNEEDLE TIED TO TROT DRUGGING
description: While one trainerdriver took a liedetector test, investigators theorized yesterday that tablets or a tiny palmneedle might have been used to drug two horses in the paddock last Thursday night at Roosevelt Raceway.

title: Basketball Poll COACHES RATING
description: The top 20 with votes figured on a 10987654321 basis for first through 10th places (firstplace votes in parentheses) and wonlost records through games of last Saturday:

title: LearningPlan Test Is Called a Failure
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 The Office of Economic Opportunity pronounced a reluctant but blunt judgment of failure today on performance contractingthe use in public schools of private concerns, teaching machines and incentive payments in an effort to conquer slow learning by poor children.

title: POLICE SLAY A MAN WIELDING 2 KNIVES
description: A man who threatened two policemen with a pair of throwing knives was shot and killed last night, the police said.

title: 81 U.S. Concerns Display Computerware in London
description: LONDON, Jan. 31To the accompaniment of beeps, buzzes, pings, clicks and whirs, 81 American manufacturers of computerized graphics and design equipment today opened a weeklong show designed to pry open the British market to their sophisticated wares.

title: Wood, Field and Stream
description: Looking ahead to the time when June, breezes are warm across the waters of the Northeast, the Babylon Tuna Club is seeking some way to end the everincreasing violations of chum lines.

title: Michaelian Says His Goal Is to Hold Line on Costs
description: WHITE PLAINS, Jan. 31 Westchester County Executive Edwin G. Michaelian, describing a county forced to nearausterity by state and Federal cutbacks, pledged today that his chief objective for the next year he to hold the line on expenses and to afford a measure of easing property taxes for Westchester's 900,000 residents,

title: Valerie Ogden, Actress, Bride Of Walter Massey Phillips Jr.
description: GREENWICH, Conn., Jan. 31Miss Valerie Sterling Ogden, a stage and television actress, was married here tonight to Walter. Massey Phillips Jr., an Assistant United States Attorney for the Southern District of New York. The Rev. William Murphey of the Presbyterian Church, Old Greenwich, performed the ceremony at the Ogden residence.

title: IMPROVED MISSILE IN CHINA REPORTED
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 31Senior American analysts said today that China had started to deploy intermediaterange ballistic missiles with greater range than on an earlier nuclear rocket and with a much improved propellant system.

title: DUDLEY SWIM, LED NATIONAL AIRLINES
description: Dudley Swim, chairman of National Airlines, died yesterday of a heart attack at his home in Carmel, Calif. He was 66 years old.

title: Lindsay to Enter Precinct Races in 5 More States
description: WHITEWATER, Wis., Jan. 31Encouraged by his second place showing in the Democratic piecinct election in Arizona on Saturday, Mayor Lindsay of New York said today that he enter similar contests in Colorado, Kansas, Oklahoma, Virginia and the state of Washington.

title: CONNALLY PRESSED ON U.S. DEBT RISE
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 Members of Congress of both parties accused the Nixon Administration today of refusing to face reality and concede that Federal taxes will have to be raised next year.

title: Labor Arbitrator Resigns
description: Miss Eva Robins resigned yesterday as deputy chairman of the New York City Office of Collective Bargaining to resume the private practice of arbitration of labor disputes in the public and private sectors. Miss Robins, a lawyer, had served as deputy chairman of the agency since its inception in 1968.

title: U.S. Aides Decline Comment on Action By North Vietnam
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 31The Nixon Administration took note today of North Vietnam's decision to make public its own ninepoint peace plan, but declined any specific comment.

title: U.S. Cuts Its Contribution To World Food Program
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Jan. 31The United States has cut its contribution to the World Food Program from 50 per cent of the program to 40 per cent, explaining it wanted other goy ernments to share more fully in the international undertaking.

title: JERSEY PREPARES RENTCONTROL BILL
description: TRENTON, Jan. 31 A bill that stabilize rents in New Jersey at Jan. 1 levels and allow landlords limited increases from this base will be introduced in the Assembly next Monday by Speaker Thomas H. Kean, Republican of Essex.

title: STATE FILES SUIT ON SCHOOL PLACING
description: State Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz sued in Manhattan Supreme Court yesterday to put out of business a Long Island corporation that was said to have promised, for fees as hih as $25,000, to get studentsg admitted to medical and dental colleges in the United States.

title: Computer Speeds Braille Translation, Opening Vistas for Blind
description: BOSTON, Jan. 31With a group of blind persons listening and feeling in astonishment, engineers from the Massachusetts Institute of Technology demonstrated today a new computer system that translates English into Braille almost instantaneously.

title: Japan Retailer Sees Hard Year
description: A 360yearold retail concern in Japan, the Matsuzakaya Company, Ltd., expects to have one of its most difficult years in 1972 because of the yen revaluation and the pressure on Japanese exports.

title: HENRY C. MARTINEAU, BREEDER OF CATTLE
description: Henry C. Martineau of Watton, Norfolk, England; a leading breeder of Friesian cattle, died of pneumonia Jan. 23 in St. Moritz, Switzerland, at the age of 67.

title: GUIDELINE ON RIGHTS TERMED A RETREAT
description: PALM BEACH, Fla., Jan. 31 The head of the American Jewish Committee charged today that proposed new Government regulations thwart efforts to end religious discrimination by companies with Federal contracts.

title: 1,081 in Moroccan Military On Trial for Abortive Coup
description: KENITRA, Morocco, Jan. 31 A total of 1,081 army officers and men who staged an abortive coup against King Hassan II last summer appeared for trial before a military tribunal in this small harbor town today.

title: Louisiana State Triumphs
description: KNOXVILLE, Tenn., Jan. 31 (UPI)Louisiana State outscored Tennessee, 156, in the first 10 minutes of the second period and went on to edge the Vols, 6362, in the Southeastern Conference night. Al Sanders led the Tigers with 21 points.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today Feb. 1. 1972
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: Marshal Matvei V. Zakharov, ExSoviet Chief of Staff, Dead
description: MOSCOW, Jan. 31 Marshal Matvei V. Zakharov, who as Chief of Staff was the secondranking military leader of the Soviet Union until his retirement last September, died today at the age of 73.

title: Bell Telephone of Canada Shows Higher Net in 1971
description: The Bell Telephone Company of Canada reported yesterday gains in operating revenues and net income for the final quarter and full year 1971. The preliminary annual report placed fourth quarter operating revenues at $261,810,000 against $241,053,000 a year earlier. Net income rose to $36,799,000, or 91 cents a share, from $31,577,000, or 82 cents a share, in the like 1970 period.

title: MRS. THOMAS PURCELL
description: OCEANSIDE, L.I., Jan. 31Mrs. Annette E. Purcell, the mother of Francis T. Purcell, presiding supervisor of Hempstead, died today in South Nassau Communities Hospital here after a brief illness. She was 78 years old and lived at 56 Norwood Avenue, Malvern. Her husband, Thomas, died in 1942.

title: C.I.A. Drug Role Urged
description: MIAMI, Jan. 31 (AP) Senator Hubert H. Humphrey, Democrat of Minnesota, said tonight that the Central Intelligence Agency should be put to work in the effort to end heroin smuggling. He spoke at a drug creatment center in Miami.

title: St. Bonaventure Wins, 9074
description: OLEAN, N. Y., Jan. 31 (UPI)Six straight long baskets by Vic Thomas enabled St. Bonaventure to penetrate a 131 defense tonight and record 9074 victory over the Univercity of South Florida.

title: 2 SENATORS REJECT VALUEADDED TAX
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 31Senators George McGovern of South Dakota and Edmund S. Muskie of Maine, both rejecting the concept of a national sales tax, outlined their own approaches today to reform of local property taxes.

title: L.I.I.R.R. Strike Postponed For 10 Days by U. S. Court
description: The United Transportation Union obtained a 10day adjournment yesterday of a hearing on the Long Island Rail Road's application for an injunction against a walkout. The effect was, to continue the current stay against a walkout.

title: Trevino Gets Hickok Belt
description: ROCHESTER, Jan. 31 (UPI)Lee Trevino, who won the United States, British and Canadian opens in 1971, received the $10,000 diamondstudded Hickok Belt tonight at the 22d annual dinner of the Rochester PressRadio Club.

title: Muskie Moves Forward
description: To the steadily growing list of endorsements he has attracted from Democratic leaders around, the country, Senator Muskie of Maine has now added victories in the Presidential preference contest among Arizona and Iowa Democrats. The Gallup Poll shows him running neck and neck with President Nixon in national popularity nine months before Election Day.

title: A NEW PROVOST IS NAMED AT YALE
description: NEW HAVEN, Jan. 31Richand N. Cooper, a 37yearold international  trade specialist who tutored Henry Kissinger in economics and who rides a red motor scooter to and from his office, will become the provost of Yale University July 1.

title: Bomb Breaks 40 Windows In a Dormitory at Boston U.
description: BOSTON, Jan. 31The explosion of a bomb shattered more than 40 windows early yesterday morning in the cafeteria of a men's dormitory at Boston University.

title: Shift of Miss Davis's Trial Asked, Protesters Held
description: SAN JOSE, Calif., Jan. 31After 17 of her supporters were arrested by the police during a protest, attorneys for Angela Davis tried again today to have her trial shifted to, another county.

title: Ballet Folklorico of Mexico Opens in City Center Tonight
description: The Ballet Folklorico of Mexico will begin a twoweek run at the City Center tonight at 8 o'clock. It was incorrectly reported yesterday in The New York Times that the National Ballet of Washington open here tonight, but the National is not due until Feb. 15.

title: Even Now, Helping With Abortions Is Traumatic Shock for Some Nurses
description: Some nurses left hospitals, some transferred to different departments and a number went through group therapy and counseling sessions after New York State passed one of the most liberal abortion laws in the country.

title: SENATE KILLS MOVE TO LIMIT RIGHTS BILL
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 (UPI)  The Senate voted 59 to 16 today against excluding 10.1 million state and local government employes from Federal protection against job discrimination.

title: Repertory and Recipes All in a Juilliard Actor's Study
description: On the second day of the first semester, the incoming class at the Drama Division of the Juilliard Schoolfresh, eager and hopeful about its future in the American theateris thrown into King Lear, or another Shakespearean masterpiece.

title: STORE SALES HERE OFF 1% IN JANUARY
description: New York department stores got off to a slow start in 1972 with stores in the downtown areas showing a 1 per cent loss in January sales while suburban branches went ahead by 4 per cent.

title: HIJACKER ADMITS GUILT AT HEARING
description: The hijacker of a Los AngelestoNew York jetliner who was shot and captured at Kennedy International Airport on Saturday admitted his guilt in an outburst at his arraignment yesterday and was subsequently remanded to Bellevue Hospltal for 30 days of psychiatric evalutation.

title: G.I. Slain by Allied Patrol
description: PLEIKU, South Vietnam, Jan. 31 (UPI)  South Vietnamese soldiers patrolling a downtown bar strip in this Central Highlands capital killed an American soldier and wounded another early today, military sources reported. The cause of the shooting has not yet been determined. The names of the Americans were withheld until their families are notified.

title: Chargers Make 3 Trades, Getting Cards Edwards
description: In advance of pro football's annual draft meeting, which begins today, trades continued yesterday with the San Diego Chargers making three.

title: Beaty Scores 34 Points As Stars Defeat Cougars
description: SALT LAKE CITY, Jan. 31 (AP)Zelmo Beaty's 34 points and 27 rebounds led the Utah Stars to a 135115 victory over the Carolina Cougars tonight.

title: 1.8 Billion Capital Budget Is Proposed by the Mayor
description: Mayor Lindsay proposed a $1.8billion capital budget yesterday in which education, transportation and environmental protection receive a total of 71 cents every construction dollar in the next fiscal year.

title: MEDICAID SEEKING FASTER PAYMENTS
description: The city's Medicaid program for the sick poor has introduced a new preaudit payment system to speed payments to doctors, dentists and similar providers to encourage more of them to take part.

title: Prices of Prescription Drugs
description: To the Editor: There is virtually no product or service that a prospective customer does not know the price ofor get a reasonable estimate forprior to purchase. The only notable exception is a commodity that tens of millions of people purchase  prescription drugs. In most cases, the customer does not even know the price of the item until he has placed the order and has the bottle or vial in his hands.

title: HIJACKING SCREEN WIDENED BY F.A.A.
description: The Federal Aviation Administration ordered the nation's scheduled airlines yesterday to put in use by this weekend an approved passenger and baggage screening system to prevent hijackings and sabotage.

title: Updating the Law
description: WASHINGTONCongress does not want for work or problems, but more of both are headed that way unless Congress recognizes that the machinery for grappling with transportation disputes is rickety stuff that no longer works.

title: SafeCrackers Succeed In Locking Out Police
description: A team of professional safecrackers managed to bypass a burglar alarm in a wholesale jeweler's safe Sunday morning and make off with diamonds, gold and platinum valued at $200,000, the police reported yesterday.

title: MOBIL POSTPONES TODAY'S FINANCING
description: In a move that reflected the rise in interest rates over the last three weeks, the Mobil Oil Corporation announced yesterday that it postponed its $300million financing scheduled for today.

title: Drug Charges Dismissed
description: BENTON, Tenn., Jan. 31 (AP)Charges of possessing narcotics and drugs against Steve Kiner, a linebacker for the New England Patriots, were dismissed today.

title: Tribal Strife Plagues SouthWest Africa
description: JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, Jan. 31The Government's troubles with the Ovambo tribesmen of SouthWest Africa appear to be far from over.

title: Prices to Farmers Rose 3% in Month That Ended Jan. 15
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 (AP) Prices farmers received ford raw products rose 3 per cent in the month ended Jan. 15 and averaged 13 per cent more than a year earlier, the Agriculture Department announced today.

title: Syrians Expect War but Plan for Peace
description: DAMASCUS, Syria, Jan. 21The talk is still of war in the Syrian capital but the tone is more resigned than aggressive and there is a new accent on peacetime needs.

title: RITES DUE TODAY FOR 2 SLAIN POLICE
description: Funeral services for Patrolmen Gregory Foster and Rocco Laurie, the two policemen who were shot and killed Thursday night in the East Village, will be held today.

title: PLYWOOD OPTIONS TRADED BRISKLY
description: For the first time in a number of weeks plywood futures were traded briskly yesterday in the New York Mercantile Exchange, with a total of 2,266 trades made.

title: Allowable Texas Oil Output Is Increased for February
description: AUSTIN, Tex., Jan. 31The Texas Railroad Commission today issued an emergency order increasing the February rate of oil production from the 71.7 per cent originally set to 75.8 per cent of the wells ability to produce.

title: PACERS TOP SQUIRES AS NETOLICKY STARS
description: HAMPTON, Va., Jan. 31 (UPI) Bob Netolicky sparked the Indiana Pacers in a late rally tonight as they won the ninth game in their last 12 starts in the American Basketball Association by beating the floundering Virginia Squires, 123115.

title: Production of Steel Rose 6.2% in Week
description: Steel production for the week ended Jan. 29 rose to 2,358,000 tons, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday. This was a 6.2 per cent above the 2,200,000 tons produced in the preceding week.

title: Austrians Will Appeal Olympic Ban on Schranz
description: SAPPORO, Japan, Jan. 31 (Reuters)  Austrian officials will decide whether to withdraw their team from the Winter Olympics here in protest against the expulsion of their skiing ace, Karl Schranz, after an appeal tomorrow.

title: Front Page 1  No Title
description: To see how an enemy spy can Influence a U. S. presidental election, read Farago's The Game of the Foxes.Advt.

title: U.N. AND WORLD BANK DEFY PAKISTAN VIEW
description: NEW DELHI, Jan. 31The United Nations and the World Bank apparently are treating East Pakistan as a separate entity in defiance of the attitudes of the United States and Pakistan.

title: News Analysis
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 31In the last few months, there has been a dramatic turnabout in many officials public statements on the explosive subject of federally subsidized housing. Instead of strongly defending the programs and their administration, as they once did the top authorities are increasingly joining in the criticisin. The critics say that the programs have produced a high percentage of poorly constructed housing on questionable sites at an enormous cost to the Treasury.

title: China and Soviet Support Militants at U.N. Session
description: ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia, Jan. 31 China and the Soviet Union staked out positions firmly behind the most militant African delegates at the United Nations Security Council meeting here today, as the lines began to be drawn for the several remaining days of debate.

title: AMERICAN SMELTING RAISES LEAD PRICE
description: The American Smelting and Refining Company announced yesterday that, effective today, its domestic lead price rise to 14.5 cents a pound from 14 cents. The company said the increase fall within the Nixon wageprice guidelines.

title: Philippines Plant Sought
description: The General Motors Corporation said yesterday that it and two other companies had submitted a proposal to the Philippine Board of Investments to establish a jointly bwned vehicleassembly operation.

title: Ortiz Knocks Out Eastman
description: WALTHAM, Mass., Jan. 31 (AP)Carlos Ortiz, threetime former lightweight champion of New York, scored the fourth straight knockout of his comeback tonight, stopping Ivelaw Eastman of British Guiana in 2 minutes 10 seconds of the second round. Ortiz floored Eastman near the close of the first round. Eastman went down again from a left hook and the referee stopped the bout.

title: ULSTER CATHOLICS PROTEST KILLINGS;
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Jan. 31Stunned by the killing of 13 persons in yesterday's civil  rights demonstration in Londonderry, Northern Ireland was torn today by protests, bombings and terror.

title: Metreveli Wins Tennis Title
description: PERTH, Australia, Jan. 31 (Reuters)Two Soviet Union players won singles titles at the Southwest Australia tennis championships today. Alex Metreveli beat Australia's Gary Pemberthy, 63, 64, for the men's crown while Olga Morozova captured the women's title with a 64, 62 victory, over Australia's Janet Young.

title: A.B.C. RENEWS PACT FOR COLLEGE GAMES
description: The American Broadcasting Company signed a $27million twoyear contract with the National Collegiate Athletic Association yesterday for the rights to televise regularseason N.C.A.A. football games in 1972 and 1973.

title: Plan Described
description: PNOMPENH, Jan. 31 (AP)Diplomatic sources here report that the Cambodians are prepared to accept an agreement whereby the North Vietnamese and the Vietcong withdraw to sparsely populated provinces east of the Mekong River and to an area north of rubber plantations along Route 7 that is almost due east of here.

title: 2 Monks Strike It Rich in Worldly Oil
description: OUR LADY OF GEROWVAL MONASTERY, Miss., Jan. 25 The men who drill for oil have left their derricks and gangling slowmotion pumps iri some strange places over the years, from school playgrounds to the baek yards of houses to the floor of the ocean. They have now done, themselves. They have struck oil at a monastery.

title: Return to Reason on Trade
description: The one good thing to be said about America's deteriorating trade and payments position in 1971 was that it helped to shake the Administration out of the lethargy of its old game plan. Last year brought the United States its first foreign trade deficit since 1888, the year of the Great Blizzard. In 1971 the trade deficit was $2.047 billion and in 1888 a mere $37 million.

title: RESIDENTS DECRY VILLAGE ZONING
description: A midsummer nightmare, a cancer, a carnival and creeping honkytonkismthese denunciations of commercial developrnent were hurled last night at the City Planning Commission by Greenwich Village residents who charged that the normal protections of zoning had broken down in their community.

title: UNION IS ORDERED TO PAY ANOTHER
description: In an unusual ruling, a trial examiner of the National Labor Relations Board has ordered a local union that he found guilty of collusion with a Long Island employer to reimburse a competing union for its organizing expenses and attorney's fees in battling the sweetheart arrangement.

title: Magnus Wahlstrom Is Dead; Machine Inventor Was 68
description: EASTON, Conn., Jan. 3 (AP) Magnus Wahlstrom, cofound er of Bridgeport Machines, Inc., and coinventor of the Bridgeport Miller died yesterday at his home after a long illness. He was 68 years old.

title: EDWARD M. HONAN
description: Edward M. Honan, assistant vice president of the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company in charge of electronic installations, died of a heart attack Sunday in Arlington, Va., while on a weekend trip. He was 56 years old and lived at 12 Iris Court, Somerset, N. J.

title: CHRYSLER TO CLOSE A UNIT FOR 10 DAYS
description: The Chrysler Corporation said yesterday that it planned to close its Newark, Del., assembly plant for 10 days, beginning Feb. 7, in order to balance production with inventory. The plant, which employs 4,900, was also closed for a week in January for another inventory alignment.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:. In your Dec. JO editorial Vietnam's Korean Solution,' you state that in 1965 Korea was notified of an Ameritan plan to, withdraw two American divisions from forward positions and base them near Pusan as a Strategic reserve for all of Asia:, The editorial goes on to say that President Park had seen the handwriting On the wall and offered to send equivalent Korean troops to Vietnam if the two American divisions remain in place near the North Korean border.

title: Democrats Pick Askew To Give Keynote Speech
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 (AP)Gov. Reubin Askew of Florida will deliver the keynote address at the Democratic National Convention in Miami Beach next July 10, Lawrence F. O'Brien, chairman of the Democratic National Committee, announced today.

title: OBSERVER
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 31It is now obvious that the North Vietnamese are not going to get a peace settlement unless they make allowances for the ancient American concept of face.

title: Stricter U.S. Standards Urged for Orange Juice
description: People who lunch on hot dogs and orange juice may be eating nothing more than a sausage of fat, corn syrup and lots of chemicals and washing it down with a beverage of water, more chemicals and a little fruit juice, the city's Commissioner of Consumer Affairs, Bess Myerson, said yesterday.

title: Barenboim and Zukerman Play Beethoven in Immaculate Style
description: Beethoven did not compose his sonatas for piano and violin with Philharmonic Hall in mind. Granted that, what are the options available to any duo playing them in such a roomy place, with its ambiance of remoteness and acoustical factors so weighted against the chambermusic ideal?

title: Larry Campbell, 46, Dies; Convicted With Hoffa in 64
description: DETROIT, Jan. 31 (AP) Larry Campbell, a teamsters union business agent who was convicted of jury tampering during the trial of the union's president, James R. Hoffa, in 1964, died Friday. He was 46 years old.

title: NIXON ASSURANCE GIVEN TO RIBICOFF
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 President Nixon reaffirmed his support for his welfare reform program in a telephone call today to Senator Abraham A. Ribicoff, Connecticut Democrat, who announced Friday that he no longer supported the full Administration bill.

title: Results of Oils Mixed Phillips Advances
description: The Phillips Petroleum Company reported yesterday increased net income for the quarter and the year ended Dec. 31. The Union Oil Company of California managed an advance for the year, despite lower fourthquarter earnings. Pennzoil United, Inc., and American Petrofina, Inc., reported profit declines for the quarter and the year.

title: DR. PHILIP'SHORR
description: Dr. Philip Shorr, author and former history teacher at Franklin K. Lane and Abraham Lincoln High School, who had also lectured at City College, died yesterday in University Hospital. He was 73 years old and lived in Sea Gate, Brooklyn.

title: Cambodia Asks Talks Through Soviet
description: PNOMPENH, Cambodia, Jan. 31 (UPI)The Government of Premier Lon Nol has reportedly approached North Vietnam through the Soviet Embassy here, seeking negotiations in the hope of ending the fighting in Cambodia.

title: BHUTTO IN PEKING; CHINA WARNS INDIA
description: HONG KONG, Jan. 31President Zulfikar Ali Bhutto of Pakistan arrived by air in Peking today for talks with Chinese officials as China delivered an atack on India and the Soviet Union, warning that they ultimately suffer defeat on the subcontinent.

title: INDICTED SERGEANT LEAVES ARMY TODAY
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 (AP) Sgt. Maj. William 0. Wooldridge, once the Army's top enlisted man now under Federal indictment on charges of conspiring to defraud enlisted men's clubs in Vietnam, will retire tomorrow with full pension and benefits, the Army announced today.

title: TARIFF CUT DELAYED ON WINDOW GLASS
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 President Nixon postponed today for an additional 90 days the longdelayed start of a reduction in the tariff on window glass.

title: Market Place:
description: What stocks does a conservative oldline mutualfund organization buy for its new growthandincome fund?

title: Gross Auto Product Lags
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 31The strong growth of the gross national product in the fourth quarter came without any help from the auto or steel industries, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: L.I. Restaurants Boycott French Wines
description: WOODBURY, L. I., Jan. 31 A boycott of French wines, liquors and brandies in an attempt to have the French Government deal more forcefully with the heroin problem was started today by the owners of many of the top restaurants in Nassau, Suffolk and Queens counties.

title: Staph Closes a Yale Nursery After Halt in Use of Germicide
description: NEW HAVEN, Jan. 31An outbreak of staphylococcal infections among newborn infants who had not been bathed with hexachlorophene has forced pediatricians to close one of three nurseries at the YaleNew Haven Hospital.

title: Obituary 2  No Title
description: CHICAGO, Jim, 31 (UPI)Memorial services set for tomorrow for Miss Jackson have been moved from the church where she began her career to the McCormick Place Convention Center to accommodate the thousands expected to attend. The shift was made at the suggestion of Mayor Richard J. Daley.

title: Suspicion of Fraud Cited in Warrants in Hughes Case
description: ZURICH, Switzerland, Jan. 31 District Attorney Peter Veleff of Zurich Canton said tonight that the Swiss police had issued warrants for the arrest of Clifford Irving, the writer, and his wife in the dispute over an alleged autobiography of Howard R. Hughes; the billionaire.

title: Decline Is Registered Despite Sales Gain
description: Earnings of OwensIllinois, Inc., for the quarter and year ended December, 1971, declined despite higher sales, it was reported yesterday.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: VIENNA, Jan. 31  The exclusion of Karl Schranz, Austria's skiing hero, from the Winter Olympics was received with wide indignation and anger to day.

title: RUSTIN AT LIBERTY ON SWORD CHARGE
description: Bayard Rustin, who was arrested here late Sunday night on a charge, of possessing a dangerous weapon, was released on his own recognizance yesterday after waving his right to a hearing pending action of the Manhattan grand jury.

title: Companies in the Field See DoortoDoor Sales Rising
description: Directselling credit companiesthe employers of those doortodoor salesmen that call on householders throughout the country  expect 1972 to follow 1971 as a strong year for their industry.

title: Van Arsdale Fights Licensing of Gypsy Cabs
description: Harry Van Arsdale vowed yesterday to enlist the member unions of the Central Labor Council, which he heads, to defeat legislation that license nonmedallion taxicabs.

title: MISS JACKSON LEFT $1 MILLION ESTATE
description: CHICAGO, Jan. 31 (AP)The estate of Mahelia Jackson, the gospel singer who died Thursday at the age of 60, has been estimated at $1million.

title: The Course of Military Justice
description: AS a signatory of the Geneva Convention of 1949, the United States is bound to search for and bring to trial all persons who have committed grave breaches of the laws of war, and to enact any legislation necessary to provide effective penal sanctions for persons committing grave breaches. As the nation which for over a century took the lead in codifying and applying the laws of war, the United States is bound to govern the conduct of its armed forces by the standards that have been applied to the soldiers of Germany, Japan and other nations. Now that the last of the courtsmartial relating to the Mylai killings has concluded, it is time to assess our Government's role and obligations.

title: Executive Changes
description: H. Marshall Schwarz has been promoted senior vice president of the United States Trust Company of New York.

title: Democrat Is Winner in Election For Governorship of Louisiana
description: NEW ORLEANS, Feb. 1 (AP) Edwin W. Edwards, a Democratic Representative who is pledged to a reform of Louisiana government, won today over David Treen, a Republican, in their race for Governor.

title: Advertising:
description: Henry Luce 3d, publisher of Time magazine, has availed himself of his company's threeyearold sabbatical program and taken one. Ralph P. Davidson, associate publisher, is acting publisher for the next six months.

title: CITY VALUATIONS GO UP $1.8B1WON
description: The tentative assessed value of the city's taxable real estate has jumped to a record $38.5billion, an increase of $1.8billion, Finance Administrator Richard Lewisohn reported yesterday.

title: Nets Home Streak Ends As Squires Win, 117105
description: WEST HEMPSTEAD, L. I., Feb. 1The Virginia Squires, looking at times like the Olympic track team, sprinted to a 117105 victory over the New York Nets tonight for the Nets first loss at home in seven games.

title: Paul Swan, ArtistDancer, Dies; Also Had Career in the Movies
description: Paul Swan, dancer, painter, sculptor and actor, whose career spanned the 71 years of this ceptury, died yesterday at the Bedford Adult Home, Bedford Hills, N.Y. Mr. Swan, who had been residing and working at the home for several months, was 88 years old.

title: I. R. S. PROTESTS BILL FOR POSTAGE
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 Like an aggrieved citizen who thinks he has been overtaxed, the Internal Revenue Service has protested a bill of some $11million from the United States Postal Service.

title: STRUCK BUILDINGS MAINTAIN SERVICE
description: Supervisory personnel were pressed into service yesterday to handle heating and steam operations in many of the city's major office buildings after union operating engineers struck for higher pay and improved benefits.

title: Nixon's World Pays a Call at White House
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 1President Nixon had breakfast today with the Rev. Billy Graham, dinner with Republican Governors and in between found time to greet, salute and be photographed with astronauts, Boy Scouts, Nebraska football stars and Gov. Ronald Reagan.

title: Carrier for Dr. King Urged
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 2. (UPI)  Armed Forces Journal, the oldest military magazine in the country, proposed today that the Navy's next aircraft carrier be named for the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., symbolizing that the Navy, once the most lily white of all the services, has finally come into the 20th century. The publication dates to the Civil War.

title: Witness in the Dilts Trial Tells Of Deal for Minimal Sentences
description: HACKENSACK, N. J., Feb. 1 A Paterson lawyer named as a key figure in the indictment of Robert Dilts, the suspended Bergen County Prosecutor on trial here, testified today that he had met secretly with Mr. Dilts to work out reduced sentences for three of the lawyer's convicted clients.

title: C.A.B. Extends Air Accord
description: The Civil Aeronautics Board yesterday extended the interim management agreement between Eastern Air Lines, Inc., and CaribbeanAtlantic Airlines, Inc., to. Feb. 29. It also approved Eastern's cash commitment to support Caribair by an additional $50,000 during February while considering the proposed merger of the two carriers.

title: In Scottish Isles, Common Market Role Will Be Blessing
description: STROMNESS, ScotlandHere in Orkney Countythe low, galeswept islands lying between the Atlantic and the North Sea seven miles north of the Scottish mainlandBritain's controversial entry into the Common Market is viewed almost unanimously as a heavensent answer to the most wearisome local problem. That problem is the drift from the islesa strong ebb tide of sons and daughters southward from the northern islands to Kirkwall, the county capital, and from there farther south.

title: Dacca Strife Ends, but Hostility Lingers
description: DACCA, Pakistan, Feb. 1After three days of violence, the shooting between Bengalis and nonBengalis died down here today, but the hostility between the two communities in East Pakistan remained fierce and the problem threatened to be a long and festering one.

title: LUDWIG RAUBENHEIMER
description: Ludwig P. Raubenheimer, president of the Peter Partition Corporation in Brooklyn, died yesterday at his home, 95 Cranford Avenue, Cranford, N.J. He was 72 yehrs old.

title: U.S Jets Continue Raids on the North
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Wednesday, Feb. 2The United States command announced this morning that American warplanes conducted five bombing raids on antiaircraft sites in North Vietnam yesterday, bringing the number of such strikes to 11 in two days.

title: FOREIGN AFFAIRS
description: JERUSALEMNowadays Asia is the most warlike continent and has replaced Europe as the scene of great power competition to gain influence in the global balance. During recent years there have been successive miniwars in Yemen, along Arabia's Trucial coast, between the Kurds and Iraqis, among Pathan tribesmen, the Naga hill people and in Burma, where civil conflict is so common as to be the norm.

title: Drawing Collection Of Rockwell Kent Goes to Columbia
description: Rockwell Kent's personal collection of 3,300 of his working drawings and sketches has been given to Columbia University.

title: U.S. Steel Corp. Fined
description: CHICAGO, Feb. 1 (AP)The United States Steel Corporation was fined $7,500 in Federal Court here today for dumping iron oxide into Lake Michigan from Sept. 26 through Sept. 30, 1969 and thereby polluting the water.

title: U.S. Releases Its Own Text Of Hanoi Peace Proposals
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 1The Nixon Administration today released its own text of the ninepoint peace proposal it received from North Vietnam last June 26 and reiterated its willingness to try to negotiate an agreement on the basks of its provisions.

title: Troops at Border Outpost Unruffled By Predictions of Early Enemy Drive
description: BENHET, South Vietnam, Jan. 30I trust God, an American adviser to the South Vietnamese Rangers in this mountainous border outpost in the Central Highlands wrote in chalk in the bunker where he sleeps.

title: One Youth Is Cleared and Another Is Arrested in October Shooting Into the Soviet Mission
description: Handwriting and palmprint analysis led yesterday to the arrest of a 17yearold former Jewish Defense League activist and the clearing of a rabbinical student in connection with the firing of shots into the Soviet Mission here.

title: AUSTRIA, HEEDING SCHRANTS APPEAL, REMAINS IN GAMES
description: SAPPORO, Japan, Wednesday, Feb. 2 (UPI) The Austrian ski team, heeding a personal plea from Karl Schranz, decided this morning to remain in the Winter Olympics despite the International Olympic Committee's decision to disqualify Schranz from the Games because of professional activities.

title: SENATE REFUSES TO CLOSE DEBATE
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 1The Senate refused today to cut off debate on the bill to give the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission the power to order companies to end job discrimination.

title: Roosevelt Raceway Posts Record Exacta of $1,726
description: WESTBURY, L. I., Feb. 1 (UPI)The biggest exacta payoff in the history of Roosevelt Raceway was produced tonight when Camden Savage won the fifth race and Justly Yonder finished second.

title: Giants: Dryer Trade Shows Policy Shift
description: After a bewildering series of maneuvers during the last few days, the New York Giants wound up yesterday with no Fred Dryer and no Fran Tarkenton but with Eldridge Small, a defensive back, and Larry Jacobson, a defensive end, as their two top draft choices.

title: Sniper Kills Soldier
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Feb. 1A sniper killed a British sentry here today as he was opening a barrier for a military vehicle.

title: Price Changes
description: The Reynolds Metals Company said yesterday that it would raise prices on most of its lines of aluminum commercial and farm roofing and siding by approximately 4 per cent.

title: Kings Beat Hawks, 74
description: INGLEWOOD, Calif., Feb. 1 (UPI)  Jim Johnson scored twice and Bill Lesuk added his third goal in three games as the newcomers powered the Los Angeles Kings to a 74 victory over the Chicago Black Hawks tonight.

title: DISPUTE ON ULSTER BREAKS THE TRUCE OF BRITISH PARTIES
description: LONDON, Feb. 1The Brit; ish parties political truce over the Irish question, which Ns. been frayed by the deaths and bitterness in Ulster, finally broke tonight.

title: Howard Barlow of the Voice of Firestone Is Dead
description: BETHEL, Conn., Feb. 1Howard Barlow, who was the Voice of Firestone on radio and television from 1943 through 1961, died last night, apparently of a heart attack, at his home here. He was 79 years old.

title: PAN AM AIR CLEARS CORPORATE CHANGES
description: The board of directors of Pan American World Airways have approved a new organizational structure for the carrier, Najeeb E. Halaby, chairman and chief executive officer, announced yesterday.

title: THOUSANDS MOURN NIAIIALIA JACKSON
description: CHICAGO, Feb. 1Mahalla lived in a house she tried to repair, the Rev. C. L. Franklin said. And now Mahalia has moved on, on to her other house.

title: Obituary 1  No Title
description: Obituary 1  No Title

title: Books of The Times
description: THE KID. By John Seelye. 119 pages. Viking'$4.95.

title: Bomb Found at Stanford
description: STANFORD, Calif., Feb. (UPI)  Stanford University campus policemen discovered today an incendiary bomb that had been placed against the rear of the home of a professor who voted on a faculty advisory board to dismiss Prof. H. Bruce Franklin, a radical. Officials said the device, a bottle containing gasoline, did not go off. It was found outside a bedroom and family room at the campus home of Prof. Sanford Dornbusch.

title: ALIOTO JUDGE DIES; TRIAL PUT IN DOUBT
description: SEATTLE, Feb. 1 (AP)The judge for the feesharing trial of Mayor Joseph L. Alioto of San Francisco died today, leaving the future of the long trial in doubt.

title: EUROPEANS URGE NEW TRADE ROUND
description: BRUSSELS, Feb. 1  The European Economic Community declared tonight that it is prepared to open a new round of worldwide negotiations to liberalize international trade.

title: In Quiet Clothes, They Went to a Quiet Fashion Show
description: Fashion and charity, an unbeatable daily double, came through again yesterday. More than 500 women, most whom had clready settled on a hemline length (the knee or just below) and a look (casual, conservative, uncluttered) jammed into the ballroom of the Plaza Hotel for the first major spring show in New York.

title: Sonics Defeat Bulls
description: CHICAGO, Feb. 1 (UPI)The Seattle Supersonics beat the Chicago Bulls tonight for the first time this season, 121103, with a potent attack headed by Spencer Haywood. Haywood netted 27 points.

title: The Talk of Dublin
description: Not very much happened in Dublin on June 16, 1904. People went about their usual business, read in their newspapers of the General Slocum ship disaster in New York, visited their favorite pubs, talked about the races and discussed the weather. In the library, the resident intellectuals debated Shakespeare. An ordinary day, but a day that has been immortalized in James Joyce's novel, Ulysses, which was first published in Paris on Feb. 2, 1922, 50 years ago today, which was also Joyce's 40th birthday. In every book Joyce wrote, he had one principal subject: Dublin.

title: Bhutto Confers With Mao and Lauds Results of His China Visit
