description: SAN ANTONIO, Feb. 2 (AP) The Houston Rockets took charge in the second half tonight and went on to defeat the Seattle Supersonics, 11188.

title: OTC and Amex Volume Rises; Prices Up for 5th Day in a Row
description: The upward price trend on the American Stock Exchange and in the overthecounter market continued for the fifth consecutive session yesterday in heavy trading.

title: CONSUMERS REMAIN CAUTIOUS ON BUYING
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 (AP)  American consumers are still cautious about increasing their spending, a Government survey showed today. It found that consumers plans to buy new cars weakened in January.

title: French Red Deputies Display Tax Returns
description: PARIS, Feb. 2  Thirtythree Communist members of Parliament handed their incometax statements over to the press today to show they had paid their taxes, while they contended Premier. Jacques ChabanDelmas had managed for four years to escape his.

title: Top Aide of Brezhnev Visiting U.S.; DataProcessing His Official Interest
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 2  A top aide of Leonid I. Brezhnev, the Soviet Communist party leader, has come to the United States on an unpublicized mission that has aroused considerable interest in Government and diplomatic circles here.

title: Alpine Caper
description: If you go to movies for your serious skiingand given the current winter, I don't know where else you'd gothen you may wish to see "Snow Job," which opened yesterday at neighborhood theaters. For "Snow Job" stars Jean-Claude Killy up and down the Swiss and Italian Alps, and it features surely the finest skiing south of 86th Street.If you go to the movies for tips to aid you in your larger burglaries, then you may wish to see "Snow Job," in which a quarter of a million is lifted happily, healthfully, and with no worse than a little bump on the head for anyone. But it will help if you have an Alp or two handy on which to hide your loot, and also if you take it not just because it's money but becausewell, because it's there. You, too, should be so pure.But if you go to the movies just to see movies (an almost extinct vice, which I apologize for mentioning), then there is less to say for "Snow Job," which succeeds well enough with skiing and stealingbut fails in such otherwise superfluous areas as writing, acting and directing.There is, of course, much careful authenticity. Like the skiing, the places are authentic: Zermatt in Switzerland; Cervinia in Italy. The people are mostly authentic too. I mean, except for his name (and the fact that he has better ways to make money) Jean-Claude Killy is Jean-Claude Killy. And his girlfriend (Daniel Gaubert) is, at least according to Warner Bros. publicity, the true-life girlfriend of Jean-Claude Killy. His sidekick, Cliff Potts, is an actor, but a snow-loving actor (Warner Bros. publicity again). And you would think that by putting all this together in a ski-resort caper, you couldn't help but fall into the real thing.But, in fact, asking this cast to do drama, even melodrama, is a little like having the stars of, say, "Endless Summer" play "King Lear"and the result, off the slopes, is a certain wooden charm and petrified cheerfulness. In addition, George Englund ("Signpost to Murder," "Zachariah") directs mostly by having his actors face the camera, pause, and smile before they speakand he thus creates an atmosphere of iron-clad good humor in which crucial moments with emotion-packed lines like (Miss Gaubert to Killy) "You know what? I might be bad, but you're worse?" fail somewhat of their intent.Toward the end there comes a small redemption in the person of Vittorio De Sica, a supposed insurance investigator and the major monkey wrench in an otherwise perfect plot. De Sica's part is pure hogwash, and he himself brings much of the ham to it. But he is so beautiful, and so marvelously, joyously phony, and he has such a trick of turning everyone else's fixed grin into a kind of maniacal laughterthat despite the sun and the snow and the skies, he almost persuades us we are at the movies.

title: Chicago Judge Refuses to Bar Official's Indictment in Panther Case
description: CHICAGO, Feb. 2State's Attorney Edward V. Hanrahan lost today his last chance in the local courts to avoid trial on charges that he obstructed justice in the Chicago Black Panther case.

title: Anniversary in Court
description: KNOXVILLE, Tenn., Feb. 2 (Reuters)Chester and Ruth Angel celebrated their 24th wedding anniversary today by appearing before United States Magistrate Harve Duggins and waiving preliminary hearing on charges of operating a still and possessing, moonshine.

title: Canucks Rout Seals, 51
description: OAKLAND, Feb. 2 (UPI)Five Canucks scored tonight as Vancouver defeated the California Golden Seals, 51.

title: Britain's Currency And Gold Reserves Surge to New High
description: LONDON, Feb. 2 (Reuters) Britain's gold and currency reserves increased by $397.8million last month, the Treasury announced today.

title: BUCKS TRIUMPH OVERSUNS,106103
description: PHOENIX, Feb. 2 AP)Oscar Robertson hit two free throws with 44 seconds left tonight as the Milwaukee Bucks scored a 106103 victory over the Phoenix Suns.

title: GOLD PRICE SOARS; DOLLAR BUFFETED
description: ZURICH, Feb. 2The dollar was buffeted today by the strongest speculative flurry since the realignment of currencies Dec. 18 as heavy demand for gold, a barometer of monetary anxiety, pushed the price to nearly $50 an ounce.

title: Inching Toward Taxi Sanity
description: Regulations governing the taxi industry in New York City have always been caught in heavy political traffic; in past years, whenever members of the industry sounded their horns in outrage over proposed rules changes, members of the City Council could be counted on to jump to their command. At a public hearing this week, taxi union spokesmen and fleet owners once again made the air blue with threats against any infringement of the municipally protected monopoly. The public interest requires more independent Councilmanic response this time.

title: Demonstration in London
description: LONDON, Feb. 2 (UPI)Some 1,500 marchers held up rush hour traffic in Park Lane today with a demonstration headed by a van carrying 13 coffins.

title: Morton Appoints Aide
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 (AP) Secretary of the Interior Rogers C. Z. Morton announced today the appointment of J. W. O'Meara as director of the Office of Saline Water. He has been acting director of that agency since last March 9.

title: Closings Vex 5th Ave. Retailers
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 Allan R. Johnson, chairman of Saks Fifth Ave, said at a Federal Trade Commission hearing here today that his company had fully expected to derive business benefits when Best & Company closed its Fifth Avenue store. This, however, did not develop.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: Senator Javits in a recent letter and Harry Schwartz in a recent column have, I believe, confused a number of different Issues in their consideration of whether or not we need more physicians to meet the health care needs of the nation.

title: Miss Meyer Breaks Ankle
description: SACRAMENTO, Calif., Feb. 2 (UPI)Debbie Meyer, who announced her retirement from competitive swimming last week at the age of 19, has broken an ankle while learning to ski. Mrs. Betty Meyer said today her daughter suffered the injury Monday while skiing with friends at Lake Tahoe.

title: Ganging Up on Muskie
description: MANCHESTER, N. H., Feb. 2The New Hampshire primary campaign is just now getting started in earnest, but the most persistent theme of conversation in all the candidates camps is the possibility that Big Ed Muskie of Maine may be in some trouble here not headed for defeat but not due for a smashing victory in home territory.

title: Anne Henning's Skates Digging for Olympic Gold
description: SAPPORO, Japan, Thursday, Feb. 3  If there is gold medal for the United States in the Winter Olympics that opened today, the bet must be that it goes to 16yearold Anne Henning.

title: Jet Football Player Cleared On GunPossession Charge
description: W. K. Hicks, a defensive back for the New York Jets, was cleared yesterday of a charge of illegally possessing a gun. The charge was dismissed by Criminal Court Judge Peter J. McQuillan.

title: Royals Surge Defeats Knicks, 116 to 105
description: CINCINNATI, Feb. 2Little Nate Archibald, who was rejected last year at the players entrance to Madison Square Garden because he was only six feet tall and could not identify himself, scored a personal professional high of 49 points tonight to lead the Cincinnati Royals to a convincing 116105 victory over the Knicks at Cincinnati Gardens.

title: 5 Years Probation Imposed on Grocer Who Killed Thief, 19
description: A 55yearold man who a year ago shot and killed a teenager he said was robbing his grocery store was given a suspended sentence yesterday and put on five years probation.

title: 2d Phone Rate Rise Is in Effect Today; Price Review Due
description: Telephone rate increases granted last month, by the New York State Public Service Commission went into effect today at one minute after midnight pending a review by the Price Commission in Washington.

title: For Hungry Bihari Refugees in Karachi, Future Is Bleak
description: KARACHI, Pakistan, Jan. 28 Tiny children, most naked, play with twigs and stones in the gritty dirt. Some have dried, cracked lips. The stomachs of others are puffed. The bodies of most are filthy.

title: LEAFS TOP STARS, END LOSS STREAK
description: TORONTO, Feb. 2 (UPI) Gary Monahan's long drive from inside the blue line helped Toronto snap, an eightgame losing streak tonight'as the Maple Leafs beat the Minnesota North Stars, 32.

title: Bengalis Put Casualties At 100 in Dacca Fighting
description: DACCA, Pakistan, Feb. 2A spokesman for the Bengali armed forces said today that 100 or maybe more Bengali soldiers had been killed or wounded since last Friday in clashes in Dacca's two nonBengali neighborhoods, Mirpur and Mohammedpur.

title: Apollo Fuel Tank Replaced; Moon Mission on Schedule
description: CAPE KENNEDY, Fla., Feb. 2 (UPI)A damaged fuel tank on the Apollo 16 spacecraft has been replaced, and the spacecraft and its Saturn 5 rocket will be returned to the launching pad next Tuesday, the National Aeronautics and Space Administration reported today.

title: JEROME S. JENNINGS
description: Jerome S. Jennings, board chairman of the Universal Cigar Corporation and president of the Chamberlin Company of America, died on Monday at his home, 21 East 87th Street, He was 71 years old.

title: Dance:New Cunningham
description: Merce Cunningham and his dance company made a blithe and spirited return to the Brooklyn Academy of Music on Tuesday night, offering the world premiere of Landrover, a fullscale major work for the company.

title: Zenith Finds TV Hazard
description: CHICAGO, Feb. 2 (Reuters)The Zenith Radio Corporation said today that it had found a possible shock hazard in three of its 12inchscreen blackandwhite television models. The company said that it notified distributors and dealers last week to modify the models before shipment or sale and to get in touch with owners of the sets to arrange for modifications.

title: Newsman Charges Discrimination at WNBCTV
description: The Human Rights Commission is investigating charges by a television newsman that he suffered harassment and discrimination as a reporter for WNBCTV News and was ultimately dismissed in December allegedly because he was a Puerto Rican.

title: Frederick S. Moseley Jr. Dies; Headed Lighthouse for the Blind
description: Frederick S. Moseley Jr., a stockbroker who had been president since 1966 of the Lighthouse for the Blind and a vice president and board member since 1947 of the New York Botanical Garden, died Tuesday in ColumbiaPresbyterian Medical Center. He was 68 years old and lived at 417 Park Avenue and at 400 South Ocean Avenue, Islip, L.I.

title: S.E.C. PROPOSES BROAD REVISIONS IN STOCK TRADING
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 2The Securities and Exchange Commission proposed today a number of basic changes in the way stocks are traded, most of them aimed at bringing to investors the benefits of greater competition among different parts of the securities business.

title: Convicted Hijacker Tells Jury He Bribed Dilts to Gain His Aid
description: HACKENSACK, N.J., Feb. 2 Stephen Cannold, a 29yearold convicted extortionist and hijacker, testified today that he had seen Robert Dilts receive a $200 bribe.

title: Dock Workers Pact To Keep Ports Open Past U.S. Injunction
description: Thomas W. Gleason, president of the International Longshoremen's Association, said yesterday that the union's executive board had approved an agreement that would keep Atlantic and Gulf Coast dockworkers on the job for 30 days beyond the Feb. 14 expiration date of a TaftHartley injunction.

title: ROBERT WIMMER
description: Robert Wimmer, a civil engineer for New York City who layout and design of the West Side piers and docks on the Hudson River around the turn of the century, died yesterday in Stamford (Conn.) Hospital. He was 98 years old and had been living recently in a Stamford nursing home.

title: No. 442 Promises He'll Make It
description: On the 77th birthday of one of its founders, George Halas Sr., owner of the Chicago Bears, the National Football League yesterday concluded its annual draft of college players, the reinforcement system that keeps the game going. Best thing we ever did, said Halas of the draft, which began 36 years ago.

title: Market Place A Broker Tells How He Works
description: About that business of finding a good broker. Now that the market is roiling again, the roasted and toasted investors of the Great Bear Market of 196970 are coming out of the recovery room. If you're one of these walking dead, you're naturally interested in finding a broker. One who will treat you rightfind you a winner once in a while.

title: Price Changes
description: Spring Mills, Inc., a major textile manufacturer based in South Carolina, announced higher prices yesterday for Consumer products. It will make selective increases on sheets by 3 per cent to 5 per cent, effective Feb. 15. Towel prices generally will be increased by 5 per cent beginning March 1. Bedspreads and cotton thermal blankets generally will be raised by an average of 5 per cent, effective Feb. 15. Spring Mills said the changes were necessary to cover partially the increased cost of cotton.

title: 4 Suspended City Employes Plead Guilty in Medicaid Case
description: Four suspended employes of the city's Department of Social Services pleaded guilty yesterday in State Supreme Court in the Bronx to a charge of receiving unlawful gratuities from Rugby Funding, Ltd., a factoring concern for Medicaid bills.

title: Mr. Humphrey and the Bombing
description: WASHINGTONHubert Humphrey's recent reference to his stance on Vietnam during the 1968 Presidential campaign (I pledged an end to the bombing, a ceasefire and an immediate troop withdrawal) has, not surprisingly, brought forth some pointed reminders of his much more ambivalent position at the time. Tom Wicker rightly recalls that Humphrey's actual statement on the Vietnam issue made in late September 1968 was weak in its substance and tardy in its timing. Mr. Wicker takes on the painful task of going back into recent history as part of the press duty to keep the record straight. But there is more to the record and this is as good a time as any to reveal it.

title: Extra Work Prompts Vote to Strike at G.M. Plant
description: LORDSTOWN, Ohio, Feb. 2 Nick Schecodnic, a repair welder at the huge General Motors plant here, drove to the union hall at 5 A.M. yesterday to be one of the first to vote in favor of a strike in a labor dispute that has raised issues that will have wide impact on the auto industry.

title: News of Dogs
description: Although Afghan hounds stand only No. 31 of the 116 breeds registered by the American Kennel Club, its devotees during the last year brought their favorites out in great numbers at shows.

title: World Jurists Group Urges International Ulster Inquiry
description: GENEVA, Feb. 2The International Commission of Jurists called on Britain today to sponsor an international investigation into the killing of 13 civilians in Londonderry, Northern Ireland, Sunday.

title: DELAY IS POSSIBLE FOR U.S. GOLD BILL
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 2The possibility arose today that action by Congress to raise the official price of gold from $35 to $38 an ounce might be delayed.

title: Agnew Questions U.S. Aid For Poor to Sue Officials
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 2In moves that are likely to touch off a heated national debate, Vice President Agnew has opened a challenge to the right of poor people, using federally paid lawyers, to sue elected officials.

title: BRITISH EMBASSY IN DUBLIN BURNED IN ULSTER PROTEST
description: DUBLIN, Feb. 2The British Embassy was destroyed by firebombing tonight as the Irish Republic observed a day of national mourning for the 13 persons killed in Northern Ireland by British soldiers.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: This refers to your Jan. 19 editorial  and Sad Plan for Colleges. We applaud your firm stand taken against Governor Rockefeller's proposal to increase tuition at lowcost or free campuses.

title: McKuen Quits Random House for Simon & Schuster
description: Rod McKuen, whose verses celebrating love and loneliness have made him the bestselling poet since Kahlil Gibran, has left Random House, his publisher, for Simon & Schuster.

title: Front Page 1  No Title
description: TO SEE how on enemy spy can influence a U.S. presidential election, read Faraka's The Game of the Foxes.Advt.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Martin J. Feldman, a Democrat, was ruled the winner yesterday by a 15vote margin in the hotly contested race for County Legislator in Suffolk's predominantly Republican 15th Legislative District.

title: U.S. Says It Asked Soviet to Discuss Limiting 2 Navies But Has Had No Reply
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 2The United tates has asked the Soviet Union to discuss possible limits on the naval forces of both countries but has so far received no reply to the monthsold request, the State Department said today.

title: Ozawa Leads the Philadelphia In Concert With Gagaku Group
description: Is there a more consistently exciting conductor unnder 40 these days than Seiji Ozawa? One could easily doubt it after Mr. Ozawa's work at the head bf the Philadelphia Orchestra Tuesday night at Philharmonic Hall. The 36yearold Japanese) musician led a stylistically mixed program that kept one absorbed from start to end.

title: Market Recognition Due
description: LUXEMBOURG, Feb. 2 (UPI) The six members of the European Common Market have agreed to give diplomatic recognition to Bangladesh, a Market spokesman announced today.

title: News Analysis
description: LONDON, Feb. 2When Queen Victoria named Gladstone as Prime Minister for the first time, he told friends: My mission is to pacify Ireland.

title: CHARLES RADDOCK, WROTE ABOUT JEWS
description: Charles Raddock, an author and journalist, died on Monday, apparently of a heart attack, at his home, 330 East 80th Street. He was 55 years old.

title: Lady Granard, a Daughter Of Ogden Mills, Dies at 88
description: The Dowager Countess of Granard, the former Beatrice Mills Of New York, died Sunday at her Paris residence, 73 Rue de Varenne, according to word received by relatives here. She was 88 years old.

title: Horrors of 'Rue Morgue' and 'Yorga'
description: Skip, if you can. "The Return of Count Yorga," a dull, amateurish vampire brew, and catchif you've a penchant for imaginative horror"Murders in the Rue Morgue." The double bill opened yesterday on the circuits.This is the third go at this Poe we know of. And with all due respect to Bela Lugosi, Sidney Fox and that slobbering ape back in 1932, it's the most interesting, at least artistically.First things first. The ape gets short shrift. Now he's only a key costume at a Grand Guignol theater, in the turn-of-the-century Paris, that triggers the action. All they use, actually, of the original is the title itself on the chamber-of-horror marquee.Secondly, the gimmick here is revenge, as a strange, cloaked figure from the past begins doing in former members of the acting troupe, headed by Jason Robards. The punctuation is thick Freud, moored to the scary nightmares of Christine Kauffmann, as Robard's jittery actress wife. Both the plot and the trickery mesh well until the last reel. But a tacked-on, drawn-out postscript almost flattens the fun.However, the entire film is a gorgeous eyeful in excellent color, with lavish period decor and costumes and some perfectly beautiful dream montages. And under Gordon Hessler's intelligent direction, the suspense deepens, as do some enigmatic characters. Two in particular are well played by Herbert Lom and Michael Dunn. For that matter Robards looks considerably more alive than usual, and Miss Kauffmann is quite good.The denouement is sound but fairly predictable. Curiously, it bypasses another solution, lurking right there in the wings, that would have made a marvelous, jolting wind-up. Compounding this myopia, the picture reaches over into "Phantom of the Opera" pasture for an old-hat showdown. But even minus Poe and our favorite ape next to Kong, see it.

title: Early School Strike Divides Madison Township
description: MADISON TOWNSHIP, N. J., Feb. 2Seventeen of the 18 schools in the 13,000pupil school district here were open today, but a highly effective strike, now in its second week, continued to keep more than 95 per cent of the members of the professional and nonprofessional staffs from their jobs.

title: WEST VIRGINIA CHIEF RUNS FOR NEW TERM
description: CHARLESTON W. Va., Feb. 2Gov. Arch A. Moore Jr. of West Virginia announced today his candidacy for reelection, ending speculation that he would challenge Senator Jennings Randolph, a Democrat, who is also seeking reelection.

title: Recess of Talks Explained
description: VIENNA, Feb. 2The decision to end the current round of United StatesSoviet talks on the limitation of strategic nuclear arms was made yesterday primarily because of a deadlock over submarinebased missiles, a reliable source reported today.

title: News of Skiing
description: WOODRIDGE, N. Y., Feb. 2Elmer, the 20foot high snowman, who looked like a wellsculptured giant mound of white glue when the weather was cold last Christmas at the Big Vanilla at Davos ski area, has suffered from the rigors of this winter. Because of unseasonably warm weather in January, Elmer's wellformed contours have slowly melted away. Today, he was nothing more than mass of snarled wire and straw.

title: RAY KINNEY IS DEAD; HAWAIIAN SINGER, 71
description: HONOLULU, Feb. 2 (AP)Ray Kinney, an entertainer who wrote and sang songs of the Hawaiian Islands for more than 50 years, died Monday. He was 71 years old.

title: 2 Die in Belfast
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Thursday, Feb. 3 (UPI)A bomb explosion shattered a rural pub here last night, killing one person and injuring five others. Earlier a man was killed by gunfire during a day of rioting through Belfast's Roman Catholic areas after the funeral services in Londonderry.

title: Wood, Field and Stream: Price of Wanton Hunting
description: When cornered by nonhunting conservationists, beleaguered hunters often resort, with indisputable logic, to the classic argunient that the interests, they represent were concerned with the problems of protecting wildlife long before the present laudible surge of interest in things ecological was upon us.

title: State Unit Opens Hearings Into Government of City
description: The state commission investigating the city government held its first public hearing yesterday in what many expect to be a politically volatile inspection of the Lindsay administration.

title: ISRAELIS APPROVE TALKS WITH EGYPT ON OPENING CANAL
description: JERUSALEM, Feb. 2The Israeli Government decided today to accept a threemonthold United. States proposal to begin negotiations with Egypt aimed at a special agreement to reopen the Suez Canal.

title: ARGENTINA BESET BY SOARING PRICES
description: BUENOS AIRES, Feb. 2 An Argentine worker becomes an angry man when a beefsteak and a bottle of red wine, the staples of his daily fare, are priced beyond his reach.

title: Jessie Royce Landis Is Dead; Stage and Screen Actress, 67
description: DANBURY, Conn., Feb. 2Jessie Royce Landis, the actress, died this evening in Danbury Hospital at the age of 67.

title: Survey Finds U.S. Youth Unskilled in Written English
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 2Young Americans mastery of the form and mechanics of written English ranges from adequate to almost nil, according to the first nationwide survey attempt to find out how well Johnny can write.

title: Message Citing Senseless War Stirs Albany Debate
description: ALBANY, Feb. 2The Legislature ended its fifth socalled work week of the 1972 session today after the Assembly engaged in irate rhetoric over the wording of a resolution expressing the deep feelings of sorrow and shock of the members over the slayings of two New York City policemen last week.

title: Blasts Destroy 5 Buildings
description: NEWPORT, Ark., Feb. 2 (UPI)NEWPORT, Ark., Feb. 2 (UPI) Two explosions, caused by leaking gas, and fires that followed the blasts destroyed five buildings in downtown Newport this morning and caused 93 persons to be evacuated from a hospital. No one was injured. City Manager Gene Davis said that damage totaled $2million.

title: CHRIS EVERT WINS IN STRAIGHT SETS
description: FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., Feb. 2 (AP)Chris Evert, now 17 years old, playing in her hometown today defeated Corinne Molesworth of Britain, 6.2, 6.3, in the $25,000 women's international tennis tournament.

title: U.S., BRITAIN REPLY IN SECURITY COUNCIL
description: ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia, Feb. 2  The representatives of the United States and Britain, which have come under steady attack at the special meeting of the United Nations Security Council here, made their first full replies today to charges that they are unsympathetic to Africa.

title: 5,000 Japanese Welcome ExSoldier
description: TOKYO, Feb. 2 After 31 years of exile and privation, Shokichi Yokoi returned to an emotional welcome in Japan today, bringing with him his World War II rifle, tears of joy and an apology to Emperor Hirohito.

title: LongHaired Cop Is Dismissed For Failure to Maintain Norm
description: John Bal, 26 years old, who was known as the longhaired cop, was dismissed by Commissioner Patrick V. Murphy from the Police Department yesterday for failing to live up to the minimal requirements of order, authority and discipline that police work demands.

title: Man in the News
description: AUCKLAND, New Zealand, Feb. 2Descriptions append themselves to John Ross Marshall like tails to kites. And the higher he rises in the public life of New Zealand, the longer grows the train of Aides, descriptions and adjectives used in efforts to depict him. Today the 59 yearold Mr. Marshall picked up a new titlePrime Minister designate, He traded in an old one deputy leader of the National partyand took on another fresh oneparty leader. He also prompted further attempts to reconcile his surface with his substance.

title: 1971 EARNINGS GREW AT L.I. LIGHTING CO.
description: The Long Island Lighting Company yesterday reported gains in revenues and net income for 1971. Revenues totaled $346,182,000, up from the yearearlier $300,881,000. Earnings rose to $50,221,000, or $2.11 a share from 1970's $42,370,000, or $1.95 a share on fewer shares.

title: Russians Welcome Sadat
description: MOSCOW, Feb. 2President Sadat arrived in Moscow tonight, and in the wake of the Nixon Administration's decision to provide Israel with more jet planes, the Kremlin is considered likely to be receptive to his requests for more weaponry.

title: Pistons End Losing Streak
description: DETROIT, Feb. 2 (AP)Dave Bing made nine straight shots and finished with 33 points tonight as the Detroit Pistons whipped the Cleveland Cavaliers, 133.108, to snap a sixgame losing streak.

title: STREET WATCHING 2 STALLED STOCKS
description: Trading remained stalled yesterday in shares of the Levitz Furniture Corporation and Diversified Industries, Inc., on the New York Stock Exchange as investors and exchange officials awaited further clarification of the situations surrounding each.

title: Jets Pluck 360Pound Wrestler in Draft
description: Having aimed for quality in selecting Jerome Barkum and Mike Taylor on the first day of the draft, the Jets went for quantity yesterday and plucked a 360pound center from the legion of nameless collegians remaining in football lottery.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: As Democratic leaders continue to endorse Senator Muskie's candidacy and as public opinion polls reveal him as leading in state primaries, it should become painfully obvious to the candidates of the political left and their supporters that their current electoral strategy will produce neither victory nor influence on public policy. Senator Muskie is now virtually assured of the nomination, and centrist policies will prevail for at least another four years. Meanwhile, the left candidates Chisholm, Lindsay, McCarthy, McGovern, and Spockpursue their individual candidacies, dissipate whatever electoral strength the new left might have had, and guarantee the election of either Nixon or Muskie.

title: The Bergdorf Sale
description: The Federal Trade Commission rarely suffers from excess of zeal, but there is danger that a current commission effort to keep commercial competition alive may actually have the reverse effect of rushing one of New York's quality stores into extinction.

title: Impossible or Not, Patterson's Dream Keeps Him Going
description: Did you ever see a dream sparring?

title: LeBoutillier Rites Tomorrow
description: A memorial service for Philip LeBoutillier, the former president of Best & Co., who died on Tuesday, will be held tomorrow at 11 A.M. in St. James Episcopal Church, 865 Madison Avenue.

title: NEW CHIEF NAMED IN NEW ZEALAND
description: AUCKLAND, New Zealand, Feb, 2Sir Keith Holyoake resigned as Prime Minister today after nearly 12 years in office, and a caucus of his governing National party chose his deputy, John Ross Marshall, as his successor.

title: Nixon Accuses Congress Of a Lag on Dock Strike
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 2President Nixon, in strong and sometimes bitter language, accused Congress today of having failed to respond swiftly and decisively to put a stop to the prolonged West Coast dock strike and end its appalling human costs.

title: NATALIE BARNEY AUTHOR, 94, DIES
description: PARIS, Thursday, Feb. 3 (Reuters)Natalie Barney, an Americanborn writer who included Ernest Hemingway, Marcel Proust and James Joyce in her literary circle on the Left Bank, died today at the age of 94.

title: BENJAMIN CHEW JR.
description: PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 2 Benjamin Chew Jr., a director of the Historical Society of Pennsylvania, died Saturday of a heart attack while playing tennis. He was 57 years old and lived in nearby Villanova.

title: To Save Our Society
description: WASHINGTONThe factors of economic necessity which led to the rise of great cities in this country have ceased to exist. Not only will factories continue to leave the cities, but offices, retail stores, restaurants movie houses and eventually the theater and cultural, centers will go as well.

title: Tentative Cut Is Planned In Debt Ceiling Request
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 (UPI) The House Ways and Means Committee tentatively agreed today to cut President Nixon's request for a $50billion increase in the national debt limit and require the Administration to return to Congress this summer to further justify another increase.

title: DEMOCRATS FILE FOR OHIO PRIMARY
description: COLUMBUS, Ohio, Feb. 2The groundwork was laid here today for a bruising primary fight for control of most of Ohio's 153 delegates to the Democratic national convention in July.

title: France's Deus Ex Machina
description: In 1958, France was coming apart at the seams, and all her famous couturiers could not sew her back together again. Algeria was a painful hot foot; the army was threatening a military putsch; the national image was bereft of that socalled sense of glory that is as necessary to Frenchmen as a good digestion; and a succession of factiontorn governments had shown themselves impotent to do anything but bicker.

title: City Repair Unit $9Million in Red, Beatne Says
description: Controller Abraham D. Beame reported yesterday that the city's scandalscarred Emergency Repair Program was nearly $9million in the red and called for reforms in its practices and procedures.

title: Arts and Letters Body Elects Barzun as Head
description: The National Institute of Arts and Letters, made up of artists, writers and composers prominent in their fields, has elected Jacques Barzun, biographer, critic, historian and long associated with Columbia University, as president of the institute.

title: 76ers Rout Braves
description: PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 2 (UPI) Fred Carter led a balanced Philadelphia attack with 23 points tonight as the 76ers coasted to a 119104 victory over the Buffalo Braves.

title: MISS DAVIS ASKS FOR FINANCIAL AID
description: SAN JOSE, Calif., Feb. 2Angela Davis said today that, unless the state was ordered to pay the cost of her defense, she would be unable to present an adequate defense in her forthcoming trial.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: Despite the fact that the gross national product registered a healthy, 6.1 per cent growth rate in the last quarter of 1971, according to the latest Department of Commerce figures, there was no decline in the unemployment rate in the same period.

title: Hundreds of Copies of Hughes Memos Are Readily Available in Las Vegas
description: LAS VEGAS, Nev., Feb. 2Personal papers of Howard Hughes have been widely circulated here over the last few years, and hundreds of copies of memorandums about his thoughts and business affairs are easily available.

title: U.S. Welcomes Move
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 2The State Department said today that it welcomed Israel's acceptance of a United States proposal to begin negotiations with Egypt on the reopening of the Suez Canal.

title: David F. Houston Jr., 72; Art Dealer's Representative
description: David F. Houston Jr., a former art dealer's representative here, died Tuesday at his home, 400 East 58th Street. He was 72 years old.

title: U.S. MOVES TO BAR PELTS OF BIG CATS
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 2The Interior Department proposed today that eight species of spotted cats, such as the cheetah and the leopard, be added to its list of endangered animals to stop what it called heavy exploitation by the skin trade.

title: Legislature Gets 11 More Bills on Prison Reform
description: ALBANY, Feb. 2A package of 11 bills designed to correct what were described as some of the worst abuses in the state's prisons was introduced in both houses of the Legislature today with bipartisan support.

title: Ford Truck Made in Japan Will Go on Sale in U.S.
description: DETROIT, Feb. 2 (AP)The Ford Motor Company said today that its new Japanesebuilt compact pickup truck would go on sale in the United States in March 17 with a goal of 35,000 sales in its first year.

title: Chairman of Ampex Quits Post; Company Sued in Class Action
description: The troubled affairs at the Ampex Corporation took a new turn yesterday with the announcement of the resignation of its chairman and the filling of a class action suit against the company, its directors and its auditors.

title: Court Dispute Holding Up 48 New Penn Central Cars
description: While thousands of commuters on the Penn Central's Hudson Division ride in some of the most wretched railroad cars in the country, 48 new, airconditioned commuter cars sit unused at the station at the Belmont Park Race Track.

title: F.D.A. Backs Germicide Use in Staph Outbreaks
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 2The Food and Drug Administration said today that hospitals should consider a temporary return to use of hexachlorophene for bathing newborn babies if other measures fail to stem outbreaks of staphylococcus infection.

title: Continental Oil Net Fell 31.7 % in 71
description: The Continental Oil Company's net income last year dropped 31.7 per cent from 1970, John G. McLean, president and chief executive, reported yesterday. The nationwide coal strike and adverse developments in oil operations were cited as factors in the downturn.

title: 2 Multiuse Towers to Rise In Midtown Shopping Area
description: Two new multiuse skyscrapers in the fashionable midtown shopping districtone on the site of the old DePinna store on Fifth Avenue and the other alongside the Ritz Tower on 57th Street east of Park Avenue were announced at City Hall yesterday.

title: Memo to the Secretary General
description: The installation of a new Secretary General is an occasion to take stock of the large and latent assets of his office. Ordained by the charter as a principal organ of the United Nations and endowed with an exclusively international character, the secretariat's potential for peace has been neglected by the members of the United Nations generally, and by the major powers in particular.

title: MRS. WILLIE LONG, EXHEAD OF VACS
description: Mrs. Willie J. Long, who as Col. Westray Battle Boyce was named director of the Women's Army Corps in 1945, died on Monday at Walter Reed Army Hospital in Washington, where she made her home. She was 70 years old.

title: American Motors Accelerates Its Earnings
description: DETROIT, Feb. 2The American Motors Corporation today reported a rise in net income to $6.7million, or 26 cents share, for the first fiscal quarter, ended Dec. 31. This was up 13.6 per cent from the yearearlier $5.9million, or 23 cents a share.

title: Article 2  No Title
description: BOSTON, Feb. 2 (AP)Flames engulfed half of the Japanese fishing trawler Taiyo Maru 77 today as crews from a sister ship fought to stem the fire and keep the vessel from sinking, the Coast Guard reported.

title: FRANCE EXPECTED TO REPAY ISRAELIS
description: PARIS, Feb. 3France and Israel were reported by reliable diplomatic sources today to be near an agreement under which Israel would be reimbursed for 50 Mirage fighter planes bought in France but never delivered.

title: Lawyers Call for Appointment Of All Judges Sitting in City
description: Labeling the present method of selecting judges an obsenity, a farce and a charade, eight of the city's most prominent lawyers joined with a Republican legislator yesterday to demand a new system under which all judges sitting in New York City would be appointed rather than elected.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: STORRS, Conn., Feb. 3 (AP) The University of Connecticut, led by Cal Chapman, scored an 89.81 victory over Georgetown tonight.

title: Commodity Price Index Up 0.4 From WeekAgo Level
description: The commodity spot market price index of foodstuff and industrial materials rose to 111.9 from 111.5 last week.

title: Institutions Prepare to Join Big Board, but Delay Is Expected
description: Major institutional investors began preparing yesterday to join the New York Stock Exchange in the wake of the Securities and Exchange Commission's newly adopted position in favor of a limited form of institutional membership.

title: Study Finds News Parley Nearly Dead Under Nixon
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 (AP)  A news study committee says, President Nixon has come close to killing off the Presidential press conference as a public institution during his term of office.

title: SILVER FUTURES DECLINE IN PRICE
description: Prices of silver futures here declined yesterday following a drop in the price of gold in London to $48 an ounce, under profit taking, after gold had reached $48.25 an ounce on Wednesday.

title: Boyer Says Budget Trims Imperil State U. Libraries
description: ALBANY, Feb. 3The chancellor of the State University said today that a critical situation had developed in the university's libraries because state budget economies had forced a drop of more than 40 per cent in the acquisition of new volumes.

title: Shop Owner Is Shot Dead in Downtown Brooklyn
description: The 72yearold owner of a wholesale barber supply concern on a busy street in downtown Brooklyn was found shot to death yesterday inside the shop he had operated for some 40 years.

title: Enlistment Rise Bolsters Hope for Volunteer Army
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 Prospects for a volunteer army by the summer of 1973, when the draft is expected to end, are improving steadily, according to Lieut. Gen. George I. Forsythe.

title: 71 Profit at Peak For Kraftco Corp.
description: The Kraftco Corporation, the world's largest processor and distributor of packaged foods and leading dairy products maker, realized the highest annual sales and earnings in its history in 1971, with record fourthquarter results, Gordon Edwards, chairman and chief executive, reported yesterday. Directors increased the quarterly dividend to the allowable rate.

title: LATE RALLY CUTS MARKET LOSSES
description: Stock prices moved lower yesterday in somewhat jittery trading as interest in lowprice issues stretched out its weeklong boom.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Councilman Edward L. Sadowsky called on Housing and Development Administrator Albert A, Walsh yesterday to cancel a multimilliondollar contract for emergency heating of neglected slum buildings under the Emergency Repair Program.

title: Back on the Track
description: In best Perils of Pauline fashion, welfare reform has once again been rescued from the Congressional barbecue pit. The imaginative plan proposed by President Nixon for a guaranteed Federal floor under family income had seemed dead after Senator Ribicoff of Connecticut walked away from it last week. But now the Senator and the Administration are back together in support of a plan that keeps alive all the essential elements of the original proposal.

title: Court Bars Democrats EqualTime Pie,
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 3The United States Court of Appeals here has ruled that the Democratic party is not entitled to free television time to answer broadcasts by President Nixon that provide information and are nonpolitical.

title: FILION TAKES AIM: 493 TO GO FOR 500
description: WESTBURY, L.I., Feb. 3Nerve Filion, who shattered two world harnessracing marks in 1971 when he brought home 543 winners and drove standardbreds that earned an aggregate of $1,915,545, said today he had set two goals for 1972: topping the 500victory mark again and surpassing $2million in purse money.

title: Accord Seen Near
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 3 (UPI)Negotiators in the West Coast dock strike bargained intensely toward a settlement today. They appeared to be close to one.

title: Rockingham Snowbound
description: SALEM, N.H., Feb. 3 (AP)Racing was canceled at Rockingham Park tonight because of snow.

title: MINORITY BUSINESS SHOWS SMALL GAIN
description: John L. Jenkins, director of the Government's Office of Minority Business Enterprise said yesterday that despite the dissipation of overt discrimination, minority companies have been unable to make significant inroads into the enormous intercorporate marketplace.

title: Shape of Things to Come
description: Mayor Sam Massell proposes to spare Atlanta the fate of some other cities by annexing a few of the lush suburbs on its immediate borders. The effect, if the Georgia Legislature approves, would be not only to give the city breathing room and a financial blood transfusion, but to preserve a balance between blacks and whites that might assure its social health in the years immediately ahead. Moving, however vaguely, in the direction of regional government, the plan is a hint of things to come.

title: PORTER E. LEACH
description: FLEETWOOD, Pa., Feb. 3Porter F. Leach, advertising consultant for The Journal of Commerce, the New York business newspaper, died today at his home here. He was 75 years old.

title: Rangers Top Sabres, 42, As Gilbert, Ratelle Star
description: BUFFALO, Feb. 3There was a sign hanging from the balcony in Memorial Stadium tonight that read: Win Sabres. Try it. You'll like it.

title: G.M. Net Up;
description: DETROIT, Feb. 3The General Motors Corporation had record sales of $28.3billion in 1971, while its net income of $1,936,000,000 was the second highest for any year.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: Dennis Clark (letter Jan. 16) speaks very bitterly of the terrorizing and ruthless military rule of the British Army in Ulster. He is appalled by the policy of internment and the hardships on the civilian population that it involves, but the carefully planned policy of assassination practiced by the Irish Republican Army does not seem to disturb him. The fact that an Ulster Senator was shot and killed in front of his wife, for no other reason than that the murderer did not agree with the Senator's politics, is too trivial an event to be mentioned.

title: News of Skiing
description: MIDDLEFIELD, Conn., Feb. 3While almost everyone in the ski country has been wondering whether winter has come and gone, owners of the Powder Ridge Ski Center in the central precincts of the Nutmeg State have been wondering whether a $125,000 investment will continue collecting rust. Herman and Louis Zemel, operators of the local resort, have been seeking for 18 months to have a fourplace, 2,650foot long chaill lift installed at their busy ski area. They've run into legal body blocks by some of the local citizenry.

title: Earth Tremor Felt in South
description: COLUMBIA, S. C., Feb. 3 (AP) An earth tremor was felt over a wide area of South Carolina and the Augusta area of Georgia this evening but there were no reports of damage. Most reports indicated one tremor lasted about five seconds. The time was put at 6:12 P.M.

title: L. I. R. R. Is Sued Over Cancellation Of 10Trip Tickets
description: MINEOLA, L. I., Feb. 3 The refusal by the Long Island Rail Road to accept its 10trip tickets for a year beyond the original purchase date, as stipulated on the ticket, was challenged in State Supreme Court here today.

title: ShortTerm Interest Rates Will Firm Up Stans Says
description: Secretary of Commerce Maurice H. Stens expressed the belief here yesterday that shortterm loan interest rates had probably reached bottom and were likely to firm up soon.

title: RAIN AND WINDS BUFFET CITY AREA
description: A driving rainstorm with heavy winds swept through the metropolitan area last night, flooding some lowlying areas and imperiling motorists. The temperature rose to a high of 53 degrees but began falling around midnight to the more frigid levels that had been predicted for today.

title: AGNEW'S POSITION IN SUIT EXPLAINED
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 3The White House said today that Vice President Agnew was acting on his own as chief Federal liaison with local governments in questioning lawsuits brought by Federal antipoverty lawyers against elected officials.

title: Suit Cites White & Case Among Others Charged in a Varied Scheme
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 3The Securities and Exchange Commission named a prominent New York law concern and a major national accounting company today as participants in a fraudulent scheme involving the stock of the National Stu dent Marketing Corporation.

title: Commissioner Won't Reinstate Two Dismissed at Willowbrook
description: Acknowledging that reconciliation efforts had failed, Dr. Alan D. Miller; State Commissioner of Mental Hygiene, announced yesterday that a doctor and a social worker dismissed from the Willowbrook State School for mental defectives will not be reinstated.

title: Buzkashi, Knight in Armor Win Divisions of Arcadia
description: ARCADIA, Calif., Feb. 3 (UPI)Bill Shoemaker recorded the 550th stakes victory of his career today at Santa Anita when he drove Buzkashi to victory in one division of the Arcadia Handicap. Knight in Armor won the other division.

title: PRICES OF BONDS DROP SLIGHTLY
description: A mediumquality electric utility bond issue was offered yesterday at a yield of 7.50 per cent, and it failed to cause much enthusiasm from investors.

title: Judge George Sylvester Dead; Served State Court of Claims
description: Former Judge George Sylvester of the New York State Court of Claims, who had been a leader in; welfare activities, died Wednesday of uremic poisoning in Mount Sinai Hospital. He Was 80 years old and lived at 40 East 78th street.

title: FAST BRUIN START DOWNS STARS, 61
description: BOSTON, Feb. 3 (AP)Boston scored two goals in the first minute and 44 seconds tonight and went on to defeat the Minnesota North Stars, 61, as the Bruins Ed Johnston tied a National Hockey League record for assists, by a goalie in a season.

title: Advertising:
description: Ketchum, MacLeod & Grove has been given the Jackson Brewing Company advertising assignment, which brieflyever so brieflyhad been assigned to Lennen & Newell.

title: Irish Throughout the City Are Enraged Over the Slaying of 13 in Londonderry
description: Since the 13 men were slain by British troops in Londonderry on Sunday, 20 IrishAmericans have dropped by Michael Healy's travel agency in the Bronx to pick up tickets for flights to Dublin so they can be with their relatives.

title: MANGIONE PRESENTS CARNEGIE PROGRAM
description: Chuck Mangione is a fairto middlin jazz trumpeter and competent arrangercomposer. Tuesday night he performed at Carnegie Hall with 60odd musicians, many of them from the Eastman School of Music.

title: Market Place: Gains by Levitz In Sales Studied
description: Levitz Furniture began trading again yesterday on the Big Board under new ground rulesno credit purchasesand the action was frantic as usual.

title: The Antidrug Is Coming
description: PARISThe pious must of every study of drug addiction is to pin down its cause to social neglect and ensuing despair, to view it as a consequence of alienation, a passive form of dissent and revolt. This kind of understanding is tantamount to encouragement, as it supplies the youthful addict with a glamorous aura of the desperado type, a trash romanticism that flourished in the twenties in the books of future Fascists such as Ernst von Salomon and Drieu La Rochelle, a skullandbones posturing already played to a pitch by Alfred de Musset and his mal du sicle kids in 1830. The dark beauty of this psychological getup suits the young well and they buy It eagerly.

title: A New Prosecutor in City To Handle Only Narcotics
description: A new and powerful position special assistant district attorney for New York Citywas established yesterday. For the first time, one man was given citywide jurisdiction over all major narcotics cases, including the right to empanel grand juries and initiate investigations anywhere in the five boroughs.

title: Car Industry's Saks Rise
description: DETROIT, Feb. 3January's newcar sales rose 4 per cent to 609,406 United Statestype autos from 585,644 a year before.

title: Dacca Suburb Site of Sporadic Fighting
description: DACCA, Pakistan, Feb. 3 (UPI) Bangladesh Army troops used automatic weapons and mortar fire today in sporadic fighting with nonBengali Moslems in the suburb of Mirpur.

title: Eberle Sees Dollar Step Next Week
description: BRUSSELS, Feb. 3William D. Eberle, the United States trade negotiator, said today that the Nixon Administration intended to present a dollardevaluation bill to Congress next week regardless of the outcome of trade talks with the European Economic Community.

title: Canadian Contralto Offers Bright Recital at Tully
description: More composers who write songs should have singers like Maureen Forrester to promote them. In the Musica Aeterna concert at Tully Hall on Wednesday night, the Canadian contralto sang Harry Somers's Five Songs for Dark Voice so eloquently that one was prepared at the end of them to think they might be great works of lyric art.

title: Javits Chides Governor and Mayor
description: Senator Jacob K. Javits accused Governor Rockefeller and Mayor Lindsay yesterday of letting their political feud permeate statecity dealings and said they should merge their competing investigation commissions.

title: Nastase Wins First Match In Title Kansas City Tennis
description: KANSAS CITY, Feb. 3 (AP) Top  seeded Ilie Nastase of Rumania, using a crisp serve and precise play, defeated Mike Belkin of Canada, 64, 68, today in the opening round of the $15,000 Greater Kansas City indoor tennis championships.

title: Fine Fare at Small New Restaurant
description: Restaurants reviewed on this page on Friday are rated both for their food (four stars to none) and for their atmosphere, service and decor (four triangles to none).

title: House Panel Backs Interim Rise Of $20Billion in the Debt Limit
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 3The House Ways and Means Committee decided today to approve only a temporary increase in the statutory debt ceiling and to make the increase much smaller than the Administration wanted.

title: R W. Young Jr. Weds Mrs. Airey
description: Mrs. Margot Egerie Airey and Robert Winthrop Young Jr. were married in the chapel of Christ United Methodist Church here yesterday by the Rev. George Teague.

title: Dollar Rebounds From Lows
description: LONDON, Feb. 3 (AP)The dollar rebounded from record lows today and moved up for the first time this week on some of Europe's money markets.

title: Black Rhodesian Leader Finds Intimidation by Whites on Pact
description: SALISBURY, Rhodesia, Feb. 3The chairman of an African committee leading the opposition to the proposed settlement of Rhodesia's rebellion against Britain charged today that the Rhodesian Government and white employers were using explosive intimidation in an attempt to force blacks to accept the settlement.

title: STOCKS DECLINE ON AMEX AND OTC
description: The fiveday advance on the American Stock Exchange and in the overthecounter market ended yesterday as both lists declined in continued active trading.

title: ULSTER CATHOLICS, IGNORING HEATH, CALL NEW MARCH
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Feb. 3Roman Catholic civilrights leaders today, scheduled a big march for Sunday, a week after 13 Catholic men were killed by British soldiers at a protest in Londonderry.

title: ROGERS TO CUT 13% IN INTELLIGENCE UNIT
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 3Secretary of State William P. Rogers has reversed, a decision to cut the State Department's intelligence branch by approximately a third, department officials said today.

title: FOREIGN AFFAIRS
description: HERZLIYA, Israel  Jovial Joseph Luns, NATO's Secretary General, calls Israeli Premier Golda Meir Pistol Packing Mama and the term might be applied with equal aptness to her political peer, Indira Gandhi, redoubtable chief of India's Government. These two women, at the top of profession generally dominated by men, have shown obdurate toughness in the world of politics and war.

title: Foe Takes Laotian Town
description: VIENTIANE, Laos, Feb. 3 (UPI)Enemy forces have overrun the town of Muong Kassy On Route 13 about 90 miles north of here, Government sources said today.

title: SatelliteBorne Dowsing Rod to Be Orbited in Spring
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 3The Federal program to locate the earth's natural treasures with electronic dowsing rods carried aloft by satellites is finally scheduled to blast off this spring after years of delays and unending complaints of bureaucratic footdragging and infighting.

title: News Analysis
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Feb. 3American officials, in a reversal of a 10yearold policy, appear to he going to extraordinary lengths to spread bad news about the war in Vietnam.

title: RIGHTS BLOC BEATEN IN 2D CLOSURE VOTE
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 3The Senate defeated today another attempt, cut off debate on bill to give the Equal Employtnent Opportunity Commission the power to order companies to end discrimination in jobs.

title: CLINICS FOR HEROIN ARE ARGUED HERE
description: The creation of clinics to dispense heroin and other drugs under medical supervision to registered addicts was hotly disputed at a hearing yesterday, with supporters of the proposal contending that it would eliminate the black market in drugs and reduce crime and with critics saying that it might attract the entire population of the country's addicts.

title: Mundt, Ill, Is Stripped of Senate Posts
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 3Senate Republicans voted today to relieve their incapacitated colleague, Karl E. Mundt of South Dakota, of three important committee assignments, thus opening up opportunities for a younger generation of Republican Senators.

title: Lindsay Gets Friendly Greeting From Critical Boston Students
description: BOSTON, Feb. 3The city of Boston got two visitors from the South today the heaviest snowstorm of the year and John Vliet Lindsay, a Presidential candidate from New York.

title: sports of The Times
description: Let the jury consider their verdict, the King said, for about the twentieth time that day.

title: Savings Bond Sales Exceed Redemptions
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 (AP) Sales of United States Savings Bonds exceeded the value of those cashed in by $110million in January, the Treasury Department said today.

title: MORTON CITES LACK OF FUNDS FOR PARKS
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 3Secretary of the Interior Rogers C. B. Morton told Congress today that the national parks were in trouble because of lack of funds to deal with problems created by a sharp increase in the number of visitors.

title: A Deputy Inspector In Morals Division Demoted to Captain
description: The deputy inspector who was in charge of the Police Department's PublicMorals Division in lower Manhattan has been relieved of his command, demoted to captain and reassigned to the Bronx because he no longer enjoys the special confidence required, it was announced yesterday.

title: City Ballet Gives Watermill Premiere
description: Very properly there were cheers, boos, and coughs for Jerome Robbins's new ballet Watermill, which was given its world premiere by the New York City Ballet at the New York State Theater last night. This is the kind of innovative theater that needs a mixed blessing at its birth. And, in my opinion, the boos were from fools, the cheers were from heroes, and the oughs were from that strange and disinterested subscription audience that City Ballet wears round its elegant neck like an albatross.

title: Fleisher Gets Wouk Chair
description: The Abraham Wouk Family Professorship in English has been established at Yeshiva University, Dr. Samuel Belkin, president, announced yesterday. Herman Wouk, the novelist, will give an annual lecture as part of the chair, established in memory of his father. Dr. David Fleisher, professor of English at Yeshiva College, was appointed to the chair for two years.

title: Leader of Damascus Jews Hopeful, Says Plight Is Exaggerated
description: DAMASCUS, SyriaLeaders of Syria's Jewish minority hope that the new liberalization of the Syrian regime will bring them greater freedom.

title: Duty Honor (and Self)
description: ALBUQUERQUE, N. M.  The real tragedy of Mylai remains obscure even after the Medina and Henderson trials dragged on in Calley's wake. The ultimate tragedy was not Calley: his killing was horrible enough, And it was not the coverup which in its long term effect on the Army will probably prove just as horrible, Rather, the real tragedy was Mylai as the culminetion of several incidents which, taken together, indicate a disturbing degree of erosion of moral principle within the Army.

title: Books of The Times
description: Richard Brickner's second novel is about that side of artistic endeayor that America knows how to do best build buildings. It doesn't always build the best buildings; but it builds there faster and in greater, clusters. If we can put up the house, the theory rues, we'll find something to house a theater repertory company, an opera company, a movie archive, old, airplanes, something. Whatever troubles afflicted the Metropolitan Opera, the, solution certainly didn't lie in, moving to Lincoln Center and doing the same at twice the price. Tosca may be easier to preduce at the new house, but it is the same operaeven more so. And though it's great to have fresh lighting for The Ring or Tristan and the stage permutations for Die Frau Ohne Schatten, the esthetic charge they generate may be no greater than the pleasure derived from Wagner in the days of Flagstad and, Melchior.

title: Waldheim Urges Action On Problems in Africa
description: ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia, Feb. 3After five days of speeches, the United Nations Security Council moved today into the substance of its special session here, taking up five draft resolutions that deal with some of Africa's most pressing political problems.

title: Coast Films Shown in Whitney Series
description: In movies, as in life, the West Coast has always stood for beautiful surfacesleaving the East with only beautiful souls. One remembers Hollywood, of course, but even in what comes after there seems a positive split between the spirit of East and West, and the difference is evident enough in the excellent program of West Coast Films now playing at the Whitney Museum. For these are wonderful looking movies, even when they are not very good. And when they are good, they achieve their excellence at least partly through a willingness to play with rich and beautiful surface effect.I suspect that Scott Bartlett's "Serpent" puts too much trust in its surface imageshandsome enough but absurdly solemnto the degree that they become portents, signifying everything and meaning very little.However, Jordan Belson, in his lovely, very brief "Meditation," eschews signification and allows his formssoft expanding circular formsto exist, and to be exchanged for one another in accordance with the simplest of rhythms. Some day there may be a Jordan Belson film festival. Every movie will look pretty much like every other movie, and for Jordan Belson lovers (I am one) that will be perfectly all right.The centerpiece of the West Coast Films is Peter Hutton's 37-minute "July 1971In San Francisco, Living at Beach Street, Working at Canyon Cinema, Swimming in the Valley of the Moon." This is a diary film, a currently popular type, and the title tells you what it is all about. Hutton's film aspires to the condition of home movie. But it has been photographed with such attention to composition, light and deepening shadow that it looks rather like a home movie made by Matthew Brady.Such a diary can have been compiled only for publication, and you are left with the feeling that nothing in it really is as interesting as the author wants it to seem.Robert Fulton's "Running Shadow" and Pat O'Neill's "Easyout" are the best of the Whitney show. They are also the most difficult, the wittiest, the most concerned with putting their medium to work. "Easyout" is a kind of closed-circuit, 9-minute science fiction made up of negative transformations and unsettling superimpositions that continually seem to be communicating somethingwhich is perhaps nothing but the idea of communication."Running Shadow," on the other hand, really does communicate something, about the life of forms understood as changethrough a lightning-fast succession of gorgeous natural images, and finally through the swooping and soaring of the camera itself. It is altogether the most exhilarating 10 minutes I have spent at the Whitney, and among the happiest times in recent moviegoing.

title: Flyers Edge Wings
description: PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 3 (AP) The Philadelphia Flyens erased a 20 deficit tonight and beat the Detroit Red Wings, 54.

title: 11 Boys Leave Note to Mr. Kool, A Memorial to Slain Policeman
description: Eleven youngsters who played basketball and baseball in the Tompkins Square playground with Gregory P. Foster, the slain patrolman, left him a letter saying they missed him and would not forget him.

title: Dr. Chester Keefer Dies at 74; Held Boston U. Medical Posts
description: BOSTON, Feb. 3Dr. Chester Scott Keefer, an internationally known medical leader, died today at his home in Brookline after a long, illness. He was 74 years old.

title: Murphy Suggests Roving Band May Have Killed 2 Patrolmen
description: Police Commissioner Patrick V. Murphy said yesterday that small, unstructured and Unconnected bands of black youths, fired up by the rhetoric of betterknown militants, might be responsible for some police killings.

title: A.11.81T. EARNINGS SET RECORD IN 71
description: The American Telephone and Telegraph, Company reported yesterday that 1971 operating revenues and earnings reached the highest levels of any year to date.

title: Boston U. Sextet Wins
description: BOSTON, Feb. 3  Boston University's hockey team posted a 53 victory tonight over Colgate at Walter A. Brown Memorial Rink, The Terriers trailing, 21; early in the third period scored three goals in three minutes. Bob Gryp, Paul Giandomenico and Don Cahoon tallied. The Terriers wonlosttied record is 1621.

description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 3The chairman of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee urged Senators today to find a way to force Henry A. Kissinger, the President's adviser on national security, to appear before his panel and testify on American foreign policy.

description: A local bill that would require the building trades to employ one minoritymember trainee for every four journeymen on cityfinanced construction was termed yesterday reverse racism.

description: MONTREAL, Feb. 3  The Canadian Stock Exchange delisted today the shares of Pan American Mines, Ltd. At the same time, the Quebec Securities Commission ordered brokers to cease overthecounter trading in the issue.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: The problem with the Democratic answer to Richard Nixon's State of the Union address was that, in a campaign dominated by issues of credibility and candor, the television hour was so totally lacking in both. The assorted Democratic participants had been carefully chosen: (1) because they were types  i.e., women, blacks, doves, Southerners, and (2) because they were innocuous. There was no Bella Abzug, no Ron Dellums or William Fulbright, not even a Wilbur Mills.

title: Landis Rites Tomorrow
description: RIDGEFIELD, Conn., Feb. 3A graveside service for Jessie Royce Landis, the actress, will be held at Branchville Cemetery on Saturday at 2:30 P.M. The rites originally had been set for Sunday. Miss Landis, the wife of Maj. Gen. J. F. R. Seitz, died last evening in Danbury at the age of 67.

title: Lynch Blame
description: DUBLIN, Feb. 3Prime Minister John Lynch, speaking to an emergency session of Parliament, today condemned the men who burned the British Ernbassy yesterday as a small minority who under the cloak] of patriotism seek to overthrowi the institutions of this state,

I will have been the victim of one of the numerous packs of muggers that have turned the streets of Bedford  Stuyvesant  williamsburgh into an asphalt jungle filled with terror and violence for my fellow black and Puerto Rican neighbors and myself and my family.

description: MIAMI, Feb. 3 (AP)President Nixon arrived tonight for a weekend at Key Biscayne, Fla.

description: ARCADIA, Calif., Feb. 3 (UPI)Joe Hernandez, who was known as the Voice of Santa Anita, died yesterday at Arcadia Methodist Hospital, where he was under treatment for heart ailment. He was 62 years old.

But the slowmoving timetable under which the committee is operating makes it doubtful that it will have any specific reforms to recommend in time for action by a Legislature bent on early electionyear adjournment.

description: The World Bank announced yesterday it had approved two loans and one credit, for a total of $88.3million to assist propects in Brazil, Venezuela and Ecuador.

title: PHILIP LIEBMANN, HEADED BREWERY
description: Philip Liebmann, former president of Liebmann Breweries, makers of Rheingold Beer, died Wednesday night in a nursing home at Port Chester, N. Y., after a long illness. He was 56 years old and lived in Rye.

description: Combustion Engineering, Inc., announced yesterday formation of a division to be known as Construction Equipment International, a heavy construction equipment rental company.

title: Hughes Book Includes TwiceTold Tales
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 3Selections taken from what was described as The Autobiography of Howard Hughes indicate that these excerpts could have come from previously published anecdotes about the reclusive industrialist, without any special inside information.

title: 250 Books Chosen by Inmates Added to Rikers Island Library
description: They stood silent and sullen, clad in stiffly starched khaki uniformsmore than 100 black and Puerto Rican young men, all inmates at the city reformatory on Rikerd Islandwhile Legal Aid Society lawyers, volunteers and three Bronx librarians passed out 250 library books yesterday.

title: ANTIC HUMOR MARKS NUMBERS PREMIERE
description: Racquets play a prominent part in Le Jardin au Monsieur McGregor, a dance work that Dan Wagoner once set in the midst of a real badminton game. Rackets, however, play no part in Numbers, Mr. Wagoner's new piece, which received its premiere Wednesday night at New York University's Eisner and Lubin Auditorium.

title: Shop Talk
description: The rhinestone pins of the nineteenforties  the jade jewelry of the twenties  will the thirties favorite, ivory, be the next revival? Henri Bendel's is betting, on it. The store is gathering all the old ivory it can find, adding some new pieces and building a collection in its Jewelry department on the Street of Shops. Claire Hgl, Bendel's accessories buyer, says she got the idea some months ago when two young men brought in ivory disks centered with cabochon stones that they had made from materials picked up in India.

title: Obituary 1  No Title
description: Obituary 1  No Title

title: F.T.C. ACTS TO CURB MAIL SALES PLANS
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 The Federal Trade Commission moved today to correct alleged abuses without outlawing the negativeoption device used widely to sell books, records and other merchandise by mail.

title: Nets Defeat Floridians, 122120, On Rebound Goal With 0:03 Left
description: WEST HEMPSTEAD, L. I., Feb. 3 When all else fails, there is always Rick Barry. And when all else failed for the New York Nets tonight, there was Barry up to his old tricks, scoring 41 points and otherwise taking charge, as the Nets edged the Floridians in the final three seconds, 122120.

title: Film: A Costume Drama:' Mary, Queen of Scots' Opens at Music Hall
description: On my list of priorities of things the world does not need now, I suppose that another dramatization of the great 16th-century battle of the queensElizabeth Tudor of England versus Mary of Scotlandwould rank near the top.I admit to that prejudice immediately because it must have reinforced my reaction to Hal B. Wallis's "Mary, Queen of Scots," starring two ordinarily lovely, passionate actressesVanessa Redgrave in the title role and Glenda Jackson as Elizabethin an exceptionally loveless, passionless costume drama.In spite of Schiller, Zweig, Anderson, Fraser and even Robert Bolt (whose "Vivat! Vivat Regina!" is now at the Broadhurst), there are, I'm sure, ways in which one might give some new excitement to this old confrontation of queendoms.Unfortunately there is no excitement whatsoever in what Charles Jarrott, the director, and John Hale, the author of the original screenplay, have put together on commission for Mr. Wallis, for whom they also worked on the Wallis screen adaptation of Maxwell Anderson's "Anne of A Thousand Days." "Mary, Queen of Scots" intends, I assume, to illuminate historyfrom Mary's widowhood in France at the age of 18 until her execution by Elizabeth more than a quarter of a century lateryet all it's really doing is touching bases, like a dull, dutiful student.I had been somewhat amused by the stately dialogue that Mr. Hale (with Bridget Boldand) adapted from Mr. Anderson's play for the screen version of "Anne of the Thousand Days," but in comparison with the original stuff that Mr. Hale has written here, the earlier film sounds, in retrospect, practically Shakespearean. Mr. Hale's language is ringed with desperation, as if like people on TV panel shows, his characters couldn't ever zero in on what they really wanted to say, fully aware that they would think of proper replies tomorrow.Thus when Mary turns on the dissolute Darnley and says: "You disgust me!", all that poor old Darnley can say in answer is "I disgust you!" The feebleness of the exchanges is almost enough to induce a kind of nutty compassion.The move is not completely without historical interest. In Mr. Bolt's play, the two queens, who never met in real life, do not actually meet but they share the same stage. Schiller's version provides a single, fine confrontation scene. In Mr. Hole's screenplay, the queens meet twice, which inspires the scenarist to reach for prose heights that are usually reserved for Literary Guild selections. "Madame," says Elizabeth to Mary shortly before the execution, "if your head had matched your heart, I would be the one awaiting death." It doesn't mean very much, but it's better than "I disgust you!"Because both Miss Redgrave and Miss. Jackson possess identifiable intelligence, "Mary, Queen of Scots" is not as difficult to sit through as some bad movies I can think of. It's just solemn, well-groomed and dumb. It opened yesterday at the Radio City Music Hall.

title: New York Port Notes
description: Although the 80day TaftHartley injunction that ended a twomonth dock strike on the Atlantic and Gulf Coast ports is scheduled to expire Feb. 14, that deadline has been made moot by the International Longshoremen's Association's agreement to continue working for 30 days beyond it. The TaftHartley Act, nonetheless, makes it mandatory for the Government to con duct a rankandfile vote on management's last offer no later than five days before backtowork injunction runs out.

title: 9 COMPANIES FACE FIGHTS ON ISSUES
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 3The Project on Corporate Responsibility announced today that it was expanding its program of bringing public issues before corporate stockholders meetings to nine more companies in addition to its original target, the General Motors Corporation.

title: Minnesota College With No Campus, Classrooms or Grades Opens
description: ST. PAUL, Feb. 1Minnesota Metropolitan State College opened here today with rio campus, no classes, no semester, no classrooms, no grades, no required courses, no library, no student organizations, no tenured faculty and no teenage students.

title: Article 2  No Title
description: SOUTH BEND, Ind., Feb. 3 ??? Will Robinson, senior guard, scored 39 points tonight to pace West Virginia to a 9787 victory over Notre Dame.

title: CREDIT EXPANSION GAINS MOMENTUM
description: The aggregate measures of Federal Reserve credit policy continued to increase their rapid rates of expansion in the latest twoweek period, centralbank data published yesterday indicated.

title: JOHN MARCUS WALKER
description: John Marcus Walker, director of new products for Remington Arms Corporation, died Wednesday of cancer in Memorial Hospital. He was 37 years old and lived at 95 Brookside Road, Darien, Conn.

title: COMDR. DELONG MILLS
description: VIRGINIA BEACH, Va., Feb. 3Comdr. DeLong Mills, Commanding Officer of the Seventh Fleet's San Carlos in World War II, died of a heart attack on Monday. He was 74 years old.

title: Roller Derby Women Have Lips and Downs
description: You don't have to love violence to be el woman Roller Derby skater, but helps. It also helps if you don't mind washing your hair every night (the sweaty helmets ruin most attempts at hairdos), traveling 60,000 miles a year by car, never getting enough sleep, and breaking a bone now and then.

title: Wood,. Field and Stream
description: BRANFORD, Conn.  The third annual meeting of the Seacoast New England Greater Scaup Waterfowlers Association produced some splendid conviviality but no ducks.

title: James Matthew Cashin, 82, A Retired Accountant, Dies
description: James Matthew Cashin, a retired partner in the international accounting concern of Haskins & Sells, died on Monday. He was 82 years old and lived at 1447 East 14th Street, Brooklyn.

title: Nuclear Venture Is Formed
description: The Chicago Bridge and Iron Company said yesterday it had formed a partnership with the General Electric Company for the production of large nuclear reactor pressure vessels in Memphis, Tenn., at facilities contributed by Chicago Bridge, The venture will be known as the C.B.I. Nuclear Company and will be managed by Chicago Bridge.

title: DUBLIN'S ATTITUDE IRRITATES LONDON
description: LONDON, Feb. 3Britain told the Irish Government today that its present critical attitude on the troubles in neighboring Northern Ireland could do lasting damage to BritishIrish relations.

title: ADDED PHONE LINKS TO CHINA REQUESTED
description: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company said yesterday that it was seeking Federal Communications Commission authority for a temporary expansion of telecommunications services between here and China in connection with President Nixon's visit. The company indicated that it anticipated the need for as many as 36 voicegrade circuits and one television channel for news coverage and other related activities.

title: Matthew Urges Black Tax For Building Plan in Harlem
description: Dr. Thomas W. Matthew, who has developed several selfhelp programs for blacks, announced plans yesterday for a $1.2million black tax on Harlem residents and merchants.

title: Soviet Skier Wins at Olympics
description: SAPPORO, Japan, Friday, Feb. 4 (AP)Ard Schenk, the flying Dutchman of speed skating and Vyacheslav Vedenine, one of the aces of the Soviet Union's powerful Nordic skiing team, won the first gold medals of the Winter Olympic Games today.

title: SALVATORE RAGUSO
description: Salvatore P. Raguso, a trustee, executive board member and chairman of the skilled crafts division of Local 237 of the City Employes Union, International Brotherhood of Teamsters, and president of Teamsters Local 80, died of a heart attack yesterday. He was 59 years old and lived at 150 West End Avenue.

title: CORRECTION BOARD URGES 14 REFORMS FOR CITY PRISONS
description: William J. vanden Heuvel, chairman of the city's Board of Correction, made public yesterday a list of 14 reforms in the city's prisons that he said the advisory board hoped could be implemented within a yearincluding the establishment of prison councils with inmate representatives.

title: Soviet Is Said to Ban Dissident Journal
description: MOSCOW, Feb. 3  The Soviet Communist party reportedly made a highlevel decision recently to suppress a leading underground journal, but in defiance of the reported ban the latest issue circulated today.

title: WILLIAMS REBUTS NIXON ON DOCK LAG
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 3The chairman of the Senate Labor and Public Welfare Committee, Harrison A. Williams Jr., attacked President Nixon today for accusing Congress of reluctance to enact legislation ending the West Coast dock strike.

title: Court in Morocco Is Told Leader's Death Foiled Coup
