description: For a couple of decades now, Louisa Matthiasdottir has been one of the steadiest and most dedicated painters on the New York scene. Nothing about her art is flamboyant or unconventional. Her subjects are, indeed, the most conventional  landscapes, figures and still lifeand her treatment of them adheres to the most solid traditions of easel painting. What is remarkable in her work is not what she does, but how she does it, for she brings to easel painting a confident, toughminded, lucid sensibility that is wonderfully appealing without being in the least ingratiating.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: The Times reported on Jan. 22 that 5,212 parking tickets were written in an area in which 947 tickets had been handed out in the corresponding six days of the previous week.

title: The Dance: Cunningham's TV Rerun
description: The second of the three new Merce Cunningham dances that Mr. Cunningham is presenting during his current season at the Brooklyn Academy of Music made its bow on Wednesday night. Called TV Rerun, in its style it appears to be something of a spinoff from aspects of the highly impressive Landrover, the major work that started off this present Cunningham season.

title: N.E. Givens Jr. Weds Anne Marie Mitchell
description: LONG BEACH, L. I., Feb. 4Miss Anne Marie Mitchell, daughter of Mrs. John E. Mitchell and the late Mr. Mitchell, was married her this afternoon to Newton E. Givens Jr., who is serving as a gunner's mate technician third class aboard the destroyer Barry, based in Newport, R. I. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Givens of La Pine, Ala.

title: Squires Beat Floridians
description: ROANOKE, Va., Feb. 4 (AP) Charlie Scott scored 27 of his gamehigh 37 points after the intermission tonight as the Virginia Squires overcame an 8point halftime deficit and defeated the Floridians, 115107.

title: DR. SAMUEL SANDLER, NEUROPSYCHIATRIST
description: HACKENSACK, N.J., Feb. 4 Dr. Samuel Abe Sandler, who retired two years ago as a neuropsychiatrist here died yesterday in Hackencack Hospital. He was 77 years old and lived at 1166 West Laurelton Parkway in Teaneck.

title: PRICE RISE ON TILE SET BY ARMSTRONG
description: The Armstrong Cork Company said yesterday that it would increase prices on selected sheet flooring materials and vinyl asbestos tile, beginning March 1.

title: Tass Reports Reactions
description: MOSCOW, Feb. 4 (AP)The Soviet press agency Tass said today that North Vietnam and the Vietcong had informed the Soviet Government that Mr. Nixon's eightpoint peace plan was an attempt to impose an American settlement in Vietnam and that they were resolutely rejecting Washington's new maneuvers.

title: Swiss Freeze 3d Account In Hughes Investigation
description: McGrawHill, Inc., which had planned to publish the controversial autobiography of Howard R. Hughes, disclosed yesterday that the Swiss police had frozen an account in a third Zurich bank.

title: FILION STARTS 72 AT A SNAIL'S PACE
description: WESTBURY, L. I., Feb. 4Followers of Herve Filion, the FrenchCanadian harness driving ace who accounted for 543 winners and earnings of $1,915,545 in 1971, had little to cheer about in his debut tonight at Roosevelt Raceway.

title: TREASURY ISSUES ARE 32% CASHED
description: The Treasury, announcing the results of its $4.5billion refinancing operation conducted earlier this week, disclosed yesterday that 68 per cent of the publicly held Government bonds coming due Feb. 15 were exchanged for new issues and 32 per cent will be retired for cash.

title: Soviet Press Terms Slaying Of 13 a Colonial Massacre
description: MOSCOW, Feb. 4 (AP)The Soviet press is giving full coverage to events in Northern Ireland. Pravda, the Communist party newspaper, termed the shooting of 13 persons in Londonderry a massacre organized by British troops in the spirit of colonial times.

title: KAISER CONCERN SHOWS PROFIT DIP
description: The Kaiser Industries Corporation, which derives its revenues mainly from worldwide engineering and construction activities, had higher sales and revenues last year but operating earnings were down 22.8 per cent, reflecting its equity in earnings of unconsolidated subsidiaries, the annual report disclosed yesterday.

title: Lack of Good Ones Convention Topic
description: HOUSTON, Feb. 4When men's apparel merchants get together, the talk usually turns to mutual problems. This year's convention of the Menswear Retailers of America has been no exception.

title: New RollsRoyce Company Is Facing Test
description: LONDON, Feb. 4A year ago today, RollsRoyce, Ltd., one of the principal props of British industrial prestige, went bankrupt in a collapse that shook the entire economy and the Conservative Government.

title: Vote on Busing Backed
description: TALLAHASSEE, Fla., Feb. 4 (UPI)A bill has been passed by the State Senate Judiciary Committee to give voters a chance March 14 to determine if they want a United States constitutional amendment against forced busing.

title: Stevenson Is Critical
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 4Senator Adlai E. Stevenson 3d, Democrat of Illinois, charged today that the Administration had ordered Mr. Spivack and his staff in Dacca to refuse contact with the authorities of Bangladesh. Mr. Stevenson, who has recently visited India and Bangladesh, urged early recognition of the new country.

title: Trotting Dates Are Revised For Two Tracks in Jersey
description: TRENTON, Feb. 4 (AP)The New Jersey Racing Commission announced today minor revisions in the harness racing dates this year at Atlantic City and Freehold Raceways.

title: HORN & HARDART TO SHOW 71 LOSS
description: The Horn & Hardart Company, operators of the Automats and other retail food establishments, will show a loss for the fiscal year ended Dec. 25, 1971, of about $4million, it was announced yesterday.

title: Mexico Sulphur Ruled Sold At Less Than Fair Value
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 (AP)  The Treasury Department ruled today that sulphur imported from Mexico was being sold in the United States at less than fair value.

title: Albert H. Mitchell, Executive With I.B.M., 41, Dies in Italy
description: Dr. Albert H. Mitchell, manager of commercial data processing for the International Business Machines Corporation, died Jan. 28 of a cerebral hemorrhage, in Milan, Italy. He was 41 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: MISS EVERT SCORES IN WOMEN'S TENNIS
description: FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., Feb. 4 (AP)Chris Evert, the national junior champion, easily defeated Kerry Melville of Australia, the world's eighthranked player, 63, 61, today in the quarterfinal round of the $25,000 Tennis Club women's international tournament.

title: LOVE AND DISCIPLINE
description: To THE EDITOR: Accolades to Mr. Shannon for his most perceptive article.

title: Buchanan in Nontitle Bout
description: TOKYO, Feb. 5 (AP)Kadota, Japan's former Orient Boxing Federation lightweight champion, will meet Ken Buchanan of Scotland, the World Boxing Association lightweight champion, in a 10round nontitle bout in London, March 27, Hitoshi Misako, Kadota's manager said today.

title: County Agricultural Agents Attune Services to Needs of Suburban Life
description: PARAMUS  The farmer has gone from Bergen County, but his friend, the county agricultural agent, is busier than ever serving a crowded urbansuburban region with but few reminders of a notsodistant rustic past.

title: Inhaling the Air of Mysticism In Nepal's City in the Skies
description: K ATMANDU, Nepal  Until about 20 years ago no travelers were allowed to visit this remote city, the capital of the Kingdom of Nepal, without special permission from the King. Save for a few adventurers who dared to climb Mount Everest, less than 100 miles from the capital, hardly anyone knew much about this country lying between India and Tibet and shut off from the rest of the world by the natural barriers of jungle and mountain.

title: Labor's Vote May Be Divided Among Democrats at Their National Convention
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 5Organized labor may have more delegates than ever, but less real influence in choosing, Presidential nominee, at the Democratic National Convention this year.

title: Home Improvement
description: ARTIFICIAL wood beams that simulate a beamed effect on ceilings and/ or walls in living rooms, dining rooms, halls and dens have been quite, popular for some time now, but most of those currently on the market are made of molded styrofoam or similar plastic that is colored and textured to look like wood.

title: BURKE SCORES 34 TO PACE VICTORY
description: Led by a sophomore, Jim Burke, who poured in a career high of 34 points, Brown continued its surprising first place showing in the Ivy League title race by defeating Columbia, 7872, before 1,008 tonight at University Gym.

title: Labor Tensions Expected Over Deferred Pay Rises
description: DETROIT, Feb. 5What would have been a relatively untroubled labor outlook for 1972, with most of the major union settlements out of the way, is being complicated by an unresolved question of national wake policy: How to deal with deferred pay increases.

title: Marianne Moore Dies
description: Marianne Moore, the prizewinning poet, died in her sleep yesterday at her home, 35 West Ninth Street. She was 84 years old last Nov. 15.

title: Lathrop Captures Men's National Downhill Skiing Title With Run of 1:54.60
description: ASPEN, Colo., Feb. 5 (AP)Steve Lathrop of Waterville Valley, N. H., captured the men's United States National downhill skiing championship on Aspen Mountain today, negotiating the 10,000foot course in 1 minute 54.60 seconds.

title: Lawrence Siegel Weds Patricia Minikes
description: ROSLYN, LT., Feb. 5 Miss Patricia Carol Minikes, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur B. Minikes, was married here this evening to Lawrence J. Siegel, son of Mr. and Mrs. Max Siegel of New York.

title: Spinning and Juggling
description: MINNEAPOLIS (UPI)Bobby Nix stands at the freethrow line, juggles three balls, and feeds them to teammates cutting toward the basket.

title: Caroline Herwig Wed
description: FAIRFIELD, Conn., Feb. 5 Miss Caroline Victoria Herwig, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert S. Herwig of Cocoa Beach, Fla., was married here this morning to James Brooks Barnes, son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Brooks Barnes of Fairfield. The Rev., Stanley L. Houston performed the ceremony in the Greenfield Hill Congregational Church. The bride and her husband are graduates of the University of Vermont. He is continuing his studies in management of natural resources at the University of Maine.

title: The Nation
description: The New York City Police Department mobilized for a grim manhunt last week to find the killers of two young patrolmen. Thirty policemen were working on leads full time; 70 more were on the case part time; thousands more volunteered to do what they could on their own time.

title: Broncos Sign 2 Free Agents
description: DENVER, Feb. 5 (AP).Wayne Meyland, a former Nebraska middle linebacker, and Mike Ernst, a quarterback from the University of California at Fullerton, signed today as free agents with the Denver Broncos.

title: Movie Mailbag
description: To THE EDITOR: Obviously, Stanley Kubrick has earned the right to film his fantasies of sex and violence; his films make money and A Clockwork Orange will probably outdraw the others, with the help of our hapless critics. But in limning his hangups, Kubrick exhibits the most complete lack of compassion one can find outside the sanctums of hired killers or secret police. He has suborned actors, but where are his people? Where is even a glimpse of humanity?

title: ln Montclair Politics, a Street Traffic Signal Can Be as Tough an Issue as the Vietnam War
description: MONTCLAIR  My wife, the county committeewoman, was elected by the Demomatte voters of the Watchung section of Montclair on the platform, Peace in Vietmull, and a Traffic light in Watchung Plaza.

title: Music Mailbag
description: To THE EDITOR: IN HIS article, Rhythm to Drive Back the Mondays, Felipe Luciano makes several statements that are not based on historical and cultural truths.

title: REVERSES SPLIT CHILE'S LEFTISTS
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, Feb. 3 The Chilean Communist party and more radical Marxist revolutionaries are blaming each other for electoral losses and for the economic difficulties facing the leftwing Government of President Salvador Allende Gossens.

title: Mrs. king Winner
description: FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., Feb. 5 (AP)Mrs. Billie Jean King overcame Mrs. Nancy Gunter, 6,0, 76, today and earned a semifinal berth in the $25,000 Women's international claycourt tennis tournament here.

title: Indiana Stops Skid
description: BLOOMINGTON, Ind., Feb. 5 (UPI)Joby Wright sparked Indiana to an 8369 triumph over Michigan State today as the Hoosiers snapped a fivegame losing streak.

title: CITIZENS PATROL BATTLING CRIME
description: JERSEY CITYA group of businessmen in this Hudson County community have formed a special citizen's patrol to fight crime.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: Various Democrt lc Presidential candidates are increasingly critical of President Nixon's policy of Vietnamization. With an election fast approaching, these critics find all manner of fallacy in the President's careful, calculated policy of extricating the country from a very difficult war. Their choice would be a quick cutandrun policy, applied not only to Vietnam but to foreign policy generally.

title: Youths Enter School Board Races
description: HACKENSACK  For the first time, candidates under the age of 21 are challenging their elders for election to Idtal school boards around the state.

title: Lefkowitz Acts to Bar Voting Watch
description: State Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz said yesterday that he had moved in Federal Court in Washington to have the state exempted from potential Federal supervision over registration and voting in Manhattan, the Bronx and Brooklyn.

title: Swiss Prosecutor Seeks Extradition Of Wife of Irving
description: ZURICH, Switzerland, Feb. 5 The prosecutor's office announced tonight it wanted Mrs. Clifford Irving to be extradited from the United States in connection with the purported autobiography of Howard Hughes.

title: Students at Douglass Weighing Report on BlackWhite Tensions
description: NEW BRUNSWICK When the commission was founded in April, tensions were at the highest, Now it's January,

title: SHOP TALK
description: BOONTON  Although it Tats been an industrial town since Revolutionary days (ironmaking then; chemicals, food, electronics, textiles, clothing, plastics now), Boonton has somehow managed to keep a lot of the charm of rural America. In fact, many parts of this town of 9,200 people in northeast Morris County are rural.

title: New & Novel
description: The author is a Ph.D., but she hasn't let this get in the way of her writingwhich is unaffected and even ingenuous. Eight wouldbe free souls try to establish a commune on a 100acre farm in the vicinity of the Napa Valley. Gauch isthe patriarch of the bunch, a philosophical Argentinian full of impossible dreams. According to Hattie (the narrator) their vision of life includes freedom and letting people alone to do what they have to do. Things come close to working out for the Magic Tortoise folks, until bad luck and the natural inhumanity of man  especially their Neanderthal neighborsget the upper hand.

title: The Nation
description: A man intent on hijacking an airliner last month aroused the suspicions of the ticket agent by exhibiting certain behavioral traits that have been found to be common to most wouldbe skyjackers traits never publicly revealed for obvious reasons. The agent asked him for identification, and the passenger, indicating he was deaf and dumb, finally produced commercial pilot's license.

title: Yale Sets Back Cornell
description: ITHACA, N. Y., Feb. 5 (AP) Yale, led by Mike Baskauskas with 34 points, including 18 from the freethrow line, beat Cornell 9187 tonight.

title: Books:
description: Bleak human and statistical underpinnings for Mr. Jones's discussion of Blacks in Business are set forth in this task force report. At the height of this country's economic boom in 1969, it notes, more than 25 per cent of nonwhite male and female teenagers in the central cities of our 20 largest metropolitan areas were unemployed. This constituted about 17 times the unemployfor white males in the entire country.

title: Television
description: LESS like caviar than like stuffed derma, the comedy of Don Rickles might fall under the heading acquired taste. For some, it will always remain tasteless. For others, it has its delicious moments of madness.

title: Master Plan Criticized at Hearing as Too Broad
description: The portion of the City Planning Commission's proposed master plan that concerns Community District 8 in the heart of Brooklyn is a portrait of a community painted with broad brush strokes that fails to show our way of life, according to Alexander Moser, vice chairman of the local board and a resident of Crown Heights.

title: Catherine. M. Roche Is Fiancee Of William Barrett McGurn 3d
description: Announc'ement has been made here by Mr. and Mrs. Guy Roche of Paris of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Catherine Marie Roche, to William Barrett McGurn 3d, son of Barrett McGum of Bethesda, Md., and the late Mrs. Mary Elizabeth Johnson McGurn.

title: Swan Song for Hatmakets?
description: The declining fortunes of the men's hat business may have hit a new low last month when the largest company in the industry announced that it planned to cease production.

title: Plans Drawn to Revitalize Decaying Waterfront from Bayonne to Edgewater
description: JERSEY CITY Although the New Jersey waterfront is, la part, a recognized model for technological advances, long stretches of the Hudson River and Upper New York Bay, from Edgewater to Bayonne, present a bleak picture of rotting piers and idle railheads from which lighters once shuttled freight to and from Brooklyn and Manhattan.

title: Ohio State Victor
description: COLUMBUS, Ohio, Feb. 5 (AP)Ninthranked Ohio State pulled away in the closing minutes today for a 7968 triumph over Wisconsin.

title: Claire Garvey Is Bride Here
description: Miss Claire Rose Garvey, an assistant counsel with the Manhattan Life Insurance Company, was married here yesterday afternoon to John T. Reid, assistant to the president and chairman of Pfizer, International.

title: UNIONS SEEKING CIVIC EMPLOYES
description: NEWARKLabor leaders in New Jersey are making plans for a major effort to expand the organization of public employes and also to liberalize state labor laws as they affect government workers.

title: Science/ Medicine; Antibiotics:
description: The theme is a favorite in sciencefiction: the unstoppable bacterium that kills. H. G. Wells used it. So does modern novelist Michael Crichton. In Wells's story of The War of the Worlds, the killergerm is hero because it destroys earthinvading Martians. In The Andromeda Strain, the destroyergerm (here a virus) acts the villian as it sweeps through the human population because no treatment can stop it.

title: MUSKIE DEFENDS PEACE AIM ANEW
description: CHARLESTON, Ill., Feb. 5Senator Edmund S. Muskie as serted today that he would rather end this war than win this election.

title: Cowboys Sign 442d Pick
description: DALLAS, Feb. 5 (AP)The Dallas Cowboys of the National Football League signed Alfonso Cain, a defensive tackle, their 17th round draft choice today. The 6foot3inch, 271pound Cain was the 442d and last collegian selected in the N.F.L. draft on Wednesday and is the first Cowboy draftee to sign.

title: Sports of The Times
description: Josh Gibson, reputed to be one of the great catchers in baseball history, is expected to be named to the Hall: of Fame Tuesday by the special committee on the Negro leagues that elected Satchel Paige last year:

title: Rediscovering Chattaway
description: BECAUSE of all of the film scholarship being done these days, it was with a great deal of chock that I learned last week that absolutely nothing has been written about Henry Tuck Chattaway. There is no mention of him in the American Film Institute Catalogue of Films, 19211930, in the Index of Lewis Jacobs's The Rise of The American Film, no passing reference to him in any of Pauline Keel's books, and in Andrew Sarris's The American Cinema, Tuck Chattaway doesn't even rate inclusion in either the Lightly Likable or Strained Seriousness chapters, although Tuck Chattaway's films were, to some extent, both lightly likable and seriously strained.

title: Royals Honor 5 Players
description: CINCINNATI, Feb. 5 (AP)Five former Cincinnati Royals including Clyde Lovellette and Wayne Embry have been nominated for the National Basketball Association club's hall of fame. The Royals announced tonight that Dave Piontek, Tom Hawkins and Connie Dierking had also been nominated by a panel of news media representatives.

title: Consumer Gadflies Stinging Business and Government
description: PRINCETONThe architecture of the building that houses the Center for Analysis of Public Issues here may be Tudor, but the style of its occupants is strictly Ralph Nader modern.

title: The World
description: JOHANNESBURG  The summer rains have been good in Ovamboland and the millet Is high. Strong hands are needed to reap and store the grain. That may be one reason why thousands of Ovambo tribesmen in the South Arican protectorate of South West Africa  of which Ovamboland is part  seem unwilling to end sixweek strike against white industries in the protectorate, even though the strike has already won them better conditions.

title: God in the Dock
description: D. Bruce Lockerbie's comment on C. S. Lewis's God in the Dock contains the following statement: Lewis's writing is replete with quotations

title: Republican Back in Politics
description: BOSTON, Feb. 5 (AP)Frederic C. Dumaine, former chairman of the Massachusetts Republican State Committee, who has largely been out of politics since 1968, is resuming an active role as a candidate for election to the committee in the April 25 Presidential primary. Mr. Dumaine, who lives in Weston said that he would file nomination papers Monday as a candidate in the Fifth Middlesex District.

title: Education
description: An idea widely heralded on college campuses emerged in 1970 from the student uprisings that followed the American invasion Cambodia. Instead of seeking change through violent rebellion, why should not students woi'k within the electoral system for reform? This was the basis for the socalled Princeton Plan, which provided a preelection recess so that students could work fulltime for political candidates of their choice. The plan was copied at many schools.

title: The World
description: WASHINGTON  It was 11 months ago, on March 10, 1971, that Richard Nixon offered his potential Democratic opponents some free advice on how to run their campaigns in 1972.

title: Legislative Hearings Listed
description: ALBANY, Feb. 5Following are public hearings scheduled for the near future by committees of the Senate and the Assembly:

title: Minnesotans Outraged by Brawl
description: MINNEAPOLIS, Feb. 5 The beatings of three Ohio State University basketball players during a game here last week has prompted University of Minnesota officials and students to question strongly the direction of Minnesota's intercollegiate athletics program.

title: Toronto Rink Tops Albany, Gains in Medal Bonspiel
description: MT. HOPE, N. Y., Feb. 5The Mississaugua Curling Club rink of Toronto, skipped by Stanley Jones, with an 87 victory over Albany C. C., advanced to the semifinal round of the championship New York Caledonian Medal event today in the 17th annual Cuthbertson bonspiel at St. Andrew's Golf Club.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: Article 1  No Title

title: Letters To the Editor
description: To THE EDITOR: have been skiing for 10 years, but this letter is written in behalf of the new skier who has taken up the sport since the making of artificial snow was introduced. He has bee so propagandized by articles and reports about these snow machines that he feels that so long as it is cold he can expect to find a ski area covered with artificial snow. However, snowmaking costs money, not only for the cost of the machines but also for blowing out the snow once the equipment has been installed. Thus, most areas seem to conserve their snowmaking, and in many instances make just enough to be able to report that we've made snow.

title: Oriental mix
description: SEEING REDIn contrast to the cool tones of the living room, the walls of the dining room are a vibrant Chinese red, foil for the steelandmirror furnishings. The Parsons dining table is a huge mirrored square set with Brno chairs covered in blue suede. Stepped mirrored pedestals, topped by plants, add more glittering reflections. Paisley prints, lacquered surfaces and tenting could be construed as part of the current Oriental craze. But it's not necessarily so. The influence of the East on Western decorative arts has always been importantfrom the chinoiserie invasion of the 18th century to the fantasies of the Brighton Pavilion in the early 19th century. What new is the audacious use of Oriental themes in a thoroughly modern context. In this Manhattan apartment, designers WinklerPatina have hyped up traditional Oriental colors to a fresh vibrancy, troduced mirrorandsteel furniture, a geometric carpet and modern art to classic paisley patterns and Far Eastern lacquer ware.

title: Enlightened torture and Reagan said backwards
description: And by the way, Dick Gregory tells us in his Political Primer, 'Reagan pronounced backwards is nigger. That's why I've always hoped Governor Reagan would pull himself together and get elected President. Then we could say we have a backward nigger in the White House.

title: A Magical Time for the Hardy Birdwatcher
description: For months the crowds have been gone, and it will be months before they return. It is now, in the middle of winter, that Long Island returns most closely to its original state, a region of vast ocean, endless sky and pure sand, of wild bayberries and a bewildering variety of birds.

title: MAN IN BUSINESS
description: The extra step might be the biggest one.

title: BRIEFS SEEK BAIL FOR ANGELA DES
description: The dean of the Howard Umversity. Law School and professors from both the Harvard and Yale Law Schools have filed amicus curiae, or friend of the court, briefs in the Supreme Court of California and in Federal district court arguing that Angela Y. Davis should be released on bail.

title: Not a great war, a thesaurus no treasure
description: There is something perverse in the idea of trying to make a work of reference more accessible to young minds by undermining its utility. It's like trying to train a musician on a toy piano.

title: Poets Academy Honors Hunter College Teacher
description: James Wright, who has received recognition for his own verse and his translations of the poetry of Herman Hesse and Pablo Neruda, has been awarded the 1972 Fellowship of the Academy of American Poets.

title: Regional Rule Called Vital As Urbanization Spreads
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 5  A Federal study has concluded that the urbanization of America is proceeding so rapidly that not even metropolitan governments will suffice and that broad regional governments are desperately needed.

title: HOUSING PROTEST IN BOERUM HILL
description: A group of residents of the Boerum Hill area of Brooklyn have begun to mobilize opposition tothe income requirements of a state Urban Development Corporation project that is planned for their neighborhood.

title: The World
description: WASHINGTON Improved Missile in China Reported, a newspaper headline announced last week. Pentagon officials reported evidence of a new Chinese ballistic missile that has better propellant system and travels farther than previous models. What does it signify about Communist China's nuclear stockpile and missile forces?

title: McGrady Beats Evans by 5 Yards in 600 at Cleveland for 2d Night in Row
description: CLEVELAND, Feb. 5Martin McGrady is doing his thing again on the indoor track and field circuit.

title: 9 Convicted in Hijacking
description: GREENSBORO, N. C., Feb. 5 (AP)Nine persons were convicted yesterday by a jury in Federal District Court of conspiring to hijack a truckload of cigarettes valued at $101,810. Sentencing was delayed. Testimony by another defendant indicated the cigarettes were owned by the Lorillard Corporation and were stolen in Maryland.

title: The Nation
description: Just as New York City is beginning to phase out rent controls, across the Hudson River New Jersey seems likely to impose them, though in limited form.

title: Unable to Confirm Move
description: Mr. and Mrs. Irving, who were registered at a midtown New York hotel, could not be reached for comment yesterday on the latest development.

title: Bulls on Silver
description: The bulls on silver continue to complain about what they call the unfairness of low silver prices and efforts by silver users to keep prices down. Prices must go up, they insist, because demand exeeds supply.

title: MARINARO TO GET NEW AWARD HERE
description: Ed Marinaro, Cornell's allAmerica running back, will be presented with the Lou Little Award to the outstanding athlete in this area on Tuesday night in the grand ballroom of the WaldorfAstoria Hotel.

title: Test Ordered in Copter Case
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 5 (UPI) A man accused of trying to hijack a helicopter as the first step in an attempt to get to Cuba was ordered yesterday to undergo psychiatric observation in Federal prison. Patrick Henry McAlroy, 27 years old, who said he wanted to go to Havana because he was tired of running from the law, was arrested Jan. 26 after he pulled a gun on the only employe at Berkeley's heliport. Later he surrendered to the police.

title: The Nation
description: Will Mory's be hoist by its own tankard? That prospect loomed last week for the famous old private alehouse in New Haven around whose tables Yale gentlemen have gathered for 110 years. The Connecticut Liquor Control Commission announced that it had voted to revoke Mory's liquor license because the club discriminates against women.

title: Movies
description: Is there an audience for serious films In America, and how can you reach that audience? The studios obviously don't know the answer, and they are helplessly trying to market their best films as if they were exploitation pictures. Cisco Pike, an extraordinary first feature written and directed by Bill Norton, opened without any advance publicity a few weeks ago, and slipped into neighborhood theaters, doublebilled with a sleazy Italianmade gangster movie, Machine Gun McCain.

title: Bowdoin Six Routs A.I.C.
description: BRUNSWICK, Me., Feb. 5Bowdoin scored five goals in the last two periods today to defeat the American International College hockey team, 73. Bruce Anderson scored twice and Jim Burnett, Peter, Flynn, Fred Ahern, Ned Dowd and Tom Murphy got a goal apiece for the winners. Paul Pacific, Clarence Morrison and Doug Anderson scored, for A.I.C.

title: Movie Mailbag
description: To THE EDITOR: How altogether fittinga Private Vision film for a Private Vision Critic. The real, deadly danger of course is that Vincent Canby will make Gospel out of Kubrick and A Clockwork Orange will become Film History and its filmic language of fast cuts, stopfreeze frames, antiheroes and Bloody Violent Boobism the coin of the Murky Turkey Cineastes.

title: Lanimons Vows to Keep His Job as Jet Tight End
description: In the serenity of Lake Amistad on the border between Texas and. Mexico, one receives little news about what is happening in the world, especially news concerning a football team couple of thousand miles away.

title: Minnesota Wins by 1
description: MINNEAPOLIS, Feb. 5 (AP)Jim Brewer sank a field goal with 90 seconds to play and a free throw with 12 seconds left as Minnesota beat Iowa, 5352, tonight to keep a share of the Big Ten lead with Ohio State.

title: An AllStar Dual in the Sun
description: SAN JUAN, P. R., Feb. 5 (UPI),Fred Biletnikoff sank a sixroot putt for a double eagle on the last, hole today to enable the Oakland Raider receiver, and his partner, Willie Davis of the Los Angeles Dodgers, to take a onestroke laid in the $30,000 American Airlines Golf Classic.

title: POULSEN IS HURT, OUT OF OLYMPICS
description: SAPPORO, Japan, Feb. 5Eric Poulsen, considered the top United States hope for a medal in the skiing giant slalom at the Winter Olympics, was scheduled to fly home after having suffered a fractured left arm, two broken bones in his right wrist and torn knee ligaments in a training spill yesterday.

title: Shorter Reviews
description: One of the larger monuments of the Civil War, this almanac has almost daily entries describing what was taking place both in the war and on the home front. Mr. Long writes well, although with necessary terseness. There are maps, a massive bibliography and a superb index.

title: Susan E. Wheeler Plans Nuptials
description: EASTON, Md., Feb. 5Miss Susan Elliot Wheeler, a member of the faculty of Sidwell Friends School in Washington, and Dr. Philip Reid Hirsh Jr., a clinical instructor in the department of psychiatry at the Georgetown University Medical School, plan to be married this summer.

title: BRADLEY NETS 30
description: Without the aid of Dick Barnett and with very little help from Earl Monroe, but with more torrid shooting by Bill Bradley, the New York Knicks solidified their playoff berth by beating the Philadelphia 76ers, 112 104, at Madison Square Garden last night.

title: Movie Mailbag
description: TO THE EDITOR: WHEN I first met Stanley Prager 25 years ago, he was preparing to pray the part of a killer in Abraham Polonsky's film, Force Of Evil. The casting seemed piquant, to say the least. It was hard to imagine this round, sunny man killing anyone. But the incongruity and the talent worked, and it was this combination of what seemed disparate elements that continued to work in Stanley's life.

title: Henry James
description: With the publication of The Master, the fifth and final volume of his biography of HenryJames, Leon Edel brings to a close one of the most extraordinary literary labors of our time. So far as the art of literary biography is concerned, it may well be the most extraordinary. The greatest of American writersthe only one to produce an oeuvre on the scale and quality of the European mastershas at last been rendered his due in a Life that is itself a firstclass work of art.

title: City Council Seeks Assurarzce $700Million in New Housing Aid Won't Go to Municipal Loan Program
description: Longstalled because of a combination of political and governmental complications, the city's plan to make available $700million in new money for housing is scheduled for a hearingand still more trouble this week.

title: Shorter Reviews
description: Essays on German history from Bismarck to Adenauer. The linking theme is the idea that Germans since 1870 have not managed to tolerate open discussion, the testing of theories and policies, or living with contradictions. Stern is an eminent Germanist; however, the most interesting recent interpretations of German history have come from Germany itself.

title: Ellen Feldman to Wed
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. William Feldman of Sunnside, Queens, of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Ellen Irene Feldman, to Michael Rosenberg, son of Mrs. William Rosenberg of Hewlett, L.I., and the late Mr. Rosenberg. The wedding is planned for March 26.

title: CHURCH SCHOOLS FACE PAY CRISIS
description: NEWARKIt was a situation with many familiar elements in Newark: a job action by teachers demanding higher salaries; the assertion by school authorities that they lacked the funds to meet these demands, and, as so often happens in such impasses, the disruption of the education of many children.

title: Letters To the Editor
description: To THE EDITOR: In running the article No One Realiy travels Now We Are All Tourists by V. S. Pritchett (Travel section, Jan. 2), you noted that Mr. Pritchett had taught at Princeton and, Columbia but failed to mention Smith College. He was here for the third time this past fall as Elizabeth Drew visiting professor of English. While in residence, he was also writing a life of Balzac.

title: Controversial Plan to Rotate Principals Defeated on L. I.
description: NORTH BELLMORE, L.I.The school board has just gone through a series of three tumultuous meetings in which, in order, it took the following actions:

title: Shorter Reviews
description: The word at the moment is that the Mexican War was pure imperialism, one of the most disgraceful episodes in U.S. history. Here an Oklahoma and a Texas historian trace the tangled story from 1810 forward, judiciously giving attention to political maneuvering in Washington, the Southwest, Mexico, London and Paris; to the antislavery and pacifist movements throughout the country; to the military campaigns themselves. In judging the results of the war the authors can find no benefit to Mexicans. For Americans the bag was mixed: territory with immensely valuable mineral deposits, security from British intervention on the West Coast, and a giant step toward the Civil War. Particularly valuable for students of U.S. history is a rich annotated bibliography of the principal writing on the subject during and since the war.

title: Music
description: THE Thorne Music Fund has the nice habit of granting its fellowships to composers with no strings attached. This year it has had the help of a $30,000 grant from the National Endowmen for the Arts in expending a total of $60,000. Francis Thorne, president of the fund, has announced that $10,000 will go to Jacob Druckman and $5,000 to Lucia Dlugoczewski. Paul Des Marais is getting a third annual fellowship. In addition, commissions have gone to Hale Smith and David Diamond for orchestral works and to Lester Trimble for a chamber work.

title: THOMAS F. NOONAN
description: LINDEN, N.J., Feb. 5Thomas F. Noonan, retired vice president and controller of the Chicago Pneumatic and Tool Company, in New York, died today in Elizabeth General Hospital. He was 66 years old.

title: Opera: Boston Production of Trojans Completed
description: BOSTON, Feb. 5Now it has passed into history, the first complete staged performances in this country of Berlioz's opera The Trojans. Part I, The Sacking of Troy, was given at the Aquarius Theater on Thursday night, Part II, The Trojans in Carthage, followed last night.

title: Congested Honolulu Considers Trains
description: HONOLULUIt's been a long time since quaint little trains rattled through the pineapple fields and along the coast near here. But congested Honolulu, crowded between mountain and shore, is now taking a serious look at another type of train as way out of its traffic jam.

title: Mayor of Jersey City Is a TakeCharge Leader
description: JERSEY CITY The 31yearold public health physician who won the Mayor's job here three months ago, ending more than 50 years of City Hall domination by an aging political machine, is winning a reputation among friends and foes alike as an aggressive takecharge leader.

title: In the Mailbox:
description: To the Editor: I read with great interest an article, Munich Looks Good for the Olympics, by Steve Cady in The Times in September. This article mentioned that in the first sales period, 81,000 of 110,000 tickets allocated to the United States were sold. The remaining 29,000, for sports in which it was said there is little American interest, were returned to the German Organizing Committee.

title: R.P.I. Five Turns Back Brooklyn Poly Here, 60.40
description: Led by Tom Neufeer, with 21 points and 14 rebounds, Rensselaer Polytechnic scored an easy 6040 victory over Brooklyn Polytechnic here yesterday.

title: Front Page 2  No Title
description: JOBS IN TIM MEDICAL FIELD. Openings for professional and nonprofessional workers appear today In The New York Times, See Section 4 and 9. (Section 9 is distributed In New York and vicinity.)Advt.

title: PENN'S QUINTET IS 8666 VICTOR
description: HANOVER, N. H., Feb. 5 (AP) Phil Hankinson scored 33 points to lead Pennsylvania to an 8666 Ivy League basketball victory over Dartmouth tonight.

title: The World
description: What with Pancho Villa, Emiliano Zapata and others, the tradition of the romantic guerrillas has a long history in Mexico. And in the past five or six years, Genaro Vasquez Rojas seems to have continued the tradition.

title: Union County Gets Mobile Crime Lab
description: ELIZABETHNew Jersey's first sleuthmobile, has gone to work in Union County. It was called in on a murder case just two hours after it arrived from the factory and has been out on two or three jobs a week since then.

title: Movie Mailbag
description: To THE EDITOR: Somehow, upon reading his comments on A Clockwork Orange, I got the impression that Vincent Canby quite enjoyed being sickened, as he put it, and disoriented, by the antics of Awful Alex and his arrogant atrocities.

title: Academy Offers Phone Regulations
description: The Brooklyn Academy of Music has announced that reservations for its entertainment programs may be made by telephone.

title: Bon Bon Hogs the Honors at Poodle Obedience Trial
description: Mrs. Virginia Berman left the Statler Hilton Hotel yesterday afternoon with her arms full. Her tiny toy poodle, Rowano Acres Chocolate Bud, U.D., won the utility class at the 20th trial of the Poodle Obedience Training Club of Greater New York and retired two massive sterling silver trophies. In addition, his 198 points made him the highest scoring of the 119 poodles at the event and resulted in four more prizes.

title: Black isn't always bleak
description: To say to anyone who has read one of his previous books that We Can't Breathe is the latest from Ronald Fair should be recommendation enough. To say to others that this is not the best introduction to his work is not to say that it is a bad book. Ronald Fair is primarily a novelist. His first three books are novels while We Can't Breathe is a fictionalized autobiography. It is not as wellshaped as his previous books, Many Thousand Gone, Hog Butcher or World of Nothing.

title: Raising the Price of Gold
description: To the Editor: In your letters columns of Jan. 30, Stresemann argues against raising the legal price for one ounce of gold from $35 to $38 and in favor of assimilating the gold price to the loss of purchasing power of the dollar. This would lead to a reduction of the value of the dollar to one third, or to a price of $105 for one ounce of gold.

title: At the. Center of the Great Cognac War,. Quantity vs. Quality Is the Question
description: PARIS  The thirst of Americans, Britons and overseas Chinese for the finer things of life has provoked a conflict known around here as La Petite Guerre du Cognac.

title: Mississippi Democrat Seeks Vice Presidency
description: CHARLESTON, W. Va., Feb. 5 (AP)Charles G. Hamilton, a former member of the Mississippi Legislature, filed tonight with the West Virginia Secretary of State to run for the Democratic VicePresidential nomination in the. May 9 West Virginia primary.

title: Divorces Double
description: TRENTON  Before New Jersey's divorce law was liberalized last Sept. 13, Mortimer G. Newman Jr., chief clerk of the Superior Court, and the 17 clerical workers in the matrimonial section kept comfortably abreast of their routine paper work.

title: Real Note, $7, Wins Liberty Bell Finale
description: PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 5Menotti Aristone thwarted Robyn Smith's effort to turn Liberty Bell Park's closingday card into a Women's Lib showcase today by riding his father's Real Note to an easy victory in the $55,450 Quaker Handicap.

title: The World
description: LONDONDERRY  An icy rain fell on the bleak hilltop overlooking Londonderry. One by one the 13 coffins were borne from St. Mary's church, the name's of the dead echoing through the streets from loudspeakers. Patrick Doherty  William Nash  Michael Kelly

title: David Spivak Marries Denise Goldman
description: Miss Denise Yvette Goldman, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert F. Goldman of Forest Hills, Queens, and Upper Black Eddy, Pa., was married here last evening to David Bennett Spivak, son of Mr. and Mrs. Benjamin Spivak of Brightwaters, L. I. Rabbi Josiah Derby performed the ceremony at the St. RegisSheraton Roof.

title: Blanche Pickens Meiklejohn Fiancee of Scott L. Alexander
description: GREENWICH, Conn., Feb. 5Mr. and Mrs. Robert P. Meiklejohn have announced the engagement of Mr. Meiklejohn's daughter, Miss Blanche Pickens Meiklejohn, to Scott Lee Alexander, son of Mr. and Mrs. Donald Alexander of Pemberville, Ohio.

title: Soccer League Will Hold Draft Of Collegians Here Wednesday
description: The eight franchises of the North American Soccer League, the top soccer league in the nation, will draft about 40 collegiate players on Wednesday, 80 per cent of them American citizens. But statistics show that the best crop of American born players are not yet eligible for the draft.

title: Twice So Fair
description: When Rosalind Wells finds her professorhusband and a girl student dead in the girl's gasfilled studio, she suspects the worst. The worst, however, is both better (and worse) than anything Rosalind could possibly imagine. If you don't follow me, try following Miss Tyre in this decidedly sluggish novel of suspense.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: Letters to the Editor

title: Yevtushenko Hears Bombs and Balalaikas
description: EF I see vun woman on zee street vich is attacked by some bahstards who try to force hereef at same time I vill just to valk on other side of street only to observe the stars, thinking about eternity, I viii feel myself as a bahstard.

title: Queens Electrician Finds and Returns a Negotiable Check for 1.6Million Lost in the Financial District
description: A sharpeyed electrician from Queens cleared up $1,665,920 worth of worry yesterday for a Texas grain exporter.

title: Hempstead vs. Gasoline Alley
description: HEMPSTEAD, L.I.In a rare display of unity, Hempstead Town officials and representatives of civic associations in the township have agreed that while gasoline stations are a necessary evil, too many of them are too much.

title: New & Novel
description: Two chief warrant officers, with a record of combat service in Vietnam, have run up a very funny burlesque out of some of that largely unfunny war's ambiguities. Army lampoons are all too easy to initiate; this one has an infusion of honest venom that lifts it above journeyman comedy.

title: The Nation
description: Reflecting last week on the results of caucuses in Iowa and Arizona, the first two states in which the delegate selection reforms adopted by, the Democratic party have been tested, Senator George McGovern admitted that, Under the old system, where national convention delegates were mainly chosen by party leaders, I would have had no chance. Ed Muskie would have the nomination cinched by now.

title: 74 to Challenge Moore For World Sunfish Title
description: Ted Moore, a Harvard graduate student from Binghamton, N. Y., will defend his title in the world Sunfish Class sailing championships that open next Thursday at Hamilton, Bermuda.

title: Gardens
description: So primed with good purpose are the springtime bulbs, the rarest of warm winters will push them out. Not needing calendars, but sunshine, moisture and warmth, the small delicate snowdrops flowered magnificently in recent days. So tiny and sweet are the little flowers, they might be missed by the speedy passerby. Crocus, too, responded with an enthusiastic spurt not all of them, but a few where the sun was warmest on the winter ground. Early bloom? Some say it was. Perhaps it was just a good omen of a bright spring to come.

title: Wintertime View of Giants Depth Chart
description: If the New York Giants had to make a three deep lineup this week, it would look like this. (Rookies drafted last week, not yet actually signed, are shown in italics).

title: SAIGON SAYS ENEMY LOST 54 IN CLASHES
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Feb. 5 (AP)South Vietnamese headquarters said today that 54 enemy soldiers had been killed in clashes in the Central Highlands along the Coast, many of them in ambushes.

title: Shorter Reviews
description: A guide that addresses itself to the special problems of the black traveler. A frank appraisal of how he is likely to be treated at various resorts, hotels, restaurants, nightclubs. A handy item that could forestall some embarrassing encounters; also mentions sites with special interest for vacationing blacks. The author owns a travel agency.

title: $2Million Campaign Set Against Breast Cancer
description: The American Cancer Society has announced that it plans to spend $2million over the next two years on a steppedup campaign to combat breast cancer, a disease that is expected to kill over 30,000 women in the United States this year.

title: McGovern and McCloskey Spar in New Hampshire
description: CONCORD, N. H., Feb 5An aggressive competition that could become bitter is developing between the campaigns of Democratic Senator George McGovern and Republican Representative Paul N. McCloskey Jr, for New Hampshire's independent voters.

title: BUCKS TURN BACK ROCKETS, 119112
description: HOUSTON, Feb. 5 (AP)Kareem AbdulJabbar scored 41 points to lead the Milwaukee Bucks to a 119112 National Basketball Association victory over the Houston Rockets tonight. The start of the game was delayed 30 minutes because of a late arrival by the Rockets.

title: A Second Candidate To Attempt to Form Government in Italy
description: ROME, Feb. 5  President Giovanni Leone today asked Giulio Andreotti, the ChristianDemocratic floor leader in the Chamber of Deputies, to make a second and perhaps final attempt to form a centerleft government to replace the one that fell three weeks ago.

title: Dominique PaulCavallier Fiance of Margaret Davis
description: CORNWALL, N. Y., Feb. 5 The engagement of Miss Margaret Ellen Davis to Dominique PaulCavalier of Paris has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. Harrison M. Davis Jr., parents of the future bride. Her fianc is the son of Mrs. Daniel PaulCavallier and the late Mr. PaulCavallier of Nancy, France.

title: COLOR BLINDNESS
description: To THE EDITOR: There was more moral confusion than wisdom in William Shannon's article on child rearing, but I found particularly objectionable the two examples of prejudice in children.

title: The Right to Live Differently
description: The Human Rights Commission of New York City has given hotels and residences which admit only men or women one year to eliminate their singlesex policy. The order raises delicate questions as to basic meaning of discrimination and the definition of human rights.

title: Stamps
description: CAPE Hatteras National Park on the Atlantic coast of North Caro lina has provided the basis for a unique block of four 2cent, United States States stamps that will be issued April 5, at Hatteras, N. C.

title: Bored with diamonds? Consider jade
description: Bored with diamonds? Consider jade

title: PRIMARY DRIVES BEGUN IN ILLINOIS
description: CHICAGO, Feb. 5The Illinois Presidential primary campaign began this weekend as Senators Edmund S. Muskie and George McGovern opened their drives for as many as 100 Democratic convention delegates and for a favorable impression on Mayor. Richard J. Daley.

title: GOMEZ KEEPS TITLE BY STOPPING MORA
description: MARACAY, Venezuela, Feb. 5 (AP)Antonio Gomez of Venezuela retained the World Boxing Association version of the featherweight title tonight by knocking out Mexico's Raul Martinez Mora in the seventh round of a scheduled 15round bout.

title: Bridge
description: IT is a truism that defense is the hardest part of the game, and misjudgments in opening leads and signals are a constant source of pleasure to declarers. A spectacular example from the Open Pair Championship at the TriState Regionals last month demonstrates how a certain triumph can be turned into disaster by thoughtless defense at the first two tricks.

title: The Final Chord of the Quintet
description: A year ago, on Jan. 12, a winter's day much like any other in New York, I rose at 6, prepared my breakfast, glanced at the front page of The Times and sat down at my typewriter. For 15 of the 20 years I had worked on my fivevolume life of Henry JamesI emulate Lawrence Durrell and call it my James QuintetI had sat in this room or the adjoining one and looked out over rooftops: a very Londonish view for Manhattan. But in recent years the highrises at the end of the street had chiseled away great chunks of my sky and diminished the flushed dawns or the gray filtered smoggy mornings of other years.

title: Beach HighRise May Alter The Asbury Park Economy
description: ASBURY PARKNew residential construction here, including a 26story apartment building across the boardwalk from the beach, is seen as marking at least a partial turn from Asbury Park's traditional economy based on seasonal resort activities, city officials say.

title: TABLE MANNERS
description: To THE EDITOR: Equating table manners with civilization is not only laughable, it is sick. If I ever thought that my success as parent depended on having my 4yearold's aplomb rival headwaiter's, I'd quit right now. Mr. Shannon's weekly trips to a restaurant probably cost about the same amount that welfare allows to feed family of four for a week.

title: Letters To the Editor
description: To THE EDITOR: The Larchwood Inn in Wakefield, R. I., and the Wilcox Tavern in Charlestown, R. I., are also very good country inns. Both serve fine meals, but the Larchwood alone has accommodations.

title: Proximity Talks?
description: Middle East peace prospects slightly improved last week with Israel's acceptance of American proposals for close proximity talks on reopening the Suez Canal and with the issuance of a SovietEgyptian communiqu calling for resumption of United Nations efforts promote a wider ArabIsraeli settlement. There was added encouragement from the apparent failure of the kremlin to make specific new arms commitments Piesident Sadat during his twoday visit to Moscow. This should sober Egypt's impatient hawks, at least temporarily, and may inspire greater flexibility in Egyptian diplomacy.

title: Belgian Coalition, Off to Shaky Start, Must Bring Together a Jigsaw Nation
description: BRUSSELS, Jan. 27  As Premier Gaston Eyskens rose in the Chamber of Deputies last Tuesday to read the statement of policy of his new Cabinet, six women deputies walked out, Four woman senators did the same thing in the Senate half an hour later.

title: A Half Million Refugees Counted in West Pakistan
description: RAWALPINDI, Pakistan, Feb. 5At least half a million West Pakistanis have become refugees along the border with India as a result of the December war, according to international relief officials. The number of registered homeless is new evidence of the magnitude of Pakistan's military defeat on the western front in the war.

title: 8.1 Million Needy Children Getting School Lunch Aid
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 (AP) The Agriculture Department says that almost one out of every three school children who participate in Government lunch programs are getting free or reducedprice meals.

title: Criminals At Large
description: There is something to be said for those verite books about police procedure that show Cops As They Are. Cops as human beings; cops who go home to wife and family; cops who worry; cops who grow roses or chase girls or attend law school at night. In Sweden (as I remarked recently in this space), the SjowallWahloo books follow that formula. Dell Shannon's books about Lieut. Luis Mendoza and the L.A.P.D. are of that school. And there is Lesley Egan, who writes about the Glendale fuzz, close to Los Angeles.

title: Alison F. Campbell Plans Nuptials
description: OYSTER BAY, L. I., Feb. 5 Dr. and Mrs. Rolla D. Campbell Jr. have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Alison Fraser Campbell, to Christopher Arnold Weeks, son of Mr. and Mrs. Phillips Noble Weeks of Scituate, Mass. A spring wedding is planned.

title: FISHERMEN'S UNIT CITES U.S. ON FINE
description: The conservation organization that supplied evidence that the Anaconda Copper Company was polluting the Hudson River is to get $25,000 of the $200,000 fine, the largest ever ob tained by such a group.

title: THE WEEK IN FINANCE
description: Suppose the nation's unsatisfactorily elevated unemployment rate remains sticky around the 6 per cent level for several months more. What new initiatives, if any, should Washington take to get it started on a downward track?

title: Poll in New Hampshire Gives Nixon 5to1 Lead
description: BOSTON, Feb. 5 (UPI)President Nixon holds a 5to1 edge over his closest. Republican rival in the March 7. New Hampshire primary, according to a poll in The Boston Sunday Globe.

title: Susan L. Burr Engaged To Michael R. Clifford
description: HUNTINGTON, L. I., Feb. 5Mr. and Mrs. Robert Page Burr announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Susan Long Burr, to Michael Robin Clifford at a champagne reception at their Lloyd Neck home here today. The future bridegroom., an ornithologist, is the son of Maj. Peter F. S. Clifford, British Army, retired, and Mrs. Clifford of FramptononSevern, Gloucestershire, England.

title: $170Million for Amtrak Backed by House Panel
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 (AP)  A $170million bill to keep financially ailing Amtrak in the railroad passenger business has been approved by a House panel.

title: NETS BOW, 126117, IN FAREWELL GAME
description: WEST HEMPSTEAD, L. I, Feb. 5Nobody sang Auld Lang Syne or poured champagne or even shed a tear tonight as the New York Nets said goodby to the Island Garden, their home court for 107 games over the last 2 Years.

title: JOHN DE F. STULL
description: LEONIA, N.J., Feb. 5John De Forest Stull, an artist who was chairman of the art department of Leonia High School, died Jan. 27 at Beth Israel Hospital, Newark. He was 61 years old.

title: Mobile Carries Religion
description: DUBLIN (AP)The Rev. Robert Dunlop, a Baptist preacher, has a 40seat churchmobile complete with Gothic coachwork, a pulpit and a foldaway spire for serving the remote parts of his parish.

title: Shorter Reviews
description: Another jaundiced look at the med game by a youngturk psychiatrist. The picture is familiar, although Dr. Kunnes does add a psychiatric dimension.

title: India Will Investigate Pill For Birth Control Program
description: NEW DELHI, Feb. 5 (UPI)The Indian Government has appointed a committee to decide whether the birth control pill is safe before recommending its use for a mass population control program.

title: Dodgers Sign Two
description: LOS ANGELES, Feb. 5 (UPI) Chris Cannizzaro, a catcher, Larry Hisle, an outfielder, both acquired last season, signed today with the Los Angeles Dodgers.

title: Oil Truck Overturns, Killing Driver Near Battery Tunnel
description: An oil truck carrying 1,500 gallons of fuel oil overturned on the BrooklynQueens Expressway near the BrooklynBattery Tunnel just after midnight this morning, killing the driver and spilling oil over the highway.

title: NOVOSTI ATTACKS, HSINHUA PARRIES
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Feb. 5The Soviet Uion and China are vying in the Middle East to discredit each other in Arab eyes.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: As a former Legal Services attorney, I was distressed by Alan S. Oser's article Housing in Southeast Bronx Under Continuing Pressure [Jan. 16]. It is reassuring to read that an anonymous judicial official believes housing to be a social problem rather than a legal one. I would be somewhat more reassured, however, if this official and other members of the judicial family had recognized the social dimensions of the housing situation five years ago, before Legal Services offices got Involved in the picture.

title: About Motor Sports
description: The International Motor Sports Association, which sanctions a variety of roadracing competition for sports cars, sports sedans and purestock subcompact cars, has expanded its GT schedule to 11 races for. 1872, The GT class: the club's most popular division, is open to sports sedans of the MustangCamaroJavelin type and to sports cars such as Corvette, Ferrari GTB4 and Porsche 911.

title: The Travel Bookshelf
description: ON ICE AND SNOW AND ROCK. By Gaston Rebuffat (translated from the French by Patrick Evans). 190 pp., with photographs and line drawings., Oxford University Press. $15.

title: CANDIDATES AIDES REPORT ON FUNDS
description: With the New York Democratic Presidential primary still nearly five months away, three Presidential campaign committees have already spent more than $100,000 in the state.

title: Artichoke
description: Rouille means rust, which is the color of a peppery red mayonnaiseRice sauce often used as a condiment with fish soup the south of France. Here it is combined with two familiar, relatively bland foods, artichoke bottoms and poached eggs. The result is an attractive contrast of textures and tastes. This kind of composed dish, though not in Escoffier, illustrates basic principle of classic cookingartful juxtaposition.

title: Jackie Pung to Revisit Scene of Unlucky 6
description: HONOLULU, Feb. 5 When the men's pro golf tour bids aloha here at the conclusion of the Hawaiian open, it will leave the islands most noted woman golfer planning for the future. Jackie Pung has often toured the United States, but next June she hopes to be at the Winged Foot Golf Club in Mamaroneck, N. Y., again for sentimental reasons.

title: New Hampshire TV Station Accused by Aide to Hartke
description: MANCHESTER, N. H., Feb. 5 (AP)  The national campaign manager for Senator Vance Hartke charged today that television station had refused to give the Indiana Democrat air time to debate other candidates in the New Hampshire Presidential primary.

title: Letters To the Editor
description: I agree with many of Barry Commoner's concerns, as reported in Michael Crichton's review of Commoner's book, The Closing Circle: Nature, Man and Technology. But Commoner's cavalier dismissal of the role of population growth in environmental deterioration should not go unchallenged.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: The decision by Massachusetts to abolish institutions for Juvenile offenders during the next two years is a courageous step in the right direction, The substitution of a range of programs designed to rehabilitate and integrate the Juvenile into the community instead of jailing him is a rational approach to dealing with young offenders.

title: The Irish Question1843, etc.
description: I want to see a public man come forward and say what the Irish question is. One says it is a physical question; another, a spiritual. Now it is the absence of the aristocracy, then the absence of railroads. It is the Pope one day; potatoes the next.

title: In the Mailbox:
description: To the Editor: As a skier and winter sports enthusiast, I was very interested in Arthur Daley's Jan. 23 column on the Winter Olympics.

title: 9 Taiwanese Ski Into Olympics
description: TAIPEI, Taiwan On this subtropical island, where most people have never even seen snow, a small but dedicated band of young sportsmen has developed a passion for skiing in the last few years.

title: In the Mailbox:
description: To the Editor: Arthur Daley's Jan. 23 column on the Winter Olympics reaches the right conclusion for the wrong reason. Yes, the Olympic Winter Games should be abolished; but not because many of the skiers, hockey players and skaters are paid professionals. If this were the reason, then many of the Summer Olympic events should be terminated, too.

title: Naval Surgeon Plans to Marry Cornelia Clark
description: PRINCETON, N. J., Feb.5 Mr. and Mrs. J. Dudley Clark Jr. of Princeton and Harbour Island, the Bahamas, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Cornelia Thayer Clark, to Surgeon Lieut. Comdr. Michael P. W. H. Paine, Royal Navy, son of Comdr. Geoffrey W. W. H. Paine, Royal Navy retired, and Mrs. Paine, of Brandean, Hampshire, England.

title: There in body and spirit, but not in imagination
description: All of us have dark stirrings of doubt and fear whenever the Donner Party is mentioned. In such extremis what would we do? Snowtrapped and starving in the Sierras with no hope of relief, would we fall to devouring each other? Our fathers? Our children? Our lovers? How close to the animal are we? How far from the desperate beast? In the purely physical realm of survival, what justifies what?

title: Saigon to Shift 24,000 In Delta Security Drive
description: TANHOA, South Vietnam  This isolated hamlet is one of the last two in the Mekong delta where, according to official security ratings, the Vietcong govern and the South Vietnamese Government has no control General Nghi and has worked with him since the operation began on Jan. 7. He does not like the idea of shifting the peasants.

title: LETTERS
description: It's a fascinating and frightening spectacle we observe each time the freedom to abuse is paraded before us with all the dignity and sanctity of the Bill: of Rights, as Chester Posey sought to do in his article Political Campaigning and TV (Jan. 23).

title: Dance: Don Redlich Presents Works
description: The Don Redlich Dance Company opened a miniseason at the Riverside Church on Friday night, to run through tomorrow. Mr. Redlich is a most individual dancer and he specializes choreographically in anxieties fringed by the wilder shores of neuroses.

title: Vacant Lots Reflect Dispute Barring Camden Urban Renewal
description: CAMDEN  When Mayor Joseph M. Nardi Jr. looks out a window of his compact office on the 17th floor of City Hall, he sees block on block of vacant land to the north, where houses and retail shops were torn down about three years ago to make way for urban renewal projects.

title: SOVIET HOBBLED BY UNUSUAL COLD
description: MOSCOW, Feb. 5Some of the coldest weather recalled in the southern reaches of the Soviet Union is threatening to cause setbacks in both agri culture and industry.

title: Orthopedic Surgeons Elect
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 (UPI) Dr. Philip D. Wilson Jr. of New York City, was named president on Thursday of the 5,500member American Academy of Orthopedic Surgeons at the group's annual meeting in Washington. He is a clinical professor of orthopedic surgery et Cornell University Medical College.

title: Parkway Widening to Ease Drives to Shore
description: WOODBRIDGE  A wintertime.; constructive job now being pushed should assure motorists on the Garden State Parkway of easier trips to and from the Jersey shore this summer.

title: Japanese Urge Governors From U.S. to Attend Parley
description: TOKYO, Feb 5 (AP)  The National Governors Association of Japan has written the United States Governors Conference expressing hope that at least 10 American governors will attend the 11th JapanUnited States Gubernatorial Conference. The meeting is tentatively scheduled lo open here April. 7.

title: City's Loss of U.S. Welfare Aid Put at More Than $100Million
description: City investigators said yesterday that New York City was losing more than $100million per year in Federal funds because the state had failed to file a welfare plan on social services.

title: Kahn's Comeback: Excerpts From The Diary of an Aging Snow Bunny
description: EAND I  E is my wife  decided to take the boys skiing not long ago. They had never tried it before, and neither had she. I of course gave the the peculiar sport a decade ago  unequivocally, I thought then, and forever. But why should deprive the family of what is widely regarded as a treat merely because regard it as a threat? Not, in truth, that I ever gave up much. Over my skiing years I had accumulated quite an assortment of boots, skis, goggles, mittens and the other costly appurtenances of the pastime, Nit I had never acquired any complementary skills, and all I had to show for my diligence was the scar from the operation for my broken leg. I used to pretend to ski a lot, but I never really did, or could; the bleak truth was that insofar as performance was concerned I had never got much beyond being rank beginner, or, as they called us in the old days, a snow bunny.

title: War Objector Wins Plea
description: BOSTON, Feb. 5 (AP)  The U.S. Court of Appeals has ordered Robert J. Armstrong Jr., 24 years old of Paramus, N.J., discharged from the Army as a conscientious objector. The court's 2to1 decision Tuesday reversed a lower court ruling.

title: Many Greeks View U.S. As Barrier to Democracy
description: ATHENS, Jan. 29  After nearly five years of authoritarian rule by the junta, many Greeks rank the United States alongside Premier George Papadopoulos as a principal barrier to the restoration of democracy.

title: The World
description: LONDON  Now for our Irish wars, says King Richard II, full of confident vigor in Act II of Shakespeare's play. He returns from Ireland in the next act a broken man, ready, to say:

title: Judith Barrett Bride of George Egbert Jr.
description: Miss Judith Ellen Barrett was married here yesterday afternoon to George Pennington Egbert Jr., a senior vice president of the First National City Bank. Msgr. James W. Asip performed the ceremony in the Lady Chapel of St. Patrick's Cathedral.

title: Chess
description: THE Columbia University chess team, perennially and traditionally a victor at the royal game, won the 1971 PanAmerican Intercollegiate Tournament at Toronto, Canada, with 7 match points, as against 6 for Western Ontario. There was a threeway tie for third, fourth and fifth with 6 points for M.I.T. (A), C.C.N.Y. (A), and Chicago (A).

title: Profit at Banks
description: The nation's banks last year apparently produced the skimpiest profit gain in a decade and the nearterm outlook now is only for a modest improvement at most institutions, securities analysts declare.

title: Intrigue, Texas Size
description: GALVESTON, Tex.  With its huge oak trees draped in Spanish moss and its silent rows of empty, longdefunct cotton warehouses, this small seaside city has a sleepy look. Indeed, its biggest industry would appear to be the hot dog stands proliferating along its beach.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: The delicate question of recognition of Bangladesh is now before the governments of the free world.

title: New & Novel
description: Top Topor's novel pinpoints a menace in Riverside Park. Not spacedout assassins, or rapists in the rest rooms, or Tat packs. The present menace is an F.B.I. agent who happens also to be a sex maniac. O.K.?

title: Paul Kammerer Jr. Weds Sheila Wilde
description: Miss Sheila Edith Margot Wilde, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur D. Wilde, was married yesterday morning to Paul T. Kammerer Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Kammerer. Both families are of Bayside, Queens where the ceremony was performed in All Saints Episcopal Church. The Rev. James D. Webster, rector of the church, and the Rev. Michael J. Connelly, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony.

title: SOVIET DISOWNS AN EROTIC NOVEL
description: MOSCOW, Feb. 5A Soviet literary weekly has suggested that a pornographic book widely advertised in the United States as the first modern erotic novel from the Soviet underground might be a West German forgery.

title: Linz Faces Water Shortage
description: LINZ, Austria, Feb. 5 (Reuters)  Linz's reservoirs are almost empty due to an abnormally dry winter. Residents have been warned against waste.

title: WAR TOLL MASKED, KENNEDY ASSERTS
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 (AP) Senator Edward M. Kennedy said today that the United States and Cambodia had joined in a conspiracy of silence about an increasing toll of civilians and refugees in Cambodia.

title: Cable Man
description: The grandfather of the K. D. D. Maru sat back in his easy chair in, his office on the 26th floor at 32 Avenue of the Americas. He took a long puff on a Cuban cigar sent to him by his friends in the Philippines telephone system, blew out a cloud of smoke, watched it drift around and said:

title: Amateur Hophey TeamYearns for Morris Rink
description: SOUTH ORANGE, N. J.Are amateur hockey players different from you and me?

title: The Nation
description: WASHINGTONDr. Curtis W. Tarr, the Selective. Service director, said at the beginning of last week's draft lottery that he had decided to hold the drawing a full 11 months before any of the 19yearolds would be eligible for the draft so that young men will be able to make plans as soon as possible,

title: Cinderella Who?
description: THIS seems to be the year of Elizabeth I in show business. A short while ago at Lincoln Center, the Virgin Queen was doing her thing at the Vivian Beaumont in Mary Stuart and at the State Theater she'll soon be doing it with music in Roberto Devereux and Maria Stuarda. Currently, she is reigning on Broadway in Viva! Vivat Regina! and at Radio City Music Hall in Mary, Queen of Scots. Next Sunday, she will ascend the TV throne in Elizabeth R, a series to last six weeks. Not to mention the fact that playwright Paul Foster will install Elizabeth I Off Broadway In March, Net season this phenomenon will occur againonly this time with the famous fairy tale character, Cinderella. Several important Broadway figures are going to be presenting this classic tale on the stage:

title: STREET INFLUENCES
description: To THE EDITOR: I applaud William V. Shannon's article. The fact that he and his wife have succeeded in banishing TV from their home is no small achievement. In our own case my wife and I have managed over the years to keep the boob tube blacked out during dinner, and we do not permit our children to view it while doing homework, or while engaged in other indoor activities.

title: Grant for Jericho Schools
description: JERICHO, L. I.,  The Jericho public schools have been awarded a grant of $3,600 from the National Science Foundation for a cooperative school  college science program. The purpose of the grant, the project director, Joseph S. Verdone, explained, is to strengthen scientific research and understanding by teacher training.

title: Mrs. Lytell Engaged
description: REMSENBURG, L. T., Feb. 5The engagement of Mrs. Chary Ann Halsey Lytell, widow of Gerald H. Lytell, to James P. Griffin has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. Lloyd 0. Davis, parents of the future bride. Her fianc is the son of Mr. and Mrs. James L. Griffin of East Patchogue. An August wedding is planned.

title: MURPHY, ON 205, KEEPS SHOT LEAD
description: HONOLULU, Feb. 5Bob Murphy says he likes to play golf in the wind. Today he had a chance to do so, scored a 70 and retained the lead by a stroke in the $200,000 Hawaiian open with a 54hole total of 205.

title: Miss Mintz Betrothed
description: WHITE PLAINS, Feb. 5 Mr. and Mrs. Sidney Mintz have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Cherie Ann Mintz, to Bruce Bramley, son of Mrs. Elias J. Bramley of Poughkeepsie and the late Mr. Bramley. The future bride, a graduate of St. Margaret's School in Waterbury, Conn., attends Emerson College in Boston, Mr. Bramley is an alumnus of Union College.

title: Prep Schools Reevaluating Roles in Today's Education
description: MONTCLAIRRising costs, changing urban patterns and increasing demands for coeducational training are forcing independent preparatory schools in the state into a reevaluation of their roles as educational institutions.

title: Robins and Redwings
description: It is almost instinctive to think of migrant robins and redwing blackbirds in February. If the sun is warm and friendly the impulse is to say, Maybe tomorrow. If the wind is blowing a gale laden with snow the thought This can't last. Maybe next week. But down in our hearts we know the migrants won't be back much if any before the vernal equinox, which is still six weeks away.

title: The Nation
description: Who's running the city?

title: Dance
description: LAST weekend two modern  dance companies ended their twoweek season at the Brooklyn Academy of Music and the American Ballet Theater ended its season at the City Center. Following these coinpanies were the Merce Cunningham troupe in Brooklyn and the always familiar and always welcome Ballet Folklorico of Mexico.

title: Miss Amy Sandler To Marry June 11
description: SOUTH ORANGE, N. J., Feb. 5Miss Amy Sandler, who expects to be graduated in June from Sarah Lawrence College, and Charles Levin, a junior at the University of Rochester, plan to be married June 11.

title: The Last Word
description: In his review last week of Frances Stevenson's Lloyd George: A Diary, Peter Stansky stated that David Lloyd George and Winston Churchill are the two greatest British politicians of the 20th century. It happens that the official biography of Churchill has recently reached its massive third volume in which Martin Gilbert covers The Challenge of War, 19141916 (Houghton Mifflin), the years in which the two giants reached for the highest political power they both felt was their due. In their very different ways, the one revealingly informal, the other masterfully formal, these books illuminate an issue sharply focused by first the Pentagon Papers and more recently the socalled Anderson Papers.

title: Movie Mailbag
description: To THE EDITOR: It is as if the critics had to save the season with sensational accolades for a film which speaks with a kind of monolithic ennui to the more violent side of human fantasy. Yes, fantasies lead to symbolic interpretationthe perfect topic for the sophisticated cocktail partybut as Clayton Riley so lucidly argues, violent fantasy and the apocalypse of Ludivico are merely the kind of cheap catering and delivery service which the New Movie (and A Clockwork Orange in particular) thrive upon.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: New Yorkers continued to buffer themselves against the cold and wind yesterday as 25mileanhour gusts combined with temperatures in the low 20's to make it one of the coldest days of the winter.

title: Movie Mailbag
description: To THE EDITOR: Clayton Riley brilliantly isolated the basic weakness of A Clockwork Orange its total lack of profundity. At best, the film was the dubious triumph of technique over thought; at worst, it was an encounter session for host of critics who discovered they were not the only ones who were confused about morality.

title: American Gets U.N. Post
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Feb. 5 (Reuters)The United Nations Relief and Works Agency for Palestine Refugees has announced the appointment of C. William Kontos, an American, as its deputy commissioner general. Mr. Kontos, 50 years old, has served with the United States Agency for International Development.

title: Mary Connorton to Wed in March
description: Dr. and Mrs. John V. Connorton of New York have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Mary Grace Connorton, to Daniel P. FitzGerald, son of Mr. and Mrs. W. Francis FitzGerald of White Plains.

title: Princeton Routs Harvard
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Feb. 5 Princeton's junior guards, Brian Taylor and Ted Manakas, triggered a firsthalf spree that resulted in a 4222 lead as the Tigers posted a 9166 victory over Harvard tonight.

title: SHERWIN STARS IN LAST MINUTE
