description: To THE EDITOR: VINCENT CANBY admirably points out the satirical implications of Kubrick's A Clockwork Orange. But Clayton Riley persists in analyzing fragments of the film rather than looking at it as an organic whole.

title: DUSTING OFF OLD VALUES
description: To THE EDITOR: At long last a different and refreshing article on the older generation's relationship to its offspring. William V. Shannon is to be commended.

title: 27 Held in Gambling Raids; $10Million Ring Reported
description: Twentyseven persons were arrested on gambling charges yesterday as more than 100 state and local policemen in the city and Westchester and Rockland counties moved against what was described as a $10millionayear gambling operation.

title: L. I. Weighs Impact Of Report on Schools
description: Just as there is a wide disparity in the wealth of school districts on Long Island, there is a diversity of feeling about the recommendations made last week by the Fleischmann Commission to revamp school finance in New York State.

title: Mrs. Galen Has Daughter
description: A daughter was horn Jan. 13 to Dr, and Mrs. Robert Galen of New York in the Harkness Pavilion. Mrs. Galen is the former Amy Feinberg of Newton, Mass.

title: Prayers and Call for British Boycott Mark Irish Protests Here
description: Silent prayers, angry demonstrations and a call for a nationwide boycott of British goods and services marked a day of petition and protest in New York yesterday over the situation in strifetorn Northern Ireland.

title: Carol Vayo Is Bride Of H. Cameron Barr 3d
description: OLD GREENWICH, Conn., Feb. 5  Miss Carol Louise Vayo, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Reginald Lawrence Vayo of Greenwich, was married here this afternoon to H. Cameron Barr 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Barr Jr. of Riverside. The Rev. Merton E. Libby performed the ceremony in the First Congregational Church.

title: Lawyer Weds Miss Henning
description: WASHINGTON TOWNSHIP, N. J., Feb. 5Miss Martha Jean Henning and John Van Voorhies Cockcroft Jr. were married here this afternoon in the Roman Catholic Church of Our Lady of Good Counsel. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Thomas F. Norton, a Roman Catholic priest, and the Rev. Thomas M. Foster, an Episcopal priest.

title: Coeds of Notre Dame Top Cheerleading Poll
description: OVERLAND PARK, Kan. (UPI)Notre Dame's coed cheerleaders have been named America's top collegiate cheerleading squad by the International Cheerleading Foundation, Inc.

title: LETTERS
description: Paul Heffernan in an article, The School Tax Issue (Jan. 16), needs to be helped out of his confusion about the United States Constitution. One part of it says that no state shall impair the obligation of contracts. Another says that no state shall deny any of its citizens the equal protection of the laws.

title: Article 3  No Title
description: CHICAGO, Feb. 5 (AP)The Chicago Bulls walloped the Buffalo Braves, 13096, tonight.

title: Byron W. Cartozian To Wed Miss Quinn
description: PLANDOME MANOR, LI., Feb. 5Mr. and Mrs. James Robert Quinn have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Janet Anne Quinn, to Byron Wallace Cartozian. He is a son of Mrs. Dorothy Cartozian of White Plains and W. Wallace. Cartozian of Seattle. The wedding will take place May 13.

title: Son for the Bambergers
description: BELLMORE, L. I., Feb. 5A son was born Jan. 21 to Mr. and Mrs. Jay. Bamberger in the MidIsland Hospital in Bethpage. Mrs. Bamberger is the former Miss Barbara Blumenthal, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Irving J. Blumenthal of Wantagh. The child has been named Eric Lawrence. His father is a salesman with the Ben Shapiro Shoe Company, Inc., of Brooklyn.

title: Priest's Marijuana Charge
description: LOS ANGELES, Feb. 5 (Reuters)An activist Roman Catholic priest, the Rev. Louis Demescio Jaramillo, was ordered this week to stand trial Feb. 17 on charges of possessing marijuana. Father Jaramillo, 40 years old, was charged with drug possession after a policeman testified that marijuana cigarettes were thrown from a car in which he was a passenger when it was stopped in Los Angeles on Jan. 5.

title: Coalition Says A.E.C. Employes Are Gagged at Safety Hearings
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 5An environmental coalition charged today that officials of the Atomic Energy Commission had been tampering with witnesses testifying at a public hearing aimed at drawing up new safety standards for nuclear power plants.

title: LETTERS
description: I refer to the article The Night People of Wall Street (Jan. 30).

title: Petain Found the de Gaulle of 1920's to Be a Proud and Touchy Ghostwriter
description: PARIS, Feb. 5  Specialists have long believed that Marshal Henri Philippe Main once had a staff writer named Charles de Gaulle and that they had a falling out. Now the deGaulle family has released their full literary correspondence, for publication in a weekly magazine of Gaulliana.

title: Women's Caucus Has New Rallying Cry: Make Policy, Not Coffee
description: Make policy, not coffee! is the slogan these days among members of the new Women's Political Caucus.

title: Appeals Court Review Asked In TV Licensing Dispute
description: BOSTON, Feb. 5 (AP) WHDHTV filed a petition in the United States Court of Appeals for the First Circuit yesterday seeking a review of a Federal Communications Commission order that granted Boston Broadcasters, Inc., a license to use Channel 5.

title: T.V.A. to Cool Water To Help Aquatic Life
description: KNOXVILLE, Tenn., Feb. 5 (AP)The Tennessee Valley Authority has announced plans to install water cooling towers at its Browns Ferry nuclear power plant to help protect aquatic life in the Tennessee River.

title: Author to Publisher
description: As one of the innumerable authors in New York who write on the lee side of a double bed in a crowded bedroom, I have a suggestion that might give competitive edge to the company that took it up.

title: Movie Mailbag
description: To THE EDITOR: Clayton Riley says the speeded up sexual encounter between Alex and the two girls is amateurish and pointless. In point of fact, this, scene is a perfect union of literary content and cinematic style. Clearly, there is no real emotion involved in this act of sex, and this elemental sense of detachment is perfectly represented by Kubrick's visual approach to the scene.

title: State's Medical School Program Moving Ahead With New Building
description: NEWARK  After years of delay, the faculty and students of the New Jersey College of Medicine here have high hopes that their future home will rise at last outside the windows of their temporary quarters in the riotscarred Central Ward.

title: Brisker Tallies 52
description: GREENSBORO, N. C., Feb. 5 (AP)John Brisker scored 52 points and George Thompson added 39 tonight to lead the Pittsburgh Condors to a 136129 victory over the Carolina Cougars.

title: PURDUE DEFEATS MICHIGAN, 8474
description: LAFAYETTE, Ind., Feb. 5 (UPI) Bob Ford and William Franklin sparked a secondhalf Purdue surge as the Boilermakers beat Michigan, 8474, today, to stay in the thick of the Big Ten basketball race.

title: A 9cent radio and guerrilla architecture
description: This provocative book by a young M.I.T. professor of architecture describes the reasons for his metamorphosis from liberal cityplanning student to advocacy planner to radical proponent of an activist architecture of liberation. It is also inevitably a scathing review of corporate and bureaucratic citymakers; and the professionals who are in uneasy alliance with the power institutions of American capitalism.

title: The Nation
description: The Nation

title: Education
description: Performance contracting, as a means of educational reform, had all the qualities normally admired by the Nixon Administration. Under the concept, private industryproducers of teaching materials and electronic or computerized instruction machinerywould go into the schools and, in return for a fee, attempt to raise the level of student achievement, particularly among the disadvantaged. If a contracting company failed to produce the level agreed upon with a local school board, it would refund part of the fee.

title: Bulldozers Raze an Era
description: This business of saving landmarks, even famous ones, John Hayes noted sadly, why is it that only when the bulldozers start going up the front stoop of a building someone realizes it's historical?

title: Music
description: HERBERT KUPFERBERG, in the December issue of the Nieman Reports, gives some very good reasons why music reviews in The New York Times appear a day late. Then he goes on to bemoan the delay, wondering if music criticism has become secondclass news.

title: Mrs. Whitman
description: PITTSBURGHMarina von Neumann Whitman, a 36yearold, auburnhaired economist who has suddenly burst into the national spotlight as one of the highest  ranking woman appointees of the Nixon Administration, describes herself as an economic problem solver rather than an intellectual bomb tosser.

title: WALLACE LOSES BID FOR PRIMARY
description: MONTGOMERY, Ala., Feb. 5 Gov. George C. Wallace has failed in an attempt to pass legislation intended to give him control of the Alabama delegation to the Democratic National Convention this summer.

title: The Secrecy Dilemma
description: IT says in the 29th chapter of Deuteronomy, The secret things belong unto the Lord our God.

title: Basketball Hall of Fame Elects Its First Black: Douglas of Rens
description: Six men, including the first black, have been elected to the Naismith Basketball Hall of Fame on the campus of Springfield College in Massachusetts. They were Bob Douglas, Eddie Gottlieb, Cliff Wells, Ed Diddle, Paul Endacott and Max (Marty) Friedman.

title: Street Plan
description: A blueprint for change in Wall Street has now been laid out by the Securities and Exchange Commission and, if the Federal agency has its way, the securities industry is going to be a very different place to do business.

title: Enlightened torture and Reagan said backwards
description: First there was the shootout at San Quentin, then the shootin at Attica, and for a time the public showed some interest in prisons. But already one senses the concern drifting off to other, more pressing issues: the economy, the elections, last month's Super Bowl.

title: Stolen Apples
description: Yevgeny Yevtushenko, that worldweary globetrotter, is shuttling once again between the cities of Yes and No. (New York and Moscow?) Much as one might be tempted to dismiss him as a stalking horse for the Soviet Government, Yevtushenko is not the type of troubadour who is easy to pin down. Indeed, this new collection of verse raises far more questions than it answers about Russia's most famous licensed rebel.

title: Colonel Qadhafi Libya's Mystical Revolutionary So much oil money, and so little to spend it on
description: TRIPOLI, Libya. O N a humid North African night last summer a tall young man in Arab robes, his face halfhidden behind a swath of cloth, presented himself at Tripoli's teeming Central Hospital in a state of great vexation and de manded to see a doctor. When at last the doctor came, the young Arab cried: Oh, Doctor, come with me at once to my house! My father very ill!

title: 91 HURT IN LONDON IN ULSTER PROTEST
description: LONDON, Feb. 5The police charged a crowd of demonstrators protesting British policy in Northern Ireland here tonight. Authorities said that 91 people were injured, more policemen than civilians, and that 20 had been taken to hospitals.

title: SCHOOLS FEAR END OF STATE DRUG AID
description: A drugeducation specialist at Alfred E. Smith High School in the Bronx recently received what he regarded as the ultimate reward from some students: wrappedup packages of their worksdrug paraphernaliatogether with assurances they would never go back to using drugs.

title: GALLUP FINDS RISE IN MARIJUANA USE
description: The percentage of United States college students who have used marijuana continues to climb, with 51 per cent saying they have used the drug at least once, according to the Gallup Poll.

title: Lynn Dixon Is Bride of R. F. Johnston
description: In St. Thomas Episcopal Church here yesterday afternoon, Mis Lynn West Dixon, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Augustus McCord Dixon of Reno, Nev., was married to Robert Fowler Johnston, son of Brig. Gen. William. Saunderson Johnston, U.S.A.F., retired, and Mrs. Johnston of Bay Head, N.J. The Rev. Dr. Frederick Morris performed the ceremony.

title: IrishUlster Border Area Near Newry Is a NoMan'sLand Under Heavy Guard by the British Army's Troops
description: DUNDALK, Ireland, Feb. 5A noman'sland of fear stretches from here to the town of Newry in Northern Ireland, where a mass civil rights demonstration is planned for tomorrow. The specter of Londonderry and the 13 who were killed last Sunday looms large, even on this side of the border.

title: JO N S. WILSON'S MUSIC
description: MARTINSVILLE  Once each year this little community in the Watchung Mountains becomes a magnet for jazz musicians and jazz fans  primarily those who were friends and admirers of the late Pee Wee Russell, the clarinetist.

title: HIGHLIGHTS OF THE WEEK
description: GENERAL MOTORS reported earnings of $542million, or $1.88 a share, in the fourth quarter, in contrast to a yearearlier loss of $135million American Telephone and Telegraph showed a profit of $3.99 a share In 1971, the same as in 1970.

title: Photography
description: THE American Society of Magazine Photographers (ASMP) 60 East 42d Street, New York, N. Y. 10017, a professional society of photographers engaged in photojournalism, motion pictures and similar communications media, is now offering membership to students (18 years or older) in visual communications. There is a $25 annual fee which entitles the studentmember to a subscription to Infinity magazine; the monthly ASMP bulletin; the membership directory which contains a list of members, as well as a definition of rights, and a number of codes governing fair practices in the industry; notification of meetings and other activities; and an opportunity for the cultivation of friendship  among all types and levels of camera workers.

title: Light Years
description: Above us the village, petrified in the white light, began to lose its balance. It leaned over toward the valley, threatening to roll down at any minute. I could see it from my bed by the window. Its ramparts, crushed by the weight of the houses, seemed to be splitting apart, and every morning, as I woke, it seemed to me that these splits were a little wider. This is an early passage from a remarkable account of his childhood and adolescence by a painterCyrus, he calls himself in the novelwho writes from a vantage point of sexual delight and singular harmony. He belongs to no fraternity. His humor, his vision, and his heritagehe's the son of a Russian mother and a magician father from Persia  these must be unique.

title: Heart Disease Termed Cause of Most Deaths
description: UNIONMore than half of the deaths in New Jersey during 1970 were caused by about 20 different heart diseases, according to Dr. Sidney Atteit, president of the American Heart Association in New Jersey.

title: DR. SAMUEL KULKIN
description: Dr. Samuel Kulkin, an ear, nose and throat surgeon, died of a cerebral hemorrhage at his home, 1095 Park Avenue, yesterday. He was 80 years old and had retired in 1950.

title: Pity the Poor Lincoln Memorial: It Has A Very Bad Case of the Blahs
description: WASHINGTON The capital's number one tourist attraction, the Lincoln Memorial, is decomposing so rapidly that, in the words of one alarmed authority, it is like a giant AlkaSeltzer tabletyou can almost hear it fizz when it rains.

title: Letters:
description: TO THE EDITOR: We returned recently from an unescorted motor trip in Central America and can only conclude that the Guatemala described in William Allen's humorous but unflattering account (Travel section, Jan. 16) bears no resemblance to the country. To take issue with specific points: (1) it is well known that Central American borders close for lunch; (2) visas or tourist cards are easily obtained in large cities (such as Mexico City); (3) the tales of guerrillas are mostly hearsay. Mr. Allen did not discuss the many wonders of Guatemala. For example, though the lost Mayan cities of Tikal and Uaxactun are somewhat out of the way, the smaller but dramatic ruins of Zacaleu and Quirigua lie virtually on the main road. Incidentally, to us, the people were infectiously friendly.

title: PAKISTAN URGES HELP FOR BIHARIS
description: RAWALPINDI, Pakistan, Feb. 5The Pakistani Government appealed to other nations tonight to help stop what it called atrocities being committed by Bengalis against the Bihari minority in East Pakistan, now Bangladesh. It said that nations that had prematurely recognized the Bangladesh Government had a special responsibility to ensure the protection of the nonBengali population.

title: An Appraisal
description: A good claim can be made that of all the poets of the 20th century writing in English, Marianne Moore was the most original and singular. She was the product of no school. Critics sought to find her beginnings in Poe, in Henry James, in a variety of Frenchmen. But their very lack of agreement suggests her uniqueness. She was accused of eccentricity when she was only herself. Originality, she wrote, is a byproduct of sincerity. Her style developed early and showed a firm consistency throughout. It was a style that had the rhythm and pacing of prose, but it was too tight, too condensed for prose. Her poetic mode was her natural mode with words. It was often pointed out that her criticism of poetry turned into poetry itself.

title: One Pocket 3Length Victor In Feature at Fair Grounds
description: NEW ORLEANS, Feb. 5 (AP) One Pocket won the $10,000added Thelma stakes for 3yearold fillies at the Fair Grounds by three lengths today, turning the six furlongs in 1:11 15 and returning $9 straight.

title: Students Dispersed in Tunis
description: TUNIS, Feb. 5Riot policemen using tear gas and clubs entered the Tunis University campus today and dispersed a meeting of 7,000 striking students. It was the first time since the strike started Monday that force was used against students who have been in a state of unrest since the beginning of the school year last October.

title: Antarctic Sanctuary No Longer?
description: Environmental and wildlife organizations are suspicious that a proposed Convention for the Conservation of Seals, now being worked out by the Antarctic Treaty bountries at a meeting in England, is in reality nothing more than a green light for the slaughter of those persecuted creatures.

title: Malcolm Is Sure City Will Meet Deadline Set for Rikers Reforms
description: Correction Commissioner Benjamin J. Malcolm said yesterday that he was confident the city would meet the sixmonth timetable that the State Commission of Correction had set for it to improve conditions at the Correctional Institution for Men on Bikers Island.

title: Wheels Up for Mosinee (Wis.) With Senator Muskie & Co.
description: M IAMITwo bellmen were waiting for Peter Kyros here at the hotel, the SheratonFour Ambassadors. How many bags? says one of them when. Kyros, 23 years old, just out of Yale and carrying thousands of dollars in cash because almost nobody gives him credit, introduces himself. Kyros points to a truck and answers, Two hundred and twenty.

title: The World
description: The United States delegation is encouraged by the progress, said Gerard C. Smith, the chief American delegate, as the United States and Russia concluded the sixth round of strategic arms limitation talks (SALT) in Vienna last Friday. There were signs of an agreement of some sort in the foreseeable future, possibly before President Nixon goes to Moscow in May.

title: The Nation
description: The first, gentle stirrings of what could be the start of a fiscal revolution were heard In Washington last week., But they were buried in such welter of budgetary statistics and electionyear politics that they were difficult to discern.

title: REVERSAL SOUGHT IN PHONE COSTS
description: ALBANY, Feb. 5Lawmakers across the state, protesting the recent $160.6million rate increase granted the New York Telephone Company by the State Public Service Commission, are taking action to have the increase overturned.

title: Photography
description: WRESTLING does not seem too promising a subject for serious photography: all those overstuffed men in comicbook capes and masks flying through the air at each other or rolling around on the mat in simulated pain. Not even wrestling in Houston, which is the subject of Geoff Winningham's new book, Friday Night in the Coliseum. Much more promising is life in prison. And if your prison book hits the market just as a rash of bloody and fatal prison riots break out, as Danny Lyon's recent Conversations with the Dead did, you can pride yourself on a scoop.

title: Early U.S. Payment Of U.N. Dues Asked To End Fiscal Crisis
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Feb. 5A senior United States diplomat at the United Nations has told a Congressional subcommittee that the constant problems of the world organization in coping with daytoday financing could be ended if the United States paid its assessments on time or in advance.

title: Conversions
description: In his new book, George P. Elliott argues that the socalled Enlightenment was a regrettable turning point in human affairs. It brought in Modernism, which substituted science for religion, technology for magic, democracy for monarchy, change for tradition, and progress for salvation. For Elliott the medieval society of Byzantium, memorably evoked by Yeats, forms a perfect contrast:

title: Participant Feels U.N. Session In Africa Stirred Some Interest
description: ADDIS ABABA Ethiopia, Feb. 5  Weary delegates streamed out of this mountainous capital city today on their way home from the special meeting of the United Nations Security Council.

title: Art
description: THE general opinion, which I share, is that this year's Whitney Annual, which is the 40th, isn't half bad or at least, being no more than half bad, is pretty good, considering. At other Whitney Annuals of recent years one has hardly known whether to despair of American art, if the show represents what is going on, or to despair of the Whitney, if it can do no better in summarizing something that can't possibly be as hopeless as the annuals have made it look. But the annuals are much too easy to belabor, and to belabor them may even be in part a critics copout or his failure to recognize that to put together a firstrate survey of the scene of the moment is virtually impossible.

title: Lindsay Is Touched by a Meeting With P. O. W. 's Wives in Florida
description: FORT WALTON, Fla., Feb. 5 In probably the most poignant event of his Presidential campaign so far, Mayor Lindsay met here today with a dozen wives of American servicemen who are either prisoners of war or missing in action.

title: 72 Giant Prognosis: Same as 71
description: Having drafted 18 players and acquired four others in trades, the New York Giants have embarked on a youth movement. More trades are possible, but they are not likely to be earthshaking, since the two most marketable items, Fran Tarkenton and Fred Dryer, are gone.

title: L. I. Coliseum: Dress Rehearsal
description: The Nassau Coliseum, the stately $28million arena that will elevate Long Island into major league sports and stadium events, had its first dry run yesterday in preparation for its opening game next Friday.

title: Art
description: IT was to be expected that the 90th birthday of Pablo Picasso, which occurred on Oct. 25, would bring forth the ritual quota of illconceived exhibitions and fanmagazine personality pieces, and we were certainly not disappointed in this respect. The Christmas season, too, brought Its annual glut of expensive Picasso picture books, which, to judge from all appearances, the public is still prepared to consume with the nonchalance of a python swallowing rabbits. It has been left to the Museum of Modern Art, however, to mark this anniversary with a serious tribute to the artist's accomplishments rather than his public personality or the sundry forms of marketing that are carried out in his name.

title: Farm to Market: How Price of a Hog Rises
description: BLACK EARTH, Wis., Feb. 5Don Ripp leaned over the rail of his hog pen and gazed happily at one of the grunting, shuffling, 200pound porkers that was soon to be transformed into a variety of bacon, ham and sausage products.

title: The French ConnectionIn Real Life
description: MARSEILLES. MIMET is a tiny Provengal village of narrow alleyways and old buildings where blackshawled women doze in the sun and elderly men play ptanque under the plane trees ringing its square. Just beyond the village, on the road of Our Lady of the Angels, clinging to a hillside of scrub pine and wild olives, is a tacky, creamcolored villa with orange shutters. It is like thousands of other such houses in the miles of countryside around Marseilles, the kind of dreary residences described as coquette by the realestate salesmen who try to foist them off on the city's middle classes searching for a country retreat. One thing, however, sets that particular villa apart. It was there on Monday, Oct. 9, 1969, that the French police seized a heroinconversion laboratory, the third they had uncovered in 20 years.

title: OBSERVER
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 5Here is the early form sheet on the Presidential election. It was produced in Las Vegas by the distinguished oddsmaker Eddie the Cretan:

title: JobFinding Fees Cut For Vietnam Veterans
description: TRENTON  Many private employment agencies in New Jersey will charge reduced fees when they help obtain Sobs for returning Vietnam veterans, Richard J. Miele, chairman of a state task force on veteran's employment, has announced.

title: FOREIGN AFFAIRS
description: TEL AVIV Israel's present policy, which focuses on long  range peace rather than any interim solution paving the way to that goal, is founded upon strategic thinking. This, in turn, is based on the logic of to have and to holduntil there is real assurance that shooting won't start up again.

title: Nixon Plans Job Message
description: KEY BISCAYNE, Fla., Feb. 5 (AP)  President Nixon announced today that he would send Congress Monday a message on revenue sharing for manpower development programs. The President said his message would propose ways to improve training and job placement for the unemployed.

title: Music
description: COLIN DAVIS is not at all put off by the less than ecstatic reviews of the Met's new production of Pellas et Mlisande, which he had conducted for the first time in his career. It is the afternoon after the opening, and the musician appears relaxed and dapper looking, sporting a bulky tan turtleneck and formfitting brown trousers. Davis explains that he, like most mortals, found it difficult to warm up to Debussy's unique (take your pick) masterpiece/crashing bore. That was before he began studying the score. Pellas took him longer to learn than any other opera except, perhaps, Wozzeck, but once he had it down pat, he became a staunch champion of the work. His enthusiasm was mirrored In his interpretation, which proved individualistic enough to cause one critic to write that it sounded more like R, Strauss than C. Debussy, and another to report that the orchestral volume elicited by Davis was more than the composer requested. Neither complaint particularly provoked the unflappable maestro.

title: Swiss Girl, 17, Bursts Onto Skiing Scene
description: SAPPORO, Japan, Feb. 5By the blink of an eyelash Annemarie Proell of Austria, the world champion, was beaten in the Olympic women's downhill ski race. The girl who beat her had come on the skiing scene in such a hurry that most sources on the subject did not even list her name.

title: Daughter to Mrs. Haber
description: A daughter was born Jan. 14 to Mr. and Mrs. Robert Jay Haber of New York at the University Hospital, Mrs. Haber, a psychologist is the former Miss Roslyn A. Small.

title: WORLD OF SEVENTH AVE.
description: Someone once said that product guarantee was an act of faithfaith on the part of the giver that it would seldom be necessary to make good.

title: Article 5  No Title
description: STONY BROOK, L. I., Feb. 5 City College saw an early lead evaporate but rallied to gain a 7264 victory over Stony Brook tonight.

title: Ryun Travels a Tortoise Path to Olympic Rainbow
description: LOS ANGELES, Feb. 5 Jim Ryun, intense master of the nuances of pacing in a. mile race, is trying to apply an easydoesit approach in the long run to the 1972 Summer Olympics.

title: OutofCity Landlords Urged To Follow Rent Guidelines
description: Charles J. Urstadt, the state's Housing Commissioner, said yesterday his office was encouraging the owners of rentcontrolled buildings outside New York City to stay within Federal rent and price guidelines even if they might be entitled to more.

title: MRS. GANDHI OPENS TALKS WITH MUJIB
description: CALCUTTA, Feb. 6  The Prime Ministers of India and Bangladesh, Mrs. Indira Gandhi and Sheik Mujibur Rahman, opened two days of talks here today, and informed sources said that they were likely to sign a treaty for mutual defense and economic cooperation. Today's talks lasted more than three hours.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: PHOENIX, Ariz., Feb. 6 (AP) The Phoenix Suns hit 65 per cent of their shots in the third period on the way to a 10794 victory over the Portland Trail Blazers tonight. It was the ninth time in a row they had downed Portland.

title: Man Aids 2 Boys in Water; Saves One, Drowns With 2d
description: CLARK, N. J., Feb. 6 (AP)A teenaged boy ice skating on a reservoir and a man who tried to save him after he fell through the snowcovered ice drowned today, the police said, after the man rescued the youth's companion.

title: Coast Steel Mill Shut in Dispute With Union Over Sharing Plan
description: LOS ANGELES, Feb. 6The largest steel plant west of the Mississippi River has been shut down because of a unionmanagement disagreement over a plan designed to prevent strikes.

title: HIRING OF NEWSMEN IS OFF, SURVEY FINDS
description: PRINCETON, N. J., Feb. 6 (AP)About onequarter of 163 newspapers surveyed around the country hired 5.4 per cent fewer newsroom employes last year than they did in 1970. Nearly a third of the newspapers predicted that their hiring would decline this year.

title: City to Test Private Pickups of Refuse
description: Environmental Protection Administrator Jerome Kretchmer said yesterday he would conduct an experiment to determine whether private pickup of refuse might be cheaper in some areas than city collections.

title: Lye Is Poured on 2 Policemen During Gun Duel With Suspect
description: Two plainclothes policemen were doused with lye yesterday evening by a woman whose husband had shot at them through an apartment door in the East New York section of Brooklyn, the police reported.

title: Advertising:
description: A McCannErickson spokesman has reluctantly verified that the agency plans to establish a national broadcast spotbuying operation on March 1.

title: Lack of Convertibility Held Chief Dollar Drag
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 6A prominent expert on the world monetary system believes that the chief reason for the recent weakness of the dollar on foreign exchange markets is the failure of the leading nations, and particularly the United States, to move toward at least an interim arrangement for the official convertibility of the dollar.

title: Obituary 1  No Title
description: Obituary 1  No Title

title: Mo KhanBinns Pair Keeps Crown in Squash Racquets
description: Mo Khan and Ken Binns were pressed to the maximum of 10 games in the semifinal and final rounds yesterday at the Heights Casino in Brooklyn, but retained their championship in the David C. Johnson Jr. Memorial open squash racquets doubles competition.

title: Africa: The Wind Rises
description: Admonishing Britain for vetoing a resolution on Rhodesia at the final session of the United Nations Security Council in Ethiopia last week, Somalia's delegate declared: Africa is awake and, veto or no veto, nothing will diminish the pace of our march to freedom, to development and the inevitable African revolution.

title: Llewellyn Thompson Dead at Age of 67; ExEnvoy to Soviet
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 Llewellyn E. Thompson, former Ambassador to the Soviet Union, whose diplomatic career spanned four decades, died today. He was 67 years old.

title: Results in Winter Olympic Games
description: Results in Winter Olympic Games

title: Elia Kazan, Novelist and Moviemaker, Prefers the Pen
description: In celebration of Elia Kazan's contribution to theater, films and literature over a span of 40 years, the New York Public Library is giving him a party tonight at which he will receive New York City's highest cultural award, the Handel Medallion. This Is Mr. Kazan's month, a harbinger that 1972 may be his most rewarding year.

title: 6 Die in Argentine Mishap
description: BUENOS AIRES, Feb. 6 (AP) Six persons were killed and 32 injured today when a train bringing tourists from Crdoba to Buenos Aires was derailed 90 miles north of here. Three of the dead were children, the police said.

title: Carolina Bus Hijacker Seized After Fleeing With Hostage
description: SALISBURY, N. C., Feb. 6 (AP)The police said that an escaped mental patient hijacked a Continental Trailways bus with 10 passengers aboard today, took a teenaged girl hostage, and led officers on a 40mile, fourcounty chase before crashing the bus into a roadblock.

title: Selling of President Set for Broadway
description: A Memphisbased record and music publishing company, whiteowned and blackrun, will be a major investor in a forthcoming Broadway musical.

title: L.I.R.R. Freight Operation Criticized in Levitt Report
description: ALBANY, Feb. 6  State Controller Arthur Levitt said today that there was a need for more effective management and closer supervision of the Long Island Rail Road freight operations.

title: Snowfall No. 2 Is a Slippery One
description: A slow, steady snowfallonly the second measurable one in the metropolitan area this winterlaid a treacherous coating on streets and highways yesterday that slowed traffic to a trickle and caused scores of minor accidents.

title: Italy: The Crisis Deepens
description: It is symbolic of the sad state of Italy's political and economic health that Rome was paralyzed by a general strike, called to protest soaring living costs, the day after Emilio Colombo gave up his effort to form a new Government. So the political crisis drags on in the midst of deepening recession. Over the weekend President Leone made another attempt to form a new Government, but the probability is that he will have to dissolve Parliament a year early and call new elections this spring.

title: KINGSLEY HUMBERT SR.
description: WEST NEW YORK, N. Feb. 6Kingsley E. Humbert Sr., a founder of the Manhattan advertising agency of Humbert & Sons, died yesterday in the. Hudson Manor Convalescent Center, North Bergen. He was 76 years old and lived at 6010 Boulevard East.

title: PROFITS ROSE 24% AT 932 COMPANIES
description: Out of the mixed bag of economic uncertainties, such as the effects of the wageprice freeze, currency crisis, surcharge and high unemployment, have come encouraging fourthquarter corporate profits that give evidence of underlying strength.

title: U.S. Agency in Middle on Pollution Dispute in Smelting Industry
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 6The smelting industry and the Governors of Montana and Arizona have presented William D. Ruckelshaus, administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency, with a pair of thorny problems.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: Your Jan, 25 articles and Jan. 26 editorial reflect some confusion on the estimated costs of the space shuttle.

title: Chess: Even the Routine Victories Are Sometimes Masterpieces
description: A small international tournament held recently in the town of Matenz, near Basle, Switzerland, ended in a triumph for the veteran Hungarian grandmaster Gideon Barcza.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: Your editorial Vendetta in Peru concerning the Peruvian military Government's action in ousting Pedro Beltran from his famous newspaper, La Prensa, is a good opening salvo in a new conflict between the pen and the sword.

title: The Mood for Summer: Fashions That Are Romantic, Pretty and Revealing
description: When the model racing down the runway at the opening of Oscar de la Renta's boutique show whipped off her batwingsleeved white organdy jacket and continued her stride In black jersey pants with a strapless bodice, she practically summed up the whole new summer look in one outfit.

title: lueens Policeman Is Seized On an Auto Theft Charge
description: A 21yearold city patrolman, arrested early yesterday at Ridgedale Street and Merrick Boulevard in Queens Village, Queens, was charged with the theft of an auto and possession of stolen property.

title: Case to Support Nixon
description: Senator Clifford P. Case said yesterday that he saw no reason why he would not support President Nixon for reelection next year, according to United Press International. The New Jersey Republican, who said Mr. Nixon has done and is doing an extraordinary job, was interviewed on WNBCTV's program Newslight.

title: Von Ruden Shows Again He Is FirstClass Miler
description: Tom Von Ruden, the miler nobody knows, has emerged as the runner of recent in this Olympic year

title: Roger Hull, MONY Head, Dies; Led in Insurance Innovations
description: Roger Hull, chairman and chief executive officer of Mutual of New York, one of the nation's largest insurance concerns, died yesterday of cancer in Stamford (Corm.) Hospital. He was 64 years old and lived in Darien, Conn.

title: Marches in Republic Back Catholics in North
description: DUBLIN, Feb. 6 (Reuters) Thousands of people in Ireland turned out today to support the Catholic civil rights march in Newry and to pay tribute to the 13 people killed in Londonderry last Sunday.

title: Braves Triumph, 121108
description: CLEVELAND, Feb. 6 (AP)The Buffalo Braves won their first season series ever in the N.B.A. tonight as Walt Hazzard scored 24 points in the second half in a 121108 victory over the Cleveland Cavaliers.

title: ARMY STILL RULES CHINA'S PROVINCES
description: HONG KONG, Feb. 6Military men are still very much in evidence as key political figures in China's provinces despite the purge of Defense Minister Lin Piao and topranking members of the armed forces in Peking.

title: BILL WOULD SLOW FASTTRIAL ORDER
description: Legislative sponsors are predicting passage for a state bill that would soften the Judicial Conference mandate requiring a trial for defendants within six months of their arrest or the dropping of all charges.

title: Israelis Report Seizure Of Jerusalem Terrorists
description: TEL AVIV, Feb. 6Israeli security authorities in the occupied west bank of Jordan said tonight that 13 Arab guerrillas were seized this week in Ashayuk, a village lour miles northeast of Hebron, and that two of the prisoners confessed to terrorist attacks in Jerusalem in September and October.

title: Dutch Ace Sets Olympic Mark Russi Captures Downhill
description: SAPPORO, Japan, Monday, Feb. 7 (AP)Ard Schenk of the Netherlands set an Olympic record in the 10,000meter speedskating race today and became the first triple goldmedal winner of the 11th Winter Games.

title: Mujib on Bangladesh Bills
description: DACCA, Bangladesh, Feb. 6 (AP)  Bangladesh currency notes will bear the portrait of Sheik Mujibur Rahman, the Prime Minister, on one side and a picture of a Bengal tiger on the other, A. M. Hamidullah, governor of the Bangladesh Bank, announced today.

title: The UriSound Bridge
description: New York State, pleading poverty every hour on the hour, has now been urged by official consultants to build a sixmile bridge across Long Island Sound at a cost that could easily reach as high as $235 million. The state, which once before came extremely close to sanctioning this longstanding dream of Robert Moses, should have no difficulty now in rejecting the advice of the consulting firm hired by its Department of Transportationif only on the ground of the project's low social priority. But, with Governor Rockefeller enthusiastically committed to it, the sole hope for averting this folly lies with the Legislature.

title: Sabres, Off to 60 Lead, Turn Back Bruins, 8 to 2
description: BUFFALO, Feb. 6 (UPI)Don Luce, Gerry Meehan and Rick Martin scored goals in a threeminute span late in the first period tonight as the Buffalo Sabres played their best game in two seasons to throttle the Boston Bruins, 82, in a National Hockey League game.

title: Jorge Bolet Earns His Bravos Playing Liszt Piano Sonata
description: Jorge Bolet's reputation as master Liszt interpreter was confirmed anew at Alice Tully Hall Saturday night in a concert benefiting the Scholarship Fund of the Indiana University School of Music. The pianist, who is on the faculty at Indiana, made a remarkably persuasive case for Liszt's potentially tiresome B Minor Sonata, then followed it with a sizzling Rhapsodie Espagnol, finding In both scores a happy medium between romantic impetuosity and steely control.

title: Hans Graf, Pianist, Makes Local Debut
description: Hans Graf, a pianist from Vienna presently teaching at Indiana University, gave his New York debut late yesterday afternoon in Carnegie Recital Hall. Only two composers were represented on the program, and the musical contrast could not have been greater: two of Beethoven's most introspective, cryptic late sonatas (Op. 101 and 111) and Stravinsky's three flashy virtuoso studies from Petrushka prefaced by the Four Etudes (Op. 7).

title: Weisberg Leads First Concert Of a Chamber Series at Hunter
description: A threeconcert series entitled The Contemporary Chamber Ensemble at Hunter began at Hunter College Playhouse on Saturday night under the direction of Arthur Weisberg.

title: Flyers Tie Blues, 22
description: PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 6 (AP) A pair of goals in the final three minutes enabled the Philadelphia Flyers to tie the St. Louis Blues, 22 tonight.

title: Chavez's Farm Union Seeking to Organize Florida Citrus Workers
description: MIAMI, Feb. 6The United Farm Workers, of California, in its first major organizing drive in the East, has sent a mission to Florida where working conditions for indigent and migrant field hands are among the worst in the nation.

title: LAKERS TROUNCE BULLETS, 151127
description: LOS ANGELES, Calif., Feb. 6 (AP)The Los Angeles Lakers overcame an early 11point deficit and coasted to a 151127 victory over the Baltimore Bullets tonight to run their winning streak to six games.

title: Prices and Orders At Steel Mills Up As Demand Grows
description: PITTSBURGH, Feb. 6Orders and prices of steel mills moved up last week.

title: Jewish Group Elects Chief
description: The election of Jacob Stein as president of the Conference of Presidents of Major American Jewish Organizations was announced yesterday. The Presidents Conference, with headquarters at 515 Park Avenue, is the coordinating body of 25 major Jewish religious and secular groups devoted to promoting AmericanIsraeli relations. Mr. Stein, realestate broker, is president of the United Synagogue of America, congregational arm of Conservative Judaism.

title: Squash Racquets to Taylor
description: Hoyt Taylor of the Harvard Club won the Lone Star Boat Club Class B invitation squash racquets tournament yesterday, defeating Gorge Kellner of the University Club, 157, 1115, 1510, 156. In the semifinals, Taylor beat Ed Vaughen, 158, 815, 1510, 1511, and Kellner downed Mike Taylor, 1817, 1510, 915, 159.

title: Checkers Victor at Rye
description: RYE, N. Y. Feb. 6Checkers, owned by Mrs. L. Andrews and handled by Jack Rockwell, captured the regular working hunter championship with 9 points and finished as reserve champion to Cedar Lodge Farm's Arvy in the limit working hunter competition today in the Coach House Stable's show.

title: NEEDS OF CITY U. FOUND CRITICAL
description: The City University is critically in need of new and additional facilities, a State Education Department study has found.

title: Farms in State Declined 32% Over 10Year Period
description: ALBANY, Feb. 5The number of farms in New York State continues to decline, but agriculture remains as the state's largest single industry, according to reports issued here this week.

title: Meskill Expected to Ask the Assembly For Another Increase in State Sales Tax
description: HARTFORD, Feb. 6  Gov. Thomas J. Meskill is planning to ask the General Assembly for another increase in the sales tax when he addresses its opening session here Wednesday.

title: Politics and Uncertainty Cloud Public TV Funding
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 6Longterm funding for the Corporation for Public Broadcasting is stuck in an uncertain and increasingly partisan fight.

title: Amtrak's Las Vegas Fun Train Lives Up to the Name
description: LAS VEGAS, Nev., Feb. 6Amtrak's Gambling Special from Los Angeles chugged to a stop on a railroad siding here shortly before midnight Friday, and 355 passengers on the first of the Las Vegas fun trains disembarked for a weekend in the gaming parlors.

title: Mishap Closes Expressway
description: A section of the BrooklynQueens expressway near the Hamilton Avenue exit and the Gowanus Expressway was closed to traffic between midnight and noon yesterday after a fueloil truck overturned, killing the driver and spilling 1,300 gallons of oil on the roadway. The driver was identified as Frank Latella, 28 years old, of 76 Montgomery Avenue, New Brighton, Staten Island.

title: Baseball's Palmer Sparks Duo To 2Shot Victory in San Juan
description: SAN JUAN, Puerto Rico, Feb. 6 (UPI)  Baltimore's team of Jim Palmer and Willie Richardson carded a bestball score of 16underpar 56 today to capture the $30,000 American Airlines Golf Classic by two strokes. The threeround tourney pairs baseball and football professionals.

title: LAVER TRIUMPHS OVER DRYSDALE
description: RICHMOND, Feb. 6 (UPI) Rod Laver overcame early problems with his serve today to defeat Cliff Drysdale for the singles championship of the $50,000 Fidelity World Championship Tennis Tournament.

title: Cold War Entente
description: Perseverance, patience, a willingness to talk and a capacity for friendship were all qualities that served to make Llewellyn E. Thompson one of the nation's most effective diplomats in often  difficult dealings with the Russians during the cold war. As an exponent of the art of quiet diplomacy, he managed to keep open the channels of communications between the United States and the Soviet Union at times when the two superpowers were barely on speaking terms.

title: LORD CROWTHER, ECONOMIST EDITOR
description: LONDON, Feb. 6  Lord Crowther, former editor of The Economist magazine and chairman of a hotel group from which he recently resigned after a takeover struggle, died of a heart attack at London's Heathrow airport last night. His age was 64.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: Recent decisions by threejudge Federal courts in the District of Columbia and in Georgia suggest a potential conflict between the requirements of the Fourteenth Amendment of the Constitution and application of certain rules adopted by the McGovern Commission on Party Structure and Delegate Selection to the Democratic National Committee.

title: UNE DE MAI TAKES PRIX DE FRANCE TROT
description: PARIS, Feb. 5Count Pierre de Montesson's champion mare, Une de Mai, won the $50,000 Prix de France today in a finish decided by a photo at Vincennes trotting track.

title: Bringhurst Wins Marathon
description: LAS VEGAS, Nev. Feb. 6 (UPI)  Scott Bringhurst of Salt Lake City captured his second straight Las Vegas marathon today in a record time of 2 hours 19 minutes 24 seconds. Torn Berger of Coloredo State University finished second.

title: Man in the News
description: NEWRY, Northern Ireland, Feb. 6In the cramped, noisy secondfloor office on Hill Street, Kevin Boyle picked up the telephone. Father, you've got to understand, he quietly told the Roman Catholic priest. We don't want a confrontation with them. But we've got to march. He hung up, and quickly embraced a visitor, Bernadette Devlin, the militant Catholic member of the British Parliament. The telephone rang again. We're not going to stop it, he patiently told the caller. Understand, it's a question of rights, our rights.

title: Pirates Sign Clemente With a Pay Increase
description: PITTSBURGH, Feb. 6 (UPI)  Roberto Clemente has signed a 1972 contract with the Pittsburgh Pirates, the team's general manager, Joe L. Brown, announced today.

title: Diane Snow Bride Of Arthur Bresnick
description: LAKE SUCCESS, L. I., Feb. 6Miss Diane Snow of Missoula, Mont., and Arthur Bresnick, vice president of Estate Auto Service, Inc., distributors for the Gulf Oil Company in New York, were married here at noon today by Rabbi Jerome K. Davidson. The ceremony took place at the home of the bridegroom's brother and sisterinlaw, Dr. and Mrs. Philip A. Bresnick.

title: Airwest in Tentative Accord With Mechanics in Strike
description: SAN MATEO, Calif., Feb. 6 (UPI)  Hughes Airwest and striking mechanics reached tentative agreement today on a contract that could end sevenweek walkout against the regional airline.

title: Carnegie Endowment to. Aid Foreign Policy Magazine
description: The Carnegie Endowment for International Peace announced yesterday that it would help finance and supply offices and facilities for Foreign Policy magazine, the yearold quarterly journal of opinion on foreign affairs.

title: RHODESIA PACT FOE IS ON HUNGER STRIKE
description: SALISBURY, Rhodesia, Feb. 6 (Agence FrancePresse) Judith Todd, who is being detained for her opposition to the proposed BritishRhodesia settlement, yesterday went on a hunger strike that would last, she said, until I am released from prison.

title: THE FARM EXODUS WORRIES MOSCOW
description: MOSCOW, Feb. 6  A Leningrad sociologist, reflecting the concern of Soviet economic planners over the exodus of Soviet youth from farms, has just published findings that in some regions only one rural youth in 20 stays on the farm.

title: AMEX COMPANIES GET LOUDER VOICE
description: The American Stock Exchange announced yesterday the formation of a new advisory committee to give listed companies a bigger say in the, exchange's policy matters.

title: Saigon Museum Is Spruced Up
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Feb. 6 The National Museum of South Vietnam is a huge peach  colored building with great flying eaves in the style of a Confucian temple.

title: All U.S. Airlines Set Up Hijacking Screen
description: Trans World Airlines flight 41 was about to leave for San Francisco yesterday morning when a ticket agent whispered to a security officer, I've got two.

title: Lindsay Extols His Record to Floridians
description: TAMPA, Fla., Feb. 6Mayor Lindsay is confronting headon in the Democratic Presidential race the issue of his City Hall record in an effort to make a political asset out of what many politicians and critics believe to be his Achilles heel.

title: St. Andrew's No. 1 Rink Wins Cuthbertson Curling
description: MT. HOPE, N. Y., Feb. 6The St. Andrews Curling Club No. 1 rink, skipped by Donald G. McKay, won the championship New York Caledonian, Medal event of the 17th annual, Cuthbertson bonspiel at St. Andrew's Golf Club today.

title: Floridians Score, 144117
description: MIAMI, Feb. 6 (AP)Mack Calvin, shaking the effects of the flu, tallied 37 points to pace the Floridians to a 144117 rout of the Pittsburgh Condors tonight.

title: Waldheim Back From Trip
description: Secretary General Waldheim returned to New York yesterday from his first trip abroad since taking over his United Nations post. Mr. Waldheim visited Rome; Athens; Addis Ababa, Ethiopia; Nairobi, Kenya, and Mogadishu, Somalia.

title: SERENITY MARKS 2 BY CUNNINGHAM
description: Merce Cunningham was probably the first to take the ego out of modern dance. There Was no place for it in a theory in which performance consisted mainly of a coming together of separate elements  time space and sound.

title: AMERICAN CEMENT AND BUTLER AGREE
description: Butler Aviation International, Inc., and the American Cement Corporation said yesterday that they had settled lawsuits against each other.

title: Supercomputer Is Designed to Aid in Predicting LongRange Changes in Earth's Climate
description: Engineers at a Texas electronics concern are building a new kind of supercomputer that is designed to help weather scientists study and, perhaps someday, predict longrange changes in the earth's climate.

title: W. H. Auden Plans to Move Back Home to England
description: Another great institution is leaving New York Citya oneman corporation of letters named W. H. Auden.

title: Catholics March Through Newry but Avoid a Clash
description: NEWRY, Northern Ireland, Feb. 6Thousands of Roman Catholics surged silently through the streets of Newry today in a civil rights protest against the British and Northern Ireland Governments.

title: JOHN AARON DIES; TV PRODUCER, 51
description: AMITYVILLE, LI., Feb. 6John A. Aaron, the television producer who coproduced the Columbia Broadcasting System's Person to Person, starring the late Edward R. Murrow, died today in Brunswick Hospital Center after a short illness. He was 51 years old and lived at 3 East 66th Street, New York.

title: NICOLAYSEN WINS IN SKI JUMPING
description: ROSENDALE, N. Y, Feb. 6 Gray skies, subfreezing temperatures and a slick hill proved a happy combination for Richard Nicolaysen of St. Lawrence University today during a spillpunctuated skijumping tournament.

title: Advertising:
description: The Carling Brewing Company has picked Smith/Greenland to handle advertising for its Black Label Lager and Black Label Malt Liquor.

title: Article 2  No Title
description: PNOMPENH, Cambodia, Feb, 6 (AP)The Cambodian high command reported today that 20 civilian workers taken prisoner by enemy forces last month near the Temples of Angkor had been killed by their captors Thursday and that the report of the killings had been brought to the provincial capital of Siem Reap by a Buddhist monk.

title: 2 ENTER PRIMARY IN WEST VIRGINIA
description: CHARLESTON, W. Va., Feb. 6  West Virginia's May 9 Democratic Presidential primary will apparently involve only two candidates, Senator Hubert H. Humphrey of Minnesota and Gov. George C. Wallace of Alabama.

title: The Issues in Ulster
description: The primary aim of the Roman Catholic minority Northern Ireland is to achieve civil rights equal to those enjoyed by the Protestant majority.

title: British Plan New Concessions in Ulster
description: LONDON, Feb. 6The British Government has prepared a radical new political plan for Northern Ireland, ready for release when it thinks the time is right. The peaceful march in Newry today could help clear the way for early action.

title: GinzburgA Failed Deterrent
description: Ralph Ginzburg, publisher of lurid erotica, quite understandably does not want to go to jail, and has said so in impassioned public appeals. His impending threeyear imprisonment is the result of a conviction on charges obscenity in 1963. The United States Supreme Court in a fivetofour opinion upheld the conviction and last year turned down an appeal for a new hearing.

title: Javelin Pays Back Mill Advance Made By Newfoundland
description: MONTREAL, Feb. 6A joint statement from the new Conservative Government of Newfoundland and the Javelin group of companies, issued in St. John's, stated that the Javelin group had repaid advances totaling $24million made by the former Smallwood administration for its new linerboard mill at Stephenville.

title: Muskie's Grade a C In Politics on Campus
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 6The credibility of Senator Edmund S. Muskie's politics of trust is undergoing its toughest test on the nation's campuses, and so far it appears to be getting little more than average grades.

title: Feuerbach Betters Record
description: POCATELLO, Idaho, Feb. 6 (AP) Al Feuerbach bettered his world indoor record in the shotput last night while Tom Von Ruden, posted a victory in the 1,000yard run.

title: The Mundt Case
description: Since he suffered a severely disabling stroke more than two years ago, Senator Karl E. Mundt, Republican of South Dakota, has been unable to appear in the Senate or attend committee meetings. As one of the most senior Republicans, Mr. Mundt was a highranking member of three important committees and had a share in the appointment of minority staff members.

title: Personal Finance
description: There's no doubt that the volume of checks processed each day is staggering and that the banks would like to lessen the ever increasing burden. However, it looks as if their vision of a checkless society is farther away than they had hoped. Customers don't like the idea, as Franklin National Bank found out recently.

title: Kennedy Panel to Consider Amnesty in Draft Evasion
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 (AP) Senator Edward M. Kennedy announced today that a Senate subcommittee would hold hearings on Selective Service procedures and on the possibility of granting amnesty to draft evaders through administrative procedures. Kennedy, who heads the subcommittee on administrative practice and procedures, said that the panel would hold three days of hearings beginning Feb. 28.

title: Robert P. Crossley Dead at 58; ExEditor of Popular Mechanics
description: STAMFORD, Conn., Feb. 6  Robert Pierce Crossley, who retired as editor of Popular Mechanics magazine last year after having suffered a stroke, died today at his home, 43 Glendale Road. He was 58 years old.

title: City Bar Backs NoFault Insurance
description: The Association of the Bar of the City of New York called yesterday for the early enactment of a pure no fault automobile insurance system.

title: Students to Vote in Florida
description: Students plan to hold a Presidential straw vote on 37 college campuses in Florida on March 7, a week before the state's formal Presidential preference primary, United Press International reported yesterday.

title: Boat Driver Loses His Hand in Mishap During Trial Run
description: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., Feb. 6 (AP)Bob Erra's left hand was severed today when he collided with his Skiboat in the air after the craft flipped and threw him during the 34th annual Southland Speedboat Regatta.

title: Gonzales Defeats Goven
description: DES MOINES, Iowa, Feb. 6 (Reuters) Pancho Gonzales, giving away 20 years and an early lead to a Frenchman, Georges Goven, won today's singles final of the Des Moines international tennis championships.

title: Leadership Elected By Polish Writers; Liberals Show Gain
description: LODZ, Poland, Feb. 6The congress of Polish writers, which ended here last night, elected a new leadership that reflected the increased liberalization in Poland's cultural life in the last year.

title: Gannon, in St. Patrick's, Assails Britain's North Ireland Policies
description: Some of Britain's policies in Northern Ireland were denounced as stupid and bungling from the pulpit of St. Patrick's Cathedral yesterday during a solemn pontifical mass for peace and justice in Ulster.

title: CHARLES L. HAYDEN, TELEPHONE AIDE, 70
description: LARCHMONT, N. Y., Feb. 6 Charles Leslie Hayden, a retired telephone company public relations executive, died today in United Hospital, Port Chester. He was 70 years old and lived at 60 Beach Avenue in this suburban community, which provided the setting for much of the gently witty verse of his wife, Phyllis McGinley, the Pulitzer Prizewinning poet.

title: Hempstead Decides Not to Build Housing for the Poor Or Elderly
description: The Town of Hempstead intends to drop its proposal for 250 units of federally assisted housing for the elderly, rather than keep an earlier agreement to build the units for largely black, lowincome families.

title: Buckley, Senator a Year, Aspires to 2 More Terms
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 6After one year in the United States Senate, James L. Buckley has concluded that it's a nice place to visit and he would like to live there for two terms more.

title: U.S. Handball Team Wins And Qualifies for Olympics
description: ELKHART, Ind., Feb. 6 (AP) The United States captured the Western Hemisphere team handball eliminations today, beating Canada, 1511, and gaining a spot in the Olympic Games in August at Munich. Team handball is a combination of soccer and hockey.

title: KNICKS VANQUISH 76ERS,109 TO 107
description: PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 6 Displaying again their current trademark, the New York Knicks proved the steadier team down the stretch today in another fierce struggle with the Philadelphia 76ers, and all but wrapped up a playoff berth by posting a 109107 victory.

title: Another KingEvert Match
description: FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., Feb. 6 (UPI)Chris Evert, the 17yearold tennis star from Fort Lauderdale, defeated Australia's Judy Dalton and Mrs. Billie Jean King downed Wendy Overton in the semifinals of the Virginia Slims international tennis tournament today.

title: COLLIDING: Rangers Brad Park checks Toronto's Rick Ley
description: The classic signs of a slump misses from up close, a wrong bounce, losing the leadwere again in abundance yesterday as the Rangers gave up thirdperiod goals to the Toronto Maple Leafs in a 22 tie.

title: Justice Steps Down Pending Inquiry on Conduct
description: A Rockland County police justice has been ordered to step down until a grand jury can determine if he should face charges of official misconduct in allegedly seeking to have shoplifting charges against another police judge withdrawn.

title: Rockets Turn Back Pacers
description: DENVER, Feb. 6 (UPI) Chuck Williams, reserve guard, scored a careerhigh 36 points today to lead the Denver Rockets to a 115107 victory over the Indiana Pacers in the second game of a doubleheader.

title: 40 Professionals Mold The Lindsay Campaign
description: On the 13th floor of 415, Madison Avenue, beyond the electronically operated door that is guarded by a uniformed private security man, a peripatetic staff of 40 political professionals are shaping the Presidential campaign of John V. Lindsay.

title: Humphrey Invokes Nostalgia in Campaign
description: MIAMI, Feb. 6A woman voter shook hands with Hubert H. Humphrey on a Charleston, W. Va., street corner last week and remembered doing the same thing at the same place in the same context 12 years ago.

title: Canadiens Triumph, 42
description: VANCOUVER, British Columbia, Feb. 6Jim Roberts's goal with his team shorthanded midway through the third period helped the Montreal Canadiens pull out a 42 National Hockey League victory over the Vancouver Canucks today.

title: SLAYER OF POLICE STILL NOT KNOWN
description: Chief of Detectives Albert A, Seedman said yesterday that the Police Department was still trying to identify the killers of two patrqlmen in the East Village 11 days ago, and a deputy police commissioner added that no arrests appeared imminent.

title: Books of The Times
description: THE PRODUCER. By Christopher Davis. Illustrated. 321 pages. Harper & Row. $8.95.

title: JOSEPH J. DREYER
description: Joseph J. Dreyer, a lawyer in Brooklyn since 1923, died yesterday at his home, 930 East Ninth Street, Brooklyn. His age was 80. Surviving are his widow, Dinah, and a sister.

title: JOHN K. M'CLARE
description: MOUNT VERNON, N.Y., Feb. 6John Kenneth McClare, a certified public accountant and a partner in the accounting firm of S. D. Leidesdorf & Co., died yesterday at his home at 1 Park Lane. He was 65 years old and had been suffering from a respiratory illness.

title: Mrs. Abe Freedman Dies; Late Editor's Mother, 83
description: Mrs. Anna Liverant Freedman, mother of the late Emanuel R. Freedman, former assistant managing editor and longtime foreign editor of The New York Times, died yesterday apparently of a heart attack in Manhattan Eye and Ear Hospital. She was 83 years old and lived at 500 East 87th Street.

title: Life Jackets and Debris Of Missing Tanker Found
description: GALVESTON, Tex., Feb. 6 (AP)Two life jackets from the missing tanker V. A. Fogg were found today about 50 miles from Freeport, Tex., the Coast Guard said.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
description: Committee on relations with United States as host country10:30 A.M.

title: Haber Says City is Very Close to Accord on a Pact With P.B.A.
description: After more than 13 months of offandon negotiations, the city expects to reach a contract agreement today with the 30,000member Patrolmen's Benevolent Association.

title: Israelis Dropping Deal for French Jets
description: JERUSALEM, Feb. 6Israeli officials said today that agreement had been reached in Paris to terminate Israel's fiveyearold order for 50 Mirage aircraft, embargoed by de Gaulle at the outbreak of the 1967 ArabIsraeli war.

title: Atuttuersartes
description: SIEGELBen & EthelHappy 35th Mom & Dad. Much loveJoan, Martin, Susan, Larry, Margo, Louis.

title: Fiduciary Banker Sees 1972 Corporate Profits Up 15%
description: QUESTION: What is your overview of the stock market in terms of where it's been, where it is now and where it may be headed?

title: Celtics Beat Sonics
description: BOSTON, Feb. 6 (AP)The Boston Celtics built a 21point firsthalf lead on the shooting of John Havlicek and then withstood a prolonged cold spell to post their seventh consecutive victory today, 128123, over the Seattle SuperSonics in the National Basketball Association.

title: American Schools in Europe Seek to Offer U. S. Way of Life
description: LONDONAt 8 A.M. each weekday six buses move through London to pick up students waiting to attend the American School. Near the Via del Corso in Rome, in St.Germain in Paris, in the

title: EUROBONDS FIND ANTIDOLLAR BIAS
description: BRUSSELS, Feb. 5A number of analysts believe matters will get worse before they get better, as far as straight dollar debt on the Eurobond market is concerned.

title: Economic Analysis
description: The many millions of American consumers who shop in the large regional shopping centers may soon win or lose on two important issuesthe right to have a wider choice in pricing and the right to shop in more diverse types of stores in the centers. Last week, following two similar complaints filed last year by the Federal Trade Commission, a class action suit was filed by a retailer asking $1.25 billion in damages from a group of shoppingcenter operators. The charge is that they gave preferential treatment to a select few of their major tenants, mostly department stores.

title: Miss Waiman Gives Town Hall Recital
description: Esther Fuerte Waiman a vigorous and determined pianist from Brazil, presented a recital Friday night in Town Hall. Her forthright nononsense approach to the music at hand was at least completely free of interpretive mannerisms, but unfortunately she offered very little to counterbalance this basic quality in essential matters of style supple phrasing, tonal coloring and, when necessary, requisite virtuosity.

title: U.S. IS SAID TO DROP NAPALM ON THE FOE
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Monday, Feb. 7 (AP)American helicopters dropped napalm yesterday on what appeared to be newly built North Vietnamese bunkers 25 miles northeast of Saigon, according to field reports. The operation was said to be intended offset anticipated Tet Lunar New Year attacks in the capital region.

title: Metreveli Wins Aussie Title
description: PERTH, Australia, Feb. 6 (AP)Alex Metreveli of the Soviet Union won the Western Australian men's singles ten nis championship for the second successive year today, defeating an Australian Davis Cup squad member, John Cooper, 62, 36, 64, 61.

title: Excerpts From Thuy and Rogers Interviews on Television
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 Following are excerpts from interviews with Xuan Thuy; the North Vietnamese delegate to the Paris peace talks, and Secretary of State William P. Rogers as broadcast today on the Columbia Broadcasting System television program Face the Nation, and transcribed by The New York Times. Mr. Thuy, whose interview was taped Friday in Paris, spoke in Vietnamese and his remarks were then translated into English.

title: GIRL, 15, DIES IN TREK FROM CRASHED PLANE
description: EAST DORSET, Vt., Feb. 6 (AP)A teenage girl and a young boy struggled down a snowcovered mountainside for help today after a private plane crashed. However, another girl died trying to make the walk and two other persons who had been aboard the plane were missing and feared dead, the state police reported.

title: Gougeon in IceBoat Sweep
description: BANTAM, LAKE. Conn., Feb. 6  Jan Gougeon of Bay City, Mich., successfully defended his North American ice boat championship today by sweeping the three championship races, the first time that has been done in 19 years of the competition. Eighty eight boats from 10 states and Canada competed.

title: Hawks 50 Victors
description: CHICAGO, Feb. 6 (UPI) Dennis Hull and Jim Pappin each scored twice and helped Tony Esposito earn his seventh shutout of the season in a 50 triumph for the Chicago Black Hawks over the Minnesota North Stars tonight. The triumph raised Chicago's West Division lead to 14 points over Minnesota.

title: Exodus of White Students Angers Retired reacher
description: Max Cantor saw Thomas Jefferson High School change from 95 per cent Jewish to 95 per cent black and Puerto Rican in the 44 yetkrs he spent there as a teacher and, for the last decade, as dean of boys In the nowblighted East New York section of Brooklyn.

title: Snow Slicks Roads Here
description: The city's second snowfall of the winter began yesterday at 1 P.M. By early today more than three inches had come down, creating hazardous driving conditions. Four inches of snow were expected in all. Details on Page 33.

title: Fordham's SecondHalf Rally Subdues Boston College, 6558
description: Fordham, hoping for its, second straight trip to the National Collegiate basketball tournament, played ineffectively against Boston College for the first 20 minutes yesterday, then had a good second half to beat the Eagles, 6558, at Rose Hill Gymnasium in the Bronx.

title: Hearings Show City Planners That People Are Real
description: Donald H. Elliott, the affable and tenacious chairman of the City Planning Commission, was asked the other day in an interview whether there was any significant issue that had been brought to his attention for the first time or which he had changed his mind about as a result of the public hearings now under way on the city's master plan.

title: MISS PRISS TAKES HORSE SHOW TITLE
description: HUNTINGTON, L. I., Feb. 6Julian Cascardi's Miss Priss captured both time classes to score 10 points and win the preliminary jumper championship today at the Thomas School of Horsemanship show.

title: Walker Scores 56 Points
description: CHICAGO, Feb. 6 (UPI)Chet Walker scored a Chicago Bulls team record and personal career high of 56 points today to lead the Bulls to a 11994 victory over the Cincinnati Royals, their eighth victory in the last 11 contests.

title: Part Vietnamese, Part BlackAnd Orphans
description: SAIGONAngela will be 3 years old in April, but she walks like a tiny old woman who falters because she is afraid of falling.

title: 2 New Chase Units Abroad
description: The Chase Manhattan Bank announced over the weekend the opening of two new branches abroad, bringing its overseas total to 79. They are in Freeport, the Bahamas, and in Agana, Guam.

title: Thousands Cross Border Peaceably
description: CLOGHOGE, Northern Ireland, Feb. 6For the first time in nearly four years of civil rights, demonstrations in Northern Ireland, thousands of persons from the Irish Republic crossed today to join in the Newry march.

title: Chris Evert Center of Dispute In Women's Tennis Rankings
description: Chris Evert has become the center of a ranking dispute within the United States Lawn Tennis Association, which starts its annual meeting in Houston tomorrow.

title: Federal Agencies Ponder Extradition of Mrs. Irving
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 6The State and Justice Departments are looking into the question whether Mrs. Clifford Irving should be extradited to Switzerland, Government sources said today.

title: African Women Show Enterprise in Business
description: ACCRA, GhanaHere and elsewhere in West Africa, market women have long been a symbol of business enterprise.

title: Mrs. Andrews Likely to Fill Husband's Seat in Congress
description: MONTGOMERY, Ala., Feb. 6 (UPI)Mrs. George W. Andrews will apparently be the new Congress woman from Alabama's Third District.

title: Hawaiian Volcano Eruption Creates 2 Lakes of Lava
description: HIT O, Hawaii, Feb. 6 (UPI)Two lakes of lava formed today from a quiet and very calm eruption in Hawaii Volcanoes National Park.

title: U.C.L.A. May Get a Bonus: Perfect Season
description: The University of California, Los Angeles, has won the last five national championships, but in taking the last four an unbeaten season has eluded the greatest college basketball machine ever assembled.

title: HANOI SAYS P.O.W.'S WILL NOT BE FREED UNTIL WAR IS OVER
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 North Vietnam says that American prisoners of war will be released only when the United States has withdrawn its support from the administration of President Nguyen Van Thieu in Saigon and the war has been brought to an end.

title: Schenk Glitters Even Without Skates
description: SAPPORO, Japan, Feb. 6He's a Viking god, said the Finniih woman reporter, crowding into the front row.

title: Schenk Wins 3d Title
description: Ard Schenk of the Netherlands completed a triple in Olympic speed skating at Sapporo Monday by winning the gruelling 10,000meter event in the redord time of 15 minutes 1.35 seconds. He previously won the 1,500 and 5,000 for his first two gold medals. Details on Page 39.

title: Wings Trounce Seals, 82
description: DETROIT, Feb. 6 (AP) Mickey Redmond scored a goal in each period tonight to lead the Detroit Red Wings to an 82 trouncing of the California Golden Seals, moving the Red Wings into sole possession of fourth place in the National Hockey League East Division.

title: Jones Wins Hawaii Golf, Beats Murphy in Playoff
description: HONOLULU, Feb. 6Grier Jones, a 25yearold golf professional from Kansas, beat Bob Murphy today on the first hole of a playoff to win the $40,000 top prize in the $200,000 Hawaiian open.

title: Antiwar Lawyers Group Gives Award to Ellsberg
description: Daniel Ellsberg received a world citizenship and national patriotism award here last night from the Lawyer's Committee on American Policy Towards Vietnam.

title: Chaplin Finds No Takers For Airport Chase Scene
description: LONDON, Feb. 6 (AP)Charles Chaplin, the 83yearold master comedian, challenged 4yearold Louise Brat to a wheelchair race today down the corridors of London Airport. But Louise, a Berkshire girl, was too smart for Mr. Chaplin and declined.

title: Garbage Dumps Surface As Issue in Westchester
description: WHITE PLAINS, Feb. 3With pickets, a lawsuit, a Federal investigation and the promise of more action to come, garbage disposal has emerged as the hottest public issue of the new year in Westchester County.

title: Theater: Hutchins's Two if by Sea
description: There is absolutely no substitute for failureit is unmistakable, and, in its way, perfect. Last night I was chilled to the core of my brain, the marrow of my mind, by a musical called Two if by Sea. Within two or three minutes you were wishing they had come by land.

title: When Smugness Collapsed
description: When I lived in Washingtonwith two babies and my husband, the young sister of a friend came to visit one night. She had just joined a liberation group at the university, and she had a list of complaints about the role of women in contemporary life.

title: SoHo Scene May Include Pollock Pl.
description: August Heckscher, the city's Parks, Recreation and Cultural Affairs Administrator, proposed yesterday that a fiveblock stretch in lower Manhattan's SoHo artists colony be renamed for the late New York abstract artist Jackson Pollock.

title: Shop Talk
description: It isn't easy designing clothes that never become dated. Take it from Jean Cacharel, a man who built a fashion empire on variations of a single theme. Mr. Cacharel, a 39yearold Frenchman, with three factories near Nimes, and exports to 40 countries, designs pants, skirts, shirts and blouses, and the changes from season to season are basically in color, fabric or length. But that's what makes it hard work.

title: The Danger of Candor
description: WASHINGTON  Some Americans are convinced that the United States Government should conduct its foreign affairs with far less secrecy than is now the case. A nation, they say, should lay its cards on the table, announce its intentions, reveal its aims, its strengths. If this is done, neither side will miscalculatecrisis through ignorance will be avoided.

title: Bond Calendar This Week The Heaviest in 2 Months
description: The bond market, which has been in a threeweek slump, hopes to find itself this week. Financing activity will be the heaviest in two months.

title: Irish in Australia March to Protest Killings in Ulster
description: SYDNEY, Australia, Feb. 6Some 5,000 Irish  Australians marched through downtown Sydney today with 13 coffins, one for each of the victims of British gunfire in Londonderry last week.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: A $4.5  million neighborhood family care center is scheduled to be built by mid1973 at Amsterdam Avenue and 145th Street to provide ambulatory medical services for 55,000 residents of the area, which has a shortage of private physicians, dentists and psychiatrists.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: The purpose of the McGovern Commission reform is not, as Mary Jo Bierman seems to think, to make the party more receptive to the candidates, nor is it to facilitate the delegates natural desire to support a winner [letter Jan. 26]. The whole purpose is to make the party more responsive to the peopleto give the people some say in who the winner will be.

title: Bar Foundation Gives Award to New Yorker
description: NEW ORLEANS, Feb. 6A New York lawyer, Cloyd Laporte, was awarded last night the highest honor conferred by the Fellows of the American Bar Foundation.

title: Melville's 'Bartleby' Transformed for the Screen
description: In adapting Herman Melville's great tale of Bartleby the scrivener to the screen, Anthony Friedman has moved the action from New York in the 1850's to London in the 1970's. He has changed his hero's occupation from copyist to bookkeeper. He has opened things up so as to allow Bartleby walks through the city on his time off, to permit some spoken personal thoughts (beyond "I would prefer not to"), in effect, to provide a bit of private life in order to round out the character, who is as flat as the walls of Wall Street in Melville's story. He has even gone so far as to make him a point-of-view character, whereas for Melville it had been crucial that Bartleby never furnish the point of view.I cannot imagine a less appropriate treatment of "Bartleby," or one less likely to succeed.
