And yet this movie does very largely succeedin ways that some recent, more reverential adaptations of great books do notat least partly because it has the sense, or maybe just the innocence to make of itself something else.That something elseBartleby as modern alienated manis none too promising. But as the bookkeeper sits at his desk and prefers not to work, and then prefers not to move, and finally prefers not to cat until his preference is for the absolute discretion of death, he keeps much of his mystery. For Bartleby is proof even against the communications of Bartleby, and that is the basis of his profound appeal both to us and to the good-natured accountant who employs him.From time to time Bartleby takes walks through London, and on these walks he usually sees, in order, paper behind plate-glass windows; trash littering the streets; great flights of birds leaving bare trees; people in alleyways and under bridges, always up against walls. These sequences, which I find very moving, do a good deal to establish Bartleby in a perceptible world, though they do not fortunately, explain him.The same is true of the principal performancesboth that of Paul Scofield as the employer, which is very fine, and that of John McEnery as Bartleby, which is beautiful. Bartleby is a person very nearly at the end of expression, at the end of mere movement, and I suspect the temptation to a kind of virtuosity of strained inwardness in playing him must have been very great. McEnery not only avoids such temptation, he also finds a way of effacing his character almost into the nonexistence that is Bartleby's privilege and everyone else's dismay. It is a stunning job of acting, all the lovelier for its quietness, and the best aspect of a generally impressive film."Bartleby" opened yesterday at the Paris Theater.

title: Japan Strikes Ski Gold
description: SAPPORO, Japan, Feb. 6The Japanese sent a 78man delegation to the Grenoble Olympics in 1968. The result: two eighthplaces. In all the Winter Games, Japan had won one medal, a silver in the slalom in 1956 by Chiharu (Chick) Igaya, who learned to ski at Dartmouth.

title: Bridg, Jersey Tourney Is Marked By High Frequency of Slams
description: In an average bridge session, one should expect one slam contract in every 28 dealsat least, according to the statistics of the CulbertsonLenz match played 40 years ago.

title: Premier's Tax Avoidance Stirs French
description: PARIS, Feb. 6Premier Jacques ChabanDelmas and the French tax system are both in trouble following only halfdenied charges that he used the system to escape taxes for four years.

title: AT HOME ABROAD
description: LONDON, Feb. 6When Senator Edward Kennedy said last October that Northern Ireland was becoming Britain's Vietnam, he outraged a broad spectrum of British opinion. The xountry's largestselling paper, The Daily Mirror, spoke for leaders of both parties when it said his call for withdrawal of British troops from Ulster was irresponsible, contemptible, mindless, asinine twaddle.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: A recent editorial, I am afraid, slights the work of the talented and dedicated staffprofessional and civil serviceof the Office of Administration, which, under Mayor Lindsay's direction, has made significant and longlasting contributions to the management of the City of New York.

title: Arts Abroad
description: AMSTERDAM, the Netherlands Piet Mondrian, the Einstein of painting as he has been called, would have been a hundred years old this year. To celebrate the occasion the Gemeentemuseurn in The Hague is planning a huge retrospective show of Mondrian's work around its own extensive collection of the artist's production, in fact the world's largest. Although Mondri aan (as was his name at birth) was born March 7, 1872, the show is scheduled to open in June to coincide with the opening of the annual Holland Festival of the Arts.

title: FERRARI FINISHES I, 2 AT DAYTONA
description: DAYTONA BEACH, Fla., Feb. 6The Ferrari factory team from Italy finished one, two in the sixhour Daytona Continental today for its second victory in two races of the 1972 World Manufacturers Championship.

title: COLONELS REPEL NETS BY 118106
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky., Feb. 6 (AP)  Louie Dampier's hot shooting paced the Kentucky Colonels to a 118106 American Basketball Association victory over the New York Nets tonight.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: I was shocked to read in Henry Raymont's news article and the Jan. 27 editorial in The Times that Pedro Beltran had been relieved, by the acs tion of the Peruvian Government, of the ownership and directorship of his newspaper La Prensa of Lima, Peru, with which he had been associated, with great acclaim, for so many years.

title: City Hall Notes
description: The man who wrote the book on governing New York City has taken a long view of the decentralization proposals being explored by the state commission investigating the city and found them an old Republican idea.

title: Sports of The Times
description: The Roman Colosseum is a pile of travertine and concrete, 620 by 513 feet, built by Vespasian and his son Titus in what had been the gardens of Nero's Golden House. The Nassau Coliseum is a fat concrete oval, 458 by 338 feet, built by Castagna & Son on what used to be Mitchel Field (spelled with one I because it was named not for the fiery Gen. Billie Mitchell but for John Purroy Mitchel, who as a 34yearold mayor of New York made enemies by trying to curb police corruption, lost a bid for reelection, enlisted in the Army Air Force and was killed in a crash of a training plane in 1918.)

title: De Vicenzo Wins at Caracas
description: CARACAS, Venezuela, Feb. 6 (UPI)  Roberto de Vicenzo shot a 64 today and won the Caracas open by 10 strokes with a 263 total. John Cook of Minneapolis took second place and Gene Borek of Glen Cove, L. I., was third at 274.

title: Teacher Training Curbed As Job Market Tightens
description: Several major universities, confronted by mounting numbers of applicants for teacher training at a time when there is a national surplus of teachers, are starting to limit admissions into their schools of education.

title: Grechko to Visit Somalia
description: MOSCOW, Feb. 6 (Reuters) The Soviet Defense Minister, Marshal Andrei A. Grechko, will visit Somalia later this month for talks on questions of mutual interest, Tass, the official Soviet press agency, reported today.

title: Lyrical Tones Mark Recital by Dichter
description: As a keyboard lyricist, Misha Dichter makes some of the prettiest sounds to be heard from any of today's younger pianists. His tone is unfailingly warm and fullbodied, his treatment of a singing line shapely and expressive yet rarely swooningly selfindulgent.

title: Nizer Assays Rosenberg Case in Film and Book
description: The United States v. Julius and Ethel Rosenberg: Guilty as charged, not very effectively defended and punished so harshly as to evoke questions about the cool administration of justice as well as compassion.

title: IRISHMAN REPORTS REBUFF BY LONDON
description: Dr. John O'Connell, a member of the Irish Parliament, said last night on the CBSTV news program 60 Minutes that he had unsuccessfully sought to discuss with the British Government proposals to ease the crisis in Northern Ireland and eventually to unify Ireland.

title: Bus Plunge Kills 6 in Spainl
description: SEVILLE, Spain, Feb. 6 (UPI) Six persons were killed and 43 injured when a bus plunged over a bridge near the town of Carmona today, the police reported. The cause of the accident was unknown.

title: Purchasers Report Gains In New Orders and Output
description: The optimism voted in recent remarks of purchasing agents is becoming more evident in the statistics covering January, released over the weekend by the National Assodation of Purchasing Management.

title: Rockets Beat Hawks, 120 113
description: HOUSTON, Feb. 6 (AP) Calvin Murphy scored 21 points in the second half and Mike Newlin was a perfect 4for4 from the field in the final quarter as the Houston Rockets rallied for a 12013 victory tonight over the Atlanta Hawks.

title: Purge Goes Deep Into Croatian Life
description: ZAGREB, Yugoslavia, Feb. 1 A purge of Croatian nationalists is reaching into almost every facet of life here, despite efforts by Government and Communist party leaders in Belgrade to end the twomonth crisis.

title: Menuhins Perform Beethoven Sonata
description: By the time they finished Beethoven's Sonata in G (Op. 96) yesterday afternoon, Yehudi and Hephzibah Menuhin fully deserved to be appearing under the Great Performers at Philharmonic Hall banner. The Beethoven closed a violinandpiano recital by the renowned siblings, and the performance turned into one of genuine warmth, rich detail and sophistication. Mr. Menuhin had been somewhat off form earlier, in the Brahms Sonata in A (Op. 100), but improved immensely as the program progressed.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: Percy Sutton's reaction after L'Aurore's description of the perils of New York missed a good point.

title: Nyack Motor Inn Robbed
description: NYACK, N. Y., Feb. 6A man wearing a stocking mask took $4,000 at gunpoint from the cashier at the Tappan Zee Motor Inn here at 6 o'clock this morning. The inn, adjacent to the state thruway, was robbed several times last year.

title: Senate's Inaction Exasperates Leaders
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 6Nearly three weeks after reconvening, the Senate is plagued by constant absenteeism, bogged down in a debate over a civil rights bill it routinely passed in 1970 and falling rapidly behind its legislative schedule.

title: The S.E.C.'s Halfway House
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission's longawaited report on market structure moves toward greater competition within a more closely integrated national securities market. But, by seeking to compromise the toughest issues, the S.E.C. may have intensified the problem it wants to solve.

title: Conservative Group Says 9 in Congress Score 100%
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 (AP) Americans for Constitutional Action, a conservative group, said today that nine members of Congress  all Republicans had perfect voting records on key issues last year.

title: White America in Harlem
description: In White America, the Martin B. Duberman play, will open Friday at the Harlem School of the Arts Community Theater, 651 St. Nicholas Avenue, for a run of three weekends. Dorothy Maynor is the producer and Owen Dodson the director.

title: Bridge: L. I. Group Defeats Students For Swiss Team Championship
description: The Swiss team championship played over the weekend in the Greater New York Bridge Association's fragmented sectional tournament was run on unusual lines. One hundred forty one teams competed in 14 clubs and attempted to qualify for two area finals, one, in Manhattan and one on Long Island.

title: EXCHANGES READY FOR GOLD TRADING
description: Two commodity exchanges in New York and the Chicago Board of Trade are ready to establish a futures market in gold as soon as the Congress repeals a section of the Gold Reserve Act of 1934 that has prohibited the private ownership of gold in the United States.

title: BIG BOARD LOWER AS TRADING SLIPS
description: Stock prices retreated yesterday, with numerous glamour issues sharing in the weakness, as volume also fell on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Enemy Uses Rockets
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Feb. 7 (AP)Enemy forces carried out brief rocket attacks today in the Central Highlands. American and South Vietnamese officials have been predicting a North Vietnamese offensive, this month.

title: Attacks Near Angkor
description: PNOMPENH, Cambodia, Feb. 7 (AP)North Vietnamese and Vietcong troops continued their attacks on Cambodian positions less than two miles from the temples at Angkor. The Cambodian command reported one Cambodian soldier killed and 10 wounded at a forward post near Siemreap, a former tourist center three miles from the ruins, which are Cambodia's most precious art treasures.

title: Janet Lynn a Free Skater With MovieStar Quality
description: SAPPORO, Japan, Feb. 7Janet Lynn came on the ice late in the freeskating program. She was in fourth place after two days of the compulsory figures, hopelessly behind the world champion Beatrix Schuba of Austria, and a long way back of Julie Lynn Holmes, the American brunette, and Karen Mangussen of Canada, the North American champion.

title: Front Page 1  No Title
description: Front Page 1  No Title

title: Chaplin to Visit City
description: Charles Chaplin, the master comic artist of the silent screen, has agreed to begin his first trip to the United States in 20 years with a fourday stay in New York City, during which he will be grandly feted.

title: M.T.A. Bus TakeOver In Nassau Asked by Caw
description: MINEOLA, L. I., Feb. 7A takeover by the Metropolitan Transportation Authority of some of Nassau County's failing bus companies was recommended today by County Executive Ralph G. Caso in his State of the County message.

title: JAPAN PACT RAISES TEXTILE EXPORTS
description: BRUSSELS, Feb. 7 (UPI)The European Common Market and Japan today signed a cottontextile agreement allowing Japanese exports to increase by 12 per cent.

title: Health Insurance Plan Begins To Consolidate Medical Groups
description: In a major reorganization, the Health Insurance Plan of Greater New York has begun consolidation of its 31 scattered medical groups.

title: Handwriting Analysis: Key Factor in Hughes Affair
description: The controversy over the purported autobiography of Howard R. Hughes and the mystery of who endorsed $650,000 in checks from McGrawHill, Inc., has focused attention on the science, art or craft of handwriting identification.

title: Nixon Renews Retraining Merger Plea
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 7President Nixon, in yet another effort to give some forward momentum to his revenuesharing proposals, asked Congress today to approve a $2billion manpower retraining measure.

title: Panel's Republicans Say They Did Not Have Time for Review
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 7The office of Senator Harrison A. Williams Jr, made public today parts of what it said was a report of the Senate securities subcommittee which he heads. Republican members of the subcommittee challenged the authenticity of the report which they said was a mere staff study that they had not had time to review.

title: Forest Hills: Innovation vs. Red Tape
description: The, original design for the controversial Forest Hills scattersite housing project embraced a new approach to racial and economic integration through, an emphasis on more sensitive neighborhood planning.

title: BLACK LABOR LEADER SHOT DEAD IN MIAMI
description: MIAMI, Feb. 7 (UPI)  Joseph Caleb, head of Miami's 6,000member construction union, one of the largest in the nation was found shot dead last night.

title: Shipley Principal Named
description: BRYN MAWR, Pa., Feb. 7The board of trustees of the Shipley School in Bryn Mawr has announced the appointment of Miss Nancy E. Lauber as principal, affective July 1. Miss Lauber is head of Greens Farms Academy in Westport, Conn.

title: Subversives Unit Seeks Proof Red Front Is Red
description: The longcontroversial Subversive Activities Control Board has been working since July, 1970, to prove as a Communist front an organization whose chairman said yesterday that he had formally told the board 14 months ago that we move in concert with the Communist party.

title: U.A.W. in Suit Says Pay Board Illegally Blocked Contract Rises
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 7The United Automobile Workers announced that it had filed suit today against George H. Boldt, chairman of the Pay Board, charging that the board unlawfully blocked the payment of negotiated pay increases in the aerospace industry.

title: 2 More Japanese ExSoldiers Reported Sighted on Guam
description: TOKYO, Feb. 7 (AP)An American police Inspector from Guam said today that two more persons believed to be World War II Japanese soldiers had been seen in the jungles of Guam.

title: JURY PANEL PICKED IN BERRIGAN TRIAL
description: HARRISBURG, Pa., Feb. 7A 46member panel from which 12 jurors will be selected for the trial of the Harrisburg Seven was finally completed late today.

title: Abrams Favors Decentralization Here
description: Asserting that centralized city government had become mishmash and a failure, Bronx Borough President Robert Abrams led borough community leaders yesterday in appeals before a state panel for a new system of neighborhood government here.

title: 71 NET GAINS 14.5% AT ALLEGHENY POWER
description: The Allegheny Power System, Inc., eported yesterday a gain of 14.5 per cent in consolidated net income for 1971. Charles E. Finch, president, placed net for the year at $48.8million, or $2.15 a share. The share earnings ran 5.9 per cent higher than the $2.03 earned in 1970. Total operating revenues for the year rose by 12 per cent to $312.9million.

title: Typical French Movie Costs Under $200,000
description: PARIS, Feb. 7The typical French movie these days is shot outside of the studio, in color and at a cost of less than $200,000, according to statistics released by the Government.

title: Repairs to 63d St. Tube Section Due to Take at Least 3 Weeks
description: The Metropolitan Transportation Authority said yesterday that it would be at least three weeks before repairs could be completed on a damaged sec, tion of the combined subwayLong Island Rail Road 63d Street tunnel.

title: WALTER LANG, 73, DIRECTOR, IS DEAD
description: PALM SPRINGS, Calif., Feb. 7 (UPI) Walter Lang, who directed some of the most successful musical and comedies In motion picture history, died today of a kidney ailment. He was 73 years old:

title: Merger News
description: The National Kinney Corporation announced yesterday it had agreed in principle to acquire the Starrett Housing Corporation on a shareforshare basis.

title: Any Hope for Ulster?
description: There is immeasurable relief that the march of the Northern Ireland Civil Rights Association in Newry passed off without bloodshed. The sponsors wisely changed their route so as to avoid the center of the city and the British Army wisely refrained from moving to break up the procession.

title: France Asks More In Trade Accord
description: BRUSSELS, Feb. 7 (UPI) France today blocked immediate acceptance by the European Common Market of the trade deal worked out in talks last week between the Market's executive commission and William D. Eberle, President Nixon's special trade negotiator.

title: FANNY MAY STARTING NEW SALES PROGRAM
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 7The Federal National Mortgage Association announced today a new program of selling some of the mortgages it owns.

title: Strike Is Faced Again By L.I.R.R. Commuters
description: For the third time in less than three weeks, Long Island Rail Road commuters are faced with the prospect of a strike.

title: International Nickel's Results Plummet
description: TORONTO, Feb. 7Dropping the other shoe, the International Nickel Company of Canada, Ltd., disclosed today that its sales skidded by 31 per cent in the fourth quarter of 1971 and profits plunged by 84 per cent to 11 cents a share.

title: U.N. Pollution Talks in Geneva Boycotted by Soviet and Allies
description: GENEVA, Feb. 7The Soviet Union and its Eastern European allies are boycotting a United Nations meeting on air pollution here because East Germany was not invited to participate.

title: Sidney Meyers Fund Set Up To Aid Filmmakers of Merit
description: The Sidney Meyers Memorial Fund has been established, in the film department of the Museum of Modern Art honoring the movie directorwritereditor who died here on Dec. 4, 1969. The fund, according to his widow, MrS. Edna 0. Meyers, will be used annually to purchase and/or partially subsidize movies made, by deserving filmmakers. The fund is being raised from public contributions.

title: Bowler Rolls 890 Series: 290 Game, Then 300,300
description: ST. LOUIS, Feb. 7 (AP)Ray Orf, a 30yearold St. Louis bowler, followed a 290 game with two consecutive 300 games yesterday to break the American Bowling Congress record for a threegame series which has stood for 32 years.

title: India Sets Date for Bangladesh Pullout
description: CALCUTTA, India, Tuesday, Feb. 8 (Reuters)Indian troops in Bangladesh, formerly East, Pakistan, will be pulled out by, March 25, according to a joint communique issued today.

title: U.S. Price Support Loans Extended for 1971 Grain
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 (AP) The Agriculture Department announced today a oneyear extension of Government price support loans for 1971crop wheat and sorghum grain that farmers have stored in commercial warehouses.

title: Man in the News
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 H. R. Haldeman's red brick house in suburban Kenwood, Md., may be the only place in the United States where dinner guests don't come down with instant Indigestion when the host inquires: Would anybody like to see home movies? For the movies have all been filmed in the White House or wherever else Richard M. Nixon, M r. Haldeman's boss, has lighted during his Presidency. By the end of this month, chances are, at least one more canister containing an insider's view of Mr. Nixon's journey to China will take its place with the others stacked in the closet in Kenwood.

title: Court Orders Physician to Pay ExWife Declared Insane in 41
description: Relating what he called the melancholy chronicle of the naval officer's widow and the cad, a State Supreme Court justice in Brooklyn has directed prosperous physician in the New York suburban area to support a former wife who now is in a mental hospital in Austria.

title: DONALD A. POWELL
description: Donald Adams Powell, who retired in 1966 as treasurer and assistant counsel of the Union Pacific Railroad, died yesterday at his residence, 200 East 66th Street. He was 71 years old.

title: Irving Goes Before Grand Jury; Won't Give Handwriting Sample
description: Clifford Irving, the novelist who said he prepared the disputed autobiography of Howard R. Hughes, made his first appearance before a Federal grand jury here yesterday and refused to provide a sample of his handwriting.

title: Oven Bags: Potential Burn Hazard?
description: Mrs. Marlene B. Mosher of Loudonville, N. Y., was not the first housewife to have her oven burst into flame while roasting meat in one of the new transparent plastic oven cooking bags.

title: Many From Puerto Rico Flee City for Homeland
description: SAN JUAN, P.R., Feb. 7When Abelardo Tellado left Puerto Rico for New York more than two decades ago, he went in search of a better life than he could look forward to in place where per capita income was an abysmal $250 a year.

title: British Sailor Slain in Brazil
description: RIO DE JANEIRO, Feb. 7 (AP) Security authorities said tonight that terrorists shot to death a British sailor from visiting warship as he waited for a taxi in front of a downtown hotel last Saturday night. They said subversive pamphlets had been left at the site. The authorities interpreted the killing as an effort by urban guerrillas to cause a crisis in BrazilianBritish relations.

title: New City Directive Bars Hiring Bias On Homosexuals
description: Mayor Lindsay announced yesterday that a directive had been issued to protect homosexuals against discrimination in city government hiring and promotion practices.

title: NIXON'S AIDE SAYS PEACEPLAN FOES HELP THE ENEMY
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 7  A leading White House official, H. R. Haldeman, has charged that critics of President Nixon's latest Vietnam peace plan were consciously aiding and abetting the enemy of the United States.

title: ExGovernor Heads Cable TV Concern
description: The Teleprompter Corporationwhich settled its proxy fight with Jack Kent Cooke, California sports promoter, last Decemberannounced yesterday the election of Raymond P. Shafer as chairman and chief executive officer.

title: OBSERVER
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 7There is lot of evidence suggesting that the Monday we all grew up with and learned to hate may be on its last legs. For one thing, people with jobs of routine drudgery are getting in the habit of just not showing up for work on Mondays. The figures on Monday absenteeism in productionline jobs are a sociologist's delight and an industrial captain's nightmare. It is said that automobile executives in Detroit take care when acquiring new cars to get models made in the middle of the week, when there is less likelihood that the pistons will be left out.

title: MOONLIGHT BILL DERIDED BY FOES
description: A scattershot conflictofinterest bill that would prohibit 300,000 fulltime city employes from engaging in outside employment was assailed yesterday at a City Council hearing by speakers, including some who were listed as its cosponsors.

title: Zionists Name Mrs. Jacobsonl
description: Mrs. Charlotte Jacobson, who has been active for years in various Jewish groups, was elected yesterday as chairman of the American section of the World Zionist Organization. Mrs. Jacobson, who lives in Manhattan, was the national president of Hadassah from 11964 to 1968.

title: Mrs. Smith, 74, Runs For Fifth Senate Term
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 7Senator Margaret Chase Smith of Maine, the only woman in the Senate, announced today that she would seek a fifth term.

title: NASSAU CRITICIZED ON RELIEF SHELTER
description: MINEOLA, L. I., Feb, 7The Nassau County Commission on Human Rights criticized today what it called the almost tacit approval of prejudice, discrimination and quasisegregation by county government, regardless of party leadership.particular placement in the future, do not press for multiethnic populations.

title: Quiet Decay Erodes Downtown Areas of Small Cities
description: JANESVILLE, Wis.  While concern has mounted in the last decade over the plight of the inner cities in vast metropolitan areas, the aging downtowns of hundreds of smaller cities have been quietly deteriorating with little national notice.

title: New Saigon Demand
description: SAIGON, Tuesday, Feb. (AP)President Thieu, apparently annoyed by what he considers United States efforts to impose a Vietnam peace settlement, has told American officials that any proposals dealing with South Vietnam's political future put forth at the Paris negotiations must be presented by his government, official sources discoled this morning.

title: Dublin Arrests I.R.A. Aide
description: DUBLIN, Feb. 7 (UPI)The police announced today that they had arrested Anthony Doherty, one of the top men in the militant wing of the Irish Republican Army. Political sources said that the action could mark the beginning of a new crackdown by the Irish Government against the outlawed Irish Republican Army.

title: Vaulter Striving to Double Greek Track Gold Medals
description: There are no marble statues around Athens to salute Chris Papanicolaou, the only track and field athlete to clear 18 feet in the pole vault.

title: GEORGIA TO ELECT MOST DELEGATES
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 7  A new and potentially significant element has suddenly been injected into the early weeks of the competition for the Democratic Presidential nomination by Georgia's decision to elect most of its delegates to the Democratic National Convention on March 11.

title: Aide of Ford Fund Is Named Director Of Southern Council
description: NEW ORLEANS, Feb. 7George H. Esser Jr., an official of the Ford Foundation, has been named executive director of the Southern Regional Council.

title: Restraint Advocated
description: ZURICH, Feb. 7A contradictory monetary policy in the United States is creating international monetary uncertainty, central banking officials charged here today.

title: Sports of The Times
description: If baseball dragged its feet before breaching the color line and admitting blacks to the lilywhite big league preserves, it acted in no more backward fashion than the rest of the country. In fact, the breakthrough that baseball made a quarter of a century ago accelerated a movement, the extent of whose progress is still being debated.

title: State Towns Urged To Seek More Funds
description: Charging that the state was shortchanging towns in favor of cities, the New York State Association of Towns opened its annual meeting yesterday with a call for increased financial aid from county, state and Federal governments.

title: 3 Retailers Elected to Board Of Better Business Bureau
description: The Better Business Bureau of New York has elected to its board of directors the heads of three of New York's leading department stores. They are K. Wade Bennett, president of Macy's New York; Albert M. Kronick, chairman of Abraham & Straus, and Paul A. Salomone, president of Gimbels.

title: A dvertising:
description: Paccione & Launey of New York and Hurvis, Binzer & Churchill of Chicago have merged to become Paccione, Hurvis, Churchill & Launey Advertising of New York and Chicago.

title: Riders Group Asks Price Unit To Rescind LIRA. Fare Rise
description: A group of Long Island Rail Road commuters has asked the Federal Price Commission to roll back the line's recently imposed 16.67 per cent fare increase, saying the rise will add to air pollution.

title: Film and TV Music Writers File $300Million Suit on Contracts
description: Writers of music for motion pictures and television shows yesterday brought a $300million suit against leading filmmakers and broadcast networks to eliminate the contract system that they say deprives them of all rights to the music they create.

title: RETURN IS HAPPY FOR ROCK GROUP
description: Lighthouse, a Canadian rock group, made its return to Carnegie Hall Sunday night a happy occasion. Two years ago, the group was introduced at a free Carnegie promotional concert that was a musical (and nearly a career) disaster.

title: MRS. MICHAEL TODD JR.
description: Mrs. Sarah Jane Weaver Todd, wife of Michael Todd Jr., who succeeded his late father as a firm producer and managed his estate, died yesterday of a heart attack in their home on Cricket Lane in Dobbs Ferry, N. Y. She was 41 years old and had just returned from a family skiing weekend in Vermont.

title: Sapporo: Modern Japan, Frontier Spirit
description: SAPPORO, Japan, Feb. 5An icecold bottle of Sandeman sherry was placed on the table in the Sapporo Park Hotel bar as copies of the Third Period Hokkaido Overall Plan for Development were passed around. This spacious city, the northernmost big city in Japan, is a planner's paradise.

title: New Plan Is Begun In City for Handling Of Narcotics Cases
description: A new plan for handling narcotics cases went into effect in the city yesterday. It ran smoothly for the most part with little discernible change in the way these cases had been handled previously.

title: KENNEDY IS CHIDED ON AGNEW CRITICISM
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 7Senator Edward M. Kennedy's criticism of Vice President Agnew concerning a Legal Services case in Camden, N. J., was itself criticized today by Representatives John E. Hunt, Republican of New Jersey, and Mayor Joseph M. Nardi of Camden.

title: Tiger, Tiger, Burning Bright
description: The Department of the Interior did the world a service last week in proposing to add to its list of endangered animals all the great spotted cats not already included. Unless the Department reverses itself after a thirtyday waiting period, during which opponents may be heard, the ruling will go far to save the earth's remaining tigers, leopards, cheetahs and jaguars, among other seriously declining species.

title: Article 2  No Title
description: NAGOYA, Japan, Feb. 7 (UPI)  Shoichi Yoko!, the Japanese soldier who hid out on Guam for 28 years, will receive cash gifts totaling $5,235 when he returns to Nagoya, his home city. Mr. Yokoi is resting and undergoing tests in a Tokyo hospital.

title: American Muse
description: Marianne Moore was a natural, in her life style, in her art. She simply went and did what a lot of women today merely argue about. She taught in an Indian school, established her own fashion in clothes and was a fierce Dodger fan, knowing the score and the scoreboard better than most customers. She was as far from the popular conception of a woman poet, a clinging diaphanous presence, as anyone could be. She was unflinchingly toughminded: I'm happy as a hack writer, she said giving the muses a jolt. Challenged as to the number of quotations in her poetry, she answered, If a thing has been said in the very best way, how can you say it better? Asked why The Dial under her editorship was such a good magazine, she replied, Lack of fear, for one thing.

title: Enka Sets Price Increase
description: The American Enka Company, a unit of Akzona, Inc., said yesterday that it would increase prices by a range of cents to 5 cents a pound on nylon staple fiber.

title: Out Where You Can't Buy a Decent Bagel
description: SANTA FE, N. M.Pinon logs are burning in the fireplace. There has been much snow here this winter, and the woodpile behind our adobe is getting low. Every few days I go behind the house and split a few more logs, with the axe that my wife gave me for Christmas.

title: Swiss Downhill Role Caps Uphill Effort
description: SAPPORO, Japan, Feb. 7 In the morning, big, beautiful Ard Schenk of the Netherlands had won his third gold medal in speed skating by breaking the Olympic record in the 10,000 meter; 24yearold. SvenAke Lundback out of a hamlet named Signas in central Sweden made a farce of the 15kilometer crosscountry, and then the astonishing Swiss team took over the glamour event of Alpine skiing by finishing 1246 in the downhill, with Austria third and France nowhere.

title: Connecticut Panel Favors A Modified NoFault Plan
description: HARTFORD, Feb. 7 (AP) A special legislative commission decided tonight to recommend passage of a modified form of nofault auto insurance for personal injury.

title: H. Wickliffe Rose Is Dead at 75; A Leader in the Textile Industry;
description: SHARON, Conn., Feb. 7H. Wickliffe Rose, long a leader in the textile industry, died yesterday at his home on AmeniaUnion Road. He was 75 years old.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: I want to record my debt of gratitude to The Times for at least two bright spots in our dull, gray January. We were cheered by the valiant rallying of widely scattered readers to the defense of the humble brown egg and by the small avalanche of protests from outraged New Yorkers because another Britisher had innocently, ventured to praise their, city.

title: Nixon Has Phone Talk With Argentine Leader
description: BUENOS AIRES, Feb. 7 (AP) President Nixon and President Alejandro A. Lanusse of Argentina had a 21minute telephone conversation today. China was the main topic.

title: Obituary 1  No Title
description: Obituary 1  No Title

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: Some of my colleagues at Stanford have expressed their concern that Professor Franklin's banishment is a threat to any who may in the future publicly criticize the university's policies. [Letter Jan. 26.] It would be deplorable if other institutions overreacted to provocations that fall within the pale of legitimate criticism.

title: PATTERSON PASSES EXAMS FOR BATTLE
description: Floyd Patterson, former heavyweight champion, and Oscar Bonavena of Argentina reported to Madison Square Garden yesterday for their prefight physical, a requirement for their scheduled bout Friday night in the Garden.

title: Treasury Bill Rates Fell at Weekly Sale
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 Yields on United States Treasury bills fell sharply in the Government's weekly competitive sale today of these shortterm securities.

title: Bar Group Supports Eased Abortions
description: NEW ORLEANS, Feb. 7The American Bar Association endorsed today a uniform statute to permit women to obtain abortions upon demand. The association, however, rejected a uniform nofault divorce law.

title: SitIns and Roadblocks Set
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Feb. 7  Roman Catholic civil rights leaders, buoyed by yesterday's peaceful march in Newry, today announced the start of a campaign of sitins, picketing and telephone and postal disruption.

title: Slush Hobbles City as Emergencies Go On Upstate
description: New Yorkers slogged to work yesterday through the mushy remains of the heaviest snowfall so far this winter, while snow emergencies continued in a few blizzardbattered areas upstate and schools were closed in numerous communities on the fringes of the metropolitan area.

title: SADAT BACK IN CAIRO AFTER 4NATION TOUR
description: CAIRO, Feb. 7 Presidenti Anwar elSadat returned to Cairo today from a fiveday tour that took him to Moscow in quest of more weaponry and then to Yugoslavia, Syria and Libya for further consultations on the deadlocked ArabIsraeli conflict.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: Carbon monoxide from cigarette smoke may be more of a hazard to the health of nonsmokers than indicated in the news story of Jan. 11. The article points out that breathing room air containing fifty parts of carbon monoxide per million parts of air may be deleterious, but it does not mention that undiluted cigarette smoke may contain 50,000 parts of carbon monoxide per million.

title: JERSEY TAX PANEL AGREES ON A PLAN FOR $1.5BILLION
description: TRENTON, Feb. 7Gov. William T. Cahill's tax policy committee was reported tonight to have agreed on a $1.5billion tax package for New Jersey that includes a graduated state income tax and a statewide property tax.

title: Vietnam Debate
description: Resumption of secret negotiations undoubtedly is essential if the Vietnam war is to be ended. But an informed public opinion in the United States and the vigorous discussion now under way are equally important to keep the negotiations above board. The open debate between Hanoi and Washington is contributing to that end. The latest RogersXuan Thuy exchange, on top of earlier revelations about last year's secret talks, has put Americans in a better position than ever before to judge the private negotiating positions of both sides.

title: BRITISH WILL MAKE METRIC SHIFT IN 75
description: LONDON, Feb. 7 (UPI)Britain will follow up her changeover to a decimal monetary system by switching to a metric system of weights and measurements in 1975, the Government announced today.

title: Books of The Times
description: Very odd. After finishing Helen Yglesies's first novel. The HoughtonMifflinLiteraryFellowshipAwardwinning How She Died, my first impulse was to put aside and forget it as quickly as possible. It had aroused any number of unpleasant feelings in merevulsion at the dying heroine's cancer, exasperation with her friends disorganized attempts to help her, frustration over everyone's inability to cope, annoyance at the story's refusal to soar above the muddled heads of its charactersand my inclination was to dismiss the whole business as a bad piece of work. But as I tried to put the book away, I was troubled by an unusual feeling that it was not the author's lack of skill or the failure of her imaginaion that had alienated me; it was the people themselves and the conditions of their lives. And as time passed, the novel smoldered in my memory like a burn, growing more painful even as it began to heal.

title: NIXON AIDE SEES JOBLESS CUTBACK
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 7President Nixon's chief economic adviser told Congress today that the Administration has initiated the strongest program to reduce unemployment that there has ever been in this country.

title: PRESIDENT SIGNS FOREIGN AID BILL
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 7President Nixon signed into law today a muchdelayed foreign aid authorization bill, but he protested that it cut the foreign assistance program too deeply and imposed too many legislative restrictions on the executive branch.

title: NEWSMEN NAMED FOR TRIP TO CHINA
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 7The White House released tonight the names of 87 newsmen, commentators and technicians who will accompany President Nixon on his trip to China later this month.

title: Galanos Makes It Look Easy
description: Quite a long time agoit was a little after World War I  Gabrielle Chanel won fame and fortune by putting her clients into little black jersey dresses so they looked like their maids. Well, maids have all but disappeared, even for the wellheeled clients of James Galanos, but he has something of the same idea up his sleeve.

title: Teachers to Return Today In Madison Township
description: MADISON TOWNSHIP, N.J., Tuesday, Feb. 8The Madison Township Education Association, which represents teachers who have been on a twoweek strike here, said early this morning that the walkout would end and that teachers would be back in their classrooms today.

title: Portuguese List Enemy Toll
description: BISSAU, Portuguese Guinea, Feb. 7 (Agence FrancePresse) Portuguese farces today reported having killed 21 guerrillas and captured 10 between Jan. 16 and 31 in Portuguese Guinea. The Portuguese communiqu said one Portuguese soldier died in combat during the period.

title: MRS. JEAN SPARBER, NEW JERSEY EDITOR
description: MORRISTOWN, N. J., FO,. Mrs. Jean Weinstein Sparber, editor, writer and social worker, died Friday of cancer in Morristown Memorial Hospital. She was 48 years old and lived at 96 Ogden Place.

title: Dollar Worries Japan
description: TOKYO, Feb. 7Japunese officials are showing concern over the weakness of the dollar and the strength of the yen in the Tokyo foreign exchange market.

title: Physicist Receives Einstein Award
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 (AP)Dr. Eugene Paul Wigner, 69 years old, of Princeton University, one of the scientists who helped start the American project to build the atomic bomb, was named today the winner of the Albert Einstein Award for outstanding contributions to the physical sciences.

title: Stage:Thomas,Poet Too
description: Some artists are their own best creations and sweetest memorials, especially perhaps those roaring boys with selfdestruction in their very fingernails who became dying legends in their own deathtime. Dylan Thomas was one of those.

title: New Approach to No Fault
description: State Senator Bernard G. Gordon, chairman of the Senate Insurance Committee, has introduced a good plan for nofault automobile insurance that somewhat modifies Governor Rockefeller's excellent proposal but preserves its most vital features.

title: New CrimeLitter Cleanup Pledged in Midtown Area
description: Mayor Lindsay announced yesterday that the Police and Sanitation Departments would saturate Central Manhattan, including Times Square, with personnel and facilities in a campaign to free the area of crime and litter. The campaign is to begin immediately.

title: Chou Said to Bar U.S. Visit in View of Taiwan Tie
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 7Premier Chou Enlai was reported today to have taken the position that he would never come to the United States or the United Nations so long as the United States maintained diplomatic relations with Nationalist China.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: It's rather ironic that The Times for Feb. 1 placed side by side one article about the failure of education to respond to businesslike applications and another about New York City's new approach to handling the multibillion dollar mess that welfare has become. Computers and mathematical formulas and organizational charts will be as unsuccessful in solving socialservice problems as they were in upgrading public education.

title: EXCHANGE HEAD SUES U.S. COMMODITY UNIT
description: Arthur N. Economou announced yesterday that he had sued the Commodity Exchange Authority, the Department of Agriculture, three auditors and eight individuals for $32million for allegedly trying to undermine the American Board of Trade, of which he is the founder and president.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: A sixth suspect was arrested in connection with the Jan. 2 milliondollar robbery at the Pierre Hotel.

title: Library Display Recalls the Year 1922 in Literature
description: 1922: A Vintage Year, an exhibition of manuscripts, letters, drawings, photographs and first editions from the Berg Collection of English and American Literature, will go on display tomorrow in Room 318 of the New York Public Library at Fifth Avenue and 42d Street.

title: Church Urges Benefit Rise
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 (UPI) Senator Frank Church, Democrat of Idaho, proposed today increases of up to 21 per cent in Social Security payments and a guaranteed income to wipe out poverty once and for all among the elderly.

title: British Lord to Seek Citizenship in Ireland
description: DUBLIN, Feb. 7 (Reuters)A British lord said today that he was renouncing his citizenship and returning his World War II medals because of the actions of British soldiers in Londonderry where 13 civil rights demonstrating died last week.

title: An Apartment's Sales Stopped Here
description: Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz obtained an injunction in State Supreme Court yesterday barring further sales of apartments in Cadman Towers, a MitchellLama project now under construction In Brooklyn Heights.

title: Pirandello's Son Dies
description: ROME, Feb. 7 (AP)Stefano Pirandello, son of Luigi Pirandello, the playwright, and himself a playwright under the pen name of Stefano Landi, dies Saturday. He was 76 years old.

title: FOE SAID TO SEIZE LAOTIAN OUTPOST
description: VIENTIANE, Laos, Feb, (AP)North Vietnamese troops reportedly overran a Government outpost in southern Laos early today as part of a drive to protect the western flank of their supplytrail network.

title: Audience Growth Stimulated by Theater Fund
description: The Theater Development Fund, which was founded in 1967 to encourage the production of worthwhile plays in the commercial theater, has evolved unexpectedly into a powerful and growing agent for the development of audiences for the performing arts.

title: IN THE NATION
description: CONCORD, N. H.  Broadbased tax is something of a dirty phrase in New Hampshire, the only state in the Union which has neither a general sales nor an income tax, and seems to like it that way. Nevertheless, under the pressures of necessity, the unwieldly New Hampshire Legislaturewhich has 424 members, almost as many as Congressis in special session this week to debate a question that is suddenly one of the hottest issues in the nation, tax relief for property owners.

title: Washington: For the Record
description: Activities. President Nixon signed the election spending reform bill. He sent a message to Congress appealing for enactment of a manpower training bill. He met with 24 United States Attorneys on drug abuse and law enforcement. Mr. Nixon received diplomatic credentials from new envoys from Mauritania and Poland. In the evening, he spoke to the Conference on the Industrial World Ahead.

title: Dryden Keeps Canadiens Afloat
description: We finally can see the light, said Ken Dryden yesterday, talking about second place in the National Hockey League's East Division. About two weeks ago it seemed we were on a deadend street. If we played poorly we'd finish third. If we played well, we'd still finish third.

title: Briton Bids Smith Explain The Rhodesian Detentions
description: SALISBURY, Rhodesia, Feb. 7 The head of the British commission that is here to sound out public opinion on the settlement that London has worked out for this former colony said today that the Rhodesian Government seemed to be breaking its pledge to permit normal political activity during the soundings.

title: ExBoys High Coach Still Taps Ghetto Courts
description: Severio (Pic) Picariello, the Pratt coach, pointed his finger at Howie Jones yesterday during the metropolitan basketball writers luncheon and said, If that guy gave me one player, we would be playing at Madison Square Garden.

title: U.A.W. Unit Backs Percy
description: CHICAGO, Feb. 7 (UPI) Senator Charles H. Percy, Republican of Illinois, today was endorsed for reelection by the delegates to the United Automobile Workers Chicago Area Council. The vote was 215 to 6.

title: BLACK EXPO PLANS POLITICAL EVENT
description: The second annual International Black Cultural and Business Exposition here next fall will feature a news conference with the two major Presidential nominees, a few days before Election Day, local organizers of the event announced yesterday.

title: Notes on People
description: Kenneth Rush, the United States Ambassador to West Germany for the last two and a half years, said goodby with a review of the Army's Berlin brigade at Tempelhof Airport in Berlin and a pledge of a continuing American presence in the former German capital. Mr. Rush is returning to the United States to become Deputy Secretary, of Defense.

title: LONGTERM RATES ON BONDS CLIMB
description: Longterm interest rates continued to climb yesterday as several investment banking groups underwriting new corporate bonds decided to give up the ghost.

title: Market Place: A Challenge To Solitron
description: There was a time, not so long ago, when Solitron Devices, Inc., was a force to be reckoned with. The Amphenol Corporation's management cringed when Solitron, a highflying maker of semiconductor products, Picked up a massive block of the lessglamorous Chicago company's shares with the object a shotgun wedding.

title: Reed's Left Knee Placed In a Cast for Six Weeks
description: Dr. Andrew H. Patterson, the Knicks team doctor, placed a cylindrical walking cast on Willis Reed's left leg yesterday. The cast, from the middle of his thigh to about five inches above the ankle, will immoblize the Knick captain's knee for six weeks. After that, Reed will begin a series of graduated exercises.

title: A dvertising:
description: After what has to be the largest physical move by an ad agency in the entire history of the world, Ted Bates & Co. opened its doors yesterday morning on beautiful downtown Times Square.

title: Soviet Praises the Work of Job. Bureausl
description: MOSCOW, Feb. 7 Soviet authorities, who take the official view that unemployment does not exist in this country, report that a relatively new network of employment bureaus is successfully reducing the time it takes workers to find new jobs.

title: 1776 Closes Sunday
description: 1776, the Peter StoneSherman Edwards musical, will give its final performance at the Majestic Theater on Sunday afternoon. The Stuart Ostrow production will have played 1,217 performances on Broadway.

title: STEEL PRODUCTION DOWN 0.6% IN WEEK
description: Steel production for the week ended Feb. 5 slipped to 2,345,000 net tons, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday. This was a decline of 0.6 per cent from the 2,358,000 tons produced in the preceding week.

title: Advertised Retail Prices Rose 3.44% in December
description: Prices advertised by department, specialty and general merchandise stores in December averaged 3.44 per cent higher than in December, 1970, according to the Bureau of Advertising, a division of the American Newspaper Publishers Association.

title: Woman Gets Post at Auto Maker
description: The most astonished executive at General Motors yesterday was Marguerite Novelli. She had just been named an assistant secretary of the General Motors Corporation, the highest executive rank ever attained by a woman in the automobile company.

title: W. H. MULLEN DEAD; PUBLICIST WAS 69
description: W. H. Mullen, director of the Magazine Advertising Bureau from 1943 to 1961, died Saturday of a bronchial infection and heart failure at Fairview Hospital in Great Barrington, Mass. He was 69 years old.

title: Manhattan Cable TV Viewers Get Newscast Catered to Area
description: These days when Henry A. Kissinger, Vietnam, Democratic Presidential candidates and l'affaire Howard Hughes dominate television newscasts, group of viewers in northern Manhattan is being served a very different video menu.

title: Eagle Protection Bill Passes
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 (AP)The House voted 352 to 7 today to stiffen penalties for shooting or poisoning bald and golden eagles without special permits. The bill, which now goes to the Senate, would set maximum penalties of one year in prison and a $5,000 fine for each violation, plus forfeiture of any vehicles, aircraft or other equipment used by the, violator.

title: PRISONERS UNION FORMED UPSTATE
description: The formation of the first prisoners union in the country by inmates of Green Haven Prison at Stormville, N.Y.was announced here yesterday.

title: A. & S. WILL OPEN ON TWO HOLIDAYS
description: Labor Day and Memorial Day, holidays on which business is usually at a standstill, may soon become active shopping days as a result of a decision by New York's second largest retailer to open for business this year on both days.

title: MEDICATION IS TOPIC AT HARNESS MEETING
description: BOCA RATON, Fla., Feb. 7Controlled medication for race horses and the elimination of undisclosed ownerships or fronts for undesirable persons were two of the topics discussed today at the annual convention of the Harness Tracks of America.

title: Bond Cut in Water Plot
description: CHICAGO, Feb. 7 (AP)Bond for one of two young men charged with conspiring to commit murder by poisoning Chicago's water supply was reduced from $250,000 to $50,000 today by the Illinois Appellate Court. The court reduced bond for Steve Pera, 18 years old, of suburban Evanston. Bond for Allen Schl.vandner, 19, of Chicago, remained at $250,000.

title: Benny Baker for Nanette
description: Benny Baker has taken over the role of the Bible publisher, created by Jack Gilford, in No, No, Nanette, which is at the 46th Street Theatre. The comedian, who has appeared in more than 75 films, was last seen here in The Front Page, presented in 1946.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: Senator Mark O. Hatfield visited the Soviet Union as a member of the U.S. Delegation to the Sixth Dartmouth Conference, held in Kiev. The Senate's Committee on Foreign Relations has published a report on the conference by Senator Frank Church, another member of the delegation, with an interesting appendix in which Senator Hatfield gives his impressions of the Soviet Union. He was struck by the contrast between the redcarpet treatment of the U.S. delegation and the tirade of insults to which they were subjected by academicians such as Evgenii Federov.

title: Strate, Hoffa CoDefendant, Will Be Paroled on April
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 (UPI) The United States Parole Board voted today to grant parole to Zachary A. Strate Jr., who was convicted with James R. Hoffa, former president of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, on charges of conspiracy and mail fraud in connection with the union's $800million pension fund.

title: Love Story That Began in Soviet Setting Unfolds in Great Neck
description: GREAT NECK, L.I.When we last left them, a month ago, Valerie and Deborah Kremniov, the stars of America's latest real life Love Story, were racing into each other's arms at Kennedy Airport.

title: Chou Said to Bar U.S. Visit in View of Taiwan Tie
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 7Premier Chou Enlai was reported today to have taken the position that he would never come to the United States or the United Nations so long as the United States maintained diplomatic relations with Nationalist China.

title: Executive Changes
description: H. E. Howard has been named vice president and chief financial officer of the George A, Fuller Company, builders, Raymond C. Daly, who had been president from 1956 until his retirement 1964, has been named special consultant and assistant to the president.

title: Aides Confer Separately
description: CALCUTTA, Feb. 7  The Bangladesh Foreign Minister, Abdus Samad Azad, held separate long discussions with Prime Minister Gandhi's principal foreign policy aides, P. N. Haksar and Durga P. Dhar, while Sheik Mujib conferred with Mrs. Gandhi.

title: Extradition Not Yet Asked
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 7  A State Department official said late today that no request had been received for either the extradition or temporary arrest of Mrs. Irving, who is a Swiss citizen. Warrants have been issued in Switzerland charging her and her husband, who is an American citizen, with suspicion of fraud and forgery.

title: Britain Beset by Pickets Brawls, Transport Slowdowns and Strikes
description: LONDON, Feb. 7 (AP)Picketline violence, transport slowdowns and strikes in automobile factories brought widespread disruption today to British industry.

title: CORNELIA S. PARKER, AUTHOR, DIES AT 86
description: Cornelia Stratton Parker, author of several books and former resident of New York, died Friday in Martha's Vineyard Hospital, Martha's Vineyard, Mass. She was 86 years old and had lived on Martha's Vineyard since 1969.

title: AMEX PRICES OFF IN ACTIVE TRADING
description: Prices on the American Stock Exchange finished slightly lower yesterday in active trading.

title: Thieu Is Upset by U.S. Position on His Resignation
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Feb. 7President Nguyen Van Thieu, who agreed to the American peace proposal that includes an offer of his resignation in the expectation that the Communists would never accept it on his terms, is apparently worried that the United States may be taking the offer more seriously.

title: Court Names Trustee to Liquidate S. J. Salmon, NewIssue Specialist
description: S. J. Salmon & Co., a brokerage house specializing in new issues, was placed in the hands of a courtappointed trustee yesterday and will be liquidated under the supervision of the Securities Investor Protection Corporation.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: It seems widely accepted by a multitude of nonNixonians that the first man to announce for the Democratic nomination would really be the best available choice for the job, in terms of forthrightness, political honesty and positions firmly established early in the game. However, many who feel that way have come to be persuaded that if nominated he just could not win the electionnot sufficiently glamorousand so they follow the crowd down to one of the nextbest men.

title: Cape Kennedy Chapel Gains
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 (AP) The House completed Congressional action today on a measure to provide land for a chapel at the Cape Kennedy Space Center in Florida. The bill would authorize the sale at fair market price of up to seven acres at the space center as the site for a chapel as a memorial to astronauts. The land would be acquired by the Chapel, of the Astronauts, Inc., a nonprofit Florida corporation.

title: News Analysis
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 7Describing his approach to form and function in architecture, Ludwig Mies Van Der Rohe used a phrase that has since become famous: Less is more. The officials engaged in building the Nixon Administration's economic stabilization program are apparently now adopting this same approach to what parts of the economy will be exempted from and what included in Phase Two wage price and rent controls.

title: Reserve Voted Easing
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 (AP) The Federal Reserve System began the year fostering a policy of sharper expansion of the nation's money supply to sustain gowth of the economy, according to the minutes of Dec. 14 meeting of the system's Open Market Committee released today.

title: Nixon Asks Businessmen Not to Complain on Curbs
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 7President Nixon tonight asked the nation's businessmen not to complain about wage and price controls but instead to adopt policies that would remove the need for such controls.

title: ENTHUSIASTS MASS AT SKI SUNDOWN
description: NEW HARTFORD, Conn., Feb. 7Yesterday's snowfall, from a skier's viewpoint the first halfway decent one of the winter, contributed to the unlikely congestion here tonightDollar Nightat the Ski Sundown area which had been on of the bestkept secrets in Eastern skiing.

title: HERBERT W. BEYEA, HEARST EXECUTIVE
description: Herbert W. Beyea, chairman of the Hearst Advertising Service and a director of the Hearst Corporation, died yesterday in Doctors Hospital. He was 76 years old and lived at 530 East 72d Street.

title: Neglected Refugee Camp in Vietnam Houses the Old, the Weak, the Poor
description: NINHTINH, South Vietnam. Feb, 2She is 70 years old and without relatives, and wherever she goes she carries a rusted Sir Walter Raleigh tobacco can to hold the rice she begs to stay alive.

title: Wood, Field and Stream: Hunter's Culinary Delight
description: CHARLOTTE, N. C.It had rained hard most of the night, pools of water were in the meadows, the swampy places were awash and the wind was raw, but the dogs found the birds and the shooting was good.

title: LILLIAN K. TRAVERS, Y.W.C. A. PUBLICIST
description: Lillian X. Travers, a fund raising and public relations specialist, who worked mostly for the Young Women's Christian Association, died yesterday in Bellevue Hospital, after surgery. She was 66 years old and lived here.

title: BIDDER TO PICK UP GARBAGE IS NAMED
description: The BedfordStuyvesant Restoration Corporation was identified yesterday as the neighborhood group that has a formal proposal for private refuse pickup in its area pending before the city's Environmental Protection Administration.

title: Government Through Gimmicks
description: WASHINGTONIt is always astounding and appalling when those who profess belief in the free enterprise system propose gimmicks and devices that are the antithesis of freedom in order to achieve a temporary goal.

title: Curbs on Sewage in L.I. Sound Urged
description: HAUPPAUGE, L. I., Feb. 7 A oneyear study of six of the largest harbors on Long Island's North Shore has recommended that no further sewage effluents be discharged into Long Island Sound west of Manhasset and that any further sewage discharges into these bays be timed according to the season and tides.

title: Kennedy Center Use Gets Mixed Review At Critics Meeting
description: The question of whether the John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts is suffering from an identity crisis came up for discussion yesterday at a monthly luncheon meeting of the Drama Desk, the association of New York theater critics, editors and reporters.

title: Egg Industry Sees a Doomsday
description: HILLSDALE, N. Y., Feb. 7  The news in the egg business is both bad and good bad for farmers, processors and distributors; good for consumers.

title: PARIS TO CHANGE OPERA COMIQUE House to Become Graduate School of Operatic Art
description: PARIS, Feb. 7The Opera Comique, Paris's second opera house, is to be made into a graduate school of operatic art, it has been announced by the Ministry of Culture.

title: Sinclair Weeks Is Dead at 78; Secretary of Commerce 195358
description: CONCORD, Mass., Feb, 7Sinclair Weeks, Secretary of Commerce in the Eisenhower Administration from 1953 until he resigned in 1958, died today. He was 78 years old and made his home at Cat Bow Farm, Lancastere N. H.

title: DR. JULIAN STEWARD, ANTHROPOLOGIST, 70
description: URBANA, 111., Feb. 7  Dr. Julian H. Steward, a leading social anthropologist, died here yesterday in Mercy Hospital of a circulatory ailment. He was 70 years old and lived in Fithian.

title: Miss Nadig Takes Giant Slalom for Her 2d Olympic Gold Medal
description: SAPPORO, Japan, Tuesday, Feb. 8 (AP) Maria Therese Nadig of Switzerland captured her second gold medal of the 11th Winter Olympics today with a convincing victory in the women's giant slalom ski race in a heavy snowstorm.

title: C.W.A. CHIEFS ASK RATIFYING OF PACT
description: BAL HARBOUR, Fla., Feb. 7  The top leadership of the Communications Workers of America, claiming a victory in principle, today recommended acceptance of proposed terms for settling the nearly sevenmonthold strike of telephone craftsmen in New York.

title: Dayan, in Washington, Voices Hope for Talks With Egypt Soon
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 7Defense Minister Moshe Dayan, of Israel expressed hope today that Israel and Egypt would begin serious negotiations toward at least an interim Middle Eastern peace agreement shortly.

title: 6 MEN PLEAD GUILTY IN PRISON RIOT HERE
description: Six men pleaded guilty Queens Supreme Court yesterday to charges of inciting to riot during the disturbances at the Long Island City House of Detention in Queens in October, 1970.

title: Nixon Signs a Law to Curb Spending on Campaigns
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 7President Nixon signed into law today the first important reform in nearly half a century in the controversial process of financing election to Federal office.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: In his Jan. 14 letter, F. S. King of Penn Central stated that my earlier letter had made several misleading statements concerning highspeed passenger train service in the Northeast Corridor. I can only wish that space might permit a detailed rebuttal or his criticisms, but I shall confine my remarks to just one. It is obvious that his letter is an attempt to defend the lessthansatisfactory performance of both Penn Central and Amtrak.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: In his Jan. 14 column, Realpolitik in Sports, C. L. Sulzberger suggests that we review the role of athletics in the Western world and make use of it as part of the political muscle of a country in order to enhance its image in the world community.

title: 9 Alabama Guard Officers Win Reduced Sentences
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 (AP), The United States Civil Service Commission said today that it had reduced a penalty against Maj. Gen. George R. Doster Jr., commander of Alabama's Air National Guard, from separation from the service to 120 days suspension.

title: Assembly Rejects Proposal Designed to Curb Conflict of Interest
description: ALBANY, Feb. 7A proposal that state legislators be barred from serving on committees that deal with bills that might enhance their business no bankers on the banking committee, for exampledrew angry opposition and ridicule in the Assembly this evening, and was withdrawn as it foundered.

title: DUQUESNE'S RODDY RULED INELIGIBLE
description: Duquesne, which has one of the East's best basketball records, lost its leading substitute, Dave Roddy, yesterday when he was declared ineligible by the Eastern College Athletic Conference.

title: Boston U. and Harvard Gain Beanpot Hockey Final
description: BOSTON, Feb. 7 (AP)Boston University, the 1971 winner, defeated Boston College, 41, and Harvard overpowered Northeastern, 83, tonight in the openinground games of the 20th annual Beanpot hockey tournament befor a crowd of 8,159 at the Garden.

title: Merck Increases Its Sales And Earnings to Record,
description: Merck & Co had the highest sales and earnings in its history in the fourth quarter and for all of last year, Henry W. Gadsden, chairman of the healthproducts maker, reported yesterday from the company's Rahway, N.J., headquarters.

title: MISS EVERT NUTS MRS. KING, 61, 60
description: FORT LAUDERDALE Fla., Feb. 7 (AP)Chris Biert; the sensational teenage tennis star, trounced Mrs. Billie Jean King, the National Open champion, 61, 60, today in their first meeting since their famed 1971 showdown at Forest Hills.

title: HOUSE APPROVES MEALS FOR AGED
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 7The House approved today a $250million program to provide daily hot meals for the nation's elderly. The vote was 350 to 23.

title: DAVID BERK, 75, LED FOUNDATION
description: David Berk, president of the David and Minnie Berk Foundation, died Sunday night at the Institute of Rehabilitation Medicine of a cerebral hemorrhage. Mr. Berk, who lived at 1075 East 21st Street, Brooklyn, was 75 years old.

title: Discovery of Smallest Virus Reported by Plant Pathologist
description: Discovery of the smallest known diseasecausing virusthe potato spindle tuber virus was reported by a Government plant pathologist at an international meeting of virologists here yesterday.

title: Curb on F.T.C. Sought
description: WASHINGTON, Feb.7 (AP)Senator James O. Eastland, Democrat of Mississippi, introduced a bill today to stop the Federal Trade Commission from breaking up current softdrink franchise agreements.

title: CONGRESS ACTIONS DIM HOPE FOR END TO DOCK WALKOUT
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 The chances of Congressional action to end the West Coast dock strike this week were greatly reduced today when Senate and House committees approved substantially, different bills that would order the longshoremen back to work.

title: A Reporter's Notebook: Embattled Ulster
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Feb. 7The 70minute flight from London to Belfast is crowded. Baggage is checked for weapons; women's pocketbooks are searched. The standard British airline breakfast is served: a cold slice of ham, half an egg, a tomato and rolls. Restlessness grips the passengers, who silently read of the 13 Londonderry dead.

title: Waldheim Offers Help
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Feb. 7  Secretary General Waldheim said today that he had offered his help to Britain in dealing with the grave situation created in Northern Ireland by recent civil strife.

title: S.I. Leaders Ask Return to Borough Rule
description: With nostalgia, Staten Island community leaders recalled for a state panel yesterday the days before city government was streamlined, when, they said, a telephone call to the Borough President or local political leader could get a sewer unclogged or a snowcovered road plowed.

title: ELIOT B. WILLAUER
description: WESTPORT, Conn., Feb. 8Eliot B. Willauer, an architect and an associate of the Eggers Partnership, formerly Eggers & Higgins, died on Sunday at his home, 3 Tar Rock Road. He was 60 years old.

title: Catholics Get Council of Churches Bid
description: An official committee of Roman Catholic, Protestant and Eastern Orthodox churchmen recommended yesterday that the Catholic Church in this country become a member of the National Council of Churches.

title: SHOEMAKER HITS COAST MILESTONE
description: ARCADIA, Calif., Feb. 8 (UPI) Solar Salute raced to a fourlength victory today in the $43,250 San Vicente Stakes and Bill Shoemaker recorded his 1,500th victory at Santa Anita.

title: MARKET ADVANCES IN BRISK TRADING
description: The stock market carved out another session of sawtooth price action yesterday, holding to its February pattern of small changes in the overall averages mixed with sharp fluctuations in individual issues.

title: Moss Again Seeks Chance To Study S.E.C. Changes
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 8John E. Moss, chairman of the House securities subcommitee, expanded his efforts today to keep the Securities and Exchange Commission from ordering major changes in the structure of the stock markets until his subcommittee has a chance to consider the proposed moves.

title: City Air Found 7% Dirtier Than in 69
description: City officials conceded publicly for the first time yesterday that one of the key air pollutants heresuspended particulate matter, or dirthad increased 7 per cent over the last three years despite steppedup control efforts.

title: Second Man
description: Former Gov. Endicott Peabody of Massachusetts has begun a gallant effort to force more serious public discussion of the Vice Presidency. Although recognizing that he is not likely to be nominated for second place on the Democratic national ticket, he has entered his name for that office on the ballot in New Hampshire. Mr. Peabody has also begun a speaking tour in other states to stress the potential significance of the nation's second highest office.

title: REYNOLDS FIRM HAS RECORD NET
description: Reynolds Securities, Inc., a major brokerage house, announced record revenues and earnings for 1971 yesterday in its first annual report since it went public last November.

title: ExGerman Aide Acquitted Of War Crimes in Poland
description: HAMBURG, West Germany, Feb. 8 (UPI)A Hamburg criminal court today acquitted Walter Becker, who is 74 years old, of charges of having committed war crimes in Poland during World War II, ending a trial that began in July, 1971.

title: Virginia Schools Obtain Stay of Merger
description: RICHMOND, Feb. 8  The United States Court of Appeals for the Fourth Circuit granted today a stay of a Federal District Court order requiring consolidation of the predominantly black public schools of this city with those of the predominantly white schools in two adjoining counties. It set a hearing on the issue for the week of April 10.

title: LORD PEARCE VISITS JAILED EXPREMIER
description: SALISBURY, Rhodesia, Feb. 8 (Reuters)Lord Pearce, chairman of the British commission testing the acceptability of the Rhodesia independence settlement terms, today visited R. S. Garfield Todd, the former Prime Minister, in jail, a British spokesman announced.

title: Edward A. Lovelock Jr., ExOfficial of Best Foods
description: Edward A. Lovelock Jr., former controller of Best Foods Corporation and controller of Mansion Hotels, Inc., at his retirement in 1967, died on Sunday at his home, 8450 169th Street, Jamaica Estates, Queens. He was 57 years old.

title: FIRM STAND TAKEN BY MUJIB IN TALKS
description: CALCUTTA, India, Feb. 8Bangladesh has emerged from a twoday meeting of her Prime Minister, Sheik Mujibur Rahman, and the Prime Minister of India, Mrs. Indira Gandhi, as an independent, selfassertive nation eager to cut loose from India.

title: Navy to Keep Its Academy AllMale
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 8The Navy will continue to bar women from the Naval Academy at Annapolis but will open its Reserve Officer Training Corps program to them as a compromise, Secretary of the Navy John H. Chafee said today.

title: Protest March Scheduled On Child Care and Welfare
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 8 A coalition of groups and individuals opposing the Administration's childcare and welfare programs as inadequate announced plans today for a protest march here March 25.

title: Coed at Oregon State U. Stabbed to Death in Room
description: CORVALLIS, Ore., Feb. 8 (UPI)A coed was slabbed to death in her dormitory room at Oregon State University early today. It was the third attack on campus coeds in five days.

title: Congress Gets Bills to Help Israelis Settle Soviet Jews
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 8 (AP) Bills were introduced in the Senate and House today to authorize the expenditure of $85million to help Israel meet the costs of resettling Jewish refugees from the Soviet Union.

title: LIEUT. RAYNOR W. ACH
description: KINGS POINT, L. L, Feb. 8Lieut. Raynor W. Ach, drillmaster and rifle coach at the United States Merchant Marine Academy here from its opening in 1942 until his retirement last November, died yesterday apparently of a heart attack at his home, 6 Bergen Street, Floral Park. He was 62 years old.

title: State Senate Votes to Extend Life of School Board
description: ALBANY, Feb. 8The Senate voted overwhelmingly today to extend by two years the life of New York City's interim Board of Education.

title: Advertising:
description: An interesting sidelight to Ted Bates & Co.'s move into the Times Square area is that the city is so pleased to have the agency there that it has installed a resident redtape cutter.

title: L.I.U. on Top, 7672
description: Long Island University withstood a late surge by George Washington and gained a 7672 victory at its court in Brooklyn last night. Ron Williams, with 24 points, paced the victory to their 10th triumph against nine losses, George Washington is 612.

title: Tax Proposals in Jersey Could Cut Levies on Real Property by a Third
description: TRENTON, Feb. 8A proposed $1.5billion state tax package would result in an average onethird reduction of New Jersey local property taxes, members of the Governor's tax policy committee reported here tonight.

title: SOFTENING URGED IN MARIJUANA JAW
description: ALBANY, Feb. 8  A state commission studying drug laws recomended today the softening of penalties for possession of marijuana and proposed broader state controls over narcotics and sedatives prescribed by physicians.

title: Mansfield, Berating Absentees, Deplores Record of the Senate
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 8The Senate majority leader, Mike Mansfield, publicly scolded the Senators today for absenteeism, telling them that their legislative record, to put it mildly, is abominable.

title: Arizona Democrats Decide National Delegation Division
description: PHOENIX, Ariz., Feb. 8 (AP) Leaders from the candidates camps, in preparation for Saturday's state Democratic convention here, have reached an agreement on the division of Arizona's 25 delegates to the Democratic National Convention.

title: French Woman's Pursuit of Nazi Hangman of Lyons Leads to the Arrest of a Businessman by Bolivia
description: PARIS, Feb. 8  In the spring of 1944, when Beate Kunzel was a 5yearold girl in Berlin, Capt. Klaus Barbie of the Nazi SS signed an order transferring 41 Jewish Children from France to the gas chambers of Auschwitz.

title: DOCK TALKS REACH TENTATIVE ACCORD IN TIEUP ON COAST
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 3Negotiators reached a tentative agreement today in the 123day West Coast dock strike the longest port strike in United States history.

title: Obituary 1  No Title
description: Obituary 1  No Title

title: U.S. IS CONSIDERING MASSTRANSIT AID
description: A Department of Transportation official disclosed yesterday that the Nixon Administration was taking a new look at the possibility of subsidizing daytoday losses on the nation's masstransit systems. It has consistently opposed such subsidies in the past.

title: Talks Break Off in the Malta Dispute
description: ROME, Feb. 8The talks here on Britain's use of mill tary bases in Malta broke off today in a mood of exasperation. No date for a further meeting was set.

title: Falseness Has Made Us Lonely& Lonelier
description: If failure is a kind of death, we kill ourselves a thousand times a day when we fall short of our own braggadocio. What is this love of style? Why is the beautiful confused with the good? And even now, on the lip of the Organic Age, why do we continue to praise the contrived? Why is it shameful for a person to be awkward? Why do we disparage him if he is inarticulate? What have we done to the man who, although outside the reach of change, is none the less a man?

title: HIRE BLACK POLICE, ALABAMA ORDERED
description: MONTGOMERY, Ala., Feb. 8 A Federal judge has ordered the Alabama Department of Public Safety to begin an immediate campaign of Negro recruitment and continue it until the allwhite state police force is onequarter black.

title: Hong KongPeking Phone
description: HONG KONG, Feb. 8 (UPI)Daily telephone service between Hong Kong and Peking will be opened for the first time Thursday, an official of Cable and Wireless Ltd. said today. The only telephone links between this British colony and China have been with Canton and Shanghai.

title: For Stage Tryouts, 4 Seconds of Hope
description: There are few insitutions as cruelly democratic as an open call audition for a Broadway show. Anybody can come and everybody who shows up has an almost perfectly equal chance to be rejected.

title: Brooklyn Rites for Marianne Moore
description: Final honor was paid yesterday to our beloved Marianne the poet Marianne Moore, who died here Saturdayat funeral services in the Brooklyn church she had attended for 34 of her 84 years.

title: Katy Industries, Inc., Explores Deal for First National Stores
