description: Katy Industries, Inc., the holding company formed in 1967 by the MissouriKansasTexas Railroad and now made up of a group of nontransportation operations in various fields, initiated yesterday exploratory discussions with First National Stores, Inc., in a move toward a possible acquisition of the New England supermarket chain.

title: Scene in a garment factory in Taoyuan, Taiwan. The Commerce Department announced American trade deficit in textiles of nearly $2billion, the worst in the country's history.
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 8 (AP) The nation recorded a trade deficit in textiles of almost $2billion last year, its worst in history, the Commerce Department said today.

title: A.B.A. Rebuffs Subpoena In Plea Like Newsmen's
description: NEW ORLEANS, Feb. 8 An American Bar Association committee, asserting a right to refuse to testify akin to some journalists refusals to reveal their sources, has successfully avoided answering a Federal grand jury subpoena.

title: Advertising:
description: The directresponse division of Ogilvy & Mather, which last month picked up General Foods Burpee seeds, has now been added to the agency list of one of the pioneer forces in that area of advertising: International Correspondence Schools.

title: Muskie Gains in Jersey
description: TRENTON, Feb. 8 (AP) Assemblyman S. Howard Woodson, Democrat of Mercer County, announced his support today of Senator Muskie for the Democratic Presidential nomination.

title: Boeing Gets Contracts
description: The Boeing Company was awarded yesterday $42million in Air Force contracts, including $40.8million for airborne warning and control systems.

title: SHELL CANCELS BID FOR GAS AND OIL RISES
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 (AP) The Price Commission said today that the Shell Oil Company had withdrawn requests for price increases in fuel oil, automobile gasoline and crude oil.

title: First of Attica Uprising Leaders Is Released, but He Fears Arrest at Any Time
description: Shortly after 10 A.M. yesterday, a tall young black man with a closely shaved head stepped through the small front door of the Attica Correctional Facility and surveyed the snowedin parking lot. He was Richard X. Clark, the first of the leaders of the Attica uprising last September to be set free.

title: Kuwait Finds Estimates Of Oil Reserves in Doubt
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Feb. 8Sources in the petroleum industry here have reported that Kuwait has hired United States experts to investigate a report that Kuwait's oil reserves, generally estimated at 66 billion barrels, are only about 24 billion barrels, sufficient for 12 years of production at current rates.

title: Pay Board Tightens Rules Affecting Merit Increases
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 8The Pay Board revoked its policy on merit increases today, and adopted a new, tighter policy bringing union as well as nonunion merit pay within its general guideline that limits annual raises to 5.5 per cent a year.

title: German Passenger Jet Crashes on Test Flight
description: BONN, Feb. 1One of two prototypes of West Germany's first jet passenger aircraft crashed at Bremen today. The Swiss test pilot, Hans Bardill, was killed when his parachute failed to open.

title: LEAFS BEAT BLOS IN FINAL MINUTE
description: ST. LOUIS, Feb. 8 (UPI)Paul Hdhderson scored with 53 seconds remaining in the game tonight to give the Toronto Maple Leafs a 21 victory over tangled in Caron's pads. When

title: Rusk Enters Mayo Clinic For a Routine Checkup
description: ATHENS, Ga., Feb. 8Former Secretary of State Dean Rusk, whose 63d birthday is tomorrow, entered the Mayo Clinic in Rochester, Minn., today for a routine physical checkup, his wife said tonight.

title: Music From Marlboro Concert Given With Women in Charge
description: The women were in charge at the Music from Marlboro concert Monday night in Tully Hall. Perhaps it was sheer imagination, but one result was that the performances of the four chamber works on the program seemed to take on especially gracious, sensitively lined and lyrically poised qualitiesall of which was quite appropriate for the music at hand.

title: Gold Rises Abroad on Talk of Easing Ban on American Baying
description: PARIS, Feb. 8Reports of efforts in Congress to link the dollar's devaluation with new freedom for Americans to buy and sell gold lifted the price of the metal in the major European centers by more than 50 cents an ounce in active dealings today.

title: J. CULLEN GANEY, 72, EXFEDERAL JUDGE
description: PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 8 (AP) J. Cullen Ganey; a retired Federal judge who presided, over the pricefixing trial of major electrical equipment manufacturers in 1966, died Sunday. He was 72 years old.

title: Richey Battles to Win
description: LOS ANGELES, Feb. 8 (AP) Cliff Richey was caught by surprise in the first set, then recovered to defeat Bob Kreiss of Bel Air, 57, 6.4, 62, in the first round of the $40,000 May Company tennis tournament today.

title: Irving and Wife Reported Silent As They Go Before Grand Jury
description: Clifford Irving, the writer who contends he put together an autobiography of Howard R. Hughes, and his wife appeared before a Federal grand jury yesterday, but, according to sources close to the inquiry, both refused to testify.

title: OTC AND AMEX IN MIXED TREND
description: Prices on the American Stock Exchange and in the overthecounter market finished mixed yesterday in fairly active trading.

title: Nader Suit Says Justice Department Encourages Election Fraud
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 8The Justice Department was accused in a lawsuit by a Ralph Nader group today of permitting and even encouraging nearly half a century of such wholesale, widespread and flagrant violations of Federal election laws that the Government itself had become the chief protector of corruption, fraud and dishonesty in the financing of Presidential and Congressional campaigns.

title: HAWKS TO OPPOSE RANGERS TONIGHT
description: In a game that may be more important to their emotional health than their. National Hockey League status, the Rangers face tonight the Chicago Black Hawks, the club that began the New Yorkers recent difficulties.

title: LABS OVERCOME KNICKS BY 107102
description: Brilliant basketball, and especially brilliant shooting, was the memorable element of last night's game at Madison Square Garden, in which the Los Angeles Lakers defeated the New York Knicks, 107102.

title: DANANG AIR BASE ATTACKED BY FOE
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Wednesday, Feb. 9 (AP)Enemy gunners fired more than 25 rockets into the big United States air base at Danang and the surrounding city early today, killing three persons and wounding 17, the allied commands said.

title: The Haldeman Smear
description: The charge by White House chief of staff H. R. Haldeman that unnamed critics of President Nixon's latest peace proposals are consciously aiding and abetting the enemy is, in the context in which it was made, a vicious smear. It strikingly recalls the hysterical, irresponsible cry of treason that paralyzed public debate and policymaking in the dark days of the late Senator Joseph R. McCarthy.

title: City Grants Fare Rises To 10 Private Bus Lines
description: A twostep fare Increase was authorized last night by the Board of Estimate for 10 private bus lines serving 428,000 passengers daily.

title: Noise Pollution Bill Backed
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 8 (AP) A bill to achieve a significant cut in noise levels within three to four years was approved today by the House Commerce Committee.

title: 12 JURORS PICKED IN BERRIGAN TRIAL
description: HARRISBURG, Pa., Feb. 8Nine women and three men were chosen today for the jury that will hear the Government's case against the Rev. Philip F. Berrigan and six other antiwar activists.

title: Lottery in Connecticut Will Begin Next Week
description: HARTFORD, Feb. 8Connecticut's new state lottery begins next week, with top weekly prizes of $5,000 and superlottery prizes of up to $75,000. The first week's ticket sales will begin Tuesday and the first drawing will be on Feb. 24. One $5,000 prize as well as a number of smaller prizes will be awarded for very $100,000 ticket sold.

title: U. S. Plays Down Reports Of Discord With Saigon
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 8The State Department today discounted suggestions of disagreement between the United States and President Nguyen Van Thieu of South Vietnam over negotiating flexibility on the latest allied peace proposal.

title: Charles Hart, Coordinator At Western Electric Center
description: RAHWAY, N. J., Feb. 8 Charles N. Hart, program coordinator of the management training program of the Western Electric Company Corporate Education Center near Princeton, died yesterday at Rahway Hospital. He was 63 years old and had lived in Belle Mead for the last four years.

title: Market Place:
description: There was a time when Benjamin Friedman, the selfmade man who heads Solitron Devices, was friendly with Harold S. Brady, the investor who now heads a stockholder protective committee that opposes Solitron's management.

title: Laker Backcourt Rated Best Ever by Sharman
description: Bill Sharman, the Los Angeles Lakers coach, went out on the limb last night and called Gail Goodrich and Jerry West the greatest backcourt pair that has ever played this game.

title: 10 INJURED IN BLAZE; 100 ARE RELOCATED
description: Four residents and two policemen were injured last night when a fouralarm fire tore through a Washington Heights apartment building.

title: The Dance: Borst Park
description: Frivolity is luckily at the heart of Merce Cunningham it is the stake that vanquishes the vampire of his pretentiousness. It gives his seriousness a difference and his unseriousness an excuse. Borst Park, which had its world premiere at the Brooklyn Academy of Music last night, shows Cunningham in his most playful, antic mood.

title: Rikers Prison Will Let Women Set Up Own Grievance Councils
description: A sixmonth pilot plan aimed at improving communication between inmates and staff members will begin operating at the Rikers Island Correctional Institution for Women on March 1.

title: JOHN N. THORNE JR. OF LIFE MAGAZINE
description: John N. Thorne Jr., chief of the news bureau of Life magazine, died of a heart attack on Monday while on vacation in the Virgin Islands. He was 56 years old and lived in Mount Kisco, N. Y.

title: Pakistan Says India Bolsters Forces in Kashmir and on Border
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan, Feb. 8 A top aide of President Zulfikar Ali Bhutto charged today that India had moved fresh troop reinforcements into Kashmir and elsewhere along the West Pakistani border and was making threatening naval movements.

title: Seton Hall Wins, 8984
description: SOUTH ORANGE, N. J., Feb. 8Ken House scored 37 points and grabbed 22 rebounds to lead Seton Flail University to an 89.84 victory over Biscayne College tonight. The Pirates snapped a twogame losing streak and lifted their wonlost record to 810.

title: REP STOKES HEADS THE BLACK CAUCUS
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 8 Representative Louis Stokes of Ohio took over today as leader of the 13 black members of the House of Representatives, all of whom are Democrats.

title: ALVIN M. BROWN, 78, OF JOHNSMANVILLE
description: Alvin McCreary Brown, a retired vice president for finance of the JohnsManville Corporation and an aide to Gen. Hugh S. Johnson as National Recovery Administrator in 1933, died last Thursday at his home in Washington. He was 78 years old.

title: Puerto Rican Leaders Say Remapping Cut Power
description: Several Puerto Rican leaders accused the Legislature and both major political parties yesterday of a callous, calculated conspiracy td disenfranchise the city's Puerto Rican community through gerrymandering.

title: Rates of Interest Stable At Fanny May's Auction
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 8Mortgage interest rates remained stable at the biweekly auction of the Federal National Mortgage Association, it was disclosed today. The average interest yield on the $63.9million of purchase commitments accepted was 7.612 per cent, compared with 7.613 per cent two weeks ago.

title: Debray Shifts Toward Allende View
description: SANTIAGO, Chile  Rgis Debray, the theoretician of guerrilla warfare, appears to have drastically changed his belief in rural and urban terrorism as the universal model for Marxist revolution that he and his hero Ernesto Che Guevara did much to inspire.

title: Black Representative Calls Colleague Leading Racist
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 8 (UPI) Representative Charles C. Diggs Jr., Democrat of Michigan, today accused Representative John R. Rarick, Democrat of Louisiana, of being the leading racist in this Congress and of opposing majority rule anywhere when the majority is black.

title: PASARELL SCORES A 3SET TRIUMPH.
description: PHILADELPHIA, Feb. (AP)Charlie Pasarell of Puerto Rico achieved a 67, 64, 75 victory over Fred Stolle, of Australia in the opening round of the $45,000 tennis tournament at the Spectrum for contract pros.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: Yongjeung Kim's interpretation of the current Korean situation in his recent letter seems to me neither realistic nor constructive.

title: Stage: T itus Andronicus
description: The violence in Titus Andronicus is all realizedno teething rages or intellectualized furies, but a succession of chopped limbs and severed heads. Shakespeare leaves little to the imaginationyours or hisexcept to invent diverse methods of corporal punishment. The play is tangled with carnage; seldom in Shakespeare has revenge been taken so quickly and so untidily.

title: Bulls Crush Cavaliers
description: CHICAGO, Feb. 8 (UPI)Bob Love tallied 30 points and Chet Walker got 26 tonight to lead the Chicago Bulls to their fourth straight triumph, 11490, over the Cleveland Cavaliers.

title: Manes Backs Senator Muskie for the Presidency
description: Queens Borough President Donald R. Manes endorsed Edmund S. Muskie for the Democratic Presidential nomination yesterday, calling the Maine Senator the man who can bring a new calm to a troubled country, new vision to a nation whose priorities have become blurred.

title: Mrs. Bohleber Wed To Donald Tansill
description: Mrs. Phyllis Brooks Bohleber, widow of William Bohleber, a patent lawyer, was married yesterday morning to Donald B. Tansill, a retired textile executive.

title: Quarter Aids 71 Result
description: Operations of the American Cyanamid Company last year resulted in a modest earnings gain on record sales with the fourthquarter a major contributor, according to yesterday's annual report.

title: Notes on People
description: Dr. Andrew W. Cordier, former president of Columbia University, has announced plans to resign in June 30 as dean of the university's School of International Affairs.

title: Net and Sales Surge
description: The Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company yesterday reported in Akron, Ohio, a 31.7 per cent increase in earnings last year on a sales gain of 12.7 per cent, both setting new highs.

title: PAY BOARD MEMBER QUITS BUSINESS POST
description: LOS ANGELES, Feb. 8Neil H. Jacoby, a public member of President Nixon's Pay Board, has resigned as chairman of the executive committee of Occidental Petroleum Corporation's board of directors to avoid any possible ground for criticism of the Pay Board, Dr. Armand Hammer, chairman of the board of Occidental, announced today.

title: Woman in the News
description: At meetings involving the top administrators of the school system of the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of New York, it is not unusual for the men to turn to a woman when they want a sharp, analytical evaluation of a situation. Whether it is a question of closing down a financially troubled school or improving the curriculum, that woman, Sister Elinor Rita Ford, is a person whose opinion is highly valued. So the announcement was enthusiastically received yesterday when Cardinal Cooke named Sister Elinor, who is 41 years old, as the superintendent of, the archdiocese's office of edtication the first of her Sex toy hold such a position hr any of the country's major cities.

title: Civilian Killed in Belfast
description: BELFAST, Feb. 8 (UPI)Gunmen in a speeding car shot to death a civilian in a Roman Catholic area of Belfast tonight as Catholic civil rights leaders made plans for a day of disruption tomorrow, exactly six months after the government began interning suspected terrorists without trial.

title: EQUITY FINANCING
description: The Lennar Corporation sold 375,000 shares of common stock yesterday and private holders disposed of an equal amount in an offering price at $37 by a Shearson, HanuniII underwriting group. Lennar based in Miami, builds developments of singlefamily houses in Florida.

title: Amazing Swiss End Long Ski Decline
description: SAPPORO, Japan, Feb. 8Marie Therese Nadig has her second gold medal.

title: Miss Holum Wins Skate Race, Giving U.S. First Gold Medal
description: SAPPORO, Japan, Wednesday, Feb. 9 (AP)Dianne Holum of Northbrook, Ill., flashed to an Olympic record in the women's 1,500meter speed skating race today and gave the United States its first gold medal of the 11th Winter Olympic Games.

title: WALDHEIM GETS PLEA ON OUSTED NEWSMEN
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Feb. 8 (AP)Secretary General Waldheim was urged by two news executives today to, reverse a Dec. 17 order expelling two Taiwan news correspondents from the United Nations.

title: DR. ALBERT DIMOND, PLANT PATHOLOGIST
description: MADISON, Conn., Feb. 8Dr. Albert E. Dimond, chief of the Department of Plant Pathology and Botany at the Connecticut Agricultural Experiment Station since 1950, died on Friday at his home here. He was 57 years old.

title: Income or Sales Tax Becoming New Hampshire Primary Issue
description: CONCORD, N. H., Feb. 8A special session of the state legislature opened here today to debate proposals for a state income or sales tax, with indications that the issue would spill over into the Presidential primary.

title: Tuna Shipments to Resume
description: TOKYO, Feb. 8 (Reuters)Japan will soon resume shipments of canned tuna to the United States, the Fisheries Agency said today. Shipments were suspended last August as a result of alleged decomposition of fish meat. The agency said the United States Food and Drug Administration had sent notification that an import ban on the tuna from Japan had been lifted.

title: Agnew Would Limit Role Of the Poverty Lawyers
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 8 (AP) Vice President Agnew says that poverty lawyers should not be permitted to substitute their judgments on social programs for those of public officials. He adds that this happened in the disputed Camden, N. J., urban redevelopment case.

title: Economic Analysis
description: In nearly all of America's major cities, there is a tight limit on the number of taxicab licenses that can be issued. The major exception is Washington, D.C., which is so well known for its plentiful and inexpensive taxi service that a spokesman for the American Taxi Association once complained bitterly to Congress that Washington was giving the entire taxi industry a black eye. But there weren't always taxi monopolies everywhere else. Edmund W. Kitch, Marc Isaacson, and Daniel Kasper of the University of Chicago Law School have been delving into the ways that taxi monopolies were implanted by businessmen in cooperation with municipal officials, and aided by the law courts.

title: Tax Rise of 1 Cent Is Voted in Suffolk
description: HAUPPAUGE, L. I., Feb. 3The Suffolk County Legislature today approved a 1cent increase in the sales tax effective Sept. 1 and established an Offtrack Betting Corporation, which is expected to accept its first wager in the late fall.

title: Times and 2 of Its Reporters Win 3 Polk Memorial Awards
description: The New York Times, one of its foreign correspondents and a member of its local news staff won in three of the 11 categories of the 24th annual George Polk Memorial Awards which were announced yesterday by the Brooklyn Center of Long Island University.

title: Stardom Changes Little for Student, 17
description: NEW ROCHELLE, N. Y., Feb. 8LThe morning after, the movie To Find a Man opened in New ycirk, Harold Daley, assistant principal of the high school here, went on the public address system to inform the school that yesterday one of our seniors achieved movie stardom.

title: &City Labor: One Up, One Down
description: The ratification by workers on the cityowned subway and bus lines of the New Year's Day wage agreement negotiated by their union leaders is a refreshing demonstration of civic responsibility.

title: Urban League Fete Picks Chairmen
description: The cochairmen of the New York, Urban League's seventh annual Frederick Douglass Awards Dinner this year will be Clarence B. Jones, publisher of The New York Amsterdam News, and Rudolph J. Schaefer 3d, hoard chairman and chief executive officer of the F. & M. Schaefer Brewing Company.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Considering the going prices of latemodel cars, gasoline taxes and parking rates, State Welfare Inspector General George F. Berlinger expressed incredulity yesterday when he learned that one welfare client had owned five automobiles at the same time.

title: Warriors Triumph, 111107
description: OAKLAND, Calif., Feb. 8 (UPI)Nate Thurmond scored 38 points and grabbed 23 rebounds as the Golden Gate Warriors overcame a 18point deficit to defeat the Baltimore Bullets, 111107, tonight.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: I sympathize with the wishful thinking of Professors Seymour Siegel and David Weiss regarding the benign attitude of Rabbinic Judaism toward women. (Letter Jan. 19.) The fact still remains that a woman's status under Orthodox Rabbinic Judaism as practiced in Israel today would strike fear into the heart of the most confirmed male chauvinist among us.

title: News Analysis
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 8An especially sensitive area of politics these days is environment, where reform inevitably involves regulation. And those on whom regulation falls may remember it in the polling booth during this year's election. Congress anticipated this maxim last year by talking a lot about environmental problems but doing very little beyond framing some major new water pollu tion legislation. The same electionyear caution was assessed by observers here as the underlying theme of President Nixon's environmental message to Congress today. Mr. Nixon had ample grounds for criticizing his audience as a donothing Congress environmentally, but refrained.

title: Bridge: Sacrificial Bid by Opponents Poses Problems at Duplicate
description: The problems posed by an opponent's sacrificial bid are much more delicate in a duplicate game than they are at rubber bridge or team scoring.

title: City Begins Sprucing Up Midtown Area
description: The midtown area took on a cleaner look yesterday following Mayor Lindsay's announcement of plans to saturate it with men and facilities to clear it of crime and litter.

title: New Attack on Solzhenitsyn Reported
description: MOSCOW, Feb. 8The prosecutor in the recent trial of a young Soviet dissenter reportedly attacked the Nobel Prizewinning novelist Aleksandr I. Solzhenitsyn as a spiritual emigrant hostile to Soviet life who had given his tacit consent to the use of his works for antiSoviet propaganda.

title: Chinese Airline Is Said to Get Soviet Jets
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 8China has recently received from the Soviet Union two longrange jet passenger planes that will help her begin her first European air service this year, State Department and aviation industry officials said today.

title: Pro Football Elects Ace Parker and Three Others
description: Lamar Hunt, founder of the American Football League in 1959; Clarence (Ace) Parker, a preWorld War II star for the Brooklyn Dodgers and Gino Marchetti and Ollie Matson, college teamates at San Francisco University who played for 14 distinguished seasons in the National Football League, were named yesterday to the Pro Football Hall of Fame.

title: About Motor Sports
description: In Mario Anclretti's words, 1970 and 1971 were dark years for me. I had gobs of bad luckwhen it rained, it poured. But Andretti felt the slump could not last forever, and I was itching for 1972 to begin. His luck turned at last on Sunday when he and Jacky Ickx of Belgium, driving a Ferrari prototype sports car, won the sixhour manufacturers endurance race at Daytona International Speedway in Florida. Even then it was a near thing. On the first lap Andretti discovered the Ferrari had a dead cylinder. There was no time to repair it, so the car ran the entire race on 11 cylinders. Moreover, fuel consumption was higher than expected, necessitating an extra pit stop.

title: Dead River Co. Names Chief
description: BANGOR, Me., Feb. 8Charles D. Howell has been named president and chief executive officer of the Dead River Company, one of the largest privately held concerns in New England, with sales of more than $40million a year.

title: Suspect Arrested 81 Times As Gambler Is Sentenced
description: Irving Hanerfeld, 60 years old, who the police said had been arrested 81 times on gambling charges since 1934 but never spent a day in jail, was sentenced yesterday to three years for criminal contempt for refusing to answer questions before a Manhattan grand jury investigating charges of police corruption.

title: Refusal to Block Busing
description: NEW ORLEANS, Feb. 8 (UPI)  The United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit refused today to block a school desegregation plan involving busing from going into effect next week in Richmond County in Georgia.

title: Books of The Times
description: At a recent reception given by the New School for Yevgeny Yevtushenko, I learned that the Soviet poet's books are published in printings running to hundreds of thousands. Then a distinguished American poet said that, when he was visiting Russia, he was ashamed to confess the size of his books printings. The novelist John Cheever got up and told a story about driving through a Russian city with Mr. Yevtushenko at the wheel. After dramatically breaking just about every traffic law, they were finally stopped by two policemen who asked the poet for his license. On seeing his name and recognizing him, they handed it back, crying Go! Go and write us more beautiful poems!

title: Draft Cancels Call For 11,000 Youths Who Faced Orders
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 8The Selective Service System officially announced today that it was permanently canceling induction orders for the more than 11,000 men who had been scheduled to report for duty in the first three months of this year.

title: No Comment in Capital
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 8The Department of Justice had no comment today on the reported subpoena.

title: Tickets for City Opera
description: Tickets for the 10week spring season of the New York City Opera at the New York State Theater are now on sale at the theater box office at Lincoln Center. The season will open on Feb. 23 with Donizetti's Robert Devereux with Beverly Sills appearing as Elisabetta.

title: Buckley Asks Firearms Bill
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 8 (AP) Senator James L. Buckley introduced legislation today that would impose mandatory prison sentences on anyone found in the possession of a firearm during the commission of a violent crime in the District of Columbia.

title: Commonwealth Entry Sought
description: LONDON, Feb. 8 (UPI)Bangladesh has applied formally for membership in the Commonwealth, a spokesman for the Commonwealth Secretariat said today.

title: Faulkner Calls a United Ireland Absurd
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Feb. 8Prime Minister Brian Faulkner bitterly attacked the Government of neighboring Ireland today and said that a long and bloody struggle would take place if the Roman Catholic minority here pressed for a united Ireland.

title: BEIKIN DISMISSES DEAN AT EINSTEIN
description: The dean of Albert Einstein College of Medicine has been dismissed by the president of Yeshiva University, the controlling institution, in an apparent dispute over the school's financial and operating policies.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: The Times of Jan. 18 reports that 200,000 Bangladesh women are outcasts in their own country as a result of having been raped by Pakistani soldiers because, according to Moslem custom, any woman so defiled becomes untouchable.

title: U.S. Assures Mindszenty It Will Safeguard Crown
description: VIENNA, Feb. 6President Nixon is understood to have sent assurances to Jozsef Cardinal Mindszenty that the Crown of St. Stephen, the thousandyearold symbol of Hungarian nationhood, would remain in United States safekeeping for the time being.

title: Gibson and Leonard Gain Baseball's Hall of Fame
description: Josh Gibson and Buck Leonard of the Homestead Grays were elected to baseball's Hall of Fame yesterday, one year after Satchel Paige opened the doors to legendary players of the old Negro leagues.

title: Washington: For the Record
description: Activities. President Nixon had breakfast with Republican Congressional leaders and members of his Cabinet. The President sent his environmental message to Congress. He had an afternoon appointment with Treasury Secretary Connally. Later Mr. Nixon was host at a reception for participants in the Jaycee Governmental Affairs Leadership Seminar.

title: SENATE LIBERALS YIELD IN DISPUTE OVER JOB RIGHTS
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 8Unable to break a Southern filibuster, liberal Senators gave up today on their fight to give the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission the power to order employers and unions to stop discrimination in jobs.

title: Unblocking SALT
description: Adjournment to March 28 of the SovietAmerican strategic arms limitation talks (SALT), after limited progress in Vienna over the past month, suggests that both sides are engaging in brinkmanship. The Kremlin and the White House both seem to be preparing to go right down to the finish linePresident Nixon's visit to Moscow in Maybefore striking the rough bargain both say they want.

title: Nixon to Seek Tax On Sulphur Oxides Emitted by Industry
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 8In his third annual environmental message to Congress, President Nixon said today that he would soon propose a tax on sulphur oxides emitted by the electric power, smelting, refining and other industries. This would be the nation's first pollution tax.

title: Snyder Paces Sonics
description: PORTLAND, Ore., Feb. 8 (UPI) Dick Snyder, held scoreless in the first half, hit 17 of his 23 points in the third period to pace the Seattle Supersonics to a 127119 victory over the Houston Rockets tonight.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: There is currently before the courts a case which primarily involves New York City firemen and patrolmen. However, the outcome of this case will affect every civil servant or aspirant.

title: DAVIS ST JOHN'S, HITS 1,000 POINTS
description: SOUTH BEND, Ind., Feb. 8With Mel Davis exceeding the 1,000point mark, St. John's downed Notre Dame tonight, 8675, before 8,434 fans.

title: Congress to Get Bill
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 8 (Reuters)The Nixon Administration is expected to send Congress tomorrow its historic bill to formally devalue the dollar by raising the official price of gold by $3 an ounce to $38.

title: INQUIRIES CONTINUE IN Sr. J. SALMON CASE
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission and the National Association of Securities Dealers continued their investigations yesterday into the financial positions of about a dozen brokerage houses that may have held positions in securities underwritten by S. J. Salmon & Co., which went into liquidation Monday.

title: 71 Farm Exports Set Mark
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 8 (UPI) United States farm exports reached a record total for a calendar year of nearly $7.7billion in 1971, it was disclosed today.

title: Big Board Approves a Plan To Automate Bond Trading
description: The New York Stock Exchange announced yesterday that its governing board had approved a plan to automate bond trading operations to improve service to retail brokerage members of the exchange and their customers.

title: BUCKS VANQUISH BRAVES, 126108
description: BUFFALO, Feb. 8 (AP)Kareem AbdulJabbar scored 31 points and snared 20 rebounds tonight to lead the Milwaukee Bucks to an uphill 126108 victory over the Buffalo Braves in a National Basketball Association game.

title: Merger News
description: Hill, Samuel & Co., the financial adviser to the Beecham Group, Ltd., announced yesterday that Beecham's offer to acquire the Glaxo Group, Ltd., had been allowed to lapse. Beecham and the Boots Pure Drug Company, Ltd., made rival tender offers of more than $1billion each to acquire Glaxo, the largest pharmaceutical company in Britain. Glaxo subsidiaries operate in more than 30 countries. Beecham's decision to drop its offer follows a ruling by the British Department of Trade and Industry last week that the takeover bids for Glaxo be referred to the Monopolies Commission. Under the ruling neither Boots nor Beecham is allowed to acquire any more stock in Glaxo.

title: RISE IN POSTAL RATE SCORED BY HEISKELL
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 9 (AP) Congress should go beyond condemnation of government interference with a free press and work to help make the nation's magazines and newspapers financially strong, the chairman of Time Inc. said today.

title: TV: The Enduring SucCess of Eyewitness News
description: In the beginning, about three years ago, some critcis and most competitors slapped the concept with the label of happy talk news. That was enough to trigger automatic smiles of condescension, especially among journalists, in and out of television, whose concepts of news were firmly grounded in the traditions of print.

title: Suns Down 76ers, 120108
description: PHOENIX, Ariz., Feb. 8 (AP) The Phoenix Suns outshot Philadelphia, 154, during a fourminute firstperiod spurt, but were forced to overcome 23 turnovers to gain a 120108 victory over the 76ers tonight.

title: Bankruptcy Papers Are Filed By Famous Schools of Westport
description: FAS International, Inc.the corporation that runs the correspondence courses known as the Famous Schools in Westport, Conn.and 11 of its subsidiaries filed bankruptcy proceedings in United States District Court here yesterday.

title: 9 U.S. FireFighting Bills Seek To Update Antique Techniques
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 8A Connecticut Representative introduced nine bills today to update firefighting techniques as antique as the bucket brigade, cut the enormous American death rate by fire and correct new perils such as escapeproof skyscrapers and furnishings that emit lethal smoke.

title: Hawks Acquire Bordeleati; Will Seek to Sign Schenk
description: CHICAGO, Feb. 8 (UPI) The Chicago Black Hawks acquired Christian Bordeleau from the St. Louis Blues today and announced the acquisition of negotiating rights with Ard Schenk, the Dutch Olympic speed skater.

title: FLORIDA YACHT RACE WON BY CELERITY II
description: FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., Feb. 8 (AP)Celerity II, fresh from the factory, sailed to victory last night in the St. PetersburgtoFort Lauderdale yacht race.

title: A Date for WithdrawalFrom Ulster
description: DUBLINIf the British troops were pulled out of Northern Ireland this month, civil war between Protestants and Catholics would follow, and the forces of the Irish Republic would be drawn into that war. The death toll in such a war would be far greater than anything yet seen in Northern Ireland, and the heaviest price would have to be paid by the Catholics of the Belfast area.

title: THE DIARY, COMEDY, IS DUE ON BROADWAY
description: The Diary, a comedy by JeanClaude Carriere, which ran in Paris for two seasons under the title of L'AideMemoire, will be brought to the Broadway stage in April by Arthur Cantor.

title: 10 Democrats Seek Nomination For the Governorship of Texas
description: HOUSTON, Feb. 8A wide open race is under way for the 1972 Democratic nomination for Governor of Texas and for control of the badly disorganized state Democratic party.

title: CANCER CURE SOON CALLED UNLIKELY
description: A panel of cancer researchers cautioned yesterday against any expectation of early cancer cures or prevention breakthroughs on the basis of recent research findings that suggest but do not provethat viruses may play a role in producing some types of the disease in humans.

title: BOLIVIAN EXILES ACCUSED OF PLOT
description: LA PAZ, Bolivia, Feb. 8President Hugo Banzer Suarez charged today that leftwing Bolivian exiles in Chile were organizing and training for an Infiltration attack against his antiMarxist Government.

title: 9 in Black Army Are Hunted in Police Assassinations
description: Police Commissioner Patrick V. Murphy announced yesterday the names of four men that his department was seeking as suspects in the killings of Gregory Foster and Rocco Laurie, the two patrolmen who were gunned down in the East Village the night of Jan. 27.

title: FOREIGN AFFAIRS
description: TEHERAN, IranRegional security headed the international casualty lists of the IndiaPakistan war and one of the most bruised examples is Iran, Pakistan's neighbor and partner in the CENTO alliance. From now on, the Iranian Government feels, this country must put minimum stock in pacts and maximum reliance upon its own military strength.

title: Nixon to Address Nation On Foreign Policy Today
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 8 (APPresident Nixon will make a live nationwide radio broadcast tomorrow morning in connection with his voluminous foreignpolicy report being sent to Congress, the White House announced today.

title: SCHOOLS ADVISED TO COMPUTERIZE'
description: A computerized and automated school system was proposed for the city last night by Isaiah E. Robinson, president of the Board of Education.

title: Santa Clara Aides to Permit Interviews of Angela Davis
description: SAN JOSE, Calif., Feb. 8 (UPi)Santa Clara County officials eased today a ban on interviews by Angela Davis after a strong protest in court by her attorneys.

title: Bartholomew Moynahan, Former Mayor of Peekskill
description: PEEKSKILL, N.Y., Feb. 8Bartholomew A. Moynahan, lawyer and former mayor here, died yesterday in Community Hospital. He was 78 years old.

title: 100,000 Austrians Welcome Barred Olympic Skier
description: VIENNA, Feb. 8  Karl Schranz, the Austrian skiing idol who was barred from the Winter Olympics in Sapporo, Japan, for allegedly violating the amateur rules, on his return to Vienna today got a reception that dwarfed all political demonstrations this city has witnessed since World War II. An estimated 100,000 Viennese gave him a rousing hero's welcome, lining the route from Schwechat Airport to the city.

title: COAST BANKS CUT RATES ON LOANS
description: Two giant West Coast banks announced yesterday reductions in interest rates covering virtually all categories of loans made to consumers.

title: City Aides Seeking Compromise To Ease Dispute in Forest Hills
description: The Lindsay administration, playing what one key city official terms the role of silent matchmaker, is trying to arrange a meeting between Jewish and black leaders on the controversial lowincome housing project in Forest Hills; Queens.

title: Island Venture Prepares for First Trip
description: When the cruise ship Island Venture leaves Pier 92 on her maiden voyage to the Caribbean Saturday, no one will be happier to put to sea than her captain and crew.

title: Sports of The Tines
description: Wearing a store suit, hornrimmed glasses and a smile that could light up Yankee Stadium, a sunny gentleman of 64 revisited his past yesterday and recalled what it was like to be the black Lou Gehrig on a food allowance of 60 cents a day. As Buck Leonard views it now from inside baseball's Hall of Fame, it was even better than being an airbrake repair helper in the Atlantic Coast Line shops Rocky Mount, N. C. They say, a man prompted him, that at $1,000 a month you were one of the three highest paid players in the Negro National League. A thousand a month, Leonard said, cud all expenses. I got expenses at home and on the road both. Room rent run about $6 a week and meal money was $2 a day. He interrupted himself with a delighted laugh. When I started out, meal money was 60 cents a day.

title: Hartford Session Opens Today; NoFault Insurance on Agenda
description: HARTFORD, Feb. 8Gov. Thomas J. Meskill, a Republican, will formally open the first annual session of the General Assembly tomorrow with the issue of nofault auto insurance looming large on the legislative agenda.

title: Newberry's President Resigns
description: The president of the J. J. Newberry Company submitted his resignation yesterday as the merger prospects mounted between that diversified retail company and the McCrory Corporation, a subsidiary of the RapidAmerican Corporation.

title: Connally Rejects Idea of Zero Growth
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 8Secretary of the Treasury John B. Connally told an audience of businessmen and labor officials today that he rejected the concept of zero net growth for the economy advocated by some environmentalists.

title: Soviet Fighters Capture 9 Of 11 Bouts With the U.S.
description: MOSCOW, Feb. 8 Soviet fight fans came for blood tonight and got it when a more experienced, faster, harderhitting Soviet Olympic team pounded its way to a 9.2 Victory over the American National amateur boxing team.

title: OSWALD SUPPORTS A SHIFT OF OFFICES
description: ALBANY, Feb. 8State Corrections Commissioner Russell G. Oswald said today that he would be willing to relinquish his role as chairman of the State Commission of Correction if the State Constitution were changed to allow him to do so.

title: Political Heat Rises in Finland
description: HELSINKI, Finland, Feb. 3The first heavy snow of the winter began falling this week Children skied on the small slopes on the outskirts of town, The temperature hovered near zero and a rumor circulated that a few nocturnal Finns actually went to sleep early one evening.

title: CHAPLIN DISAVOWS ANY ANGER AT U.S.
description: LONDON, Feb. 8  Charles Chaplin said today he was not as angry with his American critics as he was reported to have been when he left the United States 20 years ago, vowing never to return.

title: Barenboim, Bruckner and a Voice From the Balcony
description: The age of musical controversy is not dead. Daniel Barenboim stirred a mild tremor or two at Carnegie Hall Monday night by conducting the Cleveland Orchestra in a remarkably luxuriant and elastically phrased performance of Bruckner's Symphony No. 7 in E.

title: MILITARY JUSTICE ASSAILED AT TRIAL
description: FORT LEAVENWORTH, Kan., Feb. 8The judicial procedures used by United States military courts came under attack here today as a black exArmy specialist already convicted of one rape went on trial for allegedly raping and attempting to murder a second woman, the 38yearold wife of a white lieutenant colonel.

title: Invitation of Israelis Accepted by Brandt; Trip in Fall Is Seen
description: BONN, Feb. 8Chancellor Willy Brandt accepted an invitation today to visit Israel. He will be the first West German ??? of Government to visit ??? while in office.

title: IONESCO UPENDS MACBETH STORY
description: PARIS, Feb. 8The title of my play is Macbett'two t's, pleaseand it is not to be confused with the play of. Shakespeare, which many people must know, I should imagine, Eugene Ionesco writes in a program note. The confusion, however, is likely to persist.

title: PRICES OF BONDS RISE MODERATELY
description: The bond market, which has been in a slump for almost four weeks, showed some signs of snapping out of it yesterday.

title: Hostility to Americans Growing in South Vietnam
description: HUE, South Vietnam, Feb. 6 The charred nameplate from a Ford truck was tacked above a neatly lettered sign saying, in Vietnamese, Burn American cars to avenge the people.

title: India Denies BuildUp
description: NEW DELHI, Feb. 8official sources here denied the Pakistani allegation today. They said there had been no new military deployment since the end of the fighting in December.

title: FUTURES PRICES OFF ON SOYBEANS
description: Prices of soybean futures declined 1 cents to 2 cents a bushel yesterday on the Chicago Board of Trade and prices of grain futures were generally lower.

title: Britain to Curb Use of Power in Strike
description: LONDON, Feb. 8The British Government decided today to declare a state of emergency in the face of a threatened power shortage stemming from the monthlong national coal strike. The royal proclamation, expected tomorrow, will give the Government extraordinary powers to conserve dwindling power supplies. The decision was coupled with a new appeal from the Government for a settlement of the dispute, the first national coalminers strike here in 46 years.

title: P.B.A. DELEGATES REJECT CITY PACT
description: Police union delegates rejected yesterday a proposed, contract with the city that would have given 26,000 patrolmen a basic pay increase of $2,150 over 30 months, but would have required more of them to be on duty in the highcrime hours of 4 P.M. to midnight.

title: Gang Size, Pay Guarantee Issues in Other Port Talks
description: The size of work gangs and the guaranteed annual income appeared to be the major points at issue yesterday as Federal mediators, management representatives, and negotiators for the International Longshoremen's Association met in several ports in an attempt to thresh out agreements, on local working conditions.

title: 27Month Subway and Bus Pact Ratified by T.W.U. in Mail Vote
description: Members of the Transport Workers Union yesterday agreed to a 27month contract with the Transit Authority by a 3to2 margin.

title: If haus wif Becomes Obs., What Is There to Take Its Place?
description: In dictionaries of the English language, housewife not finding it easy to change her spats.

title: J. Ray McDermott & Co. Getting a New President
description: NEW ORLEANS, Feb. 5 (AP) Roger W. Wilson resigned as president of J. Ray McDermott & Co., Inc., because of ill health, at today's meeting of the board. He will remain director and chairman of the finance committee.

title: Shop Talk
description: Even BergdorfGoodman was nonplused by the turnout for its Givenchy Nouvelle Boutique show yesterday. With 350 seats, the store people thought they were amply prepared for all corners. About 100 more people showed up. They don't always let us know they are coming, said Leonard Rankin, the store's vice president as he surveyed the mob of well dressed custom ers shoving into the room set up for the show. What started as a sweet little operation has turned out to have an important niche in many women's lives, he said after the runway presentation, when the women milled around the shop and grabbed the clothes into the fitting rooms.

title: Five New Ministers Appointed By New Zealand Prime Minister
description: WELLINGTON, New Zealand, Wednesday, Feb. 9 (Reuters)Prime Minister John Marshall today named five new ministers in a major reorganization of his Cabinet and also created three new posts.

title: Congress Speeds Dock Bill Despite Tentative Accord
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 8The House and the Senate moved toward legislating an end to the West Coast dock strike today despite a tentative settlement of the dispute.

title: Manhattan Beats Rutgers
description: NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., Feb. 8Four of Rich Garner's 30 points enabled Manhattan to rally tonight to defeat Rutgers, 7877. With Rutgers leading, 7572, Garner sank two fouls and a jump shot leorenza Tarvin added two fouls, offsetting Steve Kaplan's late basket for Rutgers.

title: Malraux Thinks Mao Will Ask Nixon for Economic Assistance
description: PARIS, Feb. 8Andre Malraux, who has had a long acquaintance with Mao Tsetung, thinks the Chinese leader will ask President Nixon for economic aid as the primary item on the agenda of their meeting later this month.

title: Breakthrough on the Docks &
description: The interminable labor dispute on the West Coast waterfront has finally reached tentative settlement at the negotiating table, but the result can scarcely acclaimed as a triumph for collective bargaining.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: Dr. Murray Elkins Jan. 24 letter Illustrates again organized medicine's fantasy of deflating public pressure for healthcare reform by exposing statistical myths. It is a fact and not a myth that Western Europeans know how to count dead babies the same as we do, and while Continental vital statistics do indeed vary, the leading industrial countries in Europe, as compared with the U.S., all have lower infant mortality rates and higher male life expectancy rates at any age. No statistical dodge can, change that fact.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: Surely some questions should be raised as to why conditions at Willowbrook State School and Letchworth Village for the mentally retarded have not improved the last twenty years.

title: Oral Arguments Challenge Law That Permitted Chicago 7 Trial
description: CHICAGO, Feb. 8Lawyers for the five defendants convicted in the Chicago conspiracy case argued today that the law under which the socalled Chicago Seven were tried was in violation of the First Amendment's guarantees of free speech.

title: E.E.C. ACCEPTS ILS. TRADE PACT
description: BRUSSELS, Feb. 8Member countries of the European Economic Community accepted today terms of a new trade agreement worked out last week between the United States and Common Market negotiators. But the permanent representatives of the member nations agreed that the E.E.C. would tell the United States it expected future American trade concessions that were not covered by the agreement.

title: Irving's Home Searched
description: IBIZA, Spain, Feb. 8 (UPI)A twoday search of Mr. Irving's home here has uncovered tapes and documents pertaining to the purported Hughes autobiography, the police said tonight.

title: Blizzard in Jerusalem
description: JERUSALEM, Feb. 8 (UPI) A blizzard dumped eight inches of snow on Jerusalem yesterday and temporarily cut it off from the rest of the country. The snowfall was the heaviest since 1968. Sunshine and intermittent rain turned the snow to slush today; the police said traffic was back to normal.

title: Executive Changes
description: Donald E. Procknow, president and chief administrative officer of the Western Electric Company, has been named chief executive officer, effective March 1, when Harvey G. Mehlhouse, chairman of the board, retires. The latter will continue as a member of the board but the office of chairman will not be filled. James S. Herbert, vice president, Safeguard System, will be promoted to executive vice president of Western Electric and will succeed Arthur P. Clow, when the latter retires on May 31. Mr. Herbert will be succeeded in his old post by William L. Opdyke. Also appointed were Quentin W. Wiest, who becomes vice president administration, succeeding Joseph R. Branslord, who will retire; and Lee R. McClary, who becomes general purchasing director, succeeding H. Stanley Bredder, who will replace Mr. Wiest as general manager of patent licensing.

title: MILLS CITES DROP IN TAX AVOIDANCE
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 8Representative Wilbur D. Mills, chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee, argued today that the 1969 tax reform act had significantly reduced the number of highincome individuals who escape all Federal income taxes.

title: Remapping Expert Backs Plan in Court
description: ALBANY, Feb, 8The cold, complicated process of reapportionment became one man's affair of the heart today as Donald Zimmerman, the Legislature's remapping expert, came from behind the scenes and defended the latest plan from attack in State Supreme Court.

title: Advertising:
description: Robert E. Gernert, the 41yearold president and chief executive of the Campus Pac Corporation, a productsampling company, will join Grey Advertising Monday as an executive vice president for account management.

title: WASHINGTON
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 8Bob Haldeman, the most private member of President Nixon's growing White House politburo, has finally surfaced on N.B.C.'s early morning Today show, and even a casual study of his clumsy prose suggests that he should have stayed in bed.

title: Patterson's Father Dies; Bonavena Bout Still On
description: Despite the death of his father yesterday, Floyd Patterson will fulfill his 10round bout with Oscar Bonavena on Friday night at Madison Square Garden.

title: A: E. DUNCAN, HEADED COMMERCIAL CREDIT
description: BALTIMORE, Feb. 9Alexander E. Duncan, founder of the Commercial Credit Company, one of the largest financing concerns in the country, died on Monday evening at his home. He was 93 years old.

title: Third U.S. Carrier Arrives Off Vietnam
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Thursday, Feb. 10The United States aircraft carrier Constellation joined the carriers Coral sea and Hancock off the coast of Vietnam this morning, bolstering naval air forces in the Gulf of Tonkin to the level maintained at the height of the Indochina war in the late 1960's, according to a spokesman for the United States Seventh Fleet here.

title: Dr. Herman Reinstein, 60, Of Lutheran Hospital
description: Dr. Herman Reinstein, former director of medicine at Lutheran Hospital in Brooklyn, died of a heart attack yesterday at his residence. He was 60 years old and had practiced for many years at 1877 Ocean Avenue.

title: West Rallies Lakers
description: ATLANTA, Feb. 9 (UPI)Jerry West led a Los Angeles rally in the dosing minute of play tonight to give the Lakers a 117113 victory over the Atlanta Hawks.

title: C.C.N.Y. Downs St. Francis
description: City College staged a rally in the last four minutes to defeat St. Francis, 7470, on the loser's floor last night. Curly Wells hit on a 3point play to give City the victory.

title: Brown Six Tops Yale
description: PROVIDENCE, R.I., Feb. 9 (AP)Yale's Meehan Auditorium jinx worked again tonight as Brown's hockey team rallied to defeat the visitors, 43, in suddendeath overtime. Yale has never defeated Brown at Meehan Auditorium. The winning goal was scored by Steve Shea.

title: Repaired Apollo 16 Returned To Florida Launching Pad
description: CAPE KENNEDY, Fla., Feb. 9 (UPI)Apollo 16 was returned to its launching pad in record time despite rainy and windy weather today and now is on schedule for its April 16 flight to the moon.

title: Matzdorf Does 70, Loses
description: PARIS, Feb. 9 (AP)Pat Matzdorf, the world recordholder in the high jump, cleared 7 feet today but was beaten in an informal competition by the French star, Henri Elliott, who jumped 7 feet 1.8 Inches. Matzdorf is in Paris to receive an award as the world's top athlete of 1971.

title: Ottawa Regrets Deadlock
description: OTTAWA, Feb. 9 (Reuters)Trade Minister JeanLuc Pepin expressed regret tonight that Washington had turned down proposed settlement of United StatesCanadian trade differences.

title: Market Place:
description: What is it about a socalled concept company that makes its stock worth more that is, gives it a higher price earnings ratio  than the mundane alsorans?

title: Judge Bars New Rise in Phone Rates
description: The New York Telephone Company was ordered by a Federal judge yesterday to take no further action to increase telephone rates in the state.

title: Major TV Networks Pan Broad Primary Coverage
description: The three major television networks are planning extensive coverage of the Presidential primary campaign, starting with the New Hampshire contest next month. The coverage will include spe'cial programs from the major primary states, on the primary results.

title: MARTIN MARIETTA HAS PEAK PROFIT
description: The Martin Marietta Corporation had increased operating earnings for the fourth quarter and all of 1971, despite a sharp drop in profit at its 83 per centowned Harvey Aluminum, Inc. subsidiary, the concern said yesterday.

title: Pay Unit Widens Scrutiny Of Deferred Wage Rises
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 9The Pay Board ruled today that all pay increases due in the second or later years of multiyear labor contracts affecting 1,000 or more workers must be screened by the board in advance if they exceeded 7 per cent.

title: SCHOOL CURTAILS SPORTS CONTESTS
description: KINGS PARK, L. I., Feb. 9The district principal of the predominantly white Kings Park School District suspended all further athletic contests with predominantly black Wyandanch High School today.

title: Apparent Heart Attack Fells Flyers Gamble
description: OAKLAND, Calif., Feb. 9 (AP)The Philadelphia Flyer goalie, Bruce Gamble, was hospitalized with an apparent heart attack here today, doctors said.

title: HILLERY HOPES TO SEE PRESSURE ON BRITAIN
description: DUBLIN, Feb. 9Dr. Patrick J. Hillery, the Irish Foreign Minister, denied tonight that he had been rebuffed when asking foreign governments to apply pressure on Britain to change her policies in Northern Ireland.

title: Mackell Deplores Naming of Suspects
description: District Attorney Thomas J. Mackell of Queens expressed concern yesterday over the public disclosures by the police on Tuesday of the names and records of nine persons sought in connection with the killing of two patrolmen in the East Village on Jan. 27.

title: TRADING PLANNED IN 7 CURRENCIES
description: The Chicago Mercantile Exchange announced yesterday that it would provide futures trading in seven foreign currencies instead of the four currencies announced in December.

title: Tony Abbatiello Seeking Brother's Magic Formula
description: WESTBURY, L.I., Feb. 9An Abbatiello (Carmine) tops the dashwinning list of drivers at Roosevelt Raceway with 30 triumphs. Another Abbatiello (Tony) brings up the rear with no victories in 31 assignments.

title: GIACOMIN EXCELS AS RANGERS DOWN BLACK HAWKS, 41
description: Relying on his headeven to stop a shotrather than his reflexes, Ed Giacomin was a oneman show in the Rangers net last night as the New Yorkers gained an important 41 victory over the Chicago Black Hawks at Madison Square Garden.

title: Thieu Repeats 4 Noes
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Feb. 9 (AP)President Nguyen Van Thieu has reiterated his opposition to Communist political activity in South Vietn a m.

title: In Robbins's Ballet, Ito's Silent Sounds
description: The ballet that has caused the noisiest controversy in years, Jerome Robbins's hourlong Watermill, has a musical score that hardly raises its voice. In fact, the score includes what its Tokyoborn composer, Teiji Ito, calls silent sounds, as well as barely audible tendrils of tone.

title: NIXON SAYS SOVIET AND U.S. DEFINED PACT ON MISSILES
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 9 President Nixon, in his third annual foreign policy message to Congress, said today that the United States and the Soviet Union had reached an accord on the outlineif not yet the details of an interim agreement on the limitation of strategic arms. He said such an agreement could restrain the arms race without jeopardizing either side's security.

title: Artificial Brain Lets Paralyzed Monkeys Move
description: MENLO PARK, Calif., Feb. 9  A team of California researchers has developed an experimental artificial brain that has been used to restore a variety of movements in the limbs of partly paralyzed monkeys.

title: Hamilton Six Wins, 31
description: CLINTON, N. Y., Feb. 9 (AP) Brian Morin scored two goals to give Hamilton a 31 victory over Amherst in hockey tonight.

title: PRICE RICE URGED BY OIL PRODUCERS
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 9The Independent Petroleum Association of America announced today that it would seek an increase in the price of crude oil so, that the producers would have an incentive to search for and exploit new sources of oil and gas within the continental United States.

title: A Florida Vote on Busing Approved by State Senate
description: TALLAHASSEE, Fla., Feb. (UPI)The Florida Senate approved today and sent to the House a resolution calling for a statewide vote on Tuesday, March 14, the day of the state's Presidential primary, on the use of busing to achieve racial balance in the schools.

title: Personal Finance: Travel Agencies
description: Barnett Levy, chief of the State Consumer Frauds Protection Bureau, has been reading letters from irate travelers for years, and he has often wondered if all those harrowing tales of woe could really be true.

title: President Appears to Hint At Raids to Free P.O.W.'s
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 9Using his strongest terms on the subject to date, President Nixon pledged today to retrieve the American prisoners of war held by North Vietnam either as part of an overall settlement, or through other means.

title: ROVE TO ADVANCE PRIMARY BLOCKED
description: NASHVILLE, Feb. 9An attempt to move the Tennessee Presidential preference primary from May 4 up to March 30 ran into a oneman roadblock today.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: President Nixon's revelation of the exploits of Professor Kissinger (and I have no desire to minimize them even though we do not yet know whether his efforts were successful) avoided any mention of the gentleman with long and distinguished experience in diplomacy whom the President called out of wellearned retirement to sit in Paris at the Vietnam peace table.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: It would appear that the ABM battle has been fought on the basis of questionable psychological premises. While the dispute between offensive and defensive missiles began in the fifties as a power struggle between the establishments and camp followers of the armed forces, the more recent skirmishes have been polemicized as conflict between the forces of Light and Darkness.

title: Executive Changes
description: Sydney B. White, president and chief operating officer of James M. McCunn & Co., Inc., has been elected vice chairman of the board of directors of Somerset Importers, Ltd., importers of distilled spirits.

title: NIXON BIDS RIVALS NOT BLOCK PEACE
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 9President Nixon asked his Democratic challengers for the Presidency today to say nothing that might give the enemy an incentive to prolong the war until after the election.

title: Nixon's Budget Scored
description: PRINCETON, N. J., Feb. 9 (AP)The chairmen of two New Jersey chapters of the Sierra Club asserted today that President Nixon's proposed 1973 budget did not contain enough money for conservation. The charge was made in a letter to Mr. Nixon by Mrs. James Graves of Princeton and George Schindle of Summit, chairmen of the South Jersey and North Jersey chapters of the nationwide conservation group.

title: Two of 6 Alternate Jurors Chosen for Berrigan Trial
description: HARRISBURG, Pa., Feb. 9 (AP)A daylong quest for six alternate jurors yielded two prospects today at the Federal conspiracy trial of the Rev. Philip F. Berrigan and six other antiwar activists.

title: Waldheim Aide: No Word
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Feb. 9A spokesman for Secretary General Waldheim, asked about a news report from Lisbon that Portugal might refuse to pay her share of the costs of the Security Council meeting in Addis Ababa, said no such word had been received here. The spokesman said he could not see how Portugal would figure her share of the Security Council's expenses for specific meetings, except by rough estimate.

title: Nixon Edging Nearer To Tie With Bangladesh
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 9President Nixon appeared today to be edging closer to eventual recognition of Bangladesh, formerly East Pakistan.

title: More Excerpts From Hughes Book Raise Questions About Work
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 9More excerpts from The Autobiography of Howard Hughes came into the possession Of The New York Times today and, as did earlier passages, they raise intriguing questions about the controversial book.

title: Company Shortens Name To Zapata Corporation
description: Stockholders of Zapata Norness, Inc., at their annual meeting in Houston yesterday, approved a change of the company's name to the Zapata Corporation effective Tuesday

title: HAPPINESS & VITALITY
description: We teach It

title: Jersey Tax Rises Planned This Year, With More in 1973
description: TRENTON, Feb. 9The administration of Gov. William T. Cahill has decided to close part of an impending deficit in the state budget with a 5cent increase in New Jersey's cigarette tax, a 5 per cent sales tax on bottled and canned beer and ale, and a 50centagallon increase in the state liquor tax.

title: A Recipe Swap: Apple Pie for Some Treasured Italian Specialties
description: EASTCHESTER, N. 17,After 20 years as a language teacher in Westchester County, Miss Theresa Laudo spent a sabbatical semester last spring in Europe. With her sister, Vincenza, she traveled through France, Spain, Greece and Italy, the countries whose languages she had studied. But Italy, for this firstgeneration American, who says she spoke Italian before she spoke English, was not only a place to practice a foreign tongue but also the repository of treasured family recipes never written down.

title: Indian Scholarship Plan
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 9 (AP) The National Congress of American Indians will conduct a nationwide scholarship program to provide Indian college graduates with financial assistance in obtaining graduate degrees, it, was announced today.

title: Perry Making Hollywood Film  His Way
description: HOLLYWOOD  Frank Perry, the independent filmmaker who proved 10 years ago with his first feature, David and Lisa, that lowbudget American movie hits could be produced without the Hollywood Establishment, is here making his first Hollywoodbased film.

title: OBSERVER
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 9When President Nixon goes to China he will take most of the American television industry with him. Harry. Reasoner, Walter Cronkite, John Chancellor, Barbara Walters, Dan Rather, Herb Kaplow, Bernard Kalb, Eric Sevareid and many more. Thirtyfive more by precise count, including cameramen and technicians.

title: Books of The Times
description: POOR COUSINS. By Ande Mariners. 318 pages. Illustrated. Coward, McCann & Geoghegan. $8.95.

title: Drivers in State to Get I.D. Cards in June
description: Beginning June 1, every car owner in the state will be required to carry in his car an identifation card issued by his insurance company showing he has coverage for accident liability.

title: City Wants Ads for Films To Cite Foreign Language
description: Bess Myerson, Consumer Affairs Commissioner, proposed a regulation yesterday that would force theaters showing foreignlanguage films to indicate that fact in their advertising.

title: ReliefRoll Rise Here Outpaces Fiscal Year's Budget Allotment
description: The city's Department of Social Services reported yesterday that increases In the welfare rolls in the six months ended last December had run ahead of budget allotments for the fiscal year that began July 1.

title: All Atwitter in Anticipation of First Railbird
description: The sun came out at 10 A.M. in Belmont Park's stable area yesterday, dripping warmth onto the frozen ground, and reminding horsemen that the New York thoroughbred racing season would be starting earlier than ever this year.

title: Gallup Finds a Continued Rise in Use of Marijuana and LSD on Campuses
description: The Gallup Poll reported yesterday that the use of marijuana and hallucinogenic drugs continued to rise last year on college campuses.

title: HEARD, ROSBURG SHARE LEAD Al 66
description: PALM SPRINGS, Calif., Feb. 9 (UPI)  Two Californians, Jerry Heard and Bob Rosburg, shot sixunderpar 66's today to share the firstround lead by a stroke in the $145,000 Bob Hope Desert Classic.

title: U.S. Six Routed, 72
description: SAPPORO, Japan, Feb. (UPI)Despite a loss to the powerful. Soviet Union team, the United States hockey team hopes to keep its chances alive for a bronze, medal tomorrow when it plays Finland.

title: 100 Weapons Reported Confiscated at Rikers Jail
description: Bronx District Attorney Burton B. Roberts said yesterday that more than 100 makeshift weapons were found in a cellblock at the Rikers Island Adolescent Remand Shelter after a disturbance there on Feb. 1.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: It is interesting to note that the Board of Education has just ruled that members of the public will no longer be allowed to display signs and banners at its meetings. It is difficult to reconcile this new regulation with the permissiveness displayed by the board in insisting that students may not only display signs, buttons and armbands but may also distribute any kind of material within the school without prior censorship or restriction. Could it be that the board is more concerned for its own security than it is for security within the schools?

title: Czechoslovak Mother Flying To California in Custody Fight
description: PRAGUE, Feb. 9A Czechoslovak mother left here today for San Bernardino, Calif., hoping to obtain a legal decision that will restore to her the custody of her two children, who were taken out of the country after the invasion In 1968 by Warsaw Pact powers.

title: Newberry Chairman Filling Presidency Temporarily
description: The J. J. Newberry Company announced yesterday that Walter C. Straus, chairman, had temporarily assumed the presidency. Daryl D. Milius resigned from the post on Tuesday.

title: SHOWDOWN LOOMS ON MADISON MALL
description: Battle lines are being formed among midtown merchants, realestate men and civic leaders over a Lindsay administration plan to convert a 15block stretch of Madison Avenue into a permanent pedestrian mall, with limited access to buses and delivery vehicles.

title: Pacers Sink Floridians
description: INDIANAPOLIS, Feb. 9 (AP) The Indiana Pacers staged a thirdperiod rally tonight and went on to a 128111 victory over the Floridians.

title: U.S. Plans 82% Cut In Amphetamines
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 9The Government plans to cut the 1972 domestic production quota for amphetamines to about 17 or 18 per cent of last year's production in an effort to cope with one of the nation's most serious drug problems, officials said today.

title: EQUITY FINANCING
description: The Florida Power & Light Company raised an indicated $66.76million yesterday with the competitive sale of 1 million common shares. A Morgan StanleyBlyth underwriting group won the stock with bid of $66.76 and reoffered it at 6671/2. The company's shares closed yesterday at $67 on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Congress Votes Dock Strike Arbitration
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 9Congress approved contingency legilation tonight to end the 124day West Coast dock strike.

title: MAY CRAIG DEAD; IRISH ACTRESS, 83
description: DUBLIN, Feb. 8 (AP)May Craig, a member of the Abbey Theater Company, died today in a home for the retired. She was 83 years old.

title: BRITISH ACT IN STRIKE TO CONSERVE POWER
description: LONDON, Feb. 9 (Reuters) Britain today proclaimed state of emergency to conserve power supplies in the nationwide strike of British coal miners.

title: McGrawHill Reportedly Seeks Hughes Meeting
description: A key McGrawHill executive has gone to the Bahamas in what may be an attempt to seek out Howard R. Hughes to get, to the truth about the manuscript that, Clifford Irving represented as the authorized memoirs of Mr. Hughes.

title: Annie Famose Put Under Suspension By Ski Federation
description: SAPPORO, Japan. Feb. 9 (AP) Annie Famose, the French ski star, was suspended by the International Ski Federation tonight as controversy rose again at the Winter Olympics.

title: News of Skiing
description: BEACON, N.Y., Feb. 9Almost forgotten in these highpressure promotion days of the Graduated Length Method (GLM) of teaching beginners to ski in one week is Walter Foeger, the former Austrian mountain trooper, who manages the Dutchess Ski Area here. Foeger, who arrived in this country 15 years ago after a teaching stint lin Spains Pyreness, talked and taught in another theme than as the operator of Jay Peak in Vermont. There he introduced the NaturTeknik system.

title: 8LENGTH VICTORY BY SPANISH RIDDLE
description: HALLANDALE, Fla., Feb. 9 (UPI)R. E. Anderson's Spanish Riddle, who had not been raced since winning the Dade Metropolitan Handicap a month ago, made no contest of the $50,750 Hutcheson Stakes at Gulfstream Park today, scoring an eightlength victory over Gentle Smoke.

title: More Global Economic Data Urged
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 9 Peter G. Peterson, assistant to President Nixon for international economic affairs, speaking today at the White House Conference on the Industrial World Ahead, called for a greater effort by the Government in gathering worldwide economic intelligence. bert, Brussels; Robert V. Roosa, Brown Brothers Harriman; Peter G. Peterson, Secretary of Commercedesignate, and Roberto Campos of the International Bank, Brazil.

title: CourtMartial Defense in Army Rape Case Raises Issue of Capital Punishment
description: FORT LEAVENWORTH, Kan., Feb. 9The defense in the courtmartial of a black Army trusty charged with raping a white lieutenant colonel's wife argued today that the armed services legal code violates the Constitution as it pertains to capital punishment and the composition of juries.

title: Advertising:
description: The William Esty. Company, which got its foot in the Seagram door about four years ago, really seems to be part of the family now.

title: Furs This Spring? Furriers Hope So
description: Now enter the fur sweater. And why not, since both Paris and Seventh Avenue have rediscovered that handy little garment and have been giving it the biggest play since Chanel invented the sweater as fashion back in the Nineteentwenties. With the warmest winter in years behind them, the furriers are placing their hopes on spring. They'd like to convince women that furs are a yearround fashion and that a little mink sweater weighs no more than a wool one.

title: RUSSELL MEMORIAL TO HELP JAZZ FUND
description: The third annual Pee Wee Russell Memorial Stomp, a gathering of friends and fans of the jazz clarinetist who died Feb. 15, 1969, will be held Sunday afternoon at the Martinsville Inn, Martinsville, N. J. The Stomp is held to raise money for the Pee Wee Russell Scholarship Fund, which is administered by the Institute of Jazz Studies at Rutgers University. The two previous Stomps have produced $4,300 for the fund.

title: LINDSAY ASSAILED BY RABBI LEADER
description: The presidentelect of the New York Board of Rabbis, in a bristling attack on the lowincome project now being built in Forest Hills, Queens, assailed the Lindsay administration yesterday and called for a halt in construction pending discussion and a reappraisal.

title: Music: Informality at Philharmonic
description: Downtown the Philharmonic gives Encounters. In the Juilliard Theater the events are billed as Informal Evenings. The format is similar. The idea is to present music informally, with the conductor talking, with the artists and audience participating. Downtown, however, only new music is offered, and the composers are present to join in the melee. Uptown the content deals with 20thcentury masters, and Alban Berg was the composer on Tuesday night, as he will be at the second and last Informal Evening on Feb. 29 at the Juilliard.

title: Philadelphia Detective Killed
description: PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 9 (AP) An offduty city detective was shot and killed today, the police said, when two gunmen tried to hold up a bar in the Germantown section of the city. The victim was identified as Douglas Alexander, of the police internal security unit.

title: DOW IS UP BY 11.59 IN HEAVY TRADING
description: Stock prices boomed yesterday in heavy trading as a sudden renewal of investor confidence swept Wall Street. The DowJones industrial average surged 11.59 points to 918.72, thereby finishing at its best level since early September.

title: Mr. Nixon's State of the World
description: The report to the Congress on President Nixon's foreign policy is described by Henry Kissinger, its chief author, as a framework for a debate on foreign policy in this country. And, he adds, we would welcome a debate. The challenge is unlikely to be ignored. But it confronts the Democrats with serious difficulties. In what is essentially a campaign document for the 1972 Presidential election, Mr. Nixon can be seen between the lines relishing the extent to which he has stolen the opposition's shirt.

title: Advertising:
description: The SevenUp people are test marketing an unburger promotion in their latest attempt to give that simple, negative prefix positive meaning.

title: 2 GOING TO ZURICH FOR IRVING DATA
description: Two Federal investigators flew to Zurich, Switzerland, last night in the continuing investigation into Clifford Irving's involvement in a purported autobiography of Howard R. Hughes.

title: Bill on Indians Gains
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 9 (AP) A House Interior subcommittee approved today a measure extending the life of the Indian Claims Commission for four more years, until April 10, 1976.

title: 26 Jets Put on Sale By Eastern Airlines For $100Million
description: Eastern Airlines announced yesterday it is putting up for sale a fleet of 26 fourengine jetliners with an anticipated total market value of more than $100million. The book value of the fleet, according to a company spokesman, is about the same figure ($100million). He added that Eastern doesn't anticipate the sale resulting either in a capital loss or gain.

title: YUGOSLAV WRITER GIVEN JAIL TERN
description: BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Feb. 9 (UPI)Mihajlo Mihajlov said today that he had been sentenced to 30 days in jail for publishing an essay and a letter in The New York Times.

title: Part of Tunis University Is Closed After Protests
description: TUNIS, Feb. 9 (AP)The Government closed Tunis University's law and arts schools until September today after the first major protest against President Habib Bourguiba in his 15 years of leadership.

title: Plolin Arraigned in Court On Pledging of Securities
description: Charles Plohn, 69 years old, former senior partner of Charles Plohn & Co., a brokerage firm in liquidation, was arraigned in Criminal Court yesterday on charges of illegally pledging some $334,000 in customers securities as collateral for bank loans.

title: Harvard Sextet Wins
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Feb. 9 (AP)Save Hynes scored three goals tonight to lead Harvard to a 62 hockey victory over Clarkson.

title: Flu Strikes Aides in Peking
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 9 (Reuters)Several members of the White House advance party preparing for President Nixon's trip to China next week have been stricken by flu in Peking, officials said today.

title: BUCKS ACE PACES 126121 TRIUMPH
description: CLEVELAND, Feb. 9 (UPI)Kareem AbdulJabbar scored 53 points, including 12 straight baskets in the second half, tonight, to pace the Milwaukee Bucks to a 126121 National Basketball Association victory over the Cleveland Cavaliers.

title: The Jobless Constituency
description: PHILADELPHIA  Unemployment has been a Democrat votewinner since the Great. Depression. To Republican partisans, Democrats always appear, to be running against Herbert. Hoover. The incomplete unemployment statistics suggest that 1972 will be no exception. President Nixon could not have been unmindful of this in adopting his new economic policy last August.
