description: SAPPORO, Japan, Friday, Feb. 11The string ran out today for two American gold medalists, Anne Henning and Dianne Holum, in the Olympic speed skating. Anne, yesterday's winner of the 500meter sprint when she raced twice, finished third for bronze medal behind 17yearold Monika Pflug of West Germany and Atje KeulenDeelstra of the Netherlands in the 1,000 meters. Dianne, the 1,500 champion, wound up sixth.

title: ROSBURG POSTS 69 FOR LEAD AT 135 IN HOPE CLASSIC
description: PALM SPRINGS, Calif., Feb. 10 (UPI)Bob Rosburg of San Francisco, whose game is at its best in 15 years, shot a threeunderpar 69 today for the sole lead after two rounds in the. $145,000 Bob Hope Desert Classic.

title: Obituary 1  No Title
description: Obituary 1  No Title

title: Nixon at Key Biscayne
description: MIAMI, Feb. 10 (Reuters)]President Nixon arrived here tonight to spend a working weekend at the Florida White House in nearby Key Biscayne.

title: Warriors Down 76 yers
description: OAKLAND, Calif., Feb. 10 (UPI) Jim Barnett scored 12 of his 20 points in the final period tonight, triggering a rally that gave the Golden State Warriors a 121112 victory over the Philadelphia 76ers.

title: Default or Decency?
description: Congress has been put on notice that the United States will have to withdraw from the International Labor Organization unless the legislators call off the clumsy game of political blackmail they have been conducting through their twoyear refusal to pay the dues this country owes.

title: Narrow Road to Close
description: The Lincoln Center Repertory Theater production of Edward Bond's Narrow Road to the Deep North ends its run at the Vivian Beaumont Theater tomorrow night after 44 performances.

title: MELL A. FARRELL, A UNION LEADER, 75
description: Mell A. Farrell, president of the Sheet Metal Workers Local Union 28 International Association, died of heart failure yesterday in Caledonian Hospital, Brooklyn. He was 75 years old and lived at 3149 Bedford Avenue, Brooklyn.

title: Pan Am to Use Blacks On South Africa Flights
description: JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, Feb. 10 (AP)Pan American World Airways announced today that it would include black air hostesses on flights to South Africa.

title: 14 Blacks Indicted On Murder Charge In Louisiana Case
description: BATON ROUGE, La., Feb. 10 (UPI)  A grand jury indicted 14 young black men on charges of murder and inciting to riot today in connection with the deaths of two deputy sheriffs Jan. 10 in a gunfight between the police and blacks on a ghetto street.

title: Merry Clayton Sings Blues at Bitter End
description: Thunder and lightning and good vibes of all sorts were flashing around the Bitter End Wednesday night. The source was a brilliant 23yearold singer named Merry Clayton.

title: North Stars Triumph, 31
description: ST. LOUIS, Feb. 10 (UPI)Goals by Lou Nanne, Jude Drouin and Murray Oliver gave the Minnesota North Stars a 31 victory over the St. Louis Blues tonight.

title: PRICES EDGE UP IN AMEX TRADING
description: After a strong showing most of the trading day, stock prices on the American Stock Exchange lost most of the gain late in the session.

title: Glenn Weitzman and Marilyn Chris
description: The Chelsea Theater Center of Brooklyn has a fantastic record for fresh and original theater. This record is amply maintained by Allen Ginsberg's Kaddish, which had its official opening at the Brooklyn Academy of Music yesterday afternoon.

title: LEGAL GAMBLING SOUGHT IN JERSEY
description: TRENTON, Feb. 10 A legislative drive to legalize virtually all forms of gambling in New Jersey was off and running today in the State Senate.

title: WINSTON E. HOBBS
description: SCARSDALE, N.Y., Feb. 10Winston E. Hobbs, a lawyer and vice president and trust officer of the Corporation Trust Company, died yesterday here. He was 59 years old and lived at 151 Brewster Road.

title: SENATE TEST DUE ON REGISTRATION
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 10A simplified national registration plan, designed to get many of the 47 million Election Day dropouts of 1968 to the polls this year, is heading for its first major test on the Senate floor within the next few weeks.

title: REFINANCING SOUGHT FOR DEBT OF CHILE
description: An agreement in principal has been reached between the government of Chile and a consortium of United States banks on the refinancing of a portion of Chile's foreign debt, it was announced yesterday.

title: PHONE RISE HERE, UTILITY INCREASES STAYED FOR MONTH
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 10The Price Commission ordered today a onemonth freeze on all rate increases by privately owned public utilities and, at the same time, temporarily rescinded part of a rate increase already put into effect by the New York Telephone Company.

title: JACK LAURENCE
description: SOUTH PORTLAND, Me., Feb. 10  Jack Laurence, a sports promoter, died of cancer in the Maine Medical Center, Portland; today. He was 63 years old.

title: News Analysis
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 10 This is the third week of the bitter public argument between the United States and North Vietnam over the merits of their respective secret peace plans and over what each told the other in two years of onandoff secret negotiations in Paris. On the American side, this unusual and confusing diplomatic duel has already personally engaged President Nixon on four oc casions  from his surprise speech Jan. 25, when he divulged the existence of the secret talks and the rival secret peace proposals, to his surprise news conference today. It has also engaged the President's chief foreign policy adviser, Henry A. Kissinger, Secretary of State William P. Rogers, Xuan Thuy, Hanoi's chief negotiator, and assorted ambassadors and spokesmen on both sides.

title: Wood, Field and Stream: Some Catch
description: A giant bluefish caught in Hatteras Inlet off. North Carolina's Outer Banks late last month exceeded the world record for the species by more than 7 pounds.

title: Publisher Is Honored
description: LAWRENCE, Kan., Feb. 10 (AP)The William Allen White Foundation of the University of Kansas today presented its national award for journalistic merit to. John S. Knight, the Miami and Detroit publisher.

title: Louis W. Rosen Dies at 83; Lawyer for City and State
description: Louis W. Rosen, a retired New York lawyer, who had served on the staff of the City Corporation Counsel from 1938 to 1941 and later on the staff of the State Attorney General, died Wednesday in Miami Beach, Fla., where he lived. His age was 83.

title: Books of The Times
description: THE DOUBLECROSS SYSTEM. In the War of 1939 to 1945: By J. C. Masterman. 203 pages. Yale. $G.95.

title: Advertising:
description: The overseas business of the Hertz Corporation moving to McCannErickson International from Ogilvy & Mather. The billings are being estimated at $5million.

title: Big Board Approves Listing
description: Governors of the New York Stock Exchange yesterday approved the listing of common stock of Donaldson. Lufkin & Jenrette, Inc., a member brokerage firm, for trading on the Big Board. Donaldson, Lufkin 181 Jenrette was the first Big Board member to sell shares to the public in 1976.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: I must take strong exception to your Jan. 26 editorial in which you severely criticized President Nixon for not availing himself of a legal loophole and maintaining the restriction on imports of Rhodesian chrome in spite of a specific provision in the Military Procurement Act of 1971 providing that the restriction be lifted.

title: Marshal Nikolai I. Krylov Dies; Directed Soviet Missile Forces
description: MOSCOW, Feb. 10Marshal Nikolai I. Krylov, commander of the Soviet Union's Strategic Missile Forces since 1963, died yesterday at the age of 69.

title: Talks Aim at Common Market Monetary Union in 72
description: PARIS, Feb. 10France and West Germany, reaffirming their determination to reactivate plans for monetary union within the Common Market, agreed today on certain technical measures to spur the project this year.

title: Woman in the News
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 10 When Arnette Thelma Peters Giles was growing up along the Gulf Coast in the early years of this century, her childish dream was to have a huge house which would gather in all the unwanted children. I knew all the heartaches and the disappointments, she said today. I know what it is like to be unwanted, unloved and rejected. Mrs. Giles is 70 years old. In 51 years of marriage to the Rev. Charles Giles, a United Methodist preacher in Pearlington, Miss., she has reared 40 abandoned, poor children, many of them retarded, as well as five children of her own.

title: 4% Rise in Retail Food Prices Seen for 72 by Farm. Agency
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 10 Consumers will spend $6.6billion more for food this year mainly because of a rise of close to 4 per cent in retail food prices and more money paid to farmers for raw products, the Department of Agriculture predicted today.

title: DR. IRVING PERLMUTTER
description: MAPLEWOOD, N. J., Feb. 10 Dr. Irving K. Perlmutter, former director of obstetrics and gynecology at Beth Israel Medical Center, Newark, died yesterday here of a heart attack. He was 56 years old and lived at 362 Elmwood Avenue.

title: GEORGE A. BENSON
description: NEW SHREWSBURY, N.J., Feb. 10 George A. Benson, a former supervisor in the commonsystems switching department of the Bell Laboratories, Holmdel, N.J., died Tuesday. He was 69 years old and lived at 52 Birchwood Court.

title: MIHAJLOV SENTENCE IS PROTESTED HERE
description: Freedom House, a private organization here, protested yesterday against the 30day jail sentence given to Mihajlo Mihajlov, the Yugoslav dissident writer, for publishing an essay and a letter in The New York Times.

title: New Rival for Mrs. Hicks
description: BOSTON, Feb. 10 (AP) Ronald T. McDonald of Norwood, a Republican state committeeman, announced today candidacy for the ninth Congressional District seat now held by Mrs. Louise Day Hicks, a Democrat. The district was stripped of some of its heavily Democratic wards in Boston in last year's redistricting.

title: CHRYSLER LISTS PROFIT COMEBACK
description: DETROIT, Feb. 10  The Chrysler Corporation, which lost $7.6million in 1970, reported today a record $8billion in sales for 1971 and net earnings of $83.7million, or $1.67 a share.

title: Marian McPartland Offers Jazz Variety at Piano
description: After only a month, the 5:45 Interludes, the series of onehour concerts held at Town Hall every Wednesday at 5:45 P.M., seemed to have established themselves as a relaxing oasis in the normal run of New York Life. A casual, friendly atmosphere, with little suggestion of the formalities of a concert, filled the hall on Wednesday afternoon when Marian McPartland, the jazz pianist, gave a program accompanied by Jay Leonhardt on bass.

title: PATTERSON MARKS 20TH YEAR IN RING
description: Floyd Patterson, the 37yearold boxer who is the only man to hold the world heavyweight championship twice, will mark his 20th year of professional boxing fighting tonight in bout with durable Oscar (Ringo) Bonavena of Argentina in Madison Square Garden.

title: A Party for Coop Building Rated a Collective Success
description: Is there more to 470 West End Avenue than a number?

title: BELLA FROMM DIES; WROTE ABOUT BERLIN
description: Mrs. Bella Fromm Wells, author of Blood and Banquets: A Berlin Social Diary, published under her maiden name by Harper in 1942, died Wednesday in Mount Sinai Hospital. The widow of Dr. Peter F. Welles, she was 71 years old and lived at 65 West 95th Street.

title: Katz Sparks Rider
description: RUTHERFORD, N.J., Feb. 10  Bill Katz scored 31 points and grabbed 11 rebounds tonight to lead Rider to a 6965 victory over Fairleigh Dickinson. Rider snapped a threegame losing streak, while Fairleigh Dickinson lost its third straight.

title: Senate Panel Supports Curbs On Presidential War Powers
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 10The Senate Foreign Relations committee contended today that proposed legislation defining the war powers of the President represented a needed and useful step toward restoring the constitutional balance between Congress and the executive branch.

title: Commonwealth Plan Set
description: The Commonwealth United Corporation  a once widelydiversified company that came to fame during the height of the conglomerate era  announced a plan yesterday that it said would enable it to make settlements with most of its creditors, claimants and litigants.

title: SUNS TROUNCE BULLETS, 13198
description: PHOENIX, Ariz., Feb. 10 (AP) The Phoenix Suns held the Baltimore Bullets to three baskets in the second period as they handed the Bullets their sixth straight loss, 13198, in the National Basketball Association tonight.

title: Barbara Cochran of U S. Wins Slalom
description: SAPPORO, Japan, Friday, Feb. 11 (AP)Barbara Cochran of Richmond, Vt., twisted through a heavy snow today to win the women's special slalom and give the United States its first Olympic gold medal in Alpine skiing since 1952.

title: Nastase Defeats Gorman In Coast Tennis Tourney
description: LOS ANGELES, Feb. 10(AP) Nastase of Rumania recorded his second straight victory in the $40,000 International Open tennis tournament last night, downing Tom. Gorman of Seattle, 62, 63.

title: Aussie Pacer Concludes A Long Journey Tonight
description: WESTBURY, L. I., Feb. 10 A horse that is flown considerable distance, such as the 12,000mile plane trip from New Zealand or Australia to this country, may find the going more taxing than an astronaut does on a flight to the moon.

title: Boy Falls Off Subway Train
description: A 16yearol dboy was critically injured yesterday when he fell from a Queensbound subway train on the Williamsburg Bridge to the vehicular roadway. The boy was identified as Hughey Levon, of 111 Moore Street, Brooklyn. The police said he fell shortly before 4 P.M. either from between cars or from hitching pride on the rear. He was taken to Beth Israel Hospital.

title: Store Sales Increase
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 10The Commerce Department today estimated last week's department store sales at $601million, up 10 per cent from the yearearlier $545million. Last week's total retail store sales were about $9,223,000,000, up 7 per cent from $6,955,000,000.

title: Youth Takes City Aide on Tour of East New York
description: Bryce Murray, an 18yearold high school senior, led the city top planner yesterday on a tour of Bryce Murray's East New York section of Brooklyn.

title: Protest in New Zealand
description: WELLINGTON, New Zealand, Feb. 10 (UPI)Prime Minister John Marshall said today, that New Zealand would make a forceful protest to Rhodesian authorities unless they either released or formally filed charges against Garfield Todd and his daughter, Judith. Todd is a New Zealander by birth and entitled to the protection afforded by citizenship, Mr. Marshall said.

title: Dubious Integration Plan
description: The Fleischmann Commission has properly given high priority to the racial integration of the state's public schools, and it has clearly described the disturbing trend of increasing segregation as the school population of the major cities turns predominantly black and Puerto Rican.

title: ROBERT ATKINS, 85, ACTOR AND DIRECTOR
description: LONDON, Feb. 10  Robert Atkins, the actor and director, died in hospital here yesterday. He was 85 years old.

title: RightWing Parties Unite
description: SALISBURY, Feb. 10 (Reuters)Rhodesia's two extreme rightwing political parties, the Republican Alliance and the Rhodesian National party, formed a white Opposition front against the Smith Government tonight at a rally at which 800 white Rhodesians heard the Government attacked for accepting independence terms that would mean eventual black rule.

title: Stewart Betters Record
description: JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, Feb. 10 (AP)Jackie Stewart, world champion driver from Scotland, left South Africa today after breaking the track record during a week of trials for the Kyalami Grand Prix on March 4. He cut 3.6 seconds from the official lap record. He will drive a Ford Tyrell in the Kyalami Grand Prix.

title: Any Enemy Offensive Expected to Be Long
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 10Senfor Pentagon officals say that if North Vietnamese forces open a major offensive in the South, as has been widely predicted in Washington and to a lesser extent in Saigon, they expect it to last as long as three months.

title: WILLIAM J. MACKAY
description: William J. Mackay, who retired in 1957 as treasurer of the Mutual Chemical Division of the Allied Chemical Corporation, died Wednesday in Fayetteville, N.Y. His age was 78.

title: Appeals Court Upholds Medicaid Abortions Curb
description: ALBANY, Feb. 10  The state's highest court today upheld a directive by the state's Social Services Commissioner, George K. Wyman, banning the use of Medicaid funds for abortions on demand.

title: Palestine Alternative
description: The ArabPalestinian entity is not a newcomer to the Middle East political arena. Both the Israeli and the Arab governments have painstakingly shunned acknowledgement of its existence. Neither Zionism, solely Jewish, nor panArabism, mainly antiseparatist, have made any accommodation to the reality of the existing situation. From time to time, however, these opponents have seemed to agree on a common stand when forced to deal with the nonexistent problem. Last September, the divergent courses taken by Israel and Jordan arrived at a common denominator: Crush the resistance and break the backbone of the Palestinians as a separate entity.

title: Pakistan Announces a Curb on Labor Agitators
description: KARACHI, Pakistan, Feb. 10 President Zulfikar All Bhutto announced a new labor policy today and warned that his martiallaw Government would take tough action against anyone who stirred up labor unrest that led to disturbances.

title: 2 BRITONS KILLED BY MINE IN ULSTER
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Feb. 10 (UPI)  Two British soldiers were killed tonight when a mine exploded under their phtrol car near the border with the Irish Republic, a British Army spokesman said.

title: ATTACK ON TEMPLES HINTED BY CAMBODIA
description: PNOMPENH, Cambodia, Feb. 10 (AP)The Cambodian Government announced today that it reserved the right to attack enemy troops occupying Angkor Wat and Angkor Thom, two of Asia's most precious monuments.

title: Inquiry Told City Pays Heavily for State Apathy
description: Witnesses at a public hearing of the City Commission on StateCity Relations charged yesterday that failure of liaison and lack of state initiative was costing as much as $445million a year in lost Federal subsidies for local social service programs.

title: Egypt's Party to Meet
description: CAIRO, Feb. 10A special congress of the Arab Socialist Union, Egypt's only political organization, will be convened Wednesday to hear reports on President Anwar elSadat's recent talks with the Soviet leaders and to work out a new strategy against Israel, it was announced here today.

title: Nixon Warns His Peace Critics On Possible Blame ii Talks Fail
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 10 President Nixon laid down today a sharp challenge to Democratic critics of his Vietnam peace proposals by warning that they might have to share the blame if the Paris negotiations failed.

title: Commodity Price Index Up 0.5 From WeekAgo Level
description: The commodity spot market price index of foodstuffs and industrial materials rose to 112.4 from 111.9 last week.

title: EARNINGS SHOW DIP AT PAINE, WEBBER
description: Paine, Webber, Jackson & Curtis, a major investment concern, reported yesterday that it earned $1,003,000 in the fiscal first quarter ended Dec. 31, down from $1,912,000 in the comparable period of the preceding fiscal year.

title: Aide Asserts Peron Is Willing To Seek Argentine Presidency
description: BUENOS AIRES, Feb. 10 (Reuters)  Former President Juan D. Peron is willing to run for president in general elections to be held in March, 1973, but his immediate aim is to have the elections held this year, his personal representative said here today.

title: Lefrak Bid for HighRise Project In Forest Hills Rejected by City
description: The city's Board of Standards and Appeals voted unanimously yesterday against extending a building permit that would have permitted continued construction of a 400unit Lefrak highrise middle  income housing project on the Forest HillsKew Gardens border in Queens.

title: A JUDGE IN ESSEX SLAIN IN A MOTEL
description: NEWARK, Feb. 10Judge Roger M. Yancey of Essex County Court died today of gunshot wounds the police said, were inflicted last night by a 42yearold woman in a room at the Downtowner Motor Inn.

title: 19Year Inmate, All but Free, Appeals
description: RIVERHEAD, L.1., Feb. 10Robert Clayton, a 42yearold migrant farm worker who has spent the last 19 years in prison in Attica, turned down a chance to go free today.

title: BUSINESSES IN U.S. VICTIMS OF CRIMES
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 10Ordinary crime costs the American business community at least SIGbillion a year, according to a Commerce Department report released today. Most severely affected are small retail businesses, which are estimated to have lost $4.8billion.

title: The Screen: 'One P.M.':' Parallel Movie' Begins Run at the Whitney
description: Late in 1968, Jean-Luc Godard, then in his first bloom as a post-bourgeois Marxist-Leninist filmmaker, came to America to make a revolutionary movie. Together with Richard Leacock and D. A. Pennebaker, he began shooting on locations in and around New York City on a project that came to be known as "One A.M." ("One American Movie")."One A.M." was never completed. But from some of its footage, and from footage shot while it was being made, the team of Leacock-Pennebaker have put together another film, called "One P.M." ("One Parallel Movie"), which opened yesterday at the Whitney Museum."One P.M." contains most of the cast of "One A.M."Rip Torn, Tom Hayden, Eldridge Cleaver, The Jefferson Airplane, LeRoi Jones, among others; and it also contains a good deal of Jean-Luc Godard directing and Richard Leacock photographing "One A.M.," along with a couple of sound girls, some New York policemen, one or two producer types, and, watching in the background, Godard's wife, Anne Wiazemski, and assorted friends and relatives.To a degree, then, "One P.M." functions as the record of the making of a movie, and in certain sequences it may be all that is left of a movie that was not finally made. There are moments that seem to belong wholly to the rigid Godard geometry of the late sixtiesmost notably Rip Tom's lengthy wire-cage elevator ride straight up and down over the darkening Manhattan skyline, all the while mimicking words and phrases from a radical speech played on a tape recorder that he holds in his arms.But very little of "One P.M." is like this. For as handled by D. A. Pennebaker (I should guess, the principal photographer) the film is less an essay in radical politics or in Godardian esthetics or. Heaven forbid, in the useful craft of documentary, than it is homage to the zoom lensan optical contrivance that in the hands of bad cinematographers, to whom it mostly appeals, keeps things artificially jumping, and, at least in this case, 60 per cent out of focus.I don't know why "One A.M." was abandoned. There has been talk of Godard's failure to understand the nature of the movement in America. But after looking at the quality of the film work in "One P.M." it seems to me that the reason could quite properly have been despair.

title: 17 L.I. Legislators Vow to Battle Any Busing Law
description: ALBANY, Feb. 10A bloc of 17 Republican legislators 12 from Nassau County and five from Suffolk  pledged strong opposition today to a state commission's recommendation that the Legislature require the busing of pupils, when necessary, to achieve racial balance.

title: Defense Loses Two Key Motions in Kansas Rape CourtMartial
description: FORT LEAVENWORTH, Kan., Feb. 10The defense in the courtmartial of a black Army trusty charged with raping white lieutenant colonel's wife suffered two major defeats today in its effort to prove that the armed services legal code violates the Constitution on several important points.

title: HEALTH CARE PLAN WIDENED BY N.E.W.
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 10Legislation to bring about sweeping changes in the cost, delivery and regulation of health care was proposed by the Nixon Administration today after a year of internal struggle.

title: CONTRACT AWARDS
description: Combustion Engineering, Inc., annnounced yesterday receipt of a 858million contract from the Georgia Power Company for two 880,000kilowatt steam generators. The units, scheduled for operation in mid1976 and 1977, will be installed as the first two units in the utility's Yellowdirt steam plant on the Chattahoochie River about 30 miles southwest of Atlanta. The plant will be coalfired. Georgia Power is an operating subsidiary of the Southern Company.

title: NO PROS IN GAMES, BRUNDAGE AVERS
description: SAPPORO, Japan, Friday,1 Feb. 11 (UPI)Avery Brundage, amateur extraordinary and guardian of the Olympic movement, said today that professionals will never be admitted to the Olympic Games.

title: Vandals Damage Gardens
description: EAST LANSING, Mich., Feb. 10 (UPI)Vandals broke into the botanical gardens at Michigan State University during the night and broke off name tags of every plant in the building, the campus police reported today. Damage was estimated at about $300.

title: Four on Ice Floe Rescued
description: CHICAGO, Feb. 10 (AP) Four persons stranded on an ice floe off the shore of Lake Michigan near Michigan City, Ind., were rescued today by a Coast Guard helicopter. None of them were injured.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: Arnold Whitridge's letter regarding the role of British forces in Northern Ireland [Feb. 4] very conveniently overlooks the significant facts that have contributed to the present crisis.

title: G.M. WILL EXPAND RESEARCH STAFF
description: DETROIT, Feb. 10The General Motors Corporation will greatly expand its basic research staff, a step that was recommended by a committee of scientists who were appointed last year to advise the corporation on how it could meet the broad problems of society.

title: Shop Talk
description: A versatile, lightweight, wellstyled coat that is also reasonable in price isn't unheard of, but it's often hard to find. A new import from Taiwan fills all the qualifications. The coat, which tips the scales at two pounds, is completely reversible, with buttersoft leather on one side and suede on the other Both sides are smartly outlined in white stitching, have four goodsized pockets and are snapfastened down the front. The colors are rust, red and navy blue, and the size range goes from 5 to 13. The undertheknee boot length is $95. There is also an identical jacket, weighing 1 pounds, for $79. Both are at Honeybee at 7 East 53d Street.

title: Critic on Nixon Panel In Pennsylvania Race
description: PITTSBURGH, Feb. 10 (AP) Joseph Rhodes Jr., who in 1970 served as the youngest member of the President's Commission on Campus Unrest and criticized President Nixon and Vice President Agnew on the Kent State violence, declared today his candidacy for a seat in the Pennsylvania House.

title: CANADIENS DOWN BLACK HAWKS, 71
description: MONTREAL, Feb. 10 (AP)'uy Lafleur's third threegoal game of the campaign and fivepoint night by big Frank Mahovlich powered the Montreal Canadiens to an easy 71 National Hockey League victory over the Chicago Black Hawks tonight.

title: Rail TonMileage Up 2.5%
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 10 The Association of American Railroads reported today that freight traffic in the week ended Feb. 5 totaled an estimated 14.1 billion tonmiles, up 2.5 per cent from the level a year earlier. Carloadings for the week totaled 465,521, down 1.9 per cent. The American Trucking Associations reported truck tonnage in the latest week was 4.8 per cent above the level a year ago.

title: NEW RULES URGED ON SECRET PAPERS
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 10The National Security Council has proposed an Executive order, tightening regulations governing the handling of classified information and suggested the possibility that the President might seek legislation to make it a crime for unauthorized persons to receive secret documents, a White House officiial said tonight.

title: Wings Rally Tops Sabres
description: DETROIT, Feb. 10 (UPI)Marcel Dionne's 15th goal of the season capped a threegoal second period tonight that lifted the Detroit Red Wings to a 42 victory over the Buffalo Sabres.

title: Money Supply Still Rising
description: The Federal Reserve's credit policy remained on its expansive path during the most recent twoweek period, central bank data published yesterday indicated.

title: 2 Zeckendorf Suits End;
description: A settlement of two lawsuits seeking $51million in damages from William Zeckendorf Sr., the realestate developer, for $860,000 has been approved in Federal District Court here by Judge Edward C. McLean.

title: SAIGON SEALS OFF RAIDED ORPHANAGE
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Feb. 10 (AP)South Vietnamese police have sealed off the country's biggest orphanage after raid last weekend In which officials say more than 100 draft evaders were arrested.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: Senator Kennedy's Feb. 5 letter raises an immediate question of what it is that really should appall us. The intensely romantic view of the requirements of our national heritage, recalling, as It was no doubt intended to, the tone of his brother's inaugural address, is chilling. Surely the ghastly decade of the nineteensixties with its rhetorical overkill, its inflated gestures, its escalating violence and deception is also now part of our national heritage. Hasn't anybody learned anything at all In the last twelve years about the difference between emotional commitment and the sane, dispassionate conduct of national policy?

title: B.B.C. Radio Bans Song On Ulster by McCartney
description: LONDON, Feb. 10A vocal demand by songwriter Paul McCartney to give Ireland back to the Irish is to he kept from radio listeners in Britain.

title: A Cake With Strawberries for Valentine's Day
description: In the menus below, the dishes marked with an asterisk are followed by a recipe.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: Recent Times editorials on the tragedy in Northern Ireland have been far off the mark. They have consistently understated the plight of the Catholic minority in that English province. The deaths in Derry City on Jan. 30 are tragic, but they will continue until the reforms promised since 1968 are implemented.

title: Two Deaths in Brooklyn Laid to Gas Leak in House
description: A woman and one of her three young sons died of gas poisoning yesterday in the bedroom of their apartment in the BedfordStuyvesant section of Brooklyn, the police said.

title: Britain Shows a Deficit Of $5.2 Million in Month
description: Britain lost ground in January in the battle to earn trade surplus, selling $5.2million less abroad than she bought. The deficit contrasted to a surplus in December.

title: Murphy Stars for Rockets
description: HOUSTON, Feb. 11 (UPI)Little Calvin Murphy, in a rare starting role, scored 28 points tonight to lead the Houston Rockets to a 11695 triumph over the Baltimore Bullets, only the third time in Rocket history that they have beaten Baltimore.

title: CLARA FRIEDMAN
description: Clara Friedman, who served two terms in the late 1940's as president of the Association of Retired Teachers, died yesterday in the New York Infirmary. She was 82 years old and lived at 136 East 55th Street.

title: DEMOCRATS TO GET BRIEFINGS ON WAR
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 11 The Administration, in an apparent response to criticisms from Senator Hubert H. Humphrey, said today it would try to provide highlevel briefings on Vietnam and other foreign policy problems to Democratic candidates for the Presidency.

title: CITY PUT FORWARD AS CONVENTION SITE
description: A three day program designed to sell New York as the ideal place for major conventions got under way yesterday at the Americana Hotel, Seventh Avenue and 52d Street.

title: Al Capp Is Fined $500 Plus Costs In Morals Charge
description: EAU CLAIRE, Wis., Feb. 11 (AP)Al Capp was fined $500 and costs today on one of three morals charges resulting from accusations made by a university coed last spring.

title: Merger News
description: The Esterline Corporation announced yesterday that it had reached an agreement to acquire the industrial timer division of the Singer Company and also Integrated Systems, Inc., and also agreed to purchase 80 per of a European control instrumentation company.

title: Text of Statements From Time Inc. and McGrawHill
description: Following are the texts of statements issued yesterday by Time Inc. and by McGrawHill. Inc., on the purported autobiography of Howard R. Hughes:

title: Pennsylvania Sues U.S. Steel on Air. Pollution
description: PITTSBURGH, Feb. 11 The State of Pennsylvania and Allegheny County filed suit today to compel the United States Steel Corporation to comply with air pollution regulations at the world's largest privately owned steel mill.

title: Notes on People
description: I am interested in any effort to save the natural beauty of Florida. So saying, Julie Nixon Eisenhower officially handed over $1.4million worth of Federal land to the State of Florida and various cities and counties. The ceremony, at which Mrs. Eisenhower was besieged by autograph seekers, was presided over by Nat Reed, Assistant Secretary of the Interior, and attended by a Marine honor guard and 2,000 school children. It was conducted on a 4.5acre waterfront plat in the Coconut Grove section of Miami. The land, valued at $900,000 and once an air station, will he converted into a public

title: RICHARD L. DOUGHERTY
description: FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., Feb. 11Richard L. Dougherty, former head of the purchasing department of Bell Laboratories, Murray Hill, N. J., died yesterday in Holy Cross Hospital. He was 58 years old and lived in Pompano Beach.

title: AT HOME ABROAD
description: LONDON, Feb. 11  A 61yearold gambler, drifter and exconvict died on Jan. 18 in the 13roward Medical Center, Fort Lauderdale, Fla. His name was Clarence Mud Gideon.

title: U.S. AND THE SOVIET TO POOL RESEARCH IN 3 HEALTH AREAS
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 11The United States and the Soviet Union announced an agreement today to pool efforts in a fight against cancer, heart disease and environmental health problems.

title: Soviet Meat and Egg Output Rose to Records Last Year
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 11 (AP)  Meat and egg production rose to record levels in the Soviet Union last year, the Agriculture Department reported today.

title: Hulls Dawn Hawks
description: CHICAGO, Feb. 11 (AP) A rugged defense, led by Bob Love and Jerry Sloan, shackled Atlanta's Pete Maravich and Lou Hudson tonight, as the Chicago Bulls defeated the Atlanta Hawks, 10291.

title: Miss Hewitt Married To Dr. A. Duane Beam
description: MIAMI BEACH, Feb. 11Miss Jacqueline Hewitt, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John S. Hewitt of West Springfield, Mass., and Lyford Cay, Nassau, was married here Wednesday to Dr. A. Duane Beam, son of Mrs. Arthur Beam of Grosse Pointe, Mich., and the late Mr. Beam. The civil ceremony was performed by Judge George Schulz of the Dade County Circuit Court in his chambers.

title: MOSCOW SAYS NIXON SEEKS CAPITULATION
description: MOSCOW, Feb. 11 (UPI)The Soviet Government said today that President Nixon's eightpoint peace plan was unsatisfactory and that Communist acceptance would mean full capitulation.

title: Opposition Leader In Bahamas Asks Inquiry on Hughes
description: NASSAU, the Bahamas, Feb. 11The opposition Free National Movement has asked the Government here for positive evidence that Howard R. Hughes is actually living in the Bahamas.

title: 800 at Rally Near Paris Say U.S. Sabotages Talks
description: VERSAILLES, France, Feb. 11 One of the biggest international assemblies ever held on Indochina opened here today with expressions of total support for the Vietcong and North Vietnamese positions. There was also condemnation of the United States refusal yesterday to agree to a date for the next session of peace talks because of the intolerable pressure of the assembly.

title: Cougars Suspend McDaniels, Their Missing Rookie AllStar
description: WINSTONSALEM, N. C., Feb. 11 (UPI)The Carolina Cougars of the American Basketball Association suspended Jim McDaniels for falling to appear for their game tonight with the Denver Rockets.

title: Butz Is Concerned Rise in Food Prices May Lead to Curbs
description: DES MOINES, Iowa, Feb. 11 (UPI)  The Secretary of Agriculture, Earl L. Butz, said today that consumer pressure in an election year might push the Nixon Administration into imposing a ceiling on food prices and to close the door on possible increases in farm prices.

title: Communist Support Alleged
description: SALISBURY, Feb. 11 (Agence FrancePresse)The Rhodesian Government said tonight that Communists were behind a rally in London tomorrow that is to be addressed by Bishop Muzorewa.

title: Hughes Watcher Helped 2 Publishers
description: First there were the telephone conversations. The slow voice from the West Coast, responding to questions from the offices in the McGrawHill skyscraper at 330 West 42d Street.

title: AIRMAN FACES TRIAL ON SPYING CHARGES
description: TYNDALL AIR FORCE BASE, Fla., Feb. 11 (AP)M. Sgt. Walter Perkins, a military intelligence agent who has served 19 years in the Air Force, will face a general courtmartial later this month on espionage charges, a spokesman here said last night.

title: From the Plaza to the Guggenheim: A Week's Potpourri of Fashion Shows
description: A Cuban who fled Castro and set up shop in Puerto Rico, a Japanese designer who's making wayout Western clothes in Tokyo and an avantgardist who held a vernissage at a museum because he doesn't believe in fashion shows contributed to the eclectic nature of the fashion scene in New York this week.

title: Soho Opens Its Gallery For Photos
description: If young painters and sculptors are hard put nowadays to find adequate exhibition space in New York, young photographers perhaps find it even more difficult. The galleries that specialize in photography are few in number and tend to spotlight artists of established reputations.

title: HARRELSON SIGNS, SEA VER DOES NOT
description: The New York Mets signed Bud Harrelson yesterday, but .said he and the club were stalemated  with indications that the bidding had passed $100,000.

title: Physician Says Black Lung Clinic Is in Need of Funds
description: BECKLEY, W. Va.  When coal miners fear they have in. haled too much coal dust in their years under the ground and they seek federal black lung disability benefits, the first step is usually a trip to Beckley.

title: Nyack Justice Is Indicted On a Petit Larceny Charge
description: NEW CITY, N. Y., Feb. 11Aaron G. Windheim, a 39yearold Nyack village justice, has been indicted on a charge of petit larceny in the alleged shoplifting of a ski jacket and ski hat worth $36.98.

title: Pearl Bailey Hospitalized
description: HOLLYWOOD, Feb. 11 (AP) Pearl Bailey, the singer, was reported in good condition tonight at the Mount Sinai division of the CedarsSinai Medical Center, after suffering a heart attack. A hospital spokesman said Mis Bailey, who is 53 years old, was admitted last night as an emergency patient.

title: Controllers Back Accord
description: OTTAWA, Feb. 11 (Canadian Press)Air traffic controllers, whose 11day strike in January tied up almost all commerical air traffic, have voted 3 to 1 in support of the agreement with the Government that sent their dispute to arbitration.

title: Sports of The Times
description: In the years when Weeb Ewbank was coaching the Baltimore Colts, he tested rookie offensive tackles by putting them in a oneonone situation with Gino Marchetti, then the National Football League's premier defensive end. One day, with an assistant coach imitating the quarterback's signals by barking, Hut, hut, a rookie lunged, but Marchetti grabbed him by the shoulder pads and swept by him. The rookie was advised to get lower in his stance. Again the coach barked signals. Again the 6foot4inch.

title: The Price of Gold
description: The Administration is ready to send legislation Congress formally devaluing the dollar by raising the price of gold from $35 to $38 an ounce. Chairman Patman of the House Banking and Currency Committee intends to hold hearings on the bill later this month. We trust that the committee will speedily approve this bill since devaluation is completely in the national interestand to delay might result in intensifying uncertainties about the dollar.

title: UNITY OF MILITARY WORKS IN CANADA
description: OTTAWALieut. David Cosette is a Canadian infantry officer. He spent last year aboard a destroyer in the Arctic Sea and the Caribbean.

title: Gloria Steinem Aids McGovern's Cause
description: MANCHESTER, N.H. Feb. 11 Gloria Steinem, the feminist, is endorsing Senator George McGovern before surprisingly large New Hampshire crowds as the best white male candidate for President this year.

title: DR. IRVING J. FRIEDMAN
description: Dr. Irving J. Friedman, a dentist for more than half a century, died yesterday at Mount Sinai Hospital. He was 77 years old and lived at 161 East 88th Street.

title: All Are Safe as Antarctic Cruise Ship Goes Aground
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, Feb. 11 (AP)The Norwegian cruise ship Lindblad Explorer, whipped by high, Icy winds, ran aground off St. George Island in heaving Antarctic seas today. All her passengers, mostly Americans, were rescued by a Chilean Navy transport.

title: ALBERT W. REIBLING
description: OSSINING, N.Y., Feb. 11Albert W. Reibling, senior vice president for administrative services of Ted Bates, New York advertising agency, died yesterday in Montefiore Hospital, New York, after a long illness. He was 59 years old and lived at 2 Possum Road.

title: DARTMOUTH LEADS ITS SKI CARNIVAL
description: HANOVER, N. H., Feb. 11The Dartmouth Winter Carnival started on a happy mite for the hosts today as the Big Green skiers led the teem standings at the conclusion of the first two events.

title: EDWARD LE VINE OF THE BRASS RAIL
description: GREAT NECK, L, Feb. 11Edward Levine, founder of the Brass Rail Restaurants, one of the bestknown restaurant chains in New York City, died today at his home, 1 Kensington Gate. His age was 77.

title: Books of The Times
description: TkIE DEAD OF THE HOUSE. By Hannah Green. 180 pages. Doubleday. $5.95.

title: Julie Berghold, 66 Debutante, Bride of James W. Sykes Jr.
description: Miss Julie Elizabeth Berghold, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William F. BerghId of New York, was married in St. Ignatius Loyola Roman Catholic Church here yesterday to James Ware Sykes Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Sykes of New York and East Hampton, L.I. The ceremony, performed by the Rev. D. Bradley Murray, was followed by a reception at the Colony Club.

title: East Coast Dock Vote
description: MIAMI BEACH, Feb. 11 (AP) Leaders of the International Longshoremen's Association set today a vote for March 8 on a new national contract that would avert the threat of a renewed East and Gulf Coast dock strike if it is approved by union members. The proposed contract. would cover some 45,000 men.

title: Obstruction in Rhodesia
description: It has long been obvious that Rhodesia's white Government had no intention of keeping its promise to allow normal political activities during the Pearce Commission's canvass of opinion on the proposed settlement with Britain. Even the patient Lord Pearce has finally protested the violation of the pledge and suggested that the widespread arrests of opponents of the agreement were designed to inhibit the free expression of opinion.

title: COLISEUM'S DEBUT DRAWS 7,892 FANS
description: UNIONDALE, L.I., Feb. 11 From the time the Huntington Thunderers Marching Band blasted out the National Anthem, it was apparent tonight that the new Nassau Coliseum was going to have a folksy flavor.

title: Sales Club Salutes Successful Ladies
description: The girls were honored yesterday by the Sales Executive Club of New York. It was a Valentine's Day Salute to the Ladies that was enough to break a feminist's heart.

title: Bridge: Playing a 33 Trump Suit Usually Done by Accident
description: A basic principle of bidding Is to search for a trump suit in which the combined hands have at least eight cards, with the proviso that a sevencard fit is acceptable on occasion.

title: Jewish Dropouts Found Unstructured Synagogues
description: We will not extinguish these Sabbath candles. To me they symbolize Judiasm and the people that uphold its principles. Judaism is the lamp that lights the way for many. After years of struggle against wind and water, always a spark remains to keep the lamp going.

title: Ohio State Objection
description: COLUMBUS, Ohio, Feb. 11 (UPI)The Ohio State University athletic director, J. Edward Weaver, said today he was concerned with the challenge of the Big Ten commissioner, in a decision by a Minnesota athletic committee to reinstate two suspended Minnesota basketball players.

title: Appeals Court Bars a Halt To Pentagon Papers Inquiry
description: BOSTON, Feb. 11 (AP)The United States Court of Appeals for the First Circuit today turned down a petition from Dr. Daniel Ellsberg to stop the Federal grand jury in Boston from investigating publication of the Pentagon papers.

title: Golden Girl Lets Skis Do the Talking
description: SAPPORO, Japan, Feb. 11 Vermonters are tactiturn folk, mostly minding their own business and staying put. It's in the history book that Ethan Allen and his Green Mountain Boys crossed the New York border long enough to demand the surrender of the British at Fort Ticonderoga.

title: NECESSITY MOTHER OF BID FOR HOLIDAY
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 11 This is the anniversary of the birth in 1847 of Thomas Alva Edison, inventor of the incandescent lamp, the phonograph and other things. A move is afoot to make Feb. 11 National Inventors Day.

title: Trade Talks Are Pledged
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 11The United States and the European Common Market announced today the details of a new trade agreement, aimed at helping some United States agricultural exports, and also disclosed a joint commitment for major trade negotiations in 1973.

title: KNICKS SET BACK BUCKS BY 113101; ROBERTSON RESTS
National Guard Is Short of Men As War Lags and Draft Eases
description: The Army National Guard, long able to pick and choose its members like a social club with a long waiting list, is now threatened by a serious manpower shortage.

title: Joan Diener's Mother Dies
description: Mrs. Rosalind Diener, mother of Joan Diener, the actress, died Thursday at the Methodist Hospital in Houston, Tex. Mrs, Diener, who lived at 50 East 64th Street, was 60 years old, She had gone to Houston for heart surgery. In addition to her daughter, she leaves two sisters, a brother and two grandchildren.

title: Canadian Exports Gain
description: OTTAWA, Feb. 11 (UPI)Canada's exports in January increased 5.1 per cent from a year ago to $66million, the Canadian Statistics Bureau said today. The preliminary figures showed that The increase in export shipments was confined to the United States market, as all overseas destinations registered declining demand for Canadian exports, the bureau said.

title: Export Trade Insured
description: The Foreign Credit Insurance Association announced yesterday that the Bunge Corporation, the exporter of soybeans, grains and vegetable oils has bought a master export political insurance policy for $550million, the largest such policy ever issued. With the risk spread among more than 50 insurance companies, the policy protects from losses caused by political disturbances and upheavals on its export trade to 50 different countries.

title: Express Bus Runs to Link Coney Island and Midtown
description: The Transit Authority will begin express bus service Monday linking Coney Island with Wall Street and midManhattan. It will be the authority's ninth express bus service in four boroughs and the second in Brooklyn since Jan. I.

title: Ban on Two Court Stars Is Lifted by Minnesota
description: MINNEAPOLIS, Feb. 11 (UPI) The University of Minnesota Committee on Intercollegiate Athletics announced today it had voted to reinstate two Minnesota basketball players who were suspended after fight that ended, the Minnesota. Ohio State game last Jan. 25.

title: Retail Sales Remain Steady for January
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 11Retail sales in January were essentially unchanged from the December level after seasonal ladjustments, preliminary figlures indicated today.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: Needed: A New Definition

title: Nets Christen New Home With a 129121 Triumph
Cinecom Chairman Resigns
description: Rafael Ramos Cobian announced his resignation yesterday as chairman of Cinecom Corporation, an operator of 100 motionpicture theaters. Mr. Cobian remains the largest individual stockholder of the company.

title: CELTICS CONQUER LAKERS, 121 TO 108
description: BOSTON, Feb. 11 (AP)Don Nelson, a reserve forward, scored 24 points tonight as the Boston Celtics defeated the Los Angeles Lakers, 121108, in a National Basketball Association game.

title: Border Declares Rockefeller Trails Reagan on Colleges
description: Dr. Albert H. Bowker, former chancellor of the City University and now head of the University of California at Berkeley, said yesterday that Governor Rockefeller's recent record in higher education was much worse than that of California's Governor, Ronald Reagan.

title: U. S Critic of Lysenkoism, In Film, Stirs Soviet Parley
description: MOSCOW, Feb. 11Despite the eclipse of Trofim D. Lysenko, once Stalin's ideological chief of science, a filmed appearance by one of his outspoken critics has reportedly caused a sensation at a Soviet biological congress.

title: 201 Community Aides Graduate From Police Academy
description: The first class of 201 community service officers in the Model Cities police program graduated yesterday at the Police Academy, 235 East 20th Street, after a fivemonth training program.

title: Aged Volunteers Bring a Bit Of Sunshine to Willowbrook
description: At the Willowbrook State School on Staten Island, Mondays, Wednesdays and Thursdays are a little more active and a little more cheery than the other days of the week

title: Fleet Taxi Drivers Strike at 2 Garages Over Share of Fares
description: Fleet taxi drivers at two Bronx and Manhattan garages staged wildcat strikes yesterday in a demand for a larger share of metered fares.

title: FUNSTON TO LEAVE OLIN CORP. BOARD
description: G. Keith Funston, chairman of the Olin Corporation and former president of the New York Stock Exchange, announced yesterday that he would step down from the Olin board at the company's annual meeting April 27.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: Negotiated Settlement

title: Bordaberry Named Victor as Uruguay Ends Election Count
description: MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, Feb, 11 (AP)Two and a half months after the balloting, complete but unofficial returns gave victory today to Juan M. Bordaberry of the Incumbent Colorado party in Uruguay's most bitterly contested presidential election.

title: Railroads Reach Pact With Firemen and Oilers
description: BAL HARBOUR, Fla., Feb. 11  The nation's railroads and the International Brotherhood of Firemen and Oilers, reached agreement here today on a new pact that will provide pay increases totaling 97 cents to $1 an hour for the 13,000 railroad workers represented by the union across the country.

title: Search for Youth, 20, Lost in Rockies, Ends
description: FORT COLLINS, Colo., Feb. 11The formal search ended today for 20yearold Fred Stone, a Colorado State University sophomore from Minneapolis, lost in the rugged Longs Peak Yegion of the Rocky Mountain National Park in Colorado.

title: Chicago Bear in Tax Case
description: CHICAGO, Feb. 11 (AP)Criminal charges of filing late Federal income tax returns for the years 1967 through 1969 were lodged against Dick Gordon, a wide receiver for the Chicago Bears football team who played out his option last season.

title: January Net Deposit Inflow Set Mark at Savings Banks
description: The National Association of Mutual Savings s33anks estimated yesterday that savings banks had a record net deposit inflow for a January last month of $710million. This exceeded the previous mark of $G37million set a year earlier.

title: Reading Industries Lifts Copper Water Tube Price
description: Price increases in copper water tubing, colortelevision picture tubes, sulphur and polyethylene cable were ananounced yesterday by a variety of producers.

title: Irving Is Offered Deal on Immunity
description: The Justice Department has informed the office of United States Attorney Whitney North Seymour Jr. that it would approve immunity for Clifford Irving's wife and his former researcher if Mr. Irving would plead guilty to predetermined charges.

title: State May Appeal Decision on Voting in Primaries
description: ALBANY, Feb. 11  Knowledgeable officials said today that the state would appeal the Federal Court decision declaring unconstitutional the law requiring prospective voters in a primary election to have been enrolled in a party before the preceding general election.

title: A. L. CUNNINGHAM, EXADVERTISING AIDE
description: BOSTON, Feb. 11  Arthur Lawrence Cunningham, former advertising manager of JohnsManville, Inc. buildingproducts manufacturer, died yesterday in a nursing home. He was 76 years old.

title: Congressman Asks U.S. to Subsidize Black Businesses
description: A black Congressman, declaring that the political strength of minority groups may be shortlived unless it is matched with economic strength, advised the United Mortgage Bankers of America yesterday to reject white slogans such as laissezfaire and rugged competition and concentrate instead on contributing to a black consortium of business enterprise.

title: PROTESTERS PUSH LINDSAY BACKERS
description: Top city officials led more than 1,300 guests last night through a gantlet of demonstrators, some of whom kicked and shoved them, to attend a dinnerdance of the John V. Lindsay Association of Queens at the Terrace on the Park in Flushing Meadows.

title: An Unknown Campaigns to Stir Voter
description: CONCORD, N. H., Feb. 10Edward Coll, hardly showing above a tightly buttoned tweed overcoat and beneath a curtain of hair that insisted on sliding in front of his face, shivered with the cold.

title: Businessmen Optimistic
description: WASHINGTON (UPI)  The United States Chamber of Commerce said today businesmen ended 1971 convinced of better times ahead.

title: SALVADOR'S LEFT BIDS FOR POWER
description: SAN SALVADOR, Feb. 9El Salvador, the smallest and most crowded country on the American mainland, has a reputation for conservatism matched by no other LatinAmerican republic. It offers the classic example of a wealthy minority and an impoverished majority, with only 8 per cent of the population apparently in control of half of the national product.

title: PIANO PREMIERES GIVEN BY HIM
description: Not many pianists in any season face up to recital programs as demanding as Dwight Peltzees at Alice Tully Hall Thursday night. Mr. Peltzer not only gave the first performance of Loren Rush's Hexahedron and the first New York performance of Peter Lewis's Innerldp for Plano, but also threw in, along the way, such trifles as Haydn's Sonata in E flat (the 1798 one usually known as No. 52), Beethoven's Sonata in A flat (Op 110), Salvatore Martirano's Cocktail Music for Piano and Ravel's Gaspard de la Nuit.

title: COUNCIL WEIGHS BID TO CATHOLICS
description: CHARLOTTE, N. C., Feb. 11 Whether the Roman Catholic Church should join the National Council of Churches was the question before the council's 250member policymaking general board this afternoon as it opened its fiveclay midwinter meeting here at the White House Inn.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: Make the Taylor Law a Just Law

title: Boulez Conducts Wozzeck Excerpts
description: Just about the time the New York Philharmonic concert at Philharmonic Nall on Thursday night became really engrossing, it ended.

title: Appeal Weighed in Jacobson Case
description: The Nev York Racing Association acknowledged yesterday it was considering an appeal of a court ruling that could pave the way for Howard (Buddy) Jacobson's return to New York as a horse trainer.

title: SINGER TO CLOSE ROCHESTER PLANT
description: The Singer Company announced yesterday that it planned to phase out production of its business machines division at Rochester over the next six months. Richard 0. Bally, president of the division, said the plant would then be closed permanently. It employs approximately 900 workers and produces the company's Flexowriter line of automatic writing machines.

title: Hollywood Boulevard to Add Star in Cement for Chaplin
description: HOLLYWOOD. Feb. 11 (AP) Charles Chaplin will get his sidewalk star on Hollywood Boulevard after all.

title: Mistreatment Charged
description: DUBLIN, Feb. 11, (Reuters)William Cardinal Conway, Roman Catholic Primate of All Ireland, said there was impressive evidence that men in internment in Northern Ireland were being illtreated.

title: MORE CHURCHES SOUGHT IN POLAND
description: WARSAW, Feb. 11Polish bishops called upon the GovernIment today to show understanding for the religious needs of Roman Catholics by allowing the building of new churches.

title: Miss Chaffee Is Wed to T. R. Cox 3d
description: Miss Raleigh Anne Chaffee, a stockbroker with Blyth & Co., investment bankers, was married here last evening to Thomas Riggs Cox 3d, manager of C. E. Hooper, a subsidiary of the radio and custom market research concern of Daniel Starch & Staff. The Rev. Kenneth Jones performed the ceremony in the chapel of the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church.

title: Executive Changes
description: J. Patrick Barrett has been elected vice president and chief financial officer of the Carrier Corporation. He succeeds William H. Alvord, who has been elected a director, vice president and chief financial officer of the USM Corporation, Boston.

title: Sculpture Grows in Brooklyn
description: A oneton spiraling steel sculpture by the Israeli artist Buky Schwartz, was unveiled yesterday outside the Brooklyn Museum at Eastern Parkway and Washington Avenue as part of a program to circulate large outdoor sculptures throughout the city.

title: DR. HENRY M.SCHEER, OTOLARYNGOLO GIST
description: Dr. Henry M. Scheer, an ear, nose, and throat specialist here for many years, died Thursday in West Palm Beach, Fla., where he was spending the winter. He was 79 years old and lived at 135 East 83d Street.

title: U.S. Jets Continue Raids as Foe Cuts Ground Attacks
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Feb. 11  American fighterbombers and B52 heavy bombers continued their intensified air strikes against enemy positions and supply lines in South Vietnam today, the United States command announced.

title: PERU UPHOLDS ORDER AGAINST PUBLISHER
description: LIMA, Peru, Feb. 11 (AP)Peru's military Government today upheld an order removing publisher Pedro G. Beltran as editorial director of La Prensa and ordering him to sell his stock in the Lima newspaper.

title: MISS TAZAKI SHOWS GIFT IN PIANO DEBUT
description: Two excerpts from Messiaen's Vingt Regards sur l'Enf ant Jdsus made an unconventional beginning for Etsuko Tazaki's program in Carnegie Recital Hall Thursday night. It was a shrewd choice on the young Japanese pianist's part, since it showed her off to the best advantage. She held the music, rightly, in a kind of suspended, slowly evolving motion, without letting it die. There was color and tonal charm enough for these mystical compositions.

title: Powell Refuses to Hold Up A Georgia Integration Order
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 11 (AP) Associate Justice Lewis F. Powell Jr. of the Supreme Court today refused to stay a Federal Court desegregation order for elementary schools in Richmond County, Ga.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: Fleischmann Study Flaws

title: P.B.S. RECONSIDERS A SATIRE BY ALIEN
description: Misgivings about a Woody Allen political satire television show has caused the Public Broadcasting Servzce to give its noncommercial station members an optional alternate show.

title: Workers Picket Site of Lefrak Project in queens Halted by the City
description: Angered over the loss of their jobs, more than 50 construction workers yesterday picketed the site of a 400unit Lefralt middleincome project on the Forest HillsKew Gardens border in Queens.

title: A Day Students Had to Decide What to Do
description: MAMARONECK, N. Y. Rye Neck High School's 936 students were given an exercise in multiple choice one day last week. From 8:30 A.M. to 2 PM, the seventh to twelfth graders were permitted to select from an academic smorgasbord that included a dizzying array of celebrities and subjects, including doing nothing (for which two rooms were set aside).

title: Man hi the News
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 11For him to engage in a public confrontation was improbable, a friend of Fred Speaker was saying. For the confrontation to be with a Republican Vice President was, well, unimaginable. But It happenedand that's a tribute to how seriously he took his job. Today, 10 clays

title: Thompion's Ashes Buried In Colorado Farm Town
description: LAS ANIMAS, Colo., Feb. 11 (UPI)The ashes of Llewellyn E. Thompson, former Ambassador to the Soviet Union who advised President Kennedy to remain firm in the 1962 Cuban missile crisis, were buried today beside the graves of his parents in the small farm town where he was born.

title: Measles Cases Drop
description: ATLANTA, Feb. 11 (UPI)The National Center for Disease Control reported today a decrease of 42 per cent in the number of measles cases since last fall. According to the center, this decline coincides with a significant increase in the distribution of measles vaccine.

title: Youth Counselor Is Indicted On MurclerAttempt Charge
description: A 24yearold youth counselor with the Naitonal Council on Crime and Delinquency was indicted yesterday in State Supreme Court in the Bronx on charges of attempted murder and assault.

title: Heard Gains Lead by 2 at 295 After Carding 69 in Hope Golf
ST. PATRICK PARADE TO MOURN IRISH DEAD
description: The St. Patrick's Day Parade Committee said yesterday that marchers in the March 17 parade had been authorized to wear black arm bands or sashes in memory of the 13 persons slain by British troops in Londonderry, Northern Ireland, last month.

title: Rep. Mills Officially Enters Race For the Democratic Nomination
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 11 Representative Wilbur D. Mills, Democrat of Arkansas, a previously unannounced but obvious candidate, said today that he was running for the Democratic Presidential nomination and would be at the Miami Beach convention in July seeking support.

title: White House Inscrutable On Nixon's Cram Course
description: KEY BISCAYNE, Fla., Feb. 11If President Nixon manages to resist the lure of the sun, sea and Bebe Rebozo's houseboat, Coco Lobo II, he will have a fair crack at answering many questions the Chinese may throw at him during his trip.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: Berlin's Wall Remains

title: New Look at Utility Rates
description: The Price Commission's order of a temporary freeze on rates charged by all privately owned utilities reflects a decision that control over this major element in living costs cannot be left entirely to the normal regulatory agencies in a period of overall wageprice restraints.

title: Some Parking Rules Lifted
description: Alternate  side  of  thestreet parking regulations will be suspended today because of the Lincoln's Birthday holiday. All other traffic and parking and parking meter regulations will remain in effect. Regular Saturday postal service is al3o in effect.

title: The Times's Pythias Lodge To Induct New Members
description: A ceremony for new members of the Arthur Hays Sulzberger Lodge, No. 852, of the Knights of Pythias will be held tomorrow.

title: Patterson Shows After 10 Rounds He's Standup Guy
description: Floyd Patterson began his 20th year of professional prize fighting last night by beating Oscar (Ringo) Bonavena of Argentina in 10 rough rounds.

title: MRS. MARTIN EGAN; ASSISTED CHARITIES
description: Mrs. Martin Egan, who was active in charitable causes, died Thursday at her home after a long illness. She was 83 years old and lived at 1 East End Avenue.

title: Shedding More Light on Dove's Work
description: The American painter Arthur Dove died in 1946 at the age of 66. In the quartercentury that has passed since his death, there have been many exhibitions of his work, and informed opinion more or less agrees that he is one of the most important figures in the socalled first generation of American moderniststhe generation that felt the first impact of the modern movement in Europe and succeeded in adapting its radical esthetic premises to the specifications of American experience.

title: DR. G. EDWARD HALL
description: LONDON, Ontario, Feb. 11 (AP)Dr. G. Edward Hall, a medical scientist who was decorated by the United States for aviation research in World War II, died today. He was 64 years old.

title: News Analysis
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 11 New statistics on school integration compiled by the Department of Health, Education and Welfare point up a large and growing disparity between Northern and Southern cities in racial isolation.

title: Soar Quits Umpiring For League Desk Job
description: BOSTON, Feb. 11 (AP)Hank Soar, an American League umpire the last 22 years, has given up his whisk broom to become an assistant to Dick Butler, the league supervisor of umpires.

title: 3 More Alternate Jurors On List for Berrigan Trial
description: HARRISBURG, Pa., Feb. 11 (AP)A woman who wanted to remain a prospective alternate juror got her wish today at the Federal conspiracy trial of the Rev. Philip F. Berrigan and six other antiwar activists.

title: Senator Buckley Says U.S. Fails Its Asian Alies
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 11Senator James L. Buckley of New York said today that the failure of the United States to provide adequate military aid to its Asian allies was creating agonizing doubts as to the ability or willingness of the United States to sustain its role of leadership in the Western Pacific.

title: In Rome, Protest Demonstrations Are Achieving New Heights
description: ROME, Feb, 11Monumentclimbing has suddenly become a fashionable form of protest and dissent in Rome.

title: Article 2  No Title
description: LITTLE ROCK Ark., Feb. 11 (AP)  John L. McClellan, declaring that his age may be an asset, formally announced today as a candidate for sixth term in the United States Senate.

title: MARY SULLIVAN REILLY
description: RAHWAY, N.J., Feb. 11 Mrs. Mary Sullivan Reilly of 599 West Scott Avenue, a poet and author, died Wednesday at her home. The wife of John F. Reilly, she was 75 years old.

title: GATT Gets JapanU.S. Views
description: GENEVA, Feb. 11A joint statement by the United States and Japan calling for a major international assault on trade barriers next year is being circulated to the SO nations of the General Agreement on Tariff and Trade.

title: Sheikdom of Ras al Khaima Joins New Emirates Union
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Feb. 11(AP)The Union of Arab Emirates, founded Dec. 2 on the Persian Gulf, added a seventh member today, the sheikdom of Ras al Khaima.

title: COPPER FUTURES SHOW FIRM TONE
description: Prices of most copper futures on the Commodity Exchange of New York closed unchanged, yesterday from Thursday's gain of one cent a pound. There was commissionhouse shortcovering, new buying and some trade selling. The May contract closed at 51.25 cents a pound, unchanged, from the previous close, and the July contract closed at 51.75 cents a pound, also unchanged.

title: Deaths
description: BALDORosarlo. Beloved husband of Mare, devoted father of Nicholas, Millie Giglio and Peter. Dear orandfather and great. grandfather, licensing Metropolitan Fu. neral Chapel, 191 Ave. A, (12th St.), Manh. Services Mon., Feb. 11, Our Lade of Sorrows Church, Pitt and Stanton Ste., 9:30 A.M.

title: Government Study Urges Eased Laws on Marijuana
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 11Dr. Bertram S. Brown, director of the National Institute of Mental Health, made public today a new study by his agency on the effects of marijuana that urged that penalties for the use of marijuana be eased.

title: 2 Dead in Barge Blast
description: NEW ORLEANS, Feb. 11 (AP) An explosion ripped through a barge at the Avondale Shipyards near here today, killing two men. Another man was missing and several were injured. The blast, which came while the barge was undergoing repairs, tore the vessel away from a dock on the Mississippi River, and it drifted across the river and sank.

title: Insiders Stockholdings
description: The American Stock Exchange yesterday issued its latest report on changes in stock ownership among directors, officers and major stockholders of its listed companies. The New York Stock Exchange did not publish a list for this week.

title: Pennsy Line Bondholders Want to Be Paid Off Now
description: Holders of $10.2million of bonds or a Penn Central line lowyielding securities with years still to runhave moved lo be paid off now because the road has not paid some real estate taxes. The Morgan Guaranty Trust Company confirmed yesterday that it had notified the New York and Harlem Railroad Company, a leased line that runs from Grand Central Terminal to Chatham, N. Y., that it was declaring $2.4million of 3 per cent first mortgage bonds maturing in 2000 to be due and payable immediately.

title: Miss Holum Is 2d in 3,000 Skate Final
description: SAPPORO, Japan, Saturday, Feb. 12 (AP)Dianne Holum of Northbrook, Ill., captured the United States first silver medal at the 11th Winter Olympic Games today, finishing second to Stien BaasKaiser of the Netherlands in the grueling 3,000meter speedskating test.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: Legal Services Programs

title: PICKETT SINGS HITS AT THE COPACABAN A
description: Wilson Pickett opened at the 1Copacabana Thursday night, and I hope he survives the experience. Confining the powerful soul singer's churning energies to the artificial palm tree and Del Monte fruit cocktail environs of the Copa might work in time, but it sure wasn't working on opening night.

title: Mrs. Michael DeBakey, 62, Wife of the Heart Surgeon
description: HOUSTON, Feb. 11 (UPI)Mrs. Diana Cooper DeBakey, the wife of Dr. Michael E. DeBakey, pioneer heart transplant surgeon, died of a heart attack today at Methodist Hospital. She was 62 years old.

title: Art: Horst Antes's World of Sorcery
description: Horst Antes, who has oneman show of new paintings at the Lefebre Gallery, 47 East 77th Street, is a young German belonging to a generation of European artists for whom, even more than for Americans, the cubistfauvist revolution of the early 20th century supplies the natural, the unchallenged, virtually the officially established international tradition within which to work in very much the way the Ecole des Beaux Arts served French painters in the 19th century.

title: BROWN SETS BACK DARTMOUTH, 9488
description: PROVIDENCE, R. I., Feb. 11 Brown University staved off a furious secondhalf rally by Dartmouth tonight and triumphed 9488.

title: MRS. F. N. HARTMANN
description: ST. SIMONS ISLAND, Ga., Feb. 11Mrs. Elizabeth Bell. woar Hartmann, wife of F, Norman Hartmann, retired president of the Lily Tulip Cup Corporation of New York, died yesterday at the Brunswick Nursing Center after a long illness. She was 66 years old.

title: Harvard Downs Yale
description: NEW HAVEN, Feb. 11Jim Fitzsimnions, a sophomore, scored 29 points tonight in leading Harvard to a 9274 victory over Yale. It was the first Ivy League triumph for the Crimson after six straight losses. This raised their overall wonlost record to 810. Mike McLaren had 18 points for Yale, 43 in Ivy League play and 611 over all.

title: BRITAIN ENFORCES WIDE POWER CUTS
description: LONDON, Feb. 11The British Government ordered industry today to reduce its use of electricity drastically because of the national coal strike. The move will mean a threeday iweek for most factories.

title: GUILTY PLEA ENDS ARMY TEST CASE
description: FORT LEAVENWORTH, Kan., Feb. 11A black Army trusty charged with raping a white lieutenant colonel's wife suddenly entered a plea of guilty late this afternoon after his attorneys had tried unsuccessfully for four days to challenge the constitutionality of the armed forces legal code.

title: A World Without Growth?
description: NEW HAVEN, Conn.  Anthony Lewis, in two recent issues of The New York Times, warns us of the deadly consequences of growth. Running out of resources, running into total pollution, running to the point of total exhaustion and collapse those are the ultimate rewards of growth. We must stop growth, not just of population, but of production and income.

title: Hungary's Misplaced Crown
description: The thousandyearold Hungarian Crown of St. Stephen which fell into American hands at the end of World War II was reputedly presented to Stephen by Pope Sylvester II as a symbol of appreciation for his country's conversion to Christianity. Some churchmen regard the crown as a vital token of Hungary's Roman Catholic heritage, and Jozsef Cardinal Mindszenty, the exiled Hungarian primate, has appealed to President Nixon not to release it to the present Communist rulers whom he regards as interlopers.

title: OftBombed Chicago Statue Moves Indoors
description: CHICAGO, Feb. 11.Chicago's most frequently bombed statue, a ninefoot, bronze tribute to seven policemen killed by a bomb, has been moved indoors, presumably to safer quarters.

title: JUDGE EXTENDS STAY ON SALES AT CADMAN
description: State Supreme Court Justice Jacob Markowitz continued a temporary stay yesterday barring sale of apartments in Cadman Towers and reserved decision on whether to grant a temporary injunction.

title: Patterson Gains Decision Over Bonavena at Garden
description: The ghost of Floyd Patterson walked in Madison Square Garden last night, and the sad part of it was that the ghost won. Looking no more like twotime champion of the world than one would expect of a 37yearold In his 20th year as a professional fist fighter, Patterson still had enough to win a unanimous decision in 10 rounds with rough, inept Oscar Bonavena.

title: MRS. PIETRO CORRADO
description: Mrs. Concetta Maucieri Corrado, the wife of Dr. Pietro Corrado, died of cancer yesterday at Mount Sinai Hospital after surgery. She was 65 years old and lived at 333 East 79th Street.

title: Rhodesian Blacks Reject Charge of Intimidation
description: SALISBURY, Rhodesia, Feb. 11 (Reuters)The African National Council today denied charges by Prime Minister Ian D. Smith that blacks were being intimidated into opposing the proposed BritishRhodesian settlement.

title: Two Atlantic Cables Out; Satellite Is Being Used
description: The long lines department of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company said yesterday that two of its transAtlantic cables had been severed and have been out of operation for more than a week. The Communications Satellite Corporation reported that the Atlantic Intelsat satellite had taken over the traffic until repairs are made.

title: P9rtuguese Toll of 90 Listed
description: DAR ES SALAAM, Tanzania, Feb. 11 (Agence FrancePresse) Mozambique Liberation Front guerrillas killed 90 Portuguese soldiers in the Cabora Bassa Dam area, a guerrilla communiqu for last October and November said today. It said the guerrillas carried out 19 major ambushes and 25 sabotage operations in Tete Province during the period.

title: COLUMBIA WARNED ON JOBBIAS PLAN
description: The Department of Health, Education and Welfare said yesterday that it had rejected Columbia University's latest pro:. posal concerning job discrimination and that $13.8million in Government contract awards would continue to be withheld pending the presentation of satisfactory plan by April 6.

title: Market Place Salmon's Closing Creates a Furor
description: It isn't widely appreciated outside trading circles, perhaps, but there is a furor in the overthecounter market arising out of the recent closing of S. J. Salmon 8c Co.

title: Dr. Merle Fainsod of Harvard, Leading Soviet Scholar, 64, Dies
description: CAMBRIDGE, MASS., Feb. 11Dr. Merle Fainsod, one of the nation's leading scholars in Soviet studies and director of the Harvard University Library died of a heart attack last night in Mount Auburn HospiHis age was 64.

title: Lament for Tvardovsky
description: MOSCOWThere are many ways of killing a poetthe method chosen for Tvardovsky was to take away his offspring, his passion, his journal. The sixteen years of insults meekly endured by this hero were as nothing so long as literature was not stopped, so long as his journal survived, so long as people could be printed in it, so long as people could go on reading it. But then they heaped the coals of disbandment, destruction and mortification upon him, and within six months these coals had consumed him. Within six months, he took to his deathbed: and only his characteristic fortitude sustained him till now, to the last drop of consciousness, of suffering.

title: Vietcong Said to Free 10 Captured Filipinos
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Feb. 11 (AP)United States sources said tonight that 10 Filipinos captured by the Vietcong last August, reportedly after their boat washed ashore in a storm off the South Vietnamese coast, had been released.

title: Envoy From Cairo Says Door To Suez Talks Remains Open
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 11 Egypt has not closed the door to participation in indirect talks with Israel on the possibility of reopening the Suez Canal, a senior Egyptian diplomat said today.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: Hazards in New Buildings

title: Soviet Boxers Held To a 33 Deadlock By American Team
description: ZF1DANOV, Soviet Union, Feb. 11 (AP)Bobby Lee Hunter, a convict on leave from a prison in Columbia, S.C., Marvin Johnson and Duane Bobick led the United States boxime team to a 33 tie with the Soviet Union today Tass, the Soviet news agency, reported.

title: Denial of Source
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 11Stanley Meyer, an entertainment executive, said in an interview tonight that he once had possession of both the unpublished manuscript of Mr. Phelan's book on Mr. Hughes and the one that is now being published under the title of Howard, the Amazing Hughes.

title: COOKERY LIVENED BY TEDDY WILSON
description: Teddy Wilson is back in town for the first time in two years, playing at the Cookery, University Place and Eighth Street, and it is almost as though he had never been away. From year to year, decade to decade, Mr. Wilson remains constant. His crisp, precise touch, the calm orderliness of his style, and his ability to appear both concentrated and detached as he sits at the keyboard seem the same today as when he was playing with the Benny Goodman trio and quartet more than 35 years ago.
