Even the tunes he plays Stompin at the Savoy, Sophisticated Lady, Liza, Body and Soul, Somebody Love Me, Don't Be That Wayare the same tunes he has been playing down the

title: 3 Cleveland Jail Aides Suspended as 19 Flee
description: CLEVELAND, Feb. 11 (AP) Three top officials at the city work house were suspended today after 19 inmates sawed their way out of the facility in Warrensville Heights last night.

title: Poison Charges Hold Two
description: CHICAGO, Feb. 11 (UPI)Two youths charged with conspiracy to commit murder in a plot to poison Chicago's water supply system were held for grand jury action today. Criminal Court Judge Robert Sulski said he would order a court psychiatrist to examine the two Allen Schwandner, 19 years old, of Chicago, and Steven Pera 18, of Evanston.

title: Jobs Urged for Veterans
description: CHICAGO, Feb. 11 (UPI)In an appeal to business to hire more veterans, James D. Hodgson, Secretary of Labor, said today that the unemployment rate for veterans was higher than for nonveterans in the same age group. Mr. Hodgson, addressing the American Management Association, said that veterans were flooding the employment marketmore than 400,000 veterans without jobs todayand we owe it to ourselves to see that he gets one.

title: Then Came Galich's Turn
description: On Dec. 29, 1971, Aleksandr Galich, a Soviet playwright and film scenarist, was expelled from the Moscow branch of the Writers Union. Galich, 53 years old, is especially famous inside Russia for his ballads and songspoignant and often sharply satirical works which he plays on the guitar for his friends. He sings about the realities of everyday Soviet life, about prisons and concentration camps (which he knows from years of personal experience), evoking laughter through tears in the tradition of Russian satire. The Soviet authorities have never permitted publication or recording of Galich's songs, but they are privately and widely circulated on tape and in the uncensored typewritten transcripts of sanazdat.

title: Music: Young Boheme
description: Puccini's La 13oheme is a perpetually young opera that deals with young people, and it is nice to see young people in it, as does not always happen in the world's opera houses. There we often get aging sopranos and superannuated tenors whose tendons creak as they make love to each other. The opera never fails to make some kind of effect; it is almost foolproof. But it is best served when believable bohemians are cast in it, and that is what the Juilliard American Opera Center managed to do at the Juilliard Theater Thursday night.

title: Lisbon Investigates Angola Subversion
description: LISBON, Feb. 11Portuguese military and police forces have begun investigations of subversive activity in southern Angola, bordering the troubled Ovamboland area of SouthWest Africa, according to reports reaching here.

title: Brooke Won't Be Delegate
description: BOSTON, Feb. 11 (AP)Senator Edward W. Brooke, Republican of Massachusetts, will not go to the Republican National Convention in San Diego this summer as a delegate, the Republican State Committee announced today.

title: Area at Truman Home Declared a Landmark
description: INDEPENDENCE, Mo., Feb. 11 (UPI)The property surrounding the home of former President Harry S. Truman has been declared a national historic landmark, Secretary of the Interior Rogers C. B. Morton announced today. The annownement came three days before the 87th birthday of Mr. Truman's wife, Bess Wallace Truman. Mr. Truman is 87.

title: Rockefeller Is Disputed on York College
description: ALBANY, Feb. 11  State Senator Jack E. Bronston charged Governor Rockefeller today with grossly distorting the impact of New York City's openadmissions policy on privatecollege enrollment.

title: Antiques: Hunting for Fan Designs of the 18th and 19th Centuries
description: You can buy a recent novelty fan at the local flea marketbut why not hold out for a really fine earlier example?

title: SOME TEAMSTERS OPPOSE DOCK PACT
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 11 (UPI)The longsimmering dispute between teamsters and longshoremen unions created possible major obstacle today to settlement of the West Coast dock tieup.

title: COAST DEMOCRATS TO CAUCUS TODAY
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 11Democrats in this state will hold an unusual series of political meetings tomorrow, and while party members have high hopes, no one knows whether the new procedure will work.

title: Blasts in Belfast Wreck Store and Office
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Feb. 11 (AP)Bomb blasts wrecked a furniture store and an office in downtown Belfast today.

title: M.T.A. Buys 35 Buses In Nassau for Local Use
description: The Metropolitan Transportation Authority yesterday bought for 6356,336 a fleet of 35 buses owned by Nassau County and operated by three private bus companies in that county.

title: MILTON C. BRITTAIN
description: Milton C. Britain, an investment broker with Harris Upham & Co., Inc., died at Roosevelt Hospital on Thursday. He was 65 years old and lived at 1160 Third Avenue.

title: H. S. RICHARDSON SR., PHILANTHROPIST, 86
description: WESTPORT, Conn., Feb. 11 (AP)  H. Smith Richardson Sr., chairman of Richardson, Merrell, Inc., head of the H. Smith Richardson Foundation and noted philanthropist, died today in his home. He was 86 years old.

title: Six Jewish Groups Suggest a Meeting With Black Leaders
description: Six Jewish organizations expressed willingness yesterday to meet with black leaders, politicians, the interference of politicians, in an effort to reduce spiraling racial tensions or to find a solution to the argument about the lowincome housing project being built by the City Housing Authority in Forest Hills, Queens.

title: Abraham Lincoln in New York
description: On Feb. 27, 1860, Abraham Lincoln came to New York and delivered an address at the Cooper Institute (now Cooper Union). Henry J. Raymond's New York Times reported, There was a very large meeting of Republicans last night to listen to the noted political exhorter and prairie orator, Abe Lincoln, who was vehemently cheered and frequently applauded. Horace Greeley's New York Tribune said, No man ever before made such an impression on his first appeal to a New York audience. These closing remarks on slavery put Lincoln in the national limelight.

title: F.C.C. AIDE WEIGHS SENATE RACE IN IOWA
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 11 (UPI) The Federal Communications Commissioner. Nicholas Johnson, an outspoken critic of the broadcast industry and even of his own regulatory agency, is considering running for the Senate from his home state of Iowa.

title: Malraux to Visit President Before the Journey to China
description: PARIS, Feb. 11 (UPI)The writer Andre Malraux, who visited Peking in 1965 and talked with Mao Tsetung, said today that he had accepted an invitation to confer with President Nixon in Washington before the President leaves for China.

title: Notes On Metropolitan Congressmen
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 11In contrast to some 6f his colleagues from New York who are worried about challenges in the June primary election because of redistricting, Representative Peter A. Peyser, Republican of Westchester County, has few doubts about the identity

title: Ginaburg to Surrender Here
description: PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 11 (UPI) Ralph Ginzburg, the magazine publisher, will surrender to the Federal authorities in New York next week to begin serving a threeyear prison sentence on a 1963 conviction of distributing obscene materials through the mails. It was disclosed today in a letter to Federal District Judge E. Mac Troutman that Ginzburg would surrender to a United States marshal next Thursday in Foley Square.

title: Dance: King Is Dead
description: Dunas's Work Is Given at Theater Laboratory

title: Breakdown of Truce at Angkor Imperils Cambodian Temples
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 11 The fragile truce that has protected the historic Cambodian ruins of Angkor for 20 months has broken down in recent weeks, and officials here fear that heavy and destructive fighting may soon develop in the area.

title: Lending Rates Steady
description: The First National City Bank and the Irving Trust Company said yesterday following weekly reviews of their floating prime lending rates that the current 4 per cent level would be maintained for the week beginning. Monday. The rest of the banking system is at 4 per cent.

title: The Rights of Lincoln
description: One hundred ten years ago, in his message to Congress, President Lincoln reminded the legislators and his countrymen that even in the midst of a war our national strife pertains to ourselvesto the passing generation men; and it can, without revulsion, be hushed forever, with the passing of one generation.

title: China and Japan in Frogs Legs Trade War
description: GENOA, ItalyJapan and Communist China, each armed with kingsized frogs legs, are fighting a mini trade war for domination of the market in Italy, where land reclamation and pesticides have almost exterminated frogs.

title: Rev. Pal Brezanoczy, 60, Hungarian Archbishop, Dies
description: VIENNA, Feb. 11 (AP)The Right Rev. Pal Brezanoczy, Roman Catholic Archbishop of Eger in Hungary, died today after a long illness, the Hungarian news agency, reported. He was 60 years old.

title: Arise, Ye Prisoners.
description: Even if prison authorities were normally more receptive than they are to proposals for basic reform, it would be easy to understand the swift refusal of State Correction Commissioner Oswald to recognize the prisoners union formed by inmates of Green Haven prison in the Hudson Valley.

title: Protestant Accuses Army
description: TORONTO, Feb. 11 (AP)A Protestant member of Northern Ireland's Parliament has accused the British Army of premeditated murder of the 13 civilians killed in Londonderry.

title: Wallace Listed as Democrat In Massachusetts Primary
description: BOSTON, Feb. 11 (AP)The name of Alabama's Governor, George C. Wallace, has been placed on the Democratic party ballot for the April 25 Presidential primary by Secretary of State John F. X. Davoren.

title: DOS TAKES STAND TO DEFEND OFFICE
description: HACKENSACK, N. J., Feb. 11  Robert DIIts, the suspended Bergen County Prosecutor, took the witness stand today at his trial in Superior Court here to deny any wrongdoing in the conduct of the office he held until his indictment here last June.

title: Life Finds Irving's Manuscript a Hoax And Cancels Plans to Publish Excerpts
description: Life magazine has canceled its plans to publish excerpts from an alleged autobiography of Howard R. Hughes because, it was charged in a statement issued for the magazine last night, the manuscript is hoax perpetrated by Clifford Irving.

title: Ali Defeats Johnson And Handles Referee
description: PORTAUPRINCE, Hati, Feb. 11 (AP)The former heavyweight champion, Muhammad Ali, knocked out Alzon Johnson tonight in the fifth round of a scheduled 10round exhibition fight that included some ribbing of the referee.

title: LAVER, ASHE, OKKER, ROSE WALL ADVANCE
description: PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 11 (AP) The first four seeded players Ken Rosewall, Rod Laver, Tom Okker and Arthur Ashewon places tonight in the semifinal round of the United States professional tennis championship at The Spectrum.

title: Moscow Theater Tour
description: The Children's Theater of Moscow will make its first appearance in this country at the Saratoga Performing Arts Center in Saratoga, N.Y., on June 21. Additional performances are being planned. The group, consisting of adult performers, Is being brought to the United States as part of the Fourth International Congress of the Association Internationale du Thetltre Pour L'Enfance et la Jeunesse.

title: Patents of the Week
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 11Jack Anne] recommends his gamma ray equipment, which was patented this week, as an inexpensive means of sterilizing medical And health sup plies, including surgeons gloves and throwaway uniforms. Mr. Armel, who is president of the Gamma Process Company, Inc., Ballston Spa, N. Y., and two coinventors were granted Patent 3,641,342. A prototype was built for the New York State Atomic and Space Development Authority at Malta, N. Y., and has been experimentally operated by Gamma Process. It is available for lease, and Mr. Armel says his concern is ready to run it for the lessee.

title: GoverningPower Shifts Criticized
description: Controller Abraham D. Beame yesterday criticized the practice of shifting government functions to special authorities. I urge extreme caution in further extending this practice, he said.

title: Police Panel Head In Dallas Named As 1925 Deserter
description: DALLAS, Feb., 11 (UPI)The Dallas police said today that the head of the local police civilian review board had, under another name, been listed as a deserter 47 years ago.

title: Court Bars a Sutton Place Shift to Coop
description: A State Supreme Court order has barred the owners of a 20story Sutton Place apartment house from converting its rentstabilized apartments into tenantowned cooperatives.

title: DR. JOHN J. KILCOURSE
description: Dr. John J. Ki'course, who retired in 1960 as a general practitioner and surgeon, died on Wednesday at his home, 2351 21st Street, Astoria, Queens, after a long illness. He was 80 years old and was a 1914 graduate of Flower Medical College.

title: Paris and Bonn in Accord
description: PARIS, Feb. 11  President Pompidou of France and Chancellor Willy Brandt of West Germany ended two days of talks today with an agreement to support the creation of A political seeretariat for Common Market countries and a move to press ahead immediately with plans to make Western Europe a singlecurrency zone in the nineteeneighties.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Repair Contracts Help Cut Rent Complaints to 8,482

title: DENISON WOULD SELL URANIUM STOCKPILE
description: Denison Mines, Ltd., is negotiating the disposal of its uranium stockpile, S. R. Roman, chairman, told stockholders at yesterday's annual meeting in Toronto. He said the stockpile had been established a year ago by the company and the Canadian Government.

title: POINT OF VIEW
description: The public accounting profession is presently haunted by the specter of a growing and highly embarrassing litigation. Court eases indicate that an evolutionary change has taken place. Instead of being primarily responsible to his traditional client, who hired him, the C.P.A. is now held accountable to the public at large that reads the certified financial statements.

title: Theater ht London
description: LONDON

title: Alternative Realities
description: So many holes have been poked in Western civilization that now that all the hot air is gone and a cold and alien wind is coming in, the civilized elite seem to be drawing deeply into themselves and their old convictions in search of warmth and comfort. In these declining years of the Magnus Annus the most interesting minds seem to have moved on long ago; now only the intellectuals remain, wrapped in their greatcoats of Europe, dreaming of leftist politics or the new creation of the avant garde; but tlfese are the warm dreams that come charitably to all those who are about to freeze to death. Better to turn and die running in a new direction than to stand still and become a historical monu

title: Williams College Fees Up
description: WILLIAMSTOWN, Mass., Feb. 12 (AP)  Williams College announced yesterday an increase in tuition by $250 to $2,700 yearly, and in room rent by $50 to $700, effective next September. The fee for board remains at $730.

title: Oh! What a Lovely Wharf: Notes from the Nassau Waterfront
description: NASSAU, Bahama IslandsAs he has done so many hundreds of days at Nassau's waterfront, Captain Fowler, a black Bahamian in rubber boots and wrinkled khakis, sits spreadeagled in the bottom of his small open boat, chipping away with a rusty hatchet at a sandencrusted conch shell drawn from the pile in front of him. Above his head, atop the concrete seawall, native customers call their orders for the succulent conch meat the captain slips from the sensuous red mouth of the shell after making educated knife cuts in the areas weakened by the hatchet blows.

title: New Evidence on Jesus Life Reported
description: JERUSALEM, Feb. 12 Two Israeli scholars believe they have unraveled an elusive mystery of early Christianityan apparently forged description of Jesus attributed to the JewishRoman historian Flavius Josephus.

title: SHOP TALK
description: VERONAYou may never have set foot in this borough, you may never have heard of it, but chances are you've been brought to your feet many a time by products made here, for Verona's 125yearold Annin & Co. is the largest maker of flags in the country.

title: Indoor Soccer Tourney Packing the Arena
description: PATERSON  Offside, offside! a man in a dark suit shouted from the upper level of the Paterson Armory. Is the referee blind? The guy was offside when he scored!

title: Jews in Remote Corners of the World
description: A harmless, rather readable item that will appeal to travelpage readers. The author has sought out unexpected places where Jewish convounities have settledTahiti, Fiji Islands, Philippines, New Zealand, Australia, Singapore, Japan, Hong Kong, India, Afghanistan, even Iran and Turkey. Some history of the places, some accounts of individual Jews.

title: Dick
description: GUESS what rare bit that Welshman Richard Burton is up to now: he's going to play the late Italian dictator Benito Mussolini, Burton, Who recently completed movies in which he appears as Trotsky and as Tito, has signed to play 11 Duce in The Last Days of Mussolini, a Leo PescaroloItalo Zingarelli coproduction to be filmed in English under the direction of Carlo Cotti. The original screenplay is by Mario Soldati and Cesare Garbo11, and shooting should begin in Italy in the fallafter Burton returns from Budapest, where he'll be loving it up with the likes of Raquel Welch, Ursula Andress and Joey Heatherton in

title: People moving under the skin; A Long Day in November; By Ernest J. Gaines. Illustrated by Don Bolognese. 137 pp. New York: Dial Press. $4.95. (Ages 10 to 14)
description: The trouble with many children's books about blacks is that they tend to be ethnic. Which means that they end up describing a group rather than telling a story about people. They also tend to be solemn and so full of suffering and sociology that the reader, if he is still there at the end, can only conclude there is just no fun being black.

title: THE WEEK IN FINANCE
description: IN two days, it will be exactly six months since the lqixon Administration shed its public confidence about the state of the economy and unveiled a new new economic program for fighting inflation and expanding employment on the domestic front and combatting trade and payments deficits on the international scenea bold effort and an historic one as well.

title: American Blacks Seeking to Influence the African Policy of U.S.
description: BARRANQUITAS, Puerto Rico Many black Americans are mobilizing to exert a greater influence on America's foreign policy toward Africa.

title: TV Mailbag
description: TO THE EDITOR:

title: CZECHS LOSE, b TO 2
description: SAPPORO, Japan, Sunday, Feb. 13 The Soviet Union's powerful ice hockey team completed the competition at the 11th Winter Olympic Games today with a goldmedal victory that also gave the silver medal to the United States, the Americans first hockey medal since their upset triumph in 1960.

title: 5 Countries Asked To Prohibit Hunting Polar Bears on Seas
description: GENEVA, Feb. 12Scientists from five countries with territory extending into the far north have asked their governments to conclude an agreement to prohibit the hunting of polar bears on the high seas.

title: 0:5.8 By Washington at 60
description: EAST LANSING, Mich. Feb. 12 (AP) Two Michigan State sprinters set indoor records tonight and five other meet records were shattered as tip, Spartans dominated the 49th annual Spartan Relays at Jeniscn Field House.

title: The World
description: BELFAST  Outside Londonderry last week, roadblocks interfered with traffic into the city. In Newry, the main street was shut down; rioting broke out. Nearly 1,000 persons marched through the streets of Strabane. And here in Belfast, hundreds of schoolchildren staged sitins, sang We Shall Overcome outside a jail for terrorist suspects and threw rocks at British soldiers and the police.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: Lee Kanner in an article Jan. 16 [Drop a Hint to an Architect in Mexico, and Wow!] gives the impression that Mexico is inhabited by bunglers and bandits. Only two weeks earlier the society section leads off with a piece damning Acapulco as an ecological wasteland and a tinsel Coney Island.

title: Roman star
description: Femme fatale and fin de siAcle are two faces of Valentino's romantic look for evening. The black chiffon dress is covered up to the neck in front, but plunges to the waist in back where it is marked with a pink camellia. The shirtwaist has a pink and white checked taffeta skirt.

title: PATROLMAN CHARGED WITH ROBBERY PLOT
description: A 24yearold policeman assigned to the 25th Precinct on East 119th Street was charged yesterday in Manhattan Criminal Court with conspiracy in allegedly helping a man to buy a gun for use in a planned robbery.

title: MANILA WILL TRADE WITH ALL RED LANDS
description: MANILA, Feb. 12The Philippines opened all doors yesterday to trade with Communist countries, incuding the Soviet Union and China.

title: Dunfrey Simpson Bride of Soldier
description: NEW CANAAN, Conn., Feb. 12Miss Dunfrey Holmes Simpson and Specialist 5 Harrison Souder Coombs Jr., U.S.A., were married hero this afternoon in the Congregational Church by the Rev. Charles Crawford Smith, assisted by the Rev. Grant A. Morrill, rector of St. Mark's Episcopal Church.

title: Italian Census Seems to Reveal Little More Than the Population's Reticence
description: ROME, Feb. 12Where did you spend the night from October 23d to 24th? was one of the many questions asked last fall on the 20page form in Italy's national census.

title: Packer to Close Its College in Spring
description: It's been a long run  127 years, to be exact. Enough to make the twoyear women's college of the Packer Collegiate Institute in Brooklyn Heights one of the oldest junior colleges in the state, one of the oldest women's colleges in the country and the last private twoyear academic college in the city.

title: Golf Writers Will Honor Trevino
description: Lee Trevino has been named winner of the Metropolitan Golf Writers Association's Gold Tee Award.

title: Dance: A Ballet That Extends Ballet
description: THE first thing to be said about Jerome Robbins's new ballet, Watermill, is that it is not a ballet. It is a theaterpiece that is so designed and structured that it could only be performed by trained (lancers, The second thing to be said about Jerome Robbins's Waterrain is that it is one of the two most important theatrical events of the seasonthe other is Peter Hall's staging of Harold Pinter's Old Times. Unlike the Pinter, however, Watermill is im. mediately innovative and represents a completely new phase in its creator's career.

title: Humphrey, Nixon sacked
description: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., Feb. 12 (AP)The St. Petersburg Times, Florida's secondlargest daily, has announced its endorsement of Senator Hubert H. Humphrey's candidacy in Florida's March 14 Democratic Presidential preference primary. On the Republican side, the paper endorsed President Nixon.

title: What Price Peace?; There Are Profits in Tennis War, Too, And Most Pro Players Are Cashing In
description: Professional tennis players, once nomads on a loosely organized tournament circuit, have become the latest group of athletes to cash in on a war situation within their sport.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: Clark Clifford's Formula

title: The Nation
description: Crisis Report.

title: Daughter for Mrs. Lemer
description: A daughter was born to Mr. and Mrs. Albert Lerner of Forest Hills, Queens, on Feb. I in the Klingenstein Pavilion, Mrs. Lerner is the former Miss Ellen Halbreich of New York. The child, whose father is a partner in Bass 8: Lemer, a certified public accountant firm here, Is named Alison Hope.

title: Drug Abuse Program Slated
description: YONKERS, Feb. 12A daylong educational program dealing with the problems of drug abuse will be held for physicians and paraprofessionals at the Carvel Inn here on April 26, under the auspices of the Yonkers Youth Services Agency and the Westchester Academy of Family Physicians. Dr. Sanford A. Kaplan, the academy's educational coordinator and adviser on narcotis to the Mayor of Yonkers, said manuscripts of up to 2,500 words dealing with new approaches to the management of drug addiction were being solicited by the program's sponsor.

title: Nigel MacEwan Weds Alison Jones
description: OLDWICK, N. J., Feb. 12Miss Alison Montgomery Jones and Nigel Savage MacEwan were married here this afternoon in the Zion Lutheran Church by the Rev. Russell Gromest.

title: St. Peter's Is Beaten
description: BUFFALO, Feb. 12 (AP) Two foul shots made by Aaron Covington in overtime tonight gave Canisius the edge over St. Peter's, 9695 in college basketball. A short jump shot by Coverington had knotted the game, 8686, and sent it into overtime.

title: The World
description: RAWALPINDI, PakistanThe I3ihari Moslems of Bangladesh are the latest victims on the Indian subcontinent, where hate, racism and religious intolerance have enjoyed triumphant pasts and in all probability share bright futures.

title: Jewish Militant Charged On Coast in Attack on Nazi
description: EL MONTE, Calif., Feb. 12 (UPI)The head of the Los Angeles chapter of the Jewish Defense League, a militant group, has been charged with assault with intent to commit murder against the head of the local Nazi party.

title: 5 Women Here Sue CARE, Alleging Sex Discrimination
description: Five womenthree employes and two former employes of CARE, Inc.  have filed suit against the international relief organization, charging it with sex discrimination in violation of the 1964 Civil Rights Act.

title: Women Find Work Behind the Camera
description: NEWARK  New Jersey's Great Swamp, a marshy magnet for nature lovers, school children, and wouldbe deer hunters, also attracted two women who have turned many hours of trying to ignore their wet feet into a special exhibit at the Newark Museum, 4349 Washington Street.

title: Poetry Has Made Friends With Everyone
description: There may be no more readers of poetry now than in the past, but there is no question that there is more poetry available for them to read. Profusion is a problem for initiates and beginners alikeall those schools swimming before us, striped and spotted on the paperback shelves. The refuge and true guideas was 15 years egois still Randall Jarrell's POETRY AND THE AGE (Noonday, $2.85), the best collection of essays on modern American verse. With its general pieces (The Obscurity of the Poet and The Age of Criticism), with its pioneering essays on Robert Frost, its remarks on Wallace Stevens, above all with its penetrating introductions to Whitman and William Carlos Williams, the most visible influences on our contemporary verse, Jarrell's book still has the power to prepare us for the poetry now appearing. It also provides models for thinking about poetry as it comes out: there are superb early reviews of Elizabeth Bishop and Richard Wilbur, and tough praise and blame for the early books of Robert Lowell, who ob

title: Words Are Money in Zurich
description: ZURICH, Switzerland, Feb. 12 (Reuters)A local member of the Zurich Canton Parliament told fellow members during a debate how he had worked out that every minute of debate cost the Zurich taxpayer $10. He ended his fourandahalfminute speech apologizing for the fact that it cost $45.

title: What the Higher Sales Tax Means In Suffolk
description: HAUPPAUGE, L.I.Every man, woman and child on Long Island will be spending, on the average, $25 more next year.

title: About Pro Football
description: When they were making the television movie last year about Brian Piccolo and Gale Sayers, the one called Brian's Song, Abe Gibron played himself and the casting was perfect. Abe at the time was a 45yearold assistant coach for the Chicago Bears who weighed 300 pounds. who had a bullfrog voice and a philosophy honed while playing guard for 10 years in the Na tional Football League. Abe was everyman's version of football coach.

title: Mrs. Williamson Married in Capital
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 12 Mrs. Ann Dolan Williamson, widow of Ronald Stanton Williamson, was married here this morning to Charles Steinman Foltz Jr. of Brookville, Md., senior editor of the international staff of U. S. News &, World Report. Superior Court Judge Theodore R. Newman Jr. performed the ceremony in his chambers.

title: The Philippines Has A Disneyland Too
description: ANILA  The muscular, sunbronzed islander wore a loincloth and carried a wickedlooking spearand fell into a slouch that made him look like a bored young movie extra.

title: Daley and McCarthy Both Weaker, in a Replay of 68
description: CHICAGO, Feb. 10Two of the principal antagonists in the drama of Chicago, 1968  the confrontation on the floor of the old amphitheater and in the parks and streets of the cityare moving toward another con. test.

title: Rosewall and Laver Reach Pro Tennis Final in Spectrum
description: PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 12 (AP) Ken Rosewall, playing in his first tournament since last December, lost the first set and then staged a comeback to take the next three as he defeated Arthur Ashe, 26, 76, 76, 62, today in the semifinal round of the $45,000 United States professional indoor tennis tournament.

title: Russo Is One of Six Trenton Prisoners Injured in Stabbings
description: TRENTON, Feb. 12Anthony Russo, a chief of organized crime in Monmouth County, was injured seriously yesterday when he and five other inmates of the Trenton State Prison were stabbed.

title: Professor Panels Are Urged for the State
description: The establishment of panels of distinguished professors to serve clusters of colleges in different regions of the state was suggested last week by Dr. Ernest L. Boyer, chancellor of the State University.

title: New Hampshire Five Wins
description: BURLINGTON, Vt., Feb. 12 (AP)Dave Pemberton became the fourth man in the school's history to break the 1,000point career mark today as he led New Hampshire to a 6955 Yankee Conference basketball victory over Vermont. Pemberton was high scorer for New Hempshire with 29 points, to raise his career mark to 1,028.

title: WASHINGTON REPORT
description: WASHINGTON Some additional issues have been added to the long list raised and only partly resolvedby the report of the Securities and Exchange Commission on the future of the securities market.

Pico Boulevard, Los Angeles, Calif. 90064 (N. Y. office; 5820 Broadway, Woodside, N. Y. 11377). The development of this camera began several years ago with a series of consumer seminars in which experienced amateurs and professionals were queried as to what they

title: Stamps
description: THE Winter Olympic Games are on in Sapporo, Japan, and many nations, including the host country, have released stamps commemorating the event.

title: Makarios Rejecting Greek Demand for a Larger Role on Cyprus
description: NICOSIA, Cyprus, Feb. 12 (AP)The President of Cyprus, Archbishop Makarios, has rejected a Greek demand for greater. Greek influence on Cyprus, Government sources here said today.

title: Jersey Bill Will Seek to Limit Heavy Industry Along Shoreline
description: TRENTON, Feb. 12Legislation to ban new heavy industries along most of New Jersey's Atlantic coastline and beside the Delaware River as far north as Trenton is expected to be introduced in the State Assembly tomorrow.

title: Court Bars Return of Child To Mother After Adoption
description: PROVIDENCE, Feb. 12 (AP)  The Rhode Island Supreme Court has ruled that an infant voluntarily and legally given up for adoption shall not be returned to the natural mother if she changes her mind.

description: Trends

title: ROCKEFELLER HAILS NIXON AT 2 DINNERS
description: Governor Rockefeller extolled President Nixon as the Man of the hour and, at two lavish Republican dinners In the city last night, enthusiastically called for his reelection in November.

title: DogLittering Foe Puts The Onus on the Owners
description: We citm't hate dogs, Fran Lee said. In fact, I dig dogs. and they kind of dig me.

title: Auto Buyers Doubt Warranty
description: DETROIT, Feb. 12She called me a liar and I lost the sale, said Ray Altimari, an American Motors car dealer in Philadelphia.

title: Trial in Yablonski Case
description: WASHINGTON, Pa., Feb. 12 (UPI)Paul E. Gilly, 38 years old, of Cleveland, one of five sons charged in the slaying of a United Mine Workers official, Joseph A. Yablonski, and his wife and daughter in 1969 will probably go on trial Feb. 22. Washington County Court Judge Charles G. Sweet is expected to rule early next week on motions seeking a change of venue and challenging the jury selection system.

title: U.S. AIR ATTACKS IN SOUTH VIETNAM HEAVIEST SINCE 70
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Sunday, Feb. 13An intense United States bombing campaign against Communist base areas along the LaotianSouth Vietnamese border entered its fifth day today as the United Statees command reported the heaviest American air raids in South Vietnam in two years.

title: Adamant James, Top Dog in 71, Honored for Record 86 Blues
description: Silver trophies, the Academy Awards for the dogshow world, were presented last night to the owners and handlers of the six dogs that had won the most groups during 1971. The ceremonies took place in the WaldorfAstoria at the 17th annual KenL Ration awards dinner and were attended by 400.

title: Jean K. McLeod Is Wed in Pelham
description: PELHAM, N. Y., Feb. 12In Christ Episcopal Church here this afternoon, Miss Jean Knight McLeod, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Anderson McLeod of Pelham Manor, was married to David LaRoy McAndrews, son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph L. McAndrews of Westerly, R. I. The Rev. David S. Hoag performed the ceremony.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: The article Lease Can Be a Time Bomb [Dec. 5] was a cruel disappointment to me. As I wish to be represented fairly, there are a few points which require elucidation.

title: Morris Watson, Newsman, Dies; Won Key Labor Law Test Case
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 12 (AP)Morris Watson, an early organizer of the Newspaper Guild, whose test case estabIshed the constitutionality of the National Labor Relations Act, died Saturday of cancer. He was 71 years old.

title: Muskie Wins 9 and Lindsay Gets 6 Arizona Delegates
description: PHOENIX, Ariz., Feb. 12Senator Edmund S. Muskie of Maine won nine delegates today as Arizona became the first state to pick delegates to the Democratic National convention in July.

title: George Guthrie Weds Laura McCord
description: RYE, N. Y., Feb. 12Christ's Episcopal Church was the setting here this afternoon for the marriage of Miss Laura Richardson McCord to George Gordon Guthrie. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Alanson B. Houghton, uncle of the bride, assisted by the Rev. Dr. Wendell W. Phillips, rector of the church. A reception followed at the home here of the bride's stepfather and mother, Mr. and Mrs. Sidney J. Weinberg Jr.

title: Lea Sigiel Bride on L.I.
description: CEDARHURST, L. 1., Feb. 12  The marriage of Miss Lea Sigiel, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. David Siglel of the Bronx, to Dennis C. Gross, son of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur Gross of Riverdale, the Bronx, took place here today at the Sephardic Temple. Rabbi Arnold B. Marans performed the ceremony. The bride, a City College graduate, teaches in New York.

title: Guerrillas Near Vientiane
description: VIENTIANE, Laos, Feb. 12 (Agence FrancePresse)AntiGovernment forces have advanced into the Vientiane Plain immediately north of the capital for the first time, military sources disclosed today. The sources said that on Thursday, men believed to be Pathet Lao guerrillas killed four truck drivers in a forest 25 miles northwest of here and escaped with their vehicles and a bulldozer.

title: Old Papers Collected In Effort to Save Pines
description: FORT WORTH, Tex., Feb. 12This city of more than 400,000 residents will begin on Monday a pilot program that it believes ultimately could save 34,000 pine trees each month.

title: Kerr: A LoveSuicide That Leaves Us Cold
description: THE general and his lady who dispose of themselves publicly In Romulus Linney's The Love Suicide at Schofield Barracks leave a great deal behind them. They leave, of course, the costumes in which they have killed themselves during the performance of an ancient Japanese play. They leave wills, all of their money going to Eurasian orphanages. They leave a tape recording of their actual deaths. And they leave detailed instructions for the official Army ingtmry into their motives that is to be conducted Immediately upon their demise. Would that they had left Mr. Linney some hint of how to make a of it all.

title: Hunt an Inviting Target
description: on Hunt of the Montreal Expos set a major league record last season when he was hit 50 times by pitched balls.

title: Drama Mailbag
description: To THE EDITOR:

title: SOVIET CONVERTS LENINGRAD PLANT
description: MOSCOW, Feb. 12  The Soviet Union has disclosed that the Leningrad cokegas plant, one of the worst industrial polluters of the nation's second largest city, had been shut down and converted to manufacturing.

title: Is Stanford's Business School Trying Hard Enough?; Given Its Status, Some Ask Why It Isn't No. 1
description: PALO ALTO, Calif. Their Profits Our Blood. The graffiti blemished one exquisite sandstone wall of the Stanford University Graduate School of Business last week, a pertinent reminder that there may be serpents in this paradise, too. Or at least skeptics about the role that this privileged Avis is playing in elite management education.

title: Residents on East Side Protest HighDensity Apartment Plans
description: Representatives of the City Planning Commission came to the Upper East Side last week Os sound out sentiment on local development programs under the city's master plan. A lot of the sound they heard on their tour were in opposition.

title: Paper Names Editor
description: FITCHBURG, Mass., Feb. 12 (AP)J. Robert Pelletier, managing editor of The Fitchburg Sentinel since 1968, has been named general manager and editor of the afternoon daily.

title: Victoria Ross Plans Nuptials
description: Mrs. John B. Dolan of Dublin has announced here the engagement of her daughter, Miss Victoria Leeming Ross, to James Lloyd Shreve. He is a son of Mr. and Mrs. James R. Shreve of Manlius, N. Y.

title: Wining, Dining, Wooing Starts In Albany on No Auto Plan
description: ALBANY, Feb. 12  The forces involved in the nofault auto ii.surance controversy have begun wooing the Legislature in earnest, with the State Trial Lawyers Association taking legislators out to dinner and public interest growing in the form of heavy mail support.

title: Cambodia Opens Attack Orr Angkor, Aide Says
description: PNOMPEN11, Cambodia, Feb. 12 (Reuters)  Government troops have opened an attack against enemy forces in and around the ancient Angkor temples, a high official said tonight.

title: State's Washington Lobby Pays Off
description: WASHINGTONThe Federal Government is growing by leaps and bounds, and so often the people back in the state government will look at a department like Health, Education and Welfare and see there are 110,000 employes, with offices in three large buildings here, plus Bethesda and Rockville. They don't know whom to see about their problem. So that's our jobto at least get the people together.

title: SOVIET TROUBLED BY TEENAGE CRIME
description: MOSCOW, Feb. 12To Western ears the story had a tragically familiar ring, but for the Soviet Union it was unusually frank  a gang of teenagers beginning with petty thefts and ending with murder, escaping boredom and getting their kicks out of violence.

title: Long Island Show Opens 9Day Run at West Hempstead
description: WEST HEMPSTEAD, L. I., Feb. 12Jammed to the gunwales with boats, motors and accessories, the Long Island Boat Show embarked today on what will be its final cruise at the Island Garden.

title: Child to Mrs. Fredricks
description: A daughter was born Feb. 1 to Mr. and Mrs. Richard Fredricks of New York in the New York University Hospital. Mrs. Fredricks is the former Judith Pennybaker of Stockton, Calif. Her husband is a baritone with the New York City Opera Company.

title: David vs. Goliath in Air
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Goliath is trying to topple David on one of the world's heavily traveled air corridor  between San Francisco and Los Angeles, Goliath in the scenario is United Air Lines, the nation's largest airline. David is tiny Pacific Southwest Airlines (P.S.A.), which flies only within California.

title: Beth Bornstein To Be a Bride
description: Mise Beth Ann Bornstein and Steven Elliot Locke have made plans to be married In June.

title: Marshall Has Romp
description: HUNTINGTON, W. Va., Feb. 12 (Al')  Russell Lee and Tyrone Collins combined for 149 points tonight to power Marshall's 11thranked team past Bowling Green, 9167. Lee, a senior center and Collins, junior guard, collected 26 and 23 points, respectively, in making Marshall's wonlost record 192.

title: Abelard And Heloise
description: These two books, from a series contributed by historians of academic distinction, deal with subjects that are among the halfdozen most familiar and most controversial in medieval history. The one presents the enigmatic story of the French philosopher and theologian Abelard, the other the suppression by crusades and Inquisition of the most notorious heretical sect of medieval Europe.

title: Largest Pothole, Oldest Plastic Church, Biggest Underground Mountain
description: ejUST as it is not for every, land to boast an authentic wonder of the world, not every American town cart rightfully claim a world's tallest building, longest bridge or slipperiest skating rink. Nevertheless, enterprise and imagination have enabled many an American community to heave itself up by its communal bootstraps, so to speak, from recordbook anonymity to the status of worldbeater. Of sorts, at any rate. The following listing records but a tantalizing sample of the riches America has thus developed:

title: Summer Bridal for Susan J. Lager
description: ATLANTIC BEACH, L. I., Feb. 12The engagement of Miss Susan Jill Lager to Richard Eric Teller has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. Fred Lager, parents of the future bride. Her fianc is the son of Dr. and Mrs. Aaron Teller of Great Neck.

title: Visions and revisionsan accursed implement
description: For some years the poet Clayton Eshleman, who is now in his midthirties, has been working to achieve a complex vision of himself. A revision, one might call it; his own term is emancipation, a deliverance of the self from the nonbeing of conventionality into the being of originality. At all events it is present aspect of the poetic rebirth known through the ages to poets of many mystical persuasions; and in his new book, Altars, Eshleman comes near to it. Except that the very nature of his task, imposed by the changing condition of time, denies him hope of completion. His success is only the first stage of an achievement that

title: Peter Bishko Weds Sherry B. Bostwick
description: SOUTH ORANGE, N. J., Feb. 12 In the Episcopal Church of the Holy Communion, where the bride's parents were married in 1936, Miss Sherry Bannister Bostwick, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Burdette Edwards Bostwick of Short Hills and Charleston, S. C., and Peter Bishko were married here this afternoon by the Rev. Robert B. Wardrop.

title: The Last Word
description: In the current issue of Partisan Review, Morris Dicksteinwho is white and Jewishhas written an article called The Black Aesthetic in White America. It is a calm, thoughtful look at Hack writing from Richard Wright to George Cain. It is also a breath of fresh air in a locked room gone stale from fulminations.

title: Education
description: In the report issued last week by the Fleischmann Commission, there is a quotation from the Pledge of Allegiance in which the words under God are omitted. Evidently it passed unnoticed by the commission's critics because had the error been detected, it probably would have been seized upon as one more example of what was called the commission's prejudice against nonpublic schoolsparticularly churchrelated ones.

title: Hispaniola's the Name of the Island.
description: BARBRA STREISAND and Elliott Gould took the Dominican route last July and early this month George C. Scott of Patton fame and his actresswife Colleen Dewhurst did the same. Both couples took advantage of recently liberalized divorce laws that have made the Dominican Republic one of the two new divorce capitals of the Western Hemispherethe other being Haiti, its neighbor on the island of Hispaniola.

title: Letters:
description: To THE EDITOR:

title: Claims Filed Against Prospector
description: SHAWNEE, Okla.  Merle I. Zweifel is a nervous man with a billiondollar scheme.

title: Music
description: THE first time I heard American Pie 1972's first real hit song was more than a year ago in San Francisco. Don McLean was passing through the Bay City on his way back to New York and stopped by my hotel for a long and pleasant rap about the then somewhat shaky condition of his career. His first recording, Tapestry, had been out for few weeks and I was enormously impressed with itin some ways even more than with American Pie.

title: Triple Bend 2d in Strub
description: ARCADIA, Calif., Feb. 12  Unconscious, the beaten favorite in last year's Kentucky Derby, made a smashing comeback today under the riding of Bill Shoemaker, winning the $130,000 Charles H. Strub Stakes for 4yearolds at Santa Anita by a neck.

title: Miss Susan Wemyss Is Married Upstate
description: LAKE PLACID, N. Y., Feb. 12  Miss Susan Leslie Wemyss and Winthrop Carter Lockwood Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Lockwood of Lake Placid, were married here this afternoon.

title: Alumni Total 79,998
description: NEW BRUNSWICK  Rutgers, the state university, has 79,998 living alumni, of whom 51,858 are New Jersey residents. Essex County has more of the alumni8,897 than any other Jersey county.

description: MYSTERIOUS PEKING CHICKEN

title: New Novel
description: Summer Games exhibits a crosssection of yearround lotus eaters inhabiting a pleasure colony in Florida. Beneath those expensive tans, the author suggests, are rotting personalities, debilitated by prolonged exposure to sun, booze and the easy life. Even the local dentist has gone native.

title: For Fun and Profit in San Francisco
description: In many ways, the preChristmas gettogether in a pavilion in San Francisco's verdant Golden Gate Park seemed like a vintage West Coast happening. There were readings by Michael McClure and other local poets. The Free City Puppets were there along with the People's International SilverString Macedonian Band. There was an organic food stand doing a brisk business. It was a gathering of the tribes that put The Whole Earth Catalog's Stewart Brand in mind of the trips festival he and Ken Kesey had staged in preTom Wolfe days  but it was something else as well. The San Francisco first International Book Fair was, most of all, a flexing of wit and muscle by a new, audacious crop of West Coast publishers, who, in keeping with their generation, put out

title: BEST OF CHIHUAHUAS IS LITTLE CRUSADER
description: Ch. Quantico's Little Crusader was chosen best yesterday in the eighth annual specialty show of the Chihuahua Club of Metropolitan New York.

title: LETTERS
description: F.D.A. and Nader

title: The World
description: MOSCOW  Vladimir Bukovsky is not a Nobel prizewinning writer like Solzhenitsyn or a renowned scientist like Sakharov or a wellknown publicist like the Medvedyev brothers. Unlike these men, he does not capture wide attention at home or abroad when he speaks out as a Soviet iconoclast. There was little serious stir, therefore, when a Soviet court condemned him recently to 12 years in labor camps and exile for antiSoviet activity.

title: Miss Dinah Guernsey
description: OLD WESTBURY, L. I., Feb. 12Mr. and Mrs. Peter Eaton Guernsey of Old Westbury and Martha's Vineyard, Mass., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Dinah Haynes Guernsey, to Timothy Reath, an insurance broker with Marsh Se McLennan, the insurance firm, of which his fiance's father is senior vice president. His father, the late George Reath, was head of Marsh & McLennan's Philadelphia office.

title: Defiance
description: It is customary these days to say that the radical movement is in disarray, fragmented. After all, the campuses are quiet, aren't they? Then there is the more fundamental question of whether there is a Movement. Even though radical organizations selfdestruct or undergo identity changes with the rapidity of those Tinguely machines full of sputter and fury, it is impossible to deny that there is a very loose coalition of groups and people, sharing similar goals, namely the need for a revolution in this countryalthough not necessarily a violent oneand antipathy toward racism, sexism, fascism, militarism, colonialism, imperialism and several other isms not as yet named. They cover an ideological spectrum from Maoism to anarchism to hippyisrn.

title: Mary Laidlaw, Frank E. Hart Plan Marriage
description: GLADSTONE, N. J., Feb. 12Mr. and Mrs. Norman H. Robbie have announced the engagement of Mrs. Robbie's daughter, Miss Mary Holmes Laidlaw, to Frank Edward Hart, son of Mr. and Mrs. Julian Hart of New Orleans.

title: W. Richard Bingham Is Fiance Of Miss Carol Hume, Teacher
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 12 Miss Carol Hume, a teacher at the Town School in New York, and W. Richard Bingham, a partner in the New York investment banking house of Kuhn, Loeb & Co., plan to be married March 18. Their engagement has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. Javelin Hume, parents of the future bride. Her fiance is the son of Wheelock H. Bingham of Southbury, Conn., former president of Macros California and the parent company R. H. Macy & Co., Inc., and Mrs. Evelyn F. Bingham of New York.

description: A 5yearold Mexican International champion bitch from Texas answering to the name of Honey captured the laurels at the Rhodesian Ridgeback Club of the United States 27th specialty show yesterday in the Hotel New Yorker.

title: Harpeis Have Son
description: A son was born on Jan. 20 to Mr. and Mrs. James W. Harpel of New York at the New York Hospital.

title: 2 Mississippi Papers Sued
description: JACKSON, Miss., Feb. 12 (UPI)Jackson's two daily newspapers have been accused in a Federal court suit of listing helpwanted advertisements by sex in violation of the Civil Rights Act. Civil rights attorneys filed the suit Tuesday against the Mississippi Publishers Corporation on behalf of Paula Morrow, an 18yearold black coed at Tougaloo College. The corporation publishes The Jackson ClarionLedger and Jackson Daily News.

title: Coins
description: JOHN ADAMS, our first Vice President and second President, is honored on the latest medal issued by the Hall of Fame for Great Americans on the campus of New York University. It is the 78th specimen in the commemorative series and part of the proceeds from the sale of the medals is used to help defray expenses of the Hall.

title: New Humphrey Aide
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 12 (AP) Senator Humphrey appointed Lloyd Hand today as deputy manager of his Presidential campaign. Mr. Hand, a 43yearold Los Angeles lawyer, was an assistant to President Johnson and was United States chief of protocol.

title: CRIME IN CAPITAL FOUND ORGANIZED
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 12Illegal lotteries, sports betting and traffic in hard narcotics in the District of Columbia are increasingly coming under the control of organized crime, law enforcement officials believe.

title: A Woman Who Shaped an Idea Into a Worldwide Movement
description: GREENWICH, Conn.For Isaac Newton the midwife to the birth of a great idea was a falling apple. For Mrs. Dickerman Hollister it was a peanut butter sandwich.

title: Vortex, Ky., Recalls Robert Kennedy
description: VORTEX, Ky., Feb. 10A young gas station attendant confided that he posts three pictures on his bedroom wallsElvis, Jesus and Robert Kennedy.

title: Protests Cancel 7thGraders Abortion Debate
description: ROCKAWAY TOWNSHIP  A debate on abortion by seventh graders of the township's school system was canceled abruptly last Friday afternoon amid a rousing debate by their elders how it could have been allowed in the first place.

title: the trayglefs world
description: ST. GEORGE'S, Grenada, West IndiesThe last leg of our eightclay trip on the schooner Sundowner through the Grenadine Islands was to be downwind for all the 72 miles from St. Vincent to our starting anchorage in St. George's. Sailing downwind is the equivalent, to the landlubber, of running downhill, but like most everything they tell you about life at sea, this is mostly theoretical. The early afternoon sun was shining, the sky was blue and the Caribbean's surface was blue and relatively smooth when we hoisted sail and turned southwesterly with the diesel engine turned off and only the wind powering our 143foot.

description: Miss Regina Mary Frey and Gerald Michael Schultz were married at noon yesterday in St. Margaret's Roman Catholic Church, Riverdale, the Bronx by Msgr. Fredrick J. Frey, the bride's uncle.

title: Madeleine L'Engle corning to her real self
description: Anyone who has read many of Madeleine L'Engle's excellent novels for young people must hanker to know something about her, to find out why beautiful mothers and radiantly warm family life recur in her books, and why her female characters achieve fuller dimension than her male, and how she dares champion the forces of good in these dark times.

description: JERICHO, L.I.Mrs. Daniel Sirota, a housewife who rarely speaks before audiences, told a group of 1,000 angry residents last week:

description: Of nearly a quarter million privately owned homes in Suffolk County, 5 per cent are valued at more than $50,000, and 12 per cent are valued at $35,000 to $49,999.

title: Beef roll, Warsawstyle
description: Zrazy is one of the few Polish dishes to make its mark on the international repertoire. It is prepared in many ways, but usually consists of pounded, rolled beef. This recipe, which is the official Polish Government version, uses filling of veal and herring. It may sound odd to use fish with beef, but the taste is not at all peculiar, simply unique.

title: FOSTER CARE COST SHOWN IN SURVEY
description: It costs $122,500 to raise a foster child in New York City from infancy to age 1Sleast four times what it costs natural parents to raise a childaccording to two Columbia University professors.

description: INDEPENDENCE, Mo. (UPI)  Bess Wallace Truman, who observes her 870 birthday today, finally is beginning to make a few concessions to time. But she's still The Boss.

title: Shorter Reviews
description: Jokes, verse, parodies from Worm Runner's Digest, a little periodical that has fun with science. While scientific humor is roughly equivalent to legal humor, the pieces here on gmntmanship, jargonism, elaborate experiments probing into nothing, and scientific sadism are on target The trouble with science, the Worm Runner's Digest seems to be saying, is scientists, who are willing to study anything but themselves; and the antidote for their occasional absurdities is humility engineered by Worm Runner's Digest.

title: Stamps

Aside from the political difficulties and bloodshed in the northern province of Ulster, Hugh Smith, The New York Times's correspondent in Belfast, reports that Ulster postal officials have come across at least two issues of British stamps issued for Northern Ireland events that had been overprinted with republican slogans.

title: HUNTER WILL AID NURSING STUDENTS

description: Trustees of the New Jersey State Bar Association are expected to give their approval this week to plans for a program of prepaid insurance to cover the cost of legal fees for New Jersey residents.

title: Black Army Captain Freed

Raymond H. Hopkins, stationed at Aberdeen Proving Ground, contended that he was the victim of a command conspiracy to dehumanize and depersonalize black soldier who wore an Afro hairstyle and identified with black culture.

title: Lear Introduces Vapor Turbine Engine
description: RENO, Nev., Feb. 12William Lear's longawaited vapor. turbine engine was operated publicly near here yesterday in a 50passenger General Motors bus.

title: Interne Fiance of Dr. Wilkins
description: BETHESDA, Md., Feb. 12 Mrs. Jerome Kermit Wilkins has announced the engagement of her daughter, Dr. Diane Theodora Wilkins, who received her M.D. degree from the Tufts Medical School, to Dr. Steven Phillips Mickley, a graduate of the Harvard Medical School.

title: M.I.T. Gets $80,006 Grants
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Feb. 12 (AP)The Massachusetts Institute of Technology has announced that it has received grants totaling $80,000 from the du Pont de Nemours & Co. of Wilmington, Del. The grants are to support teaching and research in science and technology.

title: Potsdam State Wi ns, 10765
description: POTSDAM, N. Y., Feb. 12 (AP)Clarkson College became the third team to lose twice this season to Potsdam State as the host team won, 10765, in basketball today.

title: Hennessy Grand Prix Set for July 19
description: Next July's Hennessy Grand Prix at Point Pleasant, N. J., is one of 22 sanctioned offshore powerboat races announced for 1972 by the Union of International Motorboating.

title: Crazy Horse Is Muffled
description: PARIS, Feb. 12 (Reuters)Col. Jean Hercisse has won a court order forcing his rowdy neighbor  the worldfamous nightclub Crazy Horse Saloon to soundproof the hall where nightly striptease shows are backed by the blare of rock music. I heard everything but saw nothing, the colonel said, Justice is done.

title: Anationals
description: WASHINGTON  Visualize an island somewhere in international waters, alive with activity, launches rushing back and forth ferrying executives and white collar workers to a sprawling office complex housing the world headquarters of The Dow Chemical Company.

title: Audrey Shore Fiancee
description: FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., Feb. 12The engagement of Miss Audrey Dianne Shore to Richard Victor Schwartz, son of Mr. and Mrs. Leslie Schwartz of Cedarhurst, L. I., has been announced by the future bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Albert P. Shore. Miss Shore, an alumna of Beaver College, is doing graduate work at the City University of New York. Her fianc, who was graduated magna cum laude from Lehigh University, is working for an M.B.A. degree at New York University.

title: The Good Word
description: Bruce Cook's The Beat Generation is a brave attempt to find missing link between the booziferous Beat and the acidophilic hippie. But this question seems to be still in the awkward stagetoo stale for journalism and not ready for historyand the specimens he interviewed backed off from it in a body. The Beats are still recovering from old limelight burns, selfinflicted, and are currently in the silent ward with Sontag, Bob Dylan and other victims.

title: SHOP TALK
description: PATCHOGUE, L. I. Bobbins once spun in the Patchogue  Plymouth Lace Mill in this 79yearold viiage by the Great South Bay. Saws buzzed at a lumber mill, farmers hauled produce to markets and summer guests lingered perhaps a day or two longer than planned at large resort hotels.

title: Illinois Students Registered To Vote Under Court Order
description: URBANA, Ill., Feb. 12Champaign County officials registered &ore than 200 students at the University of Illinois to vote for the first time here today under a Federal court order prohibiting discrimination against students in voter registration.

title: Bowles Supports Muskie
description: HARTFORD, Feb. 12Chester Bowles, former Ambassador to India, announced today his support of Senator Edmund S. Muskie of Maine for the Democratic Presidential nomination.

title: Lieut. Pamela Walker Bride of Air Captain
description: PLATTSBURGH, N.Y., Feb. 12  Lieut. Pamela, Jean Walker and Capt. Donald Harry Hart, who are serving irt the Air Force, were married here today at the Old Base Chapel, Plattsburg Air Force Base. Maj. Winston P. Fox, an Air Force chaplain, performed the Protestant ceremony.

title: Women's Tax Rebellion Urged To Achieve Political Equality
description: Wilma Scott Heide, president of the National Organization for Women, asked its 11state regional conference opening yesterday to seriously consider a tax rebellion to dramatize the political status of women that she said meant taxation without representation.

title: Wings, Hawks Tie, 33
description: DETROIT, Feb. 12 (UPI) 1 Mickey Redmond skated in all alone on Chicago's goalie, Tony Esposito, and beat him for a thirdperiod goal tonight to allow the Detroit Red Wings to tie the Black Hawks, 33.

title: 9TOWNPLANSET FOR WESTCHESTER
description: WHITE PLAINS, Feb. 12 Faced with intense local opposition nearly everywhere it has turned in Westchester for the last year, the New York State Urban Development Corporation has adopted a new approach in its dealings with local governments here.

title: Titles in the Running for 1972
description: At last count there were nine Democratic Presidential candidates, one DemocraticAmerican Independent, and three Republicans. Of course, all 435 House seats are up for grabs, as are 14 Democratic and 19 Republican seats in the Senate. Some new rules will be used this year in the selection of delegates to the Democratic convention (the Republicans hope to make some changes on a voluntary basis) and presumably some new rulescontroversial and bound to be challengedwill be used in the running of the Democratic convention. New Federal laws are in effect aimed at reducing the amount of money squandered on radio and television campaigning, and reducing also the fraud

title: Suffolk Skaters in Olympics Win Audience, Lose Judges
description: SAPPORO, Japan Murk Militano launched his sister, Melissa, into the sensational double throw axel, finishing off the sequence with a reverse position overhead lift. It brought down the house at the Makumanais Skating Rink.

title: 10 Seized in New Hampshire In Romney Speech Protest
description: MANCHESTER, N. H., Feb. 12 Ten antiwar demonstrators were arrested by the police here today after an effort to disrupt a speech by George Romney, Secretary of Housing and Urban Development.

description: Time magazine received court approval late yesterday to publish excerpts from the Clifford Irving book on Howard R. Hughes in its attempt to prove its charge that the work is a

title: WORLD OF SEVENTH AVE.
description: In an industry that always tends to overdo things, the big challenge on Seventh Avenue these days Is to underdo things sufficiently without risking sudden enthusiasms by unpredictable consumers.

title: CONNECTICUT SEEN EDGING TO MUSKIE
description: HARTFORD, Feb. 12John M. Bailey, Connecticut's Democratic state chairman since 1946, has not yet named his choice for the party's Presidential nomination, but he says Senator Edmund S. Muskie is the strongest candidate at the moment for the state's 51 delegates to the National Convention in Miami Beach in July.

title: Drama Mailbag
description: NO SUCH THING

title: Pearl Bailey in Hospital
description: LOS ANGELES, Feb. 12 (UPI)  Pearl Bailey was in good condition today at Mount Sinai Hospital after having suffered a mild heart attack Thursday. Miss Bailey, 53 years old, who received the Heart of the Year award from President Nixon a little more than a week ago, was admitted as an emergency patient, but a hospital spokesman said she was making good progress.

title: SPOT TESTING SET ON CARS IN STATE
description: TRENTONNew Jersey will test its annual automobile safety inspection program next month with an experimental spotchecking system of cars picked at random.

title: The World
description: LONDON  Piccadilly Circus fell dark. The lights dimmed in Parliament and 10 Downing Street. Stores reported a run on candles and flashlights. And women turned up at parties without their eye makeup, reporting, You need light for such finishing touches, dear.

title: OBSTACLES BESET PLAN FOR PRISON
description: A plan to establish a maximummaximum security prison for chronic troublemakers In the state's prison system has run into major obstacles.

title: Columbia Appoints Woman Assistant Vice President
description: Dr. Susan Ritner, a political scientist, has been appointed assistant vice president for academic affairs at Columbia University, it was announced last week by Dr. William J. McGill, president of Columbia.

title: Compromise on East Germany Reported to End Boycott Threat at Talks on the Environment
description: GENEVA, Feb. 12East Germany has agreed to accept observer status at the United Nations Conference on the Human Environment in Stockholm in May, dispelling the threat of boycott by the Soviet bloc, reliable sources said tonight.

title: $7Million Is Given to Columbia In 4 Months Since Aid Appeals
description: More than $7million in unrestricted funds have been given to Columbia University during the last four months, in response to appeals from the university's president, Dr. William J. McGill.

title: New Novel
description: In the beginning there was old Bolivar Chandler, who took over a failing North Carolina cotton mill in 1917, and ran it up into a paternalistic textile empire. Then came Bolivar's son Heath, World War I ace, who dabbled in playwriting and aeronautics before grudgingly shouldering the burden of his patrimony. Finally, there is Andrew Ford, a poor local boy, who returns from World War II to marry a Chandler and launch an advertising campaign in the saucy manner of Elliott White Springs.

title: Bucks Rout Warriors, 123100, as Allen Excels in Place of Injured Robertson
Letters Raise Question of U.S. Responsibility for Allied Atrocities
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 12The issue of the United States moral responsibility for war crimes committed by its allies has been raised in letters published in the February issue of the Foreign Service Journal.

title: CONTRACT AWARDED FOR AIR.CUSHION CAR
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 12 The Department of Transportation announced today that it had awarded a contract for the construction of a prototype of the country's first passengercarrying vehicle which will run without wheels on a cushion of air.

title: A Deliberate Censorship
description: LONDON  There is a dangerous kind of censorship, now growing in force in both America and England, that does not rely on legal restraints on what may be said. It appeals instead to the idea that the press, television and other media have a professional responsibility to exercise their legal freedom with selfrestraint, because their power to inform and persuade sometimes includes the power to embarrass or even cripple national policy.

title: JERSEY GUIDE
description: With spring less than six weeks off, anyone who wants, to let out on the ice with the family better start moving.

title: TO OUR READERS
description: The New York Times now offers additional Sunday edition coverage of New Jersey. The supplementary report, consisting of news and features, of special interest to readers in the state, appears in the main news section of all copies distributed in New Jersey and Richmond, Rockland and Orange Counties.

title: A Scholar Who jousts With the Skepstics
description: PHILADELPHIA  In scholarship, majority does not rule, said Solomon Zeitlin, who may be scholarship's most extraordinary minority of one.

title: Hofstra Plan Would Restructure N.C.A.A. Sports Scope
description: A sweeping proposal to restructure the scope and priorities of intercollegiate athletics will be presented to member colleges by Hof stra University this week.

title: John De LeHis Dead at 79; Con Ed Electrical Engineer
description: VALHALLA, N. Y., Feb. 12John De Lellis, who retired as a ManhattanBronx division Engineer for the Consolidated Edison Company in 1960, died yesterday at his home, 196 Prospect Avenue. His age was 79.

description: The World Hockey Association took a major step toward big league recognition yesterday when its New York entrant accepted Madison Square Garden's 40 proposed playing dates for next season.

description: The mysteries of the epidemic of infectious hepatitis that incapacitated the Holy Cross College football team in 1969 have been unraveled by a team of doctors.

title: Buyer of Air Time For Nixon Drives Switches to Muskie
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 12Senator Edmund S. Muskie has stolen one of President Nixon's secret political assets.

title: Art
description: THE Pierpont Morgan Library's new exhibition, French Painting in the Time of Jean de Berry, displays and examines a magnificent group of illuminated manuscripts made In Prance between 1350 and 1450 and is fully as scholarly a project as its title in combination with the name of the sponsoring institution indicates. But there are two ways you can enjoy it. You can study it with the help of the excellent explanatory labels by John H. Plummer, the library's research fellow for art, or you can settle for simple basking in the state of euphoric bedazzlement that the exhibition must induce. Either way, you can't miss. The manuscripts axe so alluringly displayed that to examine them as anything but objects of purely visual delight seems at first an unnecessary or even unwelcome dissection, but a dip into the explanatory material reveals the depth and variety that lies beneath their surface

title: Vitamin E New Fad
description: Dubbed the fertility vitamin, tocopherol, or vitamin E, has become one of the glowing performers among the alphabetized vitamins.

title: WALL STREET
description: Those bullish breezes that have been sweeping through the stock market in recent weeks have brought a healthy glow to brokeragehouse stocks, which only a few months ago looked very sick indeed.

title: Music To Enhance Life.
description: THOSE who think or ethnic music as anything from the Kingston Trio to Simon and Garfunkel's adaptation of Peruvian Quechua songs, a koto record, or Ravi Shankar at Monterey will be amazed by the range and beauty of many recently recorded examples of music of the world's people. For the first time we are attaining a standard of technical fidelity and a perceptive selection of music that will shortly disappear or be transformed into what Westerners usually think of as the norms of

title: State Agency Says It Aided 64 Concerns Here Last Year
description: The Division of Metropolitan Operations of the State Commerce Department has reported that it assisted a record total of 64 concerns in the metropolitan area to relocate or expand their facilities during 1971, an increase of 72 per cent over 1970, the year the division was created.

title: Felons Right to Vote Urged
description: WASITMGTON, Feb. 12 (UPI) Representative Charles B. Rangel, Democrat of Manhattan, has introduced a bill to restore the right to vote in Federal elections to felons who have served their sentences. Mr. Rangel said only a handful of states now permit felons to be reenfranchised automatically after completing their sentences.

title: Row Rich Is a Rich Apache?
description: DULCE, N. M.

title: Toxin Found in Pistachio Nuts; $1.MillionWorth Rejected Here
description: More than $1 million worthl of Iranian and Turkish pistachio nuts have been rejected as imports by the Food and Drug Administration here in the last two months because they contain a mold contaminated with a cancerproducing substance called aflatoxin.

title: LETTERS
description: Taxes

title: 41 to Compete for U.S. junior Handling Title
description: Fortyone boys and girls from 19 states will compete at Madison Square Garden for the national junior handling title and the sterling silver Leonard Brumby Sr. Memorial Trophy, which goes to the winner.

title: Gardiners Island Monument Opposed
description: WILLIAMS13URG, Va., Feb. 12Scientists attending a research meeting this weekend on the North American osprey, a large, fisheating bird, have supported an effort to prevent a Federal takeover of Gardiners Island, a 3,300acre privately owned island between Long Island's eastern forks.

title: RAYMONDGETTINGER, PATHOLOGIST, DEAD
description: Dr. Raymond Gettinger, director of the pathology department of St. Joseph's Hospital in Yonkers, died yesterday at the hospital. He was 65 years old and lived at 7340 195th Street, Flushing, Queens.

title: OBSERVER
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 12We went down to the cellar to light the box and live a little. Presently tiny black figures began flitting about on snow. The voice of the box said we were in Sapporo, Japan, watching the Winter Olympics.

title: President Thieu's Peace Veto.
description: In his attempt last week to reassure President Thieu about his intentions in the Vietnam peace talks, President Nixon perhaps inadvertently undercut hope that his recently publicized peace plan might lead to fruitful negotiations.

title: Art
description: THE sculpture of Edgar Negret, the 52yearold Colombian artist and a. sometime resident of New York, is so fastidiously conceived and executed, so perfect in its composure, that it seems to have sprung, fullgrown, from the creator's mind rather than to have evolved under his hands. The exhibition of eight sizable recent pieces by Negret, now on view at the Galeria Bonino, 7 West 57th Street, affords a good opportunity to study the admirable lucidity and authority of his style.

title: 6 Die in Massachusetts Fire
description: LOWELL, Mass., Feb. 12 (AP)  A generalalarm fire in a threestory rooming house left six persons dead early today. The dead were identified as James O'Brien, James Boland, John McGuinn, Arthur Richardson, Edward McQuire and Albert Sieko. Seventeen residents of the building escaped.

title: The Nation
description: No more fantasizing on the subway, no more speculating at cocktailsdamn you, Clifford Irving, you've taken our fun away. All those lovely Machiavellian schemes we'd been devising to explain how you really did write Howard Hughes's autobiography, all gone.

title: French Settler Triumphs By Length at Fair Grounds
description: NEW ORLEANS, Feb. 12 CAP) French Settler stayed near the front all the way, then surged ahead for a onelength victory today in the $15,000 added Bayou Handicap at the Fair Grounds.

title: Miss MaryAnn Dattola Affianced
description: Mrs. McCarthy Dattola of New York has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss MaryAnn Dattola, to James Harlan Rich Jr. of Haverford, Pa., son of Mrs. Raymond Rich of Beach Haven, N. J., and the late Mr. Rich of Philadelphia.

title: About Motor Sports
description: A rally named the St. Valentine's Day Massacre Is described by its funloving organizers as the toughest, nastiest, nerve .shatteringest event you'll ever enter. It may cover any territory from the Statue of Liberty to the Golden Gate Bridge, with bypasses as long as 1,000 miles encompassed in a single route instruction. For all the breadth of the Big Picture, you must keep track of such incidentals as the town whose name is made up of parts of two roads you have traveled. And you can run the rally without leaving your kitchen table.

title: POLE AT DAYTONA TAKEN BY ISAAC
description: DAYTONA BEACH, Fla., Feb. 12 (UPI)  Bobby Isaac drove his 1972 Dodge to a speed of 186.632 miles an hour today to edge A. J. Foyt's Mercury for the pole position in the $200000 Daytona 500 next Sunday.

title: 66 JUDGES NAMED FOR GARDEN SHOW
description: William W. Brainard Jr. of Marshall, Va., heads a slate of 56 judges from 20 states and England who will officiate at the twoday Westminster Kennel Club show at Madison Square Garden.

title: The Nation
description: It was a classic replay from an earlier age. Liberals in the Senate were pushing a strong civil rights measure. Southern conservatives, adamantly opposed, filibustered. Efforts to break the filibuster failed, and all that was left to the civil rights forces was weak compromise.

title: Ryen Wins Trophy In Dahlen Jumpoff At Bear Mountain
description: BEAR MOUNTAIN, N.Y., Feb. 12  Nils Ryen, a 26yearold Staten Island carpenter, moved up a notch to Class B competition today and won the Anund Dahlen Jumpoff Trophy during the metropolitan ski jumping tournament today.

title: Required reading for all parents and teachers
description: Education, like its contrary, war, is far too serious a business to be left to professionals. Their view is too limited, their interests too involved. With the advent of community control, teacher militancy and student power, education has sometimes taken on the appearance of war, but to those who are serious minded, the challenge to the educational power structure has brought into prominence the need to consider the learning significance of the social and administrative organization of the educational enterprise itself.

title: Boyne Improvement
description: CERAMIC tile has been around for centuries although there have been many improvements made in the varieties available and in the methods of installation  but many people still are confused about the type they should buy (some don't realize that there is more than one type), about where or how it can be installed, and as to how to clean and for it.

description: STEEP FALLS, Me.

title: South Korea Urges Removal Of Arms From Buffer Zone
description: SEOUL, South Korea, Feb. 12  South Korea called on North Korea today to help reduce tension on the Korean peninsula by removing all military installations from the demilitarized zone along their border.

title: How Low Is Substandard'?
description: In extending the Economic Stabilization Act, Congress voted to exclude any control over wage increases to the working poor and to employes with substandard earnings. The Cost of Living Council has now decided that the exclusion should apply to all workers earning $1.90 an hour or less, a figure thirty cents above the Federal minimum wage.

title: Visions and revisionsan accursed implement
description: Edgar Allan Poe has always been the most problematic of our major American poetsa genius as much committed to a life of thoughts as of sensations; an emotionally crippled psychic explorer; an apocalyptic visionary breathlessly acting out in his life (alcohol, demonic energies, marriage with a sisterlike child, intellect and vision warring with each other) the internalized romantic quest so profoundly pursued in his best work; a literary hack, a caricature of American fascination with the gimmicky, the mechanical and the technical in literature.

title: A Liberal Fights Back
description: LIBERALS, said Malcolm McDowell, star of A Clockwork Orange, hate that film. The implication is that there is something shameful in the liberals reactionthat at the very least they don't know the score. Quite the opposite is true. Any liberal with brains should hate Clockwork, not as a matter of artistic criticism but for the trend the film represents. An alert liberal should recognize the voice of fascism.
