title: Art
description: THE exhibition of paintings and drawings by Le Corbusier that is currently on view at the Geierle Denise Rena, 6 West 57th Street, is an event with more than one claim to our attention. For those who know Le Corbusier only or primarily as an architect or as an architectural theorist, this exhibition will serve as an excellent introduction to his lesser known but nonetheless substantial pictorial accomplishment. Even those of us more or less familiar with the pictorial work that once commanded a large share of his extraordinary gifts are given a rare opportunity here to renew our acquaintance with the strongest pictures he ever producedthe early pictures of the socalled Purist period. Indeed, the exhibition would have been even stronger though certainly less completeif it had concentrated exclusively on the work of this period, for once Le Corbusier moved outside the orbit of the Purist esthetic, the quality of his work as a painter suffered

title: Cynthia Keating Wed
description: NEW CANAAN, Conn., Feb. 12Miss Cynthia Antoinette Keating, daughter of the late Mr. and Mrs. Edward N. Keating of New Canaan, and Joseph Edward McClanaghan were married here this afternoon in St. Aloysius Roman Catholic Church by Msgr. Francis X. McGuire. The bridegroom is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph N. McClanaghan of Greenville and Narragansett, R. I.

title: Official Party Named For Nixon China Trip
description: KEY BISCAYNE, Fla., Feb. 12 The White House announced today the names ot the members of the official party accompanying President and Mrs. Nixon to China.

title: ECOLOGICAL DRIVE GROWS IN FLORIDA
description: SARASOTA, Fla.The magic word in Florida these days is environment.

title: How Big Is Too Big?; Size of I.B. M. Raises Problems For Trust Busters
description: Should the International Business Machines Corporation be broken up?

title: Sports of The Times
description: When the Olympic flag was reverently lowered during the closing ceremonies of one set of winter Olympic Games at an Alpine resort area some years ago, anxious officials gave sighs of relief. This was the last Olympic flag they had on the premises. All the others had been stolen by souvenirhunters or mischiefmakers. The Japanese are much too polite and disciplined ever to permit themselves to be embarrassed by such a gaffe. Hence everything will be in order today for the always lovely, ritualistic closing ceremonies that will bring to an end this refrigerated appendage to the noble Olympic Games.

title: Shorter Reviews
description: Books about the stock market are falling on us like the descent of the DowJones average in 1970. The reason for the largesse of the former is perhaps the crisis of the latter. That is to say, with an estimated paper loss of $280billion during those dark days a lot of ordinary Americans got skinned. Now conic the witty, sardonic confessions of a broker who if he doesn't exactly say that you'll never get rich does offer practical advice and sound cautions. There are numerous anecdotes about his clients, some of whom should never have copped their inheritance. Written in diary form, the book covers the last six months of 1970. Brutus ends up bullish about the system. He sounds like a stockbroker.

title: Shorter Reviews
description: All about the brain, in a poplevel treatment of numerous scientific experiments. Stevens describes various theories of brain function from the ancients on up (the Egyptians, for instance, thought it an inconsequential mass, and located the seat of the emotions in the heart and liver). Later experiments with electric excitation differentiated the functions of various brain areas. Contemporary experiments with rats show that the cortex actually grows if sufficiently exercised by intellectual stimulation (well, by what passes for intellectual stimulation among rats). Stevens's approach is largely physiological: his message is that where once the brain was thought to be the host of the soul, relentless lab work has forced that shadowy concept

title: Laotian Airliner Missing
description: VIENTIANE, Laos, Feb. 12 (Reuters)  A Royal Lao Airlines fourengine plane with 23; persons aboard today was reported missing while on a flight from Saigon, South Viet nam, to Vientiane. A spokesman, for the airlines said that contact with plane was lost early Friday, evening.

title: Spines
description: To the Editor:

title: Medicine
description: Yes, there has been an influenza epidemic after all. The experts who scoffed at the idea last month have acknowledged their error, and all those millions of ordinary citizens who claimed there was an epidemic because they had fevers, headaches, sore throats and assorted other aches and pains have been vindicated.

title: A patrolman of the old school
description: Officer Bumper Morgan, the hero of Joseph Wambaugh's new police novel, says he doesn't accept cash gifts from people on his beat. But he adds, I never felt bought if a guy gave me free meals or a case of booze or a discounted sport coat. Bumper is an oldschool patrolman on the Los Angeles forcewhere Wambaugh himself learned about the policeman's lot as a sergeant, and wrote about it in last year's highly successful first novel, The New Centurions.

title: 68 Notes Reflect Hughes's Varying Moods
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 12 Howard R. Hughes is shown as alternately fearful and courageous, docile and autocratic, beseeching and demanding in collection of correspondence that has come into the possession of The New York Times.

title: The Nation
description: WASHINGTONThere is more than meets the eye in those pillars of black smoke rising from the stacks of electric power plants and the chimneys of office and apartment buildings. There is colorless sulphur dioxide hidden within them, and it is not good for man or beast, or vegetation or house paint.

title: Great antidote for selfcontempt
description: The Dead of the House is one of the most important works of fiction I have read in quite a while. It is not major, propounds no theories, participates in neither rear nor avantgarde maneuvers. Hannah Green's novel simply is, a family chronicle and a fictional memoiralways spontaneous, rich in atmosphere, its feelings specified, felt, projected. A beautiful book, nowhere bigger than itself, nowhere grander than its own scope or subject. It has been shaped with the caressing skill of a lover of people and words, but the words do not take over and perform a sideshow, and the people aren't always that lovable, and Hannah Green is of

title: Plain English foodhighspirited raps
description: Well, this extended autobiographical statement by Nikki Giovanni is not an autobiography. It may therefore disappoint many among her plentiful followers who will buy a copy, hoping to find out about their poet. If you read through the 13 separate essays, you can conclude that Nikki Giovanni came from a middleclass background: Both parents were college graduates and pursued professional careers. She grew up in Knoxville, Tenn. She took her own undergraduate degree at Fisk University: She loved her grandmother, and her mother, especially, loves her son, Thomas, loves her sister, Gary, and liked to fight for her, front) when she was 4 years old. Her family has long regarded Miss Giovanni as a genius, and she has long regarded herself as a genius. More than that, of an autobiographical nature, her fans will not learnnot

title: Emptied Walk in Safe Stands As a Memento of Boss Hague
description: JERSEY CITY  There is one remaining monument to the late political boss, Frank Hague, in the old City Hall at Grove and Montgomery Streets  a huge, walkin safe.

title: For 300 Convention Planners, a Valentine Weekend Here, With Love, From the City and Other Suitors
description: The New York Convention and Visitors Bureau assembled 300 convention planners here yesterday for a Valentine's Day weekend on the town.

title: Tax Reform: Ogre or'Great Opportunity?; Impact on Schools Raises Questions
description: MORRISTOWNThe question, said W. Sheldon Bennett, pausing for a momont at his desk in the offices of the new Morris Regional School District, is: How are they going to let us add to whatever the state contributes?

description: To the Editor:

title: Tax Bite Rises Steeply
description: About two weeks ago, President Nixon told Congress that the Federal income tax bite out of the individual paycheck is becoming measurably less. But many Americans don't go along with him  and the new withholding tables are the reason why.

title: U.S. Estimates Put 71 Rise in Aid to Hanoi at 25%
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 12 (AP) Current United States intelligence estimates indicate that both the Soviet Union and China stepped up their economicl and arms aid to North Vietnam over the last year.

title: Art Notes
description: WHAT! No demonstrations, confrontations or raw eggs on the stairs of the Whitney Museum? Well, in case you thought the women's movement in art had abated somewhat, rest assured that it's very much in business. It's simply entered a quieter phasethe symposium  forum  conferencefestival  exhibition stage, building throughout the country. This season is buzzing with such events, and there are more to come. In fact, to prove that the Movement is perking even harder, here's a brief roundup of some current goingson in New York

title: Sickle Cell Anemia Clinic Is Opened
description: The Health Services Administration recently announced the opening of its fifth sickle cell anemia screening clinic and its first in Brooklyn. The center. which Is at 259 Bristol Street in Brownsville, tests individuals to determine if they are carriers of the noncontagious hereditary blood disease, and counsels persons who have the sickle cell trait on preshould take.

title: Backlog of Cases In the Civil Court Is Finally Cleared
description: For the first time in threeH decades, the city court a handling smaller civil suits have cleared their backlog of cases.

title: Korean Hints Vietnam Pact
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Feb. 12 (UPI)The Korean Defense Minister, Yu Jae Hung, apparently has reached a tentative agreement with South Vietnam to leave some or all of about 40,000 Korean troops in this country for another two years, spokesman said today. Mr. Yu, who flew back to Seoul today after a fourday visit here, was quoted by the spokesmen as saying he had reached a good understanding with President Nguyen Van Thieu.

description: RABBI KAHANE AND THE I.D.L. (CONT.)

title: Union and Jail join To Get Jobs For Inmates
description: EAST MEADOW, L. I.  A labor union and officials at the Nassau County Jail have been cooperating quietly in efforts to place released inmates in jobs and return them as productive members of society.

title: Letters To the Editor
description: To THE Enrroa:

title: Probing Defense Spending
description: PresWent Nixon's soaring defense budget appears be shaping up as a major issue in the Congress. The need for a $6.3billion increase in budget authority in the fiscal year beginning July 1 is being questionedwith good reasonby one of the Pentagon's best friends on Capitol Hill, Senator Stennis, chairman of the Senate Armed Services Committee, and by Majority Leader Mike Mansfield. A close, hard look needs to be taken at the plethora of new weapons systems projected by the armed services and at what Mr. Stennis describes as the rocketing costs of military manpower.

title: HEINRICH BRIEGER MEDICAL PROFESSOR
description: PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 12 Dr. Heinrich Brieger, emeritus professor of occupational medicine at Thomas Jefferson University, died today at his home, 2031 Locust Street. He was 76 years old.

title: Arehateeture
description: FOR an instructive, comparative view of architecture of the 1970's and the 1870's, the places right now are small show of the prizewinning design for Le Centre Beaubourg in Paris at New York's Museum of Modern Art (until Feb. 20), and the just opened, restored Renwick Gallery in Washington.

title: IN THE NATION
description: That is a tough proposition President Nixon has laid down for his Democratic Presidential challengers: Go ahead and criticize my Vietnam peace proposals if you must, but you make Hanoi think it can make better deal with you after the election, you will get the blame for prolonging the war until then.

description: OPTIONS

title: The World
description: If there's anything the French like less than drinking water with meals, it's paying taxes, Dodging the tax collector is almost a national sport. But last week Frenchmen took a more serious view of the game because of charges that their Premier, Jacques ChabanDelmas, might be playing it.

title: Three in Army Are Killed, Three Hurt, in Plane Crash
description: MABLETON, Ga., Feb. 12 (UPI)Two Army colonels and a warrant officer were hilted today when their twinengine pane crashed and burned. The three other persons aboard were injured.

title: Letters:

title: Actor Cleared in Assault
description: BOSTON, Feb. 12 (UPI)George Peppard, the actor, was cleared yesterday of assault and attempted rape charges brought by an exotic dancer from Cambridge. Joan McLaughlin, 24 years old, charged Mr. Peppard attacked her and tried to rape her in the actor's room in the Ritz Carleton Hotel on Jan. 30. She testified she bit the actor on the cheek when he hugged me too tightly.'''The only assault was on the man who got. bitten on the face, said Judge Elijah Adlow in Boston Municipal Court as he dismissed the rape charge and found no prob. able cause in the assault charge.

title: Mrs. Fabian Has Child
description: A daughter was born Jan. 31 to Mr. and Mrs. Abe Fabian of New York at Mount Sinai Hospital, Mrs. Fabian, whose husband is with the Fabian Enterprises, is the former Miss Joanna Semon.

title: The World
description: SALISBURY, RhodesiaThe young barefoot African standing outside Chief Gwebu Fish's beer hall in a remote part of Rhodesia's Sabi tribal trustland last Tuesday was wearing paper sign around his neck that said: No to any proposal.

title: Deborah Savino Wed
description: Miss Deborah Savino, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James Savino of Spring Valley, N. Y., was married here yesterday morning to Gil Hodges 2d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Gil Hodges of Brooklyn. The bridegroom's father is manager of the New York Mots baseball team. The Rev. Michael Gallagher performed the ceremony and celebrated the nuptial mass in St. Patrick's Cathedral.

description: ECONOMIC AND

title: Vermont Editors Named
description: BURLINGTON, Vt., Feb. 13 (AP)  The Burlington Free Press announced yesterday that Clinton F. Andrews had been named managing editor and Lawrence 0. Clayton executive editor.

title: Fletcher Wins 7th Award
description: Walter R. Fletcher of The New York Times received an award from the Dog Writers Association of America last night at the Riverboat Restaurant, for his coverage of the Puerto Rico Kennel Club's show. It was the seventh year in a row he won an award. The publication, Dogs of Puerto Rico, received a prize for best local bulletin.

title: Stage: A Play for Peace
description: Speaking for myself. I would always prefer to make love than war, and there are some plays that nowadays are convincing me that there are times when I would rather make love than go to the theater. A case in point is a sloganbearing little drama that describes itself as a play for peace. Wow! With plays like this, peace needs no generals.

title: City Hall Notes
description: Lindsay administration officials say that one reason they are reluctant to scale down the Forest Hills lowcost housing project from three, 24story towersdespite their fear that standing fast will cost the Mayor votes in some Presidential primaries is that they would have to resubmit any new proposal to the Board of Estimate, which would probably vote against it. Indeed, an informal poll of board members indicates that many believe that a vote for any housing project on the site would be a form of political suicide.

title: St. John's Clinches Subway Ride to NJ. T.
description: St. John's virtually assured Itself of a subway ride to Madison Square Garden for the National Invitation Tournament Saturday night with its 7860 victory over Fordham. As for a longer trip, the one the Redmen would prefer and the one a National Collegiate Athletic Association berth would provideWs too early to predict.

title: Foreign Newsmen in Capital
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 13 (UPI) Twenty foreign journalists on a United States Governmentsponsored tour will be sitting in on the regular White House briefing for newsmen tomorrow. The group, representing 18 European nations, will also receive briefings from State Department and Capitol Hill officials.

title: Brooklyn Bank is Making Loans to Reputed Mafiosi
description: For more than a decade, reputed Mafia members have obtained numerous loans from Brooklyn bank despite poor credit ratings, long criminal records and frequent false information on applications.

title: Sapporo's Olympic Flame Is Returned to the Sun
description: SAPPORO, Japan, Feb. 13 (AP)The flame of the Olympic Winter Games slowly dwindled and disappeared tonight after burning for 11 days. It will be relighted in 1976 in Denver for the 12th Winter Olympics.

title: Visitors Jam Into Rio For Carnival Parade
description: RIO DE JANEIRO, Feb. 13 (Reuters)Tens of thousands of people streamed into Rio today for the big night of carnival, the parade of the samba schools that Brazilians say is the greatest show on earth.

title: Marylou Speaker of Bostonians Shows Artistry in Violin Debut
description: Early Saturday afternoon, less than seven hours before she was due on stage at Carnegie Hall to play in the violin section of the Boston Symphony Orchestra, Marylou Speaker went next door to the Recital Hall and made her New York solo debut.

title: CollegeTuition Assistance for the Poor Is Proposed
description: A plan to enable students rom lowincome families in the state to attend private colleges and universities with their tuition paid for by public sources was proposed yesterday by the chairman of the Joint Legislative Committee on Higher Education.

title: Raped by the Law
description: New York City police statisticswhich undoubtedly grossly understate the true situationshow that 2,415 cases of rape were reported here in 1972, a 12 per cent Increase. The understatement reflects the fact that many victims do not report this crime because of fear, shame, and a deep sense of personal humiliation.

title: Show of Fashions and of Friendship
description: A bouffant black point d'esprit evening shirtdress by Bill Blass from Saks Fifth Avenue shared the runway with a navy and white sports dress by Susan Thomas from Bonwit Teller. The lace evening dress costs $1,100, the casual style $42. A coat and dress costume by Donald Brooks from Bergdorf Goodman was $735; a similar style by Leslie Fay from B. Altman was $74.

title: Israel Plans Inquiry on Damage To Jews Sacred Jerusalem Wall
description: TEL AVIV, Feb. 13Premier GoIda Moir set up a committee of inquiry hi Jerusalem today to investigate charges that the sacred Western Wall of the Temple Mount in the Old City had been desecrated by municipal workers.

title: LOCALCARE PLAN URGED ON DOCTORS
description: The outgoing president of the Medical Society of the State of New York urged physicians yesterday to begin planning energetically for comprehensive health care to preserve the integrity of the medical profession.

title: ITZHAK PERLMAN HEARD ON VIOLIN
description: Itzhak Penman indulged himself in a lightweight program at Hunter College Saturday night that really did not get off the ground until after intermission. Tartini's Devil's Trill Sonata and the Brahms Sonata (Op. 120, No. 2) had flashes of the violinist's customary exuberance and warm commitment, but there was a touch of perfunctory surface skating that bespoke a certain lack of total involvement.

title: Greece Warns U. S. Criticism May Peril Talks an Part Rights
description: ATHENS, Feb. 13  Greece has warned the United States State Department that its recent remarks about Greek internal affairs might affect current negotiations on homeport facilities for American warships in Greece.

title: BILL ON GAMBLING GAINING IN ALBANY
description: A proposed constitutional amendment that would allow the Legislature to legalize whole range of gambling is ready for rapid passage in the State Senate, legislative sources said yesterday.

title: Inch of Rain and High Winds Lash the City and Suburban Areas1
description: Lashing rain and winds gusting up to 50 miles an hour created traffic disturbances over the metropolitan area yesterday afternoon, flooding roadways, endangering bridge traffic, showering debris and glass from construction sites, and causing the collapse of an eightstory building framework in Rockaway.

title: Two Grand Juries Due To Resume Work Today
description: Two grand juries are scheduled to resume hearings here today on the Clifford Irving case.

title: Relocation of Taxi Stands Is Studied to Cut Cruising
description: Taxi Commissioner Michael J. Lazar disclosed yesterday that his agency was studying ways to relocate taxi stands in midtown with the aim of reducing cab cruising and thus decreasing air pollution and traffic congestion.

title: Jewish Leaders Urge Strong Diaspora
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 13Leaders of the nation's largest Jewish organization emphasized today the need for a continuing and independentminded Diaspora (Jews living outside of Israel) as a force for strengthening Jewish life.

title: Witch Hunter Tops Yorkshire Terriers In Specialty Debut
description: Ch. Yorkfold the Witch Hunter, a 2yearold 7pounder, was the victor at the Yorkshire Terrier Club of America specialty show yesterday at the StetlerHilton Hotel. There were 140 in competition, and William Bergum of Ventura, Calif., judged the event.

title: JACKSON IMPRESSIVE ON CARNEGIE PODIUM
description: If you are a betting man, get something down on Isaiah Jackson, who is already an impressive young conductor and who needs only a big chance or two to register with a large public. Mr. Jackson is music director of the Youth Symphony of New York, and by the sound of the concert he led yesterday afternoon at Carnegie Hall he is doing tremendously effective job.

title: INTENSE BOMBING CONTINUED BY U.S. IN SOUTH VIETNAM
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Monday, Feb. 14One of the heaviest American bombing campaigns of the war was concentrated over the weekend on base areas and infiltration trails west of the Central Highlands city of Kontum. Enemy attacks throughout South Vietnam declined yesterday for the third consecutive day.

title: UNIROYAL PROFIT UP SHARPLY IN 71
description: Uniroyal, Inc., announced yesterday a sharp profit increase in 1971 over 1970, when the company was hit by strikes.

title: The Right to Choose Death
description: WASHINGTONRecently 3,500 delegates attended the White House Conference on Aging to discuss the needs and rights of the twenty million Americans who are 65 or over. We have still fresh In our minds the wonderful picture of a man of 95 dancing, but this should not cause us to forget the Many who are incapacitated or suffering hopelessly.

title: Bunker Returns to Saigon
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Feb. 13 (AP)Ambassador Ellsworth Bunker returned to Saigon today after 12 days of consultations in Washington and Paris.

title: A Dinner at Home Here Cost More in December
description: Whether your main dish was beef or chicken, it cost more to prepare a Sunday dinner at home in December than in November, according to figures for the New YorkNortheastern New Jersey area issued yesterday by the United States Bureau of Labor Statistics.

title: Bridge: Doing in Corsica Baffle French WriterPlayer
description: From the days of Napoleon, Corsicans have had a reputation for shrewdness in outwitting their rivals, whether operating as bandits or generals.

title: Dockers Caucus Snagged In Bid to Ratify Contract
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 13 (UPI)West Coast longshore union leaders, faced with rankandfile dissatisfaction, met again today to ratify a contract that could end the nation's longest waterfront strike.

title: Public TV.
description: The director of the White House Office of Telecommunications, Clay T. Whitehead; takes a singularly narrow view of the public responsibilities of public broadcasting. He has warned the fourth network, the 212 publiceducational stations such as New York's Channel 13, that there is a real question as to whether public television, particularly the national federally funded part of public television, should be carrying public affairs, news commentary, and that kind of thing.

description: To the Editor:

title: Judge Dorothy Kenyon Is Dead; Champion of Social Reform, 83
description: Dorothy Kenyon, a former Justice of the Municipal Court and a leader in the struggle for women's rights and social reform for more than half century, died Saturday at her home, 433 West 21st Street. She would have been 84 years old On Thursday.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: Funds for Libraries

title: Toward Peace in Ulster
description: Despite steady polarization of the two communities. Northern Ireland there can be no doubt that the overwhelming majority of Protestants and Catholics alike still fervently desire a peaceful solution for the future of the province. And despite the recent escalation violence and bloodshed, an outline has emerged for settlement that might yet find acceptance by both sides.

title: DUDLEY T. COLTON JR.
description: Dudley T. Colton Jr., manager of planning for residential products division of the JohnsManville Corporation, died yesterday at the New York HospitalCornell Medical Center, after having received a kidney transplant Jan. 21 from his brother, Donne. He was 43 years old and lived in Martinsville, N.J.

title: ANNUAL MUSIC FEST HELD AT TOWN HALL
description: WNYCs 33d American Music Festival, held annually in various auditoriums throughout the city during the days between Lincoln's and Washington's birthdays, began Saturday afternoon at Town Hall under the auspices of the National Federation of Music Clubs. None of the music played by the New York Philomusica and guest instrumentalists was particularly memorable, but the catholic mixture of styles from conservative to notsoconserative did provide variety.

title: Sabres Martin Ties Mark
description: BUFFALO, Feb. 13 (AP)Rick Martin, Buffalo's 20yearold left wing, scored his 38th goal of the season tonight to equal the N.H.L. record for a rookie set last season by his teammate, Gil Perreault, as the Sabres tied the Philadelphia Flyers, 44.

title: Fame N Fortune Judged Best of 283 Irish Setters
description: Ch. Webline Fame N Fortune celebrated his fifth birthday three days early yesterday by taking the bestofbreed trophy of the Irish Setter Club at the 13th annual show of the Combined Setter Clubs of America at the Stetler Hilton Hotel.

title: SOVIET SPURRING SUGARBEET CROP
description: MOSCOW, Feb. 13The Soviet Government has ordererd a rise in prices It pays to domestic sugarbeet growers in move that may drive prices down on world sugar markets.

title: Penguins Beat Canucks, 64
description: PITTSBURGH, Feb. 13 (UPI) Jean Pronovost scored his second goal of the game at 903 of the third period to snap a tie and the Pittsburgh Penguins went an to defeat the Vancouver Canucks, 64, tonight.

title: Es, DISGRUNTLED OYER GROUP OF 10
description: PARIS, Feb. 13  Europe's financial authorities are wondering whether the United States really wants to break up the Group of 10 and if so what will take its place as the forum for negotiating the reforms in the monetary structure that all the major nations think are necessary.

title: AT HOME ABROAD
description: LONDON, Feb. 13There is very little panic in Britain as the coal strike gradually darkens the streets and stops industry for want of electric power. The wellknown British phlegm in the face of crisis is admirable. But it cannot conceal the troubling questions that this strike poses for established political and economic ideas.

title: Peabody to File in Primary
description: PITTSBURGH, Feb. 13 (UPI) Endicott Peabody, former Massachusetts Governor, said today that he would file on Tuesay for Vice President on the Democratic ticket in the Pennsylvania primary.

title: JOBLESS IN CITY PUT AT5003 000
description: Jule M. Sugarman, the city's Human Resources Administrator, declared yesterday that far more persons needed jobs than were counted in current Federal unemployment statistics500,000 in the city, as against the official estimate of 250,000.

title: and Cable TV
description: In the more complex area of cable broadcasting, similar principle of greater choice and diversity on the dial should prevail. Here, too, the influence of the White House Office of Telecommunications Policy (O.T.P.) has been felt. It has helped to effect agreement between commercial broadcasters and cable operators but only by restricting the possibilities of bringing in any and all programs from one location to another.

title: Headon Crash Kills Five On Sunrise Highway on LI.
description: SOUTH HAVEN, L. I. Feb. 13 (UPI)Five persons were killed today in a headon collision on Sunrise Highway here.

title: A Community Where Family Togetherness Is a Thing of the Past
description: When a neighborhood decays, family life erodes, too.

title: Pope Consecrates 19 Prelates, One a Controversial Dutch Conservative
description: ROME, Feb. 13Pope Paul VI consecrated 19 Bishops and Archbishops from four continents today. Attention at the threehour ceremony in St. Peter's Basilica centered on a controversial Dutch conservative and an ecumen1.9.1minded Irish prelate who are among the new members of the Roman Catholic hierarchy.

title: Tracking Florida Voters Along the Chisholm Trail: The Route Is Uphill, Tough but Very Well Defined
description: TAMPA, Fla., Feb. 13Hello brother, hello sister, hello mom. I'm Shirley Chisholm and I'm running for the Presidency of this country. I'm the only black woman in Congress. Give me one chance, one vote, on March 14.

title: Rangers Top Kings, 42, for 3d in Row
description: Unfortunately for the Los Angeles Kings last night, they weren't awarded five penalty shots. They got only one, cashed it in as if shooting at an empty net, but bowed to the Rangers, 42.

title: Emerson Is Victor
description: TORONTO, Feb. 13 (Canadian Press)Roy Emerson of Australia beat Bob Maud of South Africa, 64, 64, in the first round of a $50,000 tennis tournament for contract pros today.

title: Soviet Jews in Israel Protest Sabbath Work
description: TEL, AVIV, Feb. 13 (Agence FrancePresse)Five hundred new immigrants from Soviet Georgia demonstrated today at Lydda international airport here, protesting that Soviet Jews employed at the airport were obliged to work on Saturday, the Jewish Sabbath.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: 3 Candidates Display Strength At Coast Democratic Caucuses.
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 13Three candidates showed considerable organizational strength in the Democratic Presidential caucuses in California yesterday, while six others betrayed serious weaknesses.

title: TOBY JUNIOR WINS TERRIER LAURELS
description: Toby Junior II, who was 2 years old on Feb. 5, took top honors yesterday in the 64th annual Boston Terrier Club of New York specialty show at the City Squire Motor Inn. The victory left Toby, owned by Mr. and Mrs. Harry N.

title: Navy Shifts Claims Review To an AllMilitary Board
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 13 (AP) The Navy has established an allmilitary board to review contractor claims after abolishing a civilian board whose chairman accused four members of Congress from Louisiana of using undue political pressure in behalf of a shipbuilding concern.

title: Man Found Slain
description: CLONES, Northern Ireland, Feb. 13 (AP)The hooded body of a young man shot through the head was found today in this village 30 miles to the southwest of Enniskillen on the border with the Irish Republic. The police believe he may have been executed by the Irish Republican Army.

title: IRAN SAYS6OPERSONS DIED IN AVALANCHES
description: TENERAN, Feb. 13Sixty persons have been killed in, avalanches in northwest Iran after the heaviest snowfalls in more than 10 years, according to official figures released tonight.

title: Little Dragonfly Victor
description: Ch. Sheeba's Little Dragonfly won first honors yesterday in the American Pomeranian Club specialty show at the Hotel New Yorker. The 2yearold orange Pomeranian is owned by Sam Zaneoff of New York. Dragonfly, who will be shown at Westminster today is a bestinshow and group winner. He Is a son of the famed Pomeranian, Ch. Corn Duke's Dragons fly.

title: Advertising:
description: Norman Cousins new magazine is getting closer to being a reality all the time.

title: Village Vanguard to Lose a Musical Staple to Soviet for 5 Weeks
description: The Thad JonesMel Lewis Band, a multiracial 18member group of seasoned musicians long featured at the Village Vanguard, will play five weeklong engagements on a tour of five Soviet cities, beginning next month or early in April.

title: 7 Stabbed in Trenton Prison; One Inmate's Condition Critical
description: TRENTON, Feb. 13  New Jersey correction authorities began an investigation and a search for handmade knives at the Trenton State Prison today following the stabbing of seven inmates, including a reputed Mafia leader and an underworld associate, since last night.

title: Cowles Squash Racquets Is Won by Niederhoffer
description: Victor Niederhoffer of New York, the topseeded player, won the 26th annual Harry Cowles invitation squash racquets tournament yesterday at the Harvard Club by defeating Anil Nayar of Boston, 1512, 1512, 1514, in the final.

title: Saigon Shuts Orphanage; 3,000 Children Missing
description: LONGTHANH VILLAGE, South Vietnam, Feb. 13South Vietnam's largest orphanage was silent today following a police action Friday during which the orphanage was shut and nearly 3,000 Vietnamese children were carried away In trucks.

title: Race Issue Polarized By Rhodesia Inquiry
Books of The Times; james (and Biography) Rescued
description: HENRY JAMES. The Master: 19011916. By Loon Edel. 591 pages. Illustrated. Lippincott. $12.95.

title: New Giants Work Out on Parking Lot
description: If you happened to pass by the Yankee Stadium private parking lot around noon on Saturday and saw a group of men in blueandwhite football jerseys running through peculiar maneuvers, you were not hallucinating. It was only part of an orientation session the New York Giants held for their newly drafted, but still unsigned, players.

title: La Mama to Start 2d Repertory Season March
description: Ellen Stewart's La Mama network now spreads from Tel Aviv to Tokyo, with home base still at 74A East Fourth Street. To give her numerous companies a sense of continuity and to expand La Mama's New York community, last month Miss Stewart instituted a public repertory season (which continues through Feb. 20) with plays by Wilford Leach and John Braswell and their ETC Company.

title: Democratic Groups In Mississippi Pick Convention Slates
description: JACKSON, Miss., Feb. 13Mississippi's two feuding Democratic factions, the whitecontrolled regulars and the blackcontrolled loyalists, held separate county conventions yesterday in most of the state's 82 counties, but a fusion ticket emerged in at least a few counties.

title: Fleetwood Mac Scores
description: MIDDLE ISLAND, L. I., Feb. 13Fleetwood Mac, a 7yearold bay gelding owned and handled by Sue Ford of Huntington, won both time classes to capture the intermediate jumper championship today at the final Middle Island Arena indoor horse show of the season.

title: SLOW DOLLAR FLOW TO U.S. IS STUDIED
description: Establishing wider foreignexchange bands helps explain why the expected larger inflow of dollars from abroad has not taken place.

title: CANDIDATES SEEK LABOR'S BACKING
description: BAL HARBOUR, Ha., Feb. 13Organized labor's top leaders are meeting here this week in an atmosphere charged with politics, but there are no plans now to take sides officially in the Democratic Presidential race.

title: BAUER'S MOUNT CAPTURES HONOR
description: SOMERS, N. Y., Feb. 13Among the Stars, a former national highpoint champion, captured one division of the regular working hunter competition at the Primrose Farms Horse Show yesterday. Fred Bauer of Weston, Conn., owns and rides the horse.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: Jailing Mihajlov

title: The 13alance in the War Powers Bill
description: WASHINGTONA national debate has begun on the War Powers Act.

title: Clashes Near Temple
description: PNOMPENH, Cambodia, Feb. 13 (Reuters) The Cambodian command reported  today sharp series of clashes around the ancient Angkor temples where a senior Cambodian official has reported a Government offensive under way.

title: U.S. Medal Tally: Wornen 7, Men 1
description: SAPPORO, Japan, Feb. 13 (AP)A story book ending, said one man who helped write it, the unflappable United States hockey goaltender, Michael Curran.

title: More Writings on Hughes Like Irving's Are Revealed
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 13Still more evidence emerged today that Clifford Irving's book The Autobiography of Howard Hughes strongly resembles a variety of published and unpublished materials produced by others.

title: Reasons for College Dropouts Studied
description: One of the most comprehensive studies ever made of the national college dropout phenomenon shows what its author says Is a somewhat lower dropout rate than the popular folklore would have you believe.

title: BRITONS WARNED ON POWER CRISIS
description: Britain will be forced to impose an almost total electricpower blackout and a complete shutdown of industry in about two weeks if tne nationwide coal miners strike continues that much longer, the Government said today.

title: Sports of The Times
description: The Sons of the Purple Plains were in El Paso this last week mucking around with a lot of misanthropic bulls and antisocial broncos. When the last of them was scraped off the arena fence yesterday. The Rope led Nancy Redstar into her trailer, slid behind the wheel of his station wagon and set off on the 600mile haul to San Antonio. At 42 The Rope doesn't ship as well as he did 15 years ago; nevertheless, he has stashed his golf clubs in the closet and returned to rodeo's dusty road with two targets dead his sightshis 12th world championship and the largest loot he has seen in one bundle since he was getting a daily handout of raisins and beans from the Welfare for Dependent Children station in Nampa, Idaho.

title: HOFFA TERMS NIXON BEST QUALIFIED MAN
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 13 (AP) James R. Hoffa, former teamsters chief, who was released from prison at President Nixon's order, said today that he considered Mr. Nixon the best qualified Presidential candidate.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: H.R.1: Questionable Reform

title: Japan's Auto Makers Apply the Brakes
description: TOKYO, Feb. 13Japanese automobile producers are applying the brakes this year after the explosive export growth in 1971 that startled them and alarmed their competitors in the United States.

title: The Junior College, Belittled in Past, Now a Major Force
description: MIAMI, Feb. 13Public junior colleges, once scorned as high schools with ash trays, have exploded since 1960 into a major social force that is shaping industrial development, urban services and personal pride.

title: CONGRESSMEN RATED BY WOMEN VOTERS
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 13 (UPI) The League of Women Voters gave 100 per cent ratings to 73 members.of Congress today, including Senator Edward M. Kennedy of Massachusetts and five candidates for the Presidency.

title: St. Mark's Square Flooded
description: VENICE, Italy, Feb. 13 (AP) St. Mark's Square here was under almost three feet of water today, and shops in the tourist center were flooded. The flooding came as strong east winds backed up the high morning tide over the city's waterfront for the second consecutive day.

title: MISS JONES, SOPRANO, DISPLAYS FINE VOICE
description: From a purely vocal standpoint, Betty Jones's Tully Hall recital Sunday afternoon was outstanding. Her soprano is rich and fullbodied instrument that moves with easy assurance throughout its compass. The top rings out clearlyonly a hint of a fluttery vibrato intrudes, a touch of intriguing individuality rather than a flaw in this caseand her lower range has the strength and dark timbre that a mezzo might envy.

title: New Hampshire Primary Fades into Numbers Game
description: MANCHESTER, N. H., Feb. 13With three weeks remaining until Election Day, the New Hampshire primary campaign looks more like a problem in arithmetic than a momentous political struggle.

title: GAUDIN 0:04 VICTOR IN FISK TROPHY SKI
description: WOODSTOCK, Vt., Feb. 13Nimble Laurent Gaudin, the 17yearold Dartmouth freshman who won his school's carnival slalom last Friday, captured the Fisk Trophy today at Suicide Six.

title: ROBERT L. KIDD
description: BARTLESVILLE, Okla., Feb. 14 (AP)Robert L. Kidd, former board chairman and president of the Cities Service Oil Company, died here yesterday. He was 70 years old.

title: Nixon Returns to Capital After Weekend in Florida
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 13 (UPI) President Nixon returned to the nation's capital this evening after a weekend in Florida and made final preparations for meeting tomorrow with Congressional foes of school busing to plan strategy for preventing the practice.

title: Morris Watson, Newsman, Dies; Won Key Labor Law Test Case
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 12 (AP)Morris Watson, an early organizer of the Newspaper Guild, whose test case establshed the constitutionality of the National Labor Relations Act, died Saturday of cancer. He was 71 years old.

title: Bowles Takes Sunfish Title
description: HAMILTON, Bermuda, Feb. 13 (AP)Robert Bowles of Garden City, L. I., won the third world Sunfish championships today with a low point score of 27.4. Carl Knight of Mamaroneck, N. Y., took second place with 38.4 points.

title: Advertising:
description: Helmut Krone has left Case & Krone, which he and Gene Case founded in the spring of 1969.

title: Chess: A Pair of Interesting Games Gloggnitz, of All Places
description: Chess tournaments, logically enough, are usually identified by the name of the city in which they were played and the year they took place. The latter is vital informationsome cities have been host to scores of tournaments since the first one of note in London in 1851.

title: Young Chicano's Triumph Reflects Delegate Reform
description: PHOENIX, Ariz., Feb. 13When Anna Chavez was 7 years old, her family moved to Arizona from Mexico, and the little girl was often confused. Our first home was in the projects and they were all painted the same, she recalled today. I'd walk out the front door and get lostit happened several times.

title: 62 CHILDREN DIED IN 71 FROM ABUSE
description: There were 52 deaths officially attributed to child abuse in the city last year  17 of them caused by physical beatings  according to a report issued yesterday by the Human Resources Administration.

title: Stage: A Lucid Oedipus
description: Blanche Du Bois wasn't the only one who ultimately depended on the kindness of strangers. So, it seems, did Oedipus.

title: Monetary Policy and the Dollar
description: Arthur F. Burns has made a vigorous defense of the expansionary monetary policy that the Federal Reserve has been following since the international agreement on devaluation of the dollar last December. The Fed's critics, both at home and abroad, contend that a country which devalues has the obligation thereafter to tighten its money supply and raise interest rates as a means warding off further devaluation.

title: Masselos Displays Versatility and Style In Piano Marathon
description: William Masselos, a pianist whose enthusiasm for playing all kinds of music seems to be matched by an appetite for playing a lot of it at one time, staged one of his marathons at Hunter College Playhouse on Saturday. It began at 4 P.M., was interrupted for a dinner break shortly after 6 P.M. and got going again for the evening around 8.

title: Sadat Sees Chiefs Amid Reports Soviet Aide Is to Visit Cairo
description: CAIRO, Feb. 13President Anwar elSadat began a series of meetings with his top aides today amid reports that the Soviet Defense Minister, Marshal Andrei A. Grechko, would fly here shortly for a fourday visit.

title: Queen Elizabeth Visits Thai Provincial Capital
description: CHANGMAL, Thailand, Feb. 13 (UPI)  Queen Elizabeth IT flew to this heavilyguarded provincial capital today to begin the final phase of her state visit to Thailand.

title: Douglas L. Elliman Dies at 89; Leader in RealEstate Activities
description: Douglas L. Elliman, honorary chairman of the real estate company he founded 60 years ago, died yesterday at his home, 485 Park Avenue. He was 89 years old.

title: Dream for Women: President Chisholm
description: A dream about a meeting of President Chisholm's Cabinet,

title: LAYER TRIUMPHS N FOURSET FINAL
description: PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 13 The click of confidence has returned to Rod Layer's tennis arsenal.

title: SLAIN ULSTER 13 HONORED BY 4,000
description: ENNISKILLEN, Northern Ireland, Feb. 13About 4,000 demonstrators marched through this border town today in memory of 13 Roman Catholics shot dead by British troops in Londonderry two weeks ago.

title: COL. LEO J. MEYER, 76, ARMY HISTORIAN, DIES
description: CLOSTER, N.J., Feb. 13Col. Leo J. Meyer, a retired Army officer and historian and former history teacher at New York University, died yesterday at his home, 55 Ann Arbor Place. He was 76 years old.

title: BUCK HAWKS WIN FROM LEAFS 31
description: CHICAGO, Feb. 13 (AP)Thirdperiod goals by Cliff Koroll and Chico Maid gave the Chicago Black Hawks a 31 victory over the Toronto Maple. Leafs tonight in a closechecking game.

title: Jennings Captures Ski Jump
description: SALISBURY, Conn., Feb. 13 In one of the wettest Eastern ski jumping championships held in the 50year history of the tournament, Bruce Jennings of Lebanon, N. FL, retained his Class A crown in a rainstorm today.

title: Entry of 3,093 Dogs Arrives Slowly For TwoDay Main Event at Garden
description: While 20 specialty shows in nine sites caused the principal excitement yesterday, they were but a prelude to the main event, the 96th edition of Westminster, which gets under way this morning and will end tomorrow night. The sporting, hound and toy groups will be judged today.

title: Laotians Retake Town
description: VIENTIANE, Laos, Feb. 13 (UPI)Government troops supported by tanks, armored vehicles, artillery and air strikes retook the strategic town of Muong KassY, 92 miles north of Vientiane on Route 13, Laotian military spokesmen said today.

title: Laurence Goldstein, 35, N.B.C. Newsman, Writer
description: LEONIA, N. J., Feb. 13Laurence Goldstein, a newsman and writer for the National Broadcasting Company, died last night of an electrical shock while working on a television set at his home, 100 Glenwood Avenue. He was 35 years old.

title: Democratic Women in South to Challenge Rules on Picking Convention Delegates
description: NASHVILLE, Feb. 13Democratic women from half a dozen Southern states made plans here this weekend to challenge the rules and procedures under which delegates to the Presidential nominating convention are being chosen.

title: AComparison of Excerpts Taken From Manuscripts and Book About the Life of Hughes
description: Following are excerpts read from the Clifford Irving manuscript on Howard R. Hughes and recorded in New York by The New York Times:

title: ARPAD SANDOR, 75, AN ACCOIPANIST
description: Arpad Sandor, a leading piano accompanist here and abroad, died Thursday in Budapest at the age of 75.

title: SHIPWRECKED 144 DUE IN CHILE WEDNESDAY
description: PUNTA ARENAS, Chile, Feb. 13 (AP)The 92 passengers and part of the crew of the Lindblad Explorer, stranded just above the Antarctic Circle, were reported today to be on their way to Punta Arenas and expected to arrive Wednesday.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Some in City to Mark Lincoln's Birthday Today

title: As Tet Nears, Nervousness Increases
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Feb. 13With the Tot holiday beginning tomorrow evening, American and South Vietnamese officials have become visibly nervous with the discovery of what they say are increasing signs of an impending major Communist offensive.

title: BugEatBug, Operation Jeopardized in Pakistan
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan, Feb. 7Pakistan's withdrawal last week from the British Commonwealth will probably not have much effect on wine production in Saudi Arabia, the hashish supply in New York, chemical pollution in California or  to be slightly esoteric  the rhinoceros beetle population in the Seychelles.

title: Westinghouse Banking on Semiconductors
description: Just at a time when many of the giants are phasing out of semiconductor manufacturing, the Westinghouse Electric Corporation believes it has a new system that can propel it to the top rank.

title: Engine Explodes, Killing Truck Concern's Owner
description: The owner of a trucking company in Queens was burned to death yesterday. afternoon and an employe was seriously burned when the feel system of a tractortrailer engine they were working on exploded.

title: Some SteelOrder Gains Made; Signs of a Full Recovery Seen
description: PITTSBURGH, Feb. 13Steel producers said a full market recovery was strongly indicated but was not yet certain.

title: COLIN M. MIEOD, A MICROBIOLOGIST
description: LONDON, Feb. 13 (AP)Dr. Colin M. MacLeod, an American microbiologist and former White House science adviser, died Saturday in an airport hotel here. He was 63 years old.

title: SHADRACK GAINS TOP BOXER PRIZE
description: Ch. ScherKhoun's Shadrack, a mahogany brindle showman owned and bred by Mr. and Mrs. Ben B. DeBoer of Thornmill, Ontario, paced a field of 265 yesterday in taking bestInshow honors at the 29th annual American Boxer Club event in the Stetler Hilton Hotel.

title: WRITERS SEEK TO BAR JAILING OF GINZBURG
description: Statements by about 40 writers, editors and publishers calling themselves the Committee for a Free Presswere Issued yesterday deploring the imminent Jailing of Ralph Ginzburg, who was convicted nine years ago of charges of mailing obscene materials.

title: BIG POWER DUEL WORRIES BURMA
description: RANGOON, Burma, Feb. 8Diplomats and officials here believe China and the Soviet Union will intensify their maneuvers for influence in Burma as a result of recent developments in South Asia.

title: TONY M TRIUMPHS IN PRIX DE PARIS
description: PARIS, Feb. 13The French trotter, Tony M, today breezed home to an easy victory in the $60,000 Prix de Paris, the last leg in the winter triple crown competition at Vincennes.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: Modern or Medieval Men?

title: Montgomery Ward Is Cheered by Its New Stores
description: Montgomery Ward, now in its 101st year of existence, hopes that it has shaken off its troubles and can fully concentrate on what is contributing 75 per cent of its sales and 95 per cent of its profitsits new stores built in the last decade.

title: It Would Have Been Perfect for Valentine's Day
description: Alexander Girard's Valentine is postersized and fabric with LOVE printed across a big fireengine red heart on a white background. Problem is, the Santa Fe architect's Love Heart, as the design is called, will have to be presented two days late or 364 days early, because the graphics collection it is part of will not go on sale at the Herman Miller showroom, 600 Madison Avenue (at 58th Street) until Wednesday. Mr. Girard says he doesn't think he'll lose any sales because of his timing, for he and the Miller concern consider the hanging a yearround decoration. It is available either unhemmed and unseamed to be framed or stapled on wall at $21 or sewn on four sides and with a rod top and bottom at $34.

title: Swimmer Sues Host
description: AKRON, Ohio, Feb. 13 (UPI) William G. Kerns, who says he was under the influence of alcohol when he was injured in a swimming pool accident at a friend's home, has sued his host for $250,000. Mr. Kerns's suit, filed yesterday in Corn. mon Pleas Court, charges that Robert Cook was negligent in allowing him to swim and dive when he had been drinking.

title: CANAMENS PLAY BRUINS TO 22 TIE
description: BOSTON, Feb. 13 (UPI)Ken Dryden, in the goal, allowed only two goals by Wayne Cashman despite a 41shot barrage today to earn the Montreal Canadiens a 22 tie with the Boston Bruins.

title: Controls at 6 Months: Inflation Rate Curbed
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 13 After six months, President Nixon's economic stabilization program is plowing through rough seas, seemingly in the right general direction, but it could still be blown off, course, and many or the passengers are complaining about the ride.

title: LINDSAY ASSAILS NIXON ON BUSING
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 13 Mayor Lindsay attacked President Nixon today on the ground that the President was encour= aging a constitutional amendment against school busing.

title: Bloodletting Is Being Tested As a Preventive of Coronaries
description: For the last eight months, 140 volunteers have been bled regularly at St. Vincent's Hospital in a pilot experiment designed to determine whether frequent bloodletting lessens the chance of coronaries and strokes in males.

title: CORRECTION OFFICER SLAIN BY CITY POLICE
description: A Greenwood Lake, N.Y., man identified as an offduty correction officer at the Ossining Correctional Facility, also known as Sing Sing prison, died early yesterday after being wounded in an exchange of shots with two Manhattan policemen.

title: BEST OF BULLDOGS IS PRINCE DOMINO
description: Ch. Prince Domino of Grabel, owned and bred by Lee and Mary Grabeel of Reseda, Calif., won the top award for the second successive year yesterday at the Bulldog Club of America specialty show at the Hotel McAlpin.

title: 2 Killed While Digging for Coal
description: BARNSLEY, England, Feb 13 (AP)  A man and a youth were killed by falling earth today as they tunneled into coal seams to dig fuel for their homes.

title: Ginteno, Itarthes in Final
description: LOS ANGELES, Feb. 13 (AP) Andres Gimeno of Spain and Pierre Barthes of France gained the final of the $40,000 international open tennis tournament today.

title: Bartels Resigns as Scott Panel's Counsel
description: John R. Bartels Jr. has resigned as the top investigator of Governor Rockefeller's commission examining city government, reportedly out of dissatisfaction with the highly charged political climate he feels the Mayor and Governor have created over the commission's work.

title: A Peace Bid That Failed in 1965 Disclosed by ExU.S. Officials
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Feb. 13 North Vietnam considered, and then set aside, secret Miffed States peace offers in 1965, well placed informants have now disclosed.

title: Davis Leads Bostonians With Bishop as Pianist
description: The Boston Symphony, with Colin Davis conducting and Stephen Bishop as piano soloist, gave a particularly rewarding concert at Carnegie Hall on Saturday night.

title: Deaths
description: AHERNBello V., on Feb. 13th, 1972. Dear sister of Caroline and tha late Mrs. Henry Benson Donahue and Mrs. Henry Jules Laurencot. Reposing Gallagher Funeral Home, Manhasset. Mass of the Resurrection Wed., 11:15 AM, St. Anastasia's RC Church, Douglaston. Interment Holy Cross Cemetery, Brooklyn, N.Y.

title: A WIDE DISPARITY IS FOUND IN CRIME THROUGHOUT CITY
description: Proof of the vast disparity with which crime falls across New York City and evidence of wide differences in the ability of individual precincts to arrest criminals have emerged from the most detailed analysis of crime statistics ever known to have been completed here.

title: TANNER ADVANCES IN INDOOR TENNIS
description: SALISBURY, Md., Feb. 13 (AP)With all the seeded players taking the day off, three young Americans captured the spotlight today in the first round of the 1972 national indoor open tennis championships.

title: NETS LOSE, 123117, IN TWO OVERTIMES
description: DALLAS, Feb. 13 (AP)The Dallas Chapparals overcame 47 points by New York's Rick Barry and the ejection of Donnie Freeman to post a 123117 doubleovertime victory over the Nets in an American Basketball Association game tonight.

title: DAPPER DAN GAINS KERRY BLUE HONOR
description: Pete Green handled three best of breed winners but the happiest owners at yesterday's 55th specialty show of the Associated Terriers Clubs were Mr. and Mrs. Robert Belviso of Schwenksville, Pa.

title: IRVING TREATMENT RAISES QUESTIONS
description: The handling of the Clifford Irving manuscript at Time Inc., which publishes Time and Life magazines, has aroused discussion in recent weeks in that organization and has raised numerous questions in the publishing field.

title: BOND MARKET SET FOR FRESH GAINS
description: Shortterm interest rates late last week dropped to the same low levels they reached In January, and the credit markets are beginning to think they will stay down for a while. If so, the bond market may be in better shape than it thought.

title: MRS. GERALD W. BREESE
description: PRINCETON, N.J., Feb. 13Mrs. Alice Janette Bailey 1Breese, a speech therapist in the Princeton regional school system and the wife of Dr. Gerald W. Breese, professor of sociology at Princeton University, died of multiple myeloma today in Princeton Hospital. She was 58 years old and lived at 195 Russell Road.

title: CAHILL PROPOSING $2B1LLION BUDGET
description: TRENTON, Feb. 13  Gov. William T. Cahill will propose to the State Legislature tomorrow a $2billion budget that, he says, is probably the last one in New Jersey that will not include local property tax reform or a major new source of statewide revenue, such as an income tax.

title: FILIPINOS EXPECT NEW RICE SCARCITY
description: MANILA, Feb. 13The Philippines, the land where the Green Revolution began, appears to be going from one rice crisis to another.

title: TV Review
description: As music and artistic director of N.E.T. Opera Theater, Peter Herman Adler has been articulately pleading for timetime to demonstrate that he could go beyond imports and coproductions to original and imaginative opera presentations specifically tailored for television.

title: Beautiful Forgeries of Hughes Fooled Writing Expert at First
description: Albert D. Osborn, the noted examiner of questioned documents and senior partner of the firm that first declared valid and then termed a forgery handwriting alleged to be that of Howard R. Hughes, said yesterday, that several factors had been involved in the switch  including the fact that his was not an exact science.

title: DIVERS FIND WRECK OF SHIP OFF TEXAS
description: FREEPORT, Tex, Feb 13 (UPI) A team of divers from a seismic research ship identified today the wreckage of the tanker V. A. Fogg, which disappeared Feb. I, in 90 feet of water in the Gulf of Mexico.

title: Frances Ellen Ross Is Married in Haifa
description: Miss Frances Ellen Ross, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Martin Ross of Floral Park, L. I., was married last evening in Haifa, Israel, to Yehiel Orgal, a lighting designer for Israeli theatrical productions. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Moshe Orgal of Haifa, where his father is a textile merchant.

title: Versailles Antiwar Assembly Backs Plan for U.S. Campaign
description: VERSAILLES, Feb. 13Plans for a sixweek campaign, beginning April 1, by peace groups in the United States to end the Indochina war on terms laid down by North Vietnam and the Vietcong received pledges of international support here today.

title: Drop in Heroin Addiction Tied to Legal Marijuana
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 13An end to criminal penalties for the possession of marijuana, to be recommended by the National Commission on Marijuana and Drug Abuse, could reduce heroin addiction, a report to the commission has concluded.

title: Chiefs Beat Jolters, 4240, In Roller Derby League
description: The Chiefs defeated the Jolters, 4240, in an international Roller Derby League game yesterday at Madison Square Garden as Mike Gamon scored points as time ran out.

title: AGNEW FINDS CRITICS UNDERMINING NIXON
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 13 (UPI) Vice President Agnew said today that, although Democratic Presidential candidates may not have been doing it consciously, their criticism has undermined President Nixon's Vietnam peace proposal.

title: Is There a V.A.T. in Your Future?
description: The big tax story of 1972 is about a complicated new taxthe V.A.T., or valueadded taxthat almost certainly will not be proposed, let alone imposed, this year.

title: KRIS KRISTOFFERSON OFFERS SONGS HERE
description: It is fortunate for Kris Kristofferson that there are other singers besides himself who like to sing his songs. He has excellent credentials as a song writer  Me and Bobby McGhee, Sunday Morning Cornin Down, Help Me Make It Through the Nightbut in his appearance yesterday afternoon at Philharmonic Hall as part of the Great Performers series, he hardly lived up to the adjective.

title: I.R.S. Offers Assistance on 1971 IncomeTax Filing
description: The Internal Revenue Service will be ready this week in offices in New York State, New Jersey and Connecticut to help taxpayers fill out their returns on 1971 income.

title: Man in the News
description: PARIS, Feb. 14  The knowledge about China that Andre Malraux imparts to President Nixon over the dinner table tonight has been gleaned through a unique combination of thought and action, contemplation and adventure.

title: Radicals and Asylums in the Soviet Union
description: When Ivan Yakhimovich, the head of a collective farm in Latvia, got into trouble for criticizing the higher authorities, they had him examined by psychiatrists. The latter listed among his peculiarities that he puts the public interest higher than his own and believes that he has to dedicate his life to the ideals of Communism. The story is told in A Question of Madness by the Medvedev brothers and illustrates one of the saddest paradoxes of Soviet life. The successors of the Promethean handful who set out to change the world now regard any effort to change theirs with suspicion. Obsessive reformist delusions has become a familiar diagnosis in the psychiatric police records smuggled to the West by Soviet dissidents.

title: MRS. JAMES HARPER
description: PELHAM, N. Y., Feb. 14 Mrs. Helen Leale Harper, widow of James Harper, an executive of Tiffany & Co., died today in Greenwich (Conn.) Hospital. She was 89 years old and lived at 66 Harmon Avenue.

title: Rock Island
description: CHICAGO, Feb. 14 (AP) The Chicago, Rock Island & Pacific Railroad reported today that it cut its losses for 1971 to $6.4million from $16.6million in 1970.

title: Thieu Prays for Peace
description: SAIGON, Feb. 15 (UPI)President Nguyen Van Thieu today opened the celebrations of Tet, the Lunar New Year, with a prayer for peace in Vietnatn and renewed opposition to any plan that would sacrifice the nation to the Communists.

title: STATE UNIT HIRES EXLINDSAY AIDE
description: A former member of the Lindsay administration was hired yesterday by the state commission investigating the operations of the city government, while the commission's assistant general counsel disclosed his resignation.

title: Texas G.O.P. Leader Resigns
description: AUSTIN, Tex., Feb. 14Peter J. O'Donnell Jr. of Dallas resigned today as Republican national committeeman from Texas.

title: Hamilton Replaces Informality With Precision as Deputy Mayor
description: The clubhouse atmosphere is gone from the Deputy Mayor's office at City Hall. Mayoral sides no longer lounge in the armchairs, talking politics, their legs dangling over the sides, as in the days of former Deputy Mayor Richard R. Aurelio, the consummate politician who quit to manage the LindsayforPresident campaign.

title: THOMAS NACLERIO
description: Thomas Naclerio, executive vice president of the Naclerio Construction Company and the Pelham Contractors Equipment Corporation of the Bronx, died Sunday in Albert Einstein Medical Center, after a long illness. He was 54 years old and lived at 2341 Gunther Avenue, the Bronx.

title: Blue Cross Asks Increase
description: BOSTON, Feb. 14 (AP) Massachusetts Blue Cross and Blue Shield filed with the State Insurance Commissioner today a proposal for an average of 26.1 per cent increases in nongroup rates.

title: Gen. Coulter Weds Mrs. Byron Foy
description: PALM SPRINGS, Calif., Feb. 14Mrs. Virginia Peine Foy, a widow of Byron C. Foy, Chrysler Corporation vice president, was married here today to Lieut. Gen. John B. Coulter, U.S.A., retired.

title: AntiPeking Signs Mark Chinese New Year Herei
description: The arrival today of Chinese lunar year 4670the Year of the Rathas a special bite in Chinatown where the traditional holiday banners across Mott Street have sharp, antiCommunist slogans.

title: BANK AND 2 STORES BOMBED IN BELFAST
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Feb. 14 (AP)Bombs set by guerrillas blasted more Belfast buildings today while Britain's chief judge opened an inquiry into the 13 deaths of Londonderry's Bloody Sunday two weeks ago.

title: Florida High Court Voids 103YearOld Abortion Law
description: TALLAHASSEE, Fla., Feb. 14 (UPI)  The Florida Supreme Court voided the state's 103yearold abortion law today, declaring the statute unconstitutionally vague, indefinite and uncertain.

title: Boston U. Top Harvard In Beanpot Hockey Final
description: BOSTON, (AP)Boston University scored three powerplay goals tonight and defeated Harvard 41 in the final of the Beanpot hockey tournament.

title: A Rather Grand Larceny
description: Not since the Merry Pranks of Til Eulenspiegel has rascality won as wide and eager an audience as the alleged deeds of Clifford Irving. There is an added liveliness, even a certain gaiety, in the conversation of dinner guests and literate barflies since the charges first surfaced concerning the obscure writer from Ibiza who sold Life magazine and McGrawHill, Inc., an autobiography the recluse, Howard Hughes.

title: GUILTY PLEA FILED IN MEDICAID CASE
description: One of the leading figures in a concern that handled $12million annually in Medicaid claims on the city pleaded guilty yesterday in the Bronx to conspiracy and to aiding and abetting in the theft of $2million from the city.

title: IN THE NATION
description: Senator Henry M. Jackson, whose Presidential candidacy is hardpressed by George Wallace in the Florida primary, has stolen some thunder from Mr. Wallace with a proposed Constitutional amendment to roll back school Integration. That's what the Jackson amendment would do, under the guise of stopping busing and providing quality education.

title: Ship's Loss Laid to Blast; Death of 39 Called Instant
description: GALVESTON, Tex., Feb. 14 (UPI)Evidence obtained by divers inspecting the sunken wreckage of the tanker V. A. Fogg indicated today that the vessel, which carried a volatile chemical, was blown apart and her 39 crewmen killed instantly.

title: Paul E. Kovenock
description: Essentially a scholar, 35 years old Graduated from the University of Wisconsin, spent three years in a graduate program of Far Eastern studies at the University of Washington and two years as a Fulbright Scholar in Taiwan, learning Chinese In 1966, joined United Nations Development Program in Taiwan as a sociologist Since 1970, has lived in France (his wife is French), teaching urban studies at the University of Paris Having done occasional contract interpreting for the State Department,. was asked by the Government last month to go to China with the President To do so, he signed up with the Civil Service last week, presumably suspending his teaching career for the

title: Bill to Kill Forest Hills Project Picks Up Supporters in Albany
description: ALBANY, Feb. 14  State Senator John J. Marchi said today that a bill designed to kill the controversial Forest Hills public housing project would be rifled out of the Committee on the City of New York as soon as possible.

title: HUGHES SECLUSION JARRED BY EVENTS
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 14Howard Hughes's privacy, which he holds so dear, has taken severe blows in the controversy over a purported autobiography of the eccentric billionaire.

title: News Analysis
description: No fault Is today's consumer catch phrase, as important a goal as better foodlabeling or reform of the credit laws. Nofault automobile accident insurance, the consumer advocates say, is a boon to consumers and those who oppose it are anticonsumer. And the consumer themselves, remembering long and often futile efforts to collect damage payments after their own accidents, and envisioning speedy and full payments under no fault, are for the most part in ready agreement.

title: Woody Allen's Satire Program Withdrawn for Public TV Airing
description: The Politics of Woody Allen, a satire scheduled for showing on public television, has been withdrawn from national distribution for further review and study.

title: Jabara Gains in Squash
description: Topseeded Gerry Jabara of the New York Athletic Club eliminated Dennis Eagle of the City A. C. last night in the first round of the Fowler invitation Class C tournament at the seventh Regiment. The scores were 1510, 1510, 1511, Ted Wheeler of the Heights Casino beat Doug Thom of Sleepy Hollow, 1511, 159, 1513 and Arthur Kaiser of the Princeton Club defeated Bruce 13ernann of Seventh Regiment, 152, 151, 1716.

title: Donald McBride, 53, Dead; BankAmericard Executive
description: WALNUT CREEK, Calif., Feb. 14 (AP)Donald R. McBride, president of BankAmerica Service Corporation, which was instrumental in spreading the Bank of America's credit card throughout the country, died here on Friday of a cerebral hemorrhage. He was 53 years old.

title: Red Baron, Move Over Another Flier Is in the News
description: The face that has not been seen in public since the fifties has been imprinted on thousands of shirts, perhaps an inevitability in an age where the medium is the Tshirt. And anyone who can fork over the very unHugheslike price of $2 can sport Howard R. Hughes's likeness for all the world to see.

title: INVENTORIES UP DURING DECEMBER
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 14Total business inventories rose by SS2Umillion in December, well above the monthly average for the year, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: MURPHY DECRIES U.S. AMIE AID
description: Police Commissioner Patrick V. Murphy criticized President Nixon yesterday for not seeking more Federal funds for law enforcement assistance programs while crime is beginning to destroy us and the system to prevent It is breaking down.

title: French Racing Quarters In Paris, Marseilles Bombed
description: PARIS, Feb. 14Two plastic bomb attacks damaged the headquarters of thoroughbred racing authorities in Paris and in Marseilles at nearly the same hour early this morning.

title: OftenAbsent Senator Asks Longer Workweek
description: WASHINGTON, Feb, 14 (AP)One or the most frequent truants in this year's absenteeridden Senate session returned today from a week's skiing holiday in Europe and proposed that his colleagues stretch their workweek to five days.

title: Obituary 1  No Title
description: Deaths

title: Antibusing Moves Opposed
description: CHARLOTTE, N.C., Feb. 14 (AP)The general board of the National Council of Churches has called for a determined effort to end racial imbalance in the nation's schools and asked government leaders to oppose antibusing measures. The board, in its midwinter meeting yesterday, adopted a measure restating the commitment to equal educational opportunity it first made in 1952.

title: Charles W. Freeman Jr.
description: At 28, has mastered Mandarin in less than two years at State Department language schools in Washington and Taichung, Taiwan Also fluent in French and Spanish A Washingtonian who graduated from Yale and attended the Harvard Law School, joined the State Department in 1965 Especially interested in Asia Assigned to Madras, India, in 1966 for two years, then turned to Chinese studies Currently attached to the Mainland China Section of the State Department's Office of Asian Communist Affairs So intensive were Chinese studies that he and his wife, Patricia, spoke only Mandarin at home Has old family ties to China: Great grandfather, John R. Freeman, was employed by the Manchu Dynasty at the turn of the century on Yangtze River

title: Syracuse U. Names Dean
description: SYRACUSE, Feb. 14 (UPI)Syracuse University announced today the appointment of Henry F. Schulte, 47 years old, as associate dean of its SI. Newhouse School of Public Communications, effective immediately. Mr. Schulte, who has been chairman of the newspaper department of the school, also will serve as acting dean, pending selection of a new dean to replace Wesley C. Clarke, the dean since 1952, who is returning to fulltime teaching and research.

title: Women's Caucus Is Dissatisfied With Arizona Democratic Slate
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 14Echoes from the Arizona Democratic convention, which on Saturday chose the state's 251 delegates to the party's national convention, reverberated today.

title: Raiders Draft Two Black Hockey Players
description: The prospect of New York letting its first black hockey player, as well as three of the most prized junior players in Canada, was disclosed yesterday by Richard Wood, the frustrated Ranger fan who became the owner of the New York Raiders of the World Hockey Association.

title: Senate Rejects 2 Attempts To Stiffen Rights Measure
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 14 (AP) The Senate defeated today two amendments to a bill to stiffen the Federal law banning racial and other discrimination in employment.

title: Alabama Robber Kills Two
description: MOBILE, Ala., Feb. 14 (UPI) Two employes of a downtown finance company were shot and killed and three other persons injured today by a gunman who robhed the office and fled with an undetermined amount of money. The two persons killed were identified as Jerry Moore, 30 years old, manager of the Mutual Finance Corporation of Mobile County, and Tanya Robinson, 19.

title: Letters to the Editor; (Civil) Right to Work
description: To the Editor:

title: The Screen: A Profile of Pete Seeger
description: Robert Elfstrom, an excellent documentary film director, who two years ago made a fine movie about Johnny Cash, has now made a perfectly dreadful movie about Pete Seeger. It is called Pete Seeger A Song and a Stone, and it opened yesterday at the Evergreen Cinema.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: BELFAST, Feb. 14 (Reuters) A murdered inan found hooded and shot through the head yesterday near Northern Ireland's bordei. with the Irish Republic was identified today as a 20yearold British soldier.

title: Labor Leaders Say Controls Hurt the LowerPaid
description: BAL HARBOUR, Fla., Feb. 14 Top leaders of the A.F.LCIO. attacked the economic control program of the Nixon Administration today, calling it unfair and weighted against lowerpaid workers.

title: Busing Plan Sets Off White Boycott in Augusta, Ga.
description: AUGUSTA, Ga., Feb. 14 (UPI)A new school integration plan involving massive busing was put into effect in Richmond County (Augusta) today, triggering a widespread boycott by whites.

title: Fainsod Rites Thursday
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Feb. 14 A memorial service will be held at 2 P.M. on Thursday in Memorial Church, Harvard Yard, for Dr. Merle Fainsod, director of the Harvard University Library and former director of its Russian Research Institute. He died on Friday at the age of 64. The Rev. Charles P. Price will officiate.

title: Many Clerics Resigning to Get Involved
description: LOUISVILLE, Key., Feb. 13When the Black Workers Coalition is calling for his ouster and the white public officials are grumbling about his policies, Dr. Martin N. Perley feels right at home in the cross fire.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Plan to Give Jersey Flood Plain Control Is Due for Hearing
description: TRENTON, Feb. 14A public hearing was promised in the State Assembly today for a controversial Cahill administration proposal to empower the state to controland in some areas to blockdevelopment in the 7 per cent of New Jersey that is chronically subject to flooding.

title: Hancock Acts to Recover Stock Fees
description: In a move to recapture commissions paid on stock purchases, the giant John Hancock Mutual Life Insurance Company disclosed yesterday that it would seek preferred nonmember status on both the Boston and the Pacific Coast Stock Exchanges.

title: PROFIT GAINS CITED BY UNITED UTILITIES
description: United Utilities, Inc., reported yesterday sizable gains in revenues and sales and net income for 1971.

title: Request Not Received Yet
description: NEW DELHI, Feb. 14 (AP) The Indian Foreign Ministry said today that the Government had received no request as yet from Mr. Bhutto for a meeting. Officials said they did not see any chance of a meeting until latter state elections in India March 6 to 11.

title: 18 More U.S. Technicians In Peking to Await Nixon
description: PEKING, Feb. 14 (Reuters) A party of 18 United States technicians arrived in Peking today to join about 70 White House staff and technicians preparing for President Nixon's visit next Monday.

title: M'GRAWIIII1 AIDE GIVES IRVING DATA
description: Beverly Loo, a key figure in McGrawHill's purchase of the Clifford Irving manuscript on Howard It Hughes, spent nearly two hours yesterday before New York County grand jury giving details of the transaction and how it came about.

title: Prices on the Amex Decline as Turnover Retreats
description: Stock prices declined reluctantly yesterday on the American Stock Exchange. At the close the exchange's index was 27.44, down 0.03. Volume retreated to 5,044,005 shares from 5,652,310 on Friday.

title: Crib Death Bill Sought
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 14 (UPI) Senator Walter F. Mondale, Democrat of Minnesota, said today that he would seek a $10million Federal commitment to finding the cause of crib death, which kills thousands of seemingly healthy babies every year as they sleep. The malady claims an estimated minimum of 10,000 infant lives each year in the United States.

title: ARCHITECT NAMED TO DIRECT CENTER
description: Thomas F. Galvin resigned yesterday as chairman of the city's Board of Standards and Appeals to become executive vice president of the nonprofit corporation that will build 8100million convention center, the nation's largest, on the Hudson River waterfront between 44th and 47th Streets.

title: PEKING LIFTS MN ON A DOZEN BOOKS
description: PEKING, Feb. 14About a dozen books banned during the Cultural Revolution went on sale again today, setting off a rare melee in Peking's main bookshop, where hundreds jostled each other at the counters to buy copies.

title: F.A.A. HEAD BACKS SHORTRANGE JET
description: Calls It Better Outlay Than Cutting Noise of Old Craft

title: East Side Group Elects
description: William J. Williams has been named president of the East Side Association, a civic group of businessmen devoted to improvement programs in such areas as public safety, noise abatement, beautification and antipollution efforts.
