Mr. Williams is a senior vice president of The Tishman Realty and Construction Company, Inc.

title: JOSEPH Y. HONEYCUTT
description: Joseph Y. Honeycutt, a vice president of the Brown & Williamson Tobacco Corporation, died yesterday of a heart attack in Philadelphia. He was 65 years old and lived In Louisville, Ky.

title: A Chinese and Valentine Theme at Raffles
description: It's Leap Year, and last night encompassed both the eve of the Chinese New Year and the waning hours of Valentine's Day. The triple play, among a group that likes any excuse for a gettogether, was too good to resist. Raffles had a party.

title: Bridge: Marathon in Paris Recalls Games That Went On and On
description: The longest scheduled session of tournament play is no doubt the Marathon in Paris, where the players start in the evening and emerge haggard and unshaven at breakfasttime.

title: Governor Praises President; Bids Women Run for Office
description: ALBANY, Feb. 14Governor Rockefeller lauded President Nixon here at a gathering of Republican women and said to their obvious delight that the time has come when women should be elected, to full partnership in the political process.

title: Police Efficiency Constant All Over City, Study Finds
description: Police efficiency, as measured by the number of robbery and burglary arrests in comparison to citizen complaints, appears to be roughly the same in the slums as in other sections of the city, a precincttoprecinct analysis has found.

title: 36 Youths Harass Passersby In Bronx Until Police Arrest 22
description: Three dozen teenagerssaid to be members of three youth gangs on their way to a rumble with a fourth gang. stampeded through a Bronx intersection last evening, harassing passersby and stealing merchandise from newsstands on an elevated station.

title: Mexico Recognizes China
description: MEXICO CITY, Feb. 14 (AP) Mexico established diplomatic relations today with mainland China, the Foreign Ministry announced. Other Hemisphere nations that have diplomatic ties with Peking are Cuba, Chile, Peru and Canada.

title: Sutton Urges Decentralization By Use of Neighborhood Plan
description: A proposal to decentralize city government by dispersing much of City Hall's power among 49 elected neighborhood councils was put forth yesterday by Percy E. Sutton, Manhattan Borough President.

title: Kennedy Welcomed in Dacca
description: DACCA, Bangladesh, Feb. 14 (AP)Senator Edward M. Kennedy arrived in Bangladesh to a cheering welcome today and visited areas where Bengalis bones still lay bleached in the sun.

title: MUSIC AND POETRY HEARD AT FINCH
description: The comingtogether of music and poetry, as an old Tory named Plato was quick to understand, can be an exciting and even disruptive event. But there is such deep suspicion on both sides, with the word men often ignorant of music and the music men positively disdainful of speech, that it requires a master armtwister such as Wagner or Hugo Wolf to bring the parties into a mutually respectful relationship.

title: Fund Buying $50,000 in Tickets
description: The Theater Development Fund, which provides financial assistance to commercial plays of artistic merit, has made a commitment to buy a total of $50,000 worth of tickets to two forthcoming productions.

title: CanadaBangladesh Ties
description: OTTAWA, Feb. 14Canada added her name today to the more than 30 countries that have recognized Bangladesh. formerly East Pakistan. Mitchell W. Sharp, Secretary of State for External Affairs, said that Canada would be diplomatically represented at first by a mission in a country near Bangladesh.

title: Wood, Field and Stream
description: KEY LARGO, Fla.Slim, blonde and vivacious Nina Horstman, who with her husband, Robert, founded the Sea Mammal Motivational Institute two years ago, is delighted to have a new and permanent home for her charges on the grounds of the posh Ocean Reef Club.

title: Gimeno Triumphs in Final
description: LOS ANGELES, Feb. 14 (AP) Andres Girneno of Spain, volleying for perfect placements tonight, defeated Pierre Barthes of France, 63, 26, 62, in the final of the $40,000 International open tennis tournament.

title: Sports of The Times
description: To the considerable embarassment of all male chauvinists, seven of the eight medals awarded to the United States at the recently concluded Winter Olympic Games were won by the female of the species. Less deadly by far were the males. It took the collective effort of a dozen and a half of them to produce one other medal, the one for ice hockey.

title: Stolle Upsets Drysdale
description: TORONTO, Feb. 14 (AP) Fred Stolle of Australia upset fourthseeded Cliff Drysdale of South Africa, 60, 63, and thirdseeded Tom Okker of the Netherlands outlasted Nikki Pilic of Yugoslavia, 6 4, 67 76, in firstround matches of the S50,000 World Championship Tennis tournament today.

title: Advertising:
description: As they have on and off since late fall, the creditors committeesome 40 strong gathered in the large conference room on the executive floor of Lennen & Newell yesterday with the agency's top brass.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Lord Sidi of Marks and Spencer, Retail Chain, a Zionist, Is Dead
description: LONDON, Feb. 14Lord Sidi, president of Marks and Spencer, the multimilliondollar department store chain, and a leading Zionist, died today. He was 82 years old.

title: Notre Dame Triumphs, 92.65
description: SOUTH BEND, Ind., Feb. 14 (UPI)Tom O'Mara scored 21 points and Garry Novak added 20 to lead Notre Dame to a 9265 victory over Bowling Green tonight, the sixth victory in 20 starts for the Irish. Brian Scanlan was high for the Falcons with 12 points.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: CHIEF RABBIS TERMS EXTENDED BY ISRAEL
description: JERUSALEM, Feb. 14 (UP!)The Israeli Cabinet warded off a possible crisis yesterday by extending the term of office of the country's two chief rabbis by six months, but ordered that elections for their successors be held within five months.

title: Rangers, On Coast, Face 3 Contests In Span of 4 Nights
description: The prognosis for the Rangers health the remainder of the National Hockey League campaign may be determined by the end of the week, when the New Yorkers will have completed three games in four nights on the west coast of Canada and the United States.

title: FDA WEIGHS ROLE OF IRON IN BREAD
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 14The Food and Drug Administration hopes to resolve within the next six months the issue of whether to increase the iron content of enriched white bread and flour.

title: COURT ORDER HALTS L.I. EDUCATION GROUP
description: State Supreme Court Justice Jacob Markowitz ordered an end yesterday to the operations of a Long Island corporation that promised, for fees as high as $25,000, to get students admitted to medical or dental colleges.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Intelsat 4 Begins Operation, In Time for Nixon Trip
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 14 (AP) A new communications satellite went into operation today, in time to carry reports of President Nixon's visit to China.

title: Protest at Courthouse
description: SAN JOSE, Calif., Feb. 14 (Reuters)About 300 supporters of Angela Davis staged a silent protest march today past the courthouse where she is to stand trial later this month on charges of murder, kidnapping and conspiracy. The rally was called to protest a new law lbanning demonstrations outside cousthoulas.

title: SCHOOL HEAD ASKS AID FOR RETARDED
description: The director of the Queens State Training School told. two Congressmen yesterday that he could triple the school's enrollment, as well as produce some wageearners among its student body, with more money and greater cooperation from government leaders.

title: U.S. Aides Fear New Cyprus Fighting
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 14 United States officials expressed concern today about the possibility of fighting on the island of Cyprus as a result of demands by the Greek Government for greater influence in Cypriote affairs.

title: NIXON WILL MOVE TO OFFSET RULINGS FOR PUPIL BUSING
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 14 President Nixon told members of Congress today that he would take some step to offset recent Federal court decisions that require a great amount of busing to achieve school integration.

title: World Trade Rise Slowed Last Year
description: GENEVA, Feb. 14International trade experts expect the physical volume of the world's commerce to expand this year at best by no more than the 5 per cent they believe was achieved in 1971.

title: Malfatti Sees Japanese
description: TOKYO, Feb. 14 (Reuters)  Franco Maria Malfatti, president of the European Economic Community, was reported to have agreed with Japanese leaders today that the community and Japan should cooperate with each other in expanding international trade.

title: Ashbrook, Nixon's Rival on the Right, Finding Florida Campaign Trail Rough
description: MIAMI, Feb. 14 I'm an American first, a conservative second, and a Republican third, Representative John M. Ashbrook was saying to 45 cheering supporters of his challenge to President Nixon in the Florida Presidential primary.

title: NASSAU PROPOSES CONTAINER CURBS
description: MINEOLA, L. I., Feb. 14 A ban on the sale and distribution of some nonreturnable bottles and cans was proposed today for Nassau County.

title: SMITH ADVANCES IN OPEN TENNIS
description: SALISBUFtY, Md., Feb. 14 (Reuters)Stan Smith of California, the No. 1seeded player, breezed to a secondround victory today in the national indoor open tennis championships by beating a South African, Ray Moore, 62, 63.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Jos. Sehlitz Brewing Co.
description: Record earnings last year of $35,249,000, or $3.66 a share, were reported by the Jose Schlitz Brewing Company. Profits were up from $29,051,000, or $3.02 a share, in 1970.

title: The System Is a Desperate Injustice to Alcoholics
description: Alcoholism as such is not a legal problemit is a health problem. More simple drunkenness per se should not be handled as an offense subject to the processes of justice. It should be handled as an illness, subject to medical treatment.

title: The China Negotiations, From a Hope to Reality
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 14On Friday, Feb. 20, 1970, the United States conveyed to China in secrecy a proposal from President Nixon that a senior Administration official travel to Peking as a demonstration of the American seriousness about improving relations between the two countries.

title: Rumania Reported to Have Shot Officer for Giving Data to Soviet
description: PARIS, Feb. 14 (AP)An authoritative, diplomatic source said today that a Rumanian general had been executed by a firing squad for passing secret information on Rumanian defenses and rocket operations to the Soviet Union.

title: Executive Changes
description: Joseph A. Rice has been elected senior executive vice president of the Irving Trust Company.

title: Bridal Held for Mary H. Edson And David S. Smith, a Lawyer
description: Bridal Held for Mary H. Edson And David S. Smith, a Lawyer

title: JEWISH GROUP PLANS A POLL ON AMNESTY
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 14 The policymaking body of B'nai B'rithitself split on the issuevoted today to solicit the views of its 500,000member constituency on the question of extending amnesty to Vietnam war evaders.

title: In Pubs and Picket Lines, Miners State Their Case
description: LONDON, Feb. 14Candles flickered in the East End pub off Bidder Street. The striking miners ordered pints of bitter and listened in silence to the radio news about blackouts across Britain.

title: MISS VAN CORTLANDT
description: SHARON, Conn., Feb. 14Charlotte A. Van Cortlandt, a descendant of Jacobus Van Cortlandt who was Mayor of, New York in 1710 and 1719, died today at her home on South Street. She was 80 years old.

title: Russians Loft Moon Craft
description: MOSCOW, Feb. 14The Soviet Union announced today the launching of the unmanned spacecraft Luna 20 with the apparent mission of landing an automatic station on the moon.

title: TAXI DRIVERS HERE CONTINUE WALKOUT
description: The wildcat strike of younger taxi drivers at some garages continued into its fourth day yesterday, with no noticeable effect on the public, but taxiindustry officials said they feared a spread of the strike to other garages and older drivers.

title: Lindsay Stressing TV Exposure on Key Issues in Florida Drive
description: MIAMI, Feb. 14 Mayor Lindsay has brought a carefully revised version of the media campaign that surprised politicians in Arizona into the bigger, keener, more expensive competition of the Florida Presidential primary.

title: A Message From the Director
description: WASHINGTON  The search for truth in many courtrooms today has taken on new dimensions. In some instances, the court, in addition to administering justice, is forced to justify its existence and physically police its proceedings to maintain a modicum of decorum.

title: Newark Tenant Group Refuses To Disclose Data on Rent Fund
description: NEWARK, Feb. 14Leaders of the Stella Wright Tenants Association announced today they would defy a court order that demands an accounting of the rents withheld by association members during the 22 months of their public housing rent strike.

title: CHINA TRADE CURB IS FURTHER EASED BY THE PRESIDENT
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 14With three days left before his trip to China, President Nixon ordered a further relaxation today in United States trade policy toward Peking. He also talked about China with Andre Malraux, the French writer whose knowledge of that country dates from the nineteentwenties.

title: Theater: Grease, 1959 as Nostalgia
description: They are starting to be nostalgic about 1959 nowand almost all I can remember abotit it is that it was a great year for Burgundy. However, it was probably quite good for CocaCola as well, and last night at the Eden Theater we had the opening of Grease, a rock n roll musical that tries to transport us back to those dear dead days when Elvis still had his pelvis, butter didn't melt in Sandra Dee's mouth, hair styles looked like James Dean's and Marlon Brand() rode a motorcycle.

title: Grooms Not Dogging It at Show
description: Not all the action was in the rings yesterday at the Westminster Kennel Club show.

title: United Aircraft Has Loss
description: The United Aircraft Corporation incurred a loss of $43942,423 for 1971 after a special writeoff of $137million, the company reported yesterday.

title: New First Lady of French Cinema: Annie Girardot
description: PARIS  Annie Girardot, according to the latest polls, has sprung to the fore and now ranks as the first lady of the French cinema. Jeanne Moreau and Brigitte Bardot, former holders of the title, have lost much ground in the race because, in large part, of faulty judgment on scripts. ParisMatch, the national pictorial weekly that is modeled after Life, placed Miss Girardot on its cover as the woman of the year.

title: N.B.A. Votes to Extend Hardship Status Deadline
description: Extension to April of the chance for college players to seek hardship status for this year's draft, new playoff rules for 1973, the realignment of Phoenix and Houston next season and distribution of playoff money for this year were decided yesterday by the Board of Governors of the National Basketball Association, meeting at the Marriott Essex Housel Hotel.

title: D.J. Is Best of Sporting Dogs; Basenji Maltese Also Victors
description: The topwinning dog of 1971 keeps right on the winning trail. He is the English springer spaniel, Ch. Chinoe's Adamant James, owned by Dr. Milton E. Prickett, a veterinarian from Lexington, Ky.

title: Merger News
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 14 (AP) Imperial Chemical Industries, Ltd., will divest itself of two divisions of Atlas Chemical Industries, Inc., of Wilmington, Del., the Federal Trade Commission announced today.

title: New Jersey's Old Budget
description: The budget that Gov. William T. Cahill unveiled yesterday for New Jersey for the coming fiscal year is holdtheline budget, as he called it. It is also more than this; it is an old budget for a new year with spending levels essentially unchanged, an inadequate budget that necessitates deferment once again of real solutions to the state's pressing problems.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
Blue Angel Dies in Crash
description: EL CENTRO, Calif., Feb. 14 (UPI)A member of the Navy's Blue Angels precision flying team was killed today when his F4 jet crashed at a target range in the Superstition Mountains. He was Lieut. Larry Watters, 29 years old, of Fresno.

title: Heart Attack Slash Is Linked to Drug In an Airline Study
description: A drug that lowers fats and cholesterol in the blood has reduced the incidence of nonfatal heart attacks among a group of more than 3,000 airline employes who had. not previously had heart disease, according to two doctors.

title: F.T.C.FRANCH1SE RULE IS ENDORSED BY S.B.A.
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 14 (AP) The Small Business Administration endorsed today the Federal Trade Commission's proposed rule requiring franchisers to provide free financial disclosure to prospective franchisees.

title: Cinemation Plans to Screen Some 16 Films This Year
description: Cinemation Industries, Inc., the locally based, independent film distributing and producing company, will release at least 16 and perhaps 20 feature films this year, which compares favorably with the number of movies distributed annually by the major companies, according to Jerry Gross, president.

title: Douglass Home Dedicated
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 14 (AP) The Washington home of Frederick Douglass, Civil War era campaigner for equal rights, was formally dedicated today as a part of the National Park Service.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: The Roadhogs
description: The Highway Beautification Act of 1965 began the Federal effort to bring billboards under moderate regulation, but progress in the last six years has been painfully slow. There are weaknesses in the law and the highway lobby has exploited them. State governments have been reluctant to comply with Federal regulations. Congress has been derelict in appropriating money.

title: ExSeals Aide Likely to Get Post With Long Island Club
description: William Torrey, the former executive vice president of the California Golden Seals, is expected to be named today to a toplevel position with the new Long Island team of the NaItional Hockey League.

title: Women's Pro Tour Reaches Agreement With U.S.L.T.A.
description: The women's pro tennis tour has settled its differences with the United States Lawn Tennis Association, Mrs. Gladys Heldman of Houston, director of the women's tour, said yesterday.

title: Ford Sets Earnings Mark;
description: DETROIT, Feb. 14The Ford Motor Company today reported record fourthquarter earnings of $204million, or $1.94 a share, up 35 per cent from the yearearlier $151million, or $1.40 a share.

title: Brightening Up Big Board's Block Trading
description: Suppose you work for the New York Stock Exchange and, when you call a block trader for an appointment, he says he's too busy to see you. What do you do?

title: TODD'S DAUGHTER FORCEFED IN JAIL
description: SALISBURY, Rhodesia, Feb, 14  Judith Todd, 29yearold daughter of Garfield Todd, a former Prime Minister, has ended a weeklong hunger strike in prison.

title: LEON J. MORGAN, 71, BROOKLYN LAWYER
description: Leon J. Morgan, senior part, ner in the law firm of Morgan & Marshall, 165 Montague Street, Brooklyn, died Sunday morning at South Nassau Communities Hospital in Oceanside, L. I. He was 71 years old and lived at 61 Park Lane, Rockville Centre, L. 1.

title: Books of The Times
description: DAISY BATES. By Elizabeth Salter. 266 pages. Illustrated. Coward, McCann Se Geoghegan. $6.95.

title: U.S. Trade Center In Mexico Opens
description: MEXICO CITY, Feb. 14As one  machine spewed potato chips into little plastic bags, sealing them, and another nearby rapidly turned cardboard into finished milk cartons, the United States opened its first trade center in Latin America today.

title: CLASS SUIT DENIED ON MASTER CARDS
description: A Federal judge ruled here yesterday that a suit charging Chemical Bank with failure to disclose finance charges on monthly statements of its Master Charge credit card did not qualify as a class action.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Calvin E. Mehlert
description: A 43yearold Californian, called from Saigon, where he serves as a political officer at the United States Embassy, to accompany President to China Greatgrandfather was an officer with the British Pacific Fleet along the China coasts in 1800 In Tientsin as a Marine Corps private first class in 1945 and 1946, helping with repatriation of Japanese soldiers Holds master's degree in Chinese studies from the Johns Hopkins School of Advanced International Studies Served in American Embassy in Taipei, then attended the United States language school at Taichung, Taiwan, learning Mandarin In 1962, served as interpreter at meetings between the United States and Chinese Ambassadors in Warsaw Later worked on Chinese affairs in the State Department and studied Chinese and Vietnamese history

title: For Legal Equality
description: Through the Office of Economic Opportunity's legal services program, some 2,200 attorneys in 900 neighborhood law offices all over the country have enabled large numbers of poor clients to achieve a kind of legal equality with the rest of the citizenry. But because O.E.O. attorneys have had the temerity to challenge Government agencies in court and administrative actions on behalf of indigent clients, neighborhood law programs have often disturbed Government officials.

title: $450,000, A Record, Is Paid for Mare At Widener Auction
description: LEXINGTON, Ky., Feb. 13 (AP)A world record of $450000 was set today in the auction of What A Treat, a thoroughbred broodmare in one of three sales of the horses of the late George D. Widener.

title: BANKERS TRUST CUTS PRIME LENDING RATE
description: The Bankers Trust Company cut its floating prime lending rate to 4 per cent from 4, effective this morning, bringing it into line with the First National City Bank and the Irving Trust Company. Most of the nation's biggest banks have been at the 43 level since midJanuary.

title: BUSING REFERENDUM ADVANCES IN FLORIDA
description: TALLAHASSE, Fla., Feb. 14The Florida Legislature completed action tonight on a bill to set up a straw vote on busing, public prayer and equality of education after the House leadership was defeated in an attempt to remove all reference to busing to achieve racial balance.

title: Lawyer Put on Probation For Assault in Maryland
description: BALTIMORE, Feb. 14Arthur F. Turco Jr., a 29yearold lawyer for leftist organizations who had been charged with assault with intent to murder, pleaded guilty in Baltimore Criminal Court today to the lesser charge of simple assault and was placed on probation for five years.

title: Poor Man Is King on Rio's OnceaYear Day
description: RIO DE JANEIRO, Feb. 14 The deepest drum, as high as a big man's waist, began to pound at 1:45 this morning with a beat that matched the pulse and made the skin tingle.

title: YOUTH FOUND COOL TO CAREER IN F.B.I.
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 14A conservative group that commissioned a study of attitudes among young people toward the Federal Bureau of Investigatlion has found that only 21.5 per cent would like to be an agent of the F.B.I.

title: Best Dressed Lawman Credits It All to Wife
description: At least one man on this year's bestdressed list got there in $90 suits. And his wife thinks that's a stiff price to pay.

title: Most Rev. William Adrian, ExBishop of Tennessee
description: NASHVILLE, Feb. 14 (UPI) The Most Rev. William L. Adrian, Roman Catholic Bishop of Tennessee from 1936 through 1966, died last night at the age of 88.

title: Greek Denies Ouster Plan
description: NICOSIA, Cyprus, Feb. 14Constantine Panayotaltis, the Deputy Foreign Minister of Greece, denied here today that his Government had any plans for the removal of Archbishop Makarios from the presidency of Cyprus violently or otherwise.

title: 65 in St. Olaf Choir Sing Sacred Music Of Several Periods
description: It is rare to find a program of sacred music so intriguing as the one the St. Olaf Choir brought to Philharmonic Hall Sunday evening, and even rarer to find an amateur ensemble with such secure professionalism.

title: Booth in SouthWest Africa To Attend Nonwhites Trial
description: WINDHOEK. South  West Africa, Feb. 14 (UPI)Judge William H. Booth of the Criminal Court of New York City arrived today to represent the International Commission of Jurists at the trial this week of 12 nonwhites charged with illegal strike action in South Africancontrolled SouthWest Africa.

title: News Analysis
description: MOSCOW, Feb. 14  In the seven months since President, Nixon unveiled his surprisingi plan to visit Communist China, the Russians have fashioned a counterstrategy that has substantially enhanced their influence in Asia on the eve of the historic American venture in Peking. In Europe also the normally conservativeminded Kremlin leaders adapted fairly readily to President Nixon's pronouncement that not only Washington and Moscow but Peking, Tokyo and other centers as well should have their say on vital world problems.

title: TWO SITES CHOSEN FOR TITLE CHESS
description: Dr. Max Euwe of the Netherlands, president of the International Chess Federation, announced yesterday that the world championship match in which Bobby Fischer of the United States will oppose the defending champion, Boris Spassky of the Soviet Union, would be played partly In Belgrade, Yugoslavia, and partly in Reykjavik, Iceland.

title: Puerto Ricans Halt Bias Hearing Here
description: Dissident Puerto Rican groups here, shouting and overturning chairs, forced the United States Commission on Civil Rights yesterday to adjourn a hearing on discrimination against Puerto Ricans.

title: Jersey Institutions Workers Call In Sick as a Protest
description: TRENTON, Feb. 14 (UPI)Nonprofessional workers staged sickcall protests today at several state institutions for the mentally ill and retardecL They later threatened to increase the absenteeism unless New Jersey agreed to their contract demands.

title: STEEL PRODUCTION ADVANCES IN WEEK
description: Steel production for the week ended Feb. 12 edged ahead to 2,362,000 net tons, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday. This was an increase of 0.7 per cent from the 2,345,000 tons produced in the preceding week.

title: Rough Outline for Trip Issued by White House
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 14 (UPI)Following is the very rough schedule for President Nixon's visit to China issued by the White House today:

title: Suffer Little Children
description: President Thieu's repressive national police have written another ugly chapter in the annals of Vietnamization with their recent assault on and subsequent dismemberment of an alleged hotbed of antiwar and antiGovernment activitySouth Vietnam's largest orphanage Longthanh Village, near Saigon.

title: Ancient Mass Is Celebrated For the Vietnam War Dead
description: Wearing an embroidered blue 15thcentury vestment, Prof. J. Robert Wright sat at the foot of a catafalque in the Cloisters in Fort Tryon Park yesterday and received, in turn, a figurine, the flags of North and South Vietnam, two bayonets and two caged mourning cloves.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: City Museum Notes Rise in Attendance, Decrease in Deficit
description: The Museum of the City of New York drew a record number of visitors to see a record number of gifts in the year that ended last June 30.

title: Treasury Bill Rates Fall at Weekly Sale
Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: STRENGTH
description: Arica Institute (212) 489.7430. Advt.

title: Hints Came Last Fall
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 14 Specialists here on Rumanian affairs said today that the first indications that General Serb was in disgrace had filtered out of Bucharest last October.

title: Ida Kaminska Stages %liar at Queens College
description: There's one new housing project in Queens that's good news all the waythe project that has found a house for Ida Kaminska and her Yiddish drama troupe at Queens College.

title: Conspiracy Rally Held By Berrigan Backers
description: About 100 persons gathered in a midtown Episcopal church last night for a public conspiracy to kidnap Henry A. Kissinger, the President's national security adviser, to blow up heating tunnels in Washington and to raid Government offices in nine states.

title: DURYEA REJECTS TUITION AT CITY U.
description: ALBANY, Feb. 14Assembly Speaker Perry B. Duryea today ruled out action in this electionyear Legislature on a proposal to impose tuition at the City University.

title: Gould Retires From The Times After 25 YearsinRadioT V Post
description: Jack Gould, radio and television editor and critic for The New York Times for more than 25 years, has retired at his own request. Mr. Gould had asked for and received relief from his duties as a critic last year following an illness but he had continued to cover the field and write news stories and articles. John S. O'Connor succeeded him as critic.

title: EQUITY MIX URGED WITH INSURANCE
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 14 William J. Casey, chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, strongly encouraged the insurance industry today to expand its sales of insurance policies combined with equities.

title: Jonathan Logan
description: Jonathan Logan, Inc., reported net income for 1971 of $17537,000, or $3.49 a share, after including an extraordinary gain of $1,027,000, or 21 cents a share, from, among other things, insurance recovery, the sale of some fixed assets and revaluation of the dollar. Net income in 1970 was $9,425,000, or $2.08 a share, after a loss of $2,205,000 from discontinued operations and extraordiary charges of $2,426,000.

title: Council of Churches Hears Fund Need Perils Ecumenism
description: CHARLOTTE, N. C., Feb. 14 Ecumenism on the local and regional level is fighting for its life, according to a report issued today by a commission of the National Council of Churches.

title: Isherwood Looks At an English Era
description: With me, everything starts with autobiography, Christopher Isherwood, the Englishborn writer and longtime resident of this country, was saying the other day.

title: Stock Splits Are Proposed By a Variety of Companies
description: Stock splits were proposed yesterday by several companies, including American Express, Minnesota Mining St Manufacturing, CocaCola Bottling of Los Angeles and Church's Fried Chicken.

title: Aiken's Home Robbed
description: PUTNEY, Vt., Feb. 14 (AP)Thieves broke into the Vermont home of Senator George W. Aiken, Republican of Vermont, and made off with a television set, a hifi and a quantity of liquor, Windham County sheriff's deputies said Monday.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Strike Against Delayed Until Thursday

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Tourist Clubs Buy Own Planes
description: Special to The New York TimesSEATTLE The lowest priced economyclass roundtrip ticket on a scheduled airline between Seattle and Paris this summer will cost $445. But members of a private association here called Club International will make the trip for only $249  in their own Boeing 707.

title: ALEXANDER H. KING
description: NEW HAVEN, Feb. 14Alexander Henderson King, a retired mechanical engineer and designer for the United Aircraft Corporation, died yesterday here. He was 79 years old and lived in Branford, Conn.

title: At This Grocery and Meat Market, Customers Rarely Quibble About the Price
description: Fred Metsch has become conglomerateur, in a fashion. Not in industry, but in the small grocery and meat market business, which has seen longestablished stores disappear in the city because of demolition, rent increases and other escalating overhead costs.

title: Two U.S. Fighters Remain Unbeaten; Soviet Tour Ends
description: MOSCOW, Feb. 14 (UPI)A Soviet boxing team defeated an American team 52, today at Yerevan, Armenia, during the third and final meeting of the AmericanSoviet tour, Tass, the Soviet news agency, reported.

title: Notes on People
description: There Was high praise In New Haven for Michael Casey, a Vietnam veteran who was named winner of Yale University's 1971 Younger Poets competition. Stanley Kunitz, the Pulitzer Prizewinning poet who judged the competition's 700 entries, said that Mr. Casey 'invented a new poetic idiom out of G. I. lingo, for which he has a matchless ear. He added: This book by an unknown Is the first important work of imagination to come out of the war in Vietnam. Yale will publish the book by Mr. Casey, a 25yearold physicist, in May. It's called Ob

title: OldTimer Suspends Publication
description: The oldest magazine covering the advertising business is suspending publication because of a lack of advertising.

title: ASSEMBLY PASSES SCHOOL BOARD BILL
description: ALBANY, Feb. 14The Assembly gave final passage today to a bill that extends the life of New York City's interim Board of Education for two years.tion of board members from each borough.

title: Economic Analysis
description: AMSTERDAM, the NetherIlandsBarely eight weeks after the Washington currency accord, which President Nixon hailed as the most significant monetary agreement in the history of the world, new strains have appeared in the Western economic alliance.

title: PRISON STABBINGS IN JERSEY RACIAL
description: TRENTON, Feb. 14  The stabbing of seven inmates at the State Prison here over the weekend was attributed today to apparent racial conflict.

title: Bhutto Says He Will Meet Mrs. Gandhi and Mujib
description: KARACHI, Pakistan, Feb. 14 (AP)President Zulf ikar Ali Bhutto of Pakistan announced today that he planned to meet Prime Ministers Indira Gandhi of India and Sheik Mujibur Rahman of Bangladesh shortly.

title: Coast Dock Union Aides Reviewing Pact Accord
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Feb 14 (AP)  Longshoremen's union delegates spent a third day today reviewing terms of a tentative agreement to end the 128day West Coast dock strike.

title: Soviet U.N. Aide Seized on L.I. as Spy
description: A 32yearold Soviet citizen who works as a translator for the United Nations Secretariat was arrested last night on espionage charges outside a restaurant in Patchogue, L. I., according to Robert Morse, the United States Attorney for the Eastern District.

title: BOWIERIEWON BY REM BACK
description: BOWIE, Md., Feb. 14 (UPI)Rockem Back, son of a former Kentucky Derby winner, Carry Back, defeated eight rivals today at Bowie race track to win the $30,450 Vertex Handicap for Marylandbred horses.

title: AIR RAIDS HEAVY ON THE EVE OF TET
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Tuesday, Feb. 15  Heavy American bombing of two enemy base areas along the Laotian and Cambodian borders continued yesterday through the first day of a fourday ceasefire proclaimed by the Communists.

title: Multinational Companies In U. S. Set Job Pace in 60's
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 14 United Statesbased multinational corporations in manufacturing industries increased their domestic employment in the last decade more rapidly than the average for manufacturing as a whole, a survey by the United States Chamber of Commerce showed today.

title: FROST SHOW MOVING TO 11:30 ON WNEW
description: WNEWTV announced yesterday that David Frost would continue on the station after March 13, when Mery Griffin takes over his 8:30 P.M. time slot. A spokesman for Channel 5 said that Mr. Frost would occupy the 11:30 P.M. slot nightly, placing him opposite Johnny Carson on the National Broadcasting Company and Dick Cavett on the American. Broadcasting Company.

title: Attorney General Asks Details Of N.H.L. Business Methods
description: As part of a farreaching investigation into organized hockey, the Antitrust Division of the United States Attorney General's office yesterday demanded that the National Hockey League turn over its records detailing the league's method of operations.

title: Layoffs Due to Power Cut Cripple British Industry
description: LONDON, Feb. 14British industry was severely crippled today when several hundred thousands of workers were suspended from their jobs as Government orders limiting the use of electricity in factories went into effect.

title: Senators Try to Decide if Little Cigars, Growing in Popularity, Are Cigars or Cigarettes
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 14The growing popularity of little cigars that are the same size and shape as cigarettes is generating a new round of debate over smoking and health.

title: KayserRoth Corp.
description: The KayserRoth Corp. ration realized a 14.2 per cent increase in operating earnings on a sales gain of 9.2 per cent in the second fiscal quarter ended Dec. 31 and somewhat smaller gains for the halfyear period, the company reported. Net income, however, was reduced from the yearearlier periods by an extraordinary charge for revaluation or West German currency.

title: BANKER SENTENCED IN MORTGAGE FRAUD
description: Jerome D. Hoffman, 39 years old, an investment banker who admitted one of 32 mailings in an alleged scheme that defrauded 500 mortgage loan applicants of about $1million, was sentenced to two years in prison and fined $1,000 yesterday.

title: SOVIET LINEUP A FACELESS ONE
description: The director of Friday night's United States Olympic invitation track and field meet praised his starting lineup yesterday, but criticized the quality of athletes currently touring the country from the Soviet Union.

title: Motorola Cuts Portable Line
description: CHICAGO, Feb. 14 (AP)Motorola, Inc announced today'it was withdrawing from the portableancltableradio, portabletapeplayer business. The company said the items would no longer be marketed once airrent factory inventories are depleted. Lagging profit returns lwere cited.

title: L.I. Patrolmen Sue For Right to Grow More Hair on Face
description: MINEOLA, L. I., Feb. 14The president of the Nassau County Patrolmen's Benevolent Association filed suit in State Supreme Court today in an attempt to compel the Police Commissioner to permit policemen to wear longer sideburns and to grow beards or goatees.

title: PAUL T. BABSON, 77, A BUSINESS ADVISER
description: BOSTON, Feb. 14Paul Talbot Babson, an investment adviser and publisher who was elected chairman when the Standard & Poor's Corporation was formed in 1941, died yesterday in Sarasota, Fla., where he was spending the winter. He was 77 years old.

title: New Drive Opens To Unseat Crews As Brooklyn Chief
description: A campaign to supplant 78yearold John R. Crews as Republican leader of Kings County was begun last night at the second annual Lincoln Day dinner of the Republicans for Good Government.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: Following is a sampling of letters or excerpts from letters received in response to the Feb. 2 editorial Postal Service.'

title: ROGER W. WILSON OF DRILLING FIRM
description: NEW ORLEANS, Feb. 14Roger William Wilson, who retired recently as president of J. Ray McDermott & Co., Inc., a leading offshore engineering and construction firm, died Saturday after a brief illness. His age was 63.

title: OBSERVER
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 14  Dear Spiro:

title: The Talk of Northbrook, Ill.
description: NORTHBROOK, EL Feb. 14  It was a bright, beautiful day here today, but the sunshine didn't go over too well with some.

title: Wilkins Scores Nixon
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 15Roy Wilkins, executive director of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People, decried yesterday President Nixon's announced intention to offset recent Federal court decisions in favor of school busing.

title: WASHINGTON
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 15  President Nixon is now on the verge of his historic voyage to China, and a lot of serious men are raising some questions about it. Former Under Secretary of State George Bail is saying that summit meetings in general are bad. The President's own former Ambassador to the United Nations, Charles Yost, is saying that summit meetings can be useful, but maybe this one to China will lose more in Japan and Russia than it will gain in Peking.

title: Murdered Woman Was to Be Witness In Narcotics Trial
description: A 28yearold woman who was to have been a key Government witness in a narcotics case was found murdered 12 days agofour days before she was to have testified, an assistant United States Attorney disclosed yesterday.

title: Lansing Quits as Fordham Coach
description: Jim Lansing resigned yesterday as head football coach at Fordham University. He will continue as assistant athletic director, intramural director, and coordinator of the National Summer Youth Sports Program.

title: ENOS F. JONES JR., 75, BOYS CLUB FOUNDER
description: Enos F. Jones Jr., founder of the Paul Revere Boys Club of Jersey City, died on Friday at the Hudson Manor Convalescent Home, North Bergen, N. J. He was 75 years old and lived at 47 Cottage Street, Jersey City.

title: J.CURTIS SANFORD
description: DALLAS. Feb. 15 (UP1)J. Curtis Sanford, Dallas real estate developer and a founder of the Cotton Bowl, died Sunday night while dining at Boca Raton, Ha., restaurant. He was 69 years old.

title: Market Place: Street Studies A Pension Bill
description: Wall Street is just beginning to be aware of an important new legislative proposal that could bring new billions to the financial markets.

title: FRENCH PREMIER DENIES TAX FRAUD
description: PARIS, Feb. 15  Premier Jacques ChabanDelmas, looking grim and drawn, went on nationwide television tonight to counter persistent charges that he had evaded taxes for four years and had hidden his wealth. It was the first time within memory that so high a French official had gone on the air to fight for his political life.

title: Revenues Show Gain
description: The El Paso Natural Gas Cornpany reported yesterday gains in operating revenues and net income for 1971.

title: MITCHELL QUITS; NOMINATION GOES TO KLEINDIENST
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 15Attorney General John N. Mitchell resigned today to direct the President's reelection campaign, and Mr. Nixon immediately nominated Deputy Attorney General Richard G. Kleindienst to succeed him.

title: Ten's a Crowd
description: If any more candidates were entered in Florida's Democratic primary, the ballot would have to come rolled up like a Chinese scroll. The law of that state and seven others now is that a single functionary or a handful them can make official those candidacies that they think, to quote the Florida version, are generally advocated recognized in the news media.

title: STOCKS KEEP SOME OF MORNING GAINS
description: Led by glamour issues, the stock market rebounded with verve in. early trading yesterday, but it gave up many of its best gains near the close.

title: BULLETS CONQUER ROCKETS BY 11398
description: BALTIMORE, Feb. 15 (UPI) Jack Mann scored 39 points tonight as the Baltimore Bullets snapped an eightgame losing streak by downing the Houston Rockets, 11398, in the National Basketball Association. Wes Unseld, the Bullets center, was back in the lineup after missing five games with an ankle injury. The rebounding of Unseld and Gus Johnson moved the Bullets to a 5146 halftime martin that stretched to 8970 after three

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Clarkson Routs Colgate Six
description: HAMILTON, N. Y., Feb. 15 (AP)  Three secondperiod goals by Clarkson broke a 22 tie and paced the Golden Knights to a 83 college hockey victory over Colgate tonight.

title: L.I. Hockey Club Hires ExOakland Aide
description: WESTBURY, L. I., Feb. 15Bill Torrey, who spent six months working for Charles 0. Finley and survived with his sense of humor intact, took on another difficult task today. He was named general manager of Long Island's new National Hockey League team.

title: THE SUPERFECTA IS TOUGH TO BEAT
description: WESTBURY, L. I., Feb. 15  The superfecta, in which the first four finishers must be picked in cbrrect order, appears to be the main attraction for the nightly bettors at Roosevelt Raceway.

title: Shanghai and New York
description: The city, located on a major navigable river on the East Coast, is the country's most important seaport and Its most important center of commerce and industry, contains its tallest buildings and is by far its largest metropolis. The city proper consists of six million people, and the surrounding closelyrelated countryside holds an additional four million. Most of the other people of the province in which the city lies live in rural areas, and are little concerned wih the affairs, problems, or benefits of the city.

title: China: It's the Latest American Thing
description: American interest in China, held back for more than 20 years by mutual isolation, suspicion and animosity, has suddenly surged with the dramatic shift in United StatesChinese relations. The interest in China extends to all things Chinese and involves a whole spectrum of activities, from fashions to food, from travel to trade, and from science to education.

title: Chaps Defeat Squires
description: DALLAS, (AP)Rich. Jones and Lenny Chappell led a fourthquarter rally, pacing the Dallas Chaparrals to a 116111 victory over the Virginia

title: Del Buono, to Replace Arese In 1,500 Meters at Garden
description: Gianni Del Buono of Italy, the winner of the Columbian onemile run here a year ago has been substituted for his teammate, Francesco Arese, European mile champion, in the Olympian 1,500 meters at the Olympic invitation meet in Madison Square Garden Friday.

title: Four Foundations Set Up A Council on Drug Abuse
description: Four private foundations announced yesterday the formation of a national Drug Abuse Council to provide information, program evaluation, researchand independent leadershipin the divided and confused field of drugabuse prevention.

title: Dance: 2 Young, Talented Companies
description: Joffrey II and Harkness Troupes Perform

title: Modified NoFault Car Insurance Bill Given a Shaky Introduction in Albany
description: ALBANY, Feb. 15A controversial modified no fault automobile accident insurance bill was introduced in the Legislature today, and one of its principal sponsors immediately said he would not vote for the measure in its present form.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Soviet Six Routs Poland
description: TOKYO, Feb. 15 (AP)The Soviet ice hockey team, winner of the gold medal at the Sapporo Winter Olympics, routed Poland, 100, in the opening match today of the postOlympic sixnation international tournament. West Germany edged Japan, 54, in the second game.

title: WILLIAM LYNCH; TAUGHT PHYSICS
description: WYNNEWOOD, Pa., Feb. 15 Dr. William A. Lynch, professor of physics emeritus of Fordhatn University, died yesterday in the Fitzgerald Mercy Hospital in Darby after a long illness. He was 79 years old and had been a resident of the Bronx until four months ago, when he moved to the Wynnewood Plaza Apartments in this community.

title: Queen's Cousin Will Wed a Secretary
description: LONDON, Feb. 15Prince Richard of Gloucester, 27yearold cousin of Queen Elizabeth II, will marry a 25yearold Danish secretary, Miss Birgitte van Deuri, this summer.

title: Aaron Levy, Textile Man, Turned to Abstract Painting
description: Aaron J. Levy, who turned to painting in the abstract impressionist style after retiring in 1951 as president of E. Milius & Co., a textile concern, died Monday at his home, 480 Park Avenue. He was 73 years old.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: OTB IS CHANGING COMPUTER SETUP
description: Unable to keep pace with what it calls walltowall horseplayers, the Offtrack Betting Corporation acknowledged yesterday it had begun a major realignment of its computers.

title: Families of the Dead Will Shun Inquiry on Londonderry Killings
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Feb. 15Families of the 13 men killed by British soldiers in Londonderry on Jan. 30 have refused to have anything to do with the Britishappointed inquiry into the deaths. Their decision has destroyed any hope of cooling passions in the grietstricken city.

title: New Connecticut Lottery Starts With Sale of Tickets by Meskill
description: HARTFORD, Feb. 15Gov. Thomas J. Meskill officially opened the $75,000 Connecticut lottery here today by sell= ing $10 worth of tickets to a 78yearold retired baker, who, with his son, had won $11 million in the New York State lottery.

title: Study of Confucius and Mao Replacing FairyTale Chinain U.S. High Schools
description: In the American school curriculum of today, China is no longer limited to a onceoverlightly treatment Involving such obvious and sometimes quaint exotica as silkworms, the Great Wall and peasants wading in rice paddies.

title: .EXMAYOR WAGNER ENDORSES MUSKIE
description: MIAMI, Feb. 15  Mayor Lindsay's predecessor in New York's City Hall declared here today that Senator Edmund S. Muskie of Maine was his choice for the Democratic Presidential nomination.

title: RANGERS VICTORS OVER CANUCKS, 51, AS RATELLE STARS
description: VANCOUVER, British Columbia, Feb. 15  Jean RateIle, the highscoring center of the New York Rangers, took just three shots at Dunc Wilson in the Vancouver Canucks goal tonight. Ratelle shot 1.000, scoring three times in carrying the Rangers to a 54 victory over the twoyearold expansion club in the Pacific Coliseum.

title: Gentry Arrives at Camp
description: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., Feb. 15 (AP)  Tom Seaver is likely to be missing when the New York Mets open spring training for pitchers and catchers tomorrow. The 20game winning righthander has not signed his contract for the 1972 baseball season.

title: China Is Refusing Visas For NonU.S. Newsmen
description: PEKING, Feb. 15 (Agence FrancePresse)China is expected to turn down most of the 1,000 requests for visas by nonAmerican journalists to cover President Nixon's visit.

title: LAIRD SAYS U.S. FACES NEW RACE IN MISSILE SHIPS
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 15Secretary of Defense Melvin R. Laird warned today that unless the Soviet Union agreed to mutual halt in missile submarine construction, or stopped production after catching up with the American lead, the United States was prepared to resume that element of the arms race.

title: I.M.F. Acts on Gold
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 15 (Reu ters)The International Mono tary Fund announced today its decision to redeem, at the re quest of the United States, its special $544million ht United States goldobligation holdings

title: Angkor Clashes Said to Grow; PNOMPENH, Cambodia, Feb. 15 (Agence FrancePresse) clashes between Cambodian and enemy troops near the ancient temple complex of Angkor have grown in violence and frequency in the last two days, Informed sources said today.
description: A 4,000strong enemy force dug into heavily wooded areas west and south of the perimeter wall surrounding the Buddhist shrines are holding off Government units based In the town of Seim Riep, they said.

title: JOE WILLIAMS, 81, SPORTS COLUMNIST
description: Joe Williams, who wrote a provocative and assertive sports column six days a week for 34 years for The New York WorldTelegram & The Sun and its predecessors, died yesterday in. Pine Brook, N. J. He was 81 years old and had retired in 7964.

title: Notes on People
description: In Ohio, Gov. John J. Gilligan is supporting the Democratic Presidential candidacy et Senator Edmund S. Muskie, and heading Mr. Muskie's slate of delegates in the state primary. His son, Donald D. Gilligan, a 24yearold high school English teacher, is supporting the candidacy of former Senator Eugene J. McCarthy and circulating petitions in his behalf. For a time, it appeared there's be some dissension in the Gilligan family because the younger Mr. Gilligan was thinking of running as a McCarthy delegate. I don't plan to run anymore, he said. The whole thing will be misconstrued and blown out of proportion as a contest between my father and me and that wouldn't be the

title: Isidor PaIca, 83, Leader In the Diamond Industry
description: Isidor Palca, a retired diamond merchant who was a founder and for many years a director of the Diamond Dealers Association, died yesterday in Roosevelt Hospital. He was 83 years old and lived at 155 Riverside Drive.

title: AUSTRALIAN YACHT WINS THIRD IN ROW
description: MELBOURNE, Australia, Feb. 15 (AP)Quest III needs only one victory to retain possession of the Little America's Cup, after winning her third race today at Sorrento.

title: Kiddie Parties That Spare the Parents
description: Louis Jennings is not your ordinary Manhattan soda jerk. He drives a dark green Jaguar Mark I. His ice cream concoctions have been consumed by Mrs. Richard M. Nixon, Joan Crawford, Senator Mark Hatfield, Carol Channnig and Joan Sutherland. He is writing an autobiography called The Sex Life of a Calorie.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Karen Phillips,Violist, in a Solo Debut
description: Karen Phillips, a young violist who gave her first New York solo recital Monday night at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, must have been slightly nervous. Although she is an experienced ensemble musician, a solo debut is, after all, a solo debut. But Miss Phillips is one of those fortunate musicians who know how to concentrate their energies and their audience's attention, and she played calmly and introspectively, as If drawing music from some deep inner well of serenity.

title: 71 PaymentsDeficit a Record for U.S. at $29.6Billion
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 15 The Government made official today what had been generally known from private estimates that the United States suffered a massive record deficit of 529.6billion in its balance of international payments last year on one of the four measures currently used.

title: Gibson and Council Compromise On Newark Model Cities Funds
description: NEWARK, Feb. 15Mayor Kenneth Gibson and the City Council publicly ended their feud over the operation of proposed $7million Model Cities program today and pledged a nev. spirit or cooperation that has been missing since the city administration was elected 21 months ago.

title: Floridians Score, 125124
description: DENVER, Feb. 15 (AP)Craig Raymond's short jump shot with 1:01 remaining in overtime gave the Floridians a 125124 victory over the Denver Rockets tonlght.

title: BUSING SUPPORTED BY LABOR COUNCIL
description: BAL HARBOUR, Fla., Feb. 15 The Executive Council of the A.F.L.C.I.O. approved a statement today wholeheartedly supporting the busing of children when it would improve their educational opportunities.

title: D.J., Springer Spaniel, Best at Westminster Second Year in a Row
description: Ch. Chinoe's Adamant James, bought as a birthday present 3 years ago for Dr. Milton E. Prickett of Lexington, Ky., made Westminster Kennel Club history last night when the English springer spaniel was named best of 3,093 dogs at Madison Square Garden.

title: Fletcher Among Four Receiving Fido Awards
description: John A. aAfore Jr., president of the American Kennel Club; Mrs. Julie Gasow of Troy,  Mich., noted judge and English springer spaniel breeder; George Ward of Constantine, Mich a handler, and Walter R. Fletcher, dog writer for The New York Times, were honored by the Gaines Dog Research Center at the Statler Hilton yesterday. Each received a Fido statuette, the Oscar of the dogshow world.

title: ABRAHAM FRIEDMAN
description: Abraham Friedman, a lawyer for many leading composers and conductors of classical arid contemporary music here and abroad, died on Monday while appearing in the Surrogate's Court in White Plains. He was 72 years old and lived at 205 West 57th Street.

title: Peabody Is Rejected
description: HARRISBURG, Pa., Feb. 15 (AP)Endicott Peabody, former Governor of Massachusetts, was turned down today by state officials in his bid to enter Pennsylvania's primary as a VicePresidential candidate.

description: Prices on the American Stock Exchange and on the overthecounter market finished mostly higher yesterday in brisk trading.

description: MIAMI BEACH, Feb. 15 (Reuters)James R. Hoffa, former president of the teamsters union, expressed doubt today that the rankandfile laborer would support the Presidential candidate endorsed by George Meany, president of the American Federation of Labor and Congress of Industrial Organizations.

title: Bridge: 300 Clubs Seek Franchises For League's Charity Game
description: The biggest bridge game ever will be played next month on March 24. With more than a month to go, more than 300 clubs, a record, have applied for franchises to take part in the American Contract Bridge League's nationwide charity game.

title: Warriors Defeat Braves
description: BUFFALO, Feb. 15 (AP) Cazzie Russell's gamehigh 32 points, including a pair of lastminute free throws, enabled the 1Golden State Warriors to withstand a Buffalo rally tonight and beat the Braves, 103100.

title: Increase in January at 0.3%Personal Income Rose
description: WASHINGTON, Feb, 15Industrial production rose threetenths of one per cent in January and still does not show boomlike trend, the Federal Reserve Board disclosed today.

description: To the Editor:

title: Shiebler, Chief of E.C.A.C., To Be Cited at Dinner Here
description: George L. Shiebler, commissioner of the Eastern College Athletic Conference, will be honored at a dinner Tuesday in the Olympia Room of the Royal Manhattan Hotel, on the eve of his retirement. Shiebler has been with the E.C.A.C., largest college conference in the country with 208 members, since 1947 and became its commissioner in 1970.

title: Met Gives Levine New Podium Job
description: James Levine, the 28yearold conductor who made his Metropolitan Opera debut last June, is being named today principal conductor of the company. No conductor in the history of the Met ever has held that title.

title: Laver, Rosewall Win
description: TORONTO, Feb. 15 (UPI)Topseeded Rod Laver and secondseeded Ken Rosewall had little trouble in handling a pair of inexperienced opponents tonight in the first round of a $50,000 tennis tournament.

title: Market Bloc's Steel Output
description: LUXEMBOURG, Feb. 15 (Reuters)Common Market crude steel production reached 8.6 billion tons last month, according to figures released today by the European Economic Community statistical office. This compared with 7.7 billion tons in December and 8.9 billion tons in January, 1971.

title: Fanny May in First Auction On Conventional Mortgages
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 15The Federal National Mortgage Association issued today commitments to buy $34.9million of mortgages in its first auction involving conventional mortgages.

title: Exclusive Coast Club Spurs Gilts 0f Millions for Nixon and G.O.P.
description: NEWPORT BEACH, Calif., Feb. 15One of the most bountiful but least known sources of big campaign money for President Nixon is an exclusive club of California businessmen who like to boast that, without their efforts and generosity, he would not be occupying the White House today.

title: Soviet Attacks U.S. Plan For Navy Facility in Greece
description: MOSCOW, Feb. 15The Sovlet Government said today that a United States decision to establish a naval base in Greece tended to aggravate tensions in Europe and might prompt a Russian countermove in the Mediterranean Sea.

title: News Analysis
description: LONDON, Feb. 15Thousands of miners marched outside Westminster Palace today to let the members of Parliament inside know the strength of their feelings about the coal strike. Judg ing by their shouts, the bitterness was aimed mainly at one man: Edward Heath.

title: Cougars Down Condors
description: FAYETTEVILLE, N. C., Feb. 15 (AP)The Carolina Cougars rallied from 17 points down in the first half to defeat the Pittsburgh Condors, tonight. 126113.

title: Taxi Strike Closes Two More Garages
description: A wildcat strike by taxi drivers protesting a labor contract negotiated 14 months ago  but never ratified  spread to two more garages yesterday. As a result, the job action has now idled about 10 per cent of the city's 6,800 fleet. owned cabs, but has not affected 5,000 driverowned cabs. The Metropolitan Taxicab Board of Trade, an association of taxifleet owners, said that since the walkout began Friday a total of five of the city's 68 fleet garages had been shut down.

title: BOSTON COLLEGE UPSETS ST. JOHN'
description: NEWTON, Mass., Feb. 15 Boston College didn't take the lead until three minutes remained in tonight's game with St. John's, but once the Eagles did, they held on and upset the Redmen, 7066, before 3,000 at Roberts Center.

title: WARRANT ISSUED FOR MRS. IRVING
description: At the request of the Swiss Government, an arrest warrant for Edith Irving, wife of Clifford Irving, the author, was issued in Federal Court in Manhattan yesterday by a United States magistrate.

title: BUTZ DOUBTS GAINS ON IMPORTED MEAT

Part of the problem is technical, mired in poor sound reproduction and unimaginative visual direction. Part is practical, stemming from the dubious programing theory that the mass public is not all that interested in good music and dance.

title: Economic Analysis; A New Marco Polo?; Economic Rewards of President's Trip To China Are Hazy at This Juncture
description: From hi g throne in Peking, the Great Khan asked Marco Polo's father, Nicolo, and his uncle, Maffeo, to bring him back 100 learned men and some oil from the lamp that burned in the Holy Sepulcher in Jerusalem. But when the Polos returned to the court of Kublai Khan, all they had were two Dominican priests, the holy oil, and young Marco Polo. Yet Marco delighted the Great Khan because he was very clever and had mastered the Tartar language. Seven centuries later, President Nixon is completing preparations for his first voyage to China.

title: Hexachlorophene Dilemma
description: The current furor over staphylococcal infections newborn babies in about two dozen hospitals provides a poignant example of the dilemmas increasingly plaguing modern man. In this case the problem revolves about the germicidal chemical hexachlorophene, but similar dilemmas abound regarding substances ranging from D.D.T. to saccharine.

The Virginiaborn artist, who Is a guilliard School alumnus and a teacher at Northern Illinois University, was making his debut here, and he played with the technical control and musical sophistication that is pervasive among young American pianists today.

title: Sports of The Times
description: The swiftest Greek in 27 centuries and the highest Greek in all eternity are appearing this week in New York, where there are more Greeks than in Sparta, Olympia and Marathon put together. They are here to attain such speed and altitude as they are able to in Friday night's Olympic Invitation track and field meet in Madison Square Garden. There is a nice literary justice here, for the Olympic Games are a Greek invention and the motto of the quadrennial muscle dance is Citius, Altius, Fortius, which translates roughly as Swifter, Higher, Stronger. Among the visiting Greeks, Papa George is swiftest and Papa Nick is highest. Papa George's square name is Vassillios Papageorgopoulos and he holds the Greek record of 10.1 seconds for running 100 meters. Now. as all school children know, the first Olympic event ever contested was a sprint won by a hometown boy named Coroebus in a meadow beside the river Alpheus at Olympia in Elis at the time or the full moon in the month Apollonius in 776 B.C.

description: INDIANAPOLIS, Feb. 15 (UPI) Field goals by Jim O'Brien and Artis Gilmore helped the Kentucky Colonels beat the Indiana Pacers, 10199, in an American Basketball Association game tonight.The Pacers raced to an 8175 lead in the third period but Kentucky reeled off 11 straight points to open the final session and took an 8681 lead.Indiana came back to tie, 9696, but O'Brien got a field goal and Gilmore sank a jump shot for a 10097 lead after Rick Mount had dropped in a free toss for the Pacers.Billy Keller scored on a layup to trim the margin to a point with 30 seconds left but the Pacers couldn't tally again. Mike Gale sank a free throw with 4 seconds left, ending the action.

title: Brando Stars in 'Nightcomers' on Baronet Screen
description: Although "The Nightcomers" makes no attempt to re-create the style and the feeling of "The Turn of the Screw" (which may be the nicest thing one can say about it), Michael Winner, who directed the film, and Michael Hastings, who wrote the original screenplay, have not hesitated to ransack the Henry James novella for everything they could carry off in a thin, small notebookthe names of characters, the outline of incidents and the description of architecture.The movie, which is quite bad under any circumstances, thus qualifies as a particularly listless and greedy parody, the sort that makes no coherent comment on the work it so freely exploits.If "The Nightcomers" were just a little more broad, it would also qualify as another example of the kind of middle Gothic comedy turned out by Hammer Films, the company that improvises mostly on Bram Stoker and Mary Wollstonecroft Shelley."The Nightcomers," which opened yesterday at the Baronet Theater, insists on telling us everything we never wanted to know about the events that occurred before those in "The Turn of The Screw" (filmed as "The Innocents" by Jack Clayton in 1951). That is, how Flora and Miles, the beautiful orphans whose possession is not of the self, came to be besieged by the ghosts of Quint, the defrocked valets, and Miss Jessel, their former governess, and especially how Quint and Miss Jessel came to be ghosts in what I suppose you would call the last place.Actually, had the film made no call on "The Turn of the Screw," and were the talents of Mr. Winner and Mr. Hastings somewhat less lumpy, "The Nightcomers" might have been a rather interesting movie, if only for the performance of Marlon Brando, which is, in a phrase James used, "a succession of flights and drops."There are times when this still extraordinary actor, as Quint, seems to be in another film entirely, looking like a slightly mad Ben Franklin, and then there are small, beautiful moments when Brando's intelligence creates a truly complex character. I think immediately of a short scene in which the unlaundered Quint, the terrifying idol of Flora and Miles, enchants them with the tale of how his father once sold an old nag by pasting rabbit fur over the horses' bald spots and inserting a piece of ginger in a sensitive orifice.Such moments, however, are few, since it is Mr. Hasting's idea that Flora and Miles were corrupted by their isolation in old Bly house with the ignorant Quint and the fearful Miss Jessel, whom Quint liked to tie up and beat as part of their guilt-ridden love-making. Where "The Turn of the Screw" deals in the supernatural, "The Nightcomers" trafficks in dippy Freud. As the producer's synopsis points out: "Quint loves as he can, mingling pain with secrecy."In addition to Brando, there are several other small, unredeeming pleasuresVerna Harvey and Christopher Ellis, who are properly placid and pretty as the children, and the handsome old countryhouse, in Cambridge-shire (according to the credits) where most of the movie was shot. Shot is not quite the right word, perhaps. Because of Mr. Winner's fondness for fast zooms into particular objects, I had the curious feeling that the movie was more or less fallen into, horizontally.
