description: MILWAUKEE, Feb. 16 (AP)Secondranked Marquette dissipated a 13point firsthalf lead tonight, then stormed back to beat Jacksonville, 8879, for its 21st victory of the season without defeat.

title: Ringling Complex Due Close to Disney World
description: ORLANDO, Fla., Feb. 16 (AP)Ringling Brothers and Barnum & Bailey Circus plans to open a $50million, yearround amusement complex just 10 miles southwest of Disney World, sources said today.

title: Market Place: Wisest Advice, So He Thought
description: What kind of broker do you want? Well, we talked to a couple of them recently. You may remember that one of them took the don't call us, we'll call you point of view, while the other said he wanted to talk to his customers to make sure he didn't put them into water so deep they wouldn't be able to sleep nights.

title: flues Down Kings, 31
description: INGLEWOOD, Calif., Feb. 16 (UPI)Garry Unger scored from 25 feet out with 13:43 remaining and Gary Sabourin added an insurance goal as the St. Louis Blues defeated the Los Angeles Kings, 31, tonight to move into a tie for third place in the National Hockey League West.

title: WASHINGTON
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 17Just before President Nixon left here for Chinn, Admiral Thomas H. Moorer, the chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, told the Congress that, regardless of how U.S.SovietChina relations may develop in the future, the United States must alwaym retain enough nuclear power to cope with both the Soviet Union and China simultaneously.

title: 3,300 Autos Driven To Capital in Protest
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 17A motorcade of about 3,300 automobiles streamed from Richmond to Washington and back today as their white drivers and passengers showed support for legislation or a constitutional amendment to prohibit the busing of children outside their present school districts.

title: ROLE IS DEFENDED BY RINKEISITAUS
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 17William D. Ruckelshaus, administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency, vehemently denied today that the Office of Management and Budget had usurped his decisionmaking powers.

title: Murphy Asks for Federal Help In Hunt for Policemen's Killers
description: Police Commissioner Patrick V. Murphy appealed yesterday to the President, the United States Attorney General and the Federal Bureau of Investigation to give the highest priority to the hunt for the men wanted for the murders of Patrolmen Gregory Foster and Rocco Laurie.

title: Beame Protests Rating of Bonds
description: Controller Abraham D. Beanie of New York City urged yesterday that bond rating agencies be placed under Federal supervision and regulation.

title: Pentagon Aide Says Soviet Has the Edge In Several Weapons
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 The Pentagon's chief scientist said today that the United States, which has long enjoyed a technological edge over the Soviet Union in weapons systems, has now fallen behind in several instances.

title: Mac Kinsbruner, Star Athlete At St. John's in 1930's, Dead
description: KIAMESHA LAKE, N. Y., Feb. 17Mac Kinsbruner, member of St. John's University Wonder Five in the nineteenthirties and resident manager of the Concord Hotel here, for 23 years, died of a heart attack yesterday in Community General Hospital. His age was 63.

title: EIS CASE RESTS ON KOOSMAN'S ARM
description: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., Feb. 17Now that Tom Seaver's salary has been settled and Tug McGraw's mustache shaved, the New York Mets bore down today on the really burning issue of spring training: Can Jerry Koosman regain his stuff and help pitch the Mets back to the top?

title: Back on the Line
description: The sevenmonth strike of New York telephone installers and repairmen has endedpredictablyon terms that represent only a nominal improvement over those originally available to the 38,000 strikers.

title: Ginzburg Begins 3Year Term For 1963 Obscenity Conviction
description: LEWISBURG, Pa., Feb. 17 Ralph Ginzburg, the publisher, went to prison today, 10 years after he distributed a shortlived quarterly magazine called Eros that emphasized sex.

title: 2 Reputed Maliosi Among 8 Seized Herein Loan Frauds
description: Eight men, ln,cluding two reputed Mafia members and three officials ef the Italian:American Civil Rights League, were arrested yesterday by Federal Bureau of Investigation agents for allegedly giving false information last, year to obtain loans from the Kings Lafayette Bank in Brooklyn.

title: Quiet Seems to Prevail At Truce Line in Punjab
description: SHAKARGARK, Pakistan, Feb. 13  There is a barricade on the dirt road at the eastern edge of this town that stops truck drivers from unknowingly rolling into a field of land mines 500 yards beyond in the driedup bed of a torrential stream.

title: Lost in the Stars Will Be Here in April
description: The Maxwell Anderson and Kurt Weill musical Lost in the Stars, which is based on Alan Paton's novel, Cry, the Beloved Country, will come to Broadway in April after, a limited run at the Opera House of the Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts in Washington.

title: Rites for George Benrieyan
description: A memorial service for George Benneyan, a newspaper and magazine promotion executive for 40 years until his retirement in 1960, will be held at the Church in the Highlands, White Plains, on Sunday, Feb. 27, at 3 P.M. Mr. 13enneyan died on Feb. 4 at the age of 77.

title: Laos Refugees Keep U.S. Aides Busy
description: VANG VIENG, Laos, Feb. 11  Barney Chessin, a communitydevelopment adviser employed by the United States Agency for International Development, does not think that Laos is much of a place for community development because of the Vietnam war.

title: FastMail Routes Added
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 (AP) The United States Postal Service said today that it would add 28 routes to its new preferential road and rail network being developed to speed surface mail across the nation.

title: AvantGarde Cartoons at the Whitney
description: The program for the Whitney Museum's new animation film festival notes that unlike the traditional cartoons made for mass audience appeal and usually comic effect these films are more an intimate view of the filmmaker's inner dreams, fantasies and nightmares.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Housing Patrolman Fights Ruling on Sick Leave

title: New Military Junta in Ecuador Bars Arrests in Drive for Unity
description: QUITO, Ecuador, Feb. 17 (UPI)A new military junta promised today that there would be no political reprisals or arrests following a nonviolent coup against President Jose M. Velasco lbarra.

title: MRS. F. D. LASCOFF
description: Mrs. Emma Meyer Lascoff, the widow of Dr. Frederick D. Lascoff, who operated the J. Leon Lascoff & Son Apothecary at 1209 Lexington Avenue, at 82d Street, died yesterday at her home, 125 East 72d Street.

title: Aborting Abortions
description: The New York Court of Appeals, in a decision that defies logic and undermines human rights, has ruled by a fourtothree margin that Medicaid funds cannot be used to pay for elective abortions. The effect Of this decision is to deny the poor the equal protection of the laws to which they are clearly entitled.

title: Kepler's Odd Genius Intrigues Scholars
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Feb. 17  Every time a spacecraft is lifted into orbit around the earth or moon, it travels an oval shaped path A; ailed a Replerian ellipse. This elementary fact is testimony to the durability of the Jaws of planetary motion formulated over three centuries ago by the great but rather strange German astronomer named Johannes Kepler.

title: 6 Charged With Defrauding 25 Banks of 614.5Million
description: CHICAGO, Feb. 17 (UPI)Six men, including four former officials of a nowbankrupt auto financing concern, were indicted today on charges of defrauding more than 25 banks and lending institutions of 514.5million.

title: Paris Police Recover Stolen Picasso Painting
description: PARIS, Feb. 17 (Reuters) The police said today they had recovered the Picasso painting Harlequin's Head, valued at $286,000 which was stolen from a Paris art gallery in November.

title: Chamberlain Shrugs Off 30,000th
description: LOS ANGELES, Feb. 17No big deal, said Wilt Chamberlain of the Los Angeles Lakers after scoring the 30,000th point of his 13season National Basketball Association career.

title: Store Sales Increase
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 17The Commerce Department today estimated last week's department store sales at $633million, up 7 per cent from the yearearlier $593million. Last week's total retail store sales were about $7,213,000,000, iv: 4 per cent from $6,933,000.000.

title: Advertising:
description: I want to run my own company, said M. Carl Johnson Jr. and he wasn't the first adman to say it. Well he's going to do it, too.

title: 3 PITCHERS SIGN YANK CONTRACTS
description: Three pitchers, Mel Stottlemyre, Fritz Peterson and Jim Magnuson, signed their 1972 New York Yankee contracts yesterday, bringing the total number of players in the team's fold to 26 of 39.

title: American Standard Shifts Land and Shelter Units
description: American Standard, Inc., has reorganized its land and shelter operations, which last year sustained both operating and extraordinary losses. Full year figures for the company and the subsidiary have not yet been reported.

title: ABM COMPROMISE WITH SOVIET SEEN
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 17The first phase of the talks on limitation of strategic arms is expected to end in May, with a treaty allowing both the United States and the Soviet Union to deploy 150 to 200 defensive missiles anywhere on their territories.

title: Strong Advance in the 2d Half of 1971 Puts Profit Ahead 4%
description: The Eastman Kodak Company posted record results for last year and the fourth quarter buoyed by a strong recovery in the second half of 1971, according to the annual report yesterday from Rochester headquarters.

title: Dilts Awaits Bid by Cahill to Resume Job
description: HACKENSACK, N. J., Feb. 17  Robert Dilts, who was acquitted in Superior Court here yesterday on charges of conspiracy, bribery, obstructing justice and misconduct in office, waited in vain today for word from Gov. William T. Cahill that he had been restored to duty as Bergen County Prosecutor.

title: FREDERIC JAY WELLS
description: OLD SAYBROOK, Coma, Feb. 17Frederic Jay Wells, a retired Navy officer and business executive, died today of heart complications in Lawrence Memorial Hospital, &ew London. He was 71 years old and lived on Outer Cove.

title: U.S. Grand Jury Date for Irvings Put Off
description: Assistant United States Attorney John T. Tigue Jr. met for nearly two hours yesterday in the Federal Court House at Foley Square with lawyers for the author, Clifford Irving, and his wife, Edith.

title: Monday a Postal Holiday
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 (AP) The nation's post offices will operate on a holiday schedule on observance of Washington's Birthday next Monday

title: College Football Hall of Fame Elects 10
description: NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., Feb. 17 (AP)Angelo Bertelli, Notre Dame quarterback, and the late Bruce Smith, Minnesota halfback, both Heisman Trophy winners, were among 10 former college stars named today to the National Football Foundation's college Hall of Fame.

title: Suspect Killed by Companion
description: ST. LOUIS, Feb. 17Ronald Carter, a suspect in the slaying of two New York City policemen, was killed by a bullet fired by one of three men he was riding with Tuesday night, and not by the police, according to a ballistics test.

title: N.Y.U. Students Protest
description: More than 700 students demonstrated yesterday on the New York University Heights campus in the Bronx against a proposal to sell the campus to the state, to provide financial relief for the school. Dr. James M. Hester, the school's president, has backed a suggestion made by a special state commission on higher education that the Bronx campus be acquired by the State University.

title: Miss Stove Upsets Mrs. King
description: OKLAHOMA CITY, Feb. 17 (UPI)Betty Stove of the Netherlands upset topseeded Mrs. Billie Jean King, 63, 76, in the semifinal round of the $20,000 Virginia Slims invitation tennis tournament today.

title: Italian Newsman Set Free After 6 Weeks in Czech Jail
description: ROME, Feb. 17  Valerie Ochetto, a 41yearold Italian newsman, returned home today after six weeks in a Czechoslovak prison on subversion charges.

title: Wood, Field and Stream Enchanting Everglades
description: FLAMINGO, Fla.One must savor Florida's Everglades as one does the nuances of a fine wine.

title: Music: A Wolpe Tribute
description: That there happened to be good music at the Stefan Wolpe retrospective concert at Columbia University's McMillin Theater Wednesday night turned out to be almost unnecessary, though welcome. The program was presented by the Performers Committee for 20th.Century Music as a kind of avantgarde birthday offering to the composer (he wia be 70 on Aug. 25) and brought out a sizable audience of his admirers. They applauded Mr. Wolpe so much and so warmly that one might have thought he was someone as important as an opera singer.

title: MANY CAUTIONS ON DOCK STRIKES
description: BAL HARBOUR, Fla., Feb. 17 George Meany, president of the American Federation of Labor and Congress of Industrial Organizations, criticized the Pay Board today and warned of the possibility of new dock strikes if recently negotiated East and West Coast settlements were trimmed by the board.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
description: Committee on Elimination of Racial Discrimination 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: Canada Says She Will Seek Improved Trade Relations With U.S.
description: OTTAWA, Feb. 17  The Canadian Government announced its intention today to press for improved trade relations with the United States, the nation's best trading partner.

title: Tokyo Stooks Set High
description: TOKYO, Feb. 17 (Reuters)Prices on the Tokyo Stock Exchange closed today at a record, following active buying. The average rose 25.15 to 2,913.81, compared with 24O.69 on Dec. 18,

title: The President's Departure Statement
description: Following is a transcript of President Nixon's departure statement, made on the South Lawn of the White House before he left for China, as recorded by The New York Times:

title: FRANCIS ZETTERBERO
description: PALO ALTO, Calif., Feb. 17 (AP)Francis Zetterberg, sports and political cartoonist for 50 years, died Tuesday night at Veterans Hospital. He was 75 years old.

title: Mr. Nixon's Attorney General
description: Attorney General John N. Mitchell is returning to the post from vvhich he catne and which, spiritually, he has never left: campaign manager for Richard M. Nixon. This is a post for which Mr. Mitchell is infinitely better qualified than the one he has held during the last three years.

title: Cost of Living Panel to Disclose Data on Complainant's Request
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 The Cost of Living Council ruled today that anyone who complained about a possible violation of wage or price controls must be informed about action taken on his complaint.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: Financing Housing

title: Gap Widens in Equal Pay
description: Women today earn not only less than men, for the most part, but the differences in earnings are greater now than in the midnineteen fifties, long before the advent of the women's liberation movement.

title: Belmonte Just Misses 6Victory Day at Races
description: ARCADIA, Calif., Feb. 17 (UPI)Eddie Belmonte rode five winners today at Santa Anita but missed by a head making it six in the $35,050 Santa Catalina Stakes for 3yearolds.

title: ECONOMIC MOVES HELD TOO STRONG
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 17  A majority of economic consultants to the Business Council expressed strong concern today that the Government's fiscal and monetary stimulus for the economy was too strong and could mean more rapid inflation later this year and in 1973.

title: 2 Mush Oxen Are Going To China as Nixon Gifts
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 17Among the gifts that President Nixon will be taking on his trip to China are two musk oxen.

title: 9 Sailors Who Quit Sanotury Put on VietnamBound Ship
description: SAN DIEGO, Feb. 17 (AP) Nine young sailors who refused to leave for Vietnam with their ships were taken into custody today and flown by helicopter to the carrier Kitty Hawk at sea.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: COLORISTIC VARIETY BY DAVIS ON VIOLIN
description: Beethoven's Kreutzer Sonata is one of the touchstones of the violinist's repertory and if David Davis has not yet fathomed all the music's potential, he gave the work a solid technical and musical representation Wednesday night in Tully Hall.

title: Official Silence in Israel
description: TEL AVIV, Feb. 17Responsible Israelis in the military establishment and the Foreign Ministry said tonight that they know nothing of President Sadat's charge that Israeli agents had been involved in the Cairo disturbances.

title: A Speedier Dispatch System For Ambulances Set for March
description: I The Health and Hospitals Corporation announced yesterday that it would start a speedier ambulance dispatching system next month by eliminating unnecessary runs.

title: PRESIDENT LEAVES ON TRIP TO CHINA; STOPS IN HAWAII
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 17President Nixon left for China today.

title: Soviet Agrees to New Talks On LendLease Debt of 45
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 17The State Department said today that the Soviet Union had agreed to reopen talks on settling its multimilliondollar'debt for lendlease aid during World War II.

title: ORANTES UPSETS RICHEY BY 61, 64
description: SALISBURY, Mcl., Feb. 17 (AP)  Manuel Orantes upset sscondseeded Cliff Richey today in the fourth round of the $55,000 national indoor tennis tournament.

title: Woman Gets Justice Post
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 (UPI) Attorney General John N. Mitchell announced the appointment today of Mary CecilIan Lawton as a Deputy Assistant Attorney General Miss Lawton, 36 years old, will become the No. 2 official in the Justice Department's Office of Legal Counsel.

title: Woman Nominated to A.T.&T. Board
description: The world's largest stockholder family will get a chance on April 19 to elect a hanker from Milwaukee as the first woman on the board of directors of the giant American Telephone and Telegraph Company. She is Catherine B. Cleary, president and a director of the First Wisconsin Trust Company.

title: U. S. Ends Its SteppedUp Raids on North
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Friday, Feb. 18 One hundred twenty five American warplanes, flying through a barrage of surfacetoair missiles and antiaircraft fire, completed a 29hour series of attacks on artillery and air defense sites in and just north of the demilitarized zone yesterday, the United, States command announced.

title: Winter Storm Watch Is Issued lor Tonight
description: The National Weather Service yesterday issued a winter storm watch for the metropolitan area for tonight, the start of the threeday George Washington's Birthday holiday weekend.

title: Soviet Employe at the U.N. Indicted on Spy Charges
description: A twocount indictment against a Soviet United Nations employe accused of espionage was handed up yesterday by Federal grand jury in Brooklyn.

title: DOLLAR DECLINES TOR A SECOND DAY
description: PARIS, Feb. 17The dollar was pummeled for the second consecutive day in the major money centers as the United States came under renewed criticism for not giving sufficient consideration to foreign interests in the delicate transitional phase of monetary alignment.

title: CAIRO LAYS UNREST TO ISRAELI AGENTS
description: CAIRO, Feb. 17President Anwar elSadat charged today that Israeli intelligence agents were involved in student demonstrations that erupted in Cairo universities last month.

title: Soviet Endorses U.S.China Reconciliation if It Is Not Directed Against Russians
description: MOSCOW, Feb. 17As President Nixon left on his journey to Peking today, the Soviet Union affirmed that it viewed a reconciliation between the United States and China as natural development as long as it was not directed against the Russians own interests.

title: VW Claims Production Record, But Ford Spokesman Disputes It
description: BONN, Feb. 17The Volkswagen Company today set what it believes to be a world record in automobile production for a single model.

title: No Fault Plan Faces Attack in Senate
description: ALBANY, Feb. 17An influI ential Republican Senator disclosed today that he was preparing, with the approval of his majority leader, a major legislative attack on the modified no fault automobileaccident insurance plan that is supported by Governor Rockefeller.

title: 2 G.I.'s Killed in Week
description: SAIGON, Feb. 17 (UPI)Two American soldiers were killed in action last week, bringing to 21 the number of United States combat deaths in Indochina this year, the United States command reported today.

title: Proxmire Scores Navy Claims Payment
description: Senator William Proxmire said yesterday that he was asking the General Accounting Office to determine the legality of provisional payments on contractor cost claims such as the $48.5million in payments the Navy has agreed to make to a Louisiana shipyard.

title: Man in the News
description: NICOSIA, Cyprus, Feb. 17 Scrawled on the stone wall of the refectory at the medieval Kykko Monastary, one of the great mystical sites of the Orthodox world, is the scribble of a schoolboy, the words Zeto I Ennis, Long Live Enosis.

title: BLACK SCHOOL BAN IN CAROLINA UPHELD
description: RICHMOND, Feb. 17 (AP)The United States Court of Appeals for the Fourth Circuit upheld today.a modification of the school desegregation plan for the current school year in CharlotteMecklenburg County, N. C.

title: Agnes Blanch Noyes Dies; A Painter of WaterColors
description: Mrs. Agnes Blancke Noyes, an artist and wife of Jansen Noyes, a founding partner of Hornblower & WeeksHemphill Noyes, the brokerage house, died Wednesday in Palm Beach, Fla., after a long illness. She lived in Montclair, N. J., and Fishers Island, N. Y.

title: M'DANIELS SIGNED BY N.B.A:S SONICS
description: SEATTLE, Feb. 17 (AP)The Seattle SuperSonics of the National Basketball Association today signed Jim McDaniels to a sixyear contract, but a spokesman for the team McDaniels left said he wouldn't be too surprised if we remedied the situation.

title: 58% Back Muskie in New Hampshire Poll
description: MANCHESTER, N. H., Feb. 17  A poll conducted by the New Hampshire Public Television Network shows Senator Edmund S. Muskie of Maine with a commanding lead over his opponents in the March Democratic Presidential primary.

title: Hughes Shows Up In Nicaragua Hotel After Secret Trip
description: Howard R. Hughes, caught between political factions in Nassau, the Bahamas, moved to a hotel in Managua, Nicaragua, yesterday.

title: Garden Echoes With 18 Rah, Rah, Rahs for Tradition
description: Sexist exploitation? asked Mary Scarborough of Western Kentucky University, twirling her vinyl pompon. What in the world are they talking about?

title: ROUSE OF COMMONS NARROWLY BACKS ENTRY IN MARKET
description: LONDON, Feb. 17By a margin of only eight votes, 309 to 301, the House of Commons tonight approved in principle legislation to take Britain into the European Economic Community.

title: Hassler Killed at Daytona In Crash Involving 12 Cars
description: DAYTONA BEACH, Fla., Feb. 17Friday Hassler, a 36yearold race driver from Chattanooga, was killed instantly today in a tangled 12car pileup during a 125mile stock car race on the 2.5mile trioval of Daytona International Speedway.

title: But Don't Bet on It
description: As one of several critics of the American railroad system, we confess to being overwhelmed at the response Amtrak has been making on Its Gambling Special from Los Angeles to Las Vegas. Where we chronic complainers asked only for occasionally dusted cars, seats for all who paid for them and perhaps approximate schedules, the Gambling Special is not only clean, airconditioned and equipped with usable plumbing but festooned into the bargain with balloons and paper streamers.

title: Aston Martin Acquired
description: LONDON, Feb. 17 (Reuters) Aston Martin Lagonda, makers of sports cars, has been acquired by Company Developments, a firm of investment bankers, it was announced today.

title: Food Both Sublime and Substandard
description: Restaurants reviewed on this page on Friday are rated both for their food (four stars to none) and for their atmosphere, service and &col. (four triangles to none).

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: A LastMinute Addition: First Lady's Beautician
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 The White House announced a lastminute addition to the official party accompanying the President and Mrs. Nixort to China as the farewell ceremonies were in progresa today. The addition is Mrs. Nixon's hairdresser, Mrs. Rita Desantis.

title: RANGERS TRIUMPH OVER KINGS BY 64
description: LOS ANGELES, Feb. 17It's been almost total frustration this season for the Los Angeles Kings. Tonight in the Forum, the Rangers beat them, 64, for the sixth time this season.

title: Baked Red Snapper With Oriental Touch
description: In the menus below, the dishes marked with an asterisk are followed by a recipe. Mussels ravigote Baked red snapper, Oriental style* Snow peas Rice Spanish melon with freshly grated coconut BAKED RED SNAPPER, ORIENTAL STYLE

title: Albany Session Labeled Do Nothing
description: ALBANY, Feb. 17  Democratic leaders today labeled the curreht session of the Legislature as a donothing session and charged the Republican majority with ignoring the problems in the state.

title: SOYBEAN FUTURES IN HEAVY DEMAND
description: There was new buying in the soybean futures complex on the Chicago Board of Trade yesterday n the belief of traders that soybeans anti soybean oil woutri make up a major part of the United States food and grain contribution to Bangladesh.

title: Egypt Said to Oust Russian Over Slur to Armed Forces
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Feb. 17 (UPI)  Travelers from Cairo said yesterday that Egypt had expelled the chief Soviet military adviser to the Egyptian Minister of War, Gen. Mohamrned Sadek, for criticizing Egyptian armed forces.

title: State Officials Not Covered By Job Bias Bill in Senate
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 (AP) The Senate voted today to exempt state and local elected officials and their personal assistants and immediate advisers from a Federal ban on discrimination in employment.

title: SMITH SAYS TODDS WILL GET A REVIEW
description: SALISBURY, Rhodesia, Feb. 17 (Reuters)  Prime Minister Ian D. Smith of Rhodesia said today that Garfield Todd and his daughter Judith, who have been detained without trial since Jan. 18, would be brought before a judicial review tribunal.

title: Iraqi Group Ends Soviet Visit; Receives Promise of More Aid
description: MOSCOW, Feb. 17A highlevel Iraqi delegation ended a weeklong visit to Moscow today with promises of more economic and military aid from the Soviet Union and an agreement calling for the development of ties at the party level.

title: FOREIGN AFFAIRS
description: NEW DELHIShortly after his emperor had brought in Czarist Russian troops to put down a revolt in Hungary, the Austrian Chancellor, Prince Schwarzenberg, was asked if this did not impose upon the Viennese regime tin intolerable debt of thanks to Russia. The bounds of my ingratitude will be limitless, replied the Chancellor. He proved this so well that a famous Square in the capital was named Schwarzenberg Platz.

title: Ford Disputes Claim
description: DETROIT, Feb. 17 (UPI) A Ford historian Leslie Henry, disputed the Volkswagon claim today.

title: Dr. Boris G. Yegorov, 79, Soviet Neurosurgeon, Dies
description: MOSCOW, Feb. 17 (AP)Boris Grigoryevich Yegorov, Soviet brain and neurosurgeon and father of a Soviet cosmonaut, has died at the age of 79, Izvestia, the Government news. paper, reported today.

title: Morocco's Ruler Agrees To Give Up Some Powers
description: RABAT, Morocco, Feb. 17 King Hassan II moved to save his throne tonight by agreeing to yield some of his power to a new government and parliament under Morocco's third Constitution in nine years.

title: Wednesday's Fights
description: New York (Sunnyside Garden)  Diego Alcala, 136 pounds, Panama, knocked out Alfredo Escalera, 140, Puerto Rico, 8 rounds; Juan Ruiz 151, Panama, outpolnted Carlos Cells, 156, Mexico City, 10.

title: LOVE
description: Arica Institute (212) 48974.10 ADVT.

title: News of Skiing
description: Thanks to snowmaking machines, Williams College will start its twoday Winter Carnival on schedule this morning. Because there is little snow on the campus hill IA Williamstown, Mass., carnival officials have moved the site of the two Alpine events to nearby Brodie Mountain. Jim Kelly, who runs Brodie, is turning part of his area over to us for three days, Ralph Townsend, Wil liams's ski coadh, said yesterday. He isn't charging us for lifts. He's even offered to videotape our racers so they can see how they did on the playback.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: No Fault Assessed

title: A Senator and Governor To Join Muskie Backers
description: TALLAHASSEE, Fla., Feb. 17  Senator Frank Church and Gov. Cecil Andrus of Idaho, the senior Democrats in their state, will announce on Saturday their support of Senator Edmund S. Muskie's bid for the party's Presidential nomination.

title: Cairo Editor Assails the U.S.; Says Talks Would Be a Trap
description: CAIRO, Friday, Feb. 18Mohamed Hassanein Heykal, leading Cairo editor, charged today that United States endeavors to organize proximity talks between Egypt and Israel were a trap for the Egyptians.

title: MRS. REUBEN BAKENHUS
description: Mrs. Ethel Frederick Bakenhus, the widow of Rear Adm. Reuben E. 13akenhus, died at Roosevelt Hospital on Wednesday. She was 80 years old and lived at 118 East 60th Street.

title: Books of The Times
description: MIGRANTS, SHARECROPPERS, MOUNTAINEERS. Volume II of Children in Crisis. By Robert Coles, M.D. 653 pages. Illustrated. Little, Brown. $12.50.

title: The Cleveland, Led By Gibson, Offers LittleKnown Work
description: At its Carnegie Hall concert on Wednesday night the Cleveland Orchestra had a guest conductor and a composition to introduce to New York. Neither could be called new, merely unknown here previously.

title: Highway Program of the Future?
description: WASHINGTONThe interstate highway system is now 75 per cent complete. But looming quietly in the background is a new highwaybuilding program which may be able to take up where the interstates left off. It is the economic development highway.

title: BlackedOut Britain Pins Hopes on a Report Today
description: LONDON, Feb. 19An official inquiry completed its work tonight on a report proposing a wage settlement to end Britain's national coal strike.

title: 15c Fare Charged on Bus As Cabbies Fight Gypsies
description: A bus called gypsy rolled up Madison Avenue and down Fifth yesterday, picking up passengers for 15 cents, running afoul of the law, and not making the slightest pretense that it was doing anything else.

title: Rail TonMileage Up
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 17The Association of American Railroads today estimated last week's freight traffic at 13.8 billion tonmiles, up 0.3 per cent from a year before. Carloadings totaled 457,313, down 3.9 per cent. The intercity truck tonnage report, normally out today, will not be issued until tomorrow.

title: Big Board Sets Balloting On Constitution Changes
description: The New York Stock Exchange's board of governors yesterday approved for balloting by the membership a series of constitutional amendments to reorganize the governing structure of the exchange.

title: Common Ground
description: On his first visit to the United States in 1959; Nikita S. Khrushchev told a distinguished New York audience that he had come to show Americans that he had neither horns nor a tail, but was simply another human being with whom one could talk and deal normally.

title: SCRIBNER UPHELD BY SCHOOL BOARD
description: The Board of Education yesterday upheld the action of Chancellor Harvey B. Scribner in appointing two trustees to the Community School Board of District 1, on the Lower East Side, to enable the dissentiontorn local board to fill two vacancies.

title: POLICE IN YONKERS START JOB ACTION
description: YONKERS, Feb. 17Bitter over a long deadlock on contract negotiations, policemen started a job action here today that cut the regular fleet of patrol cruisers on city streets in half.

title: 4 BERGEN TOWNS SUED ON HOUSING
description: TRENTON, Feb. 17The New Jersey Superior Court was asked today to stop further construction in four affluent, virtually allwhite Bergen County communities unless they agreed to permit the introduction of lowincome housing.

title: BRE DEFEAT FLYERS BY 41
description: PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 17 (AP) Phil Esposito's three goalshis 47th, 48th and 49th of the seasonled the East Divisionleading Boston Bruins to a 41 victory over the Philadelphia Flyers tonight in the National Hockey League.

title: City's Police Given ThankYou Dinner By Chinese Mission
description: It was a moment to exchange nightsticks for chopsticks, as the Chinese Mission to the United Nations gave a party here last night for the New York City police.

title: Books of The Times
description: CALCUTTA, By Geoffrey Moorhouse. 376 pagek Harcour irace Jovanovich. $3.05.

title: BUSINESSMEN OF U.S. AND EUROPE TO MEET
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 17The United States Chamber of Commerce announced today a meeting to be held next month in Versailles, France, that will bring together the chief executive officers of 100 large corporations in the United States and Western Europe.

title: City Agency Demonstrates $ 240 000 Gas Turbine Car
description: A $240,000 experimental gasturbine passenger car that emits a highpitched whine like a vacuum cleaner was demonstrated yesterday by city officials who hope it can point way toward easing the city's air pollution problems.

title: TEXAS INCREASING CRUDEOR OUTPUT
description: AUSTIN, Tex., Feb. 17  A mounting demand for Texas crude oil, triggered by higher costs of foreign oil, led the Texas Railroad Commission to set today a producing rate for March higher than any since November, 1970.

title: Laver and Okker Gain
description: TORONTO, Feb. 17 (UPI)Topseeded Rod Laver of Australia and thirdseeded Toni Okker of the Netherlands advanced to the semifinals of the $50,000 World Championship Tennis Tournament tonight.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Train Hits Overpass, New Autos Are Ruined
description: TOLEDO, Ohio, Feb. 17 (UP)A Penn Central freight train carrying 250 new luxury automobiles was rerouted today to tracks with lower bridge overpasses. It then failed to clear an overpass, and wound up in a massive wreck that caused explosions and fires.

title: Estimate Board Reluctant to Discuss Forest Hills Compromise
description: Members of the Board of Estimate were reluctant yesterday to take a firm position for or against the compromise plan on the lowincome housing project for Forest Hills, Queens, worked out by Mayor Lindsay's key aides, including former Deputy Mayor Richard R. Aurelio.

title: Rumania Says General, Reported Shot, Lost Rank
description: VIENNA, Feb. 17 (UPI)The Rumanian Embassy saki today that the commander of the Bucharest military garrison is no longer a general, blit refused to comment on reports that he was shot for spying for the Soviet Union.

title: U.S. Refuses Ho flu Role in Puerto Rico As Strike Mediator
description: James R. Hoffa, former head of the International 13rotherhood of Teamsters, was refused permission by the Justice Department yesterday to serve as mediator in a nineday trucking strike in Puerto Rico.

title: Merger News
description: The United States Filter Corporation and the Slick Corporation announced yesterday a preliminary agreement to merge.

title: HAKER NORWAY WINS IN SKIING
description: BANFF, Alberta, Feb. 17 (UPI)  Erik 1Taker of Norway won the first heat of the men's giant slalom today under terrible conditions in Canada's World Cup ski meet.

title: BARRETT JACOBS
description: MILFORD, Conn., Feb. 17Barrett Jacobs, president of the Jacobs Engineering Corporation of New York until his retirement two years ago, died yesterday of a heart attack in Hallandale, Fla. He was 70 years old and lived on Plains Road here.

title: Army R.O.T.C. for Coeds
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 (AP) Coeds at 10. colleges will be eligible to apply next fall for Army Reserve Officers Training Corps programs. The schools taking part in the fiveyear test program have not been selected, the Army said yesterday in an announcement.

title: UPTURN INDICATED IN BUSINESS LOANS
description: Demand for business loans at major New York and Chicago banks may be in the early stages of a longawaited advance, data published yesterday by the Federal Reserve indicated.

title: Mr. Nixon and Mr. Mao: II; What Is There to Talk About?
description: Some people wonder if China and the U.S. have anything to talk about with each other, but this gets a step ahead of reality. At present. even regular channels for dealing with each otherdiplomatic tiesdo not exist.,

title: Mounties Arrest One of Four Sought in 1970 Explosion at the University of Wisconsin
description: OTTAWA, Feb. 17  Kaneton Lewis Armstrong, wanted by the Federal Bureau of Investigation in connection with a bombing at the University of Wisconsin 18 months ago. has been arrested by the Royal Canadian Mounted Police.

title: Notes on People
description: Governor Rockefeller, after being awarded one of three Good Scout awards presented by the Greater New York Council of the Boy Scouts of America, got so carried away with the whole idea of the Scouts current fundraising drive that he pledged to match dollarfordollar contributions raised by the sponsors of the Good Scout award luncheon.

title: Lindsay Is Greeted by 200 As L.I. Headquarters Opens
description: HEMPSTEAD, L. L, Feb. 17Mayor Lindsay received an enthusiastic reception from about 200 people, mostly youths, when he opened his first campaign headquarters on Long Island here tonight.

title: WHITES PROTEST LI. SEGREGATION
description: COMMACK, L. I., Feb. 171 A group of about two dozen white parents from the Commack school district has toldl the school board that they feel their children are culturally deprived and psychologically handicapped because the district is de facto segregated.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: SALISBURY, Feb. 17 (AP)Prime Minister Smith said today that 1,505 persons have been arrested, 14 killed and four detained indefinitely in the month since the British Commission oil Rhodesian Public Opinion began assessing the acceptActivity of the Independence agreement.

title: OneParty Cabinet Is Formed in Italy; Approval in Doubt
description: ROME, Feb. 17  Giulio Andreotti, a 53yearold Christian Democrat, tonight formed a new Government, Italy's 33d since the fall of Fascism.

title: Troy Reports Warning on Redistricting
description: ALBANY, Feb. 17  Matthew J. Troy Jr., the Queens County Democratic leader, said today that he had delivered a warning to Governor Rockefeller from House Speaker Carl Albert that any major gerrymandering of certain Democratic Congressional districts could weaken the chances for passage of Federal revenue sharing.

title: Solitron Says Some Votes For It May Be Revoked
description: Solitron Devices, Inc., said it had received more than 2.5 million votes in favor of managrnent at its special meeting here yesterday but some may be revoked. The 2.5 million votes, more than half of the 4,690,00 outstanding shares, would insure a management victory in its feud with Harold S. Brady, a stockholder who nrtoduced an opposing slate of directors.

title: HENRY E. KELLEY, 77, SENIOR LAW PARTNER
description: SCARSDALE, N.Y., Feb. 17Henry E. Kelley, a senior partner in the New York law firm of Kelley, Drye, Warren, Clark, Carr & Ellis, died yesterday in St. Agnes Hospital, North White Plains. He was 77 years old and lived at 57 Edgemont Road.

title: CONSOLIDATED GAS SHOWS HIGHER NET
description: The Consolidated Natural Gas Company and subsidiaries reported yesterday gains in operating revenues and net income for 1971. The company's annual report placed total operating revenues at $667,146000 against $58%099,000 year earlier. Net income rose to $59,325,000, or $3.14 share, from $49,317,000, or $2.61 a share, in 1970.

title: Crum
description: Net income of Crum 8c Forster rose in the fourth quarter of 1971 to $9.7million, or 83 cents a share, from $6.5million, or 57 cents a share, a year earlier, the insurer reported yesterday.

title: An Odd Musical Assortment Proves Agreeable
description: Matthias Bamert threw together half a dozen oddly assorted pieces for his concert with the American Symphony Orchestra da Camera in Town Hall Wednesday night, There was a yearold work by Donald Erb, For Warsaw With Love, jostling Charles Wakefield Cadman's American Suite. Gounod's Little Symphony for Winds preceded Charles Ives's Camp Meeting Symphony. Two unusual Mozart compositions completed the list.

title: TOLL COLLECTORS TURN DOWN PACT
description: The union representing Trborough Bridge and Tunnel Authority toll collectors yesterday rejected a contract settlement with the authority recommended by an independent fact finder. There was no immediate threat of any job action.

title: Black Report Gets a Mixed Review
description: Consumer Affairs Commissioner Bess Myerson and the city's Parks, Recreation and Cultural Affairs Administrator, August Heckscher, as. sembled an allstar cast yesterday for their production, Hearings on the Black Report. As is often the case with allstar revues, the performances suffered from certain predictability.

title: News Analysis
description: MELBOURNE, Fla., Feb. 17Two of the issuesone domestic. one foreignthat are likely to dominate the political dialogue of 1972 have been set dramatically before the public in the last two weeks.

title: Chile Is in Default On U.S. Bank Loans
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 (AP) Chile, after giving forceful assurances it would not do so, has defaulted on loan payments to the ExportImport Bank, United States officials have reported.

title: Penguins Beat Sabres, 20
description: BUFFALO, Feb. 17 (UPI)Ron Shock scored two goals and Jim Rutherford, goalie, celebrated his 23d birthday with his first shutout of the season tonight as the Pittsburgh Penguins beat the Buffalo Sabres, 20.

title: Seoul Weighs Saigon Request
description: SEOUL, South Korea, Feb. 17 Defense Minister Yu Jac Heung said today that South Korea would decide by the end of March on Saigon's request for the continued stationing of two Korean Army divisions in South Vietnam until the end of 1973.

title: 20 Nations Would Accept East Germany at Meeting
description: GENEVA, Feb. 17Twenty Western countries have agreed to a proposal that East Germany attend as an observer meeting of a new subsidiary groups of the United Nations Economic Commission for Europe dealing with environmental problems. The meeting is to be held in Belgrade Feb. 28.

title: Bride: For Team Event Here Monday BoardaMatch Scoring Is Set
description: In one respect the pattern of tournament play has changed remarkably in the last decade. Boardamatch scoring, which was once the ruleapart from two national team championshipsis now a rarity: it has been almost entirely displaced by knockout or Swiss events based on international match point scoring.

title: SEVERANCE URGED IN BERRIGAN CASE
description: HARRISBURG, Pa., Feb. 17A motion was filed in Federal District Court here today to sever the conspiracy trial of Eqbal Ahmad, a Pakistani Moslem, from that of the Rev. Philip F.13errigan and five other antiwar Roman Catholics.

title: Time Inc. Increases Earn;ngs for Year, Reversing Trend
description: Time Inc. reversed a fouryear trend of decreasing profits In 1971 with a 12.6 per cent gain in operating earnings, the report of Andrew Heis!cell, chairman, and James R. Shepley, president, disclosed yesterday. Profits for the fourth guarter were up 16 per cent from a year. earlier.

title: Dyce Takes Hot Streak Into Garden Tonight
description: While Jim liyun plans a return to Kansas in search of fresh psychology and Marty Liguori brushes up on speed work Byron Dyce chases another challenge in the 1,500meter run tonight during the United States Olympic invitation track and field meet.

title: Advertising:
description: A pair of recent financial debacles in the advertising world has apparently shown broadcasters that they need better credit information. Radio and TV are the only media without an organized setup in this area.

title: Executive Changes
description: Bernard L. Schwartz has been elected chalr4 man of the board of the Loral Corporation, succeeding Leon Alpert, who has retired. Mr. Schwartz formerly was chairman of the executive committee of the Leasco Corporation.

title: But Net Mr Year Drops 5.7% $17.1ffillion Loss Is Main Cause
description: Fourthquarter profits of the Singer Company rose 31.6 per cent to a record $26,731,000, or $1,52 a share, from $20311,000, or $1.15, in the 1970 final quarter. Earnings for the year, however, declined 5.7 per cent, according to yesterday's report from Donald P. Kircher, president and chief executive.

title: U.S. Marshal Confirmed
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 (AP) The Senate confirmed today the nomination of Ermen J. Pallananck as United States marshall for a fouryear term in the Connecticut judicial district. He succeeds Gaetano A. Russo Jr., who resigned.

title: MAYFIELD PERFORMS ON BILL WITH EXUMA
description: Soul music fans will have a pleasant time at the Bitter End this week. The featured acts are the coolvoiced Curtis Mayfield and the rhythm and calypso singer Exuma.

title: De Neuflize Bank Repels TakeOver Bid
description: PARIS, Feb. 17  One of France's oldest banks, de Neuflize Schlumberger, Mallet & Cie, which has just repulsed bid for control from the Banque de Paris et des Pays Bas, has announced an international alignment with the fourth biggest bank of the Netherlands.

title: Photographer Terrified Her, Mrs. Onassis Testifies at Trial
description: Mrs. Aristotle Onassis declared in a crowded courtroom yesterday that: freelance photagrapher, Ronald E. Galella, had terrified her in Central Park, outside her apartment building on Fifth Avenue and on Capri.

title: Severely Disabled, These Mothers Do More Than just Endure
description: A towheaded, elfin 4yearold clasps her arms around her mother's hips, asking for a cooky. An ordinary gesture, but for Edith, and Deedy, her daughter, touch is more than ordinarily Important. Deady was 4 months old when her mother became totally blind.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Market Place: Fcuannds Manager Scans Market
description: When Richard Carney, the laconic 32yearold portfolio manager who runs the $70million Lionel D. Edie mutual fund operation, speaks of a market climax these days, he's not talking about that familiar Wall Street phenomenon, the selling climax.

title: National Ballet Dances Its Repertory
description: Washington's National Ballet is concentrating on its fulllength ballets, The Sleeping Beauty and Cinderella, for its brief City Center season. However, it is giving one repertory program, which was given for the first time on Wednesday evening and will be seen again on Sunday, the last night of the season.

title: China Show TV's Biggest Since Man Reached Moon
description: Sunday night at 10:30, American television viewers will be able to watch President Nixon set foot on mainland China. It will be die most historic and most technically complex live television event since astronauts first set foot on the moon.

title: EDGAR P. FEELEY, 79, OF BASEBALL GIANTS
description: Edgar P. Feeley, the treasurer and counsel for the National Exhibition Company, the parent organization of the San Francisco Giants baseball team, died here late Wednesday in the company offices in the Empire State building. He was 79 years old and had been a resident of City Island in the Bronx for 50 years.

title: Minnesotans Divided Over Game Ruling for Indians
description: CASS LAKE, Minn.A controversial Federal court order went into effect yesterday, allowing local Indians to hunt, fish, trap and gather wild rice on public lands here with no regard for state laws.

title: Outsider Is Chosen for Company Post
description: U. S. PlywoodChampion Papers, Inc., which has four executive vice presidents, has selected an outsider to be the company's new president.

title: Publishers Weekly Reviews Its 100 Years
description: Publishers Weekly, the magazine for the book trade, has just celebrated its 100th anniversary. (It was called The Publishers and Stationers Weekly Trade Circular for a year before taking on its present name.) In a country that is not yet 200 years old, such longevity alone is worthy of attention. But to Richard E. Bye, publisher of PW, it is not how long the magazine has been around, but what it has done in that time that is worthy of com

title: Sports of The Times
description: Vida Blue, the brightest individual star in baseball last summer and the biggest single attraction in the American League, has been presented with a simple choice by the man who owns him: Either play for $50,000 this year or get out of the game.

title: Arrives in Hawaii
description: HONOLULU, Feb. 17 (Reuters)President and Mrs. Nixon were greeted by a crowd of 5,000 to 7,000 Hawaiians and servicemen when they landed at Kaneohe Marine Air Corps Station here today on their journey to China.

title: Dr. Douglas Lake Weds Miss Talbott
description: Miss Elizabeth Talbott, daughter of Mrs. R. G. Wingfield of Pascagoula, Miss., and the late Eugene A. Talbott, was married here yesterday morning to Dr. Douglas Lake, a widower, of New York and Southampton, L. I. He is a plastic surgeon here.

title: PENTAGON TO PRESS FOR NEW SUBMARINE
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 (UPI) Defense Secretary Melvin R. Laird said today that the Pentagon was proceeding with plans for strengthening and improving American strategic forces regardless of the outcome of United StatesSoviet talks on controls.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Kosciusko Is Appointed French Envoy to U.S.
description: PARIS, Feb. 17 (Reuters)The French Government has appointed Jacques KosciuskoMorizet as its new Ambassador in Washington, the Foreign Ministry said today.

title: Bank Involved in Loan Case Tied Closely to Brooklyn Democrats
description: The arrests yesterday of reputed Mafia figures and of people active in the ItalianAmerican Civil Rights League on charges of obtaining loans from the Kings Lafayette Bank on false representations focused attention on a relatively small Brooklyn financial institution.

title: Voices for McGovern
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 Senator McGovern is using the recorded voices of two uncommitted Democratic Senators as part of his New Hampshire primary campaign, without obtaining their permission or notifying them.

title: Books Are Closed On World's Fair
description: Stating proudly that one of its great legacies was turning a former ratinfested ash dump into a beautiful park, Robert Moses issued yesterday his final report on the New York World's Fair, 196465.

title: Chinese Press Is Giving Little Space to Visit
description: HONG KONG, Feb. 17Anyone who gave only a cursory glance to the major headlines of Peking's daily newspapers over the last six months could be excused for not knowing that President Nixon was planning to visit China.

title: VATICAN ALTERS RULE FOR ADULT CONVERTS
description: ROME, Feb. 17The Vatican today issued new rules for the initiation of adults to the Roman Catholic faith that call for a category of sympathizers who may continue practicing polygamy in countries where local usage permits more than one wife.

title: New York Port Notes
description: Shipping lines and terminal operators are losing no time in trying to offset the impact of the higher costs they expect to absorb as a result of longshoremen's wage settlements on both coasts.

title: U.S. Judge Forbids Dumping of Sludge Along Jersey Coast
description: TRENTON, Feb. 174 Federal judge invoked the 1899 Federal Refuse Act today and ordered 15 communities along New Jersey's shore to stop pumping sewer sludge into the Atlantic.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Phone Workers Ordered To Return to Work Today
description: Union leaders yesterday ordered most of the striking New York Telephone Company workers back to work, effective today, after the union members ratified a new threeyear contract with a 33.5 per cent pay increase.

title: HOUSE, 234 10 1427, VOTES TO EXPAND FRI ON POVERTY
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 17Brushing aside threats of another Presidential veto, the House passed today a $5.4billion antipoverty bill that would greatly expand Head Start programs for preschoolers and create an independent Legal Services program for the poor.

title: MISS DAVIS FACES TRIAL ON FEB. 28
description: SAN JOSE, Calif., Feb. 17After again refusing a defense request for a change of trial site, Judge Richard A. Arnason today ordered the trial of Angela Y. Davis, the black activist, to begin on Feb. 28.

title: PENN CENTRAL GETS BID ON PROPERTIES
description: The trustees of therm Central Transportation Company have been sent another bid for four of the railroad's midtown Manhattan hotels and an office building. The total bid is $60million.

title: 3 Lead Phoenix Golf by Shot With 66's
description: PHOENIX, Feb. 17 (UPI) 1 Dale Douglass, who won here in 1970, and Paul Moran and Jim Jamieson, both looking for their first tour victories, tied at five  under  par 66 today and shared the firstround lead in the $125,000 Phoenix open.

title: AMAYA NAMED HEAD OF CULTURAL CENTER
description: Mario Amaya, chief curator of the Art Gallery of Ontario in Toronto, has been appointed director of the New York Cultural Center, the gallery of contemporary art at 2 Columbus Circle. He succeeds Donald H. Karshan, who has resigned to devote his time to writing.

title: A MINING COMPANY SUED ON POLLUTION
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 (UPI) Tho Justice Department filed suit today against the Reserve Mining Company, charging its plant at Silver Bay, Minn., with three counts of polluting Lake Superior by dumping taconite tailings into it at the rate of 67,000 tons a day.

title: KENNETH F, FAGAN
description: NORWALK, Conn., Feb. 18Kenneth F. Fagan of 6 Barnum Avenue, executive director of the Norwalk Redevelopment Agency, died today in Norwalk Hospital after a long illness. He was 69 years old.

title: Bridge: Sympathy Is Given to Player For Bad Luck in Game Choice
description: Stories of bad luck often turn out to be stories of had play or had bidding. But South was surely entitled to some sympathy after the experience that befell him on the diagramed deal.

title: Sorcery Sails to Victory In MiamiLucaya Race
description: LUCAYA, Bahamas, Feb. 18 (AP)J. F. Baldwin's 61foot sloop Sorcery sailed across the finish line first today and won the MiamitoLucaya Southern Ocean Racing Conference cup.

title: Police Assert Wife Slew Cost Unit Aide And Then Herself
description: SILVER SPRING, Md. Feb. 18 (UPI)  Earl D. Rhode, the executive secretary of the Cost of Living Council, was shot to death by his wife, who then turned the antique Derringer pistol on herself, the Montgomery County police alleged today.

title: Health Maintenance Units Lag Despite Nixon Plea
description: A full year after President Nixon drew attention to health maintenance organizations, their poptilarity has grown among some segments of the health community but Congress has yet to vote any funds.

title: New Play Set for East Side
description: The Soft Core Pornographer, a new play by Martin Stone and John Heller, will open at the Manhattan Theater Club, 321 East 73d Street, on April S. Word Baker is directing.

title: Miners Chiefs in Britain Accept Strike Settlement
description: LONDON, Saturday, Feb. 19A proposed settlement the crippling national coal strike was accepted early today by leaders of the miners union after they had initially rejected it. The decision came after a day of tense negotiations.

title: $30MILLION BUILDING IS PLANNED BY G.E.
description: The General Electric Company announced yesterday plans for a $30million, 60,000squarefoot building at the company's main plant in Schenectady. The new facility will be used to test fullyassembled generators.

title: MRS. FRANK M'OUIGAN
description: Mrs. Marie Mine Mixter McGuigan, a former singer and the widow of Frank Harrington McGuigan Jr., a bond department executive of the Prudential Insurance Company, died Monday in Mountainside Hospital, Montclair, N. J. Formerly a resident of Montclair, she lived in Bloomfield, N. J.

title: Eximbank Curtails Credits for Chile; Debt Dispute Cited
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 18 (AP) The State Department said today that the ExportImport Bank has suspended credits guarantees and insurance to Chile until there is further clarification of Chile's unilateral moratorium on debt payments.

title: Black Liberation Army Called Mobile
description: They don't boast or spend their money flamboyantly, they don't associate openly with people the police might be watching and they don't drink or use drugs heavily.

title: PARTY GIVES SADAT CONFIDENCE VOTE
description: CAIRO, Feb. 18  President Anwar elSadat won unanimous affirmation of confidence in his leadership today from the 1,500member National Congress of the Arab Socialist Union, which convened in special session Wednesday for an urgent policy review following student unrest.

title: Inco's Miners Irked by Layoffs
description: SUIDBURY, Ontario, Feb. 18 The late afternoon rays of a harsh winter sun slowly slide up the International Nickel Company's 1,240foot smokestack that presides over Sudbury and Copper Cliff, the site of North America's largest nickel reserves.

title: Father Visits Bombing Suspect in Jail
description: MADISON, Wis., Feb. 18The parents of two young men wanted in connection with the bombing of a University of Wisconsin mathematics research centers. in 1970 in which a research worker died, says a son who is in a Toronto jail told them today that his brother was all right.

title: Mil Bird Displays Versatility on Piano In Tully Hall Recital
description: Any pianist who can play Brahms's Variations on a Theme of Paganini expertly, excitingly and authoritatively is one of more than ordinary attainments, and such a one is Idil Biret, the Turkish pianist who gave a recital at Alice Tully Hall on Thursday night.

title: Subject to Breakdowns
description: AMMAN, Jordan, Feb. 18 (UPI)Dr. Alami's sister Dalai described him today as a man who hates violence, is extremely kind to children and is subject to nervous breakdowns.

title: President's Jetliner Carries Small Clinic
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 18The President's Spirit of 76 jetliner, a Boeing 707, carries medical and secretarial equipment, as do the backup planes on his trip to China.

title: CHESLEY H. HUSSON SR.
description: BANGOR, Me., Feb. 18Chesley H. Husson Sr., president emeritus of Husson College, died yesterday in the Eastern Maine Medical Center here. Mr. Husson, who was 68 years old, had suffered strokes in 1970 and was forced to give up the presidency of the Bangor college.

title: Offensive in Laos
description: VIETIANE, Laos, Feb. 18 (UPI)  Laotian Government troops, with United States air support, have launched an offensive in Northern Loas against forces occupying the Plaine des Jarres. the acting Defense Minister, Prince Sisuok Na Champassack, announced today.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Cup Skiing at Banff Is Won by Haaker And Miss Lafforgue
Screen:
description: For the person who makes short films, if he is any good at all, the oneman show offers every advantagenot the least of which is that it allows his work to appear for what it is, rather than as an adjunct to somebody else's idea of what constitutes film program. For a critic, the advantages are equal and complimentary.

title: State Court Reform Awaits 1970 Panel's First Report
description: One year and three weeks after it was to have submitted its final report, the state commission created to recommend ways to overhaul the courts is only now beginning to define the system's problems and is still debating whether it can formulate proposals by next December.

title: Rifle Thief Pleads Guilty
description: OKLAHOMA CITY, Feb. 18 (AP)  A University of Oklahoma freshman pleaded guilty in Federal Court today to stealing 43 R.O.T.C. rifles from Ponca City High School on Nov. 26. Michael James Conley, 18 years old, said he threw them in like. The 1903 Springfield rifles wen valued at $109 each. The judge delayed sentencing.

title: HUGHES'S FLIGHT PLANNED QUICKLY
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 18 Hine sudden predawn departure of Howard R. Hughes from Nassau, the Bahamas, this week was organized by James 0. Golden, who once worked in the Secret Service detail that guarded then Vice President Richard M. Nixon.

title: Man in the News
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 18The head of the National Institute on Alcohol Abuse and Alcoholism is not a teetotaler and believes parents should teach their children how to drink. He is also, according to a colleague, the best man in the country for the job he holds. An energetic, gregarious individual with a whimsical sense of humor and an outspoken man in a field that is often controversial, Dr. Morris Edward Chafetz is also one of the bestknown figures in the area of alcoholism and its treatment.

title: Italian Cabinet Is Sworn Amid Political Disputes
description: ROME, Feb. 18  President Giovanni Leone swore in Premier Giulio Andreotti and his ministers today amid political and constitutional disputes and dissension in the new Government.

title: WarProtesting Priest Loses Post in Camden
description: CAMDEN, N. J., Feb. 18 (AP)A Roman Catholic priest was removed from his church post today for conducting an antiwar Ash Wednesday service at a cemetery here.

title: Truck TonMileage Shows 4.2% Increase for Week
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 18 Intercity truck tonnage in the week ended Feb. 12 was 4.2 per cent below the volume in the corresponding week of last year. Truck tonnage in the latest week was 1.0 per cent above the volume in the immediately preceding week of 1972.

title: Star guits Team in Junior Year
description: UNIDNDALE, LI., Feb. 18Jim Chones, 6foot11inch junior center of Marquette University's undefeated basketball team, signed a fiveyear contract with the New York Nets late last night, immediately forfeiting his college eligibility.

title: NAVY BARS STUDY Al 15 UNIVERSITIES
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 18Yielding to what it said was pressure from the House Armed Services Committee, the Navy has forbidden its officers to take Governmentfinanced graduate courses at 15 colleges and universities that are eliminating Naval Reserve Officer Training Corps programs.

title: DR. EUGENE RASKO
description: Dr. Eugene Rasko, a cardiologist, who was on the rehabilitation medicine staff of Goldwater Memorial Hospital, died Thursday of a heart attack at the hospital. He was 68 years old and lived at 229 East 79th Street.

title: Pay Board's Chief Is Sued By Machinists Over Wages
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 18 (UPI) The International Association of Machinists and Aerospace Workers filed suit today against the Pay Board chairman, George H. Boldt, saying that 120,000 aerospace workers were entitled to more than the 8.3 per cent wage increase approved by the Federal panel.

title: 6INCH SNOWFALL IS EXPECTED HERE
description: Alter first forecasting heavy snow for today and then revising the forecast to heavy rain, the National Weather Service early this morning issued still another revision and again predicted heavy snow.

title: A SCHOOL IN FLORIDA CLOSED AFTER FIGHTS
description: JACKSONVILLE, Via., Feb. 18 (UPI)Ribault High School was closed today after scattered fighting broke out on the campus.

title: U.S. REPORT SAYS TOP DRUG PROBLEM IS ALCOHOL ABUSE
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 18 A Government report today called alcohol abuse the nation's greatest drug problem, asserting that it warps nine million lives and costs about $15billion a year.

title: Brooks Hays to Run
description: WINSTONSALEM, N. C., Feb. 18 (AP)Brooks Hays, who served 16 years as a Representative from Altansas, an flounced his candidacy for North Carolina's fifth District Congressional scat today. Mr. Hays, 73 years old, said he wanted to use his experience for the benefit of my adopted state. A parttime consultant to Wake Forest University's Ecumenical Institute, he has maintained a residence in WinstonSalem since 1968.

title: Army Begins CourtsMartial Stemming From Georgia Riot
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 18 A series of military trials stemming from a stockade riot last October at Fort Gordon, Ga., were begun this week by the Army.

title: Notes on People
description: Thor Heyerdahl, the Norwegian explorer whose most recent feat was crossing the Atlantic in a papyrus boat in 57 clays, said in Tel Aviv that he plans another such journey in a vessel to be built along lines of a ship depicted on an ancient Assyrian clay tablet.

title: G.N.P. Growth Slowed a Bit in 4th Quarter as Inflation Picked Up
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 18Revised figures for the gross national product showed slightly less real growth in the fourth quarter of last year and slightly more inflation, the Commerce Department disclosed today.

title: China Follows Stalin's Pattern In Industrialization Program
description: The Chinese dragon slept for centuries while the West wasj harnessing science and technology to accumulate wealth and military power. Now Mao Tsetung seems determined to have his country climb the economic ladder, too, and evidence mounts that he plans to use the industrialization pattern pioneered by Stalin in the nineteenthirties.

title: Cardinal Gets Vatican Post
description: CHICAGO, Feb. 18 (AP) John Cardinal Cody, the Roman Catholic Archbishop of Chicago, was notified today of his appointment to the Prefecture for Economic Affairs of the Holy See. The prefecture supervises economic affairs of the church. The Cardinal will continue as Archbishop of Chicago and attend periodic prefecture meetings in Vatican City.

title: Spanked Boy Gets $19,000
description: CRESTVIEW, Fla., Feb. 18 (UPI)A circuit court jury awarded Thomas Tizekker, now a high school sophomore, $500 in compensatory damages and $18,500 in punitive damages yesterday as the result of a spanking by the principal of Richbourg Junior High School two years ago. The boy's father said the money will be used to send his son to college.

title: Suit Over Riverdale Housing Opens
description: The death of a controversial scattersite housing development in the Riverdale section of the Bronx  Faraday Wood  began yesterday to get a thorough airing in a lawsuit in Federal Court.

title: Defense Fund Cheered
description: The N.A.A.C.P. Legal Defense and Educational Fund, Inc., said that yesterday's decision was one of the most encouraging to occur in the group's fiveyear battle to abolish capital punishment.

title: Extradition Pushed
description: MADISON, Wis., Feb. 18 Gov. Patrick J. Lucey of Wisconsin, State Attorney General Robert W, Warren, Dane County District Attorney Gerald Nichol and Madison's police chief, Wilbur Emery, sent a joint telegram to Secretary of State William P. Rogers and Attorney General John N. Mitchell today asking immediate action to extradite Karleton Armstrong.

title: Mondale Speech Excerpts
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 15Following are excerpts from a Senate speech today by Senator Walter F. Mondale, Democrat of Minnesota, on school busing:

title: Art: A Show That Fulfills Promises
description: Adja Yonkers, whose exhibition of recent paintings and collages opened this week at the Whitney Museum, is an unusually satisfying artist. In the upanddown and nowyousecitnowyoudon't New York scene where artists and movements flourish and decline over a season, he has been. a steady presence confirming the wisdom of taking your time, thinking things out and allowing sensitivities to mature rather than depending on the gush of something passing for inspiration. 1le has examined, controlled and refined the expressive potentials of various styles from neocubism to abstract expressionism, but only recently has he seemed much more than an intelligent and conscientious analyst of modes slightly their

title: MRS. GILBERT E. FULLER
description: Mrs. Sidney Claire Michaelis Fuller, the widow of Gilbert E. Fuller, the former president of RaymondWhitcomb and a pioneer in the development of tourist cruises, died in a nursing home in Hastings, England, on Sunday, according to word received here yesterday. She was 86 years old.

title: Wilson Bids Heath Yield on Market or Call Election
description: LONDON, Feb. 18Harold Wilson leader of the Labor party Opposition, called on Prime Minister Heath today to abandon his Common Market policy or call an immediate general election.

title: PACT IS REACHED FOR CURRENCIES
description: PARIS, Feb. 18In the Common Market's secret deliberations over monetary union, a tentative agreement has been reached to let market forces, instead of a decisionmaking center, determine the movement of community currencies as a bloc within the wider band of permissible fluctuations against the dollar.

title: Moscow Holds Parley on Farm Crisis
description: MOSCOW, Feb. 18 The Soviet Union announced today that the party and government leaders of the 15 republics had been summoned to Moscow to hear a speech by Leonid I. Brezhnev, the national party chief, about the difficult agricultural situation this year.

title: ROCKEFELLER SEEN AIDING DEMOCRATS
description: ORISKANY, N. Y., Feb. 18The Democratic state chairman, Joseph F. Crangle, unofficially opened his party's 1972 election campaign today by suggesting that Governor Rockefeller could prove to be a great help to Democratic efforts to defeat President Nixon and other Republicans in New York.

title: TALKS PROGRESS AT NEWARK NEWS
description: NEWARK, Feb. 18The EveI ning News of Newark, idled for nine months by a sixmonthl strike followed by three months of contract negotiations, appeared today to have moved closer to resuming publication as a Federal mediator reportedly worked out a tentative agreement with one of four craft unions involved.

title: Executive Changes
description: Allan P. Lucht, 55 years old, president and chief executive officer of the Servomation Corporation, has been named to the additional post pf chairman. He succeeds Joseph E. McDowell, who has resigned as chairman anti as a director but will continue as a consultant.

title: Arrests Said to Block Drug Shipment to U.S.
description: FORT DE FRANCE, Martinique, Feb. 18 (AP)United States and French narcotics agents announced four arrests today that they said blocked the shipment of $1.4million worth of cocaine into the United States.

title: Western Oil Units Get Faisal Warning
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Feb. 18King Faisal of Saudi Arabia has warned Western oil companies that governments of oilproducing countries in the Persian Gulf region would resort to legislation if the companies failed to agree to their request for participation in existing concessions.

title: Spectacle and Substance
description: The footlights are up, the cameras are grinding; one of the great TV spectaculars of this or any other year is under way. President Nixon departed for China with elaborately staged fanfare on the White House lawn and the signing of a proclamation making tomorrow, the day of his arrival in Peking, a National Day of Prayer for world peace.

title: Lakers Overcome Errors
description: LOS ANGELES, Feb. 19 (AP) The Los Angeles Lakers overcame 34 turnovers and a fourtquarter Portland rally tonight to defeat the Trail Blazers, 125114.

title: Coast Dockers Vote End of Long Strike; Grain Accord is Set
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 18 (AP)Longshoremen here and in San Diego voted by widel margins today to accept an agreement to end the 134day West Coast dock strike as votes poured into other locals along the coast.

title: Dioguardi Kinship Denied
description: Philip T. Dioguardi, one of eight persons arrested Thursday on charges of giving false information to obtain loans from Kings Lafayette Bank in Brook lyn, denied yesterday that he was related to John Dioguardii the imprisoned labor racketeer: The New York Times reported yesterday that Philip was cousin of John. The identifica. tion was based on information from Federal officials.

title: Muskie Urges Floridians to Reject Wallace
description: DE LAND, Fla., Feb. 18Senator Edmund S. Muskie urged Florida voters today to reject the Presidential candidacy of Gov. George C. Wallace of Alabama so fast that his head will spin.

title: Ecuador: Again the Army
description: The motives of Ecuador's military chiefs in overthrowing President Jose Maria Velasco Ibarra at this time seem clear: They feared that the election scheduled for June 4 would bring to the presidency the leader the reformist Popular Forces Alliance and former Mayor of Guayaquil, Asaad Bucaram. Though hostile to Mr. Bucaram, President Velasco had resisted military pressures to call off the election and continue in office.

title: 2 Die in School Bus Crash
description: OLEAN, N. Y., Feb. 18 (AP) A school bus and a light truck collided near here today, killing two men riding in the truck and injuring at least 23 children and the bus driver, the state police said. All of those hurt were treated at two city hospitals for minor injuries.

title: Study Aides Voice Misgivings About Report on TV Violence
description: In the month since the public release of the Surgeon General's report on the impact of television violence on children, a growing number of those involved have begun to air their misgivings about the reports accuracy in reflecting the research on which it was largely based.

title: Deaths
description: BEISTYJohn M., of Flushing and Hampton Bays, L. I. Retired manager of Gas Supply Dept, of Brooklyn Union Gas Co. On Feb. ruary IT, 19/2. Beloved husband of Alice (nee Howard). Devoted father of Mary Jane Dunkak, James and Kathleen. Loving brother of William, James and Edward. Also survived by seven grandchildren. Re. Posing at The Frederick Funeral Horne Flushing, Northern Blvd. at 193 St. Mass of the Resurrection St. Kevins R. C. Church, Tuesday at 9:45 A.M. Interment Mt. St. Marys Cemetery. Visiting hours: 2.5 and 7.10 P.M.

title: Another Witness Is Called In Case of Book on Hughes
description: Philip Reiner, an accountant here, was subpoenaed yesterday to appear before the Federal grand jury investigating the reputed autobiography of Howard R. Hughes.

title: Max Miller, Lawyer, Dies; Head of Benevolent Groups
description: Max Miller, a lawyer here for nearly 60 years, died yesterday at the De Witt Nursing Home, 211 East 79th Street, at the age of 88.

title: Nixon Clears Aid for Pakistan; Bar by Congress Deemed Void
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 18 President Nixon has notified Congress that conditions in Pakistan are returning to normal and therefore Congressional restrictions on United States military and economic aid to that country no longer apply.

title: Marilyn Burr
description: There is something beautifully clean and simple about Washington's National Ballet. It has a generosity of spirit, but most important it is developing a style, a profile, of its own.

title: FILTH TOLERANCE IN FOOD DISCLOSED
description: The Food and Drug Administration will soon make public a previously secret list of filth allowances in foods and other products.

title: A CityState Commission
description: The abrupt resignation of several top staff members from the state commission investigating New York City's governmental structurereportedly because they do not want to participate in a mere hatchet job on the cityunderscores the commission's basic and fatal flaw. Born of political motives in the final moments of last year's legislative session, the commission has never been able to dispel the public impression that it is nothing more than a weapon of the state government against the city. Whatever hopes for impartiality had been raised by the several excellent appointments to the commission have been dimmed with the recent resignations.

title: Pollution Unit Proposes Law on Uranium Waste
description: LAS VEGAS, Nev., Feb. 18The Environmental Protection Agency has proposed a model law for nine Western states in controlling and covering huge piles of radioactive wastes from mills that process uranium ore.

title: Company in Queens With Slot Machines Raided by the Police
description: Airlines that have tried many lures, from movies to fancy cooking, to stimulate business, might take a hint from a company that manufactures parts for airplanes.

title: Communists Assail Nixon's Trip As Party Convention Opens Here
description: Gus Hall, the general secretary of the Communist party, U.S.A., and its candidate for President, yesterday decried President Nixon's trip to China and China's Communist chairman, Mao Tsetung, as the party opened its 20th national convention here.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Treigle Out for Spring
description: Norman Treigle, leading bass of the New York City Opera, is undergoing treatment for a leg injury, and has canceled his scheduled performances with the company during its spring season at the New York State Theater.

title: Redemption Plan Set
description: The Commonwealth Edison Company said yesterday that it would redeem its 9.44 per cent prior preferred stocks on March 20 at the pershare redemption price of $110, plus accrued dividends of $1.26.

title: Edward E. Myers Dead at 70; Herald Tribune Vender in Paris
description: PARIS, Feb. 18Edward Elmer Myers, chief newspaper vender of The International Herald Tribune here died of cancer of the throat at the American Hospital this morning. He was 70 years old.

title: Taipei Hides its Nervousness at Trip And Puts Its Trust in U.S. Promiseg
description: TAIPEI, Taiwan, Feb. 18The only recently erected official posters in Taipei bear nonpolitical message: File your income tax returns promptly.

title: AMEX PRICES EASE IN LIGHT TRADING
description: Prices on the American Stock Exchange and the overthecounter market finished slightly lower yesterday in slower trading.

title: ULSTER LEGISLATORS IN MODERATE PARTY
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Feb. 18Three members of the Northern Ireland Parliament, one a former Cabinet minister, announced today they had joined the moderate Alliance party.

title: 7 DRUG SMUGGLERS ARE SENTENCED HERE
description: A New Yorker who was hired to swim from a Brooklyn dock to a freighter to bring back cocaine was sentenced to seven and a half years in prison for conspiring to smuggle the drug from Chile.

title: Ruckeishaus Sees Distrust Of Government Growing
