description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 18 William D. Ruckelshaus, administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency, told the Senate Subcommittee on Air and Water Pollution today that the tragedy of the time was that we live in a society in which institutions of government are distrusted.

title: Market Place: Relief Is Urged For Little Guys
description: The Little Guy, who has few champions in Wall Street can look to Howard Stein for a little solace in these days of rising commissions.

title: Article 2  No Title
description: BELFAST, Feb. 18 (UPI)Bombs heavily damaged three shopping centers in Londonderry within a halfhour today, and raiders set fire to the town hall in the border town of Newry. In Belfast a shopkeeper tossed a bomb into the street where it was later detonated by bombdisposal experts.

title: Brazil Military Court Frees Publisher
description: RIO DE JANEIRO, Feb. 18A special Brazilian military court today unanimously acquitted a publisher who is an avowed leftist of subversion and found that charges never should have been brought.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Court Voids Restriction On State Pension Payments
description: ALBANY, Feb. 18The State Court of Appeals today ruled unconstitutional a law passed last year by the Legislature to exclude accumulated vacation credits in computing retirement benefits for state employes.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Chicago Vote Today
description: CHICAGO, Feb. 18 (AP) A tentative contract settlement ending a sixmonthold strike by longshoremen against six Chicago grain elevator companies was announced today by both sides.

title: Mets Pitching Rotation: Seaver, 4 Question Marks
description: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., Feb. 18  On the thin] day of spring training, it became apparent today that a paradox was taking hold in the New York Mets camp: The Mets, who became rich and famous through pitching, employ perhaps the fewest pitchers in baseball and now need help.

title: Wisconsin Student Burned
description: MADISON, Wis., Feb. 18 (UPI)A 20yearold student at the University of Wisconsin was listed in critical condition with burns today after he was found aflame by the police at an electric power substation near the school shortly after midnight. The police said the incident was an apparent attempted suicide.

title: STAUFFER CHEMICAL SETS A PRICE RISE
description: The Stauffer Chemical Company announced yesterday that it would increase prices of chlorinated trisodium phosphate by 75 cents per hundredweight, beginning April 1.

title: Blancas's 10UnderPar 61 for 131 Total Leads by 4 Shots at Phoenix
description: PHOENIX, Ariz., Feb. 18 (AP) Homero Blancas shot a 10underpar 61 today to take a fourstroke lead after the secdnd round of the $125,000 Phoenix open golf tournament.

title: Berrigan Lawyer Bars Mistrial, Says He Believes Jury Is Fair
description: HARRISBURG, Pa., Feb. 18 An attorney for the Rev. Philip E. Berrigan and six other persons accused in an antiwar conspiracy said today he was satisfied that a fair jury had been chosen.

title: Clinic Uses Health Concepts Tested in Nigeria
description: While medical problems in East Harlem and rural Nigeria bear little resemblance, lowcost medical concepts developed and tested successfully in Nigeria are being applied to a small segment of the mostly black and Hispanic population here.

title: GERARD J. VESTA
description: SYOSSET, L.I., Feb. 18 Gerard J. Vesta, founder and president of the Interstate Woodworking Company of Long Island City, Queens, died today in Syosset Hospital. He was 87 years old and lived at 33 Whitman Avenue.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Restoration Bill Gains
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 18 (AP) A House Interior subcommittee approved today a bill to authorize $4.5million for restoration of the Civil War gunboat, Cairo. The bill calls for restoration of the vessel for display near the Vicksburg National Military Park Cemetery in Mississippi. The Union gunboat, commissioned at Cairo, Ill., vvas sank and buried in mud in the Yazoo River. A Senatepassed bill calls for $2.5million for restoration of the fore part of the gunboat.

title: CHIEF IN NEWBURGH IS ONE OF 3 INDICTED
description: GOSITEN, N. Y., Feb. 18 The Chief of the Newburgh Police Department and two policemen who served under him have been indicted by an Orange County grand jury on charges involving burglary, petit larceny, criminal possession of stolen property and official misconduct.

title: 13,000Acre Wilderness Tract In Adirondacks Given to State
description: ELIZABETHTOWN, N. Y., Feb. 18  The state received almost 13,000 acres of wilderness land in the sixmillionacre Adirondack Forest Preserve today, without its costing a cent in state money.

title: Cleveland Strikers Back
description: CLEVELAND, Feb. 18 (UPI) Sanitation and street workers were back on the job today under a 14day restraining order that ended a twoday strike over a 10 per cent wage cut ordered by Mayor Ralph Perk in an economy move. City officials estimated that 2,800 tons of garbage had accumulated during the walkout.

title: OFFICIALS DECRY RENT INCREASES
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 18 City and town officials from New York's Westchester County appealed to key aides of the Price Commission today to halt rent increases that they contended were running as high as 50 per cent despite commission limitations.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: STATESVILLE, N.C., Feb. 18 (AP)Classes were suspended in all city schools today after a racial melee at Statesville High School yesterday left nine pupils injured, one seriously. School officials said that dozens of Negroes and whites were involved.

title: SAMUEL PALANKER
description: Samuel Patanker, a retired New York fur merchant, diedl Thursday in Miami, where he lived. His age was 75.

title: GRAEBER BEATEN IN U.S. TENNIS PLAY
description: SALISBURY, Md., Feb. 18 (AP)Haroon Rahim of Pakistan upset Clark Graebner tonight and advanced to the semifinals of the National open Indoor tennis championships.

title: State Aide Terms ExPatients Burden to Suffolk
description: HAUPPAUGE, L. I., Feb. 18  The deputy commissioner of the State Department of Mental Hygiene acknowledged today that localities were being forced to assume the burden of millions of dollars for the care of discharged state mental patients or whom the state should be paying.

title: Streets Closed by Water Main Break at Times Sq. to Open Tuesday
description: The huge bole in Broadway at 40th Street will be filled and both streets back in full service by Tuesday night, the City Department of Water Resources said last night.

title: JEWISH CHAPLAINS HEED VITAL NEED
description: The new chairman of the Commission on Jewish Chappliancy  part of the National Jewish Welfare Board called yesterday for a sharp increase of rabbis in the armed forces.

title: Bill Rates Are Mixed At Treasury Auction
Pasarell Defeats Stolle
description: TORONTO, Feb. 18 (AP)Charles Pasarell of Puerto Rico survived a shaky first set, then came on with a strong forehand to defeat Fred Stolle of Australia, 76, 63, in quarterfinal play today in the $50,000 Toronto international tennis tournament.

title: The 41nch Heel ReturnsBut This Time It's for Men
description: Mitch Meister is 5 feet 9 in his stocking feet. But when he's wearing his snappy, black and white oxfords with platforms and high heels, he's 6 feet 1. The shoes cost $45 at the JuJu boutique at 223 East 59th Street, and Mr. Meister, who is 25 and attending beauty culture school, said that neither the price nor the original discomfort of the shoes stopped him from buying them, or the other three pairs of fancy shoes and the wild pair of boots he owns.

title: The Talk of Portobello Road
description: LONDON, Feb. 18 Six oranges for 2 bob! Six oranges, 2 bob!

title: Comissiona Steps In to Conduct Clevelanders in Work by Husa
description: Sergiu Comissiona is missing his chance to bring his Baltimore Symphony Orchestra to Carnegie Hall this season, as scheduled, because it is on Ilstrike. But another conductor's illness, that of Paul Kletzki.1 brought him here as a replacement to lead the Cleveland Orchestra Thursday night in the same auditorium.

title: Angkor Gain Reported
description: PNOMPENH, Cambodia, Feb. 18 (Agence FrancePresse) Cambodian troops were reported today to have captured a temple in the western sector of the Angkor complex following 48 hours of bitter fighting.

title: AT HOME ABROAD
description: LONDON, Feb. 18  The House of Commons lends itself to drama. The overcrowded benches, the cockpit with the opponents only a pace or two apart  that is why, when the chamber was bombed, Churchill insisted on rebuilding it exactly as it had been.

title: A.F.L.C.I.O. Attacks U.S. China Policy
description: BAL HARBOUR, Fla., Feb. 18 The executive council of the American Federation of Labor and Congress of Industrial Organizations criticized today the Nixon Administration's new course toward mainland China in a foreign policy statement adopted at the federation's winter meeting.

title: Blackpool Doctor Is Charged With Stabbing Death of Girl.
description: BLACKPOOL, England, Feb. 18 (Reuters)  A 32yearold Jordanian doctor was charged today with stabbing a 4yearold girl to death in the children's ward of the hospital where he worked as an eye specialist.

title: Stopover in Anchorage
description: HONOLULU, Feb. 18 (AP)The White House today announced a change in the closing plase of the Presidential itinerary. On the return flight, iMr. Ziegler said, the President plans to spend the night of Feb. 27 at Anchorage, Alaska, after crossing the international, date line instead of proceeding directly to Washington.

title: 60 Buses Will Be Cut From Runs In Brooklyn, Assemblyman Says
description: An Assemblyman in Brooklyn charged yesterday that the Transit Authority was secretly dropping more than 60 buses from runs in that borough with the reduction to start over the Washington's Birthday weekend.

title: Books of The Times
description: EDMUND WILSON. By Leonard Kriegel. 145 pages. Southern Illinois University Press. $5.95. THE FICTION OP KATHERINE MANSFIELD.

title: Nixon, on Stopover in Hawaii, Spends Day of Study and Rest
description: HONOLULU. Feb. 18President Nixon spent most of the day in Hawaii today studying papers on China as he and Mrs. Nixon and their party rested in preparation for the next stage of their 11,500mile flight from Washington to Peking.

title: Seduction of Inga' at the New Embassy
description: As for "The Seduction of Inga," how many times can you get seduced? This listless, dull film from Sweden, with its "X" rating, will probably attract the same people who rushed to see "Inga" three years ago. Don't expect much at the New Embassy Theater. You'll got more of what you might expect at outright pornography showcases.Inga No. 2, featuring a story and terrible acting, tries to pass itself off as "adult" entertainment. The main business again, is nudity and lascivious wallowing."Yes, I'm back," coos dimple-cheeked Marie Liljedahl in the first scene. "Three years older." And no wiser, at 19. Holed up in a rundown boarding house, she eludes a rat-faced Lesbian and luckily falls into a genuine love affair with an older man. This episode could have yielded ,a perfectly sensible drama, even with a revelation of past incest.Anyway, this older chap, Lennart Lindberg, who gives the only performance in it, wisely checks out of the picture by committing suicide. Inga tangles with his daughter and finally skips off with a lippy, hippie guitarist. "Maybe I'll be back," purrs Miss Liljedahl on the dubbed-English soundtrack. "Who knows?" she adds. Honey, who cares?

title: St. Paul Protesters Shove Yevtushenko From College Stage
description: ST. PAUL. Feb. 18Yevgeny Yevtushenko, the Soviet poet, was shoved off a threefoothigh stage by several UkranianAmerican protesters tonight as he read his poetry at Macalester College.

title: U.S. IS DEVELOPING EVASIVE WARHEAD
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 18 (UPI)The United States is developing and will flighttest this year an experimental bal. listic warhead capable of evading hostile antiballistic missiles, the Pentagon said today.

title: E. 42D ST. CANDY SHOP AGAIN SHOOTING SITE
description: Policemen shot and fatally wounded a holdup man yesterday during a stakeout of a candy shop on East 42d Street the same Store where two men were killed during a police stakeout three weeks ago.

title: The Inner Circle Moves Toward Accepting Women
description: The Inner Circle, an organization of past and present male political writers, voted last night to set up a special committee to draw up constitutional changes relating to the admission of women members.

title: Bus Plunge Into Nile Canal Kills 70, Mostly Students
description: CAIRO, Feb. 18 (UPI)Seventy persons, most of them students, were killed Friday when the bus in which they were riding crashed into a wall and then plunged into an irrigation canal in the Nile Delta, the Middle East News Agency said.

title: N.C.A.A. Selectors Eying Villanova, Duquesne Fives
description: PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 18 (UPI) Villanova and Duquesne remained today among six teams being considered for three lEastern atlarge berths in the National Collegiate basketball tournament.

title: Yankees Say DiMaggio Wants Job With Club
description: FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., Feb. I8The possibility that Joe DiMaggio, whose No. 5 uniform has already been retired by the New York Yankees, might return to the club in the near future in some front office or public relations capacity was confirmed today by club officials.

title: IMOVERN, LINDSAY BACK ABZUG DISTRICT
description: Senator George McGovern and Mayor Lindsay deplored yesterday any Congressional redistricting that would break up the Manhattan Congressional District represented by Bella Abzug.

title: GEORGE RIFKIN DIES; LABOR LAWYER, 65
description: George Rifkin, a lawyer who specialized in labor cases, died Thursday of a heart attack in Peninsula Hospital, Rockaway Beach, Queens. He was 65 years old and lived at 433 Beach 138th Street, Rockaway Beach.

title: AirlineRun Tour Of Disney World Called Too Costly
description: Eastern Airlines charges notsomagical prices on its package tours of the Magic Kingdom, Consumer Reports said yesterday.

title: Painful Steps Toward Europe
description: Prime Minister Heath's eightvote majority for British entry into the Common Market in a House of Commons of 630 is a rude reminder of the crucial ground yet be covered in building a bigger, stronger European Community. At stake was not only the life of Mr. Heath's Conservative Government but the fateful question whether Britain, at a symbolic two minutes to midnight, would again turn its back on Europe.

title: U.S. SAYS PLANES HIT TWO CONVOYS
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Feb. 18 (Al')  The United States command reported today that its fighterbombers smashed at two enemy convoys in the Central Highlands in the course of nearly 150 raids on enemy targets in South Vietnam.

title: Meriwether, Washington Run Dead Heat in Sprint
description: Dr. Delano Meriwether dispelled notions that he might be a oneyear wonder in track and field, and Dave Wottle confirmed his status as one of America's coming milers last night at Madison Square Garden.

title: MARKET BLOC LISTS PRIORITIES FOR UNION
description: BRUSSELS, Feb. 18 (Reuters) The European Common Market Commission today issued a paper listing priorities to reestablish the process of economic and monetary union held up by the world currency crisis.

title: Miss Casals Gains Final
description: OKLAHOMA CITY, Feb. 18 (AP)  Rosemary CasaIs and Valerie Ziegenfuss advanced to the singles finals of the Virginia Slims invitation tennis tournament tonight. Miss Ziegenfuss defeated Mrs. Judy Dalton of Australia, 63, 62, and Miss Casals defeated Betty Stove of the Netherlands, 63, 61.

title: Campaign Notes
description: WINTER PARK, Fla., Feb. 18The banners on the train that rolled south from Jacksonville this morning said Muskie Sunshine Special, but inside the coaches and parlor cars they were talking about a man named George C. Wallace. Much of the conversation centered on a Florida poll just completed for the star of today's whistlestop extravaganza, Senator Edmund S. Muskie of Maine. The first bits of data from the survey provoked no gaiety in the Muskie staff.

title: Pacer Dies in Stall
description: WESTBURY, L. I., Feb. 18Frank T. Ace, who had drawn the No. 1 post for the fourth race tomorrow night, died of twisted intestine in his stall today. The gelding was 12 years old.

title: Mondale Appeals for End Of Efforts to Bar Busing
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 18 Senator Walter F. Mondale, saying that a twoyear inquiry by a select Senate committee had pointed up the need for continuing school desegregation, made an impassioned plea to the Senate today to avoid standing in the schoolhouse door on the emotional issue of busing.

title: Five on Transport Killed After Collision With a Jet
description: LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Feb. 18 (AP)  An Air Force jet trainer and a transport plane with five men aboard collided in the air and crashed 15 miles north of here tonight, killing all five crewmen aboard the transport the Air Force said.

title: Photographer Tells the Court His Story
description: A freelance photographer, Ronald E. Galella, testified yesterday that Mrs. Aristotle Onassis had told a Secret Service man, John Connelly, to smash his camera after he had taken pictures of her and her son, John, in Central Park on Sept. 24, 1961

title: SUGAR FUTURES SHOW PRICE RISE
description: The world faces a shortage of sugar for the next two years, an Associated Press dispatch from London, quoting European sugar traders, said yesterday. The shortage, the traders believe, will be due to failures of cane crops in the Western Hemisphere and inadequate factory capacity and warehouse space. in Western Europe.

title: Stock Markets Closed
description: All securities and commodities exchanges in the United States will be closed Monday in observance of Washington's birthday. Many banks and other financial institutions also will be closed as will most governmental offices. The postal service will operate on a holiday schedule with no regular mail deliveries.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Don't Frighten the Plants
description: Time was when vegetables made The Wall Street Journal's news columns only by way of the price of soybeans. But in these somewhat mystic days one can read on The Journal's front page about experiments suggesting that plants worry at the approach of a rough gardener and eggs faint when about to be dropped into boiling water.

title: Shop Talk
description: After taking a back seat to lightweight and transparent plastics for more than a decade, marble is making a comeback in furniture design. Gae Aulenti, the Milanese architectdesigner, has masterminded a lowslung, chunky table of the durable weighty material (in its shipping crate it weighs 550 pounds). Measuring 44inches square, the coffee table has legs made of two marble columns joined by a marble slab, making it appear even heavier.

title: Art Opener In Boston: Jack Bush
description: BOSTONThe Museum of Fine Arts, which has been under increasing attack in recent years for its neglect of the contemporary art scene, inaugurated its new department of contemporary art this week with an exhibition devoted to the work of Jack Bush, Canada's leading abstract painter. At the same time, the museum placed on display the new department's first acquisitiona painting by the late Jackson Pollock entitled Number 10, dating from 1949.

title: Fund Set for L.I.U. Library
description: The State Dormitory Authority has approved a $9million loan to help finance the construction of a librarylearning center at the Brooklyn Center of Long Island University, Dr. Albert BushBrown, the university chancellor, said yesterday. Construction of the building, at the corner of Flatbush Avenue Extension and DeKalb Avenue on the Zeckendorf Campus is scheduled to begin in June.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Notes On Metropolitan Congressmen
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 18Senator Jacob K. Javits, who used to try to play peacemaker between Governor Rockefeller and Mayor Lindsay, doesn't see much hope for that role in the near future. I tried, the Republican Senator from New York said in an interview. I think for now everybody has to cool off. I hope we have reached the high  water mark of the deterioration of that relationship [between the Mayor and Governor].

title: CALIFORNIA COURT, IN 64 VOTE, BARS DEATH SENTENCES
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 18Capital punishment was declared unconstitutional today in the State of California.

title: Penn Routs Brown, 9066, Nears Ivy League Title
Drinart Told by Officer
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 15 (AP) The restriction was acknowledged after Represenative Drinan sent Secretary Chafee a letter with a list of 15 schools that a Navy officer said he had been given as places where he could not take graduate work.

title: ShowStopping at Met
description: LA FILM DU REGIMENT. Opera by Clonlzattl In two ads, Libretto by J. H, Vernov de SaintGeorgoe end F. Bayard. Staged by Sandra Seoul. Sets by Anna Annl. Costumes by Marcel Exert?ler. Conducted by Richard Bon. vnge. At the Metropolitan Owe.

title: McCarthy Finds Students Have Changed Since 68
description: CHICAGO, Feb. 16  From among the 2,500 students, a bearded young man looking very serious and concerned stood and asked Eugene J. McCarthy the question that persistently pursued the Democratic Presidential candidate on a swing this week through Illinois and Wisconsin.

title: Taipei Can Coexist With Peking
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass.China is not new land settled by nineteenthcentury pioneers devoted to selfdetermination. The Chinese have a distinctly non. American background. We cannot settle Taiwan's status by moving in and holding a plebiscite as in Kansas or Nebraska. The concept of Taipei's autonomy under Peking's sovereignty comes from two thousand years experience in the world's largest political unit, which invented bureaucracy and civil service examinations when Europe was still in the Dark Ages. This central sovereignty and local autonomy concept has at least three components.

title: Judge J. Warren Madden Dead; First Head of N R. B. Was 82
description: J. Warren Madden, a senior judge of the United States Court of Claims, and first chairman of the National Labor Relations Board, died Thursday in his sleep in San Francisco. He was 82 years old.

title: ALLISON IS VICTOR IN DAYTONA RACE
description: DAYTONA BEACH, Fla., Feb. 18  A drenching rainstorm whipped by winds of up to 41 miles an hour transformed a stockcar race into a muddy skidwity for a while here today. The winner slid off course four times in one lap and an earlier leader needed to be towed out of the mud twice in one lap.

title: The President's Reception
description: What kind of reception will Nixon receive in China?

title: Sports of The Times
description: In the paneled conference room of the Milwaukee law firm of Cahill, Fox and Smith late Thursday night, the only 6foot11inch political science junior at Marquette University letlned down to sign a contract that had been arranged with the New York Nets after several hours of negotiation.

title: Pavarotti Thrilled by Bravos For His Singing in Met's Fille
description: Luciano Pavarotti, who burst into opera superstardom Thursday night with the spectacularity and force of a supernova, was so ecstatic yesterday that he could scarcely sit still for an interview.

title: Patents of the Week
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 18The RCA Corporation has installed at its laboratories in Zurich, Switzerland, what it calls the world's first lockandkey system based on a lasermade hologram. Patent 3,643,216 was granted this week to David L. Green. away and John P. Russell, members of the technical staff at the laboratories.

title: MurphyPromotes Dynamic Duo
description: Two young policemen known as Batman and Robin who have stalked through the tough BedfordStuyvesant section of Brooklyn for more than three years, making 600 arrests and collecting about 90 illegal weapons, were promoted to detectives yesterday.

title: U.S. WON'T COMMENT ON CAIRO SPY REPORT
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 18The State Department spokesman declined today to confirm or deny reports that an American woman diplomat was arrested by Egyptian authorities last year and accused of involvement in a spy ring.

title: BONANNO JR. SEIZED IN CONSPIRACY CASE
description: SAN JOSE, Calif., Feb. 18 (UPI)The Federal Bureau of Investigation announced today the arrest of Joe Bonanno Jr., son of a reputed one time Mafia leader in New York, on a conspiracy charge.

title: METER MAID HELD AS BRIBE SUSPECT
description: Husband Is Also Accused of $2,500 Extortion

title: AMBROSE SETS UP DRUG DRIVE BASES
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 15 Myles J. Ambrose, the new special Assistant Attorney General for the prosecution of streetlevel drug pushers, said today that he expected to have grand juries at work on indictments by May I.

title: Democrats Again Denied Equal Television Time
description: The Democratic National Committee has been rebuffed again in its efforts to receive free television time to respond to appearances by President Nixon.

title: SALES EXCEEDED BY FUND CASIIINS
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 18Redemptions of mutual fund shares exceeded sales in January on a seasonally adjusted basis, though not on an actual cash basis, the Investment Company Institute reported today.

title: Miss Davis Seeks Bail
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 18 (AP)An attorney for Angela Davis said today that her defense would ask immediately that she be freed on bail.

title: Bollinger's Ramps Shown Downtown
description: Minimal artist Bill Bollinger has been so given to experimentation in his work that each show of his during the last five years has been different. He has exhibited chainlink fences, steel barrels and plastic hoses filled with water, ropes and lamp bulbs whose twisted cords snaked their way through the display. He once sprayed one gallery floor with gray deck paint and covered another with graphite. Behind the diversity of efforts, however, lay a common characteristic: a strong interest in industrial materials and a respect for their properties and uses. Mr. Bollinger treated the materials, it seemed, with the casualness of a construction worker, piling and leaning them here and hanging them there. The works were virtually nothing more than statements of their own

title: Antiques: China's Finds
description: President Nixon's trip and the relaxation of some trade bars with China have spurred the hopes of antiques collectors, but the easing of relationships will not do much to make additional treasures available.

title: Leon J. Rubinstein, 83, A MotionPicture Pioneer
description: Leon J. Rubinstein, a motionpicture pioneer, died last evening of burns suffered during the afternoon when a heat lamp set fire to his clothing. He was 83 years old.

title: Pakistanis Have a Big Refugee Problem of Their Own
description: LAHORE, Pakistan, Feb. 15The number of Pakistanis left homeless or landless by the December. war with India and now seeking Government relief has swollen to nearly 1.5 million, adding an enormous burden to the shattered economy.

title: Casey Says S.E.C. Weighs A Spur to Venture Capital
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 18 William J. Casey, chairman of the Securities and Exchangel Commission, disclosed today that hi agency is considering changes in its rules that would make it easier for small, new companies to raise money from highly sophisticated investors.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Police Find Bare Facts And Loot in Robbery

title: F.A.A. Discloses Union Vote
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 18 (AP) The Federal Aviation Administration said today that the National Association of Air Traffic Specialists had won a nationwide election to represent more than 3,000 F.A.A. flight service station specialists. The election, under auspices of the Labor Department, gave the association about 66 per cent of the total votes cast, and the National Association of Government Employees about 20 per cent.

title: Scout Who Inspired Rockefeller Gift Remains Cool
description: Anthony Louis Giobbie, the 16  year  old Explorer Scout whose speech on the benefits of Scouting inspired Governor Rockefeller to pledge about $100,000 to the cause, is, in the words of his teacher, too calm to have his head turned around by all the excitement that resulted.

title: Nixon in ChinaA Political Pilgrim
description: Some incurable optimists would have us see Mr. Nixon in Peking as an American Moses confronting Mao, the Chinese Pharaoh, with a divine mandate to convert at once and return to the family of nations. Needless to say, this religious analogy, projected and enhanced with moralistic rhetoric, is an impious fraud. There has been no missionary mandate from God, Church or Country to Go Down Nixon. Neither has there been any appeal from godless selfgod Mao to Come, let us reason together. The plain truth is that the President of the United States is a mendicant pilgrim to Peking. And perhaps the most depressing aspect of this truth is that he is mere political pilgrim.

title: Peking Drafting Best Chefs to Prepare Delicacies for U.S. Visitors
description: foreigners commit at the first banquet. Principal among these is the tendency to tuck in too generously at the beginning of the meal, only to find there is no appetite left for the later delicacies.

title: Deaf Man Robbed, 2 Jailed
description: OAKLAND, Calif., Feb. 18 (TMAlameda County Superior Court Judge Harold D. Hove sentenced two Berkeley men yesterday to one year to life in prison for beating and robbing a 26yearold deaf man. Charles L. Bastin Jr., 22, and Michael Breckenridge, 19, drew the sentence after admitting the robbery'.

title: BOULEZ CONDUCTS VA.RESE'S'ARCANA
description: Arcane, built in 1927 by Edgard Varese, remains a wondrous machine. Listening to Pierre Boulez and the New York Philharmonic play the score Thursday night, one found himself thinking of those glistening pieces of model machinery that may be seen at fairs and exhibitions. Through glass windows the gears may be observed smoothly meshing and shifting, and the shiny pistons pumping.

title: QUIXOTE GIVEN BY CITY BEET
description: George Balanchine's ballet, Don Quixote, which was given with some new choreography and a few production changes by the New York City Ballet Thursday night at the State Theater, is a work of very modern sensibility.

title: Treasury Aide Asks Change
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 15 (AP) A high Treasury official has told Canadian officials that special trading relationships with that country are biased in its favor and must be changed.

title: PEKING SUMS UP ITS DIFFERENCES WITH U.S. POLICY
description: HONG KONG, Feb. 18 Peking accused the Nixon Administration today of continuing policies of aggression and war.

title: Bank Rule Proposed
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 18 (AP) The Federal Reserve Board proposed regulations today designed to permit big bank holding companies to lease real estate under strict conditions.

title: Naked Apes, He ays, Need a Lot of Loving
description: A desire to return to the warmth and security of the womb, far from being retrogressive and infantile, is perfectly natural and even admirable, in the opinion of 41yearold Desmond Morris, English biologist and ethologist, who has followed up his international best seller, The Naked Ape, with what he describes as a book about love. It's called Intimate Behaviour and lives up in every way to its title.

title: Hartford Lists Jobless Rise
description: HARTFORD, Feb. 18 (UPI) The state unemployment rate at the end of a 13week reporting period last week was 8.3 per cent, up from 8.1 per cent the previous week and 7.7 per cent in 1971, the State Labor Department said today. Unemployment compensation claims totaled 112,140. the department said, down 4,052 from the total 116,192 the previous week.

title: Oltun Says He Is Doubtful Administration's Policy Will Achieve Goals
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 18A leading Democratic economist told Congress today that the Administration's fiscal policy, despite the huge budget deficit, was probably not stimulative enough to achieve the nation's economic goals this year.

title: Taxi Generation Gap
description: The semiofficial strike that has taken about onetenth of the city's medallion taxicabs off the streets has had little adverse effect on riders but it does point up fundamental inequity in the still unsigned pact that ended the citywide taxi strike fourteen months ago. The settlement, which the union now insists it never agreed to, provided that veteran drivers would get commission amounting to 49 per cent of the fares they collect but newcomers to the industry would get only 42 per cent.

title: WARRANT ISSUED IN POLICE SLAYING
description: A Detroit man shot and captured in a gun battle with St. Louis police on Tuesday was named in a Criminal Court warrant here last night as one of the gunmen who killed Patrolmen Rocco W. Laurie and Gregory P. Foster in the East Villagel on Jan. 27.

title: Moroccan Parties Protest the Decision on Charter
description: RABAT, Morocco, Feb, 18Morocco's two major political parties protested today against a decision by King Hassan II to submit a new, more liberal constitution to a popular referendum March 1.

title: Firehouse TV Set Stolen
description: KALAMAZOO, Mich., Feb. 18 (UPI)The fire alarm was false but the robbery was for real. When firemen returned to their station on Bryant Street last night they discovered that their television set had been stolen.

title: 2 Fined for Shooting Eagles
description: CHEYENNE, Wyo., Feb. 18 (AP)Two men pleaded guilty in Federal District Court today to shooting eagles from aircraft over a Wyoming ranch in 1970. Judge Ewing T. Kerry said that the men had promised to cooperate with Federal officials in future major prosecutions of eagle deaths. He then fined Norm DeVilbiss 8200 and Delbert Jenkins $100 and placed them on six months probation.

title: Senator Anderson Backs Jackson for Nomination
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 Senator Henry M. Jackson of Washington was endorsed for the Democratic Presidential nomination today by Senator Clinton P. Anderson of New Mexico.

title: Wendy Millar To Be a Bride
description: BOSTON, Feb. 19  John Young Millar of Washington, a Foreign Service officer who is now political officer in the Embassy in Lagos, Nigeria, and Mrs. Eluned McLaren Millar of Boston have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Gwendolen (Wendy) McLaren Millar, to John David Phillips Jr., son of Mrs. Phillips of Riverside, Conn. The wedding is planned for May 13 in Sudbury.

title: Leafs Top Sabres, 41
description: TORONTO, Feb. 19 (UPI)Richard Martin's 39th goal of the season established an N.H.L. record for goals by a rookie tonight but was not enough for the Buffalo Sabres, who lost to the Toronto Maple Leafs, 41. Darryl Sittler scored three goals for the Leafs.

title: Philadelphia Dance Theater Makes Local Debut
description: Philadelphia has a deserved reputation for dull conservatism, which was enhanced Friday evening at the Dance Theater Workshop. A group calling itself the Dance Theater of Philadelphia, which almost seems a contradiction in terms, presented its first concert in New York.

title: Mrs. Chisholm Accuses Press Of Racism and Sexism in Hiring
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 19Representa tive Shirley Chisholm accused newspapers today of racism and sexism in their employment policies.

title: Miss Lucy Downing Blundon. Will Be Bride of Christopher S. Biddle
description: McLEAN, Va., Feb. 19Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Montague Blundon Jr. of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Lucy Downing Blundon, to Christopher Stark Biddle, son of Mrs. Sydney G. Biddle of Cuttingsville, Vt., and Philadelphia, and the late Dr. Biddle.

title: Harris Wins Marathon
description: PORTALES, N.M., Feb. 19 (AP)Charles Harris won the Eastern New Mexico University 26mile marathon run today, covering the 26 miles and 385 yards in 2 hours 29 minlutes 59 seconds.

title: Historical Museum to Get $700,000 Renovation
description: NEWARK  On a. crisp January morning in 1845, 20 men gathered in Trenton at the request of Gov. Daniel Haines to compile the state's voluminous but scattered historical records. Six weeks later, The New Jersey Historical Society was formed.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: Our Obsolete Black List

title: Tales of an Airline Reservations Clerk
description: ISPEND eight hours a day on the telephone, which makes about 9,600 hours a year. I have been doing this for the past four years, so I've heard from a great many of you when you call up to make an airline reservation.

title: LETTERS
description: To the Financial Editor:

title: HERO OF RAHWAY GETS STATE JOB
description: PATERSON  James C. Garrett, 26yearold father of four, picked up his life again last week, along with a state job much like the one he held in Hackensack the day he was arrested in July, 1970.

title: Grant Takes Peking (1879)
description: PRINCETON, N. J.When President Nixon arrives in China today on an unprecedented state visit, he will not be the first American President to have set foot on that nation's shores. Nearly one hundred years ago, while the Manchu dynasty still held sway over the crumbling Chinese Empire, Gen. Ulysses S. Grant entered the gates of Peking and was borne in an imperial palanquin into the heart of the Forbidden City.

title: Art
description: NAME a 17th  century Dutch painter. Well, there's Rembrandt of course. And Vermeer the miraculous. And Hals too. And all those socalled Little DutchmenIs the term still used?Terborch, Jan Steen, de Hooch, the others. And Honthorstl The Caravaggio of the north. Those, to begin with. And all those marvelous landscapists  van Goyen, Ruisdael, the others. De Heem and all, for still life. Then those wonderful isolated individuals.

title: WOMEN'S SCHOOL GETS A NEW ROLE
description: NEW BRUNSWICK Two disparate demandsfor building space and women's libhave combined to bring change in the structure of the higher educational system in the state.

title: Miss Millicent McKinley Affianced
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 Mrs. William Slagle McKinley has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Millicent Ogden McKinley, to Thomas Storke Co; son of Mr. and Mrs. E. Morris Cox of San Francisco. A wedding in June is planned.

title: The World
description: The World

title: British Trackmen Beat Spain
description: COSFORD, England, Feb. 19 (AP)  David Bedford ran a spectacular 3,000 meters today and led Britain to victory over Spain in an indoor track duel meet, 7652. The flamboyant, bearded distance runner won easily in 8 minutes 8/10 of a second.

title: Valerie Croy Metz To Be Wed May 5
description: Miss Valerie Croy Metz plans to be married May 5 in Paris to Philippe de Boissieu.

title: U.S. BUSINESS ROUNDUP
description: Projects aimed at stimulating what some have termed black capitalism and others refer to as minority business enterprise have been publicly and privately undertaken in considerable number and with much fanfareand mixed resultsin recent years.

title: After 59 Years. Dartmouth Topples Yale in Swimming
description: HANOVER, N. H., Feb. 1911 Fiftynine years of frustration for Dartmouth's swimming teams ended today as the Indians defeated Yale, 6350, in an Eastern Intercollegiate League meet at Karl Michael Pool. The Elis had defeated Dartmouth 46 straight times.

title: Brigham Young Hires Aide
description: PROVO, Utah, Feb. 19 (AP) Brigham Young University has announced the hiring of Jim Criner, an assistant football coach at the University of California, Berkeley, as defensive line coach.

title: The World
description: CAMOIF was an eventful week in Egypt as the country's leaders met for a somber study of the realities of the present and the challenges of the future.

title: BURMA IS HOPEFUL OF OIL IN THE SEA
description: RANGOON, Burma, Feb. 9An American oilclrilling operation 50 miles off the Tern'serim coast has become the focus of Government hopes for an early surge in Burma's lagging socialized economy.

title: FOREIGN AFFAIRS
description: CALCUTrA, IndiaOn Jan. 6, 1962, a special emissary of President Kennedy speculated in New Delhi whether Pakistan would be stupid enough to make an alliance with Communist China and then asked: How long would Asia survive without a strong, Independent India? Nine days later the same emissary said in Calcutta it would be inconsistent 'on the part of Pakistan to have a military alliance with Communist China as well as the United States though Pakistan has recognized Communist China.

title: Regrets in Akron: A Sure Thing Fails
description: AKRON, Ohio, Feb. 19You always heard the expression the rich get richer. I thought maybe this is what they meant. It wasn't.

title: Nixons Leave Hawaii
description: HONOLULU, Feb. 19 (AP)President Nixon and his party left Hawaii today on the semifinal leg of his historymaking 11,500mile journey to China.

title: Euro Slump: Is It Myth?
description: FRANKFURT, West GermanyDiether H. Hoffmann, a member of the board of management of the Bank ftir Gemeinwirtschaft here, presents anything but the image of starched elegance that is typical of the German banker.

title: Corps of Engineers Caught Up in Battle Of the Builders Against the Preservers
description: The nation's largest and most venerable builder, the Army Corps of Engineers, is for the first time in 170 years meeting widespread and relentless opposition to its digging, dredging and damming of the American landscape.

title: Princeton Sets Back Yale In Ivy Wrestling, 16 to 15
description: NEW HAVEN, Feb. 19 Princeton's defending Ivy League champions defeated Yale's wrestling team, 1615, at the Payne Whitney Gym today.

title: Navy Shipyard to Cut Jobs
description: BOSTON, Feb. 19 (AP)Capt. Raymond W. Burk, the commandant of the Boston Naval Shipyard announced today lie had been directed to cut the numher of civilian emDioyes by 41S, from 5,735 317.

description: To the Editor:

title: St. Lawrence Hockey Victor
description: CANTON, N. Y., Feb. 19 (AP) Two goals in the final period gave St. Lawrence a 75 hockey victory over Boston College tonight.

title: Suit Blocking Pittsburgh's Skybus Plan
description: PITTSBURGH, Feb. 19 The automated Skybus rapid transit vehicle, designed to be the keystone of the Pittsburgh region's mass transit system, is encountering problems in Allegheny County.

title: TV Mailbag:
description: To THE EDITOR:

title: Yachting on the Rocks: A Winter Wonderland
description: The recorded message on the special answeringservice phone was encouraging: We have hard saltwater ice, there'll be sailing on Saturday. With that assurance, members of the North Shrewsbury Iceboating and Yacht Club turned out last weekend for a regatta on the Navesinlc River in Red Bank, N.J. They were insulated for subzero temperatures: wool shirt, wool sweater, wool pants and heavy quilted zip suit of dacron that covered them from neck to feet.

title: Princeton Six Tops Yale
description: PRINCETON, N.J., Feb. 19Wait Snickenberger and Paul McNamara scored two goals each today to lift Princeton to a 61 hockey victory over Yale. The Tigers rallied from a 31 deficit late in the second period to break a string of 21 consecutive Ivy League defeats.I Princeton now has a league wonlost record of 17. YaleI is 28.

title: DEMOCRATS VOTE DELEGATE CHANGE
description: ORISKANY, N. Y., Feb. 19The Democratic State Committee decided today to name 10 per cent of the 278 delegates from New York to the party's national convention in Miami next July.

title: Annette Baser a Bride
description: RAHWAY, N. J., Feb. 19Miss Annette Katherine Baser and James Bruce Boisture were married here at noon today in the Zion Lutheran Church. The Rev. Walter Maier and the Rev. Kenneth King officiated. The parents of the couple are Mr. and Mrs. Fred Rich Baser and Mr. and Mrs. Worth William Boisture, all of Scotch Plains. The bride is a senior at the Moore College of Art in Philadelphia and her husband expects to be graduated in June from Princeton University's Woodrow Wilson School of Public and International Affairs. He will do graduate work at Oxford University.

title: Science Medicine
description: A girl on her way to work steps briskly from her Shanghai apartment, pokes her head in a door down the street and says, mark me down for today! then continues on.

title: Fluke Eggs Fertilized in LI. Lab
description: STONY BROOK, L. I.,In another generation or two, Americans may be able to enjoy fish produced commercially in hatcheries as the result of a work at the Flax Pond Marine Laboratory here and at other institutions.

title: $30,000 Clean Air Tennis Begins Play Tomorrow
description: Will New York tennis fans support a major international indoor tournament?

title: CITY IS STALLING BUILDING BUDGET
description: City officials expect to stall a final decision on schools, libraries, health centers and other projects in the capital budget until action by the Legislature on three citysponsored financing devices.

title: Fred Haliger, 75, Founded Technical Institute Here
description: Fred F. Flediger, founder and director of the American Technical Institute in Brooklyn, which prepares men for careers in building and plant management, died Thursday of a heart attack at his home, 326 54th Stret, Brooklyn. He was 75 years old.

title: Are a moneyless society and a bloodless revolution possible?; Right to Challenge; Peopte and Power in the Steelworkers Union. By John Herling. 415 pp. New York: Harper & Row. $12.50
description: Behind the fraternal facade of a movement in which every carrier of a union card is automatically brother often rage intrigues of such malevolence that Machiavelli would be hard pressed to make business agent and Benedict Arnold, shop steward. In this fascinating book John Herling, who has devoted a lifetime to affectionate observation of labor's rise (or descent) from penury to power, provides a closeup view of two decades of infighting in one of the country's strongest unions, the 1.2millionmember United Steelworkers of America.

title: FERGUSON'S BAND IS A POWERHOUSE
description: The English jazz band that Maynard Ferguson formed in 1968 and brought to this country for the first time last fall arrived with an advance reputation, based on its recordings, as one of the best bands Mr. Ferguson has led in the last 15 years.

title: The bystander will never know
description: The time is now, in New York and Boston. The hero is in his twenties, bearded and workshirted. You might expect lifestyle to be at issue. Or politics. Or technOlogy. Or new realms of awareness. But Skate's problem has nothing much to do with the times he lives in. He is not involved in the Revolution or any of its varieties. He's troubled by one of the timeless paradoxes: the web of deceptions that govern men's lives. He's so troubled by this in itself, he can fix on no specific commitment except talk and solitude.

title: Plenty Old Is Plenty Fast
description: NEW ORLEANS, Feb. 19 (AP) Plenty Old ran six furlongs in 1:10 to win the $20,000 Pelleteri Handicap by a neck today at the Fair Grounds. The winner paid 8.80, 4.20 and 2.80 for $2 across the board. Windgusher was second and Joe Frazier finished third.

title: Boom in Cooling Towers
description: Thanks largely to environmentalists, these are happy days fur companies that make cooling towers.

title: Motel Isn't Home to Those on Welfare
description: LYNBROOK, L. I.  Mrs. Edith Hughes and Mrs. Katherine Brown have learned that even a wellappointed motel is not conducive to the nutrition, stability, harmony or health of families forced to stay there month after month.

title: About Pro Football
description: Larry Csonka, the Miami Dolphins fullback now in repose at home in Plantation, Fla., between dinner engagements, modified yesterday a criticism he had made earlier of President Nixon's role as a football fan.

title: Photography
description: THE two most evil technical inventions to date, wrote the poet W.H. Auden recently, are the internal combustion engine and the camera. I agree with Mr. Auden wholeheartedly about the internal combustion engine, at least when I am walking in New York or driving out of New York on Friday night after work or even trying to breathe near a New York bus. And I agree with him about the camera when I go to a party and find among the guests a man with a camera and a flash

title: Schenk Leads in World Skating
description: OSLO, Norway, Feb. 19Ard Schenk, a triple Olympic champion from the Netherlands, won the 5,000meter race, shared first place in the 500 and took the overall lead today as he bid for his third straight world speedskating championship.

title: Frank Canosa, Columbia Junior, Is Fiance of Gloria de Aragon
description: Dr. and Mrs. Carlos Marquez Sterling of New York, formerly of Havana, gave a reception at their home last night to announce the engagement of Mrs. Sterling's daughter, Miss Gloria de Aragon, to Frank Canosa, son of Dr. and Mrs. Frank Canosa of Coral Gables, Fla., formerly of Havana.

title: Pop
description: JOHN KONGOS: Kongos (Elektra EKS75019). John Kongos's debut album takes off with a wildly exciting original, Tokoloshe Man. Playing rock n roll style guitar backed by a rhythm section that includes primitive African percussion instruments (talking drum, thunder drum, ass's jawbone), he creates rich and unusual tapestry of sound. A South African living in England, Kogos infuses all his songs with a compelling that doesn't stop even during occasional string and horn parts that would turn a lesser artist to mush. Kongos writes his own material, either alone or in collaboration with others, and he produces simple, direct lyrics. He comes across on the ballad selections as a far better musician than singer because his vocal techniques are not quite up to conveying soft and subtle emotions, Nevertheless, he does possess a unique, exhilarating sound that distinguishes him from most of the other newcomers to the music scene.

title: WORKRELIEF LAW IS TARGET OF SUIT
description: New York State's eightmonthold workrelief law is being challenged before a threejudge Federal Court. convening in Buffalo next Thursday, on the ground that it allegedly violates the Federal constitutional ban on involuntary servitude and Federal requirements for clue process.

title: U.S., Seoul Conclude Pact In Food for Peace Program
description: SEOUL, South Korea, Feb. 19 The United States has concluded an agreement here to provide $150 million worth of rice, wheat, corn and cotton to South Korea on concessional loan terms.

title: School Title Game Goes Eight Overtime Periods
description: Eight overtime periods were played before Philadelphia's Suburban One high school basketball title was won by PlymouthWhitemarsh, 6563, over Springfield on Friday night. Instead of 32 minutes, the game went 56.

title: Shorter Reviews
description: By the turn of this century the big sailing vesselsAmerican, British, German, French, Scandinavian  that regularly made the passage around Cape Horn were being driven off the seas by steam competition, a doom sealed by the construction of the Panama Canal. They stretched the number of their days by carrying cargoes no one else wanted. The ships were beauties; but the men who worked them, handicapped by the inadequacy of their cargomoving equipment, were serfs.

title: Linda Baker Engaged
description: PRINCETON, N. J., Feb. 19 The engagement of Miss Linda Anne Baker, a senior at Radcliffe College, to Donald Freeman Bogue, who is a junior at Harvard, has been announced by Mrs. Wolcott Newberry Baker, mother of the future bride. Her fiance is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard Freeman Bogue of Portland, Ore. A September wedding is planned.

title: Pop
description: EMERSON, LAKE AND PALMER: Pictures at an Exhibition/No More Walls (Cotillion ELP 66666). The crossbreeding of classical and popular music is no new phenomenon. Of late, however, efforts at breaking down the traditional barriers that have separated the oldtime longhairs from the newtime longhairs have been increasing in popularity. Ignoring the whole question of rock operas we have delta appearing on the stage of Carnegie Hall with the Rochester Philharmonic, The New York Rock Ensemble has on occasion appeared (and performed along) with the New York Chamber Soloists. And even old Johann Sebastian snuck his way up the top40 charts a few years ago with no less a hit than the Lovers Concerto.

title: JAZZ MUSICIAN SLAIN IN NIGHTCLUB FIGHT
description: Lee Morgan, a wellknown jazz trumpet player, was shot and killed early yesterday at Slugs, an East Village nightclub at 243 East Third Street where his quintet was playing.

title: Sports of The Times
description: When Joe Garagiola was a 20yearold rookie catcher on the St. Louis Cardinals he made four hits in one World Series game and had a Series batting average of 316. After that rousing start he settled down to studying the art of hitting from his vantage point behind the plate and eventually too much knowledge left him with an unimpressive career average of 257. Joe likes to pretend that he is disappointed every year when he fails to be elected to the Hall of Fame, but this is merely a running gag that comes in handy on occasions. Such an occasion came not long ago when the reformed catcher served as toastmaster for a baseball luncheon. Among those on the dais were Yogi Berra, his nextdoor neighbor as a boy in St. Louis, and Joe Medwick, the baseball idol of his youth. Both have made it to Cooperstown and yet both were notorious badball hitters.

title: Cadman Towers Fights Symbol Of MiddleClass Housing Plight
description: Thirteen years ago, after Robert Moses proposed to raze scores of quaint old houses in Brooklyn Heights and replace them with gleaming new apartment towers, residents argued fiercely over whether the new housing should be for the welltodo or the middle class.

title: Tennessee Swimmers Win
description: NASHVILLE, Tenn. Feb. 18 (AP)  Tennessee's swimmers, routed Southern MethoiliMethods,t University. 82321 today for their 33d dualmeet victory in a row.

title: Art
description: FERNANDO BOTERO, currently showing at the Marlborough Gallery, Is a 39yearold Colombian painter possessed of enormous skill and a very sharp, shrewd wit. He works in a style that might facetiously be called Historical Camp Surrealism, a seamless, highly personal pastiche of Magritte, Rubens, Spanish colonial portraiture, Early Italian and Popor some such mix; you get the idea. He is, in any case, an interesting phenomenon: a provincial painter, from a culture in which the visual arts have for the most part been either derivative or naive, who has managed to turn the obvious handicaps of his background to

title: New Novel
description: In John Ball's political fantasy, the U.S.A. is betrayed, defeated and occupied by a foreign power. This is accomplished because sonic of our leaders are pretty dense  an unarguable assumption. Thank heaven the enemy's leaders are just as dumb, and some are even dumber. This allows a terrific American undercover operation, The First Team, to grab the ball and try for a touchdown against the invaders, who have names like Rostovilch and Zalinsky. Chills, thrills and plenty of strain on the credulity.

title: New Scout Program
description: A scouting unit for blind or nearblind boys has been formed in Brooklyn. Those interested should call Larry AnteII at TR 54900 or write to Irving Cohen at 3000 Brighton 12th Street, Brooklyn, NE Y. 11235.

title: Sinan
description: A long, slowmoving, lovingly detailed biography of Joseph Sinan, the slave who became royal architect in the 16th century and for 50 years built some of Istanbul's most beautiful mosques, as well as, the author says, more buildings than any other architect who has ever lived. There really isn't enough factual material available for a proper biography; as a result the author deals in romance and historical gossip. The best parts of his book are his own close observations of the buildings.

title: Ampurias: Where The Past Is Such A Hovering Presence

As far as I know, Marti was saying, this is the only site of great ruins of antiquity bordered by delicious swimming beaches. Those early Greeks, they knew a highclass piece of real estate when they saw it.

title: Pop
description: TINY ALICE: Tiny Alice (Kama Sutra KSBS2046). Humor, alas, occurs infrequently in the serious world of pop music. But, for those who like a laugh with their rock n roll, Tiny Alice, a sevenperson Clevelandbased group, has recorded a welcome debut album that goodnaturedly spoofs the music of the thirties. The music, most of it written by the musicians themselves, has a distinct ragtime or blues flavor and the lyrics use thirties themes to poke fun at pop songwriting, as in Stock Exchange of Love, which goes: I lost my heart on the stock exchange of love And our mutual bonds was torn apart. Lyrically the band slips away from nostalgia to pay homage to MacDonald's in a song called I5c Hamburger Mama. Like Bessie Smith's Put a Little Sugar in My Bowl, it's filled with sly double entendres that would make TIonald MacDonald blush. Tiny Alice doesn't succeed on every cut, but when they do, they are amusing.

title: the traveler's world
description: AWEEK of sailing through the Caribbean islands as a working reporter and a second week of lolling about down there as tourist on holiday produced a few conclusions, some of which warrant dissemination. But first, a quick laugh:

description: There were many things to like about the !Cinderella that Washington's National Ballet gave yesterday afternoon in the first of three performances at the City Center. A larger dose of cheer would have made it even more likable.

title: New Novel
description: This is a fine, oldfashioned novel about a triangle on Philadelphia's Main Lineoldfashioned in the sense that it is concerned not with apocalyptic emotion but with introspective change. In the process of exploring the nuances of a disintegrating marriage, Mrs. Rex takes reflective note of the subtleties of caste and local geography, calling to mind the Bostonians of John P. Marquand and the New Yorkers of Louis Auchincloss. Her sympathies are clearly with her heroine, them.

title: Polly Osborn Married
description: SWAMPSCOTT, Mass., Feb. 19  Miss Polly Vanderford Osborn, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frederick Winchester Osborn, was married here this afternoon to Peter Newton Dana, son of Mrs. Newton Tillinghast Dana of Darien, Conn., and the late Mr. Dana. The Rev. Robert Barber, a Congregational minister, performed the ceremony at the Osborn home. Mr. Dana is a vice president of White, Weld gr. Co., investment hankers, in Boston. title: Nation
description: The President's allies on Capitol Hill warned that he would veto the bill if it was passed. Retorted House Majority Leader Hale Boggs of Louisiana: I don't believe the time has yet come when we're required to legislate on the basis of what the President wants. If that's the case, we don't need a legislative body. I, for one, resent being told we must rubberstamp the President.

title: GROUP TO MONITOR CAMPAIGN OUTLAY
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 19Common Caut:e has adopted as its first national project the mobilization of groups of citizens trained to uncover, publicize and prosecute violations of the new Federal law on political campaign spending.

title: News of Dogs
description: Sled dogs usually are associated with the frozen tundra of the North. Next Saturday, however, 74 Siberian huskies and 30 Alaskan malamutes, will be competing at Lincoln, R.I. But they won't be pulling sleds. Instead they will be gaiting in the rings at the 62d allbreed show of the Providence Country Kennel Club. Perhaps it is the new site that has brought out the northern breed dogs, who love to run. For the show has been shifted from the Cranston Street Armory in Providence to the Lincoln Downs race track. We have drawn a record entry of 1,638 dogs, said John A. Mutter, the lawyer and thespian who is serving his third term as president of the kennel club. Exhibitors complained about the cramped quarters of the armory and the difficulty of parking.

title: Heavy Construction Fund To Award 5 Scholarships
description: PARAMUS  Five $600 scholarships for college students enrolled in a civil technology program will be awarded in time for the school year starting next September by the New Jersey Heavy and High Construction Industry Advancement Fund.

title: Labor Leaders Here Form Unit for Justice in Ulster
description: Calling for the withdrawal of British troops and the establishment of a free and independent Ulster, New York labor leaders yesterday announced the formation of a Labor Committee for Justice in Northern Ireland.

title: About Pro Basketball
description: Among other things the signing of Jim Chones by the New York Nets marks the mapping of a major counterattack by the club owners in their fight for a merger of the American and National Basketball Associations over stubborn opposition by the players. The battleground is Congress and the well  publicized signing of college undergraduatesa few more are expected within a weekwill be used for propaganda value to the utmost. The owners hope to generate pressure on Senators and Representatives to permit the merger. A merger would end the raids that the owners contend are forced on them by player insistence, backed by a court order, that the rival leagues must continue to bid for talent.

title: The Nation
description: PHOENIX, Ariz.Democracy, said one speaker at the Democratic state convention here last weekend, is messy and painful process.

title: Inquiry in Drug Case a Worry To the Dolce Vita Set in Rome
description: ROME, Feb, 19Cafe Society here is worried about a drug Investigation that has led to the closing of a famous discotheque, the arrest of its manager, and an investigation of many Via Veneto habitus.

title: Shorter Reviews
description: The exchange of the title refers to the stock exchange on board the S. S. Berengaria, which was put into operation by Michael J. Meehan, a stockmarket plunger of the twenties. This is an account of the voyage of October, 1929the time of the Crash. On board were a colorful cast of characters: Helena Rubinstein returning to the U. S. to rebuild her cosmetics empire; Edgar Wallace, the mystery writer; Polly van Rensselaer Cogswell, society girl reporter who had lifted the curtain on Russia for Hearst; Abraham Cahan, founder and editor of The Jewish Daily Forward, back from a trip to Palestine, which left him more of a Zionist than before; and a moneybagful of assorted millionaires. This is a nice piece of minor Americana, but if Mr. Knapp meant to create a metaphorical twenties ship of fools he doesn't quite

title: Queens Banjo Player Finds 83 Golden Age
description: The banjo has made startling comeback in recent years under the impetus of such virtuosi as Earl Scruggs. But the comeback has been almost entirely in terms of the bluegrass style that Mr. Scruggs plays and a renewed Interest in the folkstyle banjo playing of the Southern hill country.

title: Sonics Will Spend Whatever To Keep McDaniels in Seattle
description: SEATTLE, Feb. 19 (UPI)Sam Schulman, the owner of the SuperSonics of the National Basketball Association, says he is prepared to spend whatever is necessary to keep his rookie star, Jim McDaniels, in Seattle.

title: Pope to Go on Retreat
description: VATICAN CITY Feb. 19(AP)Pope Paul VI will be on his annual spiritual retreat all next week, the Vatican announced today. The 74yearold Pontiff will receive no visitors during the week and will not hold his regular Wednesday general audience.

title: New Novel
description: Write what you know, admonishes the hero's English professor. If only Miss Chute had herself taken this pithy advice and opted against projecting her novel in the persona of a young man!

title: Dockers on Coast Approve Contract After Long Tieup
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 19. (AP)  West Coast dock workers finished voting today to end their 134dayold strike, the longest clock tieup ever on the United States mainland.

title: Movie
description: THERE we were, in bed together, says soprano Evelyn Lear, looking fondly at her husband, the baritone Thomas Stewart. Suddenly, Tom moved closer to me. His eyes were blazing, and his beard, and those bushy eyebrows of his seemed strangely terrifying. His head was very close to mine and he whispered to me, You know, don't you, that I'm the devil! Well, I really became frightened I became panicky, because well, because I believed him. I really did. I really thought he was the devil. Isn't that crazy?

description: A number of residents of the College Point section of Queens are protesting the continuation of work at an eightacre land reclamation project in Flushing Bay and have threatened to seek court action to stop work at the site.

title: Sports of Tile Times
description: The world turns. Lindbergh was the first to fly the Atlantic in 1927 but now astronauts walk on the moon. Silent movies were big then but now TV is bounced off satellites. And a baseball heirloom from that era, Leo Durocher, considered the ultimate manager by some, now has a mouthpiece to communicate with his players and newsmen. The mouthpiece is Hank Aguirre, once a respected lefthanded pitcher, now 40 years old, now the new information and services coach. on the Chicago Cubs, a human chapsticlt for Lippy Leo's lip. When the Cubs open their training camp tomorrow at Scottsdale, Ariz., he will be in charge of soothing players aggravated by Durocher's icy blasts.

title: MARYLAND TOPS CLEMSON5 6757
description: COLLEGE PARK, Md., Feb. 19 (AP)Tom McMillen scored 23 points and three of his teammates also hit double figures as Maryland defeated Clemson, 6757, in Atlantic Coast Conference basketball today.

title: The World
description: LONDON A month ago Edward Heath and his Conservative Government looked to be in a strong and improving position. Britain was at last on her way into the Common Market, Mr. Heath's main foreignpolicy aim. He was mastering the major domestic problem, inflation, with the rate of price rises cut from 10 to 5 per cent in a year. Only the Irish problem lurked darkly on the horizon.

title: The dogood loaf
description: In these days of conc. ern over exactly what, for heaven's sake, we are eating, there's a yearning for unadulterated basics. And what could be more basic than bread? Nothing. Unless it's the loaf with the university education known as Cornell bread. This bread was develoked the forties under the direction of the late Dr. Clive M. McCay of Cornell's department of nutrition and food. How does it differ from the standard homemade loaf? It has added protein, calcium and riboflavin (which keeps you younger longer). Some New York bakeries sell the Cornell loaf, but there's no reason why concerned cooks can't make it themselves. Here are two variations of a nutritionpacked bread to make your family happier and healthier.

title: Hobart Beats St. Lawrence
description: CANTON, N. Y., Feb. 19 (AP) Moving in front in the second half. Hobart triumphed over St. Lawrence. 8575, in college basketball today. The Larries led, 4038, at halftime.

title: India Says She Is Ready For Pakistan Peace Talks
description: NEW DELHI, Feb. 19 (AP)India announced today that she was prepared to have direct peace talks with Pakistan at any time, at any level and without any preconditions.

title: Criminals At Large
description: Sometimes you start a book and end up admiring it for reasons the author might not have intended. BLOOD ON A HARVEST MOON by David Anthony (Coward, McGann & Geoghegan, $5.95) tries to be a piece of tough crime fiction in which multiple murders are traced back to a crime committed during World War H. A wife hires her exhusband to find out what is going on, and things explode in his face.

title: Forest Hills Generates Feud Among Democrats
description: ALBANYThe community struggle to halt the three public housing towers in Forest Hills has led to growing tensions among Queens Democrats, who say there is a new mix of political ambitions focused on the State Legislature.

title: More States Are Joining PariMutuel Bandwagon
description: From Alabama to Connecticut, parimutuel developments last week reflected the growing emphasis being placed on gambling as a source of tax revenue.

title: Why Daddy rushes home to watch Batman
description: Five years ago, our older son's kindergarten teacher suggested that we watch some of his favorite television programs with him. We were horrified. It was bad enough that Paul spent his time in the company of Underdog, Mighty Mouse, Popeye and Astro Boythis being the bad old days before Sesame Street. Should we also be condemned to what seemed like indecent exposure? And would not such complicity appear to put Mommy's and Daddy's Good Viewing Seal of Approval on our son's taste in television? And would we not be bored to tears? We were, of course, reflecting the view of presumably educated parents who considered television a concession to the kids. The idea of joining them in front of the TV came as shock. But we respected this teacher, and decided to give it a try.

title: Runabouts Shedding Tin Lizzie Look
description: You don't have to be a millionaire to be a yachtsman is one of the selling points currently being espoused at the Miami International Boat Show, which began Friday and runs through Wednesday.

title: CANADIAN ASSAILS POLICY ON ARCTIC
description: TORONTO, Feb. 19Peter J. Usher, a geographer employed by the Canadian Government, has accused his own department of putting development of resources in the far north ahead of the wellbeing of Eskimos and protection of the Arctic environment.

title: We Must Run While They Walk
description: A relaxed portrait of Tanzania's President Julius Nyerere, by a former Time magazine correspondent who interviewed Nyerere's political and diplomatic acquaintances as well as a host of Tanzanian citizens and officials. Although this collage contains little political analysis, it is a readable, if thin, account of one African leader's attempt to promote economic development while staying independent of the foreign powers now making overtures to Africa.

title: LIQUOR CONFIRMS HE WILL RUN MILE
description: Barring midweek conditioning problems with his tender feet, Marty Liguori will run the mile Friday night at Madison Square Garden in the Amateur Athletic Union indoor track and field championships.

title: Professor's Ouster Costly
description: PALO ALTO, Calif., Feb. 19 (UPI)Stanford University say that hearings that resulted in the dismissal of Prof. H. Bruce Franklin cost the school about $180,000. Professor Franklin, an avowed MarxistMaoist, was dismissed on grounds that he fomented violence on the campus.

title: Growing Up in the Forties
description: THE last time America was happy, said the sell line on Esquire's cover a few months ago. Inside there were pictures of Very Important Forties People doing Very Important Forties ThingsIL M. Nixon crusading against Commie spies, Walter Winchell seated at his Stork Club table, Me Lone Ranger lone rangering, that sort of thing. There was also spread of camp objectsa Swank key chain, a Lionel electric train, model of the Constellation (it was an airplane, the first I ever flew in), an anthology of snaps from the best of the decade's great magazine features, Life Goes to a Party. Also Girl. And also this nice article.

title: Travel Notes: Eclipse Cruise, Camping Show, Carnival Switch
description: THERE will be a total eclipse of the sun July 10. It won't be visible from the continental United States, but it will be witnessed by passengers on the liner Olympic. A special oneweek Eclipse 72 cruise to the North Atlantic has been scheduled for the 23000ton Greek Lines vessel, which will leave New York July 8 on an itinerary that will also include visits to the Gaspd Peninsula, the Bonaventure Island bird sanctuary and Nova Scotia.

title: Television
description: THIS Tuesday evening, at 8:30, the WNET/Channel 13 Dateline 13 series is devoting an hour to choreographer Alwin Nikolais. Coproduced by WNET/13 and the British Broadcasting Corporation, the first halfhour consists of a biographical essay on Nikolais, showing him in his New York studio and in London working on a special project for television. The second half will feature that project, a videodance piece called The Relay.

title: British Olympic Five Visits Colgate Friday
description: Cotterell Court will take on an international flavor next Friday night when the Colgate basketball team will be host to the British Olympic team.

title: Windowsand Doors OnViewatHeckscher
description: HUNTINGTON, L. I. Theme shows like the current Windows and Doors at the August Heckscher Museum are very often tedious enterprises. Either the curator responsible for the exhibition gets carried away and uses the theme as a pretext to include almost anything or the subject matter is so closely adhered to that the inflexible approach throws too little light on the theme.given the scope of the show. It is also true that there are examples of more consummate quality that could have been used.

title: RANGERS AT HONE TO WINGS TONIGHT
description: The Detroit Red Wings will provide the opposition tonight when the Rangers return from their threegame road trip to meet the Wings at Madison Square Garden. Game time is 7:05. The contest will mark Detroit's first New York visit since Oct. 27.

title: Munson Signs as Yankees Open Camp
description: FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., Feb. 19In winds gusting up to 55 miles an hour, the Yankees opened spring training today with 23 players battling their way through a 2hour workout.

title: Under a Wigwam on L.I., Samp and Sassafras Were Served as Indians Danced
description: EAST HAMPTON, L. I.Indians in feathered headdresses gathered near a wigwam recently, and, to the beat of tomtoms, performed authentic war dances.

title: The Nation
description: In a decision unprecedented in American jurisprudence, the Supreme Court of California, on Friday, struck down the death penalty under a provision of the California Constitution prohibiting cruel or unusual punishments. The immediate effect of the 6to1 decision, rendered in the case of People v. Anderson, is to spare the lives of 102 men and five women who were awaiting execution, most of them on San Quentin's Death Row. These prisonersamong them Sirhan Sirhan, who assassinated Robert Kennedy, and Charles Manson, who murdered Sharon Tatewill now serve life sentences for their crimes (unless, of course, they earn earlier release on parole or for good behavior). Never before in the history of the American judiciary has one court decision directly saved so lives.

title: Toronto Host for Badminton
description: TORONTO (Canadian Press) Nancy McKinley, the Canadian defending champion, and Judy Rollick of Vancouver, British Columbia, head a sixmember team that will represent Canada in the Uber Cup women's badminton match. as against the United States here Feb. 26. The competition between the two countries is played every three years. Canada last won the series in 1957.

title: Governor Presents 2 Bills to Tighten Curbs on Firearms
description: Governor Rockefeller announced yesterdak that he had sent two bills to the State Legislature seeking stricter requirements for the licensing of firearms.

title: The Battle of Forest HillsWho's Ahead?
description: THE pile drivers are driving at 108th Street and 62d Drive; the picketers are picketing, the epithets are flying. A monument to many of our urban aches and pains is rising on that soggy land in Queens, commemorating the ideals and the limitations of those who are trying to manage this poor city and the dangerously conflicting needs and emotions of those who are trying to live in it.

C., Feb. 19 (AP)Brooks Hays, an early Southern supporter of civil rights for blacks in the 16 years ho was a Representative from Arkansas, announced yesterday that he would seek the Democratic nomination from the Fifth Congressional District of North Carolina, his adopted stite.

They are all multiracial and critical of the South African Government's race policies, they all receive encouragement and some financial support from abroad and they have all been visited by the security police.

description: MAYWOOD  Nancy Moore. Peter Zurla Jr. and Chorale Page are volunteers. They were referred to their unpaid jobs by the Volunteer Bureau of Bergen County, an agency that has done a lot to dispel the stereotype of the volunteer worker as an envelopestuffer and doorbellringer.

title: Robert Elzy of Urban League, Champion of Black Welfare, Dies
description: Robert J. EIzy, who devoted his life to promoting the welfare of the black community and was a retired general secretary of the Urban League of Greater New York, died Friday in the Harlem Hospital Center. He was 87 years old and lived at 2181 Madison Avenue.

description: BAYONNETwo of the most vital shipping lanes on the East CoastArthur Kill and Kill van Kullsnake around Staten Island, opening New Jersey ports to the world.

description: TUXEDO PARK, N. Y., Feb. 19Jerry Bijur of Philadelphia gained the final round of the 70th annual Gold Racquet court tennis tournament today by defeating Louis Dominguez of New York, 65, at the Tuxedo Racquets and Tennis Club.

title: A good man against theories
description: Any reader of Paul Goodman's earlier books will know in advance that his latest is just learned and personal enough to be most interesting for neither its learning nor its quirkiness. Of course it often parades both these qualities with Goodman's characteristic offhand flashiness: the names, the theories, the occasionally sentimental confessions, the repetitions, the surprising quotations and misquotations are all there. By now Goodman can probably take his own verbal mannerisms for granted like facts of history, and there is no reason why his reader shouldn't also, especially since how people actually speakGoodman's being as good an example of actual speech as anyis what this book is about. Poetry, he adds, is improved common speech, although I think that this is only partly true. The special formality of writing is not always the equivalent of speaking out. Nevertheless the reasons he prefers speaking to linguistic theory as an adequate description of verbal behavior are impres

title: Mrs. Schwarz Has Child
description: BOSTON, Veh. 19  A daughter was born last Monday to Mr. and Mrs. Richard Ira Schwarz in Beth Israel Hospital here. Mrs. Schwarz is the former Miss Lavinia Gilbert, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Jack Gilbert of Orinda, Calif. Her husband is a graduate student in biochemistry at Harvard. The child has been named Kimberly Heather. She is a granddaughter also of Mr. and Mrs. Daniel Schwarz of Scarsdale, N.Y.

description: Dr. Joseph C. Miceli, attending otolaryngoloist at Lutheran Hospital in Brooklyn, died yesterday in Kennedy Community Hospital, Edison, N. J. He was 70 years old and lived in Allenhurst, N. J.
