description: NORTH KINGSTOWN, R. I., Feb. 19C. Tracy Barnes, who had worked for a variety of intelligence agencies including the Central Intelligence Agency, died yesterday after suffering a heart attack at his home. He was 60 years old.

title: Private School Tuition: A System That Would Put All Parents on Equal Basis
description: Parents of children on scholarships in private schools have always had to bare their financial situation. Now a trend may be developing for affluent parents who are paying full tuition to be asked to report to the school their total assets, including current market value of stocks and bonds, balances in savings accounts and net current value of real estate.

title: Corporate Tokenism for Women?; 3 Companies Name Them Assistant Secretary
description: CHICAGOThree corporate giants, recently and with fanfare, announced the appointments of women to the pdSts of assistant secretary.

title: Decriminalizing Marijuana
description: Is pot harmful? Classified as a narcotic drug by law, with severe penalties imposed for its sale, use or mere possession, marijuana has been treated as an extremely harmful commodity at all levels of government for many years. Only during the last few years, however, has the medical profession closely studied marijuana. The validity of the law depends on the answer to the question: How harmful is pot? That answer only now beginning to come in.

title: CHILEAN BILL TO CURB SEIZURES IS PASSED
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, Feb. 19 (AP)  Congress voted today a series of constitutional amendments to restrict the efforts of President Salvador Allende Gossens to give Chile a socialist economy.

title: Electric Trolley Bus Yielding to Diesels in Chicago
description: CHICAGO Feb. 19The electric trolley busa mainstay of Chicago's public transit network for more than 40 years is officially doomed.

title: Education
description: At a meeting last week in a Roman Catholic high school in Manhattan, a Catholic historian told a group of educators from the Archdiocese of New York that the study of Judaism should permeate their curriculums from kindergarten through the university.

title: Her Status in Trenton Is Stressed By First Chief of Office on Women
description: RUTHERFORD  Mrs. Dorothy B. Mery of Rutherford, director of New Jersey's first Office on Women, knows from experience that she is not important enough yet to step back and wait for silence. I have to keep on talking, she said.

title: The Last Word
description: Vol. I, No. 1, of The Sewanee Review, America's oldest literary quarterly, appeared 80 years ago. Sponsored by the University of the South, at Sewanee, Tenn., the Review was founded by Sewanee English Professor William Peterfield Trent (later at Columbia and editor of The Cambridge History of American Literature), to supply the kind of literature that the English quarterly gave England. More specifically, In taking something from the older ideals of English traditions and adapting this to our own life, The Sewanee Review has regarded itself as conserving and nourishing ideals that were in some danger of being lost sight ofideals of a wider and riper culture.

title: The haute cuisine restaurants here are Up Against the Kitchen Wall
description: WHEN the fish did not arrive on schedule during a banquet the maitre d'htel Vatel had prepared for Louis XIV, Vatel, after receiving the consolation of forgiving princes, confronted his demonstrated lack of perfection by committing suicide. Contemporary opinion was divided on the wisdom and necessity of Vatel's reaction; according to Madame de Sevigne, Some blamed him, others praised his courage.

title: Officials in Egypt Confer WithGrechho and Jarring
description: CAIRO, Feb. 19  With United States diplomacy apparently pushed aside, Egyptian officials began talks today with the Soviet Defense Minister, Marshal Andrei A. Grechko, on aspects of new military assistance and with Dr. Gunnar V. Jarring, the United Nations intermediary, on whatever hopes Cairo retains for political settlement with Israel.

title: Vermont 1, 2 in Special Slalom At Williams College Carnival
The Nation
description: After seven months, $300million in lost wages and incalulable inconvenience to telephone users, the strike of phone workers in New York State has finally ended. Last Wednesday, the Communications Workers of America announced acceptance by union members of a settlement recommended by J. Curtis Counts, director of the Federal Mediation and Conciliation Service. The vote, by mail ballot, was 13,769 in favor and 9,193 opposed. The union instructed its members to return to work this Tuesday.

title: Japan and Mongolia in Pact

title: Shorter Reviews
description: Tall (but true) tales from the formative years of the Audie Murphy of World War H cartoonery  now, of course, one of the best editorial cartoonists in the country. Mauldin began cartooning in New Mexico, taking correspondence courses, drawing for the high school paper, painting nudes on spare tires. The war came, and with it, glory, precisely because Mauldin saw it as an inglorious business, involving tired, bearded men with bags under their eyes. There is a full sampler of early Mauldin cartoons on through the creation of Willie and Joe. Mauldin writes racily and frankly, taking his life to the end of the war, in 1945. An entertaining, raffish memoir that catches perfectly the G.I.'s wry, selfdeprecatory, selfpitying, antiauthoritarian humor. The cartoons, incidentally, are

title: Art
description: WE tend as a general rule to think of modern art as standing in a fixed posture of revolt against the ethos of modern life, and with good reason. To be at odds with his timesthere lies the raison d'tre of the artist, wrote Andre Gide, and there is no shortage of evidence in the vast literature of modernism to support this assumption of an essential antagonism between modern art and the social environment that has harbored it. Certainly one of the salient characteristics of the modern movement has been its critical attitude toward established conventions of feeling, and at many crucial points in its history it has carried this criticism into an advocacy of alternativeeven utopian

title: Six thousand miles over rivers, swamps and mountains
description: The Long March, a term so symbolic of the Chinese Revolution, was both disaster and triumph. Only about one tenth of those who set out from halfdozen bases in south and central China between 1932 and 1935 reached their final destination a continent away in north Shensi Province, but those 30,000 who did survive the Long March went on to become rulers of the most populous country on earth a scant decade later in 1949. How could there have been such a fantastic reversal of fortunes, from retreat and near annihilation to awesome victory?

title: Photography
description: ANEW automatic electronic flash unit recently added to the UltrablitzBauer line computes the correct light output at distances up to 5 feet. Called the E25A Express, and distributed by Allied hope>: Corporation, division of AIC Photo, Inc., 168 Glen Cove Road, Carle Place, L. I., N. Y. 11514, this new model has a builtin computer to figure the amount of light required for a given distance, and it also features optional f/stop control. It does this by means of a calculator dial that is first set for the film speed being used The f/stop is then offered in two settingsone for close distances (1% to 12 feet) and one for greater distances (1% to 25 feet). The switch is then set to the matching symbol, or it can be set for manual control (without computer) for use at distances greater than 25 feet.

title: Racing Chiefly for Fun: ThreeQuarter Midgets
description: ATLANTIC CITY  Here is indoor racing, which is as basic as racing can be. Here is hard charging in close quarters, with cars in almost constant contact and with machinery competitively matched to an incredible degree. This is the last of lowbudget racing  you can run a whole season on expenses of $1,000. Rules are so stable that the longevity of these cars seems infinite. A few drivers are younger than their cars. There also are drivers past 60 who still are winning races. One rule respects an ancient racing superstition: No car painted green will he allowed to run.hazard. The overhead roll cage of steel pipe prevents the car from falling on and crushing the driver. In three spills during one recent program, the greatest injury was a bruised hand.

title: Shorter Reviews
description: The grand illusion that became the Panama Canal continues to attract historians a volume last year and now The Impossible Dream, which is by far the best yet. Mr. Cameron, an Englishman, has a thorough understanding of the engineering problems involved; he traces the doomed French effort under the grandiose de Lesseps and shows how with better planning and a knowledge of the causes of malaria and yellow fever it might have succeeded. This is incisive history; it cuts through many myths that have surrounded that monumental

title: With the help of electricity the young could hear themselves speak
description: Sitting here and thinking about these books, I keep asking myself: Why bother with them? Grownups have better things to do than worry about these pop enthusiasms. Yet it is also true, as I sit here, that there is music playing somewhere in the housea moment ago Bob Dylan and now the Beatles. It has been that way for most of these past few years. The music has always been playing, a steady accompaniment to whatever else was happening, but also more than an accompaniment, a kind of cultural DNA with changes coded into it. One need only have been in San Francisco or Los Angeles or latesixties, stroboscopic, unisex New York to have experienced the shift in the rhythms of those places, the way life felt differently  not merely the sound of it, but the texture and resonance of things, the quality and styles of

It tells how many times the President has met a particular figure (Charles de Gaulle, five times; Nguyen Van Thieu, four; Pope Paul VI, five; Chiang Kaishekstill listed under C for Chinasix). And it contains the box score on his visits to particular countries.

title: Not for Amateurs
description: Everybody talks about haute cuisine, but practically nobody does anything about it. With good reason: though it is a superbly refined style of cooking, it is also an impossibly wasteful and almost completely outmoded way of running a kitchen and designing a meal. And though Escoffier codified it, more or less, his classic book is one that only professional chefs can use. Most haute cuisine is no more within the eeach of an unaided home cook, however dexterous, than the manufacture of RollsRoyces would be for a talented mechanic working in his back yard.

This is the improbable weekend, when the old Redbaiting American politician pays court to the old Maoist mandarins. This is the historic weekend, when the United States and China shed the habits of generation of hostility and ignorance of each other. This is the enchanting weekend, when the very heart of the mysterious Orient will be laid bare and transmitted to American homes, live and in color.

title: Recording

Conservatives are turning their noses up at the unjustly neglecteds of the 19th century, those alsoran composers who unluckily lived, worked, played and composed in the shadows of the Romantic giants, while radicals are storming the concert halls and record stores with the names of their forgotten legions. each a cause unto himself. The revolt has been injecting some life into a sagging concert format and certainty makes reviewing piano recordings more interesting.

title: Music

The city had acquired a National Arts Center, but it was something of a laughing stock, just because there was no local orchestra and, as far as anyone knew, no audience for it. In the past, Ottawans had been content to attend concerts by visiting orchestras, which played in a movie house.

title: The Sequence
description: This is the time when farmers back in the hills traditionally got out their spites and sap buckets and evaporator pans for the first rural rites of spring. This was the week, the week of Washington's birthday, back when the calendar, not an act of Congress, set the date. Even there were two feet of snow on the ground, the maplesugar folk went to the woods and set the spiles in the south side of the trees on the south slope. That's where they expected the first run of sap. If the days milded off, as they said, and the nights stayed frosty, sap would run before March.

Referring to their rented farmhouse, he declares, This is me. This is where live. I will not allow violence against this house. [And, sotto voce] No way. All this during a lull in the shouting, glasssmashing assault of the drunken locals.

title: Dance
description: ABALLET can win its place in dance history Omagh a variety of ways. It can be a work such as La SyIpnide, which heralded the Rtmantic ballet, or it can be a work such as Jerome Robbins's Fancy Free, which signaled the emergence of a completely new choreographer. Then again it can be a work such as the Balanchine and Stravinsky Agon, which proved so remarkable in its realization of choreography and music, of, as it were, space in time, that this is clearly a landmark in dance. More rarely, however, comes the work that successfully challenges, if only briefly, the whole concept of ballet

Certainly not in the long list of highly regarded and widely read historical studies of the United States from 1789 to the present that are Mr. Lens's principal sources, and which he has sedulously combed, digested and paraphrased. title: Best of two worlds
description: Parisians are startled when they enter this residence the fashionable 16th arrondissement; it's so, well, American. Instead of the standard French upperclass interior of pastels and vintage antiques, they are confronted with bold colors, gay patterns and an unorthodox pairing furniture styles. The ceiling molding and door frames in the living room (below) are a dramatic blue. In the foyer (left), matching reds and blues in strong patterns provide a vigorous background for the English and French furnishings. When Arthur Rosen's business made it necessary for him to move to Paris, it was his wife, surprisingly enough, a native Parisian, who felt, she would miss New York. So designer David Laurence Roth went to work create an interior that would make them feel at home on the Right Bank of Faris. He added provincial pieces bought in France to accent 18thcentury English antiques. The success of the transplant is apparent in the dining room (right) where the robust curves of Georgian chairs blend happily with the sedate paneling and mirrored arch

title: After Kaddish's Poetry Goes, What Is Left?
description: IN Paterson, New Jersey, a woman called Naomi has gone insane. She insistsshouts, sobsthat her husband is trying to kill her, he is taking all her money and putting poison in her food, there are wires in the ceiling and sticks down her back and voices in the radio. She is put in an asylum, and released; her illness breaks out again, and she accuses her husband of poisoning the soup. She goes to stay with her sister Eleanor in the Bronx, but Eleanor is a sick woman, and Naomi's ravings are more than she can tolerate. Naomi is institutionalized once again; she has a stroke; her son visits her for the last time. Later he receives news of her death.

title: Veronica Goodchild Is Betrothed
description: The Right Rev. Ronald Cedric Osborne Goodchild, Lord Bishop of Kensington, and Mrs. Goodchild of London have made known the engagement of their daughter, Miss Veronica Goodchild, to Terry Fieber Green, son of Mr. and Mrs. Quentin Downen Green of Grayville.

title: Leaf Storm and Other Stories
description: When Gabriel Garcia Marquez's utterly original One Hundred Years of Solitude came out here in 1970, I read itI experienced itwith the same recognition of a New World epic that one feels about Moby Dick. Whatever else you can say about contemporary American novels, they are generally overpopulated and personally too scornful to remind the reader that ours was, until very recently, a New World. This is a subject, a climate of feeling, that requires a virtually empty continent, a powerful sense of wonder at how little men change even in the most bizarre moments of discovering Nature beyond the usual conceptions of Nature, one or two characters who are too big for the society they are trying to create.

title: Draft Offices Keep Busy Biding Time for a CallUp Resumption

title: PenneyPinching

It was promising for fall. Smiling, the 48yearold West Virginian who had already spent 31 years with Penney, strolled for a few minutes and casually studied the traffic pattern in and around the shopping center.

title: Gateway Revived
description: After months of languishing in a House of Representatives subcommittee, the bill to create a Gateway National Recreational Area is again a bright lope on the horizon. Considered all but a certainty last year, when the Nixon Administration warmly endorsed it and the Senate passed the required legislation, the proposal went into a deep freeze when Mayor Lindsay testified that a great park area at the entrance to New York Harbor could not succeed unless the Federal Government helped make it accessible through lowcost transportation.

title: EXPERTISE SHOWN BY FRAN JEFFRIES
description: There is a record in Fran Jeffries's past, an LP on which she projects a softly smoky voice that is sometimes torchy, sometimes light and bright, a voice that carries perceptive nuances of shading and undertakes interesting turns of musical phrasing. Not the least memorable part of this record is the striking cover photograph of Miss Jeffries, a gorgeous, sinuous, darkhaired girl with huge Garlandlike eyes. Such a vocal and physical combination, it would seem, could scarcely miss.

Four persons were missing and nine passengers survived. The bus went into the water when a front tire blew out.

So much, or so little, for the power of television.

title: AT HOME ABROAD
description: LONDON, Feb. 20  President Nixon's visit to China, whatever else it may or may not do, marks the end of an illusory phase in American. Policy. Instead of applying a devil theory to the People's Republic, we now admit to ourselves that it has legitimate national concernsand in my case is there to stay. In short, we have stopped fooling ourselves that we have the power to fight history in that part of Asia.

title: Prospects in Peking: I
description: PEKING Understanding an interview with Premier Chou Enlai is like trying to piece a jigsaw puzzle together. One knows the creator had some design, but while the puzzle is in pieces it helps measurably to have previously seen a picture of the puzzle. As the pieces are put in place, at some point patterns become recognizable. From then on, one has increasing confidence in being able to put the remaining pieces in place.tion should be solved first, Chou and his subordinates repeatedly gave the impression that they did not wish to talk about the Vietnam war and that its termination was for the UnitedStates the Vietnamese to settle. Second, if, on the other hand, Mr. Nixon comes to China hoping for support from the: Chinese to maneuver their Vietnamese allies into a settlement acceptable to the Nixon Administration, he will leave emptyhanded. If the Chinese are not going to mix in to apply maximum diplomatic leverage on Mr. Nixon to end the war, neitherare they about to sell out their, allies. And third, the immediate health of the antiwar movement in the United States, is of relatively minor concern to the Chinese, who, believe. that the war will be settled primarily; in Viet. nim. Chinese disinterest may be a product of the severely weakened'state of the United States antiwar movement, and it is rationalized in terms of China's professed faith in the perseverance of the American movement and China's historical belief in the inevitable victory of that movement, whatever the current twists and turns.

title: OCCIDENTAL OIL POSTS 1971 LOSS
description: The Occidental Petroleum Corporation reported over the weekend that its net loss in 1971 totaled SWmillion and that cash dividends on the common stock will be temporarily suspended. In 1970, the company had a net profit of $175million, or $2.92 a share.

title: Saving Free Voices
description: For a generation now, Radio Free Europe and Radio Liberty have contributed enormously to enlarging the market place of ideas in Eastern Europe and the Soviet Union. Their transmissions have made available to those countries factual news of the outside world that the governments involved would have preferred their subjects did not know. In addition, these stations have broadcast the writings of such dissidents as Nobel Prizewinner Aleksandr Solzhenitsyn, whose masterly novels and stories are prohibited in the Soviet bloc. A Library of Congress study of these stations, made at the request of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, has paid high tribute to these organizations contributions toward liberalization of the Soviet world.

title: Five Dead in Plane Crash

All five persons on board were killed, including Rolland Smith, the president of the small airline, who was filling in for a regularly scheduled pilot. Other victims were identified as Dr. Harold McCabe, a Columbus, Ohio, dentist; Miss Leslie P. Nerrit of Santa Barbara, Calif., and Otto Carleton, a company mechanic. The identity of the fifth victim was withheld pending notification of relatives.

title: Film: French Whodunit:McBain Adaptation Is at Paris Theater
description: It takes a long time for a connected series of five murders to unravel and even longer for a detective to wrap it up in "Without Apparent Motive," a middling-good French whodunit that opened Saturday at the Paris Theater.The picture runs only 102 minutes and is still too long, even with that many corpses. As directed by Philippe Labro, the film has a vividly crisp pictorial style that seems more intent on rolling out a stunningly beautiful Riviera rug of Nice at the expense of taut, tight, head-on narrative.Finally, with the case solved, the picture dawdlingly hangs on, then curiously shrugs itself off, along with the detective hero, played with blunt, admirable simplicity by Jean-Louis Trintignant.Yet the design of murder and the interesting denouement are both credible and original and worth the waitout. To our knowledge, this is the second Ed McBain novel transplanted from America to a foreign setting. The other was that Kurosawa thriller, "High and Low," brilliantly switched to Japan.Mr. Labro, who also collaborated on the script, has extracted good, terse performances from his other players, too, especially Carla Gravina, as the hero's former mistress. And out she goes, too, as Victim No. 4 of that long-range, silenced rifle.Dominique Sanda is properly enigmatic. As for Erich Segal, that "Love Story" man, the American writer has a brief acting stint to do (as No. 3) and does it well, spouting perfect French.If only the picture were as succinct.

To an angler living beside New England trout stream, it is a crime against nature drop a fly on any river closer than Montana. This explains why Mr. Nelson Bryant, who lives on Martha's Vineyard surrounded by waters matted with fish, has lately been wallowing up to his syntax in the mangrove swamps of Florida's Everglades.

title: The President in China
description: With President Nixon's arrival in China, a historic milestone has been passed. For the first time, a chief executive of the United States has visited the world's most populous country during his term of office. This precedentshattering event testifies both to a momentous change in American foreign policy and to the new stature of the Chinese People's Republic as one of the world's greatest powers. Whatever results from this visit, the mere fact that it is taking place demonstrates the willingness of the highest leaders on both sides to put aside ancient prejudices, and to begin the effort to see whether a new and mutually beneficial relationship can be forged.

title: French Love Story: A Boy and a Woman
description: Since "To Die of Love" is a dramatization of an authentic cause clbre, it calls for more background explanation than the move at the Festival Theater provides. It opened yesterday, already bearing the laurels of a hit in its native France.But the film as presented by Andr Cayatte, the lawyer-turned-director, is both fervent in its espousal of a strange, tragic love affair and precise in its spotlighting of the vagaries of the law. His love story and the law's intransigence are compelling and stark as befits an adult view of a shattering experience.In essence, Mr. Cayatte is relating (as a complete flashback) the true saga of a 32-year-old high school teacher, who quite naturally and tenderly falls in love with a pupil, a tall, handsome, bearded 17-year-old, who appears to be a good deal more mature than his years.His parents charge her with seducing a minor despite his insistence on continuing their relationship. And it evolves basically as the story of her jailings; his incarceration in psychiatric clinics and schools and with relatives. By these methods, the lovers are kept apart legally (although they manage clandestine, bittersweet meetings) until, in final desperation, she commits suicide.As the creator of such memorable features as "Justice Is Done" and "We Are All Murderers," Mr. Cayatte this time was inspired by the actual case that was a "cause scandale" in 1969, involving Gabrielle Russier, a Marseilles school teacher, and her lover, Christian Rossi. The story was detailed in "The Affair of Gabrielle Russier," the book published here last year.The director has switched his locale to Rouen and he has made other changes. The young man's parents, for example, are seemingly bourgeois, adamant bookstore owners in the film whereas they were actually teachers, as was Gabrielle Russier herself. And, although her divorced husband remained close to her during her trials, he only appears fleetingly in the movie.Through the performances, direction and intelligent dialogue, what could have been a treacly romance becomes a tale of genuine love, implied sex, stultifying despair and a compassionate observation of man's inhumanity to man.In Annie Girardot, "To Die of Love" has its most valuable asset. Hardly the classic personification of beauty, she nevertheless projects the feeling of an intelligent girlish woman rediscovering love, ready to sacrifice herself for it. And she subtly conveys a change to despair as she is buffeted by legal ploys she cannot comprehend and by the destruction of her teaching career. It is an understated and forceful portrayal.Bruno Pradal, a newcomer who is reminiscent, of the late Grard Philipe, is equally memorable as her lover, boyish yet grown, a man affected by mental and physical turbulence he cannot fully comprehend but is ready to conquer at all costs.Mr. Cayatte also has derived natural performances from Franois Simon and Monique Melinand, as his parents; Claude Serval as a magistrate, and, among others, a covey of young, intense "pupils" who look as though they're ready to take part in another student protest.A poster in the modern living room of Miss Girardot's film "home" proclaims a Paul Valry phrase, "living is a state of mind." Mr. Cayatte and his convincing company may confuse us by not presenting us with the official source material, but the film delves deeply and often movingly into the states of mind of both the obdurate lawmakers and the tragic principals.

description: Dr. Mary Rose Sheehan, professor emeritus of psychology. at Hunter College, and for 10 years secretary of the Legislative Conference of the City Colleges, later the City University, died yesterday in Roosevelt Hospital: She was 67 years old and lived at 160 East 89th Street.

title: Gendarmes Break Up Protest At Races
description: PARIS, Feb. 20The mountted Republican Guards, splendid in their golden helmets with horsetail plumes flowing in the wind, sabers and spurs rattling, cantered up the green stretch of Auteuil racetrack today to disperse striking apprentice jockeys and stable boys who had invaded the turf to demonstrate their grievances.

title: Bill Graham Returns to World of Rock
description: Eight months after the closing of his Fillmore East on Second Avenue, rock impresario Bill Graham is moving back into the largescale production of rock music. Mr. Graham, in association with Tomorrow Productions, Inc., will produce three large concertsone in May and two next fallthat will be carried via closed circuit television to 70 theaters throughout the country.

title: Samuel G. Krivit Is Dead; Trade Magazine Publisher
description: Samuel G. Krivit, founder and former publisher of United Business Publications, died yesterday in Palm Beach, Fla. He was 68 years old and lived at 950 Fifth Avenue.

title: Chess: New American Association Promises Lively Schedule
description: The founding late last year of the American Chess Association after a series of meetings in Tucuman, Argentina, heralds a new era of chess activity all over the Western Hemisphere.

title: Crime Panel Chief In Texas Is Indicted In Embezzling Case
description: DALLAS, Feb. 20For 40 years, John McKee, president of the Dallas Crime Commission, lived a respected life here as a lawandorder spokesman, Masonic leader and executive of the Ford Motor Company.

title: Screen: 'Outback' Opens:Film Evokes Ambiance of Australian Town
description: Freed for a while from his teaching job at a rail stop in the Australian bush, young John Grant sets out to spend the long hot Christmas vacation with his girl, by the sea, and as close to civilization as he can get.He hops a train, the only train, to the small provincial city that is the air link with Sydneyand that is as far as he goes. He never takes the plane.And in the course of one weekend he sinks from passing visitor to drunken derelict in a place he seems as likely to escape as may the damned from Hell. The events of that weekend form the principal action of Ted Kotcheff's "Outback," which opened yesterday at the Little Carnegie Theater.Since "Outback" is a film I mostly admire, I had better allow that it is not without flaws. But they are flawsin plotting, in Kotcheff's penchant for using five camera positions at a time where one might dothat may be, not overlooked, but safely admitted in a work that really does move from its strengths rather than its weaknesses.Among those strengths I should have to include a sense of general foreboding that crystalizes often enough into particular terror and that is not quite like anything else I can remember feeling at the movies.Certain science-fiction films come closest to it, especially those in which some evil alien presence has taken over a community that to all outward appearances remains normalwith only the slightest most fugitive hint that something somehow is hideously wrong.Here all that really shows is a society bored to its heels, forced into friendliness, addicted to stupid but good-humored gambling, and absolutely committed to beer drinkingto the extent that everyone is always effusively, oppressively drunk. The crisp snap of a pull-tab aluminum beer can may never replace the creaking door as a clue to horror, but in "Outback" it makes a reasonable try.There are, of course, more spectacular invocations, such as a pair of kangaroo huntsone by day, one by nightwhich are in fact real, and which may show you all you ever want to see of how two-legged animals die.But scarier for me is a scene in one of the city's great sprawling saloons, a moment of hushed, terrifying solemnity when in a kind of lunatic praise of long-departed soldiers, sailors and airmen, the drinkers are admonished over a spectral loudspeaker, "Lest We Forget!" I suspect that these scenes are real, too, and to have discovered them is a filmmaker's coup.The entire cast is fine, certainly including Gary Bond as the unlucky John Grant, Donald Pleasence as the alcoholic doctor who gives him bed and board, and Chips Rafferty as the local constable who, like a slightly benevolent despot, befriends him.But I especially admired Sylvia Kay as a sullen, sexually hungry housewife, and Al Thomas as her pathetically eager husband. And for the various minor actors and, I should guess, half the male population of Broken Hill, New South Wales, Australia, there must be credit for a screen debut that ought to put them on anybody's map.

title: Rangers Turn Back Wings, 43 Cavaliers End Knicks Streak
description: Almost effortlessly, which is the characteristic of his style as a scorer and playmaker, Jean Ratelle became the first member of the New York Rangers to accumulate 100 points in a National Hockey League season during last night's 43 victory over the Detroit Red Wings.

title: Cahill Declares President Neglects the Urban States
description: TRENTON. Feb. 20Gov. William T. Cahill, expressing bitterness at what he sees as the Federal Administration's failure to help urban states. like New Jersey, believes that President Nixon doesn't relate. to the average guy in the street.

title: PRAGUE ROUNDUPS STIRRING UNEASE
description: PRAGUE, Feb. 10  A few months after the 1968 invasion of Czechoslovakia by Soviet and other Communistbloc troops, a group of actors in Ostrava, northern Bohemia, produced a parody of a Russian book.

Mr. Smith, a New Englander with degrees from Dartmouth and Harvard, joined General American Investors in 1948 as an analyst. He spoke the other day with Vartanig G. Vartan of The New York Times about the investment scene. Excerpts from their conversation follow:

Gareilk runs a frenetically busy City Council President's office, responds eagerly to complaints from neighborhoods where residents feel City Hall is pushing them around and never turns down an invitation to make a speech.

Apparently, there is to be no option suggesting to Mr. Nixon that perhaps the President's role ought to be, instead, to restore some perspective and restraint to a highly emotional situation.

Cornell's wonlost mark is 8.2 in the Ivy League. The Big Red also strengthened its hold on second place in the Eastern College Athletic Conference standing with a 143 record.

But six of America's leading, active women playwrightsMiss Fornes, Mrs. Drexler, Julie Bovasso, AdrienneKennedy, Rochelle Owens and Megan Terrydecided to name their new cooperative theater the Women's Theater Council.

title: Vietnamese Expect Attack

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Feb. 22, by George!
description: Yesterday, Congress says, was George Washington's birthday. Traditionalists who forgetfully showed up for work at the bank, on Wall Street or at the Off Track Betting parlor may not, unfortunately, take today off. Though it might have come as a surprise to Washington's parents, not to mention Julius Caesar and Pope Gregory XIII, to be told that the Founding Father was born on the third Monday in February, that's what Congress saysand that's the way it is, beginning in this year of grace 1972.

title: News Analysis
description: The movement to decentralize New York City's government has gained so much momentum and captured the enthusiasm of such diverse politicians that a sense of inevitability has developed about the likelihood that New Yorkers, within a few years, will find themselves living under a weakened City Hall and strong neighborhood governments. Whether or not it ever comes to pass. decentralization has become an appealing slogan for those in search of solutions to urban problems.

description: PEKING, Feb. 21 (AP)Throughout an eightcourse, threehour banquet in President Nixon's honor a band mingled Chinese folk songs with such Americana as Home on the Range, Turkey in the Straw and America the Beautiful.

title: A New Start
description: The Chinese Army band played America the Beautiful and Home on the Range. President Nixon quoted Chairman Mao Tsetung approvingly, used his chopsticks skillfully and clinked glasses with every Chinese official sight. Premier Chou Enlai urged his guests to drink up, sent his greetings to the American people, and chatted amiably on camera in English with the Nixons. One might have thought the Peking banquet a reunion of old. friends rather than the first social meeting of the leaders of two nations that have been bitterly hostile for more than two decades.

description: PEKING, Feb. 21 (Reuters) As Premier Chou Enlai toasted the Nixon visit tonight as a positive move and the President responded with a proposal for a long march by different roads toward a structure of peace, their words were translated by two Chinese. who have lived in the United States.

But he and many other longterm jobless who now are getting the new benefits in 13 states still worry that it will be a long time before they can take home a real paycheck.

description: PEKING, Tuesday, Feb. 22 The coming of the Americans has caused two faint cultural tremors here. They are probably insignificant on any seismic Political scale, but they certainly belong in the accounts of this strange visitation.

title: Sports of The Times
description: It undoubtedly was my misfortune to talk to all the wrong people about the Winter Olympic Games. Everyone I spoke toand there were no exceptionsthought the festival was disappointingly dull. They said so private conversation. Not having sense enough to keep my big mouth shut I blabbered out the same reactions in print. Katy, bar the door! They're still coming at me!

title: Town on the Hudson, Citing Ecology, Resists One Man's Landfill

It added that Itel, under an agreement in principle, would provide financing for up to $10million in purchases by the end of 1973.

title: Sato Comment Guarded
description: TOKYO, Feb. 21 (AP)Premier Eisaku Sato was among millions of Japanege who watched President Nixon's arrival at Peking on television today. description: Miss Lauree McMahon, daughter of Mrs. McNamee McMahon of New York and the late Daniel J. McMahon, was married in St. Vincent Ferrer Roman Catholic Church here yesterday to Gregory Charles Hickok, son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Eugene F. Hickok of Minneapolis.

The company is composed of 11 young performers who area blind or whose vision is severely impaired and a professional guest actor, Robert Shaver, who is sighted. Performances will be repeated on March 17, 18 and 19.

title: RENT STRIKE SEEN AS INHIBITING AID

She is a designer of movement and tableaus who shows a deep interett in surface textures and in their images, whether reflected or televised.

title: HighPriced Labor Peace
description: Both the United States and Great Britain have had bruising reminders in recent weeks of the inadequacy of existing methods for resolving labor disputes essential industries. The strikes in the British coal mines and on the West Coast docks inflicted widespread economic damage while the workers were off the job, but the longterm impact of the two peace settlements in heightened wageprice inflation may be even more Injurious.

description: MOUNT VERNON, N.Y., Feb. 21  Twenty people, including welfare admi,nistrators, building inspectors and others who work with Westchester County's poor gathered here last week in response to a challenge to indicate who has tailed to do what in the case of Mrs. Maggie Chisholm.

title: 5 SEEKING TO CURB POLICE PUBLICITY
description: Lawyers for five defendanee on trial in Queens for the murder of a Black Panther of ficial plan to seek a Federal Court injunction this marring to prevent the police here from making any further public statements about the Black Liberation Army.

title: Motorola Unit Plans to Offer $25Million in Debentures
description: LONDON, Feb. 21 (Reuters) Motorola, Inc., announced today that Its subsidiary, the Motorola international Capital Corporation, had proposed to offer $25million of guaranteed sinking fund debentures due March 1, 1987, through an international group of underwriters led by Goldman Sachs & Co.

title: Theater: Moonchildren
description: Once in a while a play manages to provide an epitaph for its time. Sometimes it is a great play such as The Cherry Orchard. At others it is a less than great play, such as Clifford Odets's Awake and Sing or John Osborne's Look Back in Anger. But in each instance the playwright takes a time and a place and sums it up.

title: nets Snap Loss Streak, Top Chaparrals, 10495
description: UNIONDALE, L. I., Feb. 21  A weary New York Nets team arrived at La Guardia Field early this morning after having suffered their fourth straight defeat a few hours earlier in Tampa, Fla.

title: North Korean Denunciation
description: HONG KONG, Feb. 21 (Reuters)North Korea published a bitter denunciation today of President Nixon as the American leader arrived in China, North Korea's neighbor and closest ally.

title: Democratic Governors Rebuke a Consultant Who Suggests They Concede 30 States in November
description: ANNAPOLIS, Md., Feb: 21The Democratic Governors, whose views in such matters carry little weight, did battl today with a professional campaign consultant about the party's strategy for the 1972 Presidential campaign.

title: India View Cautious
description: NEW DELHI, Feb. 21 (Reuters)  Prime Minister Indira Gandhi declared today that India would not accept any decision that might be taken on the fate of Asia at the current talks between President, Nixon and Chinese leaders.

title: The Unmuggable
description: No union is more identified with New York City than the International Ladies Garment Workers Union, born in the sweatshops of the lower East Side more than seventy years ago. And no labor leader better captures the city's restless spirit than the garment union's honorary president, David Dubinsky. He deserved a friendlier greeting on his eightieth birthday than he got from mugger at the start of the holiday weekend.

title: Mrs. Nixon Tours Peking Hotel Kitchen
description: PEKING, Tuesday, Feb. 22 (UPI)  Mrs. Richard M. Nixon, in her first outing alone in the Chinese capital, visited the stately Peking Hotel this morning.

title: Kings Point Wins, 8866
description: The United States Merchant Marine Academy defeated Yeshiva University, 8866, in basketball last night at John Bowne High School gym in Flushing.

title: Knicks Bradley Weighs Missouri Primary Race
description: Bill Bradley of the Knicks said yesterday he was considering entering the race for the Democratic nomination for State Treasurer in Missouri.

title: MUSKIE SLASHES CAMPAIGN STAFF
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 21For the second time in a year. Senator Edmund S. Musick, hascut costs and dismissed workers here in an attempt to keep his campaign for the Democratic Presidential nomination from sliding into financial default.

title: ENCEPHALITIS CURB REPORTED IN SOVIET
description: MOSCOW, Feb. 21The Soviet Union has reported a major advance in its fight against an environmental diseasespringsummer encephalitisthat has been a serious obstacle In its economic development of the forested regions of Siberia.

title: COLLEGES TO PLAY AT NASSAU ARENA
description: The new Nassau Coliseum in Uniondale, L. I., announced yesterday that it would be the site of college basketball games beginning next seasona move that is expected to help revitalize interest in the sport in the metropolitan area.

title: Bargain Hunters Defy the Cold Weather
description: There's nothing like bargains to warm a shopper's feet on a freezing day.

title: Tennessee Tops Florida
description: KNOXVILLE, Tenn., Feb. 21 (UPI)Len Kosmalski scored 25 points tonight to ledd Tennessee to a 5552 Southeastern Conference victory over Florida.

title: Baseball Tries a Shorter Spring
description: ST. PETERS13URG, Fla., Feb. 21For the first time since baseball teams started coming south at the turn of the century, a farreaching experiment is being pressed this yearthe shortened spring training season. But the New York Mets stand fast among the dissenters.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today Feb. 22, 1972
description: ECONOMIC AND SOCIAL COUNCIL Committee on Elimination of Racial Discrimination.10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M. Committee on Periodic Reports on Human Rights10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M. International Maritime Consultative Organization preparatory group for conference on container traffic.

title: SCHOOL INTEGRATION PRESSED IN BUFFALO
description: BUFFALO, Feb. 21 (AP)Ewald B. Nyquist, state Commissioner of Education, said again today that Buffalo's Board of Education must submit a desegregation plan by April 1.

title: BULLETS DEFEAT HERS, 102 TO 101
description: BALTIMORE, Feb. 21 (AP)Archie Clark scored on a jump shot with 20 seconds to Play today to give the Baltimore Bullets a 102101 victory over the Philadelphia 76ers in a National Basketball Association game.

title: Cosmos to Play in 72 At Hofstra University
description: The New York Cosmos announced yesterday that they will not return to Yankee Stadium and disclosed that Hofstra University will be their home field for the 1972 season.

title: Quebec's Nationless National Cinema at the Modern
description: I'm not altogether sure what makes a national cinema, except for a clearly defined and independent nationat one time or another Yugoslavia, Czechoslovakia, France, perhaps, and in the Western Hemisphere, of course, Hollywood.

title: A.F.L.C.I.O. Urges Funds For Radio Stations in Europe
description: MIAMI BEACH, Feb. 21 (AP)  A.F.L.C.I.O. leaders strongly opposed today a move in Congress to end Federal funding of. Radio Free Europe and Radio Liberty, which have broadcast to the Soviet Union and Eastern Europe for more than 20 years.

title: Relief Payments to Rise for Some Here
description: I Welfare recipients in federally assisted public housing Iprojects in the city will get $9million more a year to spend under an amendment to the Housing Act of 1937. The total amounts to an average of $391 a year a family.

title: At Gorky Park, Muscovites on Ice Pause to Gaze at Swimmers
description: MOSCOW, Feb. 21Winter grudgingly relaxed its grip On Moscow over the weekend, and 60 of the Soviet Union's 30,000 devoted winter swimmers took advantage of balmy midthirties weather for a bracing dip among the ice floes of the Moscow River.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: A Crown in ExileIs It Time for a Homecoming?

title: SHOEMAKER TIES ARCARO'S RECORD
description: ARCADIA, Calif., Feb. 21Bill Shoemaker piloted Practicante and Lord Derby to victories in the two divisions of the San Luis Obispo Handicap at Santa Anita today and equaled Eddie Arcaro's career Irecord for stakes winners at 554.

title: A Display of Unity
description: MIAMI BEACH. Feb. 21 (UPI)  Maritime unions, in an unusual display of unity, have agreed to work toward Labor stability in their industry in an effort to halt the outflow of American jobs to foreignflag ships.

title: Vancouver to Hold AliChuvalo Match
description: VANCOUVER, British Columbai. Feb. 21 (AP)Muhammad Ali and George Chuvalo will meet in a scheduled 12round heavyweight fight in the Pacific Coliseum On March 13, Murray Pezim Productions Ltd. of Vancouver announced today.

title: Humphrey Wins the Endorsement of Florida's Attorney General
description: MIAMI, Feb, 21Senator Hubert H. Humphrey, who has collected relatively few endorsements in his campaign for the Democratic Presidential nomination, won the support today of the Florida Attorney General, Robert L. Shevin.

title: Joseph Kennedy 3d On Plane Hijacked From Delhi to Aden
description: NEW DELHI, Tuesday, Feb. 22Three Arabs hijacked a West German jumbo jet on which Joseph P. Kennedy 3d, 19yearold son of the late Senator Robert F. Kennedy, was a passenger early, today. The plane, on a flight from New Delhi to Athens, landed safely eight hours later at Aden, Southern Yemen, at the southwest corner of the Arabian Peninsula, the airline anounced.

title: Washington Headquarters In White Plains Reopened
description: NORTH WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., Feb. 21A tiny house here that George Washington used three times during the Revolution was opened to the public for its 1972 season this afternoon.

title: The Hostess Dress: Something Between Bathrobe and Ballgown
description: Hostess dresses don't stay home any more, They really aren't meant to. They aren't filmy and edged in marabou, nor are they something you throw on in a hurry when you've just come out of the shower and the doorbell rings.

title: Seton Hall Triumphs, 7770
description: SOUTH ORANGE, N. J., Feb. 21Three players scored 20ormore points tonight as Seton Hall University defeated Fairfield University, 7770, and snapped a threegame losing streak.

title: AllVolunteer Army Unit Training at Dix
description: FORT DIX, N. J., Feb. 21The 187 men in B Company, First Battalion, Second Brigade, now in the seventh week of their basic training here, are making history of a sort.

title: Mayor Phones Dabinsky To Offer His Sympathy
description: Mayor Lindsay called David Dubinsky from Wisconsin yesterday to express his regret for the mugging suffered by the labor leader Saturday night and to wish him a happy 80th birthday today.

title: New Chief Executive Elected at the L. &N.
description: Seaboard Coast Industries, Inc., the holding company that owns the Seaboard Coast Line Railroad and the Louisville & Nashville Railroad, announced yesterday the election of Prime F. Osborn as president and chief executive officer of the L. & N. Both railroads are highly profitable.

title: Illegal Aliens Here On Welfare Said To Cost Millions
description: Illegal aliens on welfare in New York City may be coating up to $100million a year In relief grants, Assemblyman Andrew Stein asserted yesterday.

title: China Visitors Say Nixon Has Been Topic for Weeks
description: HONG KONG, Feb. 21 (UPI) Travelers from China said today that President Nixon's visit has been a primary topic of discussion at political meetings in schools, farms, factories and army posts for the last few weeks.

title: Communists Here Dropping the Use Of Term American
description: United States Communists will not call.themselves.Americans any more in party statements, a spokesman reported yesterday as the Communist party, U. S. A., closed its fourday 20th annual convention at the Towers Hotel in Brooklyn.

title: MARIA MAYER, 65, A NOBEL PHYSICIST
description: SAN DIEGO, Calif., Feb. 21 (Al')  Dr. Maria Goeppert Mayer, the first woman physicist to win the Nobel Prize since Marie Curie in 1903, died last night of heart failure. She was 65 years old.

title: Efforts to Aid Sicilian Industry Backfire
description: PALERMO, Sicily  Formidable efforts to bring new industry to Sicily, under way for the last dozen years, are backfiring. It was expected that the island's traditional industries would decline. It was not foreseen, however, that overall employment in Sicily would suffer, as it has.

title: Exhibition Pays Tribute to Art Gallery of the 1960's
description: During its brief but spectacular existence in the 1960's, the Green Gallery became one of New York's most important art galleries. By the time it closed its doors at 15 West 57th Street In 1965, after five years in operation, it had acquired an international reputation as one of the major showcases of the avantgarde.

title: Welfare Family called Younger And Better Educated Than Ever
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 21 (UN) The Federal Government said today that the average American family on welfare last year was younger, healthier and better fed and educated than ever before.

title: GALLIARDERS DEBUT IN CHAMBER CONCERT
description: If there were rough edges at the Galliard Trio's debut concert late Sunday afternoon in Carnegie Recital Hall, it was understandable. It takes time and constant practice to develop a smoothly integrated chamber group, and the Trio was formed only last spring.

title: Teaching English to Some of Britain's Shyest Immigrants
description: LONDON  I want a bottle of milk. I want a tube of toothpaste. I want a packet of cigarettes. The speaker was A hesitant young Indian woman in a blue sari.

title: 4 African Hoteliers Study Psychology Of the U.S. Tourist
description: 4 African Hoteliers Study Psychology Of the U.S. Tourist

title: Rev. Dr. George Stewart Dead; Author Fought in 2 World Wars
description: The Rev. Dr. George Stewart, author, minister and soldier, died Saturday at sea aboard the Sagafjord, near Singapore, while serving as chaplain aboard a cruise to the Orient. He was 80 years old and lived in Dublin, N.H.

title: Advertising:
description: Who's the king of the hill? Why, J. Walter Thompson is king of the hillstill.

title: AIR FORCE WASTE ON PARTS CHARGED
description: A report charging the Air Force with wasting millions of dollars in purchases of spare parts for new planes has been issued by the General Accounting Office.

title: Wood, Field and Stream: Swamp Lure
description: FLAMINGO, Fla., Feb. 21 Medical libraries contain no reference to Everglades fever, but it is a malady of considerable virulence, affecting people of all ages.

title: SovietIraqi Pact Expected
description: MOSCOW, Feb. 21Western diplomats here believe that the Soviet Union is trying to arrange some kind of friendship treaty with Iraq along the lines of treaties signed last year with Egypt and India.

title: Peking Daily Publishes Photo of Nixon and Mao
description: PEKING, Tuesday, Feb. 22 (Agence FrancePresse)Jenmin Jih Pao, the Chinese Communist party newspaper, today published on its front page photographs showing President Nixon shaking hands with Chairman Mao Tsetung.

title: Nixon,ina'Symbolic Act, Signs Bill on Dock Talks
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 21 The White House, making a show of its communications channels with Peking, announced today that as a symbolic gesture, President Nixon had signed in China legislation to force striking longshoremen back to work and to arbitrate terms of their contract.

title: The Long March: For Communist China, It Is the Central Epic
description: The author of the book The Long March 1935, from which the following excerpt is taken, was formerly director of The Far East Economic Review and is financial editor of The Straits Times and senior editorial adviser to The New Nation, both in Singapore.

title: Soviet Delegation in Syria for 6 Days of Talks
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Feb. 21A Soviet political, economic and military delegation arrived in Damascus today on a sixday visit amid signs of wider cooperation between Moscow and a number of Arab states.

title: Soft Landing on Moon By Luna Is Reported
description: BOCHUM, Germany, Feb. 21 (AP)The West German space observatory has reported that the Soviet moon probe, Luna 20; made a soft landWg today on the sunlit lunar surface.

title: TV Networks Schedule Today's China Coverage
description: The major television net9 works announced a schedule of President Nixon's China visit for today; times are New York times

title: State Police Promoting 19 In a CommandChain Shift
description: ALBANY, Feb. 21 (UPI)A largescale change in the command chain of the New York State Police Department will go into effect Thursday with the promotion of 19 officers, Including the naming of a new first deputy superintendent, it was announced today by Supt. William E. Kirwan.

title: STEWART RECITAL IN A VARIED MOOD
description: The fine qualities of Thomas Stewart's first New York liede recital, at Tully Hall Sunday night, were not unexpected. In his performances at the Metropolitan Opera over the last six years, Mr. Stewart has proved to be an exceptionally interesting vocal actor  his Wotan, in fact, has often been particularly praised for its imaginative and intimately colored articulation of the text.

title: Cold War Environment
description: Despite a reported agreement that would permit limited East German participation in a European environmental conference at Belgrade next month, cold war politics continues to threaten the larger United Nations Conference on the Human Environment scheduled for Stockholm in June. This should notand need notbe permitted to happen.

title: Mansfield Backs Askew
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 21 (AP)  The Senate Democratic leader, Mike Mansfield of Montana, ptu in another plug today for Gov. Reubin Askew of Florida as the party's VicePresidential candidate this year. Senator Mansfield, at the start of the Senate session, read an editorial lauding Governor Asknew's stand on the school busing issue.

title: Rockefeller Submits a Bill to Promote StateCity Planning on Transportation
description: ALBANY, Feb. 21  A bill to promote cooperation between New York City and the state in the planning and development of transportation corridors in the city was sent to the Legislature today by Governor Rockefeller.

title: Aides of Hughes Alter Security Procedures
description: MANAGUA, Nicaragua, Feb. 21The elevators have once again begun to stop at the eighth floor of the Hotel Intercontinental.

title: Woman Senator May Run For President of Colombia
description: gBOGOTA, Colombia, Feb. 21 (AP)  Senator Maria Eugenia Rojas de Moreno Diaz said today that she would be a candidate for President in 1974 if her father, the former dictator Gen. Gustavo Rojas PiniIla, does not run.

title: McGovern Backers Decry OneIssue Image, but Vietnam Remains as the Key Factor in His Campaign
description: NOTTINGHAM, N. FL, Feb. 21 On Sept. 24, 1963, George McGovern of South Dakota had bean a member of the United States Senate for less than year. His friend John F. Kennedy was still President, and there were only 15,000 American military advisers in South Vietnam. Nonetheless, in a Senate speech that day, Mr. McGovern categorically denounced the United States involvement in Vietnam.

title: JARRING TO VISIT JERUSALEM SOON: NEV U.N. BID SEEN
description: JERUSALEM, Feb. 21The Israeli Foreign Ministry announced today that Dr. Gunnar V. Jarring, the United Nations special representative for the Middle East, would soon visit Jerusalem, apparently in an attempt to revive his peacemaking mission after a yearlong stalemate.

title: Solitron Dissidents Seem to Have Lost
description: A proxy fight to oust the management of Solitron Devices, Inc., appears to have been defeated, figures reported by the electronics concern showed yesterday.

title: SHIFT IN SCHEDULE
description: PEKING, Tuesday, Feb. 22President Nixon's weeklong summit conference in China quickly reached a high point yesterday in a surprise meeting with Chairman Mao Tsetung.

title: Greek Say U.S. Foiled Plan for Cyprus
description: ATHENS, Feb. 21  Officials here have blamed the United States for the collapse of their plan to oust Archbishop Makarios as President of Cyprus, which had the aim of speeding a GreekTurkish compromise settlement of the Cyprus dispute.

title: Senate Alters Job Bias Bill To Exempt Church Hiring
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 21 (AP) The Senate voted today to exempt churches and other religious institutions rem provisions banning job discrimination on the basis of religion.

title: 20 Central Banks Said to Be Among Dollar Speculators
description: GENEVA, Feb. 21 (AP)At least 20 central banks from developing countries as well as from some richer nations joined speculators in disposing of unwanted United States dollars last year, adding to the pressure on the American currency.

title: Vietnam Strength 127,100
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Feb. 21 (UPI)A total of 4,100 American servicemen left Vietnam last week, reducing the number of Americans still in the war zone to 127,100, the United States command said today. It said the current strength was the lowest since August, 1965.

title: EXPANDED CENTER IN HARLEM URGED
description: Supporters of a proposal to expand the Schomburg black culture Center are urging the Board of Estimate to approve an initial $1.6million appropriation to prepare plans and acquire a site for the Center in Harlem.

title: Taipei Assembly Declares Disapproval of Nixon Trip
description: TAIPEI, Taiwan, Feb. 21 (Reuters)The Assembly of Nationalist China declared its disapproval today as President Nixon began his visit to Peking.

title: NIEDERHOFFER WINS IN SQUASH RACQUETS
description: DETROIT, Feb. 21  Victor Niederhoffer of the Harvard Club of New York, a 28yearold professor of business administration and investments at the University of California, won his second national squash. racquets singles championship today at the University Club.

title: Martin Conquers Fishbach In Junior Final, 60, 62
description: PORT WASHINGTON, L. I., Feb. 2IMike Fishbach's upset streak ended today as the unseeded Great Neck youth was beaten by Billy Martin of Cali fornia, 60, 62, in, the final of the Port Washington Classic junior tennis tournament. Results of finals:

title: C. W. Post Takes Lead
description: PRINCETON, N. J., Feb. 21Athletes from C. W. Post took first place in two of five field events today and gained the lead in the 30th annual Metropolitan intercollegiate track and field championships.

title: Israel Holds War Games, Biggest Since 67 War
description: JEBEL LIBNI, Israelioccupied Sinai, Feb. 21 (UPI)Israel conducted her biggest war games since the 1967 ArabIsraeli war here today, before hundreds of invited guests.

title: Grumman Vice Presidents
description: The Grumman Aerospace Corporation has announced the election of John M. Buxton and L. M. Satterfield as vice presidents. Mr. Satterfield was formerly special assistant to the chairman. Mr. Buxton heads tile company's operation in Houston.

title: 10,000 Longshoremen Are Back on Job Working on 218 West Coast Vessels
description: SAN DIEGO, Feb. 21Nearly, 10,000 longshoremen went back to work today unloading and loading a pileup of 218 ships that had been immobilized in West Coast ports by the nation's longest and most costly dock strike.

title: Big Copper Producer in Zambia To Get $25Million London Loan
description: LUSAKA, Zambia, Feb. 21A Britishled consortium will lend $25million, to one of Zambia's two major copper producers, it was announced today. This brings to $94.8million the total raised in loans or credits for the whole Zambian industry in the last few weeks.

title: Transcript of the Toasts by Premier Chou and President Nixon
description: Following are transcripts of the toasts delivered at banquet in Peking last night by Premier Chou Enlai of China and President Nixon, as recorded by The New York Times.

title: HAROLD C. CASE, LED BOSTON U. 16 YEARS
description: ANASQUAM, Mass., Feb. 21 (AP)Dr. Harold C. Case, president of Boston University from 1951 to 1967, died yesterday at his home. He was 69 years old. During his administration, Boston University completed extensive construction programs, including the university's 10 largest buildings and its medical center.

title: 10 DEMOCRATS LISTED ON CAROLINA BALLOT
description: RALEIGH, N. C., Feb. 21 (UPI)  Gov. George C. Wallace of Alabama and Terry Sanford, former North Carolina Governor, were among 10 Democrats nominated by the State Board of Elections today to the ballot for the state's May 6 Presidential primary.

title: Pietrangeli Still Hits Winners
description: I've lost my reflexes, I'm too slow, I can't anticipate, I've lost my confidence, said 38. yearold Nicola Pietrangeli of Italy yesterday as the second Clean (but cold) Air tennis tournament began in the Seventh Regiment Armory at Park Avenue and 66th Street.

title: Morales Pins Prof. Tanaka Before 22,090 at Garden
description: Pedro Morales pinned Professor Tanaka in a professional wrestling exhibition last night at Madison Square Garden before 22,090 fans.

title: TV: Camera in Peking Shows Affairs of State
description: Once again, in recording President Nixon's trip to China, television is demonstrating that its impact and power are unique. perhaps still beyond full comprehension. This is particularly true in the medium's live coverage of a historic event.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Fatal House Fire Is Studied
description: NEWTOWN, Conn., Feb. 21 (AP)Fire officials today were unable to determine the cause of a fire that took the life of First Selectman Timothy B. Treadwell, 41 years old at his home yesterday. His wife and three sons escaped unharmed. Fire Chief Herbert Lewis said that Mr. Treadwell was found in a room that was untouched by flames, but that it was filled with terrific heat and smoke. Mr. Treadwell was pronounced dead on arrival at Danbury Hospital.

title: 1963 Verses by Mao Are Quoted by Nixon
description: The quotation from Mao Tsetung in President Nixon's toast last night came from the last poem in the officially published collection of Chairman Mao's poems. The poem is dated Jan. 9, 1963. One published translation, differing slightly from Mr. Nixon's version, says in part:

title: Mobutu Reportedly Drops 5 Senior Cabinet Officers
description: KINSHASA, Zaire, Feb. 21 (Reuters)  President Mobutu Sese Seko of Zaire today dropped five senior ministers in a sweeping reorganization, according to the Zaire press agency.

title: Libyan Heads for Soviet
description: CAIRO, Feb. 21  Libya announced today that her Deputy Premier, Maj. Abdel Salem Jallud, would pay an early visit to Moscow. Tonight, Major Jallud arrived in Cairo for talks before flying on to the Soviet Union.

title: Books of The Times
description: THE PRINCE. By R. M. Koster, 351 pages, Morrow. $7.95.

title: Canada Brokerage House Fights Exchange Inquiry
description: MONTREAL, Feb. 21The Montreal brokerage house of Holland, Andrews, Perrier & Co., Ltd., has made a fresh lega move to contest the right of the Montreal and Canadian Stock Exchanges to hear what it calls false charges against it. Canada Brokerage House Fights Exchange Inquiry

title: Industrialist's Son Indicted
description: DALLAS, Feb. 21 (AP)Richard Allen Ling, 19 years old, son of James Ling, an industrialist, was indicted today on a charge of burglary. He was accused on charges stemming from a Jan. 15 burglary at a home here. A diamond pin, pocket watch, rifle, shotgun, radio, cowboy boots and three Kennedy half dollars were taken.

title: Net Income Climbs At BrownForman In 3 and 9 Months
description: Net income of the BrownForman Distillers Corporation, rose in the three months ended Jan. 31 to $3.38million, or 29 cents a share, from $2.3million, or 20 cents a share, a year earlier, the company reported yesterday. Sales, it added, rose to $75.81million from $50.29million in the yearearlier period.

title: Police'Designation Removed
description: STANFORD, Calif., Feb. 21 (AP)The Stanford University police department has removed the word police from its badges, shoulder patches, and cars after an editorial protest by The Stanford Daily, the campus newspaper. James Siena, legal adviser to the Stanford president Richard W. Ly man, said that the changes had been made because use of the word police could lead to misunderstandings and violations of the California vehicle code.

title: Upstate Fruit Growers Try to Save Research Lab
description: HIGHLAND, N. Y., Feb. 21 The fruit growers of the Hudson Valley are up in arms against a threat to their research laboratnry here, which they say is being butchered by state budget cuts.

title: ExConvict Is Key Witness in Plot Trial
description: HARRISBURG, Pa., Feb. 21  The Government said today that its conspiracy case against the Rev. Philip F. Berrigan and six other antiwar activists was based on the word of one informer, Boyd F. Douglas Jr., a former convict who has served seven years in Federal prisons,

title: Bridge: Life Master Pairs Contest Won by Long Island Men
description: Two of Long Island's bestknown experts, Frank Schuld of Glen Head and Emmett Pollenz of East Meadow, captured the life master pair championship at the Greater New York Bridge Association's sectional tournament at the New York Hilton Hotel Sunday.

title: Farm Workers Accepted As Union by A.F.L.C.I.O.
description: MIAMI BEACH, Fla., Feb. 21 George Meany announced today that the United Farm Workers Organizing Committee, headed by Cesar Chavez, had been accepted into the American Federation of Labor and Congress of Industrial Relations as a fullfledged union. The farm workers, numbering some 30,000 members, have had the status of organizing committee for the last several years since first being formed.

title: Market Holiday
description: All securities and commodity exchanges in the United Stales were closed yesterday for Washington's Birthday. Most banks were also shut, as were government offices.

title: U.S. REPORTS MIG DOWNED IN LAOS
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Tuesday, Feb. 22 (AP)American fighterbombers shot down a MIG21 interceptor over northern Laos yesterday and made four attacks in North Vietnam, knocking out at least four antiaircraft guns in fresh surge of aerial engagements, the United States command announced today.

title: The Talk of Apache Junction, Ariz.
description: APACHE JUNCTION, Ariz. In 1936, Don Andrea saw a movie about the search for the infamous Lost Dutchman gold mine. The hero, played by Buck Jones, found the mine by following the shadow cast by a stake he had discovered in a remote cave. The final scene showed Buck Jones and the leading lady riding down the street with gold nuggetsin their car, recalled Mr. Andrea, a heavy man who usually looks as if he had just got up. His face glowed, like a face in an inexpensive religious painting. It really was something. Mr. Andreawas 9 when he saw the the movie, back in Newport, Ky., but like thousands of people before and since, he caught the bug  gold.

title: Mao, Symbol of the New China, in 1919 Foresaw an Age of Glory
description: LONDONI venture to make a singular assertion: One day, the reform of the Chinese. people will be more profound than that of any other people, and the society of the Chinese people will be more radiant than that of any other people Our golden age, our age of glory and splendor, lies before us!

title: Winchell Buried in Phoenix; Daughter Is Only Mourner
description: PHOENIX, Ariz., Feb. 21 (AP) Walter Winchell was buried here today, in a service with only a single mourner and rabbi present.

title: 2D RALLY PLANNED ON ITALIAN UNITY
description: The ItalianAmerican Civil Rights League is planning to celebrate Italian Unity Day again this year with a rally at Columbus Circle on June 26, according to Anthony Colombo, vice president of the league.

title: JURY CHOICE BEGINS. IN YABLONSKI CASE
description: WASHINGTON, Pa., Feb. 22 Selection of a jury for the trial of Paul E. Gilly of Cleveland, who is charged with the murders of Joseph Yablowski, the United Mine Workers insurgent, and two members of his family more than two years ago, began in Washington County Court here today.

title: ACADEMY NAMES OSCAR NOMINEES
description: HOLLYWOOD, Feb. 22The Academy Award season got Under way today as three films took the lead with eight nominations apiece.

title: Sports of The Times
description: A recent item on the obituary page reported that Capt. Reaves Baysinger, quarterback for the United States Naval Academy in 1946, 1947 and 1948, had died Hodgkins disease at the age of 45. The item said his football career had included two of the most famous ArmyNavy games in the history, an understatement.

title: BUYING SPURRED ON SOYBEAN LIST
description: The settlement over the holiday weekend of the West Coast longshoremen's strike and the grain handlers strike at Chicago storage elevators tended to influence early buying of soybean and wheat futures on the Chicago Board of Trade yesterday.

title: Vacationing Ruler of Qatar Displacd by His aousin in a Bloodless Uprising.
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Feb. 22The Ruler of Qatar, one of the Perisan Gulf emirates, was overthrown in a bloodless palace coup today.

title: Levitz Plans 3forle Split And. 600,000Share Offer
description: The Levitz Furniture Corporation, whose stock has been one of the most volatile on the New York Stock Exchange, leading to three separate investigations, yesterday announced a 3for1 common stock split, without change in par value.

title: Destination Undetermined
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 22 State Department officials said today that they did not know which zoo would get the two pandas.

title: Wings Top Leafs, 54
description: DETROIT, Feb.22 (UPI)Nick Libett's second goal of the game, at 9 minutes 53 seconds of the third period, gave the Detroit Red Wings an uphill 54 victory over the Toronto Maple Leafs in the National Hockey League tonight and broke fourthplace tie between the teams in the East Division.

title: Shop Talk
description: If you live in the West 70's or occasionally make the trek to buy cheesecake from Miss Grimble, you may have come upon a tiny, shop with a plantfilled window and a sign reading Koos van den Akker Couture. If you've never been on Columbus Avenue between 75th and 76th Streets, it may be worth the trip. Mr. van den Akker operates his shop in the couture tradition: He designs a collection, produces samples and then makes up each garment to order in the customer's choice of fabric. Since he buys limited quantities of materials, most things turn out to be one of a kind.

title: NIXON SEES CHOU IN TWO SESSIONS OF POLICY TALKS
description: PEKING, Wednesday, Feb. 23 President Nixon and Premier Chou Enlai met for four hours of policy discussions yesterday afternoon as China finally let her people know that a major event was under way.

title: 2 MORE TESTS WON BY HEATH ON MARKET
description: LONDON, Feb. 22Prime Minister Heath's Government carried two stages of its Common Market legislation tonight by majorities of 30 in the House of Commons.

title: Theater: Gelber Ends 4Year Absence With Sleep
description: For any play to be set in an experimental sleep laboratory is playing with fire as well as with sleep. For critics, so many plays actually are experimental sleep laboratories that Jack Gelber's new work at the American Place Theater, titled Sleep, might be thought to be underlining the obvious.

title: CONFEREES CLEAR FORWIT AID BILL
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 22 (AP) House and Senate conferees agreed today to a $3.2billion appropriation for foreign aid and related agencies.

title: MRS. RAPHAEL HUME
description: STAMFORD, Conn., Feb. 22Mrs. Mary Ellen Butler Hume, widow of Raphael Hume, architect of many public buildings who drew the plans for the reconstruction of the University of Nijmegen in the Netherlands in 1948, died yesterday in Stamford Hospital. She was 76 years old and lived at 73 Nathan Hale Drive.

title: Soviet Hails Gains From Soft Landing On Rough Moon Site
description: MOSCOW, Feb. 22The Soviet Union announced today that with the successful soft landing yesterday of its unmanned moon. craft Luna 20 it had resolved the important scientific and technical problem of delivering an. instrumented package safely to sections of the lunar surface with rough terrain.

title: Japan's Ambassador Stiimps the U.S. To Promote Amity and Understanding
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 22For 15 months the Japanese Ambassador to the United States, Nobuhiko Ushiba, has been crisscrossing this country in an intensive crusade for the cause of alliance between Japan and America.

title: Troubles Dog Clemente, Series Hero
description: BRADENTON, Fla., Feb. 22For Roberto Clemente, the hero of the World. Series,_the_spoils of victory hang heavy as he prepares for his 18th season with the Pittsburgh Piratesmore tired and more troubled than at any time in recent years.

title: Supreme Court to Expedite Hearing on Gravel's Action in the Pentagon Papers Dispute
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 22Senator Mike Gravel's legal effort to stop a Federal grand jury in Boston form investigating arrangements he made for the publication of the secret Pentagon Papers will be heard later this spring by the Supreme Court.

title: The Music: MovieLike
description: The ballet that President Nixon and his entourage saw yesterday in Peking is a prime example of socialist realism, Chinese style. For whatever else it may be, Red Detachment of Women is a work that extols party doctrine, and that is its prime reason for being. Chairman Mao Tsetung himself approved in 1964. The orientation, he wrote, 9s correct, the revolutionization successful and the artistic quality good.

title: Saigon Police Bar Return of General From Exile in U.S.
description: SAIGON, south Vietnam, Wednesday Feb. 23The Saigon police refused to allow former Suoth Vietnamese army commander to return from exile in the United States today, and ordered the Pan American 747 jumbo jet on which arrived to leave without 200 homeward bound G.I.'s.

title: Facts About China's People and Long History
description: HISTORY

description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 22Joseph Patrick Kennedy 3d has probably seen more adventure in his 19 years than most men see in a lifetime.

title: BRUINS WIN, 43, ON ESPOSITO GOAL
description: VANCOUVER, British Columbia, Feb. 22 (AP)Phil Csposito's 52d goal, of the National Hockey League season a powerplay tally late in the second period, carried the Boston BruMs to a 4.3 victory over the Vancouver Canucks tonight.

title: A U.S. COMPOUND IS SHELLED BY FOE
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Wednesday, Feb. 23 (AP)Enemy troops harassed South Vietnamese forces in the Central Highlands yesterday and shelled the big United States Army support compound at Quinhon, the United States command reported today.

title: Kleindienst, at SenateHearing, Opposes Legalizing Marijuana
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 22Richard G. Kleindienst said today that as Attorney General he would oppose legalization of the use of marijuana because it is a euphoric substance that permits youths to escape from reality.

title: Hanoi Is Silent on Trip
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 22Two days after President Nixon's arrival in China, the North Vietnamese population apparently remains unaware of itunless individual citizens have heard the news on the Peking radio or other broadcasts.

title: Genocide Trials Planned
description: DACCA, Bangladesh, Feb, 22 (Reuters)The Government of Bangladesh plans to try 100 senior Pakistani military officers and officials on charges of genocide for actions taken during the last nine months of 1971, a Foreign Ministry spokesman said today.

title: HUGHES APPROVES AUTHORIZED LIFE
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 22Howard Hughes has accepted the urging of some of his most trusted employes and agreed reluctantly that an authorized biography of him be prepared under their direction, a Hughes Tool Company source said today.

title: 5 of jersey's 6 Black Mayors Find MoneyMajor Problem
description: Raising money takes most of my time, said George J. Phillips, mayor of Chesilhurst Borough, a town of 801 residents in southern New Jersey.

title: President's Trip Raises a Dilemma for State's Conservative Party
description: More than 200 members and supporters of the Conservative party dined on political dilemma last night.
