description: Dr. WeiPing Chen, who had had a long and distinguished career as a churchman and as a diplomat in Nationalist China, died on Wednesday in Taipei, Taiwan. He was 96 years old.

title: Avoidance of Bravura Marks Segovia Recital, First of Three
description: In Philharmonic Hall, where even famous pianists sometimes find it difficult to communicate an adequate range of dynamic nuance and color, a classic guitar recital can seem as fragile as a warm snowflake. (Listening to Andres Segovia there on Wednesday night, one occasionally fancied the Spanish master was conducting a gentle interior monologue that we were allowed to overhear. When Mr. Segovia is playing at his peerless best, even a reduced scale and loss of detail make slight difference, of course; there have been times when he could have given recital from the next county and kept this reviewer mesmerized.

title: FOREIGN AFFAIRS
description: SAIGON, South VietnamThere is a widespread habit of blaming almost every symptom of instability in the United States upon the Vietnam war and notable among such symptoms have been rising race tensions, violence among university students and an alarming rise in the use of drugs. But whether this diagnosis is accurate, whether the sick American chicken hatched the rotten Vietnamese egg or vice versa, is questionable.

title: The Dave Shade Who Died Was Not the Former Boxer
description: LOS ANGELES, Feb. 24 (UPI)Similarity in names resulted in an erroneous report on the death of Dave Shade, the former boxer.

title: $60,000 Swindle in Deposits On Rents Is Charged to 4
description: Four men who operated an unlicensed real estate company were arrested yesterday and accused of swindling more than 200 apartment seekers out of $60,000 in cash deposits on premises with which they had no connection.

title: Aide Who Criticized A.E.C. Over Safety Shifted by Agency
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 24Dr Morris Rosen, an Atomic Energy Commission technical expert who has been critical of the commission's attitude toward safety standards for nuclear power plants, has been shifted from his position.

title: How to Trim Witholding And Take More Home
description: Here, according to the Internal Revenue Service, is how a typical New York taxpayer ends up with excessive reduction of his takehome pay when the new withholding tables are used with the old system of dependency allowances.

title: PERJURY CHARGED AGAINST THALER
description: Four counts of perjury have been added to the stolensecurities charges against Seymour R. Thaler, the former State Senator and recently elected State Supreme Court justice, who goes on trial next week in Federal Court here.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: One cannot but wonder whether in the various draft documents which President Nixon presumably has as. he visits Peking and Moscow there may not be some which, albeit inadvertently, contain words or phrases which appear in the Aesopian lexicon so cherished by Communists.

title: I.R.S. Pleads for an End To Tax Overtwithholding
description: The Internal Revenue Service, disturbed because too much money is being withheld from many incometax payers, called attention yesterday to a device to bring the withholding down to where it should be.

title: Candidates'
description: CONCORD, N. H., Feb. 24The concept of absolute private ownership of land has become outmoded because of environmental needs, Representative Paul N. McCloskey said last night.

title: Animals Born on the Farm
description: As wise an owl and whimsical a water bird as ever perched on tree or land are now sitting on pebble beds and wooden shelves along with dozens of other creatures who will live in Altman's fifth floor handicrafts gallery until about March 22. The birds, antelope, moose, pigs, grasshoppers and elephants are all made from old iron farm implements, tools and farmhouse discards. The creators of this zoological garden are Bill Heise and Dom Zack, who formed sculpturing partnership in 1968 and have been welding old tractor seats and barn hinges together ever since. Both men also teach at a high school in Moretown, Vt.; the former, an art teacher, the latter, the head of the industrial arts department.

title: Pope Takes Part in Funeral for Cardinal Tisserant
description: ROME, Feb. 24Pope Paul VI broke his Lenten retreat this morning to take part in a funeral service in St. Peter's Basilica for Eugene Cardinal Tisserant, the dean of the Sacred College of Cardinals who died Monday at the age of 87. France's Interior Minister, Raymond Marcellin, attended the rite at the head of an official delegation that included Rend Clair, the film director, in his capacity as acting presiding officer of the French Academy in Paris. The Frenchborn Cardinal, scholar of Semitic languages, had been a member of the prestigious institution since 1961. The Pontiff, who wore red mourning vestments, pre sided over the ritual in the basilica's northern transept. Paolo Cardinal Mardis, archpriest of St. Peter's, officiated. Thirtyone Cardinals, including the Vatican Secretary of State, Jean Cardinal Villot, and the Archbishop"of Paris, Francois Cardinal Marty, were also in the congregation. Cardinal Tisserant will be buried tomorrow.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: It seems somewhat naive of The Times righteously to criticize [editorial Feb. 15] the assignment of six city district attorneys to the Irving case after generous, detailed and illustrated coverage of the case has appeared on the front page almost daily for the last three weeks.

title: 14 SENATORS BACK A CHILD CARE BILL
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 Senator Jacob K. Javits and 13 other Senate Republicans proposed today a modified childcare plan designed to meet President Nixon's objections to an earlier bill.

title: Warriors Down Pistons
description: OAKLAND, (AP)Cazzie Russell points in the third night as he helped Golden State Warriors 106 victory over Pistons. Russell 26 points. Calif. Feb. 24 scored 20 quarter torally the to a 116the Detroit finished with

title: Two Die After Blaze Engulfs BedfordStuyvesant Flat
description: A man was burned to death early yesterday morning and a woman died two hours later, apparently from injuries received when she jumped from the burning topfloor apartment in the BedfordStuyvesant section of Brooklyn.

title: Battery Park City
description: With the announcement that Harry Helmsley will be the builder of the three large office buildings of Battery Park City, the huge development to be constructed on landfill in the Hudson River moves closer to reality. Since these towers, the size of three Pan Am Buildings, are also the financial anchor for the rest of the planned community, including all of the housing, this is an important step forward. But carrying out this ambitious new town project for the western side of Lower Manhattan is far more complex than naming a developer.

title: Craft to Bear Message On Its Space Journey
description: Pioneer 10, the United States vehicle to he launched Sunday into a trajectory designed to carry it past Jupiter and into the cosmos, carries a message that states, in scientific symbols, who sent it and where they live.

title: Sculpture Reported Given to Mao
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 24President Nixon was reported today to have given Chairman Mao Tsetung, following their meetings in Peking last Monday, a 250pound porcelain sculpture entitled Bird of Peace, Mute Swans.

title: SENATE APPROVES COMPROMISE PLAN TO GOVERN BUSING
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 24,The Senate approved by a comfortable margin today, compromise legislation that seeks to put some restraints on the use of busing for school desegregation without turning back the integration effort that has been under way for 18 years.

title: Dollar Troubles Again
description: The Administration is pressing Congress to devalue the dollar formally by raising the price of gold from $35 to $38 an ounce in order to check speculation that a much larger devaluationor international monetary chaoslies ahead. While the Senate Banking Committee's favorable action yesterday indicated that Congress will indeed grant the Administration's request promptly, it must recognize that this step will not in itself sufficient to allay fears that the dollar is a weak currency.

title: COLUMBIA WIDENS ITS COED PROGRAM
description: A new relationship announced yesterday for Columbia College and its sister institution, Barnard College, will allow a student in one institution to take any course in the other beginning in September.

title: Candidates'
description: PAHOKEE, Fla., Feb. 24 Representative John M. Ashbrook of Ohio, campaigning in Florida's sugar cane fields for votes for President, told growers who are under siege by Cesar Chavez's United Farm Workers Union that they haven't seen anything yet.

title: China Names Tung Piwu As Acting Chief of State
description: TOKYO, Feb. 24 (AP)China has named 86yearold Tung Piwu acting chief of state, filling the vacancy created by the ouster of Liu Shaochi, a Peking broadcast disclosed today.

title: A VENOM INJECTION PRODUCES MINIFLY
description: California researchers have discovered that by injecting one component of bee venom into fly larvae they can produce flies onefourth normal weight.

title: USE OF NAME IN AD REPUDIATED BY HART
description: Senator Philip A. Hart, Democrat of Michigan, yesterday repudiated the use of his name in a fullpage advertisement in The New York Times attacking United States aid to Israel.

title: POLICEMEN PLANNING TO FORM OWN UNION
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 24John Cassese, former president of the New York Policemen's Benevolent Association, and George Hardy, president of the Service Employes International Union, an, A F.L.C.I.O. affiliate, announced today that a national police union would be formed as an autonomous division within the Service Employes Union.

title: 2 Plead Guilty in Scheme To Defraud Medicaid Here
description: Two of three defendants accused of participating in a scheme in which more than $2million was stolen from the city's Medicaid program interrupted their trial yesterday in State Supreme Court in the Bronx to plead guilty.

title: PRICES INCREASE ON AMEX AND OTC Exchange Stocks Edge Up Unlisted Issues Stronger
description: Prices on the American Stock Exchange and in the overthecounter market finished higher yesterday in steppedup trading.

title: SUSAN'S GIRL WINS SANTAANITA RACE Triumphs by 3 1/2 LengthsShoemaker Last in Bid for Stakes Record
description: ARCADIA, Calif., Feb. 24 (AP)  Favored Susan's Girl romped to a 3%length victory today in the $47,200 Santa Ynez. Stakes at Santa Anita as Bill Shoemaker finished last in his first attempt to set a career stakeswinning record for jockeys.

title: Snow Chases Berkshires'
description: PIrISFFIELD, Mass., Feb. 24Suddenly. winter has taken a turn for the better in the skithemed Berkshires. Now Paul Bousquet, head of the resort that bears his name, finds himself wondering if this season can develop into a profitable one despite early setbacks with

title: U.S. Toll Put at 2
description: SAIGON, Feb. 24 (UPI)The United States command said today that two Americans were killed in Indochina action last weekthe same number as in the previous weekwhile both South Vietnamese and enemycasualties decreased.

title: Canadiens Triumph, 42
description: BLOOMINGTON, Minn., Feb. 24 (AP)Claude Larose's thirdperiod goal into an open net turned off a Minnesota North Stars rally and clinched a 42 victory for the Montreal Canadiens tonight.

title: Death by Postal Rate
description: In an effort to make the United States mails a selfsustaining business, the Postal Service may succeed only in making a free press appreciably less free. The new agency has a legal mandate to support itself, but the rate increases it is seeking are excessive in terms of the general economy, disproportionate as between the respective mail services and dangerous to the very existence many of the country's leading magazines.

title: BusingFacts and Fiction
description: A newspaper in Richmond, Va., ignoring the facts and deliberately distorting the record, has charged The Times with hypocrisy in our editorial position on schooldesegregation busing. Central to the charge is the allegation that The Times applies a double standard to integration South and North.

title: Robert Kelly, Specialist In Labor, Maritime Law
description: PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 24Robert G. Kelly, a senior partner in the law firm of Kelly, Deasey & Scanlan, who specialized in labor and maritime law, died Sunday in Bryn Mawr Hospital. He was 61 years old and lived in Wynnewood.

title: Reporter's Notebook: But Wall Survives
description: PEKING, Friday, Feb. 25The greatness of the Great Wall of China, obviously, is that it can survive anything even an American political extravaganza.

title: Agree in Principle
description: Pfizer, Inc., and Howmedica, Inc., announced yesterday that directors of both companies had agreed in principle to the acquisition of Howmedica by Pfizer.

title: Film: 'Carol' and 'Image':2 Emshwiller Works Shown at Whitney
description: It is not too common these days for men to imagine women as tree goddesses. But at least one man, Ed Emshwiller, the independent East-Coast film-maker, makes rather a habit of it, and a magical relation between woman and tree is the controlling metaphor of a brief, lovely tribute to his wife, Carol, that opens the Emshwiller program that began yesterday at the Whitney Museum.It is a two-movie program, and "Carol" really serves as a kind of curtain raiser to "Image, Flesh and Voice," which is a feature in length (77 minutes), though I guess not in name, and certainly not in intention. It is an extremely ambitious project (though I suspect that even Emshwiller's smallest movies are ambitious projects), and it means not to tell a story, but rather to balance its elements of image and voice in a kind of contrapuntal exercise where one always meets the other but never exactly matches it."Flesh" I take to be the principal theme of the filmthe state of man, or the state of man-and-womanwhich is the central interest of the images and the constant concern of voices, a vocal montage constructed by Emshwiller and sounding like a cross between conversations overheard at a swinging singles party and group therapy. Sometimes the people who talk appear on the screen, but never while they are talking. The only performers are two dancers, Carolyn Carlson and Emery Hermans. Emshwiller has always filmed dancers with close feeling for presence and movement, and Hermans and Miss Carlson are among the movie's greater incidental pleasures.There is a good deal to like in "Image, Flesh and Voice," most of it, unfortunately, incidental. Emshwiller continues to prove himself a cinematographer of fine sensitivity and superb technique. At this stage of everybody else's development in experimental film, he begins to look like an outright classicist in his commitment to the human face and form, and in his fairly straight-forward recognition that we are drawn to one another by desire. As a matter of course, his movies have tended to include extraordinarily beautiful young girls, and "Image, Flesh and Voice" is no exception.But Emshwiller is not so interesting in his ideas, and "Image, Flesh and Voice" is full of ideasto the extent that almost all the images, even the young girls, serve as the visualization of ideasabout personality, human relations, time, etc. And in this function they become boring. Even the characteristic Emshwiller way of moving people across the screen descends from personal style to public expression, and I begin to miss the tree woman of "Carol" who also becomes a dancer and who expresses only herself, for in the obsessional space of a moving picture that is enough.

title: COMPROMISE AID BILL APPROVED BY HOUSE
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 (UPI) The House approved today by a 213to167 vote a compromise $3.2billion foreign aid appropriations bill. The measure was sent to the Senate.

title: LittlerLeads by 2 Shots With 65 in Florida Golf
description: FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., Feb. 24Gene Littler, who likes to assemble old automobiles and low scores, led the new $260,000 Jackie Gleason Inverrary Classic today with a 65.

title: Beirut Denies Charge
description: BEIRUT, Feb. 24A Lebanese military spokesman denied Israeli charges today that the killers of two Israeli civilians had come from Lebanon.

title: Suharto Vows to Crush Critics of Wife's AmusementPark Plan
description: JAKARTA, Indonesia, Feb. 21 A seemingly trivial issue, a proposed Disneylandstyle park promoted by the President's wife, has brought to public view the strong and sometimes harsh, grip of President Suharto's military regime.

title: Front Page 3  No Title
description: GINLEY'S THE NAME GUMSHOE'S THE GAMEADVT.

title: I.L.A. Talks Still Open As Date for Vote Nears
description: International Longshoremen's Association locals from South Atlantic and Gulf Coast ports went into another bargaining round with management representatives yesterday on two issuesthe guaranteed annual income and welfarefund financingthat may not be entirely resolved before the union votes on a new contract March 8. The I. L. A. has tentatively agreed on such basic master contract items as pay and hours. The only issues still on the table outside six North Atlantic ports, including New York, are such provisions as the income guarantee. They vary considerably from port to port.

title: NEW MUSICAL SERIES PLANNED BY RUTGERS
description: A new series of musical events entitled Black on Black will be presented at Carnegie Recital Hall beginning next month by the Carnegie Hall Corporation in cooperation with the Institute of Jazz Studies at Rutgers University. The artistic coordinator of the series is Chris White, a bass player and a teacher of jazz history at Rutgers's Newark campus.

title: TIMES EARNINGS DECLINED IN 1971 Data Restated to Reflect Business Acquisitions
description: The New York Times Company reported yesterday that Its consolidated net income in 1971 declined to $9,452,000, or 80 cents a share, from $13,722,000, or $1.16 a share, in 1970. Revenue rose to $290,922,000 from $282,537,000 a year earlier.

title: Border of Dances Is Explored By the Sokolow Players Project
description: Some questions may never he answered, such as What defines the border between conventional theater and dance?, but the asking of them is so beneficial that it scarcely matters. Anna Sokolow in her Players Project has for the last four years addressed herself inventively to illuminating the zone where established forms meet, and Wednesday at the Forum theater she presented three of her recent explorations.

title: Aparicio Has Visa Problems
description: WINTERHAVEN, Fla., Feb. 24 (UPI)  Luis Aparicio has been delayed in reporting to spring training with the Boston Red Sox because of problems in obtaining a visa to leave his home in Maracaibo, Venezuela.

title: Miss Evert Gains at Net; Mrs. King Is Eliminated
description: BETHESDA, Md., Feb, 24 (AP)little Chris Evert gained the quarter finals by beating Australia's Karen Krantzcke, 63, 62, tonight, but her expected rematch with Mrs. Billie Jean King fizzled when Mrs. King tumbled before Julie Heldman of Houston, 3.6, 64, 61.Mrs. King, topseeded in the Virginia Slims women's Invitation tennis tournament withdrew from the doubles, claiming she did not want to risk further possible injury to her left big toe. She also withdrew from next week's tournament in Memphis. I am physically and mentally exhausted and I can't play my best, Mrs. King said.

title: Poet Is Reported Freed From Hospital in Soviet
description: MOSCOW, Feb. 24Natalya E. Gorbanevskaya, a poet who took part in the small demI onstration against the Soviet invasion of Czechoslovakia in August, 1968, and was later declared insane, has been released from a mental hospital, friends reported today.

title: TV: Three Commercial Networks Are Presenting Worthwhile Programs Tonight
description: In a rare display of generosity, each of the commercial networks has scheduled something worthwhile for this evening.

title: Assaulted by Girls, Policeman Favors Mercy in the Case
description: A transit patrolman who narrowly escaped being thrown before an oncoming subway train by a group of teenaged schoolgirls said yesterday that lie hoped those he later had arrested would receive social rehabilitation treatment rather than be jailed.

title: AIRPORT SECURITY PROMPTS DEBATE Role for Waterfront Agency Argued at House Hearing
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 District Attorney Thomas J. Mackell of Queens urged a House judiciary subcommittee today to reject a New YorkNew Jersey compact that would give the Waterfront Commission of New York Harbor power to control cargo security at the metropolitanarea airports.

title: Killebrew Signs Twins Contract And Gets $125,000
description: ORLANDO, Fla., Feb. 24 (UPI)  Harmon Killebrew signed his 1972 contract with the Minnesota Twins at the team's training camp today. Killebrew signed for about. $125,000, which would be $10,000 over his 1971 contract.

title: Books of The Times
description: Poking around In the annals of some less than eminent Victorians, the English biographer and novelist Elizabeth Jenkins has come across a sensationmaking scandal of the late 1870'ssensationmaking even by newsworthy standards of today. The incidents as the author details them for us prove once again that though the age was Victorian, a large number of people were not. Those in good social position, of ample funds and with a choice of options bent the mores of their time to their own needs. Moreover, the two lovers in Miss Jenkins's story were so purely motivated and so innocent of mind that it never seems to have occurred to them that their behavior might mean disaster for thorn or thocp dearest to them. Love conquers all, as Chaucer caustically remarked almost six centuries ago.

title: Cracker jack: A Century Old and Still Popping
description: Chicago had just burned down when F. W. Rueckheim, a German immigrant, came to the Windy City from a nearby farm with his life savings of $200. He intended to make an honest buck cleaning up the debris from the 1871 holocaust, but instead opened a popcorn stand.

title: Wood, Field and Stream OldTimer Spins Tales of Fighting Fish When Foul Weather Strikes the Keys
description: KEY COLONY BEACH, Fla.For three consecutive days the shallow waters of the Bay of Florida were churned to a milky white by a strong, cold wind from the north or northwest, and on the ocean side of the Florida Keys waves were running as high as 10 feet.

title: Beverly Sills Keeps Devereux a Hit
description: It used to be called the spring season, and that would have caused a few wry smiles as people left the New York State Theater Wednesday night to engage the blizzard. Donizetti's Roberto Devereux was the opera within, and it started the 55th New York season of the New York City Opera a season that will extend through April 30.

title: 78% in Poll Favor Trip
description: Most Americans approve of President Nixon's visit to China, according to the Louis Harris Poll. In a nationwide survey of 1,480 households between Feb. 8 and 14, the poll reported Wednesday, 78 per cent though the visit was good idea. The poll noted that. 62 per cent of those questioned did not agree with the statement that the war in Vietnam will come to an end faster because of the trip.

title: Houston Wins 10th in Rowl
description: HOUSTON, Feb. 24 (UPI)Dwight Jones scored 27 points and Dwight Davis 24 to lead Houston to its 10th straight basketball victory, 10581, over Corpus Christi tonight. Houston outscored the Tarpins, 14I, during a 31/2minute span midway through the first half to pull from a 2322 deficit to 3624 lead. Corpus Christi never got closer than 10 point again.

title: Irvings Fail to Respond To State Court Subpoenas
description: Clifford Irving and his wife, Edith, failed to appear in State Supreme Court in Manhattan yesterday for questioning on pending lawsuits involving both Mr. Irving's hook Fake and his compilation of the purported autobiography of Howard R. Hughes.

title: ROYALS DEFEAT BRAVES, 10897 Archibald Scores 32 Points to Lead Cincinnati to 4th Victory in Row
description: DAYTON, Ohio, Feb. 24 (UPI) Nate Archibald, who scored 55 points against Portland last night, scored 32 more against Buffalo tonight as the Royals posted their fourth straight victory, 10897, over the Braves.

title: Tape Setup in Question
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 The various elements of the securities industry have reached a deadlock in their attempt to take the first step toward the ultimate goal of a unified stock marketthe creation of a consolidated tape that would show all trades in listed stocks, wherever they are made.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: The Times correctly characterizes the language of Rabbi William Berkowitz as intemperate and unfortunate. It goes on, to conclude [editorial Feb. 11], also correctly, that the talk of the preservation of ethnic entities in terms of real estate, either in Forest Hills or anywhere else is but exacerbating the racial aspects of the Forest Hills dispute.

title: N.B.C. Plans Series on U.S. History
description: An American history series its sponsors hope will revive faith and pride in our nation will be televised by the National Broadcasting Company on alternate Tuesdays, starting Nov. 14, at 10 P.M.

title: JOSEPH J. JUHASS
description: Joseph J. Juhass, a patent lawyer, died of a heart attack yesterday at his home, 120 Delafield Avenue, Randall Manor, S. 1. He was 70 years old.

title: Wings Down Canucks, 2.0
description: DETROIT, Feb. 24 (UPI) Red Berenson and Marcel Dionne supplied the goals while Al Smith guarded the goal tonight as the Detroit Red Wings defeated the Vancouver Canucks, 2O.

title: Senate Panel Unanimous In Supporting Kleindienst
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 (UPI)  The Senate Judiciary Committee today unanimously approved President Nixon's nomination of Richard G. Kleindienst to succeed John N. Mitchell as Attorney General. Senate confirmation appeared certain.

title: Advertising:
description: W. R. Simmons & Associates, which at the moment has no competition in the area of syndicated mediaproduct research, will soon be getting some from, of all sources, Walter Thompson, the world's largest ad agency.

title: Advertising:
description: We may not be able to tell you who's officially in the race for the $22million business of the American Motors Corporation, but we can at least tell you that one agency is officially out.

title: Gimbels East Officially in Business
description: Gimbels East, the first department store on Manhattan's Upper East Side, was opened officially yesterday. Within an hour ater the ribbon was cut, the storeat Lexington Avenue and 86th Street  was filled with shoppers and the simply curious.

title: Candidates'
description: MIAMI, Feb. 24.Representative Shirley Chisholm, Demo. crat of Brooklyn, visited Miami junior colleges today. She told hundreds of students that she favored legalization of marijuana.

title: Executive Changes
description: Charles A. Cronheim, formerly a senior vice president of R. H. Macy & Co., Inc,, has been elected chairman of the board of Peerage Properties, Inc., affiliated with Lazard Freres & Co. He continues as a consultant to Macy's.

title: DepartmentStores Sales Up
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 24The Commerce Department today estimated last week's departmentstore sales at $627,000,000, up 4 per cent from the yearearlier $605,000,000. Total retailstore sales last week were $7,214,000,000, up 4 per cent from $6,965,000,000.

title: Communists Walk Out of Paris Session
description: PARIS, Feb. 24The Communist delegations walked out of a session of the Vietnam peace talks today in protest against American bombing of North Vietnam. This is the first time that one side has walked Out on the other.

title: Committee Backs $3 Rise
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 24The Senate Banking Committee approved unanimously and without amendment today legislation making formal the devaluation of the dollar by an increase in the price of gold to $38 an ounce from $35.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Slushy Conditions Prevail As Snowfall Is Cleared

title: Scientist Brings Letters From P.O.W.'s in North
description: Dr. George Wald, a Haryard professor of biology and winner of the Nobel Prize in physiology and medicine in 1967, arrived here yesterday with 86 letters from prisoners of war in North Vietnam: He said that It was a cruel deception for Washington to foster the belief that there might be more alive but unlisted.

title: Larousse Is Giving Up 5th Ave. Store
description: The Larousse Book Store, which opened just over two years ago with optimistic plans for enlarging the market for French language books, is abandoning its prestigious streetfloor location at 572 Fifth Avenue.

title: EDWARD F. FLANIGAN
description: LONGWOOD, Fla., Feb. 24Edward F. Flanigan, a public accountant, who retired two years ago from Deering, Milliken, Inc., of New York, a manufacturing company, died yesterday. His age was 64.

title: Truck Tonnage Gains 6.5%
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 24The American Trucking Associations, Inc., reported intercity truck tonnage in the latest week was 6.5 per cent above the like 1971 week. Truck tonnage was 0.7 per cent above the immediately preceding week of this year. The rail carloadings report will be out tomorrow because of the George Washington Holiday this week.

title: Vietcong Assails Visit
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Feb. 24 (UPI)The National Liberation Front, or Vietcong, in its first comment on President Nixon's visit to China, accused him today of trying to capitalize on the internal disagreements of the socialist campa reference to the split between China and the Soviet Union.

title: NEARTERM RATES SHOW INCREASES A $3Billion Sale of Bills Is Planned by Government
description: Shortterm interest rates rose yesterday as the Federal Reserve again sold Treasury bills and the Government announced plans to sell $3billion of bills March 1.

title: The Menus at Peking Banquets Didn't Do Justice to the Foods
description: You couldn't tell much from the terse printed menus at the two banquets the Nixons have attended this week in Peking. So, at first, some people thought the Presidential party was getting short shriftsimple dishes and too few courses.

title: Nation's Chains Carried Sales Gain Into January
Miss Holum Entered Today in Sprint Speed Skating
description: ESKILSTUNA, Sweden, Feb. 25 (AP)  Dianne Holum of Northbrook, Ill., winner of two medals in the Winter Olympics, will carry United States hopes in the world sprint speed skating championships starting tomorrow.

title: 2 Attica Inmates T ell U. S. Panel Brutality and Harassing Persist
description: Two present inmates of Atica prison who were alloWed to testify before a Congressional committee here yesterday said that harassment and brutality against alleged participants in last fall's rebellion were still going on.

title: BIG BOARD BACKS S.E.C. ON BROKERS
description: The New York Stock Exchange informed the Securities and Exchange Commission yesterday that it agreed with the commission on the issue of institutional membership for financial institutions.

title: State Repossesses Center City Had Sought for a Jail
description: The State Department of Mental Hygiene has just repossessed an abandoned downtown state drug treatment center that the head of the City Board of Correction had been seeking, to relieve prison overcrowding.

title: Bendix Names Blumenthal As Its Chairman and Chief
description: The Bendix Corporation announced yesterday that its board had selected W. Michael Blumenthal as chairman, and chief executive officer, effective April 1.

title: General Abrams Says Addiction In Vietnam Is Down, Morale Up
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Feb. 23The morale of American troops in South Vietnam is in excellent shape and the incidence of addiction to hard drugs has declined approximately 50 per cent, according to Gen. Creighton W. Abrams, the United States commander.

title: Smoky Fire Empties Commodore Hotel
description: A fivealarm basement fire that churned up vast clouds of heavy smoke drove hundreds of guests and employes from the Commodore Hotel atop Grand Central Terminal late yesterday and created a massive traffic jam throughout the evening rush hours.

title: Bonn Paid Hijackers $5Million Ransom
description: BONN, Feb. 25The West German Government paid $5million for the release of a Lufthansa jumbo jet and crew hijacked by Arab guerrillas Monday and held at the Aden airport until Wednesday, Transport Minister Georg Leber disclosed today.

title: 2 Abreu Brothers Are AweInspiring In Guitar Program
description: The classicguitar duo of Sergio and Eduardo Abreu put on a display of synchronized teamwork at Alice Tully Hall on Thursday night that inspired awe. In five harpsichord sonatas of Scarlatti, tastefully transcribed for two guitars, the Brazilian brothers gave especially fastidious, clean and technically strong performances. Both are still in their early 20's, but they have little yet to learn about smooth arpeggios, even scales or the production of wellblended tones.

title: Behind a Great Decision
description: After months of studied neglect, Communist China's press this week suddenly gave broad, favorable coverage to President Nixon's visit, and overnight the idea of reconciliation with the United States became respectable throughout that vast country. The problem of marshalling public support for such a momentous policy shift in a democracy like the United States is not so simple. President Nixon's decision to seek a dialogue with Peking could not have been made if a substantial portion of American public opinion had not already been prepared to accept such a dramatic turnabout.

title: Water,Colors Stand Out In Winslow Homer Show
description: If you can shoulder your way through the galleries where the Metropolitan Museum of Art is exhibiting photographs of China and showing videotapes of the current excitement in that land, you will emerge in the quiet waters of the American painting galleries where a bit of further adventuring will take you to a new Winslow Homer exhibition. This is the third of aeries drawn from the museum's collection of American prints, drawings and watercolors, having been preceded by an introductory group of miscellaneous rarities and then a Sargent show.

title: Deposits at Thrift Units Up By $3.1 Billion in January
description: Deposits at savings and loan associations increased by a record $3.1billion during January, the Federal Home Loan Bank Board reported yesterday, 2 per cent higher than the yearearlier month.

title: At Least 9 Persons Killed In Brazilian Skyscraper Fire
description: SAO PAULO, Brazil, Feb. 25 (Reuters)  Firemen searched through the shell of a 26floor (skyscraper today for victims of a fire that struck the building yesterday.

title: State Abortion Law Upheld on Appeal
description: An Appellate Division decision in Brooklyn yesterday affirmed the constitutionality of the state's liberalized abortion law, overturning a State Supreme Court ruling that could have halted abortions in municipal hospitals here.

title: Market Place: View in London of U.S. Stocks
description: LONDON, Feb. 25StockMarket aficionados on this shore view the United States market a bit cautiously at this point. The feeling here is that the market needs a chance to rest after a long advance. It needs time to build a baseperhaps even retreat somewhat  before moving on to better things.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: 12TH MAN GUILTY IN MEDICAID CASE
description: The last one of a dozen persons indicted in 1970 for complicity in a scheme that resulted in the theft of $2million from the city's Medicaid program joined the 11 other defendants in the case yesterday in pleading guilty.

title: 3 KILLED AND 6 HURT IN BROOKLYN CRASH
description: Three teenage girls were killed and six teenagers were injured last night after two cars collided on Ocean Parkway at Avenue J in the Flatbush section of Brooklyn, the police reported.

title: RECORD COAL SET FOR ISRAEL BONDS
description: MIAMI BEACH, Fla. Feb. 25 American Jews were called on today to purchase a record total of $450million in Israel bonds to provide Israel with massive economic aid and to enable the Jewish state to absorb the 70,000 new immigrants expected this year, including the large influx from the Soviet Union.

title: Miss Dunn in Carmen
description: Mignon Dunn, mezzosoprano of the Metropolitan Opera, will replace Joy Davidson in the title role of Bizet's Carmen in performances to be given by thte New York City Opera at the New York State Theater tonight and Tuesday night. Miss Davidson is ill. Miss Dunn's most recent appearance as Carmen in the Metropolitan production was on Dec. 13.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 25Senator Edmund S. Muskie announced today his disapproval of the membership policies of the Gridiron Club, an allmale society of Washington journalists. He was the third Democratic Presidential candidate to do so.

title: GISBERT UPSETS GINO AT NET
description: Stan Smith, Ilie Nastase and Cliff Richey  the tapseeded three  won quarter final matches as expected yesterday in the Clean Air tennis tournament at the Seventh Regiment Armory. But they were joined in today's semifinal parings by Juan Gisbert of Spain, who achieved his second major upset of the tournament by downing Andres Gimeno, his countryman, 57, 61, 75.

title: 22 G.I.'s Wounded in Clash With Enemy Near Saigon
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Saturday, Feb. 26 (AP)  About 100 United States air cavalrymen, pursuing two enemy soldiers along a trail, ran into heavily fortified bunker line 42 miles east of Saigon yesterday, setting off a fivehour battle.

title: Chile Says She Will Pay $84.6Million to Kennecott
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, Feb. 25Chile's leftwing Government, faced with the blocking of bank accounts in the United States, announced today that it would pay $84,618,000 to the Braden Copper Company, a subsidiary of the Kennecott Corporation.

title: NEWAIIK JOB PACT TO AID MINORITIES
description: Six airlines and leaders of Newark's black community agreed yesterday to a job plan formembers of minority groups that they said should go far toward integrating the city's white construction unions and break a bitter racial impasse that has held up completion of a $400million redevelopment project at Newark Airport for 14 months.

title: Developer Gives Land To Conservation Unit
description: NAPLES, Fla., Feb. 25 Although real estate developers and conservationists are routinely in opposite camps 10 of 416 acres to be given tomorrow to the National Audubon Society, are a developer's gift.

title: Mrs. Nixon's Shopping Day: Pajamas, China
description: PEKING, Feb. 25 (AP)Mrs. Richard M. Nixon did some shopping for her family today, the final full day of her visit here, buying the President silk pajamas and choosing a set of china for her daughter, Mrs. David Eisenhower.

title: 10BILLION BUDGET WITH NEW TAXES PLANNED BY CITY
description: An expense budget of almost $10billion that assumes Albany's approval of $850million in new aid and city enactment of $133million in nuisance taxes will be made public next week, Deputy Mayor Edward K. Hamilton said yesterday.

title: Bill to Seek DayCare Centers To Aid Mental Patients in State
description: A bill proposing a new statewide program for the mentally retarded that would shift the emphasis from large institutions to smaller, daycare centers where the patients parents would exercise the majority control is to be introduced in the Assembly on Monday.

title: Art:
description: You are not likely to recognize many of your fellows or forebears in Americans in Paris, 16001900, an exhibition that opens to the public today at the New School Art Center, 65 Fifth Avenue. Although this show the giftie gi'es us to see ourselves as others have seen us, the vision is a bit foggy.

title: Dartmouth Beats Yale
description: HANOVER, N. H., Feb. 25Dartmouth outscored Yale, 134, over a sixminute stretch Midway through the second half and pulled away to a convincing 8473 victory in an Ivy League game tonight at Alumni Gymnasium.

title: Big Board Seat Is Sold
description: The New York Stock Exchange announced yesterday the sale of a seat for $240,000. Seats currently are at $200,000 bid $260,000 asked.

title: BOLDT IS OPTIMISTIC ON WAGE GUIDELINES
description: Judge George H. Boldt, chairman of the Pay Board, said yesterday that the weighted average of increases authorized by the board for 3.5 million workers was 4.3 per cent.

title: Caro's Steel Constructions on View
description: In 1960, the English artist Anthony Caro stopped sculpturing in an expressionist manner and started making steel constructions. It was these constructions that earned him an International reputation as one of the leading contemporary sculptors.

title: Test of 4Day Week Starts At Insurance Office Monday
description: BOSTON, Feb. 25 (AP)The fourday work week is coming Monday for 290 of the 7,000 home office employes of the John Hancock Mutual Life Insurance Company.

title: Shootout Suspect Seized
description: ORANGETOWN, N. Y, Feb. 25 (AP)A man warited in connection with a shootout with the police last Tuesday at a Queens motel was arrested early today at the Rockland State Hospital here, where his wife works.

title: Candidates'
description: MIAMI, Feb. 25Gov. George C. Wallace spoke scornfully of the United States Senate today by calling its passage of antibusing legislation yesterday a flimflam rusedesigned to get some of them on the record.After addressing the Kiwanis Club of Miami, the largest Kiwanis chapter in the world, with nearly 500 members, Mr. Wallace took the afternoon off to spend an hour or so in the warm, South Florida sun before attending a testimonial dinner for the Mayor of nearby Hialeah.

title: Judge Would Exempt Airline
description: A Federal judge here refused yesterday to lift attachments against nine Chilean enterprises, but urged lawyers to draw up an agreement that would permit normal operations by LANChile Airlines.

title: Berrigan Jury Told That Informer Tried to Incite. Antiwar Acts
description: HARRISBURG, Pa., Feb. 25 Two former Bucknell University coeds testified that Boyd F. Douglas Jr., the Government informer against the Rev. Philip F. Berrigan and six other defendants, not only betrayed the group but was also an agent provocateur and catalyst in the alleged antiwar conspiracy.

title: GREEK AIDE ASSAILS REPORT IN THE TIMES
description: ATHENS, Feb. 25The Greek Government tonight denounced a report in The New York Times that an Athens plan to oust Archbishop Makarios as President of Cyprus to speed a GreekTurkish settlement of the Cyprus dispute, had been foiled by a United States diplomatic intervention.

title: BALLET GALA AIDS SADLER'S WELLS
description: LONDON, Feb. 25Sadler's Wells Theater was saved early today from the threat of docure, thanks to a midnight gala given by the Royal Ballet. For the last two years, since its resident opera company moved to the larger and more central London Coliseum, the historic theater where the Royal Ballet grew up and first made its name, has remained in business as a home for visiting dance, drama and opera companies from all over the wqrld.

title: Rail TonMileage Up 2.6%
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 The Association of American Railroads reported today that freight traffic in the week ended Feb. 19 totaled an estimated 14.4 billion tonmiles, up 2.6 per cent from the level a year earlier. Carloadings for the same week totaled 474,198 cars, down 2.6 per cent.

title: SHEEHAN FACES SUIT ON ARNHEITER BOOK
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 25 (UPI)  Lieut. Comdr. Marcus Aurelius Arnheiter sued Neil Sheehan, the author of The Arnheiter Affair, for $5million today, charging that the book was unfair and inaccurate. The suit, filed in United States District Court, also named Random House, the book's publisher, and The New York Times, for which Mr. Sheehan is a reporter, as defendants. Commander Arnheiter, an Annapolis graduate who is now retired, was relieved as captain of the destroyer escort Vance on March 31, 1966, while the vessel was on patrol off Vietnam. The Navy said the action, was taken because of the commander's bad judgment and lack of integrity.

title: Newsmen Win Raises
description: ST. LOUIS, Feb. 25 (AP)A contract calling for wage increases and fringe benefits totaling from 25.5 to 42 per cent. over a threeyear period has been approved by members of the PostDispatch unit of The Newspaper Guild. The contract is subject to Pay Board approv al. The agreement calls for a maximum increase of $104 a week, bringing weekly pay in the top bracket in the third year to $360.

title: FRANK SEIDMAN, 81, ACCOUNTANT, DEAD
description: GRAND RAPIDS, Mich., Feb. 25  Frank E. Seidman, who was an executive of the Seidman & Seidman accounting firm In New York, died Wednesday at his home here after a long illness. He was 81 years old.

title: Two Dishes Served in the Great Hall
description: For those interested in approximating two of the recipes served by the Nixons at their banquet, here are directions for a crisp sweet and sour fish from Mrs. Ma's Favorite Chinese Recipes (Kodansha International, Palo Alto, Calif., $5.95) and a walnut cream, or soup, from PeiMei's Chinese Cookbook (Miss PeiMei Fu, Box 53057, Taipei, Taiwan, $2.50).

title: Mayor Opens His HomeState Campaign
description: Months after other Democratic Presidential candidates began organizing here, Mayor Lindsay opened his home state campaign yesterday by seeking the support of about 500 DemoIcratic party and public officials, many of them already committed to other candidates.

title: Chinese Delegates at U.N. Warily Venture Outside
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Feb. 25At a party in a Riverside Drive duplex, an American businessman jokingly offered $100 for a visa to China. At his side stood Chiang Haitao, a newsman sent from Peking with the Chinese delegation, who smiled broadly as the party guests broke into laughter. A few days earlier a young American teacher from Public School 84 on West 92d Street called at the Roosevelt Hotel, where the Chinese are living, and was welcomed cordially, served tea and offered cigarettes.

title: A.I.D. Plans to Ship $21Millionl In Food Grains to Bangladesh
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 25The Agency for International Development is preparing to ship $21million worth of food grains to Bangladesh in the next two to three weeks, official said today.

title: Idaho Votes Predator Bill
description: BOISE, Idaho, Feb. 25 (AP) The Idaho Senate passed a bill today that would authorize the state's Department of Agriculture to issue permits for shooting predatory animals from a plane. The measure, passed by the House, goes to the Governor.

title: SENATE UNIT BARS SUBMARINE FUNDS
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 25The Senate Armed Services Committee rejected today the Nixon Administration's request for additional funds now to accelerate development of a new class of missilelaunching submarines.

title: Brandt's Pacts With Reds Take a Bundestag Hurdle
description: BONN, Feb. 25Chancellor) Willy Brandt's nonaggression treaties with Moscow and Warsaw took the first parliamentary hurdle here today as the opposition parties withdrew their demand for an initial test vote.

title: PLAN GIVEN TO AID CATHOLIC PUPILS
description: The National Association of Laity, an organization of liberal _Roman Catholic laymen, charged yesterday that the religious education of Catholic children attending public schools was neglected and nonprofessional.

title: Coast Patrolman Cleared
description: MERCED, Calif., Feb. 25 (UPI)A grand jury today exonerated a border patrolman who shot and killed a farm worker in an incident that led to a protest from Cesar Chavez, the farm leader. The Merced County District Attorney, Patrick HaIlford, said that all but two witnesses who testified before the Grand Jury had said that the patrolman, Edward Nelson, 23 years old. fired in selfdefense when he shot Romulo Avalos, 21.

title: Zumwalt in Vietnam
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Feb. 25 (UPI) The United States Chief of Naval Operations, Adm. Elmo R. Zumwalt Jr., arrived here today for a threeday routine visit, Navy spokesmen said.

title: MRS. MOINA KALLIR, LANGUAGE TEACHER
description: Mrs. Moina Margaret Rademacher Kallir, a language teacher and former chairman of the Academic Department of the Mannes College of Music, died yesterday at her home, 1060 Park Avenue.

title: Pentagon Developing Antimissile Missile to Counter China's Expected Weapon System of Late 1970's
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 25The Defense Department is developing alongrange, maneuvering antimissile missile to defend the entire country against the intercontinental missiles that China is expected to possess in modest numbers in the late nineteenseventies.

title: GROWING DEFICIT OF GAS FORECAST
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 25The shortage of natural gas production that developed in the United States last year will continue and get worse, the Federal Power Commission said in a staff report today.

title: U.S. Industrial Capacity Stable at 74.5% in January
description: Operating capacity of United States industry in January stood at 74.5 per cent, unchanged from the December figure, McGrawHill's economics department said yesterday.

title: Man in the News
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 25Senator Robert Paul Griffin is not a novice in the political game of clash with the leader.

title: Queens Man Is Convicted Here Of 70 Shooting of 2 Policemen
description: A Queens man was convicted yesterday of attempted murder and assault in a 1970 attack on two policemen.

title: InConservative San Diego, Nixon's Trip Is Traumatic
description: SAN DIEGO, Feb. 25A retired vice admiral who spent two years on the Yangtze in the nineteenthirties walked into the bar of the Admiral Kidd Club here the other evening. On the television screen President Nixon was exchanging toasts with Premier Chou Enlai in Peking.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Candidates Day
description: HANOVER, N. H., Feb. 25 (AP)Senator Vance Hartke of Indiana attacked two of his Democratic rivals for the Presidential nomination in the New Hampshire Primary today, contending they could not beat President Nixon

title: Chang Kuohua Is Dead at 58; Led Chinese Takeover of Tibet
description: HONG KONG, Feb. 25 Chang Kuohua, one of China's most powerful regional leaders, died from a heart attack in Chengtu, capital of Szechwan Province, on Monday. He was 58 years old.

title: Tufts Plan Challenges Tradition
description: MEDFORD, Mass., Feb. 25 Prof. Seymour O. Simches is a romance philosopher by training and 26 years of practice, but his students these days are much more likely to seek out his advice on such matters as the ideology of racism, Lithuanian culture, rock music and the restoration of old furniture.

title: AETNA LIFE LIFTS PROFIT FOR YEAR
description: Net income of the nation's largest multipleline insurer, the Aetna Life and Casualty Company, rose substantially for the year but turned downward for the fourth quarter, the company disclosed yesterday.

title: China Bars a Tour By 300 Americans Aboard the France
description: The French Line said here yesterday that the Peking Government had turned down a proposed trip into China by Americans now on a world cruise aboard the liner France.

title: Sports of The Times
description: His height made him. At a slender 6 feet 8 inches, Connie Hawkins now is one of the National Basketball Association's allstar forwards. But in retrospect, his height almost destroyed him. His height deprived him presumably his five most productive seasons because had influenced his exile by the N.B.A. as an alleged intermediary in the 1961 college basketball scandal. When he was 10 years old, he was 510 and 115 pounds. He was taunted as Long Tall Sally by other boys. In the schoolrooms of P.S. 3 in the BedfordStuyvesant slums of Brooklyn, even the teachers mocked him. To avoid the humiliation of his height, he withdrew into the shell of a constant truant. And later, when he needed the awareness that an education might have provided, he didn't have it. Jack Molinas seemed like a nice person, Hawkins reflected. One time he told me he knew how hard it was for poor kids their first year at college. He said if I needed help or money, just let him know. He said he liked me.

title: Cosmos No. 475
description: MOSCOW, Feb. 25 (Agence FrancePresse)  The Soviet Union today launched its 475th satellite of the Cosmos series (carrying scientific instruments, Tass, the Government press agency, said.

title: Cypriot Setback
description: Heavyhanded Greek diplomacy appears to have wrecked a potentially promising attempt to settle the longsmoldering dispute between rival Greek and Turkish communities on Cyprus. Once again the stage has been set for a possible major Mediterranean crisis.

title: STOCKS ON AMEX MAKE GOOD GAINS
GALELLA CHANGES SOME TESTIMONY
description: Ronald E. Galella, a freelance photographer, changed his testimony several times during the span of an hour yesterday afternoon in his $1.3million lawsuit against Mrs. Aristotle Onassis.

title: GATT Will Explore FarmTrade Pacts
description: GENEVA, Feb. 25  The world's major trading nations today made their first move to follow up the recent calls by the United States, the European Economic Community and Japan for a combined assault on harriers to international trade in 1973.

title: NATIONAL CITY CUTS PRIME RATE TO.4%
description: The First National City Bank, the largest bank in New York, announced yesterday that its minimum interest rate on business loans for the week beginning Monday would be 4 per cent, down from 4 per cent previously.

title: Students Block a Speech
description: IOWA CITY, Iowa, Feb. 25 (UPI)More than 200 University of Iowa students, shouting and waving placards, blocked a speech today by a Harvard psychology professor, Richard Herrnstein. The students were mainly members of Students for a Democratic Society and the Workers and Students Alliance. The organizations charged that the. professor. attempted. to scientifically justify racism through an article published last fall that linked learning abilities with genetics.

title: I.R.A. Members Seized
description: DUBLIN, Feb. 25 (Reuters)Irish police rounded up a number of republican militants today, including Sean Kenny, a prominent fundraiser for the republican cause in the United States and Canada.

title: JUDGE BARS SHIFT OF A PATIENT HERE
description: State Supreme Court Justice Arnold L. Fein yesterday struck down as unconstitutional a provision of the state mental hygiene law under which he would have had to order the transfer of a dangerously mentally ill patient from a state civil hospital to Matteawan State Hospital for the. Criminally Insane.

title: CLARANCE STANLEY, EXG.M. EXECUTIVE
description: GREENWICH, Conn., Feb. 25 Clarance Stanley, a retired vice president of the General Motors Corporation who had once been an investment banker, died Wednesday at his home on Mead's Point, Greenwich. He was 75 years old.

title: Cut Called Acceptable
description: AUGSBURG, West Germany, Feb. 25 (Reuters) Yesterday's reduction in the German bank rate to 3 per cent from 4 per cent was acceptable in terms of internal economic policy, the Bundesbank's vice president, Otmar Emlninger, sdia today.

title: Stein Says Smaller Rise Is Expected for Food in Last 3 Quarters
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 Wholesale, prices rose substantially in January, the second month of the expected bulge in prices after the freeze, the Labor Department reported today.

title: Man Saved After Injury In 60ft. Hole
description: A construction worker at the bottom of a 60foot hole for a new sewer on 72d Street near the West Side Highway was struck on the head yesterday when several pieces of lumber fell from the top.

title: He Walks to the Voters
description: COLUMBUS, Ohio, Feb. 45 (UPI)  State Representative Howard A. Knight opened his campaign for a State Senate seat today by starting a 200mile hike through the district he seeks to represent. Mr. Knight, a Republican, said the hike would permit him to talk to the greatest number of voters before the May 2 primary. He will walk from Van Wert to Sandusky.

title: Nixon Gift to Mao First Designed as Peace Symbol
description: TRENTON, Feb. 25 (UPI)President Nixon's gift to Chairman Mao, a porcelain swan group, was designed as a new peace symbol for display in the White House, it was disclosed today.

title: Hungarian Bishops Named by Vatican; Better Ties Implied
description: ROME, Feb, 25The Vatican announced the appointment of new Bishops in Hungary today in a move implying improved relations with the Communist Government in Budapest.

title: AIR SAFETY RULES TIGHTENED BY F.A.A.
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 (AP) The Federal Aviation Administration ordered tougher safety standards today for airline passenger planes.

title: The Talk of Kuala Lumpur
description: KUALA LUMPUR, Malaysia, Feb. 25The Queen taps a rubber tree. The Queen visits the Beach of Passionate Love. The Queen, according to the local papers, gets welcomes no less than rousing and often thunderous, with smiles and cheers all the way.

title: Policeman Called In Murders Cancels News Conference
description: William it Phillips, the Knapp Commission witness who now reportedly feels he is being framed in a threeyearold murder case, canceled the news conference yesterday at which he was to have given his thoughts on the alleged frameup.

title: India Denies Allegations By Pakistanis on Talks
description: NEW DELHI, Feb. 25  India today denied Pakistani allegations that she had set preconditions for peace talks and suggested that Pakistan was muddling the situation to try to gain concessions in advance of negotiations.

title: Arthur Mallet, Author, Is Dead; A Founder of Consumers Union
description: NEW ROCHELLE, N. Y., Feb. 25Arthur Kallet, a founder of Consumers Union, which publishes the influential monthly Consumers Reports, died of viral pneumonia yesterday in New Rochelle Hospital. He was 69 years old and lived at 224 Broadview Avenue.

title: Nutritional Labeling Urged
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 (AP) Legislation to establish national standards for the nutritional labeling of all food commodities has been introduced by Representative Stewart B. McKinney, Republican of Connecticut. The average American's nutritional intake is woefully inadequate, and, surprisingly, this pattern goes steadily downhill each year, Mr. McKinney told the House yesterday.

title: Lindsay Denounces Senate For Antibusing Amendment
description: Mayor Lindsay attacked yesterday the United States Senate's adoption of an antibusing amendment, calling it a stunning blow to progress in this nationa slap in the face of millions of Americans and a stain on the United States Constitution.

title: An ExJudge, Acting as Referee, Tours Building With Rent Strike
description: A retired Civil Court judge, acting as a referee in a dispute between the owner of a highrent Gramercy Park apartment house and some of its tenants who are in the fourth month of a rent strike, made an inspection of the premises yesterday.

title: Candidates Day
description: GAINESVILLE, Fla., Feb. 25 Representative Shirley Chisholm carried her catalyst for change campaign to sundrenched Florida campuses today.

title: PEAK TV OUTLAY MADE BY 2 RIVALS
Soviet Says China Is Spending Record Amounts for Weapons
description: MOSCOW, Feb. 25The Soviet Defense Ministry charged today that Chinese military spending had reached an alltime high, amounting to about a third of Peking's overall budget, and said that Western nations supply the Chinese with strategic materials even for the production of nuclear weapons.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Letter From Comrade X
description: Dear Friend,

title: HERMAN C. KRANNERT, AN INDUSTRIALIST, 84
description: CLEARWATER, Fla., Feb, 25 Herman C. Krannert, the industrialist and philanthropist, died here yesterday of injuries he received Jan. 23 when he fell in his hotel room. He was 84 years old.

title: New Jersey's Environment
description: The State of New Jersey continues to set a vigorous pace for protection of the environment. Hearings have now been completed on a set of forwardlooking regulations for protecting the wetlands; an attempt is under way to bar heavy industry from much of the state's coastline; and Governor Cahill's administration is asking the legislature for power to limit or stop further building in areas periodically subject to flooding.

title: BIG TEN UPHOLDS BAN ON PLAYERS
description: MINNEAPOLIS, Feb. 25The Big Ten's athletic directors, following a courtordered hearing, unanimously upheld today suspensions of two University of Minnesota basketball players.The decision was announced less than an hour before the 6 P.M. deadline set by Federal District Court Judge Earl Larson. The athletes, Corky Taylor and Ron Behagen, had asked Judge Larson to nullify the suspensions. They contended that they had not been granted a full hearing when, on Feb. 11, the Big Ten commissioner, Wayne Duke, suspended them for the remainder of the season.

title: Candidates Day
description: CLEARWATER, Fla., Feb. 25 Senator Edmund S. Muskie of Maine joined a group of citizens here today in a protest against the planned development of a luxury condominium apartment complex on Sand Key.

title: Candidates'
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 25Senator Hubert H. Humphrey, in a Founders Week speech at Florida Southern College in Lakeland this morning, proposed a new service corps to be called Americans for Domestic Development.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: OSHKOSH, Wis., Feb. 24A volunteer group of 98. Washingtonians, bearing gifts of bright red apples and voicing words of political persuasion, swept into Wisconsin this week to campaign for Senator Henry M. Jackson.

title: Two in New Mexico Race
description: SANTA FE, N.M., Feb. 25, (UPI)Two leading Democratic Presidential contenders, Senators Edmund S. Muskie of Maine and George McGovern of South Dakota, filed today for New Mexico's Presidential primary. Secretary of State Betty Fiofina said both candidates had sent the $500 filing fee with. their declarations of candidacy.

title: Candidates Day
description: PROVIDENCE, R. I., Feb. 25 (AP)Dr. Benjamin Spock has filed suit in Federal District Court seeking to force officials of Quonset Point Naval Air Station to permit him and another minority party Presidential candidate to campaign on the base.

title: Princeton, Checking Late Surge, Subdues Columbia Five, 75 to 72
description: PRINCETON, N. J., Feb. 25Princeton, which was expected to run away from Columbia tonight, just barely managed to beat the scrappy Lions, 7572, and stay a game behind Pennsylvania, the Ivy League basketball leader, with three games remaining.

title: White House Aide Bids Newspapers Reject Deceptive Advertising
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 25President Nixon's consumer adviser accused newspapers today of failing to live up to their moral responsibility of rejecting deCeptive advertisements.

title: Vote Projections Attacked
description: JUNEAU, Alaska, Feb. 25 (AP)  The Alaska House adopted today a resolution urging Congress to prohibit the news media from reporting results of Presidential elections until the polls had closed in the continental United States, Hawaii and Alaska. The resolution, which now goes to the Senate, would ask Congress to stop socalled vote projections predicting a successful national candidate.

title: Misses Evert and Casals Reach Tennis Semifinals
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 (UPI) Chris Evert advanced to the semifinals of the Washington tennis tournament tonight with a 62, 64 victory over Wendy Overton of Chevy Chase, Md.

title: PENN OVERPOWERS CORNELL, 111 TO 82
description: PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 25 (AP) Penn shot 65.6 per cent from the field tonight in a 11182 rout of Cornell in an Ivy League game at the Palestra.

title: Spotlight Shines Easily On an Unruf fledChones
description: UNIONDALE, L.I., Feb. 25 If Jim Chones can make as good an impression on the basketball floor as he made today in a room full of news media representatives, the 22yearold Marquette junior will handsomely repay the $1.5million investment the New York Nets have made in him.

title: British Miners Accept Accord
description: LONDON, Feb. 25One of Britain's gravest industrial crises in years neared a close today with the miners voting overwhelmingly to return to work.

title: Ronny Whyte Offers New Yorkish Music With Songs at Cafe
description: The streetlevel cafebar of the SherryNetherland Hotel, which offers an exquisitely New Yorkish viewFifth Avenue with Central Park beyond and the plaza off to one sideis now complementing that view with a decidedly New Yorkish form of entertainment: the songs of Ronny Whyte, a singer and pianist who follows in the tradition of Hugh Shannon and Bobby Short.

title: Price Changes
description: While higher copper prices initiated Thursday spread to other producers yesterday, two producers of lead also moved to raise prices.

title: Grasshoppers: New Source for Protein?
description: Three Washington food experts sat down together here yesterday to ponder the American diet. Why not eat insects? one of them suggested seriously, adding that a portion of grasshoppers would be a good source of protein beside an order of French fries.

title: 44 Prisoners Exchanged
description: NEW DELHI, Feb. 25 (UPI)India and Pakistan exchanged 44 prisoners tonight17 seriously wounded and ill Indian soldiers for 27 disabled Pakistanis.

title: ABRAHAM NEUWIRTH, HEALTH SPECIALIST
description: Dr. Abraham Alexander Neuwirth, formerly of New York, a specialist in public health, died Wednesday in Tampa, Fla., at the age of 65.

title: Notes on People
description: State your full name, said the clerk of the Federal District Court in Manhattan of the witness.

title: A Reporter's Notebook: Thousands Bend Backs
description: PEKING, Feb. 25The wondrous silence of China's capital was shattered at dawn today by the rhythmic chomp and chop of a thousand hoes and shovels attacking perhaps a halfinch of snow in the broad Changan Boulevard outside the Hotel of Nationalities. If you listened hard, you could also hear the swoosh and slosh of a thousand straw brooms in the muck. If you looked out, it seemed as if every ablebodied citizen in the neighborhood had come to clear a path for the foreigners.

title: Books of The Times

title: Metropolitan Briefs

title: Nixon Invitations in Style Used in Taiwan

title: NEW WORLD GROUP PLANNING CONCERT

Though the dispute is not yet resolved, the concert is scheduled to be given, conducted by Dewis de Coteau with Andrew Frierson, bass baritone, as soloist.

description: SAN SALVADOR, Feb. 25 (Reuters)El Salvador's Electoral Council today declared victory for Arturo Molina, the presidential candidate of the ruling party, by a slim 11,844vote margin. His Christian Democrat opponent, Jose Napole6n Duarte, who was second called the result a fraud.

title: For Mary Ure and Robert Shaw, Marriage May Not Be Bliss but It'll Do
description: There are moments, he admits, when Robert Shaw wishes he were not married, did not have eight children to support (half by his previous wife, half by Mary Ure), did not have to accept those ghastly movie roles that keep him from his writing or good stage parts, did not have all those commitments and responsibilities.

title: Reserve Assets Increase

title: Israeli Troops and Planes Raid Lebanon in Reprisal

title: Behind the Czech Wall
description: PARISMembers of my generation may well remember those feelings of impotence we shared thirty years ago as the Vichy Government arrested our friends, or stood by as they were arrested; made it possible for professors and senior officials to be deprived of their positions, or itself stripped them of their offices; watched intellectuals who argued too much reduced to misery, or itself thrust them down; conducted roundups, or permitted them, of thousands of innocent people who, with the Vichy authorities tactfully averting their eyes, were shipped off to infamous destinations.

title: Dollar Gains in Germany;
description: FRANKFURT, West Germany, Feb. 25  The dollar made a good advance today against the West German mark in a technical reaction to yesterday's defensive measures by the Bundesbank to preserve the Dec. 18 currency realignment.

title: Senate RollCall Vote On Basing and Courts
Dance: Eclectic Joffrey
description: The City Center Joffrey Ballet is joyously eclectic. On Thursday night It presented Balanchine's Square Dance, Alvin Ailey's Feast of Ashes and Ruthanna Boris's Cakewalk. It was a program of contrasts and pleasures.

title: Head of Election Bureau In Philadelphia Indicted

title: Merger News

Edgar F. Kaiser, chairman of Kaiser Industries, said the sale was in line with the company's previously announced policy of disposing of its Interests in the automobile busi ness. He added that the sale would provide Kaiser Industries with added liquidity and the opportunity to reemploy the proceeds in other activities. The Kaiser Industries holding in A.M.C. amounted to a 22 per cent interest in the company.

description: To the Editor:

description: SYLMAR, Calif., Feb. 25 (UPI) A sharp earthquake jolted the San Fernando Valley today, causing hundreds of people to call police stations, but there were no reports of injury or damage. The seismological laboratory at California Institute of Technology said the tremor was centered in the Sylmar area.

title: Pessimism of Physicians on Sclerosis Is Deplored
description: LA JOLLA, Calif., Feb. 25Too many doctors and patients have too bleak a picture of the course of multiple sclerosis, according to the British Medical Journal.

title: Birbach Announces Plans To Run for State Senate
description: Jerry Birbach, who as president of the Forest Hills Residents Association has led the fight against the lowincome housing project being built in the Forest Hills section of Queens, announced yesterday that he would seek election as a State Senator.

title: Hangchow a Resort With Best Tea in China
description: No matter what has happened politically in Peking, President Nixon is bound to enjoy the scenic sights of the resort city of Hangchow and the finest tea in China.

title: Envoys (Taipei's Too) Asked to Greet Nixon
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 25The State Department today invited the chiefs of all the diplomatic missions hereincluding the Ambassador of Nationalist Chinato attend the airport reception for President Nixon on his return from Communist China Monday night.

title: NIXON AND CHOU ARE SAID TO REACH BASIC AGREEMENT
description: HANGCHOW, Saturday, Feb. 26The traveling White House announced today that President Nixon and Premier Chou Enlai had reached an accord on the basic agreements that they would enunciate in a communique to be written and published during the President's visit to Shanghai tomorrow.

title: SENATE, 43 TO 40, ACTS TO RESTRAIN COURTS ON BUSING
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 25In a sudden reversal, the Senate voted 43 to 40 today for legislation that would prohibit all Federal courts from ordering busing of children on the basis of their race, color, religion or national origin.

title: Crime in Parks Called Overstressed
description: Crime in the country's parks has been greatly overstressed, August Heckscher. the City's Parks Administrator, said yesterday in summing up what he described as an unprecedented meeting of top park and recreation officials from the largest cities.

title: 71 Profits at Peak For Diamond Corp.
Antiques: 1929 Bedroom
description: Jean Cocteau's 1929 bedroom set now on exhibition at the Sonnabend Gallery, 924 Madison Avenue, is a shocker that Art Deco collectors should not miss.

title: LongTime Amex Aide Retires
description: Isidore Bernard Kamp, the man who rings the bell every morning to start trading at the American Stock Exchange, finished his last full week of work yesterday after 46 years on the job.

title: PENN STATE WIDENS LEAD IN WRESTLING
description: PHILADELPHIA, Pa., Feb. 25 The defending champion, Penn State, increased its lead in the point standings as the Eastern Intercollegiate Wrestling Association championships reached the halfway point at Temple University. The Nittany Lions, who had two wrestlers defeated in the quarterfinals Friday night, lead with 30 points, five better than the runnerup Navy.

title: Notes On Metropolitan Congressmen
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 25Contrary to the general impression that only Democrats are unhappy with the Congressional reapportionment plan being drawn up by the Republicancontrolled Legislature in Albany, complaints are now coming from some Republican House members. A prime example is Representative Howard W. Robison of Owego, the senior Republican in the House from New York, who has nearly 15 years of service and a key seat on the House Appropriations Committee.

title: MIDDLEBURY GAINS LEAD IN CARNIVAL
description: MIDDLEBURY, Vt., Feb. 25Strengthened by the return of Joe McNulty, who had been competing with the United States Olympic team in Sapporo, Japan, Middlebury College staged a surprising sweep of the first three places in crosscountry today to take the team lead at its annual winter carnival.

title: Ambrose H. Casner Dead; A Leading Bridge Player
description: Ambrose H. Casner, one of New York's leading bridge players, and a manufacturer of greeting cards, died Wednesday night at his home, 100 West 57th Street. He was 68 years old, and had suffered a stroke three years earlier.

title: The Films of David Rimmer
description: David Rimmer is a 30-year-old Canadian filmmaker whose work is not likely to be known to most New York moviegoers. A selection of his short films, made between 1968 and 1971, opened last night at the Film Forum in a program that should interest anyone who cares for what movies look like and who wonders where they may be going. Rimmer has adapted several of the styles popular during the last few years, and he has done so with charm as well as skill.The earliest and the latest of these films are the least impressive  the earliest ("Square Inch Field" and "Migration") mainly repeating the expanded-mind imagery adventures that by now seem generic to the independent cinema; the latest ("West Coast Workprint"), a diary film about communal living in the Pacific Northwest, being a work in progress on which more progress has to be made.It is what I guess should be called middle-period Rimmer (1970 through early 1971) that I like the best. "Surfacing on the Thames," loop films such as "The Dance" and "Seashore" and the storefront study "Real Italian Pizza"all play wittily and rather elegantly with the idea of film itself, and all investigate the moving image with a kind of concentration most appropriate to a short film.Both "Seashore" and "The Dance" are loops made of old-movie footage, and they become ghostly evocations of lost energy, broken records of a life long past, as a pair of whirling ballroom dancers repeat the same steps beyond the limits of endurance, or as happy bathers timidly disappear again and again into the same line of surf."Surfacing on the Thames," on the other hand, sees the great river as almost motionless, caught in a misty, monochromatic print like a Whistler paintingwhile on the surface of the film, little changes take place. Wrinkles appear, or a small smudge in one cornerand you find yourself moving between the sublime and the ridiculous without budging an inch.In "Real Italian Pizza" Rimmer covers six months of sidewalk life in front of a New York City pizza parlor in 11 minutes, not by speeding things up but by slowing them down in a kind of stop-action selectivity. School-children pass by, a football team passes by, panhandlers beg, some youngsters are picked up by the police, it snows, snow meltsand a cheerful, slightly crazy jauntiness prevails that may be as close as film form can come to really capturing a mood of the city.

title: Turnabout: A Book by Hughes Company on Irving
description: LAS VEGAS, Nev. Feb. 25 (AP)The Hughes Tool Company plans to publish its own version of how the Clifford Irving autobiography of Howard R. Hughes came about, sources here said today.

title: Wisconsin Bombing Suspect Faces Three New Charges
description: TORONTO, Feb. 25 (AP)The authorities have brought three more arson charges against Karleton Armstrong, a United States student wanted for murder in the bombing of an Army research center at the University of Wisconsin.

title: Zebu Plods to Victory Over 4 Other Animals
description: BOWIE, Md., Feb. 25 (AP) One Large Hump, a zebu, easily defeated a field including a buffalo, llama and camel to capture today's $250 Noah's Ark International sweepstakes at Bowie Race Course.

title: Harvard Wins at Buzzer
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Feb. 25 James Brown, back in the starting lineup for the first time in five games, came up with a loose ball and tossed in a 20foot jump shot at the final buzzer to give Harvard an 8078 Ivy League victory over Brown tonight.

title: The American Way Of LifeWith Drugs
description: This discussion of America's drug culture by two Yale professors, Dr. David Musto, assistant professor of history and psychiatry, and Alan Trachtenberg, associate professor of English and American Studies, is excerpted from the Yale Alumni Magazine.

title: Israeli Fears on Jarring Said to Be Allayed by Visit
description: JERUSALEM, Feb. 25  The United Nations special representative for the Middle East, Dr. Gunnar V. Jarring, allayed Israel's most severe anxieties today about continuing his peace mission, according to senior Government officials.

description: MIAMI, Feb. 25  The growing controversy over school busing is enabling George Corley Wallace to broaden his voter appeal without appearing to be an avowed segregationist.

description: Shortcovering was mainly responsible for the gain of 1 cents to 3 cents a bushel In soybean futures yesterday on the Chicago.Board of Trade.
