description: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., Feb. 25The St. Louis Cardinals and Philadelphia Phillies solved two of their most vexing holdout problems today by trading the two pitchers involvedSteve Carlton to the Phillies and Rick Wise to the Cardinals.

title: The Semantics Of War
description: BOSTONLast summer, Mr. Kissinger flew to Peking to explore the possibilities arising from the SovietChina rift; a few weeks ago, Mr. Gromyko flew to Tokyo to exploit the coldness between the U. S. and Japan. The choice of verbs is not mine, but as found in various reports in this newspaper. There's just that nice distinction of sinister purpose, of the now somewhat dated fishing in troubled waters that used to be the standard description of any Red diplomatic voyage.

title: Testimony on Utility Rate Rise Canceled Suddenly by Pentagon
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 25The Department of Defense suddenly canceled today scheduled testimony on utility rates and has also withdrawn its offer to provide auditors to help the Federal Communications Commission to investigate the rate structure of the. American Telephone and Telegraph Company.

title: MANITOBA BOARD SUSPENDS CHUVALO
description: WINNIPEG, Manitoba, Feb. 25, (UPI)The Manitoba Boxing and Wrestling Commission announced a number of suspensions today as a result of the fourfight card held here Monday night. One boxer died the following day and another admitted that he took a dive under threat of death.

title: U.S. DENIES REBUFF BY JAPAN ON HANOI
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 (AP) The State Department acknowledged today that discussions were held with Tokyo on the timing of a Japanese Foreign Ministry mission to Hanoi earlier this month.

title: PRODUCTION OF CARS DECLINED FOR WEEK
WBAI IS ORDERED TO GIVE UP TAPES

He noted that, in recent years, the emphasis had been on setting up organizations managed and staffed by minority groups only.

Judges may grow remote from popular feeling, and their decisions provoke divisive political controversy; there are examples in every period of American history up to the present.

description: PEKING, Feb. 25 (UPI)Following are transcripts of the toasts delivered at a banquet tonight by President Nixon and by Premier Chou Entai of China:

description: ISLIP, L. I., Feb. 25Dr. David D. Moore, a past president of the Southside Hospital in Bay Shore, died of cancer at the hospital today. His age was 72.

title: Sweden's Isaksson Poleaults 1710 for World Indoor Mark

description: SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 25Armed guards patrolled last night the 1,700acre ranch of Rodger L. McAfee, the man who put up the collateral for Angela Davis's bail, following a number of reported telephone threats on his life and the lives of his family.Estimating that only about 5 per cent of hundreds of telephone calls supported his stand. Mr. McAfee said one caller had warned, Your family will be dead before the weekend. Scores of others called him a Communist pig and a dirty Communist among other things, he said.

title: Demagoguery in the Senate
description: The Senate's action yesterday to prohibit the Federal courts from ordering the busing of pupils for purposes of school desegregation is a landmark of legislative irresponsibility. This amendment to the $24billion education bill, which won by a vote of 43 to 40, is a deliberate challenge to the courts and a demagogic appeal to bigotry and fear.

description: PARIS, Feb. 25The United States retaliated today against yesterday's walkout by the Vietnamese Communists by, refusing to agree to meet for peace talks next week.

description: A savings bank was robbed of $3,900 yesterday afternoon by a man who gave a teller a note demanding the money and stating he had a gun, the police said. The man held up the Emigrant Savings Bank at 9 East 42d Street at 4:30 P.M., according to the police, receiving the money in $50 and $100 bills.

title: ARGENTINE LOAN SET BY LATIN AID BANK

The current storm over the degradation of the human beings institutionalized there must not be allowed to fade away in still more inaction.

title: WALTER HOWLETT, CHURCH EDUCATOR
description: The Rev. Dr. Walter M. Howlett, who retired in 1958 as executive secretary of the Greater New York Committee on Released Time, died on Wednesday. He was 88 years old and lived at 361 Clinton Avenue, Brooklyn.

title: Patents of the Week
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 25A two speed facsimile system to be patented next week for Comfax Communications Industries, Inc., New York, saves time in transmitting a document by hurrying over the blank spaces. Patent 3,626,256 will be granted to half a dozen inventors, Including Ira Kamen, chairman of the Comfax board. The promoters say a lettersize page can be sent from one office to another over ordinary telephone lines in less than one minute, which they call a record speed for such transmission. Over special intracity microwave facilities, the time is reported as less than 15 seconds.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Jabara Wins 3Set Final
description: Gerry Jabara of the New York Athletic Club defeated Peter Pochner, 1513. 157, 1716, in the final of the 24th Fowler squash racquets invitation tournament at the Seventh Regiment Squash Club yesterday. Jabara was seeded No. 1, ??

title: Peace, a Growing Storefront Commodity
description: TEANECKPeace is a fulltime business at the Bergen County Peace Center, which will be three years old in March. The only celebration planned is business as usual, which means a hectic schedule of peace education and draft counseling at the small, narrow storefront along Teaneck's main business street.

title: San Cristobal Is A Good Place For IndianWatching
description: SAN CRISTOBAL DE LAS CASAS, MexicoWhere the modern Pan American Highway roars along Mexico's mountainous backbone at San Cristobal is the gateway to a living history of the ancient Mayan empire. This second largest city in the state of Chiapas has as its neighbors two Indian villages, Chamula and Zinacantan, whose inhabitants descend from the Mayans. Indians from these two villages and from all over the surrounding regions pour into San Cristobal daily to trade at the local market and buy in local stores and gawk at tourists who have come to stare at them.

title: U.S. COURT UPSETS WELFARE CUTBACK
description: TRENTON, N.J.A Federal Judge has ruled that New Jersey may not stop payments under the Aid to Dependent Children and Aid to the Blind, Aged and Disabled programs unless it first grants a fair hearing to recipients threatened with the cutoff.

title: 1,000 IN MINORITIES GET SCHOLARSHIPS
description: The College Entrance Examination Board has announced the selection of about 1,000 black Americans, Chicanos, Puerto Ricans and American Indians as the national award winners in a program to aid minority group students transferring from twoyear colleges to fouryear programs.

title: Music Mailbag
description: TO THE EDITOR:

title: Everett F. Wells Is Dead at 67; Former Ashland Oil President
description: SCOTTSDALE, Ariz., Feb. 26  Everett F. Wells, former president and chairman of Ashland Oil, Inc., of Ashland, Ky., died here today at Scottsdale Memorial Hospital from injuries suffered in an automobile collision two weeks ago. Mr. Wells, 67 years old, was vacationing here when the accident occurred. His home was in Ashland.

title: Letter to the Editor 9  No Title
description: To THE EDITOR:I was quoted in the article about Bruce Franklin as having said that a sensitivity toward civil liberties was blatantly absent among the [Stanford] law school faculty. That statement, if I made it without qualifications is an unfair overgeneralization. There were a small number of law professors  mostly among the younger facultywho were concerned about Franklin's civil liberties. Indeed, two of them cosigned the A.C.L.U. brief with me.

title: Barbara Robbins, Smith 73, Engaged
description: ANNANDALE, Va., Feb. 26 Announcement has been made by Col. Charles Robbins, U.S.A., retired, and Mrs. Robbins of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Barbara Ann Robbins, to Dan Earl Simanek, son of Mr. and Mrs. Earl Simanek of Hinsdale. Ill.

title: Track Acquiring Sex Appeal

title: Movie Mailbag

title: Letters
description: To THE EDITOR:I do not share Mr. Shaw's inability to decide between divergent colleagues and their philosophies. By Hippocrates or Maimonides one must believe that not to operate is a basic violation of a person's right to live. I draw a very distinct difference between abortions and postnatal euthanasia. I cannot accept Dr. Shaw's posture that parents of handicapped children have the legal and/or moral responsibility of determining whether this human being lives or dies.

title: Taiwan Watching Nixon With Pained Restraint
description: TAIPEI, Taiwan, Feb. 26The people and Government of this island territory have watched President Nixon's activities of the last week in China with pained restraint.

title: SOVIET RECOVERS MOONSHOT CRAFT
description: MOSCOW, Feb. 26The Soviet Union announced today that its Luna 20 had landed safely during the night with its cargo of moon rock, completing the second roundtrip flight by an unmanned spacecraft to the surface on the moon.

title: Oxford Tutor Setup Adapted for Ramapo
description: MAHWAH Ramapo College, the newest in the state system, is offering its students a touch of old Oxford.

title: Brooklyn Museum Plans Auction
description: An auction sale of fine prints from the Brooklyn Museum collection will be held Tuesday evening. It will he the first such event since the museum's founding in 1823.

title: NINEDAY CABINET RESIGNS IN ITALY
description: ROME, Feb. 26The Cabinet of Premier Giulio Andreotti resigned late tonight after only nine days in office. The action followed a Senate vote rejecting a confidence motion, 158 to 151.

title: Medicine
description: Some 25 million Americans, about 20 per cent of the nation's adult population, have high blood pressurehypertension in medical parlance. A great mass of statistics testifies that the hypertensive individual has a substantially greater risk of premature deathusually from strokes or heart attacksthan the person with normal blood pressure.

title: Power Captures Catholic High Schools Indoor Track Title
WORLD OF SEVENTH AVE.

A new division of Davidow, Mac Dougall, Ltd., has prepared an extensive line of coats, skirts, jackets and sportswear for the fall season that will sell for approximately 40 per cent less than the regular Davidow line.

title: Skiing's Annual Mob Scene: 10 Miles of Spills and Chills
description: If the crosscountry ski race at Guilford, Vt., on Washington's Birthday is not the largest (850 entrants) in the country, it must be the most unusual. From 6yearold Andrew McKinley to 74yearold Arthur Mooney, the field encompassed men and women of all ages. Some traversed the 10 miles rolling hills just for the exercise; others were serious racers. This year's winner: Timothy Caldwell, le, of Putney, Vt. The race was introduced in 1963.

title: Meyer Weisgal So Far An Autobiography. Illustrated. 404 pp. New York: Random House. $10.
description: Like most Jews I was born in Kikl, declares Meyer Weisgal at the very outset. The event took place 70 years ago, and he is only halfjoking about the placehis smile should be taken seriously. Neither those who know and love him nor those who know and hate himfor he inspires one or the other, never indifferencehave any notion where Kikl may be found. This is hardly their fault. For geography was never its strong point. More than a town or a village, or even a hamlet, Kikl was a state of mind. Its real boundaries were not in space but in time. It was an abstract of Jewish history which can only be located in the memory, the literature and the folklore of the Jews. Clearly, Kikl is the typical Eastern European Shtedtl where Jews recited the Psalms over and over again and praised God for the bounty which filled their souls, while their goats nodded in affirmation. That their stomachs were empty was never bone of contention with Him.

title: The Erich Fromm Theory of Aggression
description: WHAT with international and civil wars, the increasing use of torture, rising violence in the cities and the threat of nuclear war, no explanation is needed for the lively current theoretical interest in the problem of human violence and aggression. In fact, if there is a question it is why it took such a long time for aggression to be recognized as major psychological problem.

title: European Air Group to Meet
description: PARIS, Feb. 26The European Civil Aviation Conference will meet here May 30 to consider a new code governing charter flights, it was announced today.

title: Masai Warrior Welcomed in Harlem
description: A 23yearold Masai warrior from Tanzania was welcomed home to Harlem last week by scores of Harlem youths who proudly told him they were warriors, too.

description: ACRE, IsraelFrom the top of the pencilslim minaret, the muezzin calls the faithful to prayer, cupping his hands against the wandering breeze. Down below, the great Turkish caravanserai, doubletiered and colonnaded, slumbers in the noonday sun while an Israeli soldier, leaning against a Roman column, chats with his fairhaired girlfriend. Outside, where the Mediterranean surf beats against the 12

title: Failures Transformed Into Workers by a Training Unit
description: NEWARK  At the Newark Manpower Training Skills Center, they take words like disadvantaged and hardcore unemployed and strip them of their meaning.

description: Dr. and Mrs. Sidney A. Sackett of Sunnyside. Queens, have made known the engagement of their daughter, Miss Roberta Susan Sackett, to Robert W. Dillon, son of Mr. and Mrs. Henry J. Dillon of Belle Harbor, Queens.

title: The Odd Lighthouse On Janiculum Hill
description: ROMETo help restore this city's historic aspect, municipal authorities recently ordered shops, hotels and restaurants to lessen the wattage of their neon signs and showy displays. But the order is not likely to dim the green, white and red lights beamed daily from dusk to dawn by the unique lighthouse atop the Janiculum Hill. A landmark for Romans and a curiosity for tourists, the lighthouse is as much a part of the city as the Colosseum.

title: The Peking Summit
description: The smiles, handshakes, public cordiality and agreed communique that marked President Nixon's visit Peking last week should have caused neither surprise nor euphoria.

title: Saigon Envoy Tells of Cordial Talk With Hanoi Aide
description: SAIGON. South Vietnam, Feb. 26On a cool evening in Paris last December, Dr. Tran Van; Do, the courtly former Foreign Minister of South Vietnam, ,walked into the suburban villa rented by the Government of North Vietnam.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Private organizations are being urged to buy litter baskets for the city's streets.

title: CORNELL RETAINS GYMNASTICS TITLE
description: PRINCETON, N. J., Feb. 26Cornell continued its domination of Ivy League gymnastics today by handily capturing the championship meet before a crowd of 300 in Dillon Gymnasium.

title: High Court to Hear Arguments This Week On Baseball's Reserve Clause
description: WASHINGTON (UPI)  A lineup of nine Supreme Court justices is slated to hear oral arguments this week on whether major league baseball's ironclad player contract is unconstitutional and whether the sport's longheld exemption from antitrust laws should be struck down.

title: Education
description: Passing the bar examination has always been a challenging ordeal for law students. It has involved hours of answering essay questions about contracts, torts and real property, and weeks of waiting while the essays were scored. And traditionally, with some exceptions, an attorney had to pass the bar exam of each state in which he wanted to practice.

title: The Old Signs
description: Tomorrow night's full moon will be the last one we will see this winter. The next full moon will brighten the sky of late March, when daylight has begun surpass darkness, and when spring peepers will be shrilling in sheltered lowlands. The fang of night chill should be dulled and there should be the touch of slowly awakening spring in the afternoon sunlight.

title: Television
description: EXCEPT for the viewer, public television is a headache. If it isn't constantly jabbing at itself with internal power struggles and petty status ploys, it is being attacked from the outside by those who deem it either too controversial or not controversial enough.

title: HIGHLIGHTS OF THE WEEK
description: THE TREASURY urged Congress to speedily raise the price of gold to $38 an ounce, thereby formally devaluing the dollar and the bill passed its first Senate hurdle... West Germany cut the discount rate from 4 to 3 per cent. Argentina devalued the peso by 9.2 per cent.... panel of economists, lawyers and government officials recommended that the I.M.F. be given power to penalize nations that refused to abide by internationally agreed monetary recommendations.... The Soviet Union is seeking a $1.51billion loan from Japan for the transSiberian pipeline.

title: Very Quiet and Very Dangerous
description: THERE has been a lot of flak In the air for the last two or three weeks, with heavy concentration over the Metropolitan Museum. The suspected target may nave materialized from its nebulous state by the time this gets into print, or may have vanished. But the excitement and apprehension were generated by something that needs thinking about in any case. Even a false alarm can call attention to potential disaster.

title: Montreal Sextette Wins
description: MONTREAL, Feb. 26 (AP)The women's ice hockey team from Loyola College of Montreal defeated Brown University, 54, after two overtime periods today to win the Montreal invitation tournament.

title: Hawaiian Volcano Erupts
description: VOLCANO, Hawaii, Feb. 26 (UPI)The Kilauea volcano spewed molten lava 60 feet into the air today as eruptions continued here at Volcanoes National Park. The eruptions centered on the volcano's Mauna Ulu vent and officials said the lava level was rising in the center.

title: How one New England newspaper kept up with the times
description: News used to mean what happened yesterday. Then it came to mean also things that have happened that you never knew before. Now it usually means things that have happened that you never knew before and what they are all about. Crude definitions, to be sure, but they suggest the expanding realm of journalism and the need for explaining, analyzing and interpreting events in an increasingly complex world.

title: State Task Force on Welfare Set Up to Study State Supervision and Local Administration
description: ALBANY, Feb. 26The State Commissioner of Social Services, George K. Wyman, announced today the creation of a task force to conduct an indepth study of the state's role in the provision of services and in the supervision of local social services agencies.

title: Yes, Virginia, in the Old Days They
description: AILEY, N. C.We lucky Americans, living inside a cornucopia of riches, often overlook the tinier, tastier morsels of places to go, things to do and sights to see that surround us. Take just the simple example of museums, with which we are blessed with an official total, including the Canadian ones, of 6,657. Very few of us have given them due attention. In fact, many of us have never even heard of the gas museum, the fourwheeldrive museum, the ham museum, the air gun museum, the coffee mill museum, the live steam museum, to mention a few that come to mind. And many of us who know them do not actually go to them; in case the accusation seems too strong, consider that the speed skating museum had only 14 visitors in all of 1970.

title: ITALY IS AROUSED BY RISE IN CRIME
description: ROME, Feb. 26A crash of gangsterism, holdups and burglaries throughout the country is alarming Italians and all but overwhelming the police.

title: Diane Dillenberg to Wed
description: SCARBOROUGH, N. Y., Feb. 26The engagement of Miss Diane Lynn Dillenberg to Capt. Frederic Ira Lederer, U.S.A., son of Mrs. Seymour G. Lederer of Oceanside, Li., and the late Lieut. Col. Seymour G. Lederer, U.S.A., has been announced by the future bride's parents. Captain Lederer is stationed at Fort Hamilton in Brooklyn.

title: Philadelphia Sees Gain In Car Pollution Drive
description: PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 26 A city Health Department campaign against motor vehicle exhaust pollution has been relatively successful, Robert W. King, acting director of the air management; services, said today.

title: CHELSEA IS UPSET IN CUP SOCCER, 32
description: LONDON, Feb. 26, (Reuters) Chelsea was upset, 32, by Orient, a struggling Second Division club, in the English Football Association Cup fifthround matches today.

title: Weiskopf and McLendon Tie Player With 210's
description: FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., Feb. 26The closer you get to $52,000, the tougher the course gets, said Tom Weiskopf after he tied for the 54hole lead in the $260,000 Jackie Gleason Inverrary golf tournament for the richest first prize of the year.

title: Hunt Starts for Dust Cloud Moons
description: NEWARK  The National Aeronautics and Space Administration has awarded a $30,000 research grant to Dr. Benjamin Carroll, a professor of physical chemistry at the Rutgers Newark College of Arts and Sciences, to investigate the possible existence of dust cloud moons of the earth.

title: He's Flunking Buster Keaton!
description: AND how are you getting along at college, Douglas? asked Mr. Fethergill. He wasn't really interested in his nephew's studies, but relatives at a family party have to talk about something.

title: Sudan and Are Said to Reach an Agreement
description: ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia, Feb. 26 (Agence FrancePresse) The Sudanese Government and southern Sudanese rebel movement reached an agreement here today ending the southern rebellion.

title: CHAPOT IS STAR OF JERSEY SHOW
description: POTTERSVILLE, N. J., Feb. 26Frank Chapot, a fourtime member of the United States Equestrian Olympic Team, and a nominee for the squad that will compete in Munich, Germany, this summer, swept the first four places in the special open jumper class at the Tewksbury Farm's winter horse show here today.

title: International Travel
description: NEW DELHI, IndiaIf you are afraid of being jostled by staring, antimonyeyed urchins, unholy cows, greedy newspapermunching goats, freewheeling bicycles (carrying families of four), burping silversmiths and mattedhair mendicants, this place is certainly not for you. You can glide around the city of Delhi in chauffeured limousine, stepping out only at the welltended tombs, mausoleums, forts, museums, boutiques and touristoriented shops. On the other hand, if you are curious and courageous, and wish to see the crowded heart of an

title: City Extends Police Lists, Yielding to Council Pressure Despite Concern About Opposition of Blacks
description: Under pressure from City Council leadersand despite apprehension about potential opposition from the Negro comrnunitythe Lindsay administration has extended six lists, for appointment to the Police) Department.

title: The long cruel road from Harfleur to Agincourt
description: To write a novel about the life and times of Henry V is risky businessthis, after, all, is Shakespeare territory  but on the whole Martha Rofheart deftly avoids the dangers. Before the battle of Agincourt the King says to his archers, Think of all the men in England who wish they could be with us. This serves as a downto earth equivalent of the famous speech in Henry V (and gentlemen in England now abed...). Mrs. Rofheart undercuts the rhetoric even further by having Lord Humphrey observe, I wish they could be too. About ten thousand of them.

title: Fort Lee Is Seized By Growing Pains
description: FORT LEEA family paying more than $600 a month rent for a twobedroom apartment atop a Horizon House tower here can overlook the nearby George Washington Bridge and New York City, and all the city's problems but cannot be certain it has left behind all the urban ills it hoped to escape by moving up above it all.

title: Writing a New Scenario for Boston
description: AT the Museum of Fine Arts the other night, visitors attending the opening of the Jack Bush exhibition were confronted, just inside the front entrance, by a ninefootlong painting by Jackson Pollock. It was his Number 10 (1949), well knownif only in reproductionto connoisseurs of the New York School but brand new to the Boston museum, which had only just acquired it from the collection of Alfonso Ossorio. The Pollock painting is, infact, the first acquisition of the museum's brand new Department of Contemporary Art, and may legitimately be taken, I think, as a sign of things to come at this museum, which has not exactly been notable for its hospitality to contemporary art of any sort.

title: Nicolette Walker London Bride of Bruce Coward
description: LONDON, Feb. 26Miss Nicolette Milnes Walker, the first woman to sail the Atlantic Ocean solo by a northern route, and Bruce Coward, advertising director of The Times of London Literary Supplement, were married today in St. James's Church, Piccadilly. The Rev. Philip Lloyd, vicar of Holy Trinity Church, Bickerton, Cheshire, officiated at the Anglican ceremony.

title: Letters
description: To THE EDITOR:May I commend Martha Weinman Lear for having recognized in her article on rape (Q. If You Rape a Woman and Steal Her TV What Can They Get You For in New York? A. Stealing Her TV," Jan. 30) the serious and burning issue that has been before the New York State Legislature for the past three years.

title: BASEBALL FACING SERIOUS IMPASSE
description: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., Feb. 26Tom Seaver, player representative of the New York Mets, said today that a very serious situation was developing between the players and club owners over benefit plans that expire March 31.

title: $2,000 Spent to Avert $15 Fine
description: Dr. C. H. J. Hull, who was arrested last May 23 while sailing on Barnegat Bay for putting a crew member on the rail during a race, had his conviction for improper boat operation overturned last Tuesday.

title: Lawyer Told to Work Free
description: PHOENIX, Ariz., Feb. 26 (AP)After pleading guilty to two misdeamor counts of fraud in connection with the financial collapse of a Phoenix land concern, Ira Broadman, a lawyer, was ordered by Superior Court Judge D. L. Greer yesterday to give free legal services to the poor one afternoon a week for four months.

title: POINT OF VIEW
description: During the decade of the nineteensixties, more than half a million jobs were lost to imports, many in industries where parent firms invested abroad and then imported to supply the domestic market. This type of behavior is encouraged by present tax laws and trade policies. More shocking yet is the fact that modern technology. often developed with the substantial participation of United States tax dollars, is licensed abroad at the expense of domestic employment.

title: You're Singing Too Much The More I Sing, the Better I Sound
description: GOD must have been in excellent spirits the day He created Placido, Birgit Nilsson observed recently. He has everything needed for one of the greatest careers ever seen: an incredibly beautiful voice great intelligence an unbelievable musicality and acting ability wonderful looks, a great heart, and he's a dear, dear colleague. He is almost the perfect linguistbut, alas, he has not yet learned how to say no in any language!

title: State and Federal Officials Intensify Scrutiny of Commercial Health Insurance
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 26A series of fullpage newspaper advertisements this month have touted the benefits of commercial health insurance, an increasingly lucrative business that has gained favor with consumers at a time of steadily rising medical care costs.

title: Leafs Down Canucks, 71
description: TORONTO, Feb. 26 (UPI)Paul Henderson scored three goals and Norm Ullman two as the Toronto Maple Leafs erupted for seven goals in the first two periods to down the Vancouver Canucks, 71, tonight.

title: CHAMBER CONCERT SUNG AT MUSEUM
description: Since concerts in the Medieval Sculpture Court of the Metropolitan Museum have proven to be such pleasing experiences, both visually and aurally, it is a pity there cannot be more of them.

title: Revenge Of the Lawn
description: To the Editor:

title: News off the Rialto
description: PETER HALL. one ofEngland's more prelean directorcome??,dream,?? even opera and movieshas accepted the challenge of staging his first musical for Broadway, Via Galactiea, by Galt MacDermot and Christopher Gore.

title: ARTHUR F. MAXWELL
description: BIDDEFORD, Me. Feb. 26 (AP)Arthur F. Maxwell, former director of the Federal Reserve Bank in Boston, died yesterday at the age of 71.

title: 3 Crash Victims Identified
description: Three teenaged girls who died in a twocar collision late Friday night on Ocean Parkway at Avenue J were identified by the police yesterday as Doreen Crescimanno, 19 years old, of 667 East 80th Street; June Stoppick, 17, of 217 East Seventh Street, and Gloria Cohen, 17, of 768 Bragg Street, all of Brooklyn.

title: Camping Show Opens Saturday With FlyCasting Ace in Spotlight
description: Bruce Brubaker of Camp Hill, Pa., is the world's professional flycasting champion.

title: The Ballet: Petrushka
description: The growth of a production, its development and changes, are among the most rewarding aspects of looking consistently at ballet over a long period of time. When the City Center Joffrey Ballet's production of Michel Fokine's Petrushka was new a couple of years ago, it had its revival attributed primarily to Leonide Massine and it was a pretty sorry mess, apart from the very sensitive reconstruction of the Alexandre Benois designs.

title: WRESTLING WON BY NEW YORK U.
description: WEST LONG BRANCH, N..L, Feb. 26New York University used four victories in the final matches to capture the 14th annual Metropolitan wrestling championships at Monmouth College today.

title: Old Jersey City Law Excludes Women From Bars
description: JERSEY CITY  The men only bar may be a fading institution elsewhere, but in this aged waterfront city, where a change in custom comes slowly, the exclusion of women from taverns is still a strongly supported and widespread practice.

title: Two Challengers Planning to Face Reid in Republican Primary
description: WHITE PLAINS, Feb. 26 Two men, one of whom says he has been promised financial backing by prominent Republicans, are preparing challenges to Representative Ogden R. Reid, the fiveterm Westchester Republican, in the June primary election.

title: MEADOWS WINS IN PRO BOWLING
description: SPRINGFIELD, Va., Feb. 26 (AP)Bobby Meadows, a 32yearold from Houston, made his first appearance in the finals of a professional bowling tournament a winning one today as he recorded a 195187 victory in the $60,000 Fair Lanes open.

title: Books About jersey
description: With the reissue of this completely rewritten edition of the Walk Book, which has quite properly been called the hiker's bible, hikers in New Jersey and New York have little excuse for not exploring one of this country's most scenically diversified areas.

title: Music Mailbag
description: To THE EDITOR:

title: Education
description: Largely in response to student urgings for reform and relevance, colleges across the country are experimenting more and coming up with new and unusual courses. Subjects like weaving and yoga have worked their way into curriculums along with more esoteric pursuits. At many colleges the students themselves have been involved in the selection and preparation of new courses.

title: Folk, Rock From Denny To Glass Harp
description: SANDY DENNY: The North Star Grossman and The Ravens (A &M SP4317). Most of the selections here, as written and performed by Miss Denny and cohorts, sound like Israeli marching songs or Irish laments, or maybe the other way around. Not a bad sound in either case. Portions of the lyrics of The Sea Captain could bemaybe arerewrites of the lyrics to She Moves Through The Fair, that prototypical Irish

title: SHOP TALK
description: HACKETTSTOWN  No need to visit Montana to see a genuine livestock auction. Just come out here any Tuesday, as do 300 to 500 people, to attend the Livestock Cooperative Auction Market of North Jersey. It opens at noon, and if you want a cow, steer, sheep, goat or a dozen chickenslive, that isat the going wholesale price, this is the place.

title: Police Grant Sought
description: MINEOLA, LXNassau County Executive Ralph G. Caso has announced that the Nassau Police Department has applied to the State Office of Crime Control Planning for a $222,000 grant to modernize techniques and equipment involved in police training. The proposed system, Project Teleview, would provide personnel and audiovisual equipment to prepare programs on video tape to he shown on television units in police precincts throughout the county.

title: Something for the girls'but not for women
description: Meet the author: She invented the slogan Waxed beauty instantly as you dust, and she says, It does my heart good to see it all these years later still on every can of Pledge. She was involved in the tense b.ut doomed search for a younger, more modern personification of Betty Crocker. (You can imagine how tough things would be out in Flourland if all those millions of women had their belief in Betty Crocker blown.) Malcontent kids like Ralph Nader and interventionist Feds like the F.T.C. or the F.D.A. get her dander up because they won't leave product claims up to the imagination of the writer.

title: The World
description: Inscrutable? No, the meeting in Peking is not inscrutable to any Chinese who saw his beloved Chairman with broad smile and bright eye clasp the hand of President Nixon. Through photographs far more meaningful than any formal communique, Mao Tsetung reassured his 800 million countrymen they need not fear war with the United States. This was no emperor haughtily acknowledging tribute from a foreign barbarian. Instead, the ideological godhead of the People's Republic of China sat joking in the relaxed informality of his personal study, waving ceremony aside as he put his visitor at ease. Through press, radio and television the message was out: The American President is here as the honored guest of the Chairman.

title: U.S. Aides Report Soviet Has Tested Advanced Missile
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 26United States intelligence sources report that the Soviet Union has tested a new underwater ballistic missile with a range of 3,000 nautical miles.

title: A Bit of Scotland
description: Despite the dismal weather conditions, management did its soggy best to maintain the festive atmosphere associated with Campbell Day.

title: A blueprint for meeting nature halfway
description: It is hard to admit, but harder still to disagree with the young resident of Canyon, Calif., who said, The earth can't support the American way of life. Yet proposed alternatives to the American way have all too often been at best genial, vague, shortlived and romantic and at worst, dreams or nightmares. Canyon is an exception.

title: Doctor's House Call A Growing Industry For New Agencies
description: The house call, a slowly dying tradition in American medical practice, is being resurrected and transformed into a lucrative service industry by a small group of medical entrepreneurs.

title: Lois Stalford, Editor, Bride of Stockbroker
description: Miss Lois Rebecca Stalford, an associate fashion editor of Harper's Bazaar, and Richard E. Freeman, partner in the New York Stock Exchange firm of Frederick & Co., were married last night at the 21 Club. The ceremony was performed by Rabbi Emeritus Morris Shmidman of Congregation Sons of Israel Synagogue, Asbury Park, N.J. N. J.

title: Miss Silverstein to Wed
description: The engagement of Miss Beryl Leslie Silverstein to Paul Harold Tannenbaum, son of Mr. and Mrs. Benjamin Tannenbaum of Newton Highlands, Mass., has been announced by the prospective bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Samuel Silverstein of Brooklyn.

title: The Nation
description: It is just barely possible that the publishing world is involved with subjects other than billionaire industrialist Howard R. Hughes.. But one couldn't prove it on the basis of developments last week.

title: HUNT ASSOCIATION REVISES ITS DATES
description: The National Steeplechase and Hunt Association has announced a revision in the 1972 spring race meeting dates. The major changes involve the switch of the Middleburg dates to May 27 and June 3 and the Deep Run dates to June 10.

title: View From Simon's Bridge
description: WHAT do you do as an encore for a recording that has earned more than $25,000,000? Especially if the recording is the 7th multimillion dollar earning production, you've made in the last five years? If you're Paul Simon, the songwriter half of the nowdetached duo of Simon & Garfunkel, you hang in there and produce more music, this time in the form of a brand new solo album.

title: Mentor of Bellevue PupilPatients to Retire
description: A couple of darkeyed boys, brothers aged 8 and 10, look up from their schoolwork with smiles as Mrs. Wanda Wright, the principal, walks through Public School 106 in Bellevue Psychiatric Hospital.

title: Arrives in Yugoslavia
description: BELGRADE, Feb. 26 (AP)Foreign Minister Ho Dam of North Korea arrived here today for an official visit to Yugoslavia. The fourday visit is the first highlevel contact between Yugoslavia and North Korea.

title: WALL STREET
description: Avid readers of the New York Stock Exchange's monthly shortinterest tables might be curious as to why there has been so much shortselling in American Telephone warrants of late.

title: Kerr on Sleep and Grease
description: INEVER thought much of my dreams, but I'll match mine with the hero of Jack Gelber's new play any time. In Sleep, which is currently being performed at the American Place Theater and is apt to put you to, a chap name Gil is stretched out on a bed beneath a spray of bright green wires. Two doctors hover to measure his REM (rapid eye movements) and various other responses, including the penile (which are not much; we get to check). Although it is not exactly clear why the doctors are so interested in Gil's nocturnal fantasies, we are given a bit of a hint by four shadowy figures who huddle on the forestage massaging what seems to be a piece of quartz. The quartz is Gil's brain, someone explains after an hour or so, and they're washing it.

title: Harvard Tops Yale, 8872
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Feb. 26  Harvard's basketball team too the lead at the start and never trailed as it whipped Yale, 8872, for its sixth straight victory tonight.

title: A Try at Heroin Clinics Wins Increasing Support
description: In an atmosphere of public frustration, and even desperation, over the inability of existing antinarcotics efforts to contain the spread of heroin addiction and addictcommitted crimes, the highly controversial idea of establishing one or more experimental heroin maintenance clinics here has suddenly gained currency and a certain political respectability.

title: Horace Mann Takes Title In Ivy Prep League Swim
description: Horace Mann School won the Ivy Prep School League swimming championships yesterday at Trinity School. Horace Mann amassed 113 points in the sixschool meet. In the 12event program, Horace Mann won four events and took five seconds and seven thirds.

title: J. N. Cohen Will Wed Francine Lynn Garten
description: SCOTTSDALE, Ariz., Feb. 26Mrs. Arlyne Garten of Scottsdale and Arthur Garten of New York have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Francine Lynn Garten, to Jeffrey Neil Cohen, son of Mr. and Mrs. Norman G. Cohen of Washington. A June wedding is planned.

title: She's Beautiful, PluckyAnd a Man
description: SOMETIMES she is beautiful, and sometimes only a sloppy caricature of beauty. She's plucky. She's mercilessly selfmocking. She talks tough when she is most vulnerable and she can suddenly be as awkward as a child holding a kitten as if it were something that could break. She is alsoat least in the Andy WarholPaul Morrissey Women in Revolt"a man.

title: Unanime, 261, Captures Gulf stream Turf Stakes
description: HALLANDALE, Fla., Feb. 26 Unanime preserved the essential flavor of the $140,600 Pan American Handicap today. A 5yearold Argentinebred, competing in the silks of the Hasty House Farm, Unanime moved to a convincing triumph in the 1mile grass event, to the general surprise of the 23,512 fans on hand.

title: A HangUp on Handel
description: WHY Handel? This is the natural question to ask Stephen Simon on first meeting. As music director of the Handel Society of New York, he has presented here in concert form Ariodante, Solomon, Orlando and Athalia. Judas Maccabaeus is coming up at Carnegie Hall on March 6 and Rinaldo on March 27. He has recorded all but Athalia and Rinaldo for RCA. That is spending a lot of time with Handel.

title: Fiction and fact, wellblended
description: The practice, tempting to publishers, of putting together a volume of occasional writings by a literary lion is all too often one that author and reader both have reason to regret. From time to time a writer will establish himself in his field, cap critical praise with a respected literary award, win sales that go beyond his usual constituency of scholars, librarians and knowledgeable readers, and presto! An uneasy collection of articles, opinion or stories will be trundled together for exposure in the bookshops. It will sell on his name, one imagines the editors muttering to each other. We may make a little, and anyway it will keep him happy.

title: 10 Fires Set on Campus
description: ANN ARBOR, Mich., Feb. 26 (UPI)Ten fires, including one that caused an explosion, were set today on the University of Michigan campus. They brought the number of fires on thel, campus since Jan. 27 to morel than 50.

title: TRACK IS SLOPPY
description: BOWIE, Md., Feb. 26On a sloppy track more suitable for seahorses than race horses, Boone the Great and Favorecidian sloshed to victory today in the divided $170,500 John B. Campbell Handicap at Bowie Race Course.

title: Funny, Moving, and Alive
description: THE most moving play in New York at the moment, and one of the funniest, is Michael Weller's Moonchildren, a deadpan nightmare about the clay after the world died. Only the world died, you understand. The people didn't. They went right on living, on top of the craters, putting all of their wit and their energy and their love and their sublime playfulness into the task of inventing what no longer exists. If there isn't a life, why, you simply make one tip  and you make it as bizarre and as natural, as intense and as preposterous, as you possibly can. The boys and girls at the Royale, which has inherited the piece whole from Washington's Arena Stage, are wonderfully good at it.

title: North Carolina Wins, 9178
description: CHAPEL HILL, N. C., Feb. 26 (UPI)North Carolina regained the Atlantic Coast Conference lead tonight with a 9178 victory over Virginia. Leading the Tar Heels were Robert McAdoo with 24 points, Dennis Wuycik with 20 and George Karl with 18.

title: Bucks Turn Back Suns, 119117 , and Clinch a Playoff Berth
description: MADISON, Wis., Feb. 26 (AP) Lucius Allen's two free throws with 28 seconds to play in an overtime gave the Milwaukee Bucks a 119117 National Basketball Association victory over the Phoenix Suns tonight and clinched a playoff berth for the defending N.B.A. champions.

title: Soviet Pushes New Vitality for Old Fitness Program
description: MOSCOW, Feb. 26All out to the track, the pool, the ski run was the slogan of the day as the Kremlin unveiled a revitalized national program of physical fitness yesterday.

title: Bari E. Shore, B.F. Thompson Married Here
description: The marriage of Miss Bari Ellen Shor to Bernard Francis Thompson, son of Mr. and Mrs. Albert B. Thompson of Overbrook, Philadelphia, and Ocean City, N. J., took place here yesterday afternoon. The bride is a daughter of Bernard Shor, known as Toots Shor, the restaurateur, and Mrs. Shor of New York.

title: Education
description: One of the attractions of the State University is a tuition that, because of taxsupported subsidization, is considerably lower than that of private universities. Any attempt to raise the tuition is usually met by stiff student resistance and political debate. and officials search for any alternative.

title: Dave Anderson
description: In college sports, all gall is not divided into three parts. The N.C.A.A. has most of it.

title: Special Talents Are Weighed by Yale
description: NEW HAVEN, Feb. 26At the Yale University undergraduate admissions office on College Street, the chairs, desks and hallways are overflowing with strangely shaped packages containing such items as macrame, straw flowers, clothing and apple cake.

title: Cry the Beloved Stevens?
description: WASHINGTON, D. C. BY all measures, the most powerful performance of the Kennedy Center's first six months has been that of Roger L. Stevens, the deceptively shy, vaguely monkishlooking millionaire who has come to dominate the Center almost to the point of making It a personal vehicle. Some day, says a Broadway producer, admiringly and only halfkiddingly, it will be renamed The Roger Stevens Center for the Performing Arts. Younger artists who question his taste and his authoritarianism had begun to call him the Robert Moses of Culture in unhappy memory of New York's master highway builder. Like him or not, almost everyone recognizes by now a distinctive Stevens style about the place.

title: State Is Moving to Control Cacophony of Noise Pollution
description: TRENTONRichard J. Sullivan was skating recently at a pond near his Ewing Township home when the earsplitting growls of motor bikes reminded him that he had a big, new job ahead of him.

title: Edna only wanted a spin in someone's PierceArrow
description: Reading The Ewings is like being trapped for 12 hours with an empty glass at a cocktail party given by cretins. John O'Hara's posthumous novel is filled with some of the most excruciatingly boring dialogue imaginable. The same inane things are said over and over again in the same flat tone and in the same lifeless words. The author is repeatedly forced to tag speeches with said Cris Teshmakee or said Bill Ewing to Edna Ewing, because without this kind of help the reader would be hopelessly lost. Without clear labels there is little way to tell one character from another.

title: THE WEEK IN FINANCE
description: THE long, cold winter and other problems have dampened public and business sentiment some what and spread a chill over some segments the nation's economy. A result has been a general malaise and a rather hesitant beginning in economic activity for a year that has been widely heralded as prospective recordbreaker.

title: Plainfield Rink Advances To Semifinals in Curling
description: MT. HOPE, N. Y., Feb. 26Rinks from the Plainfield, N. J., Curling Club; Ardsley, N. Y., C. C.; Nutmeg C. C. of Darien, Conn., and St. Andrew's C. C., the host team, won quarterfinal matches today in the 17th annual mixed bonspiel at St. Andrew's Golf Club.

title: Science
description: Tonight, if all goes well, the United States will launch the longest space mission in history. Its primary goal is to send back to earth, some two years hence, closeup pictures and scientific observations of Jupiter, largest planet of the solar system. But a more excitingalbeit uncertainmission is to announce to some distant civilization that we are here. It is the first official effort on the part. of mankind to draw attention to itself. As the vehicle, Pioneer 10, passes Jupiter, the gravity of that planet will seize it and hurl it out of the solar system. It will sail indefinitely through the vast reaches of the Milky Way Galaxy, carrying a message (reproduced above) in the form of a goldcoated aluminum plate, for any members of other planetary civilizations who may happen to encounter it. Scientists agree, however, that the chances are very slim indeed.

title: A World of Ambiguous Opposites
description: The novels represent an inner Genet; the plays are Genet's fantasies played out in public; and the largely autobiographical Thief's Journal (1947)the only major prose work of his to reach a large publicis the transition between the two. Our Lady of the Flowers (1944) is a tale of transubstantiated genders, a homoerotic fantasy. Miracle of the Rose (1945) is a celebration of love, death and betrayal set in the penitentiary; it is Genet's most deliberately lyrical and literary novel, the rose of the title being at once anus, love and death, a perversion of our normal ethic and an esthetic of the true, good and beautiful. Pompes Funebres (written in 1944 and published in 1947, Genet's first book after leaving prison) is the most literally homosexual and perverse of his novels and the one in which Genet identifies himself most fully with the public and private evils of occupied, then liberated, France and the beautiful evil of Nazi Germany. Querelle de Brest (1947) is clearer as to story and style: Its moral is that crime and betrayal can be expiated only by humiliation.

title: From governors royal to Republican
description: In the long, long catalogue of its histories, Virginia: The New Dominion must surely stand for many years to come as one of the most thorough and conscientious in modern times. In detail, it appears that the author, Virginius Dabney, missed nothing of importance that occurred between the 1607 landing of Captain John Smith's halfstarved band of adventurers at Jamestown to the final collapse, circa 1970, of the Byrd political dynasty. In tone, it is remarkably free of the romanticism other nativeson historians have lavished upon the Old Dominion.

title: Letters
description: To THE EDITOR:Dr. Shaw lumps all newborns with the mongoloid stigmata into the category severely retarded, with an I.Q. of 30. Such a stereotypic analysis fails to note that one may find a considerable variance in I.Q. scores among individuals with mongoloid characteristics. Indeed, Down's syndrome individuals may approximate normal levels of intellectual functioning as well as profound mental incapacity. Moreover, the assessment of a mongoloid newborn's I.Q. is prescientific at best. The lack of predictive reliability of all infantintelligence measures would warn against such estimates.

title: William Rogers Thinks Like Richard Nixon
description: ON a table in the anteroom of Secretary William P. Rogers's office in the Department of State lies a large rectangular glass ashtray, not terribly different at first glance from many others around Washington. Etched into the crystal is an impressive seal meant to convey the majesty of the United States Government. Senators give their favorite constituents ashtrays much like this one, but this is no everyday senatorial trinket. Ringing the eagle in the majestic seal are the words Vice President of the United States, and beneath it is the replica of signature which, in very precise penmanship, reads: Richard Nixon. This ashtray is a collector's item, rarer by far in Washington than, say, a PT109 tie clasp. It says something important about William Rogers. His detractors, in fact, might argue that it says everything there is to know. It is a reminder that Bill Rogers's relationship with Richard Nixon dates back to the whistlestopping days of the Eisenhower Presidential campaign in 1952. That's a long time for a man like Dick Nixon, who has trouble with close relationships. Indeed, Wil liam Rogers has been a good and valued friend of the President far longer than any of the other men who surround him as policy advisers.
