description: LAUREL HOLLOW, ELFor a while there, friends of Mr. and Mrs. Rudy Janesch must have thought the couple had rocks in their heads.

title: Pilot Warning Devices Urged
description: The National Transportation Safety Board has called for mandatory installation of special altitude warning devices in the nation's 2,400 commercial airliners to alert pilots when they descend dangerously close to the ground.

title: In Many Schools, the Headmistress Is a Man
description: In 1954, the Head Mistresses Association of the East had 93 members, three of whom were men. Today. with 96 members, 40 are men.

title: How I.M.C. Achieved Painful Turnaround
description: The International Minerals and Chemical Corporation was no exception to the majority of companies in the agricultural chemical business in the late nineteensixties  it took a severe pounding.

title: A School Plan With Busing Watched Throughout State
description: MONTCLAIR  Tomorrow evening this community will consider at a public meeting the most recent in a series of plans to reorganize its public school system.

title: Photography
description: FLYING In the face of its own sorry tradition, the Metropolitan Museum of Art has actually managed to mount large, timely and generally excellent (though somewhat flawed) photographic exhibit: Behind the Great Wall, a selection of 200 photographs of China covering the period from 1870 through 1971. The exhibit will be on view through April 11.

title: LETTERS
description: The article Tax Bite Rises Steeply (Feb. 13) has hit upon an essential morsel of tax informationthe takehome pay concept. Tax increases, tax decreases, rate reductions, increased exemptions, new W4 forms are all to no avail if they merely change the tax obligations of the few and leave many wage earners with less takehome pay. The man on the assembly line is not expected to understand macroeconomic concepts, but he does understand it when he must bring home a lighter pay envelope. It is then that your economic advisers, including the newly appointed woman, will he asked to guess what the influences will be on employment, spending and price levels.

title: Government Vs. Hotels
description: The hotel and motel industry, which has just had its worst year since the Depression, has another headache government competition.

title: The Nation; Vagrancy Laws: Just What Is Undesirable?
description: One evening several years ago, police in Jacksonville, Fla., stopped car occupied by two black men and two white girls. The men were arrestedand convictedon a charge of prowling by auto, a charge based on the city's vagrancy law. But they appealed the conviction on grounds that the statute was unconstitutional, and they were joined in the appeal by others convicted of being vagabonds and common thieves.

title: Street Crime Follows New Yorker to Coast
description: SAN JOSE, Calif., Feb. 26 (UPI)Frank Leon, 63 years old, sold his grocery in New York City two months ago to get away from street crime.

title: The Presidential Primaries are haphazard, unfair and wildly illogical
description: FEW political reforms conceived in logic, civic virtue and a desire for more perfect democracy can have turned out more preposterous than the institution or the Presidential primary as confronts the country in 1972. Out of the best of intentions we are now plunged into 25 of these preliminary contests (counting the District of Columbia and the Virgin Islands). They are bewilderingly varied in rules, techniques and significance and have in their totality no more relevance to the will of the people than the choice of President by a combination of poker, chess and roulette.

title: The World
description: Just a year ago the military seized political control of turbulent Turkey. Since then they have mounted a stringent campaign to wipe out leftist opposition to their conservative rule.

title: Flying With Lindy
description: I can't describe the flyingit.was too glorious. Only when he threw his hands out, I was too terrified to look down, and then, finding that the things actually worked I stopped being afraid. Only it was so funnyI couldn't keep in a straight line. There are tremendous forces in the air that one doesn't realize. It was like an unwieldy and stubborn elephant. It would go to the left and I was pushing the right rudder (not very hard, evidently!).

title: The Nation
description: Most of us are mystified by what a repair man does to the innards of an automobile or TV set. But we are still less able to judge the quality of work a surgeon has done inside our bodies. Only other doctors can judge whether the surgery has been done properlyor even whether it should have been done at all.

title: Mrs. Gunter Reaches Final, Beating Miss Melville at Net
description: BETHESDA, Md., Feb. 26 (AP) Mrs. Nancy Gunter of San Angelo, Tex., defeated Australia's Kerry Melville, 64, 64, today and advanced to the final of the Virginia Slims women's tennis tournament.

title: Jonelle Is Spelled Sex
description: WHEN Jonelle Allen struts onto the stage of the St. James Theater near the end of the first act of Two Gentlemen of Verona, you know, you just. know, that The Star has arrived. The skinny, 23yearold former child actress exudes a kind of alleyesgluedtoher feline charisma, from the tip of her glistening Afro wig to the bottom of her dangerously lowcut gown, in which she has been taped to the bodice nightly ever since one of her breasts accidentally spilled out when the show played Central Park last summer.

title: U.N. STUDY FAVORS MARIJUANA CURBS
description: GENEVA, Feb. 26There should be no relaxation of international controls aimed at eliminating the consumption of marijuana, according to a newly published United Nations. report,

title: G.O.P.in New Hampshire Debates Tactics of Nixon
Sharon Humphreys Is Betrothed
description: KATONAH, N. Y., Feb. 26 The engagement of Miss Sharon Patricia Humphreys to William Weston Driver Jr. of Bronxville, son of Mr. and Mrs. Driver of Binghamton, has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. William E. Humphreys, parents of the future bride.

title: Nixons Hangchow Host: Nan Ping
description: Host for banquet given in Hangchow for President Nixon head of Chekiang Province's Revolutionary Committee... Little is known about career before Cultural Revolution... first came to prominence in 1967 when ordered to intervene in fighting in Chekiang between rival Communist party factions and to check spreading chaos... Brought situation under control and was named political commissar of provincial military command... In March, 1968, became chairman of provincial Revolutionary Committee and still holds position... In January, 1971, named first secretary of provincial party committee... Wields considerable power as provincial military command's commissar, leader of party and government apparatus, and as a member of national party's Central Committee... Chekiang, with population of 31 million, was scene of intense power struggle during Cultural Revolution... Peking authorities took special interest in purge of top provincial officials because Hangchow was favorite resort area of Chairman MaoTsetung.

title: Hanoi Says Nixon Strives To Split Communist Camp
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Feb. 26 (UPI)A North Vietnamese broadcast said today that President Nixon was trying to split the Communist camp by negotiating with Peking and Moscow. It. said the result could be oppression of small nations.

title: Environmental Groups Opposing Plans on Jersey Meadowlands
description: HACKENSACK, N. J., Feb. 26 Enviromental groups opposed to plans to build a new city in the Hackensack Meadowlands dominated two nights of public hearings on the project's master plan, but their predictions of serious environmental consequences have failed to impress Meadowlands planners.

title: Jersey Group Schedules Program for Dog Owners
description: A program designed to help novice owners of purebred dogs who are interested in showing or obedience for their pets will be held on Thursday at 8:30 P.M., by the Watchung Mountain Poodle Club. It is directed for all breeds, not just poodles, and it will take place at the First New Jersey Bank, 1930 Morris Avenue, at Pooter Avenue, Union, N. J.

title: Books About jersey
description: The trail of the onetime master makers of handblown glass is doggedly and persistently followed by Adeline Pepper in this work, which also pursues the continuing effects of their historical role into the present.

title: If You Ain't Got Religion, You Ain't Got a Chance
description: NOW that Jesus Christ Superstar is a hot ticket on Broadwayjudging by the reviews is in critical Purgatory and financial Heavenyou can he sure other producers will jump on the religion bandwagon.

title: Music
description: ANICE lady in Washington has been thoughtful enough to send me the catalogue of the exhibition named Music Machines  American Style, which is being held at the National Museum of History and Technology. This handsome catalogue has been giving me a wallow in nostalgia. The first music anybody of my generation was likely to have heard came from a Victor crankup machine, through which emerged the voices of Caruso, Melba, Plancon and the other vocal heroes of the day. Yes, there was a time when you had to crank a phonograph to make it play. There was a time when records revolved at 78 revolutions per minute. There was a time when records would break if you dropped. them. But there also was a time when music on records was of supreme importance those, times when there was no radio to speak of, when the concert life was less full, and moving pictures were still largely onereelers. How we listened to those records, on !those archaic machines!

title: Pioneer 10 Poised for Jupiter TakeOff
description: CAPE KENNEDY, Ha., Feb. 26The first spacecraft designed to explore the environs of Jupiter, investigate the fringes of the solar system and then streak out into interstellar space was reported to be ready to embark tomorrow night on its farreaching voyage.

title: Israelis Attack Guerrillas In Lebanon for Second Day
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Feb. 26Israeli planes and artillery attacked Palestinian commando positions in southern Lebanon today for the second day.

title: Antiwar Veterans Plan Protest at G.O.P. Parley
description: TULSA, Okla., Feb. 26The Vietnam Veterans Against the War has drafted plans for massive demonstrations during the Republican convention in August at San Diego.

title: The World
description: OTTAWAMust we always be in debt to the Americans to satisfy Connally? In one form or another, this was a question put repeatedly to the 23 United States Senators and Representatives who visited here last weekend for a conference with Canadian legislators.

title: Will Summit Meeting Be Next for Thomas?
description: What, if anything, will Pete Rozelle do about Duane Thomas?

title: Argentina's Inflation MerryGoRound
description: BUENOS AIRES  Because nations, unlike people who lend them money, rarely go bankrupt, Argentina will undoubtedly survive its present unusually grave economic crisis. Whether its leaders, political institutions and economic system survive the crisis is debatable.

title: Letter to the Editor 8  No Title
description: To THE EDITOR:After extensive legal study and research, we have concluded that the repeal of the corroboration requirement would be but the first step: the crime of rape itself should be entirely redefined. The incorporation of sexual offenses into the assault statute of the Penal Code would place the crime of rape in its proper perspective.

title: Books: Using Statistics;
description: THE NUMBERS GAME. By Robers S. Reichard. 366 pages. McGrawHill Book Company.

title: Albert National Park: Where Pygmies And the Wild Elephants Play
description: AFTER eight trips to Africa, I think the most beautiful spot on that continent is the Albert National Park (Parc Nationale des Virunga), a 190milelong, 2,500,000acre tract of wilderness that sits at the eastern edge of Zaire, formerly Belgian Congo. It is virtually untouched by tourists, yet its attractions include chain of volcanoesthe Mufumbiro; great rivers and lakes, and vast grassy plains covered with animals. Arrangements for a sevenday trip to the park from Kinshasa, Zaire, can be made through A.M.I., Avenue des Aviateurs, Kinshasa, Zaire, B.P. 7597. An allinclusive trip costs about $600 for one person, $900 for two.

title: Rutgers Beats Bucknell
description: NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Feb. 126Rutgers outscored Buck184, during a sevenminute stretch early in the second half tonight and recorded a 9166 victory.

title: Cornell Six Routs Princeton
description: PRINCETON, N. J., Feb. 26 Larry Fullan, a senior center, scored four goals to pace Cornell to a 121 rout of Princeton in Ivy League hockey tonight. Cornell leads the league with a wonlost record of 92. Princeton is 19.

title: AUTO CLUB URGING VETO ON TOLL RISE
description: CAMDEN  The decision by the Delaware River Port Authority to raise tolls on the Walt Whitman and Benjamin Franklin Bridges to 60 cents effective April 1 is being challenged by the New Jersey A.A.A. Auto Club.

title: Photography
description: NATIONWIDE election year photo contest called Focus on Politics 72 is being jointly sponsored by Newsweek magazine and Konica Camera Corporation, division of Berkey Photo, Inc. Open to any amateur or professional photographer, the contest is intended to capture the mood and spirit of the election year and will continue until Nov. 25. Entries should picture people, places or events related to the eletciort process voters, candidates or issues.

title: Letters
description: To THE EDITOR:I was very moved by the article, Doctor, Do We Have A Choice? The choice being to let a sick mongoloid baby die or have it undergo surgery only to survive and be a helpless human being, who will be barely able to write his own name ever. If this child is institutionalized, he will be a financial and emotional burden to his parents.

title: Study Scores U.S. Efforts On Deficient Meat Imports
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 (UPI)Imported meat products continue to come into the United States even though they have failed to meet Agriculture Department health requirements, a Government Accounting Office study shows.

title: Purdue Wins, 7069
description: LAFAYETTE, Ind., Feb. 26 (AP) A threepoint play by Bob Ford in the final minute today gave Purdue a 7069 victory over Indiana in a Big Ten basketball game.

title: The Nation
description: TRENTON  New Jersey taxpayers did not need prestigious committee appointed by Gov. William T. Cahill to remind them that those who could afford it the least were getting soaked the most by the highest, most lopsided local property taxes in the country.

title: Movie Mailbag
description: To THE EDITOR:

title: FORDHAM QUINTET WINS 16TH, 10678
description: Fordham kept its hopes for a bid to the National Invitation Tournament alive with a 10678 basketball trouncing of Georgetown at the Rose Hill gym yesterday.

title: Humphrey Seeks to Get Close to South
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 Most political observers believe it is extremely unlikely that Hubert H. Humphrey will ever quite make it as a good old boy in the rural South, but he did his best this week in smalltown, inland Florida.

title: FOREIGN AFFAIRS
description: SAIGON, South VietnamPresident Nixon's policy of Vietnamizing the war here must inescapably lead to Vietnamizing the peaceunless some formula for settlement is found before them

title: Job Drive Begun For Addicts Using Methadone Cure
description: NEW HYDE PARK, L. T. Feb. 26Federal, state and local officials have been asked to help eliminate job discrimination against narcotics addicts now on methadone maintenance programs.

title: Stamps
description: POSTMASTER GENERAL E. T. Klassen has announced three additions to the 1972 stampissuing program, as well as projections for two 1973 issues.

title: Military School Picks Chief
description: ROSWELL, N. M., Feb. 26Col. C. Robert Kemble, 46 years old, director of the American studies program at the United States Military Academy and former executive assistant to the director of operations of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, has been named the new president of the New Mexico Military Institute here.

title: Fire Perils Mexican Tower
description: MEXICO CITY, Feb. 26 (Reuters)A woman died and 13 people were injured today in a fire that destroyed a hotel next to Mexico's highest buildinA, the 40 story Latin American Tower, the police reported.

title: AROUND THE
description: SOCIETY TALK

title: Article 2  No Title
description: THERE is a story told of a visit Henry Miller made in the thirties to England, a story which Jean Genet greatly enjoyed. A bluff goodhearted womanizing fourletterword AngloSaxon, Miller comes off the ferry at Dover: Wearing no tie of course, baggy corduroy pants probably, a grin as innocent as Middle America; he carries a cheap cardboard suitcase and no money.

title: Calendars: How the Ancients Recorded Time
description: And the days of eternity, who shall number? The height of the heaven, and the breadth of the earth, and the deep, and wisdom, who shall search them out?

title: Mrs. Rollinson Married Here
description: Mrs. Lucie Mackey Rollinson, widow of Reginald H. Rollinson, was married here yesterday to Hugh J. Grant, whose father, the late Hugh J. Grant, was Mayor of New York from 1889 to 1892. The Rev. Edwin Brooks performed the ceremony and celebrated the nuptial mass in the Roman Catholic Church of St. Ignatius Loyola.

title: A.D.A. Rejects a Move To Rate Out Humphrey
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 (UPI)The national board of Americans for Democratic Action narrowly rejected today a move to list Senator Hubert H. Humphrey, one of the group's founders, as an unacceptable Presidential candidate.

title: Weird but brilliant light on the way we live now
description: In 1952, writing in praise of David Riesman's The Lonely Crowd, Lionel Trilling remarked that contemporary social science was developing an increasingly acute and subtle sense of social actuality which contemporary literature sadly lacked. Indeed, sociology seemed to be in the process of taking over from literature one of literature's most characteristic functions, the investigation and criticism of morals and manners. Twenty years later, this process has gone farther than anyone could foresee. Where our parents and grandparents once turned to novelists, we find ourselves more and more apt to turn toward sociologists, anthropologists, psychologists, for light on the way we live now.

title: NETSLOSE, 121119, ON SHOT AT FINISH
description: HAMPTON. Va., Feb. 26Charlie Scott's 20foot jumper at the buzzer gave the Virginia Squires a 121119 victory over the New York Nets in an American Basketball Association game tonight.

title: Muskie Says He and Wife Have $153,141 Net Worth
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 (AP) Senator Edmund S. Muskie released today a financial statement showing that he and his wife had a net worth of $153,141.

title: A Handicapper's Dream
description: The Campbell honors the memory of the late racing secretary and handicapper for The Jockey Club and New York tracks. Campbell is best known as the architect of American racing's only threehorse deadheat for first in the stakes race. It occurred in the 1944 Carter handicap at the old Aqueduct, when Campbell's astute weight assignments brought Bossuet, Brownie and Wait A Bit to the finish line exactly even.

title: Witnesses Disagree in Ulster Inquiry
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Feb. 24Conflicting testimony marked the opening week of the official inquiry into the killing of 13 Roman Catholics in Londonderry on Jan. 30. Some journalists and priests testifies that unarmed civilians were shot down and that paratroopers opened fire needlessly. Others said that gunmen were seen aiming at troops in the Bogside area during the civilrights demonstration.

title: JOHN S. WILSON'S Music
description: PRINCETONBecause Stuart Berger, a physicist who is president of the Princeton Folk Music,. Society, admits that he can only play along on guitar and that he does not sing at all because I never developed my vocal chords, he is viewed by some members as an ideal representative of the group.

title: Blighted voyage to Utopia Natives Of My Person By George Lamming. 345 pp. New York: Holt, Rinehart and Winston. $7.95.
description: George Lamming is not so much a novelist as a chronicler of secret journeys to the innermost regions of the West Indian psyche. In order to ensure that he is unimpeded by the traditional novelistic conventions, he brings a private vision to bear on time and space, uniting them into an inseparable entity and islanding this entity in his own fertile imagination.

title: HotShooting Detroit Pins First Loss on Marquette Team, 70 to 49
description: DETROIT, Feb. 26 (AP)A hotshooting University of Detroit basketball team overwhelmed secondranked Marquette today, 7049.

title: Seaplane Flying Still Hangs On Along the Overpeck
description: LITTLE FERRY  The Hackensack River here remains the center of seaplane activity in the metropolitan area, but that distinction appears to be diminishing every year as aquatic aviation dwindles.

title: Home Improvement
description: THE installation of walltowall carpeting used to he a project that was definitely not one for the average doityourselferand for some types of carpeting this is still predominantly true. Many types require a separate backing or underlayment. In addition, the carpeting must be carefully stretched and tacked down, with seams sewed or joined by use of other specialized techniques and materials.

title: MRS. DENE LAIB ULIN
description: Mrs. Dene Laib Ulin, an art consultant and gallery operator, died Friday at Lenox Hill Hospital after a short illness. She was 41 years old and lived at 27 East 65th Street, where her gallery is situated.

title: KRETCHMER IRKS PACKAGING PARLEY
description: Jerome Kretchmer, the city's Environmental Protection Administrator, told an occasionally hostile packaging industry conference yesterday that he has received no cooperation from bottlers, canners and packers, who he said have added an extraordinary mess to the solidwaste problem.

title: Hungarian Delegates Home
description: BUDAPEST, Feb. 26 (AP)A Hungarian delegation headed by the Communist party chief, Janos Kadar, returned to Budapest today after a twoday visit to Rumania, where a 20year friendship treaty was signed.

title: AIRBAG TEST IS SET IN 1,000 G.M. AUTOS
description: CHICAGO, Feb. 26The General Motors Corporation is going to put air safety bags on 1,000 of its 1973 model Chevrolet Impala automobiles to test the system, the company chairman, Richard C. Gerstenberg, says.

title: Perils of a lady wrestler
description: Rosa Rubinsky meets Paul Partch in a 42d Street movie theater. He puts his hand on her leg, and she hits him. Paul is an art critic, although not a very successful one; the Warhols and Lichtensteins hang on other walls. He is obsessed by big women, needs to be handled roughly by the last in line, the funky fat, the tomboy. Rosa is a tomboy on the face of it, a primitive like Henri Rousseau. It's hard to say how old she is, 20 maybe, or 21, and she never explains where she comes from.

title: The Nation
description: COCOA BEACH, Fla.  The big question to be answered in the Florida primary is no longer what man the people of Florida would prefer as President of the United States. The big question is busing.

title: PACIFIC ISLANDERS FIGHT REEF PLAN
description: CANBERRA, Australia, Feb. 26Australia and New Zealand have joined forces with five South Pacific island states to halt the plans of an American syndicate to create a new independent minination, free of taxes and government controls, by constructing a manmade island on an officially unclaimed coral reef in shallow waters between Tonga and Fiji.

title: WASHINGTON REPORT
description: WASHINGTON  The nation, certainly the Congress, is being swamped with figures and analyses of the unemployment problem. They are enough to numb the mind. The Congressional Joint Economic Committee so far this month alone has had analyses from four Cabinetlevel officers of the Government, member of the Federal Reserve Board and seven private economists.

title: Princeton Alumni Bestow Wilson Award on Nader
description: PRINCETON, N. J., Feb. 26Ralph Nader, consumer advocate and founder of the Center for the Study of Responsive Law, was honored today by Princeton University with the Woodrow Wilson Award, one of the highest general distinctions the school can confer upon an alumnus.

title: The Last Word
description: Dear Frank Elange:

title: SOVIET PLANS TO GIVE SYRIA MORE WEAPONS
description: DAMASCUS, Syria, Feb. 26 (UPI)The Soviet Union has agreed to supply Syria with more defensive weapons m view of the gravity of the Middle Eastern situation, a SovietSyrian communique said today.

title: Busy as a Bogdanovich
description: WHAT's up with Peter Bogdanovich, the redhot director of The Last Picture Show"? What's Up, Doc?", for one thing. That's the screwball comedy with Barbra Streisand and Ryan O'Neal which will he the Easter attraction at Radio City Music Hall.

title: Tinee Town Talkbac, Australian Terrier, Named Best at Providence Show
description: LINCOLN, R. I., Feb. 26In horserace phraseology, a long shot came through at the Lincoln Downs race track today at the 62d fixture of the Providence Kennel Club.

title: Manhattan Bows 7877
description: MORGANTOWN, W. Va., Feb. 26Wil Robinson hit a 15foot jump shot from the side with less than a second to go to enable West Virginia to defeat Manhattan, 7877, before a crowd of 5,109 today.

title: Political Refugee From !rag Is Shot by Gunmen in Cairo
description: CAIRO, Feb. 26  An Iraqi political refugee, Erfan Khader Wagdi, was wounded here today by three gunmen in the latest of a series of attacks on opponents of Iraq's president, Ahmed Hassan alkakr.

title: Art: Former AvantGarde Gallery Remembered in Hofstra Show
description: HEMPSTEAD, L. I.  Art Galleries come and go, but very few leave behind an image big or important enough to stir the memory. But the Emily Lowe Gallery of Hofstra University here is now paying tribute to one gallery worth remembering with its commemorative exhibition, appropriately named The Green Gallery Revisited.

title: Land Swap With Builder Enlarges Sussex State Park
description: MONTAGUELand swapping is still practiced in New Jersey in these days of sales and leasebacks and other sophisticated ways of dealing in property. Usually, the land swaps are engineered between builders and municipalities, with the builder initiating the action to simplify or enhance a construction operation.

title: The Nation
description: At 6 A.M. last June 7, the drawbridges linking Manhattan with the outside world swung open  and stayed that way for two days, causing one of the worst traffic snafus in local history. The cause: a job action staged by 318 bridge tenders, members 013f the City Employes Union, to put pressure on commuters to put pressure on legislators to act on bill granting pension improvements to 120,000 city workers.

title: Pacers Down Chaparrals
description: DALLAS, Feb., 26 (AP)Fred Lewis scored eight points in a fiveminute overtime period tonight that carried the Indiana Pacers to a 115113 victory over the Dallas Chaparrals.

title: Toronto: Unexotic But Nice
description: TORONTO  Western Canadians find this city frantic and unfriendly; Montrealers call it colorless, but thousands of Americans who have settled here think it is too good to be true. How to describe it? Toronto is Toronto  a distinctive, modern North American city influenced by British traditions and American technology, a safe, clean, cosmopolitan city. Exotic it's not. Delightful it is.

title: Bring Me a Unicorn
description: Let her speak for herself, says Anne Morrow Lindbergh in her modest introduction to a remarkable gathering together of her early diaries and letters.. Covering six years from 1922 to 1928, this is the first volume of a personal record, to be continued through 1947 of one of the great stories of the 20th century. The account in Anne Morrow's own words begins when she was 16 with a letter to tell Grandma Cutter that we children are having a fine time traveling with Mother and Daddy in Scotland, and ends in 1928 with letter to Corliss Lamont: Apparently I am going to many Charles Lindbergh.

title: Zumwalt Says Warships Won't Quit Vietnam Soon
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Feb. 26 (Reuters)The United States Chief of Naval Operations, Adm. Elmo N. Zumwalt Jr. said today that American warships would stay in the Gulf of Tonkin as long as it was necessary to protect United States troops in South Vietnam.

title: WATER SUPPLIES AT NORMAL LEVEL
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 Water supplies in New York and most of the Northeast are within a normal range for this time of year despite a relatively open winter in some sections, the Geological Survey has reported.

title: Indians Voice Alarm on Shrinking Resources
Police Holding 4 for Questioning In Wounding of Ulster Official
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Feb. 26Four men were questioned by the police today in connection with the shooting yesterday of John Taylor, Northern Ireland's Minister of State for Home Affairs, by Irish Republican Army gunmen.

title: FOOD TALK
description: Four and twenty blackbirds baked in a pie, the nursery rhyme reads, but the Four n 20 Pie Shop in Hollis, Queens, prefers to put fruits, custard, cream and cheese fillings into its assortment of two dozen pies.

title: Lady With a Famous Name Takes a Fling at Modeling
description: Why was Lady Charles SpencerChurchill, the slender 24yearold second wife of the 32yearold second son of the 10th Duke of Marlborough, prancing around the St. RegisSheraton last week wearing first one, then another, of 15 designer creations made from duPont's synthetic fabric known as Qiana?

title: Rep. Edwards Calls for Curb On Use of Arrest Records
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 (UPI) Representative Don Edwards, California Democrat, who once served briefly as an agent of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, has called for a halt to the release of the arrest records of persons never convicted of a crime.

title: Guests Return to Commodore; O'Hagan Recovering in Hospital
description: Hundreds of guests evacuated from the Commodore Hotel during a smoky fire Friday night returned to their rooms yesterday as fire investigators sifted rubble in search for the cause of the blaze, which burned out basement store and injured dozen civilians and 29 firemen, including Fire Chief John T. O'Hagan.

title: MRS. VLADIMIR HURBAN
description: Mrs. Olga Boor Hurban, widow of Vladimir Hurban, former Czechoslovak Ambassador to the United States, died Friday in St. Luke's Hospital. She was 74 years old and lived at 521 West 112th Street.

title: POLICE SUIT ACCUSES BRIDGEPORT OF BIAS
description: BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Feb. 26 A group of black and Puerto Rican policemen and special Housing Authority guards have begun a classaction suit against the Bridgeport Civil Service Commission, seeking to force the city to recruit and promote a greater number of minoritygroup members, possibly at the expense of white policemen.

title: Pitching Is Only Weakness on Powerful Pirate Ship
description: BRADENTON, Fla., Feb. 26  Willie Stargell and Gene Alley had knee operations, Bruce Kison's arm is tired, Dock Ellis may or may not have a bad elbow, shortstop is a question and Roberto Clemente has a queasy stomach.

title: Planned Parenthood Elects New Chairman
description: The board of directors of Planned Parenthood of New York City has elected Victor A. Kovner as its chairman and chief executive.

title: The Nation
description: Utica took the brass ring, but the whole state was in the running for the unemployment sweepstakes. The State Department of Labor reported last week that the number of persons out of work in January reached 6.5 per centthe highest in nine years. Compared to the figures for a year ago, the January statistics showed an increase of 60,000 in the jobless ranks and a decrease of 135,000 in the total number of jobs available. Unemployment in the Utica area last month was close to 10 per cent.

title: Atlanta Bishop Consecrated
description: ATLANTA, Feb. 26 (AP)The Right Rev. Bennett J. Sims was consecrated today as sixth Bishop of the Episcopal Diocese of Atlanta. Bishop Sims was elected to the post last Nov. 2 and succeeds the retiring Bishop, the Right Rev, Randolph R. Claiborne Jr., who has been at the helm of the diocese for more than 19 years.

title: FRANCE WILL GIVE NEWLYWEDS BOOKS
description: PARIS, Feb. 26  Starting April 29 the 350,000 couples who are expected to marry in France from then to the end of the year will receive the beginnings of a home library, courtesy of the Ministry of Education.

title: Mich. State Wrestlers Take 7th Big Ten Title in Row
description: BLOOMINGTON, Ind. Feb. 26 (UPI)Michigan State picked up five individual championships today en route to its seventh straigth Big Ten wrestling title.

title: 5Liter Auto Series Looms as Saver
description: The Sports Car Club of America may have a saver this year in the LAM. Continental 5000 Championship to offset the relatively dim prospects of its other professional series. Entries arriving or already in hand from England, Australia, New Zealand, Canada and the United States suggest the ninerace program for those raucous 5liter, openwheel racers will be much more competitive than the other S.C.C.A. shows. Payouts are substantial, ranging up to $60,000 for a couple of events, and it is clear that many drivers will have a reasonable chance at the top prizesmore so than in, say, the CanAm. The opening race runs May 7 at Monterey, Calif.

title: State Jaycees Accused of Discriminating Against Women, but the Newark Unit Plans Suit to Admit Them

title: BOBBY DARIN BACK IN SONG PROGRAM
description: Bobby Darin returned to one of his old haunts  the Coptcabana  Thursday night. I'm not quite sure whether he pre. fers, at this point in time, to be called Bob or Bobby, ince his name, like his music, has gone through a chameleonlike sequence of changes in the decade or so that he has been a major entertainment figure.

title: The Nation
description: As it happens, notwithstanding all the slogans, speed does not often killit simply maims the mind. Now, after more than a decade of evergrowing amphetamine abuse, the Federal Goveinment is moving to curb the drug at its source: the American pharmaceutical industry.

title: Abortions on L.I.A Progress Report
description: Fifteen minutes after her abortion at a clinic in Hempstead, L. I., a 16yearold girl from New York City explained why she had chosen the clinic for the procedure instead of a hospital.

title: Letters
description: To THE EDITOR:I am disturbed by the simplistic approach Dr. Shaw takes concerning the placing of mongoloids in an Institution or rearing them at home. He states that successoriented parents (by which he seems to imply professional educated parents) are likely to institutionalize their mentally deficient offspring while parents with lesser expectations (nonprofessionals with lesser education is implied) are more likely to welcome it into their homes.

title: Reno Editor Is Promoted
description: RENO, Feb. 26 (AP)Warren Lerude, 34 yearsold, has been promoted from managing editor of The Reno Evening Gazette to executive editor of The ?? and its sister Reno newspaper, The Nevada State Journal. Both papers are members of the Speidel group. Richard J. Schuster, publisher of The Gazette and The Journal, announced the promotion Wednesday.

title: Maritime Complex to Be Built: At Shipyard in Galveston, Tex.
description: GALVESTON, Tex., Feb. 26 (AP)  The creation of a maritime complex that will include the world's largest floating dry dock and a Federal research center has been announced here by Government and industrial officials.

title: El Cordobes Is Retiring; Fought Bulls 12 Years
description: MADRID, Feb. 26 (UPI)The bullfighter Manuel Benitez, known as El Cordobes, a once illiterate peasant who became the world's highest paid athlete, announced his retirement today.

title: LOUISIANA STATE UPSETS KENTUCKY
description: BATON ROUGE, La. Feb. 26 (AP)Louisiana State, which upset Tennessee earlier in the Southeastern Conference basketball race, surprised the leagueleader, Kentucky, 8871, today.

title: Penn Title Threat in I.C.4A Track
description: Villanova's track team, dominant in the Intercollegiate A.A.A.A. for 15 years, faces formidable challenge from Penn in the 51st annual indoor championships this weekend in Princeton's Jadwin Gymnasium. A record field of 70 colleges will participate.

title: Cry Coyote
description: At the behest of Western ranchers, the Federal Government has long engaged in the cruel, senseless and wholly unnecessary destruction of wild animals. The chief victims have been coyotes because sheep raisers blame them for the loss of lambs. But since lambs are naturally fragile animals and since coyotes primarily feed upon jack rabbits, rodents and carrion, the suspicion has long existed that many sheepmen cry coyote mainly establish a basis for claiming tax losses.

title: Safety Panel Says 114,000 Died in U.S. Accidents in 71
description: CHICAGO, Feb. 26 (UPI)Accidents cost the United States 114,000 lives and about $27.711illion, the National Safety Council said yesterday.

title: L.I.U. Five Wins, 7864
description: Harvey Smith and Fred Gibson scored 23 points each last night to lead Long Island University to a 7864 victory over St. Francis College of New York at the winner's court in Brooklyn.

title: Recordings
description: FOR works that have been turned into reliquary objects by a generation of academicians and analyzed with a holy zeal that approaches the Jesuitical, the string quartets of Schoenberg have not been very well represented on records. Of the complete sets that have passed through one's own hands, the best choice now might be the Juilhard Quartet's old mono versions on Columbia. The Kohon Quartet, more recently, has offered dry and wiry stereo performances that succeed in pointing up details clouded over in the older recordings. Now, as part of a fivedisk box entitled String Quartets of the New Viennese School, the Schoenbergs appear in full, even unto the String Quartet in D of 1897, a rather genial early work (DGG 2720029). The LaSalle Quartet, somewhat distantly but beautifully recorded, plays with unfailing grace and elegance throughout the album, which also includes the quartets of Webern and Berg, and omits only the former's attractive Slow Movement (1905), recently introduced to records on Philips by the Quartetto Italiano.

title: India; Now and Through Time. By Catherine Atwater Galbraith and Rama Mehta. Illustrated. 148 pp. New York: Dodd, Mead & Co. $4.95. (Ages 10 to 14); The First Book of India; By Jean Bothwell. Illustrated. 81 pp. New York: Franklin Watts. $3.75.; Children Of India; By Sumana Chandavarkar. Photographs by Stella Snead. 128 pp. New York: Lothrop, Lee & Shepard. $4.50 (Ages 9 to 12)
description: There are a number of conventional ways to describe India: She is an undisciplined and impoverished rural society hopelessly mired in its own backwardness, a progressive state valiantly bent on modernization in a democratic context; a chaos of clashing religious and linguistic groups, or an otherworldly arena for faddists of the occult. Taken separately or together, such generalizations don't begin to suggest the real complexity, difficulty and romance of the country, or its power to clobber and beguile the senses. What they do is hold it at a safe distance.

title: Nuptials for Janet C. Waterhouse
description: SUMMIT, N. J., Feb. 26Miss Janet Christine Waterhouse was married here at home today to Ronald Stephen Reich, a lawyer with Dewey, Ballantine, Bushby, Palmer & Wood in New York.

title: Now Kubrick Fights Back
description: AN alert liberal, says Fred M. Hechinger, writing about my film A Clockwork Orange, should recognize the voice of fascism. They don't conic any more alert than Fred M. Hechinger. A movie critic, whose job is to analyze the actual content of a film, rather than secondhand interviews, might have fallen down badly on sounding the Liberal Alert which an educationist like Mr. Hechinger confidently set jangling in so many resonant lines of alarmed prose.

title: Navy Beats Army in Four Sports; 9Year Basketball Jinx Is Ended

title: Smaller Bottle Barred

This is a price increase of 18 per cent, the Price Commission said yesterday, not a 3.73 per cent increase as contended by the company, Dad's Cliquot Club Bottling Company, Inc, and its parent, the Chromalloy American Corporation.

title: The Life of Benjamin Banneker By Silvio A. Bedini. Illustrated. 434 pp. New York: Charles Scribner's Sons. $14.95.
description: Assuredly the remarkable Benjamin Banneker is among the most fascinating of American scientists. A freeborn black tobacco farmer who lived all his life (from 1731 to 1806) in an isolated community near Baltimore, he attained a reputation in his latter years as a selftaught mathematician and astronomer who calculated the ephemerides for a series of popular almanacs in the 1790's. Although he only left his rural neighborhood oncein 1791, to perform the astronomical work for the survey of the District of Columbiahe was alert to the intellectual currents of his time, not only in his specialty but also in race relations.

title: New &Novel
description: An enigmatic title, an abstract jacket and a foreword by Greta Garbo (!) are handsome camouflage for a conventional historical novel, idealizing the life of Helena Modjeska. Modjeska (18401909) was the Polish peer of Bernhardt and Duse; she toured the United States with Edwin Booth and Otis Skinner and eventually settled down in California, where her husband grew oranges. Miss Garbo also lays claim to having a thing about oranges. (Ever since childhood I have been dreaming aboutoranges!) Putting aside the citrus symbolism for whatever it may be worth, we follow the career of Greta Galingala, the author's name for his heroine.

title: The World

One of the country's most serious industrial crises in years neared an end last week as 280,000 coal miners who had been on strike for seven weeks voted 96 per cent in favor of accepting a new pay scale. The settlement would give them raises of up to $15 on previous wages that ranged from $47 to $78 a week.

title: Tennessee Singer Takes $20,000 Bye Bye Byrd Pace at Roosevelt Raceway
CONTROVERSIAL PROFESSOR FRANKLIN
description: To THE EDITOR:Kenneth Lamott's article about Stanford University's proposed dismissal of Professor Franklin (In the Matter of H. Bruce Franklin, Jan. 23) ended with the suggestion that he probably is needed on the Stanford faculty to play a gadfly role. Such a conclusion is not an unusual response from civil libertarians to violence or appeals for violence undertaken for praiseworthy motives. (Reinhold Niebuhr used to point out that we mean well and do ill and justify our illdoing by our wellmeaning.) Civil libertarians tend increasingly to subsume a variety of socially disruptive acts under the category of symbolic speech and to argue that they deserve the protection of the free speech and assembly guarantees of the First Amendment. Thus Prof. Thomas I. Emerson of the Yale Law School writes of the right to protest and goes so far as to deny the utility of distinguishing among pure speech, speech plus, and nonspeech as expressions of protest.

title: The HellFire Club: Visions of Debauchery Danced in Their Heads
description: WEST WYCOMBE, England West Wycombe House is a Palladianstyle mansion standing above a swanshaped lake in splendid park dotted with Greek and Roman temples in this Buckinghamshire village about 30 miles west of London. Now completely restored and open to the public, the house looks just as It did when Benjamin Franklin stayed in it prior to the American Revolution. Franklin, incidentally, praised not only the house but the host, who, he said, having kept the best company in the world, is himself the best existing.

title: Foreman Dancers Perform 2 Works On Pair of Levels
description: There is a serious discontinuIty between the horrid flow of events portrayed in the news media and our ordinary lives. Surely the two must have a connection, but it seems hard to relate the seemingly innocuous activities of one to the other. It is the juxtaposition of the two that fascinates Laura Foreman and formed the basis for her Friday evening program at the American Theater Lab.

title: Club of Rome a Worldwide Organization
description: In April, 1968, a group of scientists and intellectuals, alarmed at what they considered ominous trends in the world, met in one of the most venerable scientific ?? the Accademia Nazionale dei Lincei in Rome, or National Academy of Linxes.

title: New &Novel
description: Sam Peeples is a smalltown (Kanecka, Kan.) slumlord, with a collection of quirks that promise well for slapstick: his orotund diction and gaudy misanthropy give him a W. C. Fieldsian cast as he goes about his rounds, exploiting tenants and mistreating neighbors. Unfortunately, this highbinder's involvements are not on a level with his idiosyncrasies.

title: The Nation
description: About two years ago, Svetlana Alliluyeva, the daughter of Josef Stalin, was invited to visit Taliesin West, home of the architectural firm and academy founded by Frank Lloyd Wright. The invitation came from Mr. Wright's daughter, lovanna, after she lead Svetlana's book about her first year in America.

title: Mankind Warned of Perils in Growth
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Feb. 26A major computer study of world trends has concluded, as many have feared, that mankind probably faces an uncontrollable and disastrous collapse of its society within 100 years unless it moves speedily to establish a global equilibrium in which growth of population and industrial output are halted.

title: The Nation
description: PALO ALTO, Calif.Smiling, clenched fist raised, a cry of Power to the people on her lips, Angela Y. Davis walked out of the North County Jail here last Wednesday after 16 months behind bars.

title: U.S. BUSINESS ROUNDUP
description: The late Shirley Jackson's short story, The Lottery, added a chilling dimension to an ancient rite that currently is receiving feverish attention from financially pressed state and local administrations and legislators.

title: Bustling Shanghai: China's Energy Center
description: HONG KONG, Feb. 25China's biggest city, Shanghai, the last stop on President Nixon's China trip, is the economic dynamo and political power source for the country.

title: Felicity I. Forbes, Wellesley 71, Future Bride of John T. Barber
description: SOUTH DARTMOUTH, Mass., Feb. 26Mr. and Mrs. Alexander Cochrane Forbes have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Felicity Irene Forbes, to John Tippett Barber, son of Mr. and Mrs. George Fox Barber of Sewickley, Pa.

title: Adviser to Price Panel Faces Philadelphia Forgery Charge
description: PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 26An investigation ordered by Mayor Frank L. Rizzo has resulted in the arrest on conspiracy and forgery charges of Mrs. Rose Wylie, recently appointed by President Nixon to the Rent Advisory Board of the Price Commission.

title: A Maverick was his menu
description: The career of Harry Crews has followed an odd progression. A writer of most impressive talents, he has banged out five novels in as many years. Each has been funnier, more compact and more inventive than the one before it. Yet his novels have also become more sentimental and less substantial. The more Crews writes, it seems, the more he appears content to fritter away good ideas in easy soapopera resolutions.

title: Mary Duncan Is Future Bride
description: BINGHAMTON, N. Y., Feb. 26Mr. and Mrs. Thomas F. Duncan have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Mary Duncan, to Peter E. Millspaugh of Washington, son of Mr. and Mrs. Clifford T. Millspaugh. Both families are from Binghamton.

title: MAN IN BUSINESS
description: In American business, where every man is expected to be the son of his own deeds, the executive who attains rank by marrying the boss's daughter generally is not to be envied. If he wants to impress his fellows, he must often work about twice as hard as the man who came up without marital aid.

title: Florida County Freezes Zoning To Halt HelterSkelter Growth
description: WEST PALM BEACH, Fla., Feb. 26Fearing helterskelter development otherwise, the Palm Beach County Commission yesterday enacted a oneyear moratorium on rezoning.

title: Colonels Top Pros, 123100
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky., Feb. 26 (AP)Artis Gilmore scored 32 points tonight as the Kentucky Colonels snapped a twogame losing streak with a 123100 victory over the Memphis Pros.

title: TV Networks Schedule Today's China Coverage
description: The major television networks have given the following schedule for today's coverage of President Nixon's China visit:

title: ARKANSAS BLACKS PROTEST MERGER
description: LITTLE ROCK. Ark., Feb. 26The only statesupported black college in Arkansas is to become a branch of the University of Arkansas on July 1, and that has led to a torrent of protests from black leaders and sporadic violence.

title: Stamps
description: MAN in motion Is the theme behind four stamps designed by Lance Wyman of New York for the United States postal commemoration of the 1972 Olympic Games (the Winter Games that have just been completed at Sapporo, Japan, and the Summer Games, in Munich, GerMay, Aug. 26Sept. 10).

title: Fromm's theory of aggression
description: Some anthropologists claim that man is by nature a killer they propose that hominid ancestors of man, the Australopithecinae living almost two million years ago in Africa, had become a predatory, carnivorous species and that man inherited his aggression from them. Sherwood L. Washburn, the eminent investigator of human evolution, dissents from this thesis; he assigns the role of a prehistorical Adam, responsible for man's fall, to early man himself, to man the hunter. Hunting behavior, according to Washburn is characterized by pleasure in killing and cruelty; since man for almost all his history was a hunter Washburn concludes that destructiveness and cruelty were built into man's basic equipment as a result of the evolutionary process of selection during roughly a million years of his existence.

title: Nixon and Chou Stroll and Go Boating in Hangchow
description: HANGCHOW, China, Feb. 26 (UPI)President Nixon and Premier Chou Enlai strolled through picturesque gardens of cameiias, pansies and magnolias today then went boating on West Lake, one of China's leading scenic attractions.

title: Recordings
description: FORTY THOUSAND music students each year graduate from America's schools. Too bad for them, admittedly, but fortunate for the general listener, we never hear from most of them. Improved pedagogy in the piano field, particularly, and I am thinking of Irwin Freundlich, Adele Marcus, Olga Barabini and the like, enables reasonably good, young American pianists to play remarkably better, faster, and more accurately than their predecessors of a generation ago. But the price tag on competence and slickness, it seems to me, fails to take into account the diminuendo in musical values, and value itself, that has occurred visibly in concerts and audibly on discs. If you look at artistic positives, instead of economic negatives, the present day depression in the record business has one good thing about itonly the fittest to survive.

title: Bridgeton, Once a Big Polluter, Finds It Pays to Recycle Sludge
description: BRIDGETON  While attending a Rotary Club meeting here last August, Albert A. Fralinger Jr., city engineer and director of public works, had forgotten that club members were to offer goods or services to be auctioned to raise money for a Rotary project.

title: Selmin Barim Plans Bridal
description: Mr. and Mrs. Orhan Barim have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Selmin Barim, to Anthony V. Cilluffo. His parents are Mr. and Mrs. Vito Cilluffo of New York.

title: WASHINGTON
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 28Presidents have a way of stumbling into trouble from the best of motives, and imposing pointless miseries on their successors for generations to come. Thus, President Nixon was stuck in China with Woodrow Wilson's excessively moralistic doctrine of diplomatic recognition, appealing for cooperation to Government he refused to recognize as the legitimate government of all of China. This is still the bone that sticks in Chou Enlai's throat.

title: The Nation
description: WASHINGTONWhile be was campaigning in New Hampshire the other clay, Representative Wilbur Mills got into a discussion with some local folks about a major piece of national legislation for which he's responsiblerevenuesharing. Before he was done, he demonstrated in about equal measure: (1) The flexibility of politicians who try to be different things in different places, and (2) the absolute impossibility of pleasing the people of all 50 states and uncounted cities and counties with the complicated financialaid plan known as revenuesharing.

title: 37 African Nations Join in a Fair in Nairobi in Attempt to Build New Trade With One Another
description: NAIROBI, Kenya, Feb. 26Thirtyseven African nations joined this week in an allAfrica fair, an event sponsored by the Organization of African Unity in its first major economic venture.

title: Penguins Beat Flyers
description: PITTSBURGH, Feb. 26 (UPI) Jean Pronovost and Syl Apps combined for three goals and three assists today to lead the Pittsburgh Penguins to a 52 victory over the Philadelphia Flyers in a National Hockey League game.

title: 27 Pakistanis Repatriated As Part of P.O.W. Exchange
description: RAWALPINDI, Pakistan, Feb. 26 (UPI)Twentyseven ilI or wounded Pakistani prisoners of war arrived here today aboard the same plane that flew 17 Indian prisoners to New Delhi yesterday.

title: Miss Elizabeth Ann Baer Wed To John T. Perkin in Summit
description: SUMMIT, N. J., Feb. 26The Central Presbyterian Church was the setting here this afternoon for the marriage of Miss Elizabeth Ann Baer, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Andrew Baer of Duxbury, Mass., formerly of Summit, to John Thorne Perkin, son of Mrs. Richard Scott Perkin of New Canaan, Conn., and the late Mr. Perkin.

title: Deborah N. Cutler Plans July Marriage
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 Mr. and Mrs. Lloyd N. Cutler have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Deborah Norton Cutler, to James Frederick Notrnan Jr. of Denver, where he has been associated with Seafood, Ltd., retailers and wholesalers of fresh seafood. The wedding is planned for July.

title: Oklahoma Flush Impresses In Bird Dog Championship
description: GRAND JUNCTION, Term., Feb. 26 (AP)A big pointer, Oklahoma Flush, turned in a good showing this afternoon in the sixth day of the 73d national bird dog championship.

title: OBSERVER
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 The following is an excerpt from a report on the American mentality sent to Premier Chou Enlai by Chinese intelligence.

title: Prison Dispute in 11th Day
description: LEWISBURG, Pa., Feb. 26 (UPI)The curtailment of all nonessential activities at the Lewisburg Federal Penitentiary went into its 11th day today. About 1,300 inmates have been confined to their cells and dormitories since Feb. 16 when about 150 metalworkers refused to report for work. John Kilkerry, a prison spokesman, said the shutdown of all nonessential operations was standard security procedure in such cases.

title: Miss Stevens Wed To A. D. Werbeck
description: GUILFORD, Conn., Feb. 26 Miss Helen Mary Elizabeth Stevens was married here this noon to Arthur Douglas Werbeck, son of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur Werbeck of Ridgefield Park, N. J. Justice of the Peace Stanley Page performed the ceremony at the home of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Woodruff Stevens of New York and Guilford, the bride's parents.

title: Art Notes
description: HOW should a museum hireand fireits director? Get rid of objects it no longer wants? Handle controversial works of art? And function so that trustees and staff have at least a working rapport?

title: New &Novel
description: Jean Rhys is an artist at capturing the letdown and the defeated. Her heroines are innocents abroad in cities that evoke T. S. Eliot's sleazy urban landscapes. Paris is a sequence of dismal streets and cheap hotels. London is worse. (It was the darkness that got you. It was heavy darkness, greasy and compelling.) The rootless heroine who walks these mean streets is Julia Martin, an earlier (1930) edition of Sasha Jansen who appeared in Good Morning, Midnight, published in England in 1939. (Her career of ups and downs had rubbed most of the hallmarks off her.)

title: Most Queens Residents, Unlike Nassau Neighbors, Are CliffDwellers
JURORS ON MAST CRITICIZE SYSTEM
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 26This state's grand jury system has come under strong attack from the men who served on the juries in two bay area counties.

title: STUDY CRITICIZES EMINENT DOMAIN
description: ALBANY, Feb. 26A state commission called today for moderniztion of the cumplex of laws relating to the state's right to condemn private property for public purposes.

title: Bergenline Avenue: Gourmet's Delight
description: WEST NEW YORK  Bergenline Avenue begins at Washington Park in Union City as a narrow oneway street lined with aged homes, bodegas, pizza parlors, private fraternal clubs and luncheonettes. It ends to the east just past North Hudson Park in North Bergen with cleaning stores, supermarkets and wedding dressmakers. Sprinkled about in the miles in between is good eating.

title: Unconscious Captures San Antonio Stakes by a Nose With Triple Bend 2d
description: ARCADIA, Calif., Feb. 26 (UPI)Unconscious, winner of the $130,000 Strub Stakes two weeks ago, registered a nose victory today in the $86,050 San Antonio Stakes to foil Bill Shoemaker's attempt to become the alltime stakeswinning champion.

title: Mr. Nader, Have You Met Mr. Papanek?
description: VICTOR PAPANEK, Dean of the School of Design at California Institute of the Arts, and design consultant to Unesco, seems to have taken on the relatively lonesome role of Jeremiah to the industrial design profession. His recently published book, Design for the Real World (Pantheon, $8.95). is a harsh and Biblical blast at the design profession. Papanek sees today's designers as the pimps of business and industrial interests, ignoring the needs of the consumer and, equally important, the needs of society.

title: Women Choreographers Blend Moods in Experimental Dances
description: A painless evening, even a very good experimental one, took place Friday in the first performance in a current series by Dance Theater Workshop, 215 West 20th Street.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: PROTESTERS IN FIGHT AS BUSING FOES MEET
description: PONTIAC, Mich., Feb. 26 (AP) Pickets denouncing the Ku Klux Klan fought counterdemonstrators outside a hotel today where the National Action Group, an anitbusing organization was holding a conference.

title: Hawks Beat Seals, 30
description: CHICAGO, Feb. 26 (UPI)Bobby and Dennis Hull scored in the final five minutes of play tonight to help the Chicago Black Hawks shut out the California Golden Seals, 30.

title: Argentine Chief, in Bogota, Discloses Loan to Colombia
description: BOGOTA, Colombia, Feb. 26  Argentina's President, Alejandro A. Lanusse, today ended the formal part of a fourday state visit to Colombia by signing with Misael Pastrana Borrero, Colombia's President, joint declaration that included the announcement of a $10million line of credit to Colombia for the purchase of durable and capital goods from Argentina.

title: Music hit Milan
description: MILAN.WHEN it had its premiere in Leningrad in January, 1930, Shostakovich's first opera, The Nose, was widely regarded as a characteristically perverse piece of juvenile tomfoolery. That impression has lingered and eccentric and illogical, painful abstractionism, and malignant ridicule of operatic tradition are some of the charges leveled against it in studies of the composer by Soviet musicologists. Indeed, if the sin of formalism has any meaning, then this youthful firecracker, finished when Shostakovich was barely 22 and bursting with irreverence and mockery, guilty of it.

title: Coins
description: COLLECTORS can now he assured that a number of interesting medals will be officially issued to mark the 200th anniversary of this nation's birth. With the numismatic wheels spinning on Capitol Hill for the last several weeks, Americans won't have to wait until 76 to enjoy this historical windfall.

title: EFFRONTERY
description: To THE EDITOR:

title: JAMAICA WINS,6147, GAINS P.S.A.L. FINAL
description: Jamaica gained the final round of the Public Schools Athletic League basketball championship yesterday by defeating Columbus, 6147, at New York Community College in Brooklyn.

title: Son to Mrs. Kavanagh
description: A son was born Feb. 9 to Mr. and Mrs. James Penniston Kavanagh of  New York in the LyingIn Hospital. Mrs. Kavanagh is the former Miss Cornelia Kubler of New Haven. The child, whose father is a vice president and the director of brand management with Schieffelin & Co., wine and spirits importers here, has been named Alexander Penniston.

title: Joan F. Fowler, S. D. Reynolds Married on L. I.
description: LOCUST VALLEY, L. L, Feb. 26Miss Joan Frances Fowler, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert G. Fowler, was married here today to Stephen Dickson Reynolds, son of Richard D. Reynolds of Chicago and Mrs. Murtha Reynolds of Douglaston, Queens.

title: Rhode Island G.O.P. Slate Scored by Dissident Group
description: CRANSTON, R. I., Feb. 26 (AP)  ProNixon Republicans have nominated a slate of delegates for the state's Presidential primary ballot May 23 that some other Republicans charged was handpicked and that may be challenged.

title: German Airports Watched
description: BONN, Feb. 26 (UPI)Authorities intensified security measures today at West German airports because of the hijacking and ransoming this week of a Lufthansa jet. Airport guards were carefully inspecting passengers and luggage. Security was especially strong at Munich's Riem Airport. The police there discovered a newlycut hole today in A barbed wire fence guarding the runway.

title: Equestrian Center To Be Established At Bethany, Conn.
description: Plans are under way to establish a major equestrian center in Bethany, Conn., a centrally located rural town in the south central region of the state.

title: Erving of Squires May Switch to the N.B.A.
description: The National and American Basketball Associations talent war may cost the A.B.A. another of its prize rookies.

title: NEW CURBS WORRY LISBON'S TRADERS
description: LISBON, Feb. 26They're drinking local beer instead of Portuguese wines in Angolanot by choice but because of Portugal's changing relations with her African provinces.

title: Judith Haas Engaged
description: WESTON, Conn., Feb. 26Mr. and Mrs. George Charles Haas Jr. have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Judith Crane Haas, to Geoffrey Scott Baker, son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Elwood Baker of Athens, Ohio, where the future bride and her fiance are students at the Ohio University. They plan to be married March 18.

title: A Cynical Cuba Views the Trip As a Visit of the Paper Tiger
description: HAVANA, Feb. 26 (Reuters) Cuba is viewing President Nixon's visit to China with some cynicism.

title: Stamps
description: SWEDEN last week issued a booklet pane of ten 55ore singlecolored stamps in five designs of women's roles in sports, reflecting the Swedish poet Esaias Tegner's comment that Loveliness flourishes in many forms.

title: McNally's Pitch Earns $100,000 From Orioles
description: MIAMI, Feb. 26 (AP)Dave McNally, winner of 20 or more games for Baltimore in each of the last four seasons, became today the first $100,000 salaried pitcher in the American League.

title: The World
description: The Lufthansa jumbo jet with 172 passengers and 14 crew members aboard had just left New Delhi last Monday en route to Athena when three armed Arabs entered the cockpit. may ordered the pilot to fly to Aden, Southem Yemen.

title: Waldheim Leaves on Tour
description: The United Nations Secretary General, Kurt Waldheim, left yesterday on a twoweek overseas tour that will include stops in Geneva and Capetown. Mr. Waldheim said that he would confer in Geneva with Dr. Gunnar V. Jarring, the United Nations mediator in the Middle East, on further steps to take in the ArabIsraeli conflict.

title: IN THE NATION
description: Many of those who oppose busing to achieve school desegregation say that, instead, they favor quality education"a vague concept which seems to mean a program of special education and more spending in schools attended primarily by disadvantaged children. This positionwhich roughly corresponds to President Nixon's and which was often heard last week in the Senate debate on the issueraises the questions whether quality education is possible without desegregation, and whether desegregation is possible without busing.

title: MEWS LINKED TO SCHOOL'S WOES
description: PITTSBURGH, Feb. 26  A sixyearold report accusing Pittsburgh's wealthiest family of a major role in the downfall of a former Chancellor of the University of Pittsburgh has appeared in print here, but only after a courtordered restraining order that delayed publication for a week.

title: Bronx Man Is Slain; Policeman's Shot Called an Accident
description: A 20yearold Bronx man was shot to death by a policeman after a chase through Queens and Brooklyn early yesterday.

title: Rockets Beat Pistons
description: HOUSTON, Feb. 26 (UPI)Elvin Hayes hit his first seven shots from the field and finished with 36 points to lead the Houston Rockets to a 122106 triumph over the Detroit Pistons today.

title: Is a child its family's problem, or the state's?; When Parents Fail; The Law's Response To Family Breakdown. By Sanford N. Katz. 251 pp. Boston: Beacon Press. $12.50.
description: In 1890, the Superintendent of Schools of Texas warned that there are not wanting evidences of a drift toward the breakers of socialism.... I hold that compulsory education is contrary to the dominant idea which has pervaded the development of American institutions,... the evils of illiteracy are less perilous than those which result from the destruction of parental authority and the loosening of family ties.

title: a Dog in Dog's Clothing
description: HUNTINGTON HARBOR, Calif., Feb. 26 (UPI)  The dog that Mr. and Mrs. E. E. Strickler rescued from a channel near their home was a coyote, Humane Society officials said.

title: New &Novel
description: Reprieved from a life sentence of marriage, after 25 years, Eleanor Streathorne moves into a house in London's St. John's Wood and prepares to live the life of her dreams. Lovers are waiting to be unleashed, like Sir Patrick Kilcannon (My Gaelic Knight), who can be expected to pop over any day from his Irish barony. The children (four grown and one still at home) will surely rally round. But love never comes, the children want to get on with their own thing, and mother is left alone at the very end, a prey to anyone who wants to pick her up in a pub.

title: GISBERT AND SMITH GAIN TENNIS FINAL
description: Juan Gisbert, with his third straight upset of the biggest names on the independent tennis tour, reached the final of the $30,000 Clean Air tournament at the Seventh Regiment Armory yesterday.

title: Dance
description: FOR years I have been saying unkind things about Washington's cultural life and for a capital city it is still not especially well endowed. On the other hand, nowadays it is not quite the wasteland it was. The Arena Stage is one of the best theaters in the nation and, now, with its National Ballet, Washington has developed what is almost certainly the best classic ballet company in North America outside of New York. I must express some qualifications because I have not seen the San Francisco Ballet or Ballet West from Salt Lake City, and it is a year or so since I last saw the Pennsylvania Ballet. But there is no doubt that the Washington company has developed enormously over the past couple of years.

title: Reforming Pension Plans
description: The Senate Labor subcommittee is expected to call tomorrow for widespread and dramatic legislative reform of the nation's private pension system.

title: WATSON ON GUITAR A PLEASURE TO HEAR
description: Doc Watson's appearance at the Village Gaslight last week marked a welcome, tooinfrequent appearance in the New York area of one of American folk music's authentic heroes.

title: New &Novel
description: Joel Lieber died before the publication of this sad and bitter novel (his fifth), which makes the hopeful note on which it ends all the sadder. Two Way Traffic traces the road back from a crackup of Jesse Jacobi, who is, like Lieber, a successful novelist. Somewhere I have lost my strength, writes Jacobi in the journal that is the form of the novel. Why don't I act? Why don't I react? He had reacted earlier by slashing a wrist, taking a massive overdose of pills, and turning on the gas. He survives to make an agonizing recovery, during which he sees his own condition with baleful wit and harsh clarity.

title: U.C.L.A. Tops Ore. State, Clinches Title Tie, 9172
description: LOS ANGELES Feb. 26 (UPI) The University of California, Los Angeles, clinched at least a tie for the Pacific8 basketball championship tonight with a 9172 victory over Oregon State.

title: Platform Tennis Top Draw
description: More than 250 players on 128 teams will gather at the home of platform tennis, the Fox Meadow Tennis Club in Scarsdale, N. Y., on Friday to compete in the 38th annual United States men's doubles championship. This is one of seven national tournaments sponsored each season by the American Platform Tennis Association.

title: Canadiens Overwhelm Red Wings, 81, as Cournoyer Registers Pair of Goals
description: MONTREAL, Feb. 26 (UPI)Yvan Cournoyer increased his goals total to 32 by scoring twice today as the Montreal Canadiens overwhelmed the Detroit Red Wings, 81.

title: Letters
description: The respondents are correct in pointing out that some range of potential exists in the mongoloid population. For some parents the affection of their mongoloid child and the pride they take in his meager milestones more than compensate them for the sacrifices they and their normal children may make in his behalf.

title: STRESS ON AFRICA UP AMONG BLACKS
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 Africans are scared of voodoo and walk around halfnaked, a 13yearold black American responded to his teacher's question.

title: The Nation
description: HARRISBURG, Pa.  After four weeks of painfully protracted Jury selection, the hearing of evidence in the trial of the Rev. Philip Berrigan and six other antiwar activists finally began last week with a lowkeyed and unspectacular opening statement by Assistant Attorney General William S. Lynch.

title: The Aged: Where Can They Live?
description: HUNTINGTON, L. I.When the Huntinton Town Board recently approved housing development in Greenlawn designed specifically for the elderly, it moved against a seeming wave of opposition to such projects in Suffolk County.

title: Hoax Cuts Wilson Speech
description: LONDON, Feb,. 26 (Reuters) A bomb hoax cut short a speech today by Harold Wilson, leader of the Labor party, and emptied a hall of 500 elderly People, several in wheelchairs. Mr. Wilson had just begun addressing a labor rally for the elderly in Westminster.

title: Chiefs to Oppose Pioneers In Roller Derby at Garden
description: The Chiefs and the Pioneers, the top two International Roller Derby League teams meet this afternoon in Madison Square Garden at 1 o'clock. The Pioneers have been on a hot streak and are battling the Chiefs for first place.

title: Phillip S. Kallen Fiance of Chesna Cohen
description: ROSLYN HEIGHTS, L. I., Feb. 26The engagement of Miss Chesna Sue Cohen, (laughter of the late Mr. and Mrs. Irving Cohen of Roslyn, to Phillip Scott Kallen, son of Mr. and Mrs. Herbert Kallen of St. James and New York, has been announced by the future bride's uncle and aunt, Mr. and Mrs. Harold H. Harris of Roslyn Heights.

title: A New Fuel: Coal
description: Paradox: There's a growing energy shortage. At the same time, there's an awful lot of coal  more than any other fossil fuel supply  most of which can't be used because of its airpolluting qualities. How can it be used?

title: Gardens
description: GREENWICH, Conn. IVY is an interesting plant to grow. When Mrs. Howard P. Serrell grows ivy, it becomes a poodle, turtle, a cone, an umbrella, a squirrel, a circle or a heart. She is an expert at topiary, an old horticultural art of training and clipping plants to a classic form.

title: C.C.N.Y, DEFEATS HUNTER 69 TO 61
description: The first six minutes and the last six minutes of the City University basketball tournament championship game belonged to C.C.N.Y. yesterday as the Beavers defeated Hunter College, 6961, in the at Queens College.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Quintets Enter Stretch; Upsets Knot Some Races
description: Rice won its first Southwest Conference game Saturday in 12 attempts and it started cycle of upsets that led to a fiveway tic for first place before the day was over.

title: 67 Subway Change Booths Closed, to Save Funds
description: The Transit Authority has shutdown 67 subway change, booths since last April, or about, 8 per cent of the system's 830; booths. The authority said the booths had been closed in an economy measure that, over a year, would represent a saving of $1million.

title: Candidates Plan to Be On Hand For Senate's Votes on Busing
Dr. Victor Heiser, Who Wrote Of War on Disease, Dies at 99
description: Dr. Victor George Heiser, who recounted his fight against disease throughout the world in his bestselling autobiography, An American Doctor's Odyssey, died yesterday in New York Hospital at the age of 90. He lived at 200 East 66th Street.

title: TAIPEI IS BITTER
description: TAIPEI, Taiwan, Monday, Feb. 28Newspapers that closely reflect the views of the Chinese Nationalist Government today strongly condemned the communiqu issued by President Nixon and Premier Chou Enlai in Shanghai:

title: Use of a Narcotics Center For Retarded Challenged
description: The Citizens Union yesterday challenged the state's latest plan to use the former state narcotics center at 75 Morton Street in Greenwich Village as a facility for mentally retarded children. It urged that the center be used to relieve overcrowding in the city's prisons.

title: Salinger Courts French Bloc in New Hampshire to Aid McGovern Campaign
Shanghai Chief, 5th in Politburo
description: Fifthranking member of Chinese Communist party's Politburo... led guerrillas against Japanese during the war... advanced to his present position through career as Shanghai newspaper editor, cultural watchdog, political tactician and party bureaucrat... eager participant in Cultural Revolution and helped get movement going in Shanghai, where he was party leader... moved to Peking to assist Chen Pota rated among leftists of Cultural Revolution but has managed to avoid losing status in reaction against Cultural Revolution's excesses now 60 years old, is head of municipal revolutionary committee and of Communist party in Shanghai and first political commissar of the East China military region... lean, sharpfeatured and handsome, Is looked upon as one who might succeed to decisive role in national tf fairs when Chairman Mao, Premier Chou and others now in top positions die... has lately been receiving ranking Communist perrmirinies visthe and has been with Premier Chou in receiving Anerican and other nonCommunist visitor

title: Communique From Shanghai
description: The communique issued in Shanghai by President Nixon and Premier Chou Enlai is an agreement to disagree on many points, while clearing the way for future negotiations on the outstanding issues. It is a renunciation of force, in favor of diplomacy.

title: VAT'The Most Neutral Tax
description: STANFORD, Calif.No tax is a good tax in an absolute sense. The case for a valueadded tax is simply that it the least bad tax available, especially if we need substantial additional revenue.

title: CHINA VISIT ENDS
description: SHANGHAI, Monday, Feb. 28 President Nixon and Premier Chou Enlai concluded a week of unusual negotiations here today and parted with an American pledge to arrange a gradual withdrawal of United States forces from Taiwan and a joint pledge for a gradual increase in AmericanChinese contacts and exchanges.

title: Carolina Crash Kills Seven
description: SENECA. S. C.. Feb. 27 (AP) Seven youths are dead as a result of a headon collision! between two cars on South Carolina highway 2S five miles north of Seneca, the Highway Patrol said today. The dead were identified as Michale Hooper, 18 years old, and Ronnie Moss, 19, both of Wallhalla: Bobby Wilbanks, 17. and Ivan Holden, 16, both of West Union: Michael Shipman, 18, and Ronnie Beauchamp, 16, both of Seneca, and Steve Allen Gibson, 15, of Ridgeland.

title: Police in Venice Recover Stolen Guggenheim Art
description: VENICE, Feb. 27 (Reuters)The police today recovered 17 modern paintings valued at about $650,000 stolen last December from Peggy Guggenheim, the American Art patron.

title: Workers Chafe at Layoffs as the Impact of President's Policies Is Awaited
description: YOUNGSTOWN, Ohio  It was close to zero in the Ohio works of the United States Steel plant here, but the men, their breath forming little puffs in the bitter cold, were hustling to get the bright red glow of steel into the open hearth furnace that had been shut for seven months.

title: Volkswagen Discovers Outlook Is Brightening
description: WOLFSBURG, West Germany  We're not doing at all badly, thank you, considering...

title: Maloney's Team Wins Title
description: GREENWICH, Conn., Feb. 27 The unseeded team of E. Coyne Maloney Jr. and Clint Reynolds of Greenwich won the annual Westchester Fairfield C men's squash racquets doubles championship today at the Greenwich Country Club. They defeated John Barrett and Fred Warner of the Greenwich Field Club, 11.15, 15.11, 11.15, 1512, 1511.

title: Earthquake in California
description: HOLLISTER, Calif., Feb. 27 (UPI)A moderate earthquake hit the Bear Valley area, 25 miles southeast of Hollister, today, jolting residents but causing little damage. The tremor occurred in the same sparse farming area of San Benito County that was shaken by somewhat stronger one Thursday.

title: Israel Attracting U.S. Scientific Talent
description: HAIFA, Israel, Feb. 27For 35yearold Allen Reiter it was a chance to make his personal mark in developing Israel's computer systems, instead of holding down a job in the United States where he would be just on highly skilled specialist among many others.

title: City Issues Food and Furniture Rules
description: Underweight food and overdue furniture are the targets; of two new sets of regulations issued recently by the city's Department of Consumer Affairs.

title: Model of Memorial to Bunche Is Displayed at I.N. Ceremony
